dialogue:
Person1: I see the truth of it. You were at the concert, weren't you?
Person2: Yes, I was there with Alex. I was supposed to meet him fifteen minutes ago, so I...
Person1: I knew it! I told you, he's coming home to you.
Person2: How would you know that? Did he tell you everything?
Person1: Pain by nerve induction... A human can resist any pain. Our test is crisis and observation. Maybe that's what he's going through.
Person2: Could he be the one? Maybe... but will he be ours to support?

Person1: Don't worry, I've got it! Are you crazy?
Person2: The twenty third of January. On that night one of our team leaders passed away.
Person1: John? I don't remember where Emily was. I was needed in the meeting room.
Person2: Yes.

Person1: I'm telling you, he's got a certain charm.
Person2: Look out of that window. You're not seeing things clearly.
Person1: What's that supposed to mean? You think I'm blind to his flaws?
Person2: I think you're drawn to his fake confidence. It's a turn-off, trust me.
Person1: You're just jealous. You've always been skeptical of people who take risks.

Person1: You're being really loud. Can you keep it down? I'm trying to focus.
Person2: Jesus, first my neighbor, now you. You two need to relax.
Person1: I'm just trying to get some work done. What's going on that's so important?
Person2: I'm celebrating. I just finished reading The Fountainhead.
Person1: Congratulations. That's a great book.
Person2: Yeah, I know. I'm not as dumb as I act, you know. Howard Roark is my hero.
Person1: Well, I'm happy for you. But can you celebrate a bit more quietly?
Person2: Oh come on. Quit acting like a librarian and come join me for a drink. We can discuss the book.
Person1: I don't know... I really need to get this done.
Person2: Please? It'll be fun, I promise.

Person1: What's the plan for your bonus?
Person2: Ah, yeah! I'm going to invest it in a small business venture. I've got a friend who's starting a food truck, and I think it's going to be a real winner.
Person1: A food truck? You're going to put your bonus into a food truck?
Person2: Yeah, I know it sounds unusual, but hear me out. The startup costs are relatively low, and the potential for profit is huge. Plus, my friend has a great concept and a solid business plan.
Person1: I see. Well, I wish you the best of luck with that.

Person1: I've been thinking about our family's history, and I'm curious - what were you doing at the old mansion the other night?
Person2: I haven't been to that part of town in years! But I do remember hearing stories about our ancestors, like the ones who built the first windmills in the region.

Person1: Oh, gee thanks. I better go, I'll talk to you later.
Person2: What do you think? Of course, you're so lucky to have this opportunity!
Person1: What's involved?
Person2: You'll be contacted with the assignment. Just remember to have fun and convey nothing about it to anyone.
Person1: My friends can't know about this.
Person2: Ok, have fun there, and call me when you get back.

Person1: I think we should move forward with the plan.
Person2: He did it to prove a point, don't you think?
Person1: Perhaps, but there's more to it than that. He wanted to show us that he's capable of making a difference.
Person2: I'm not sure, Louis. Are you certain this is the right decision?
Person1: I'm positive. If we don't take this opportunity, I think we'll regret it.

Person1: Do you always cook like this?
Person2: My grandmother taught me everything I know. She was a great chef, and when she requested my help in the kitchen, I learned to prepare dishes with love.

Person1: You mean like, a party party?
Person2: I'm not going.
Person1: You're just going to stay here?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Okay. Hope you don't get bored.
Person2: I hope I do.

Person1: I'm so frustrated with myself. I feel like I'm always a step behind in everything.
Person2: What do you mean? Is it something specific that's bothering you?
Person1: It's just that I tried to do something new recently, and it seemed stupid. I kept thinking about how others would perceive me.
Person2: Maybe you're being too hard on yourself. We all have rough patches. Let's work together to get you back on track.
Person1: I guess you're right. I just need to focus on my own progress and not worry about what others think.
Person2: Exactly! And remember, it's okay to make mistakes. It's all part of the learning process.

Person1: I really like you too...
Person2: In a week... we will never have had this conversation.
Person1: So, what do they think -- we're not kids --
Person2: I know, but even if they go away, everybody in America knows what we're doing because... they went away.
Person1: All right. I'll come for dinner. And in the meantime... you'll think about what we discussed?
Person2: If this weren't here... ?

Person1: I'm not gonna let him get away with this. I wanna fight just as dirty as he does.
Person2: Hold on, let's not be hasty. You can't wait for the right moment to strike. It's not important to rush into things.
Person1: But I've had enough of his tricks. I want to use every advantage I can get. Can I count on your support?
Person2: I'll back you up, but let's make sure we're doing this for the right reasons. We shouldn't stoop to his level.

Person1: You sure you can handle the new shipment?
Person2: Oh, I'm more than sure. Anything happens to the cargo, I can tell you right now you don't wanna be the party that was responsible.
Person1: Like, what makes you so confident?
Person2: Like I said, we guarantee every load. Anywhere, for any reason, it comes up short, we make good. Your operations will, from now on, run risk-free.
Person1: And what's in it for you?
Person2: We become partners. Only in this territory and only on loads we run. And you don't pay us a fixed rate. You pay us thirty percent of the load. Product or cash.
Person1: That sounds like a pretty good deal. But why should I trust you?
Person2: Because we can deliver what no one else can. And I'm not just talking about the shipment. I'm talking about the whole operation.

Person1: I'm just looking at you. Does that make you uncomfortable?
Person2: We might. Yes. We can. Let's.
Person1: Depends on what you're seeing.
Person2: Whether we'll have time for a stroll after dinner.
Person1: So they say. What?
Person2: I didn't know if we'd be eating at any restaurant that has dress codes.

Person1: I'm trying to reach Dr. Lee. Is she available?
Person2: I don't think that you would understand if I told you why she's not available.
Person1: I think I understand without your telling me. I know something about her schedule, and I know she had a meeting this morning.
Person2: She's lost her confidence. After all the success and recognition, she's struggling to keep up.
Person1: Listen to me. I'm her colleague, and I need to talk to her about an urgent matter. Can you please tell me where she is?

Person1: We can at least talk about it -- we might be able to work things out.
Person2: Forget it. I've already spent too many hours trying to understand you.

Person1: We have to finalize the project tomorrow...
Person2: I'm going to give them a presentation. Thought I'd better do it now, before I forget it.
Person1: Presentation, sir? You seem a bit distracted.
Person2: I know I left my notes there. Maybe John has them.
Person1: You're forgetting the meeting at the conference room. It's at 2 PM.
Person2: Oh, yes -- yes -- that's right --

Person1: Remember the cat?
Person2: What's with the sudden nostalgia? You were just asking about the scent of acacia.
Person1: I can smell it. The taste of tea so black it falls into your mouth. I can taste it.
Person2: You're not even making sense. That's not how memories work.
Person1: Could I have a cigarette?
Person2: You know you can't smoke in here. Besides, you're not even lucid enough to hold a cigarette.
Person1: Why are you so determined to keep me grounded?
Person2: Because someone has to keep you from getting lost in your own mind.

Person1: Who do you think should lead this project?
Person2: I think it should be the one with the most experience. Curiosity got me to this point, but I'm not sure I'm ready for that role.
Person1: Remember, we need someone who can make tough decisions. I'm willing to put it to a vote if you are.
Person2: Sounds good to me. But if I don't get the role, I'm still happy to contribute.

Person1: You rock my world. You're like the most amazing person I've ever met. You're so smart and fun and crazy!
Person2: What the hell're you talking about? I'm in danger. All of you. I have no time to explain.
Person1: Wait a minute, I thought we were having a great time together.
Person2: I'm sorry, but I have to go.

Person1: I can see the city in my mind, the smell of acacia, the taste of black tea. It's like I'm there.
Person2: You're not thinking clearly, Cotton. This isn't about some fantasy, it's about what's real.
Person1: I have proof, I'm the victim. No one will ever suspect me.
Person2: Please, don't do this. You're not thinking about the consequences.

Person1: I've been trying to figure out what I want to do with my life, but it's hard when everyone's always asking me what my plan is.
Person2: _Answer_ me. What's the point of having a plan, anyway?
Person1: I guess it's just that people expect you to have your life together by a certain age. My parents, for example, they're always like, "What's your major going to be?"
Person2: And you're like, "Uh, I don't know, mom and dad, I'm still trying to figure it out." Do you want ketchup with that?
Person1: Yeah, thanks. It's just frustrating because I feel like I'm supposed to have all the answers, but I don't.
Person2: I know what you mean. Sometimes I think people just want to hear what they want to hear, you know? Like, they don't really care about what you're actually thinking or feeling.
Person1: Exactly! It's like, can't I just be unsure for once without everyone freaking out? Do you want to grab a coffee and talk more about this?
Person2: Yeah, sure. I could use a break from all the expectations.

Person1: Alright, that's it. Let's call it a day.
Person2: For goodness' sake, can we please just try it one more time? 
Person1: Eyes closed, remember? This time, focus on your breathing.
Person2: If we don't get it right, we're going to have to start all over again.

Person1: I've got a proposition for you. Would you like to get in on this deal?
Person2: I'm intrigued. What's the catch?
Person1: Well, it's either we work together and split the profits, or I go solo and take all the credit.
Person2: I think I can live with that. But I need to know more about what's at stake.
Person1: Fine. I'll fill you in. But let's discuss it over dinner. I know a great restaurant nearby.
Person2: Sounds good to me. But I have to warn you, I'm a bit of a sleuth. I might uncover more than you're willing to share.
Person1: I'm not worried. I think I can handle your prying eyes. Shall we meet Thursday night at eight?
Person2: I'll be there. And don't think about trying to cancel at the last minute. I'll be expecting you.

Person1: I've got your old rifle, and that's the new Remington you were showing me last week.
Person2: Hi.
Person1: I just wanted you to know, wherever you're going or whatever you're doing right now, I wanted to ask you about that rifle.
Person2: Yeah?
Person1: So what do I do with it then?
Person2: Well, it's a beautiful piece of work. You deserve it.

Person1: I've waited a long time for this chance to get away from this place. If I have to, I'll go alone.
Person2: So you've not considered the risks of leaving without a plan then?
Person1: I'd do anything to get out of this place. To get away from the restrictions and the monotony.
Person2: I prefer not to push the limits until we've had a chance to assess the situation properly.
Person1: But what a glorious feeling it would be to finally be free! Retire from this dull life, eh?
Person2: I thought you wanted to leave because you were unhappy, not because you wanted to make a statement.
Person1: Oh, I'm unhappy, all right. I'm unhappy with the way things are run around here. I'm unhappy with the people who think they're in charge.
Person2: And you think leaving will solve all your problems?
Person1: It's a start. And I'll do whatever it takes to make it happen. I'll find a way, no matter what.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's been going on for weeks. I've had enough of this nonsense.
Person2: I understand your frustration, but I need more information. Can you explain what's been happening?
Person1: You're not listening to me. I don't know if it will change back again. That's the worst part.
Person2: I'm trying to help, but you need to calm down and focus. What exactly do you mean by "change back again"?

Person1: You've got to relax, I'm just trying to help.
Person2: Oh, you are very welcome... I appreciate your willingness to assist me.

Person1: I'm going to give you a housewarming present. Thought I'd better do it now, before I forget it.
Person2: Would you mind walking ahead of me to the living room? I feel funny about being in a new space.
Person1: But it's cozy in there now.
Person2: Please. I want to make a good impression.
Person1: Oh, yes -- yes -- that's right -- I left the gift on the coffee table.

Person1: I've never felt this before, not even when I was lost in the woods for three days. I think I might be falling for you, Sophia.
Person2: And how did you feel when you were lost in the woods? Did you eat anything unusual?

Person1: What are you actually doing here? What is the hidden agenda?
Person2: Until then, you'll just have to wait and see.

Person1: Did you notice anything unusual about the way he was acting?
Person2: Know what you mean? He seemed a bit off.
Person1: Exactly! I was wondering how you knew that.
Person2: I saw you glance at him when he stumbled over his words. I figured it wasn't just a slip-up, and the rest was easy.
Person1: But how did you know I would pick up on it too?

Person1: I've heard rumors of a new restaurant opening downtown.
Person2: So have I. I've been meaning to try it out.
Person1: Something's off. I know it. I've got a bad feeling about it.
Person2: Now by killer, you mean...? No, no, I'm just kidding. I'm sure it's fine.
Person1: I should go check it out. I should go today.
Person2: If it's true, it might be crowded. You'd never get a table. Besides, they're only rumors.
Person1: And not a word of it to Sarah. She's agitated enough about the new development plans.
Person2: Read her the review from the local paper and rephrase it. We'll say it came out today. It'll set her mind at ease.

Person1: You're getting worked up over nothing. Just calm down and focus.
Person2: I don't know if I can do this. I feel like I'm in over my head.
Person1: It's a game, kid. Don't let him see what you've got. You've got this.
Person2: Yeah, okay. I'll try.

Person1: Don't worry, I've got it! Are you crazy?
Person2: Oh, I thought you would know. Good night, old friend.

Person1: What's the plan here?
Person2: Just an informal discussion.
Person1: You're taking notes, though.
Person2: Yeah, I like to keep track of things.
Person1: I've never seen you before. What's your connection to this?
Person2: Let's just say I'm a mutual acquaintance. You know, I met someone on a plane recently...
Person1: Oh? What happened?
Person2: Nothing much. Just a weird encounter. So, what do you think about the current situation?
Person1: Honestly, I'm not sure what to make of it. You seem to know more than you're letting on.
Person2: Maybe. But I'm willing to share if you're willing to listen.

Person1: I want you to know, I'll always cherish you.
Person2: And if you ever doubt my commitment, remember that I'm willing to make sacrifices for us.
Person1: That's the news I needed to hear. I won't let you go.

Person1: I'm so tired of being late. It feels like I'm always a step behind in everything.
Person2: Jesus, you're being too hard on yourself. We all have rough patches.
Person1: I know, but it's not just about being late. It's about feeling like I'm not in control of my life.
Person2: Maybe we can work together to get you back on track. But first, let's take a deep breath and focus on the present moment.

Person1: I'm scared, I don't know what's going to happen.
Person2: You know.
Person1: You're not helping. I need you to be honest with me. What did I do that was so bad?
Person2: Better if I just show you.
Person1: Please, I'm begging you, don't tell them. They'll think I'm awful, they'll despise me and hate me...
Person2: I said I wouldn't.

Person1: I've been researching our family's history and I think I found a connection to the Picards who settled the first Martian colony. Would you like to take a look?
Person2: That's amazing! I've heard stories about them since I was a kid. Do you have any documents or records that could help me learn more?

Person1: Oh, Governor!
Person2: I told you last night, this can be the start of something new. If something good doesn't come of this opportunity, I think we'll all be disappointed.
Person1: Oh, I don't know what to say. Maybe you can suggest something.
Person2: I'm sure.

Person1: I'm so frustrated, he hasn't said one word to me.
Person2: Maybe he's just shy. In a week, we will never have had this conversation.
Person1: That's easy for you to say, you're not the one being ignored. My friend always pays more attention to you than to me.
Person2: I think you're misunderstanding. I'm trying to help you see things from a different perspective.
Person1: I appreciate that, but sometimes I wish you could understand what I'm going through. You're so lucky you never have to deal with this.
Person2: Actually, I do understand. And I think we should focus on finding a solution rather than dwelling on the problem.

Person1: I'm not hungry, I had a big lunch.
Person2: And how did you feel when you realized you weren't hungry?
Person1: I felt relieved, I didn't want to eat that anyway.

Person1: How long was I out?
Person2: Long enough to realize you're in over your head. Listen, if you really want to get to the bottom of this, that's your problem, but don't expect me to babysit you, okay?
Person1: They've taken everything from me... my confidence, my sense of purpose...
Person2: What are you talking about? Who's behind this?

Person1: What's taking so long? You're not exactly a pro at this.
Person2: Hey, I'm trying my best. You think you can do better?
Person1: Actually, I can. Let me show you. First, you need to check the lining of their coat, like this... and then the back of the collar. Don't forget to feel inside their shoes too.
Person2: Whoa, easy does it! You're making me jump.
Person1: Sorry about that. Then you need to run your hands down their arms and legs, just in case. See, it's not that hard.
Person2: Wait, did you see that? His hand just moved!

Person1: You mean like, save him?
Person2: Pearl, shut up! You could do it, little one.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's no big deal. I can get you out of this mess.
Person2: I'm not talking about that, sir. I made a critical mistake. Our entire operation is at risk.
Person1: What do you mean? What happened?
Person2: I underestimated the enemy's air defense. I thought our pilot was good, but...
Person1: But what? What went wrong?
Person2: He got too close, and they took him down. Now our entire mission is compromised.
Person1: Wait a minute. Is the pilot okay?
Person2: I don't know, sir. I didn't check. I was too busy trying to figure out how to salvage this operation.
Person1: Well, we need to get out of here, now. We can't let them capture us.
Person2: Agreed, sir. But we need to come up with a new plan, and fast.

Person1: You're a genius, Doc - a genius!
Person2: He's completely out of his mind.
Person1: Great. Is that what you're going to say when I put you on the stand?
Person2: No. When you put me on the stand, I'll say your client is catatonic and exhibits classic symptoms of a schizophrenic, sociopathic personality.
Person1: Does he sleep?
Person2: Insomnia. Not unusual for someone in his situation.
Person1: I could kiss you! You'll get the expert witness fee, don't worry.
Person2: With pay! I'm not doing it for free.

Person1: What's the meaning of this? Who's behind it?
Person2: This is another victory, my friends. I'm just the event coordinator.
Person1: You're going to see the client now?
Person2: To finalize the details and ensure everything meets their expectations.

Person1: I'm telling you, I saw it with my own eyes. There was a guy shooting from behind that fence.
Person2: I think you must have gotten confused. We're going to head down to Baltimore, Maryland, and get out of the city for a bit.
Person1: What's in Baltimore? You're not telling me everything.
Person2: Oh, we might grab some crabs while we're there. They're in season, I think.
Person1: That's not what I meant. You're trying to distract me from what I saw.
Person2: I'm just trying to help you calm down. You're shaken up. Let's focus on getting out of here and we can talk more about it later.
Person1: I don't know if I can trust you. You're not listening to me.
Person2: I am listening. I just think there's more to the story than what you're telling me.

Person1: I've been feeling out of place lately. What's going on?
Person2: The material world is an illusion. It doesn't matter if things are there or not. The world is in my head.
Person1: But your body is in the world, isn't it? If someone offered you a place to stay, you wouldn't necessarily refuse, would you?
Person2: I'm not "people." I'm just me. And I do whatever I goddamn want to do. Got it?
Person1: It's okay to be different. And I'm here to help you through whatever you're feeling.
Person2: Thanks, but I'll manage.

Person1: You're one of the top agents, aren't you?
Person2: SAY IT!
Person1: I've studied your tactics, and I know you're not as clean as you seem. Five years ago, you were involved in a scandal that cost innocent lives.
Person2: I got that...ma'am. But do you know what the word "misinformation" means?

Person1: Don't you think you're being too reckless?
Person2: Yes, desperately. I want to prove to myself that I can do this.
Person1: Look, would you question your instincts? 
Person2: No, I trust my gut.
Person1: That's the spirit! Now let's go in there and make it happen.

Person1: We can at least try to fit in -- we might be able to gain their respect --
Person2: Yes, desperately. I don't want to be seen as an outcast anymore.
Person1: Plus, if we don't even try, we're no better than those who gave up.
Person2: That's the spirit! But we need to be careful not to compromise our values in the process.

Person1: What do you think of the new curator at the museum?
Person2: I'm afraid she's an idealist. You'll have to be politic.
Person1: Do you know how I define "idealism," Monsieur LaFleur?
Person2: I don't think that you would understand if I told you.

Person1: You're the one who said he was good looking. You think he's good looking 'cause I know you think he's good-looking.
Person2: Grateful?! You want to know what I'm grateful for? It's that I finally found someone who makes me feel like a woman, like Robert did.
Person1: Who's Robert?
Person2: Someone from my past. It's not important. What's important is that I'm with you now, and I love you.
Person1: Then why'd you say that thing about Tony Janiro?
Person2: I never noticed his face. I was just being polite.
Person1: You're not thinking of him right now, are you?
Person2: No, I'm thinking of us, and how we can move forward together.

Person1: I've heard rumors about your new business venture. 
Person2: A small price to pay for success.
Person1: I won't believe everything I read in magazines.
Person2: You'd be amazed at what some people will achieve with hard work.
Person1: I knew it. I knew you had what it takes.
Person2: And I'm not going to let anyone bring me down.

Person1: What's going on with you? You've been acting strange lately.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I've seen the way you've been looking at me. If there's no one around, we can talk about it.
Person2: I don't know what you want from me.
Person1: You're not the same person I used to know. You're hiding something.
Person2: Maybe you're just being paranoid.

Person1: You're goin' with me. I want to show you something.
Person2: And if you lose me, you'll know that I trusted you and wanted to go on trusting you.
Person1: I won't lose you. We'll figure this out together.
Person2: For your sake, I hope so.

Person1: You know, I like that scarf, Rachel. I don't know what there is about it, but it somehow makes you look more confident.
Person2: Well, well! What's the matter here? I've had enough of your flattery, Mr. Thompson. I'm not used to it, sir.
Person1: Oh, well, you know. I just give a compliment here and a compliment there. Not enough to notice.
Person2: That's right. Take a little, leave a little. But I'm not buying it, Thompson. You're working an angle.
Person1: You're a thousand percent right! I do have an angle. I want to ask for your help with a project.
Person2: I'm listening. But don't try to sweet-talk me into it.
Person1: I wouldn't dream of it, Rachel. I promise you, it's a win-win situation.
Person2: Alright, I'll hear you out. But don't think you can charm your way into getting what you want.

Person1: I'm sorry, I don't like people touching my guitar. It's not important. It's a minor quirk. I can deal with it if I want to.
Person2: There's a fire in the kitchen. We need to get out of here, now!
Person1: Who do you think you are, telling me what to do?
Person2: I'm the one who's trying to save your life, that's who.

Person1: I've got a surprise for you. Shut your eyes. Keep 'em closed.
Person2: You don't remember me, do you?
Person1: I saw you almost every day at the bookstore. I think you'll love this.
Person2: Well, well! Ain't that nice!

Person1: What's the hidden agenda behind your question? Are you trying to distract me from something?
Person2: I'm just curious, I mean, what's the real story with your past? You're not from around here, are you?
Person1: Well, I'm not a freak or anything. I just have a complicated history, that's all.
Person2: Complicated history? That's an understatement. I've heard rumors, but I'd rather hear it from you.

Person1: I have to go now.
Person2: I'll need the documents now. It's only a small favor, don't bother telling me what you're going to do with them.
Person1: Nah, I don't think so... I told you, it's the final report. And thanks to you it's overdue.
Person2: Wait... I thought we were gonna discuss this further.

Person1: I'm going home.
Person2: Someone waiting for you?
Person1: No one's waiting. I ate at a new restaurant last night.
Person2: And how did you feel about the food?
Person1: I don't know. I don't remember what I ordered.
Person2: You're a very sweet person. Where did you meet Steven?
Person1: At a coffee shop. He's a very sweet man.
Person2: Do you think he can do it?
Person1: I don't know. But I want to talk about doing crazy things.
Person2: Yes, let's talk about that.

Person1: Hey, I'm so glad we met. You seem really nice.
Person2: Mph rmph rm rmph rm?
Person1: Oh, I'm sorry. I didn't catch that. What did you say?
Person2: I said, I heard some girl got her jacket stolen earlier today.
Person1: Really? That's crazy. I just got this jacket yesterday.
Person2: Yeah, you better be careful. So, what do you think of this new coffee shop?
Person1: It's nice, I guess. I don't know... He can be nice... sometimes.
Person2: Who can be nice sometimes?
Person1: Oh, just this guy I know. He's a friend of a friend.
Person2: Oh, okay. Well, I should get going. Nice meeting you!

Person1: We can't stay here, the authorities will find us soon.
Person2: The dead can wait, we need to focus on our survival.

Person1: I forgive you.
Person2: You shouldn't. I've been avoiding you, to be honest.
Person1: What gave you that idea? You've been acting strange lately.
Person2: I got your message, but I didn't think it was a big deal. I had other things on my mind.
Person1: Well, as a matter of fact, I was rather hurt when you didn't show up that night.
Person2: I don't blame you. It was thoughtless of me.
Person1: You did the only decent thing, considering the circumstances.
Person2: Decency-wise, I'm not sure I'm as good as you think I am.
Person1: Cheers to that. Let's put this behind us.
Person2: Cheers.

Person1: Honestly, do you think I would sabotage your project without telling you?
Person2: I don't know, but I do remember you inviting the entire team to review the proposal without asking me.
Person1: Sometimes we have to adapt to new circumstances.
Person2: Think, Rachel. Does the marketing department have any connections that could help us meet the deadline?
Person1: What's happened to the deadline?
Person2: Nothing, it's just been... unexpectedly moved up.
Person1: By who?
Person2: The CEO.
Person1: Good God. Let's go talk to her.
Person2: Good idea, only one problem. I don't know if she's available to meet today.
Person1: Ah. Wait a minute. The assistant must know her schedule.
Person2: It's a little late to call the assistant.
Person1: Is it a little late to send her an email?
Person2: Maybe... I don't know.

Person1: You're crazy if you think she's not interested.
Person2: I'll be okay. I can handle it.
Person1: Just remember, it's all about being genuine. Don't let your doubts show.

Person1: I know we've been given a rare opportunity here, Professor. A real chance to make a difference in this community. They need us, and maybe that's why we were brought together, to keep us from getting too comfortable in our own little worlds.
Person2: What makes you think they need me? I'm just a historian, not a miracle worker.
Person1: Ah, but that's where you're wrong. Your expertise is exactly what this town requires. And I think you'll find that they're not just grateful, but also willing to listen and learn.

Person1: I've been thinking about our relationship lately...
Person2: What about it?
Person1: I want to make it right. Pack up the past, throw it away, and start fresh.
Person2: You mean like throwing away the garbage in black bags behind the Fang Shan Restaurant?
Person1: (laughs) No, not exactly. I just want us to move forward, without the weight of our past mistakes.
Person2: (smiling) I think that's a great idea. But it's not just about forgetting, it's about learning from our mistakes and growing together.
Person1: Exactly! I want us to grow together, to laugh together, and to support each other.
Person2: (nods) Me too. Let's do it.

Person1: What's the point of even talking to them if they're not willing to make a decent offer?
Person2: I'm just the messenger. The DA's office is willing to discuss a plea deal, but you need to be willing to cooperate.
Person1: Who's side are you on, anyway? You're not exactly filling me with confidence.
Person2: I'm trying to help you, but you need to think about your options carefully. If you don't take the deal, you could be facing some serious consequences.
Person1: What if I refuse to play along? What's the worst that could happen?
Person2: You could end up with a much harsher sentence than you're expecting. Is that really what you want?

Person1: I'm not "people." I'm just me. And I do whatever I goddamn want to do. Got it?
Person2: Question withdrawn, you may step down.
Person1: You're implying that I'm trying to control you, but I'm just offering a helping hand.
Person2: I said, no further questions. I can take care of myself.
Person1: Suit yourself. But if you change your mind, I'll be here to listen.
Person2: Thanks, but I'll manage.

Person1: You may step down.
Person2: I'm not sure what to do now. I'm not sure what he wants for me.
Person1: I'm here to help you. You've done a great thing and should be rewarded.
Person2: What do you mean? What kind of reward?
Person1: A monetary reward, of course. You deserve it.
Person2: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with that. Can I ask some questions?
Person1: No further questions. We've discussed this enough.

Person1: What do you mean by this place?
Person2: It reminds me of home.
Person1: Did you grow up around here?
Person2: No, I'm from a different world. A chunk of rock that was part of my home planet, but we moved it to inner space.
Person1: That's hard to understand. Can you explain?
Person2: It's not important. The important thing is I'm here to find something and I think you can help me.
Person1: So, you've never been in a situation like this before?
Person2: Well, kind of recently, I guess. But not too recently.

Person1: Is someone there?
Person2: Sorry to take up your time like that, Alex. Don't work too hard.
Person1: What's going on? You're being really vague.
Person2: Oh, before I forget. I talked to your professor and smoothed things over about the missed deadline.
Person1: Thanks, I owe you one.

Person1: Do you know what's going on?
Person2: What do you mean? You're the one who's been acting strange.
Person1: I don't remember... Take my advice, get out of here. Now.
Person2: What's wrong? You're scaring me.

Person1: I've got a plan to get us out of this mess. We can sneak into the abandoned warehouse and find something valuable to sell.
Person2: That's not a bad idea, but we need to be careful. We don't know what kind of condition the warehouse is in.
Person1: Ah, come on! A little risk never hurt anyone. It's not like we're going to get caught or anything.
Person2: You're not thinking about the consequences, are you? What if we get hurt or worse?
Person1: Oh, don't be such a worrywart! We'll be fine. And even if we do get caught, we can just talk our way out of it.
Person2: You really think you're that charming, don't you?

Person1: You better start making sense!
Person2: To finish last evening's delightful work. We've got a situation on our hands.
Person1: Now do you want the good news first or the bad news?
Person2: What began with the lash shall be concluded with a caress. Just tell me straight.
Person1: The bad news is the lab is compromised. We have 36 hours to contain the leak, maybe.
Person2: Then we've got to act fast! We can't let it spread.

Person1: So, what's the plan for tonight?
Person2: We're heading to Baltimore, Maryland. I've got a business meeting lined up.
Person1: That sounds great. I was worried we might need to dress up for dinner.
Person2: Oh, we might. Yes, let's dress up. It'll be fun.
Person1: I love you, and I know you want the best for me.
Person2: Of course, I do. Don't let yourself down, okay?
Person1: I won't. Thanks for looking out for me. Goodnight.

Person1: I have the evidence right here. It was accessible to everyone.
Person2: Why are you bringing this up now? Are you trying to provoke me?
Person1: I just want to clarify the facts. You admitted it was done in full public view, didn't you?
Person2: That's not the point. You're trying to twist my words.
Person1: I'm just trying to get to the truth. Let's focus on the facts, not speculation.

Person1: We need to discuss the merger. It's the only way to save the company.
Person2: I won't let you take control. I'd rather be broke than lose my autonomy.
Person1: Forget about pride, let me show you the numbers. You'll be set for life.
Person2: I'm not interested. The ball's in your court now.

Person1: Hi, I'm trying to get in touch with someone who can help me with a situation.
Person2: What's going on?
Person1: You went to my high-school, right?
Person2: No, I didn't.
Person1: Then how do you know about my situation?
Person2: You just told me.
Person1: No, I didn't. I was about to explain it to you.
Person2: Sorry, I misunderstood. Please go ahead and explain.
Person1: Okay. I work for a man named Mr. Johnson, and he's a very sick man. He's asked me to help him find his daughter.
Person2: I'm listening.

Person1: You're a genius, Alex - a genius!
Person2: I know how people with broken bones know when there's a storm coming?
Person1: You got any broken bones?
Person2: No, but something's gonna blow in this town. I can feel it.
Person1: Are you messing with me, Rachel? Is something gonna happen to my sister?
Person2: I can't tell you, Michael. 
Person1: Why not?
Person2: I saw your eyes when you stood up for her at the town hall meeting. 
Person1: Tell me, Rachel. What are you afraid of? 
Person2: I'm afraid you'll hurt her. 
Person1: It's Emily, isn't it?

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a bad investment. Every delay costs us money.
Person2: We'll be making so much profit, these setbacks won't matter. Occasionally, you have to take a risk, and that's good business.
Person1: And why should we pay more for the same service? It should cost less.
Person2: Exactly. That's why I'm offering you a partnership. We'll guarantee every shipment, anywhere, for any reason. Your operations will run risk-free.
Person1: And what's in it for you?
Person2: We'll take thirty percent of the load. Product or cash. We can deliver what no one else can.
Person1: That sounds too good to be true. What's the catch?
Person2: There's no catch. We're confident in our abilities. We're willing to put our money where our mouth is.

Person1: You're like the most amazing person I've ever met. You're so smart and fun!
Person2: I think it's important not to get too caught up in the excitement. We should stay grounded and focused.

Person1: What do you want more than anything?
Person2: It's what they want you to see.
Person1: I told you what I want. Are you sure you want to do this?
Person2: Yes. I don't know, but I'll think about it for a while.
Person1: I hope someday people understand you again.
Person2: Thank you for your help.

Person1: I'm grateful!
Person2: Who sent you, Rachel?
Person1: It's all there in the report. Read it carefully. If you don't want to, I suppose that's okay too. But in that case, I want you to know something - I never stopped trusting your instincts. You were a very good partner.

Person1: I'm going to show you how to navigate this system. Look at this file. See anything?
Person2: It's just a regular report. 
Person1: Son, I can help you get ahead with this information. It's not what it seems. Now, I'm going to teach you how to read between the lines in case you get stuck somewhere.
Person2: Sir, I was instructed to -
Person1: Your instructions are what I'm giving you now. Let's focus on the task at hand. We can't afford to waste time.

Person1: I'm sorry I doubted your idea. You were right, and I was wrong.
Person2: It's okay, I'm just glad we could work it out. But I have to say, I'm still upset about what happened with the project last week.
Person1: What do you mean? I thought we were both on the same page.
Person2: We were, but I felt like you didn't ask for my input enough. I mean, it's not just your project, it's ours.
Person1: You're right, I should have been more considerate. I'll try to do better next time.
Person2: I appreciate that. And hey, at least we got a good outcome in the end.
Person1: Yeah, Simons was really impressed with our teamwork. By the way, did I ever call you a failure?
Person2: (laughs) No, but I did think you were being pretty stubborn at one point.

Person1: I'll visit often. You've nothing to worry about.
Person2: For God's sake, can I go now? I've told you everything I know.
Person1: No, I don't think so. You're not being entirely honest with me.
Person2: What do you want from me? We've given you all the information we have.

Person1: You don't remember me, do you?
Person2: No, I don't think so.
Person1: WELL? What are your plans?
Person2: Plans? I met her at the conference and I had all that data. You know, those new market trends. I gave her a presentation before I realized... she's a tough negotiator... Jesus, she's never even compromised.
Person1: Well... It'll probably work out. We can keep her informed and peddle our services at the business convention.

Person1: I think it's better if we find this man before he finds us again.
Person2: We pretend... We're not who we say we are.
Person1: So you're telling me it was one guy with a hidden agenda? And he's been lying to us?
Person2: Yes... You understand THAT, don't you? We're all actors in our own way.
Person1: I'll see what I can do. How do I get in touch with you?
Person2: Be careful. We're not the only ones who can pretend.

Person1: I think it's better if we find this man before he finds us again.
Person2: You're fired.
Person1: What? Why? I'm the best in the business!
Person2: Not according to the board. They voted you most likely to fail.
Person1: That's ridiculous! I've got a plan to hit Poppa Joe tonight, right in the comfort of his own home.
Person2: Get your feet off that desk. We're not going to discuss this further.

Person1: You don't understand me.
Person2: After I saw what happened to Rachel - you know I changed my whole approach, took a break, re-evaluated my priorities. She really opened my eyes.

Person1: See that wasn't so bad.
Person2: And anxious to get started. What's the plan now?
Person1: Yes, we've made great progress. Now it's time to take it to the next level.
Person2: Okay. I'm ready when you are.

Person1: I'm trying to remember why I banned that new restaurant from catering our events.
Person2: Ah, yes. It was because of the way the chef outwitted the food critic, exposing him as a fraud.
Person1: Exactly! And that's what bothered me. It was like he was saying that anyone can deceive anyone, no matter their position.
Person2: I see what you mean. But didn't you used to work in the service industry? Didn't you have to deal with difficult customers?
Person1: Yes, I did. And that's why it hurt to see the chef get away with it. He was built, you know, to impress, but it was all a facade.
Person2: I understand. It's like when someone asks if you want it dirty, but they're not really asking. They're just trying to get what they want.

Person1: So, what's this about?
Person2: Well, I think you're old enough to know some things. For instance, have you ever wondered how we met?
Person1: Is this being recorded?
Person2: No, no, just a casual conversation. I'm not writing anything down, I promise.
Person1: Okay, good. So, how did we meet?
Person2: Ah, that's a story for another time. Let's focus on you. You're growing up, and there are things you should know. Like, it's not a good idea to do certain things in the shower. It's a waste of water and electricity.
Person1: What things?
Person2: Never mind. Just trust me on that one. And, um, be respectful of others' belongings, okay?
Person1: Okay... I think.

Person1: You two need a reality check. We can't just hide from this.
Person2: Don't worry, I've got it. Are you crazy?

Person1: What do you mean?
Person2: Want to go on a ride?
Person1: God, no. I don't want to go.
Person2: Go where?
Person1: I kind of tried it once, but it seemed stupid. I kept thinking about all the things we could be doing instead.
Person2: So it was recently that you tried this?
Person1: Well, kind of recently, I guess. But not too recently.

Person1: I'm sorry, I don't understand.
Person2: Jesus, first the manual, now you. You need to read the instructions.
Person1: It's not important. The important thing is I'm here to help you and I think we can figure it out together.
Person2: Like it? This new device?
Person1: Yes. It reminds me of my old lab.

Person1: What's going on? You're not yourself lately.
Person2: I'm just trying to get some credit for my work.
Person1: Credit? You think that's what this is about? You're not thinking clearly, Fran.
Person2: I'm thinking more clearly than you are. You're just trying to hold me back.
Person1: Hold you back? I'm trying to protect you from yourself. You're not considering the deal we made.
Person2: The deal's changed. And I'm not going to let you or anyone else take advantage of me.
Person1: You're being paranoid. I'm on your side.
Person2: Are you? Then why do I feel like you're trying to manipulate me?
Person1: I'm just trying to help. You're tired, that's all. Here, drink this.
Person2: I don't need your help. And I don't need your drink.

Person1: I don't understand you. 
Person2: Plans?
Person1: Life gets messy. Ugly messy. But I want it all. You guys want guarantees? I want the possibilities. 
Person2: I met her on the plane and I had all that acid. You know, those little blue barrels. 
Person1: And I think that's okay with me because, because of the rest of the stuff. All the good shit. All the surprises. 
Person2: I guess. 
Person1: It's a miracle when you come down to it. We'd have had amazing children, you and me. 
Person2: Well... It'll probably work out.

Person1: I'm not sure I understand the reasoning behind this decision, Professor. Can you refresh my memory?
Person2: Well, the data suggests that the new policy will increase efficiency, but I sense that you're not convinced.
Person1: Look, Professor, I know you're sincere and trying to do a competent job, but I can assure you the problem is with the implementation, not the concept.
Person2: Okay, let's see how things go from here on. Perhaps we can revisit the policy and make adjustments as needed.

Person1: I'm not gonna need it.  It's a precaution.
Person2: You're implying that I don't understand what's going on.
Person1: Sometimes you can't know what I'm doing.  It's better that way.
Person2: I know.  But I have a right to know.
Person1: I'll give you an update in two months.  Then we'll take a break.
Person2: Question withdrawn.

Person1: You're really cold, aren't you?
Person2: Yes, I've had to be.
Person1: But what about our past? Don't you care?
Person2: You are the most resourceful person I've met.
Person1: That's not an answer. You're just trying to deflect.
Person2: I'm sorry, Alex. You're just not a priority to me right now.

Person1: You're still holding on to that dream, aren't you? Don't lie.
Person2: What's the hurry? I see what I've been waiting for, but I need you.
Person1: You made a choice once. Do you think you would make that same choice again?
Person2: Others are waiting, but I need to know if you'd still reach up to that cash register.

Person1: What are you trying to take off her husband? That's your business. All I'm saying is, I want mine.
Person2: You know, there are many facets to this. If I can find your money, man-- what's in it for me?
Person1: Let's say a 10% finder's fee? Refill?
Person2: Better if I just show you. Does the Pope shit in the woods?
Person1: Okay, done. I like the way you do business. Your money is being held by a kid named Alex. He lives in downtown LA, near the Union Station. A real smooth talker, but I'm sure you'll be able to get it off him. So if you'll just write me a check for my ten per cent... of two hundred grand.

Person1: Did you invite them?
Person2: I'm just thinking about something. What if the new policy isn't implemented properly?
Person1: We'll be fine. It's not like it's going to be dangerous or anything.
Person2: You never know. There could be unintended consequences.
Person1: Whatever you say. I'm sure it'll work out.
Person2: Before I forget, can you put the report on the desk?

Person1: I didn't expect to run into you here, that's all.
Person2: What's going on? You seem shaken.
Person1: They've taken something from me, I just don't remember what.
Person2: Who has? What are you talking about?

Person1: I've been getting a lot of flak from the press lately. They're calling me "The Rookie Sensation". What do they mean by that?
Person2: They'd call you anything if you gave them half a chance. They've got you down as a flash in the pan.
Person1: I think I'll go down and give that reporter a piece of my mind.
Person2: No, you don't! Get this clear: Arguing with them is no solution for anything. You've got brains, kid. You'll get along swell if you'll only curb your impulsive instincts - and keep your trap shut. Don't talk to anybody! These newshounds are out gunning for you.
Person1: But what about this "Rookie Sensation" business?
Person2: That's my job. I'll take care of that. I'll keep that stuff out of the papers - if you'll help me. But I can't do anything if you go around talking to people. Will you promise me to be careful from now on?
Person1: Yeah, I guess I'll have to. Hey, you want to grab some lunch and talk about how to handle these reporters?
Person2: I think I'd better stay here for a while.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's not that far. We can make it work.
Person2: Yes, I am the richest man - too rich. I can't think of anything but money. That's the trouble with me.
Person1: What does that have to do with anything? We're talking about our relationship.
Person2: You know darn well it's relevant. You're expecting me to drive all the way to Vanderbilt for you, and I'm wondering if it's worth the investment.
Person1: It's not about the distance or the money. It's about us being together when the time is right.
Person2: The time is right when the circumstances are right. And right now, I'm not convinced it's worth it.
Person1: You're not convinced? You're the one who's always talking about the importance of relationships.
Person2: I am, but I'm also a realist. And right now, I'm not seeing the returns on this investment.

Person1: I've noticed you've been distant lately. What's going on?
Person2: I don't know. I'm just really upset with my partner right now. They're letting some old friend stay at our place without even asking me.
Person1: What upsets you about that?
Person2: I guess I'm upset because I feel like I don't have a say in what happens in my own home. It's like, I know I'm not paying the mortgage, but I do all the household chores.
Person1: That's understandable. It's not just about the chores, though. It's about feeling respected and considered in your own relationship.
Person2: Exactly. And it's not just this one thing. Lately, I've been feeling like I'm just going through the motions with my partner. I don't feel like we're really connecting anymore.
Person1: I'm here to listen, and I want to help you work through this. Can you tell me more about what's been going on with you and your partner?

Person1: I want to see you, Governor.
Person2: You're looking at me. What's your point?
Person1: Only if I repeat them outside this room. And, I will if I must... Out there, for all to hear.
Person2: You think you have the power to ruin me? I'm the one who brings prosperity to this town.
Person1: Oh? Far as I can tell, a rumor does not travel alone for long here. You're not as clean as you seem.
Person2: How dare you! I've done nothing but good for this community.
Person1: Wallowing in corruption and greed... You're not the leader this town needs.
Person2: You're just a jealous outsider trying to stir up trouble. No one will listen to you.
Person1: We'll see about that. I have evidence, and I won't hesitate to use it.
Person2: You'll regret the day you ever crossed me.

Person1: I have it now.
Person2: What's the plan, then?
Person1: I met her at the conference and I had all these ideas. You know, those innovative strategies. I pitched them to her before I realized... she's a tough negotiator... Jesus, she's never even compromised.
Person2: Well... It'll probably work out. We can keep her engaged and showcase her skills at the business fair.

Person1: Hi, I need your help. I'm trying to find someone, and I think you might be able to assist me.
Person2: What's going on? You sound a bit lost.
Person1: I am, to be honest. I've been tasked with finding a specific person, but I'm not sure where to start.
Person2: Okay, well, let's take it one step at a time. Who is it you're trying to find?
Person1: His name is Alex. He's an old friend of mine, and I haven't seen him in years.
Person2: And why do you need to find him now?
Person1: It's a bit of a long story, but basically, I promised someone I'd track him down. Someone will follow up with me once I've found him.
Person2: I see. Well, I can try to help you. But first, can you tell me more about Alex? What's he like?

Person1: What began with a spark shall be concluded with a flame. You're not thinking of going back to the village alone, are you?
Person2: I already know the way... and it's not like I have a family I have to rush home to. Between you and me, I could use the time to reflect on my journey.

Person1: I'll be at the desk, but don't introduce me, let it go, just start talking.
Person2: This is the way in?
Person1: Yes... Are you sure you want to do this?
Person2: They'll be looking at you. They don't know who you are.
Person1: It's what they want you to see.

Person1: What's going on? You're acting strange.
Person2: I'm so torn. You're a wonderful person, and I feel terrible for putting you in this situation.
Person1: What situation? You're not making any sense.
Person2: It's just that... I never stopped caring for your mother. She was a remarkable woman. It's just that my feelings for her were different. She brought out something in me that no one else has ever brought out before or since.
Person1: That's not what I'm asking. What's going on between us?
Person2: Oh, I'm sorry. I'm making a mess of things. Please, just go. Come back tomorrow. I promise I'll be clearer then.
Person1: I'm not going anywhere until you explain what's going on.
Person2: Fine. I want to give you a gift. For being such a good listener. You'll let me, won't you?

Person1: I'm stuck, I don't know what to say to myself.
Person2: Broken dreams are for the weak. You need to pick yourself up.
Person1: For self-acceptance to bend its knee, admit its flaws, implore its own forgiveness, is the hardest thing on earth.
Person2: Have you ever looked in the mirror, really looked?
Person1: I want to, but I'm scared of what I'll see.
Person2: That's the first step, acknowledging the fear.

Person1: You know, I did think about switching careers one time.
Person2: Yeah, what happened?
Person1: You're like the most amazing mentor I've ever had. You're so smart and fun and inspiring! You rock my world.
Person2: I'm telling you, what you really need is someone to believe in you. Trust me.
Person1: You think so?

Person1: I don't remember where Agnes was. I was needed in the sick room.
Person2: You look like the kind of person who has to fight them off. Doesn't he look to you like the kind of person who has to fight them off?
Person1: Oh no, I was just helping Sister Paul on that night. It was a difficult time for our community.
Person2: I bet you're quite the hero. You have yourself a few admirers this summer.

Person1: Hello, Reverend Brown. I'm so glad you could make it.
Person2: Ah, thank you, Mikhi. I'm afraid I'm a bit lost. I was supposed to perform a ceremony, but I forgot the church's address.
Person1: (laughs) Well, that's quite all right. I think we can help you with that. But first, would you like to sit down and have a drink?
Person2: No, thank you. I'm not sure I'm comfortable with... whatever this is.
Person1: (smiling) Whatever this is, is just a little misunderstanding. I assure you, we mean no harm.
Person2: (skeptical) I've heard that before. From Edvard, just before he died.
Person1: (chuckles) Ah, Edvard. Yes, well, he was a bit of a trickster, wasn't he?

Person1: I'll tell you what it is, I've had enough of your evasive answers. 
Person2: In a week... we will never have had this conversation. 
Person1: Pooh! Pooh! You're not serious, are you? 
Person2: I never was more in earnest. I'll come for dinner, and in the meantime... you'll think about what we discussed?

Person1: I'm thinking of skipping the school dance tonight. Want to come with me to the arcade instead?
Person2: I don't know...I already told Rachel I'd meet her there.
Person1: Oh, come on! It'll be more fun, I promise. And if you talk about it, you don't have to do it.
Person2: That's not the point. I don't want to bail on Rachel at the last minute.
Person1: Please, as a favour to me? So I won't be the only one ditching the dance?

Person1: I regret we have no experts to guide you through this process, Doctor. Respect my wish and let's proceed with caution.
Person2: Well, technically, the risks are minimal, but on a par with a complex surgery. Nothing you'll miss, but I'd rather have a second opinion.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly, I can't let you do this.
Person2: Listen, I took the fall for you last time, now it's your turn to return the favor. Grab your things, we're leaving.

Person1: I've got a job offer for you. It's a year's contract, and all expenses are paid.
Person2: What's the job?
Person1: I'll tell you when it's time. But trust me, it's a great opportunity.
Person2: That's quite vague. Can you at least tell me where it is?
Person1: Let's just say it's a beautiful location. You'll love it.
Person2: I'm not sure... I'd like to know more about the case.
Person1: There's ten grand in it for you. That's all I can say for now.

Person1: Are you trying to bury the truth? It happened! The city's in an uproar and you're just going to sweep it under the rug?
Person2: What's the alternative? Do you want chaos in the streets? The situation's volatile enough without adding fuel to the fire.
Person1: Maybe it's time for a change. You can't just silence people and expect them to take it lying down.
Person2: You really want to be responsible for the consequences?

Person1: I'm not feeling so well. Can we take a break?
Person2: I saw you look off when the waiter spilled the drink. I figured it wasn't just the mess that bothered you.
Person1: How did you know I needed some air?
Person2: Because that's what I would have done. Besides, it smells like something's burning in here.
Person1: Yeah, let's get out of here. Where are all the other guests?
Person2: I think they're all outside already. Shall we?

Person1: I've always thought that dressing up was about confidence, not just the clothes.
Person2: You will not be unaware of the threat now posed by the changing fashion trends.
Person1: Ah, but therein lies the paradox. It's not just about following the trends, but also about expressing oneself.
Person2: Cute. Let's have some drinks and discuss this further.

Person1: I think it's better if we find this man before he finds us again.
Person2: Well, then it all seems to be working out for you. Listen, Mr...?
Person1: On television, you seemed so sure of yourself. If you're really that confident, you'd be willing to let someone prove you wrong?
Person2: So you're telling me it was one guy with a unique story? And he was a professor?
Person1: The world would be so much simpler if it were all just about good and evil. Unfortunately, I find it much more slippery and elusive place.
Person2: I'll see what I can do. How do I get in touch with you? I have a tape of his lecture that might interest you.
Person1: I'll bet. Meet me at the University Library. Tomorrow at 2... if you want to learn more.

Person1: We can't let him get away with this. If we stop the shipment, we'll cripple his operation.
Person2: I understand your concerns, but we need to be cautious. We haven't fully identified the risks involved.
Person1: Risks? You're talking about risks? If we don't act now, we'll be responsible for more innocent lives being ruined.
Person2: I'm not saying we shouldn't act, but we need to consider the environmental concerns. We can't just rush in without a plan.
Person1: Fine. Get me the schematics and I'll come up with a plan. But we need to move fast. Time is running out.

Person1: What's the point of restoring this place?
Person2: I like to do it. I enjoy it. Take the darkness out of it, make it beautiful again. You see, my family used to live here... Nothing can live here now. I was just a kid when I first saw it, I thought it was beautiful... It was just a dark mist turning into the corner of the room... then it started to move... then death started to happen... First the workers... then my family...

Person1: I've been thinking, and I believe our new marketing strategy will fail to achieve anything fundamental. It will result in crushing criticism from our investors ...
Person2: I didn't ask what the team thinks, Rachel. What do you think?
Person1: Honestly, I think they're playing it too safe. They don't realize that our competitors only respect innovation, and they will only negotiate in good faith if they fear our bold moves.
Person2: That's an interesting perspective. But what if I were to send you a message, straight from my thoughts, Rachel? Would you take it seriously?
Person1: Ha! I think I can handle a heartfelt message, but I'd rather focus on making our strategy work than worrying about your opinions.

Person1: I've been thinking about the new art exhibit downtown. Have you had a chance to see it?
Person2: Actually, I was involved in the curation process. It's a remarkable collection, if I do say so myself.
Person1: I'm equally impressed with your expertise. How long have you been with the museum now?
Person2: Five years, but I came over from the Parisian Institute of Art six months ago.
Person1: I know we had some controversy surrounding the exhibit, but frankly I can't remember why. Can you refresh my memory?
Person2: Well, some critics felt that the featured artist's use of provocative imagery was too similar to a previous exhibition. Do you see the implications? It sparked a debate about originality in modern art.
Person1: Ah, I see. Perhaps we could discuss this further over dinner tonight?

Person1: What's going on? You're being really quiet.
Person2: Well, sometimes when we get 'em, they're not completely dead, you know?
Person1: What do you mean? I don't know if I can handle this.
Person2: Him? I don't know... He can be nice... sometimes.
Person1: Of what? What are you talking about?
Person2: Never mind. Just forget it.

Person1: I'm so tired. I think we should take a break.
Person2: You better put on the lights. I can't see what I'm doing.
Person1: It's not important. The main thing is that we're making progress.
Person2: I may spill something.
Person1: So spill it. We can clean it up later.
Person2: What's the hurry?
Person1: We better have a drink first. It'll help us relax.
Person2: Here, this'll calm your nerves.
Person1: Not yet. Let's focus on the task at hand.

Person1: You know, I've been thinking about your work, and I have to say, it's impressive. You have a certain flair to it.
Person2: Oh, thank you. I try my best.
Person1: It's more than that. You have a way of making things come alive. I've seen your designs, and they're not just functional, they're beautiful. You have a gift.
Person2: (laughs) You're making me blush.
Person1: I'm serious. You should be proud of what you've accomplished. And I think you deserve a reward. Why don't you take a look at the designs we've been working on and pick the one you like the most? Take it as a token of appreciation.
Person2: That's very kind of you. Thank you.

Person1: I'm not playing with you, these vendors are looking to rip you off. They see you, they see dollar signs.
Person2: You capitalist pig! I was just trying to get a good deal.
Person1: Okay, okay. I've set up a price comparison tool and I'll get Jahn to write out a sign. Let's get going.
Person2: I've been hearing you, but I think we should be careful not to get caught in a bad bargain.

Person1: I'll thank you to pay me the sum you owe me.
Person2: Question withdrawn, you may step down.
Person1: What's the matter here? You're implying that I'm not keeping my end of the deal.
Person2: I said, no further questions. I've had enough of your excuses, sir.
Person1: Pooh! Pooh! You're not taking this seriously.
Person2: I never was more in earnest. I expect a formal apology and compensation by the end of the week.

Person1: What's the point of this event if it's not going to make any money?
Person2: You're only thinking about the cost, what about the value it brings to the community?
Person1: The performance is free, what more do you want? I've set up a donation box and we'll get the word out.
Person2: That's not the issue. We need to talk about the real impact we're having here.

Person1: I'm implying that you're not being entirely honest with me. 
Person2: What makes you think that? I'm telling you the truth. 
Person1: I don't know. I just wish you would've asked me about it. 
Person2: Asked you about what? 
Person1: About inviting your sister to stay with us for a few days. 
Person2: Oh, that. I didn't think it was a big deal. 
Person1: It's not about it being a big deal. It's about the fact that you didn't even consider my feelings about it. 
Person2: I said I was sorry. What else do you want me to do? 
Person1: I want you to understand why I'm upset. 
Person2: Fine. I understand. Can we move on now?

Person1: Anyway, you're crazy.
Person2: Oh yeah?
Person1: You are the dumbest person in the world.
Person2: That's right.
Person1: I'll call you.
Person2: Apparently I'm not as dumb as you thought I am.
Person1: See you later.
Person2: Fine.

Person1: What do you think is the most important thing in life?
Person2: Sometimes I feel like life is passing me by and I'm just watching.
Person1: That's interesting. I've never thought about it that way. Do you think you're more of a people person or a solo operator?
Person2: I love people. All people. Even people that no one else loves, I think they're OK, you know?
Person1: That's a unique perspective. But don't you think that can also be a weakness?
Person2: No. Well, yes. I have to admit it. But I'm working on it.

Person1: What's the hurry?
Person2: Your fear runs deep.
Person1: Let us explore it together.
Person2: Others are waiting.

Person1: I'm finally taking the leap, Rachel. Me. Can you believe I'm starting my own business?
Person2: You're a brave soul, Alex. What's the plan?
Person1: I love your enthusiasm, do you know that? I'm going to make it happen, no matter what.
Person2: I love your confidence, man. You're not as dumb as you act, you know. When you make it big, I'll be right there to celebrate.
Person1: You're on. But first, let's discuss the details over a swim. My treat.
Person2: Oh come on. Quit acting like a newbie and let's get started.

Person1: I won't lose you. But I did. It's a crisis, and I'm observing my own heart.
Person2: You know when people speak the truth? Maybe it's when they're about to let go.

Person1: I don't remember... 
Person2: I have a suggestion. There's really not much time left - I mean, you haven't had a minute alone yet, and - well, I could take care of everything here and meet you at the gate.
Person1: What is going on? Are you sure you won't mind?
Person2: Of course not. I just want to help.

Person1: I've been thinking about the Ellingson tankers. You know, the ones with the infected ballast programs?
Person2: Yeah, what about them?
Person1: Well, I was wondering if you'd like to grab some food and discuss it further. I've got some ideas I'd like to bounce off you.
Person2: I'm not sure that's a good idea. I've got some things to take care of here.
Person1: Come on, it'll be good to catch up. And who knows, maybe we can figure out who's behind the Da Vinci virus.
Person2: Alright, fine. But just for a bit.

Person1: I'm so excited to finally meet you. Do you like music?
Person2: Yes, I do -- very much. But what's happening to you? You seem a bit off.
Person1: I'm just a bit nervous, that's all. Will I be able to play the harp here? It's an instrument I'm very fond of.
Person2: Of course, you can play the harp. But can I ask, what's with the strange questions? You're not acting like yourself.
Person1: I'm sorry if I seem strange. I just want to make a good impression. Will you also allow me to have a botanical garden?
Person2: You can have a botanical garden, but I think we need to talk about what's really going on here. You're not yourself, and I'm worried about you.
Person1: I appreciate your concern, but I'm fine, really. I just want to learn and grow. Will you teach me how to dance the quadrille?
Person2: I'll teach you how to dance, but first, let's figure out what's going on with you. You're not acting like the person I thought I knew.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this.
Person2: What do you mean? You're the one who suggested it.
Person1: Get in... now!
Person2: Wait, I want to say good-bye to my friends.
Person1: We can't be late. They're expecting us.
Person2: Expecting us to do what, exactly?
Person1: To talk about our experiences. Share our stories.
Person2: And why should I do that?
Person1: Because it might help others. And it might help you too.
Person2: How?
Person1: By getting things off your chest. By being honest with yourself.
Person2: I'm not sure I'm ready for that.
Person1: That's okay. We can start small. Just a few questions to get started.
Person2: Like what?
Person1: Like what's the most difficult thing you've faced recently?
Person2: That's a tough one. I'm not sure I'm ready to talk about that.
Person1: Okay, no problem. We can move on. What do you prefer, to sit or stand?
Person2: I'll sit, I guess.
Person1: Alright. Let's get started then.

Person1: I'm not sure what's going on, but I feel like I'm stuck in a rut. Without that sense of purpose, I just start questioning everything.
Person2: What do you mean? You're not making sense.
Person1: I mean, I saw this couple on the bus today, and I couldn't help but feel a pang of jealousy. It's like I'm moving in the wrong direction, away from what I really want.
Person2: You're shaking. What's wrong?
Person1: It's just... I don't know, it's like I'm trying to fill a void or something. And I feel like I'm taking it out on the people around me, like Spencer. He doesn't deserve that.
Person2: Spencer's a big boy, he can handle it. But what's really going on with you? You're not telling me everything.
Person1: Leave me alone! Why are you pushing me like this? What do you want from me?
Person2: I just want to help you, that's all.

Person1: Is someone there?
Person2: Look, I'll stay behind and hold them off. The rest of you break for it!
Person1: Are you crazy? We can't just leave you here alone.
Person2: I know what I'm doing. Just go, and don't look back.

Person1: I've never seen anything like it. It's a goldmine of information.
Person2: I doubt it. I don't think this source is so reliable you don't want to fact-check it...
Person1: You're a genius, Babe - a genius! I could kiss you! You'll get the scoop of the year out of this.
Person2: Oh, no. No. Our deal was for a month's exclusive access - with full credit.
Person1: Sure. You'll get it, Babe. You'll get it.

Person1: I'm telling you, it was a weird encounter... I met her at this art gallery... We... bonded over a painting... She told me about a project...
Person2: What project?
Person1: Honestly, I don't recall... Anyway, Rachel's all right... 
Person2: I feel like people think she's a bit standoffish.

Person1: I've got the rest of the money here in the car. Why don't you come and get it?
Person2: Just south to Baltimore, Maryland. So I know what you're going to ask next.
Person1: There's no need to bring anything dressy, or... I mean, I didn't know if we'd be eating at any restaurant that has dress codes.
Person2: He had a gun. I have it now.
Person1: What did you think I was going to ask?
Person2: Whether crabs are in season there now...

Person1: I'm telling you, we need to get a description out to the public. We can't just sit around and wait for him to strike again.
Person2: I understand your frustration, but we're dealing with a ghost. No one knows what he looks like, and those who did are no longer with us.
Person1: That's unacceptable. I guess I don't have a hell of a lot of choice but to trust your instincts on this one.
Person2: Get used to it. In this game, you're only as good as your last lead.

Person1: Are you sure you want to do this?
Person2: Yes, I was there with Alex. I was supposed to meet him fifteen minutes ago.
Person1: It's what they want you to see. You don't have to go through with it.
Person2: I think you'll find he's coming home to you. He told me everything.
Person1: How would you know that? Unless he meant us to meet, which would be a little cruel, wouldn't it?
Person2: Yes... I hope someday people understand him again.

Person1: Do you take sugar?
Person2: Yes, two please. I'm sorry, I didn't mean to pry, it's just that I really loved your book. By the way, what do you think about the recent policy changes?
Person1: Honestly, I think they're cowards. They don't realize that sometimes you need to take a strong stance to achieve real progress.
Person2: That's an interesting perspective. I didn't expect you to be so outspoken about it.

Person1: Hey, Alex! I'm surprised you still have that old guitar.
Person2: Yeah, I know. It's been ages since I played it. I try to remember why I even started, and I can't. Was it to express myself, or to impress others, or just to have fun?
Person1: You know, my dad always says that everything has a purpose, even if we don't see it. Until recently, I wasn't sure what he meant by that.
Person2: Yeah? No kidding. Listen, you still want to go to that music festival tonight?
Person1: I certainly do! But you know, this business of finding our passion  it's kind of abstract, don't you think?
Person2: Yes it is. A hobby maybe. But a passion? I mean...
Person1: Then just help me find a new hobby! That's all I ask.
Person2: Well...yeah. Okay.

Person1: Hi, I'm Sister Agnes. I'm trying to locate a patient's family member. Can I have your help?
Person2: Of course, Sister. What's the situation?
Person1: Well, Mr. Earl Partridge is a dying man and he's asked me to help him find his son, Frank TJ Mackey. I'm his nurse.
Person2: I'm not sure how I can assist you, Sister. When did you last see Frank?
Person1: I've never met him, but I have reason to believe he's in trouble. Do you know anything about him?
Person2: Actually, I do. I remember a night, the twenty-third of January, when one of our elder nuns passed away. I was needed in the sick room, but I heard rumors about Frank's involvement in some shady dealings.
Person1: That's exactly what I'm trying to uncover. Can you put me in touch with someone who might know more?

Person1: You're just trying to distract me. What's going on outside that window?
Person2: I'm not trying to trick you. I just think you should see this for yourself.

Person1: I need a new opportunity.
Person2: Is that what you're looking for?
Person1: Yeah. I don't know why I just said that.
Person2: Let's see... I can think of two reasons.
Person1: What?
Person2: You're trying to make a change and start fresh.
Person1: That's not it. I just feel stuck.
Person2: Okay. Don't worry about it. I'll help you figure it out.

Person1: Are you afraid of her reaction? Of her finding you silly for thinking of such things?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: You were her doctor. Say it.
Person2: I was her doctor.
Person1: You were there to help Dr. Patel with her treatment. Were you not?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: What upsets you about that?
Person2: I guess I'm upset because I can't really justify being upset, I mean, it's her health, really, she's the patient.
Person1: But you asked her to quit smoking, and you do have a professional obligation.
Person2: Yeah, I know.
Person1: This unexpected diagnosis notwithstanding, how are things with her?
Person2: Fine, I guess. Except right now I'm going through this where I don't want to give her false hope.

Person1: I'll teach these people what happens when they challenge our authority.
Person2: You're making this very hard. I think you're strong, but sooner or later, you'll realize you need our help.
Person1: I see a power void to be filled. As we have the most power, we may move with impunity.
Person2: I don't think so. You're going to hurt innocent people if you continue down this path.
Person1: Just perfect. I'll get together four teams to take action tonight.
Person2: You're not thinking about the consequences of your actions. Please, for everyone's sake, reconsider.

Person1: I'm going to make you see the truth, even if it's hard to accept. We can't keep living in denial.
Person2: But I like my life the way it is. I don't want to change.
Person1: Not like this. You're not even listening to yourself. We're at a crossroads here, and if we don't make a move, we'll be stuck in this rut forever.

Person1: You've got to take the right tone in things like this, or people will walk all over you.
Person2: What have you seen that the mind can't fathom?
Person1: I've got a roomful of guests down there, who think I'm a fraud. I am going to teach you something here.
Person2: Why are you doing this? Handing out these horrors!
Person1: Come on out, or I will make it so miserable that you will wish you had never lived!
Person2: You're not going to intimidate me. I know the truth.

Person1: I'm sorry... I don't like people touching my guitar. It's not important. It's a minor quirk. I can deal with it if I want to.
Person2: Forget it. Come on, don't you want to see where the music takes us?
Person1: No. They all come here. How do they find me?
Person2: You need to relax. It's just music.

Person1: I'm impressed you kids got permission to use the school's greenhouse.
Person2: Yeah, we're "special". We get to grow our own plants!
Person1: Well, I suppose that's a good use for it. I used to store my old gardening tools in there.
Person2: Maybe we can even help you with your gardening sometime.
Person1: That's okay, I think I can manage. But thanks for offering.

Person1: Why are you doing this, Captain? We're not in danger of sinking!
Person2: Grab onto me tight, we need to get out of here, now!

Person1: I know that to pursue this career is treason against my family's expectations. But not to pursue it... is treason against my passion.
Person2: Then we'll both find our own way, and lying about our choices won't be an effective tool for either of us.

Person1: I've been thinking, and I'm not sure I'm comfortable with the current state of affairs. You know, I got a job now. I'm teaching high school. Japanese and Chemistry.
Person2: What are you trying to say? That you're too busy to care about the threat posed by Republicanism?
Person1: No, no, it's not that. It's just that... well, I saw something strange the other day. A footprint, I think. Forget it, it's probably not important at all.
Person2: You're not making any sense. What does a footprint have to do with anything?
Person1: I don't know, I just feel like... someone will always get in, no matter how many doors you lock. Even here.

Person1: Whoever tossed this place wants you. And I'm looking to stay outta the line of fire.
Person2: You could have poured coffee in Starbucks, you could have learned to install track lighting in office buildings... You could have been one of ten thousand things.
Person1: They lifted my wallet to make it look like a robbery. But there's a bug in my computer keyboard, a tap on the phone and a mike in the light fixture.
Person2: You made that decision... and I find that very, very interesting. What do you think they're looking for?
Person1: Hardware's too sophisticated. It's gotta be the government. And why do I think they're looking for you?
Person2: I'm you, I take that money and get outta town while I can.

Person1: You're being reckless, Alex. Don't trust him.
Person2: You better start making sense! What's going on?
Person1: Okay, I will. The bad news is we're running out of time. We need to find a way out of here, fast.
Person2: Then we've got to move, now!

Person1: You're not even thinking about the consequences, are you?
Person2: What's the hurry? I'm just trying to keep up with what's expected of me.
