Person1: But that's exactly what I'm talking about. You're just going through the motions without a second thought.
Person2: You know how it is. Sometimes you just have to do what looks right, even if it seems crazy.
Person1: I'm starting to think that's how it is for most people, not just programs.
Person2: Yeah, and others are waiting for us to make a move.

Person1: You may step down.
Person2: You want me to believe you're satisfied, well, I'm not, that's not enough!
Person1: I'm not trying to imply anything. 
Person2: Then what, what do you want from me? Tell me...
Person1: Better if I just show you.

Person1: I think you're a nice person. I like you.
Person2: There is a way.
Person1: But it's impossible. You couldn't, it's too... complicated.
Person2: Why? What's stopping us?
Person1: No, it wouldn't work. You'd never make it. Forget I mentioned it.
Person2: I'm supposing. You're right, it's not possible.
Person1: Exactly. I can read signs if the print is large enough.

Person1: I wish everything were so much simpler... that people could just come together by the color of their hair or the size of their shoes.
Person2: What do you mean? You're not thinking of...?
Person1: I stood there and I kissed you for the last time. And I said, "I won't lose you."
Person2: But you did. You lost me, didn't you? And now you're wondering if I loved you, if I wanted to go on loving you.
Person1: That's why I'm asking you. Are you really sure... that you want to be with me?
Person2: What can I say? No. At least, not yet. I don't know... I can't even think of it... at a time like this...

Person1: You're still not listening to me? Don't lie.
Person2: What's the hurry? I've got a plan, but it's not airtight.
Person1: Others are waiting. We can't afford to have this blown wide open.
Person2: I know, I know. But I'm not some decorated vet who can just waltz in and expect everyone to buy it.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is, we can't let this get out of hand. We need to contain it, no matter what it takes.
Person2: And what exactly does that mean? "Contain it"? You're not talking about...?
Person1: Just focus on the task at hand. We'll deal with the fallout later.

Person1: We've got a problem on our hands, don't we? The local farmers are getting restless.
Person2: That's correct, sir. They're not afraid to challenge our authority.
Person1: Not that one, or that one. They're all just pawns in a bigger game.
Person2: I see what you mean, sir. But we can't let them get away with it. We need to take action.
Person1: I'll teach them what happens when they challenge progress. Assemble a team of our best detectives and let's show them who's in charge.
Person2: Yes, sir. I'll get right on it.

Person1: I've been wanting to talk to you for a while. You're doing some crazy stuff, and I think we need to clear the air.
Person2: What's on your mind?
Person1: I've been on a hot streak lately, but I think I could learn from you. You've got a certain style that's admirable.
Person2: (laughs) You're not going to try to intimidate me, are you?
Person1: No, no. I'm being genuine. I think we could have a mutually beneficial conversation. Want to grab some food and talk?
Person2: Sure, but let's go somewhere quiet. I don't want any distractions.

Person1: I'm not sure I can trust you with this task. 
Person2: Good God, you're being dramatic. 
Person1: A small mistake could have serious consequences. 
Person2: I understand. You want me to respect your wishes and take full responsibility.

Person1: I've been hearing a lot about your family's legacy. What's it like to come from such a storied background?
Person2: Honestly, it's a mix. I mean, I got it, but listen, my family's history isn't all it's cracked up to be. There are secrets, things that have been hidden for generations.

Person1: I'm afraid we can't let you in, sir. It's not safe.
Person2: You know better than that. I've been invited to this exclusive event.
Person1: I apologize, but we need to verify the guest list with the host.
Person2: Then why do you seem so nervous? Can't you see I'm a respected member of this community?
Person1: It's just procedure, sir. We have to ensure everyone's security.
Person2: Well, rest easy, I'm not going to cause any trouble. I just want to make sure my donation is being used properly.

Person1: I'll find her.
Person2: Ahh, I don't think you'll have time for that after all.
Person1: We then spent an hour in the most eloquent silence, except that, from time to time, I cried out.
Person2: I did not know that one kiss could matter so much.
Person1: I don't think so.
Person2: Let me give a thousand kisses to that heavenly mouth which has told me that I am happy.

Person1: You know, if we don't resolve this issue, it'll only get worse.
Person2: She did not do it... please listen...
Person1: I understand your concerns, but the evidence suggests otherwise.
Person2: No, sir, please... she is innocent... I can vouch for her.
Person1: I appreciate your loyalty, but sometimes we have to accept the truth, no matter how difficult it is.
Person2: But what if we're wrong? What if there's more to the story?

Person1: So, I've been wondering...what do you think people think of you?
Person2: Honestly, I'm not sure. I feel like they might think I'm a bit of a troublemaker.
Person1: Well, "trouble" is a relative term. I've got something that belongs to you, by the way. You left it at the coffee shop the other day.
Person2: Oh, yeah! I've been looking all over for that. Thanks for returning it.

Person1: I feel like they do.
Person2: Whatever the 'truth' is, let's hear that. You were her teacher.
Person1: Yes.
Person2: Say it.
Person1: I was her teacher.
Person2: You were the one who gave her a failing grade in math last semester, weren't you?
Person1: Yes.
Person2: Hmm. Well, maybe you're just a tough grader. Really, I wouldn't pay much attention.

Person1: I'm telling you, it was a Sunday... that explains it.  The museum's closed on Sundays.
Person2: But, Mr. Johnson, I am hardly to blame for the lack of exhibits.  Is this your ticket stub?
Person1: You know darn well it is.  God, I wish I could think of something else besides this exhibit.

Person1: I'm thrilled to have met you, Ms. Rodriguez. You have a fascinating story to tell.
Person2: Indeed, I do. And I must say, I'm impressed by your leadership skills. Westerburg needs someone like you.
Person1: Thank you, but I'm not sure I'm ready for that role. I've seen how it can consume people, like Heather Chandler.
Person2: Ah, yes. She was a complex person, wasn't she? But I think you have a certain... je ne sais quoi. A certain charm that could bring people together.
Person1: (laughs) You're very kind, but I think you're being overly optimistic. Besides, I'm not sure I believe in "inexpressible love" or "divine monsters" that can define us.
Person2: (smiling) Perhaps not, but I do believe that sometimes, all it takes is one moment, one kiss, to change everything. And I think we could have that moment, if you're willing to take a chance.

Person1: Dr. Lee, I've been noticing some changes in my daughter's behavior. Did you observe anything unusual during her last session?
Person2: She's always been a bit of a puzzle, but I've spent countless hours trying to understand her.
Person1: There's ten grand in here. It's yours. I'm willing to do whatever it takes to get to the bottom of this.
Person2: I'm not sure what you're insinuating, but as a professional, I can assure you that my only concern is my patient's well-being.
Person1: I'm serious. There are other kids involved, and I need your expertise to help me understand what's going on.
Person2: I'll do my best to help, but I must remind you that confidentiality is key in our profession.
Person1: I understand. Just give me something, anything, that can help me make sense of this.
Person2: Very well. I'll review her files and see if I can find any patterns or clues. But I must warn you, it may take some time.

Person1: I've seen him around, but I don't remember what he bought.
Person2: You're a wealthy businessman, Mr. Johnson. I'm surprised you can't think of anything but money.
Person1: That's the trouble with me, I suppose. But I'm trying to change.
Person2: Is this your signature on the contract, Mr. Johnson?
Person1: You know it is. What's the point of all this?

Person1: I'm not the one who suggested this meeting.
Person2: Then which one of us is trying to avoid the real issue?
Person1: Say something, anything, to convince me you're taking this seriously.
Person2: Fine. I'll start by being honest with you.

Person1: I confess, I tricked you. I just knew you were too busy to make a social call.
Person2: Hello, who is this? I wasn't expecting a call from the museum's curator.
Person1: This is Dr. Rodriguez's assistant. I'm afraid the doctor is running a bit behind schedule.
Person2: Ah, I see. I was supposed to meet him at the new exhibit, but I forgot the address. Can you remind me?
Person1: Of course! It's at the downtown gallery. You can't miss it. By the way, you look great!

Person1: I'm so glad to be back home, Grandma. Do you take sugar?
Person2: Yes, two please. I remember that Christmas dinner, when Cook made that awful plum pudding and we hid it in our pockets so we wouldn't hurt her feelings!

Person1: I've never seen a piece of equipment like this before. It's top-notch. You must be proud of your work.
Person2: Yeah, I put my heart into it. But what's the point, you know? It's not like it's going to change anything.
Person1: That's not true. This could make a real difference. And I'm not just talking about the business deal. I'm talking about the people involved.
Person2: You're right. I guess I'm just feeling a little disconnected from it all. It's hard to believe it's finally happening.
Person1: I know the feeling. But sometimes you just have to take a leap of faith. And I think this is one of those times.
Person2: You're right. I need to focus on the bigger picture. Thanks for the pep talk.

Person1: Are you getting nervous about the dinner party tonight? 
Person2: What? No, I'm fine. 
Person1: Gino Marzzone is coming, isn't he? That's a big deal. 
Person2: Yeah, he's been here twice before. 
Person1: What happened last time? 
Person2: Not much, really. I was just trying to make a good impression.

Person1: I need help. I can't carry on alone. This operation is a bad joke and I'm the punchline.
Person2: Maybe you should back off. You're not thinking clearly.
Person1: I've been thinking about Zero, how he drifts around, filling his mind with fantasies. He thinks he's real smart, laughs at us, laughs at his victims. But he has left a trail, and the trail is somewhere in those names.
Person2: I'm sorry for losing it back there, but you must remember, you have a mission to complete. Don't let emotions cloud your judgment.
Person1: I know, I know. Just say "God go with me."
Person2: God go with you, sister.

Person1: I've been traveling non-stop for months, never staying in one place for more than a night or two. Can you switch to another station? This music is driving me crazy.
Person2: I've been trying to find a solution to make my father's pain more manageable. The doctor mentioned a strong liquid morphine that could help, but I'm not sure if it's the right choice.
Person1: I understand your concern. Sometimes we have to make tough decisions to make our loved ones comfortable. But we should consider all the options carefully before making a decision.
Person2: You're right. I just want to make sure I'm doing what's best for him.

Person1: What's the catch? You're offering a partnership with zero risk?
Person2: That's right. We guarantee every load. If anything goes wrong, we make good.
Person1: And in return, you want thirty percent of the load? That's a steep price.
Person2: It's a small price to pay for reliability and timeliness. And let's be honest, it's a do or die situation for your business. If we don't deliver, you're ruined.
Person1: I don't like being backed into a corner. But I suppose it's better than having nothing to sell.
Person2: Exactly. And with our partnership, you'll have a steady supply of goods. No more worrying about lost shipments or delayed deliveries.
Person1: Alright, you've got a deal. But I'm watching you. If you're not as reliable as you claim, this partnership is over.
Person2: Fair enough. I'm confident we can deliver.

Person1: I'm your daughter. And Rachel's daughter.
Person2: Childhood is over, Emily. It's time to grow up.
Person1: No. Please. I'm not ready to leave yet.
Person2: Ain't nobody mentioned that name on this farm for 14 years. My girl was taken from me... far as I'm concerned, she's dead. Now, I ain't gonna ask you again. -- Who are you?!

Person1: I'm not sure I can do this...
Person2: I want you to stand like that until you're confident, because I don't ever want to see you doubt yourself again, you hear me?  Rachel, take her spot.
Person1: I forgot what it feels like to be part of a team...
Person2: You know, considering you've only been back for a week, you're readapting quite well.  Wait, I didn't mean that the way it sounded. I meant...
Person1: Don't worry about it, all right? I just need to focus.
Person2: Dammit, I hate sounding so critical all the time. All I meant to say was I thought you were doing well, but then I...

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you?
Person2: I like to do it. I enjoy it. But I think you're getting worked up over nothing.

Person1: I've been feeling so disconnected from the world lately...
Person2: You know, considering how much you've been through, you're holding up remarkably well. Wait, I didn't mean that the way it sounded...
Person1: Don't worry about it, all right? It's just... sometimes I feel like I'm just going through the motions.
Person2: I think that's understandable. But I've noticed you've been pushing people away. You don't have to do that.
Person1: I'm just trying to protect myself. I don't want to get hurt again.
Person2: I get that. But sometimes you need to take a chance and let people in. Otherwise, you'll be stuck in this limbo forever.

Person1: I've been thinking, what makes a team strong is when no individual stands out, right?
Person2: That's an interesting point. But don't you think it's also about effective communication?
Person1: Exactly! And that's why honesty is always the best policy, don't you agree?
Person2: Absolutely. Lying might seem effective in the short term, but it always backfires in the end.

Person1: I want to talk to you, Alex.
Person2: You got something to say? I'm right in front of you.
Person1: No, Alex. I'm the one who's been selfish and self-absorbed.
Person2: What do you want from me, exactly?
Person1: I want you to understand that I've been stuck in my grief process for too long.
Person2: Mind your own business, and let me deal with my own problems.
Person1: This is our business, Alex. We need to move forward together.
Person2: Why don't you go and focus on yourself for a change?
Person1: I'm trying to, Alex. But I need your help.
Person2: Fine. What do you need from me?

Person1: I'm a big believer in talkin', case you ain't noticed.
Person2: Whoever tossed this place wants you. And I'm looking to stay outta the line of fire.
Person1: Talkin's good. Long as you got the other? You think I'm crazy, but I've got a feeling about this.
Person2: How's this about me? I didn't do anything special, just got caught up in the wrong crowd.
Person1: Too bad they don't give an award for instincts... You'd win first prize. Especially with your sharp mind.
Person2: I like gettin' to the bottom of things, but this time I'm not so sure. It's like I'm stuck in a dream, and I can't wake up.
Person1: What's this dream about? Maybe I can help you figure it out.
Person2: It's just a feeling of being watched, all the time. And I don't know who's behind it.

Person1: Now do you want the good news first or the bad news?
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: May I speak frankly, Mrs. Rodriguez?
Person2: You may if you can, Mr. Thompson.
Person1: Well, that little incident at the warehouse, it's going to cost us a lot of money. Maybe they're trying to get back at us.
Person2: Suppose they are. How does it concern you?
Person1: Nothing personal, Mrs. Rodriguez, I just want to get to the bottom of it. Look at it this way. Now this whole mess, it says someone's trying to sabotage us. Whoever did it didn't have anything against me. They were out to get your company.
Person2: It's very personal. It couldn't be more personal. Is this a business or an obsession with you?
Person1: I'd advise you to shut up and let me finish, Mrs. Rodriguez. You needn't worry about the insurance because they're not going to pay. Save for one option.

Person1: What's the hurry?
Person2: You'll probably be safe enough on your own --
Person1: Others are waiting.
Person2: I doubt it.

Person1: I need to work. I need to make my living.
Person2: Forget it. You're not going to get that job.
Person1: Why not? I'm qualified.
Person2: You're not a one-of-a-kind, rare butterfly. You're just another applicant.
Person1: That's not fair. I have skills.
Person2: Skills, schmills. You need to have connections.
Person1: Then why did you tell me to apply in the first place?
Person2: I didn't. You just assumed I did. You need counseling.

Person1: Did you ever think that's possible?
Person2: I knew it!
Person1: But it's a long shot.
Person2: Why?
Person1: Because the odds are against us, and even if we succeed, it might not be what we expected.
Person2: So what's the point of trying?
Person1: That's a good question. Maybe we should just focus on the present.

Person1: I know why you're hesitant to invest in "Mr. Loverboy". But before you make a decision, let me ask you, are you positive that "Freaks" is the better choice?
Person2: It's a different kind of film, I can see that. But I'm not convinced that switching our investment would be the right move.
Person1: I understand your concerns, but sometimes you have to take a chance on something new. Lot of things can happen when you take a risk. You might be surprised at the outcome.

Person1: I decided to help out at the local animal shelter.
Person2: See you brought one of the dogs with you too.
Person1: What'd the trainer say about its behavior?
Person2: He said if I didn't socialize it properly, it'll never trust humans.
Person1: I wouldn't take that too seriously. It's just a puppy.
Person2: I believe what he said. It's already shown signs of fear aggression.
Person1: They're only trying to prepare you, that's all.
Person2: How do you know what they're doing? You're not a trainer.
Person1: I don't, but as long as they think you're committed to helping, they'll support you.
Person2: You mustn't let what he said bother you. It was only advice.
Person1: Go talk to the trainer again, I'll come with you.
Person2: Don't put yourself out.
Person1: Hey, I'm on your side. Remember that.
Person2: Yes, I'll remember. Thanks for the help.

Person1: I won't lose you.
Person2: What do you want from me? I'm putting everything on the line for you.
Person1: If I find out you're not telling me the truth, you'll know that I loved you and wanted to go on loving you.
Person2: Jiminy Christmas, what's gotten into you? Go to my sister's place on the coast, tell her I'm okay and to sit tight.

Person1: Do you remember that guy? People love that guy.
Person2: I don't remember. Is that what you wanted to ask me?
Person1: Oh yeah? How exciting. What's it called?
Person2: My new art exhibition. It's called "Northern Lights".
Person1: And don't forget, it's opening tonight. If they want to talk about the inspiration, we're talking about the inspiration.
Person2: If anyone asks about my creative process, I'm leaving. I am not discussing that!

Person1: What do you think about when you're alone?
Person2: You know better than to ask that.
Person1: I mean, do you think about the past or the future?
Person2: Nothing. I do remember the city streets... I told you... I remember the sounds... I think about that sometimes...
Person1: How do you remember how to navigate through the crowds?
Person2: Well, rest easy, it's just instinct.

Person1: I'm thinking about how we can improve our team's performance. We look pretty lousy out there, right?
Person2: Hey, we all have bad days. It's part of the learning process.
Person1: I just wanted to make a good impression on my first big game. I feel so foolish about those mistakes.
Person2: Understandable, but remember, nobody is perfect. We'll work on our strategy and move forward.
Person1: Thanks for the reassurance. I'll focus on my training next time.

Person1: I've never known him to say those words before.
Person2: Hey, don't worry, kid. If she's innocent, she'll be fine.
Person1: That's not his style. One thing I can say about him, he always speaks the truth.
Person2: I got it. But listen, she came to me to figure it out. She's not the one who's responsible.

Person1: I'm so tired of your condescending attitude.
Person2: Ah, the bitter sweetness of our love! It's a divine monster that can only be defined by paradoxes.
Person1: What's that supposed to mean? You're just trying to confuse me.
Person2: Not at all, my dear. I'm simply stating the complexity of our emotions. But tell me, why do you think I'm doing this?
Person1: You're doing it because you don't care about me. You're just using me for your own amusement.
Person2: That's not true. I care about you deeply. But I also know that our love is a game of push and pull. And right now, I'm just trying to find my balance.
Person1: Well, I need some space. Just let me sit down and think for a moment.
Person2: Of course, my love. Take all the time you need. But know that I'll be here, waiting for you, with a thousand kisses for that heavenly mouth of yours.

Person1: You know, if I take this job, I'll just be another employee you'll forget about soon.
Person2: Stranger? You're not a stranger to me. I've seen your work from Boston to San Francisco. Those were beautiful, golden days.
Person1: But I only came to decline the offer.
Person2: The offer? We'll have no more nonsense about the offer.

Person1: I've seen her around here before.
Person2: Why do you think I keep her away from the others?
Person1: I don't remember exactly, but I think it's because she's a threat to our community.
Person2: Ah, but that's where you're wrong. It's her isolation that makes her a target. The longer she's away, the more they'll talk. And who can promise security against gossip? Even here.

Person1: What's the situation, General? Can a single aircraft penetrate the entire enemy Air Defense when its course and target are known?
Person2: I've got to be honest with you, sir. If the pilot is really sharp, he can barrel that plane along so low... it's a sight to behold. He has one hell of a chance.
Person1: You're crazy, General. That's a huge risk.
Person2: Pull up alongside, let's take a closer look. I've got to get on there.

Person1: Honestly, do you actually think I would forget to invite you to the party?
Person2: Now, don't get alarmed. I just want to rule out some things.
Person1: Like what? You're being really vague.
Person2: I don't know, maybe you're just being really careless. I mean, besides me, does anyone else know where the spare key is?
Person1: Sometimes we have to improvise. And yes, James knows where it is.
Person2: Think, Rachel. Does James have any friends who might, I don't know... borrow the key without asking?
Person1: James? My James? What's happened to him?
Person2: Nothing, he's just been sort of... unreachable lately.
Person1: Unreachable? By who? His parents?
Person2: No, no, it's not that. I just think he might be avoiding us.
Person1: Good God. Let's go talk to him.

Person1: I feel like a man again. You know I love the Opera.
Person2: That's not true. You don't remember me, do you? You said you'd meet me at the park, but you never showed up.
Person1: For what? I don't know. For your beautiful smile. For... I feel like I've been to the Opera with you before.
Person2: Can you hang on a second? I need to clarify something.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this proposal. You're not going to hurt me, are you, Mr.?
Person2: Dr. Elliot Thompson. And no, I'm here to help. I've been working on a project to revitalize the city's water supply.
Person1: A research grant? A new facility?
Person2: Actually, I've been trying to get in touch with you, Mr. Wayne. I believe our goals align.
Person1: I'm listening. What do you propose?
Person2: Shall I begin by explaining the benefits of this new system? It could greatly reduce the city's pollution.
Person1: I'm intrigued. Go on.

Person1: Do you take sugar?
Person2: Yes, two please. I'm sorry, I didn't mean to pry, it's just that I really loved your roast.
Person1: Oh, thank you! I was worried the cheese would be troublesome.
Person2: Worse than your Kraft Holiday dip?
Person1: Ha! No, not that bad. But I do hope the plates aren't radioactive by tomorrow morning.
Person2: Yeah, yeah. Okay. Give me the book and watch your step. I'll come back for the coffee.

Person1: Hey, I've been thinking about your problem. I'm not the guy to sponsor you. It would be unethical.
Person2: What's the alternative?
Person1: Well, I could teach you how to play putt-putt golf. It's a great way to relax.
Person2: Putt-putt golf? You think that's going to solve my problem?
Person1: No, but it might help you clear your head. And who knows, you might meet someone interesting there.
Person2: Yeah, like a prince?
Person1: (laughs) Maybe not a prince, but someone nice. You never know.
Person2: Alright, why not? I've got nothing to lose.

Person1: You want to work with me?
Person2: I'll work with anyone, anytime. I know I can't be choosy.
Person1: Don't.
Person2: Anybody ever done that to you before?
Person1: No, I'm clean. Real clean. As clean as my conscience.
Person2: Positive?
Person1: Yes. I've got a clean record, no criminal history.
Person2: Age?
Person1: Twenty-six.
Person2: Education?
Person1: Some. Here and there.
Person2: Military record?
Person1: Honorable discharge. May 1971.
Person2: You moonlighting?
Person1: No, I want long shifts.
Person2: We hire a lot of people here. Fill out these forms and give them to the girl at the desk, and leave your phone number. You got a phone?
Person1: No.
Person2: Well then check back tomorrow.

Person1: Hey, I've been thinking... everything is a miracle, don't you think?
Person2: I'm not sure what you mean by that. But I do know I can't control myself around you.
Person1: Yeah? Well, I've been trying to find someone special, but it's kind of ridiculous, don't you think?
Person2: Maybe. But I'm willing to help you, not because you're trying to buy me off, but because I care about you.
Person1: Thanks, I appreciate that. You're a true friend. But I have to ask, do you want to get involved with me, or is it just a tendency of yours?
Person2: Honestly, I'm not sure. But I do know I shouldn't get too close.

Person1: I'm starvin' to death. Are you hungry too?
Person2: You're right. Only you can do that.
Person1: Do what? I just need some food and a drink. There's a party store down 54th, can you grab a six-pack of something imported?
Person2: I don't think so. You're not just hungry, you're searching for something more.
Person1: What are you talking about? I just want a beer and a snack.
Person2: Fine, but if you're making a beer run, would you mind too terribly if you did a foot run as well?

Person1: You're really terrific, you know what I mean?
Person2: Shall I begin?
Person1: Wrong. I think we should start with something else.
Person2: Say something dear.

Person1: What d'you want?
Person2: I'm impressed. Really. I would have bet good money you wouldn't show up.
Person1: What's that supposed to mean?
Person2: Makes two of us. I've been waiting for this moment for weeks.
Person1: You're not making any sense. Why did you invite me here?
Person2: Oh, I don't know. Maybe I just wanted to see if you'd take the bait.
Person1: Well, I'm here. Now what?
Person2: Now nothing. I think I've made a mistake. Maybe you should just go.
Person1: Fine. I'm leaving. But this was a weird encounter.

Person1: Tell them who I am! I'm the new team leader, and I won't be ignored!
Person2: I'm sorry, Rachel. I didn't mean to undermine your authority. I thought it would be a nice surprise to introduce you to the team.
Person1: But given our recent disagreements, you always do things without considering how they'll make me feel. You need to be more considerate and communicative.
Person2: I understand, and I apologize. From now on, I'll make sure to keep you in the loop and respect your leadership.

Person1: I'm telling you, I found it on the floor of the cab. I don't know what it is or what it's for.
Person2: You're not thinking clearly, sister. You need to focus on the bigger picture. What were you doing in that cab in the first place?
Person1: I don't remember. It was a few months ago. I was going somewhere, but I don't know where.
Person2: You're not taking this seriously enough. If you can't remember, then maybe you should try to figure it out. We can't afford to have you wandering around without a clear head.
Person1: I'll try, I'll try. But I need your help. You have to guide me.
Person2: I'll guide you, but you need to trust me. And you need to trust yourself. Now, let's start again. What's the first thing you remember about that cab ride?

Person1: You're not such a bargain, you know, conceited and thoughtless and messy-
Person2: Lying is always a very effective dating tool.
Person1: What? No, I'm serious. You're a setup for some gorgeous wide-eyed young babe.
Person2: Okay, thank you for the advice.
Person1: I don't want to be childish, I'd settle for just a few years-
Person2: You're right, I should focus on being genuine.
Person1: Am I going to lose you? Am I?
Person2: Of course not, I appreciate your honesty.

Person1: I'm sick of talking about the company's financial struggles. Let's talk about you.
Person2: Not like this. Are you even listening? We're on the verge of bankruptcy if we don't secure this investment deal.
Person1: Jeez, I'm... I didn't realize it was that bad. Well, lucky for us I have friends like Rachel who can help us navigate this crisis.
Person2: Look, I appreciate your optimism, but we need a solid plan, not just relying on friends.

Person1: I want to go home.
Person2: You don't have to do this. What are you sorry for?
Person1: I don't know. For not being able to show you a good time, I guess.
Person2: Please don't cry. Please, honey. It's not about that.
Person1: I feel like crawling back in, back to where I was before I met you.
Person2: You can't. We've come too far.

Person1: I need your help. We're looking for him. In your opinion, why did he do it?
Person2: He became obsessed with her. She hated him. He had to have her.
Person1: Is that what you want? To understand why he did it?
Person2: Yeah. I guess I do. What's going to happen to him?
Person1: We're going to leave that up to Detective Williams. I'll tell you though, you're okay. You're trying to make sense of it.
Person2: Yeah. I sure know that. Yeah, but how many more are out there like him?
Person1: Don't worry about it. Nobody'll mess with ya anymore. I'll take care of ya.
Person2: Thank you. Yeah, yeah, yeah.

Person1: I'm impressed by your skills, you're a natural with those instruments. You were a lot of help with that music project.
Person2: Thanks, I'd hoped to leave my past life behind. But it's hard to shake off old habits.
Person1: You know, you're lucky to have found a new passion. Most people struggle to find their calling. Switch to another piece, huh? You're driving me crazy with that same melody.
Person2: I've been experimenting with different styles, but I think I've found my niche. I used to play for my friends in the army, it was a great way to unwind.
Person1: Mind if I ask you something? Why'd you decide to pursue music instead of staying in the army?

Person1: Forget it. We're not getting in with what we have.
Person2: Waitaminit, I got it! We find a way to upgrade our tickets. What do you think?
Person1: Brilliance, Alex. Sheer brilliance. But how do you plan on doing that?

Person1: I'm your partner, Rachel. We're in this together, aren't we?
Person2: Ain't nobody mentioned that name in this company for years. My business partner was taken from me... far as I'm concerned, they're dead. Now, I ain't gonna ask you again. -- Who are you?!
Person1: I'm the one who's been trying to protect you, Rachel. It's not about me. I need my space sometimes. That doesn't mean I'm leaving you for good.
Person2: Rachel. Damn right, partner. And don't you forget it. We face challenges as a team, but sometimes I need to recharge on my own.

Person1: You think you're queer...?
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: I mean, we're all queer in our own ways. You told me about your high school days, remember?
Person2: No, I don't think so. You must be confusing me with someone else.
Person1: Oh, really? Then how do you know about the smell of train compartments?
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: You're not befuddled by a middle-class morality, are you? You seem like someone who can live with their choices.
Person2: I'm just trying to understand what you're getting at.

Person1: I'm on the move - heading to the highest point from where I am.
Person2: Your friend is waiting for you. Don't be late, or we'll have a problem.
Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: Honestly? I want to make sure you understand the gravity of the situation. Love can be a killer, isn't it?
Person1: What's that supposed to mean?
Person2: Just meet me at the top of Bitker ladder. We'll discuss it then.

Person1: I've been searching for that rare book everywhere. I'll need it now.
Person2: Don't even try to read it. You won't understand its significance anyway.

Person1: Did you hear about the accident on the highway?
Person2: Yes, it happened on the twenty third of January. I was needed at the scene to help with the rescue efforts.
Person1: Was anyone seriously hurt?
Person2: Unfortunately, one of the drivers didn't make it. I don't remember where the paramedics were, but I was focused on getting the survivors to safety.

Person1: I know this is your studio and all, but do you think you could keep it down? I'm trying to paint.
Person2: Then we will both create art, my friend. But not to create... is treason against my soul.
Person1: You're quite the romantic, aren't you?
Person2: I've read The Fountainhead. Howard Roark's passion inspires me.
Person1: Ah, The Fountainhead. I've always been fascinated by Dominique Francon's character.
Person2: Yes, her complexity is captivating. But I think we can create something even more beautiful together. Why don't you join me for a life drawing session and we'll discuss art?
Person1: At this hour? I don't think so.
Person2: Oh come on. Quit acting like a critic and let's create something new.

Person1: Talk to me, I need to know what's going on.
Person2: We're in trouble, I can feel it. Just shut up and listen to me for once.
Person1: Hey, calm down. I'm trying to help you.
Person2: You're not helping, you're making it worse. Just let me think for a second.

Person1: You're terrible.
Person2: Don't you see, Rachel? I was waiting for the right moment to tell you that.
Person1: Stay away from me! You even cooked up that business trip.
Person2: It might have worked. Really. I would have been delighted for you if it had. But she wasn't interested. Not my fault.
Person1: I've known Rachel for more than ten years. We're old allies.
Person2: My God. You're still trying to justify yourself.

Person1: So, what do you think? Of course, I'll help out!
Person2: Great, I'll send you the details. You'll be contacted with the assignment.
Person1: My mom can't know about this. She'd worry too much.
Person2: Okay, got it. Just remember, you have to appear normal, like nothing's changed.
Person1: Yeah, I can do that. What's the plan, anyway?
Person2: You'll figure it out as you go. And by the way, do you want onions on your sandwich?
Person1: Uh, yeah. And green peppers too.
Person2: Okay. So, what are you majoring in?
Person1: Business, I think. And maybe I'll walk onto the lacrosse team.
Person2: That's cool. I'm still undecided, to be honest.
Person1: Yeah, I know the feeling. It's like, what am I gonna do with my life, right?
Person2: Exactly! People always ask, and I'm like, "Uh, I don't know..."

Person1: Do you mind stepping inside, while I look for it?
Person2: He lavished affection on her, there was no doubt about that. Life was very different with madame Claudia, as you can imagine...
Person1: Perhaps. He knew me. He knew I would love her more than the waking world.
Person2: Thanks.

Person1: You were a monkey, always getting into trouble.
Person2: I don't think so. I was just curious.
Person1: You don't. Think so.
Person2: I'm telling you, I was careful. I didn't mean to cause any problems.
Person1: You didn't mean to. But you did.

Person1: Do you always cook like this?
Person2: For a price.
Person1: Good God, that's steep.
Person2: Yes.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a matter of principle. We can't just sweep this under the rug.
Person2: Oh, darling, you're so passionate about this. It's almost as if you're trying to convince yourself more than me.
Person1: What's that supposed to mean? You think I'm not committed to this cause?
Person2: Of course you are, my love. But sometimes, in the heat of the moment, we forget to consider the consequences. We must think about what this could do to our community, to our friends and family.
Person1: You're right, as always. I just get so caught up in the emotion of it all. But I promise you, I'll try to approach this with a clearer head from now on.

Person1: I'm thinking of working with animals.
Person2: Paid a guy to get me out of the program this morning. And tonight I'm a free man.
Person1: An evil animal trainer? 
Person2: Do what? 
Person1: You always do that! I'm trying to figure out what kind of job I can get with my skills.
Person2: How'd you know I'd help you?

Person1: Did you finish your project?
Person2: And I'm anxious to get started on the next one. What's the main challenge we're facing here?
Person1: It's mostly a lack of resources, but I believe that with determination and hard work, we can overcome it.
Person2: Conviction is key, isn't it? I'm convinced we can make a difference.
Person1: I appreciate your enthusiasm, but we need to be realistic about our limitations.
Person2: I understand, but I'm not leaving until we've explored all our options.

Person1: I've seen him around here before.
Person2: What's his story? Do you think he's trustworthy?
Person1: I don't know, we get a lot of people in here. But I really like you, and if this place weren't so busy...
Person2: Yeah, then maybe we could get to know each other better. But I think we should focus on finding out what he's looking for.
Person1: So, what do you think he's after?
Person2: Could it have been this?

Person1: Do you take sugar?
Person2: Yes, two please. You're so smart and fun, I really loved our conversation.
Person1: Oh, thanks. You're not so bad yourself.

Person1: Hey, I was just telling everyone about how I was going to bring this girl for you to meet.
Person2: Do you think I'd get along with her, Dr. Thompson?
Person1: Definitely. I think you two would really hit it off.

Person1: I know I should stay away. I know I have a tendency to get too comfortable, and...
Person2: You mean I can count on you?

Person1: What's going on? You seem to know a lot about this place.
Person2: There's a rumor going around, maybe you've heard it. I've got to get to the bottom of it.
Person1: You're really invested in this, aren't you?

Person1: I've been looking all over for Alex. His sister said I'd find him here.
Person2: He's not at home?
Person1: No, they said he was here... studying for his exam.
Person2: What's taking him so long?! He was supposed to meet me three hours ago!
Person1: Shall I begin by asking him about the project? He's right here.
Person2: No, I'll talk to him. Say something, Alex.
Person1: Why did you say he might be avoiding me? Did he say anything to you about me?
Person2: Yeah, he thinks you're a bit too competitive.
Person1: Did he say that?
Person2: Look, what do you expect? Considering how we met him.
Person1: What do you mean?
Person2: On that group project last semester.

Person1: We can at least try to reason with them -- we might be able to find a compromise.
Person2: I don't think that's a good idea. It'll go worse for us if we show any weakness.
Person1: That's a prestigious award, which is given only when there's a worthy recipient.
Person2: Yeah, yeah. So what's the story behind it?
Person1: Mr. Lebowski was recognized for his civic contributions, and this picture was taken when he met the first lady.
Person2: He's quite the achiever, isn't he?
Person1: Yes, he is. And he's committed to helping inner-city children get a better education.
Person2: That's admirable. I'm sure he's made a real difference in their lives.
Person1: He has. And I think we could learn from his example.
Person2: Maybe. But sometimes you have to stand up for yourself, even if it means fighting for what you believe in.

Person1: I wish I were a nice guy with the conscience of a forgetful person. Next best thing to no memory at all.
Person2: You're forgetting the check for your suitcase. It's at the Grand Central.
Person1: Oh, yes -- yes -- that's right -- I'm going to give her a wedding present. Thought I'd better do it now, before I forget it.
Person2: Maybe Miss Wolf has the bonds.
Person1: Bonds, sir? I know I left them there.
Person2: We can see each other, we can even have dinner... but respectably, in my house with my mother's picture on the mantel and my sister helping me broil a big steak for three!
Person1: And besides, when you say I make careless excuses, you make me out a scatterbrain.
Person2: You couldn't be a scatterbrain if you tried.

Person1: I think you're it! I don't know why, I think you're it. Take me to the city of Pasadena with you.
Person2: That's the key to the city, which I was given two years ago in recognition of my various civic achievements.
Person1: You'll get to be the champ. They'll all want you, all the girls! But I don't care. I've been undersea a long time.
Person2: I've committed to sending all of the Little Urban Achievers to college. Would you like to be one of them?
Person1: How do I know it's true? You'll get to be the champ. They'll all want you, all the girls!
Person2: I already have taken you under my wing. You're one of us now.
Person1: It's been a mysterious world for me! But I think you're it!
Person2: And in fact, we met privately with the President, though unfortunately there wasn't time for a photo opportunity.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's perfect. No one will ever suspect me. I have proof.
Person2: Hi, uh, I'm looking for Enid. Her stepmother told me I'd find her here?
Person1: Please, don't do this. You're not thinking clearly.
Person2: What do you mean? I just want to talk to Enid.
Person1: You're not listening to me. I'm trying to explain that I'm the victim here.
Person2: Victim? What are you talking about? I just want to know where Enid is.
Person1: Fine, don't believe me. But I'm warning you, you're making a big mistake.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about, but I'm not leaving until I find Enid.

Person1: I know it's you, Alex. I'm not going to talk to you unless we can discuss it...
Person2: You're in danger. All of you. I have no time to explain.
Person1: Wait a minute -- Who's behind this?
Person2: I'm sorry. I have to go.

Person1: So, you're going to look for a new job?
Person2: Yeah, well my current boss wanted me to take on more responsibilities. I didn't want to write all those extra reports they make you do -- I mean, how am I supposed to know what my "most significant contribution" was? So when I got a call from a recruiter, I said the hell with it.
Person1: At least you knew about the job opening.
Person2: Yes. And you knew I'd be looking for a change.
Person1: And now that I've shown you that I know that much, and can guess more -- will you trust me to help you with the interview?
Person2: I want you to help me.
Person1: Well, I mean, getting a new job is okay, but what am I going to be, a career coach? I really have no idea.
Person2: Oh thank God, I thought I was the only one.
Person1: You know, people are always like, "What's your five-year plan?" And I don't know. And they're like, "You'll figure it out." Yeah? When?
Person2: I know. Do you want to grab a coffee and discuss the job description?
Person1: Sure.

Person1: Your pain runs deep.
Person2: It was nothing.
Person1: Let's try to understand it together. Maybe we can find a way to move forward.
Person2: Okay.

Person1: I'm thinking of having a small gathering. What do you think?
Person2: It's refreshing to see you taking charge. Will you have friends or family saying a few words?
Person1: Do I need a sponsor for that?
Person2: It's not a question of needing to, it's an entirely personal decision. Some do, some don't.
Person1: Okay, I think I'll keep it simple then.
Person2: Mm... okay. I'll support you either way.

Person1: I've waited a long time for this chance to start anew, and you're not going to stop me now. If I have to, I'll do it alone.
Person2: I'm married, Emma. Me. I can't believe it. Can you believe I'm married, Emma?
Person1: Do you mean to tell me you want to stay in this stagnant life? I'll die if I have to stay here another minute!
Person2: You're a lucky woman, Emma. You deserve a fresh start.
Person1: I thought the people around here had instructions from the community leader not to help anyone. But I gave them more support. I've been working hard for a year. I'd do anything to get out of this place.
Person2: The community leader? Who pays any attention to him? The people around here want to know how much they can grow. Well, I've been helping them grow. I've been sharing my knowledge with them.
Person1: Look at me, do I look like someone who's given up? Is this the face of someone who's lost hope? Look into my eyes and see if these are the eyes of someone who's surrendered?

Person1: I'm not the one who chose this.
Person2: A few days... a few weeks - dunno, I can't remember. Worse thing is, I never know if it will change back again.
Person1: That's not an answer. You're avoiding the question.
Person2: Maybe I am. Maybe I just need some time to figure things out. Now, please leave me alone.

Person1: I'm taking a huge risk, you know that? Someone's causing trouble in this town.
Person2: Yeah, I know. It's exhilarating!
Person1: One of the reasons I trust you, Alex, is that you're not afraid to take a stand. Please don't do anything reckless tonight, okay? Just focus on the task at hand.
Person2: Got it. And what's the plan for after this?
Person1: We'll figure it out later. Just save the most important part for last.

Person1: I'm not going to the party tonight.
Person2: What? You're just going to sit there?
Person1: Yeah, I'm not in the mood.
Person2: You're not going to let me drive to Vanderbilt for you, are you?
Person1: What's that supposed to mean?
Person2: It means you're not willing to make an effort for something you want.
Person1: That's not fair. I'm just not feeling up to it tonight.
Person2: Fine, hope no one hits on you at the party without me.
Person1: I hope they do.

Person1: Then who the heck are you?
Person2: I'm the one who's been feeling something for you, something I've never felt before. My future is with you.

Person1: So...
Person2: What?!
Person1: When you're ready to let go, to be unsingle and unmiserable, you will. Until then...
Person2: I'm sorry. I've been a selfish shit and I'm sorry.
Person1: No, I'm the one who's been selfish and self-absorbed with all of my post-traumatic stress.
Person2: You lost your mom...
Person1: But you're right -- enough is enough. I can't wallow in the grief process forever and I can't keep lying to myself about who my mom was.

Person1: I've got to take your picture.
Person2: Oh, cut it out, will ya? I'm not exactly photogenic.
Person1: But you're stunning... your smile lights up the room.
Person2: Charlie, twenty- eight bucks is nothing. The only way to do it is through your uncle... think about it, will you?
Person1: NO!!! What do you think I am, crazy??? I just want to capture your beauty.
Person2: No, I just want to help myself, that's all. Stop staring and take a shot of that vase instead.
Person1: But your eyes... they sparkle like diamonds. You're a work of art.
Person2: All right, cut me a break.

Person1: You're really crazy about this idea, aren't you?
Person2: You know better than that. I'm not going to let my emotions cloud my judgment.
Person1: We don't know of any other way to approach this problem...
Person2: Then why do you seem so uncertain?
Person1: It's not often that someone like you takes a risk like this.
Person2: Well, rest easy, I've thought this through.

Person1: What's that?
Person2: No, Dad. I've never seen it before.
Person1: Are you sure? You're usually so curious about these things.
Person2: Yes, I'm positive. Good night, I'm tired.

Person1: I need you to focus. We'll start with your most recent memories and go backwards.
Person2: I got it. But listen, I didn't know what was on it. I mean, I came to you to figure it out.
Person1: Well, technically, the procedure itself is a bit of a risk, but nothing you'll miss. Like a night of heavy drinking.
Person2: Hey, don't worry. If I'm innocent, I'll be fine. Right?

Person1: You're not who you claim to be.
Person2: Don't you remember the incident at the Goliath, Rachel?
Person1: Stay away from me! I know what you're capable of.

Person1: I've been thinking, we should reorganize the storage room. It's a mess.
Person2: How about showing me your approach? I'm curious to see how you'd do it.
Person1: Well, first, we need to clear everything out and start from scratch. Then, we can categorize items by type and assign a specific shelf for each category. And, of course, we should label everything clearly.
Person2: That makes sense. But what about the items that don't fit into a specific category?
Person1: Ah, good point. We can create a miscellaneous section for those. And, just to be thorough, let's double-check each item to make sure it's in working order before we put it away.
Person2: You're being very meticulous. I like that.

Person1: Hey, I'm thinking of skipping the school trip to the museum. It's not really my thing.
Person2: Oh, come on! It'll be fun, I promise. You can't sleep through it, okay?

Person1: You could save him, little bird.
Person2: Shut up! You're not making any sense!

Person1: I'm sorry, Professor, if I...spoke out of turn. It's just that...I don't think I can control myself around you.
Person2: Listen, Alex. I am the only one who can help you around here, and one of the people who's going to be helping you from now on is yourself. Now you've been struggling with this issue for long enough! All that's gonna change, young man.
Person2: Tonight, we'll start with a session in my office and progress on from there...to various other forms of therapy.

Person1: Captain, I've got to get on there.
Person2: What is it, Ensign? 
Person1: I just wanted to say thanks for the training. It's been the best experience I've had so far.
Person2: Well, it's not really my job to please. Hope you learned something.
Person1: I want to take on more responsibilities, Captain. I think I have what it takes.
Person2: Figuring things out for yourself is the only freedom anyone really has. Use that freedom. Make your own choice, Ensign.
Person1: But what would you do if you were me, Captain?
Person2: Pull up alongside and let's get a better look.

Person1: I've known you for more than five years, Rachel. We're old allies.
Person2: You're the only person in this place who can see right through me.
Person1: And I have to say, you've made us look pretty good in the past week. The way you handled the press was impressive.
Person2: Just following your example. But something happened, and I realized I don't want to be stuck in a desk job.
Person1: I understand. I had doubts about your ability to stick with it too. But I think you'd be surprised at how much you can grow in that role.
Person2: Maybe. But I need to think about what's best for me, not just what looks good on paper.
Person1: Fair enough. Just remember, I'm here to support you, no matter what you decide.

Person1: Are you crazy, a rescue team?! We're not stranded, we're lost!
Person2: He's completely out of his mind. We need to get him medical attention ASAP.
Person1: Great. Is that what you're going to say when we find our way back to civilization?
Person2: No. When we get back, I'll say we were all disoriented and exhibited classic symptoms of exhaustion, dehydration, and exposure. And he doesn't sleep.
Person1: Doesn't sleep? That's not going to help our case.
Person2: Insomnia. Not unusual for someone in his situation. We need to focus on getting him help, not assigning blame.

Person1: What's the plan here?
Person2: Let's do it here. I'm the event coordinator!

Person1: I'm telling you, I saw it with my own eyes. There was a guy shooting from behind that fence.
Person2: Son, I think you're just practicing what you've been told. It's like playing tennis against a wall. You're just rehearsing for when the real questions come.
Person1: What do you mean? I know what I saw.
Person2: I'm sure you do, but sometimes our memories can play tricks on us. It's okay to question what we think we know.
Person1: But I'm not questioning it. I'm telling you what happened.
Person2: I understand that, but sometimes it's good to take a step back and look at things from a different perspective. You don't have to be so certain all the time.
Person1: I guess you're right. It's just that it all felt so real.
Person2: I'm sure it did, son. And that's okay. Just remember, it's okay to be unsure sometimes.

Person1: I'm afraid so; he's an idealist. You'll have to be politic.
Person2: Oh, why couldn't I be in charge of something simpler? If the council gets the three sections of the ancient treaty and the instructions for the new policy--
Person1: Do you know how I define "idealism," Monsieur? It's when someone thinks they can change the world without getting their hands dirty.
Person2: I'm sorry for losing my temper back there, but you must remember, you have a responsibility to the people as well as to the council.
Person1: I know, I know, just say "good luck to me."
Person2: Good luck to you, then.

Person1: You're no bargain either, pal. What's with the sloppy work? You're holding up the whole production!
Person2: Oh, all right... I'll try to do better. But can I ask, what's the big deal about this rehearsal? It's not like it's the final show.

Person1: What do you think is the key to your success?
Person2: I love people. All people. Even people that no one else loves, I think they're OK, you know.
Person1: That's great. I've heard you're involved in some civic activities. Can you tell me more about that?
Person2: Yeah, I've got a few awards for my work. Like this one from the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce.
Person1: Impressive. And I see you've met some important people, like Nancy Reagan.
Person2: Yeah, she's a wonderful woman. I've also got some kids I'm helping out, the Little Urban Achievers.
Person1: That's very kind of you. But don't you think you have any weaknesses?
Person2: Well, yes. I have to admit it. Sometimes I can be a bit too trusting of people.
Person1: I see. Well, it's been great talking to you.

Person1: You're not gonna let them get to you, are you? You're not freaked out by the cool kids anymore?
Person2: Desperately, I want to prove myself. I want the credit for my work.
Person1: That's the spirit! You can't let them take that away from you.
Person2: I know the deal, but I'm not gonna let two people from the industry take advantage of me.
Person1: You're better than that. You're not gonna quit, are you?
Person2: Watch me. I'll show them what I'm capable of.

Person1: Can I get you a drink while you're waiting?
Person2: Trust takes time to rebuild. Be patient.
Person1: I'm just trying to make it up to you. I didn't mean to inconvenience you.
Person2: I know, but it's not about the drink. It's about the actions that follow.

Person1: I'm your daughter. And Sarah's daughter.
Person2: So... I'm sorry. I've been a selfish parent and I'm sorry.
Person1: No, Mom. I'm the one who's been selfish, always blaming you for Dad's death.
Person2: You lost your father...
Person1: But you're right -- enough is enough. I can't keep lying to myself about who Dad was.

Person1: You believe that I love you?
Person2: What do you know of my pain?
Person1: And if you lose me, you'll know that I loved you and wanted to go on loving you.
Person2: Let us explore it together.

Person1: I need a new map. Where's the atlas?
Person2: It takes years to learn navigation. And years to master it...Now go to the library, it's open late.
Person1: Thank you. Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Person2: Is that what you want?

Person1: I'm trying to make amends, but you make me out to be a villain.
Person2: You're not a villain, but you're not as innocent as you claim.
Person1: I wish I could be more like you, with a clear conscience and no regrets.
Person2: I have to go, but we can catch up soon.
Person1: Can I take you out for lunch, in public, as friends?
Person2: That sounds nice, but let's keep it low-key for now.
Person1: And after lunch, can we take a walk and clear the air?
Person2: Maybe, but let's not get ahead of ourselves.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a setup. They're trying to frame me.
Person2: Hey, just shut up and listen to me for once.
Person1: I've been investigating some shady dealings, and I think I've stumbled upon something big.
Person2: We're in over our heads. We need to get out of here before it's too late.
Person1: I'm not going anywhere until I get to the bottom of this. You can leave if you want, but I'm staying.
Person2: Fine, but don't say I didn't warn you.

Person1: Oh, come on, will ya? You're being irresponsible with our business.
Person2: Don't be over-dramatic, we can't let fear hold us back. What's the worst that could happen?
Person1: NO!!! You're not thinking about the consequences. We can't just rush into this without a plan.
Person2: I'm trying to help, but you're not listening.

Person1: I don't remember you.
Person2: What gave you that idea?
Person1: You stood me up that night, and I was rather hurt.
Person2: I don't blame you. It was unforgivable.
Person1: I forgive you. You did the only decent thing.
Person2: Don't be too sure. Just because I'm new around here, that doesn't make me innocent.
Person1: One doesn't get to be a regular around here unless he's a pretty good judge of character  and as far as I'm concerned, you're tops. Cheers.
Person2: Cheers.

Person1: Honestly, do you actually think I would forget my own birthday?
Person2: Gee, I don't know, Alex. I don't seem to remember you actually asking me if you could invite 50 people over to celebrate.
Person1: Sometimes we have to improvise. And I did invite you, didn't I?
Person2: Think, Alex. Does your father have any friends? I mean, besides me and your mom?
Person1: My father? What's happened to him?
Person2: Nothing, he's just been sort of... overwhelmed.
Person1: Overwhelmed? By who? The party guests?
Person2: No, by his own expectations. He wanted to make this birthday special.
Person1: Good God. Let's go talk to him then.
Person2: Good idea, Alex. Only one problem. I don't know what to say to him.
Person1: Ah. Wait a minute. Maybe we can get some advice from Dr. Lee.
Person2: The psychologist? Maybe... I don't know.

Person1: You're a good man, Alex.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: I think you're in love with her.
Person2: Ten bucks says you're wrong.
Person1: What's the ten bucks for?
Person2: For the "I was wrong" fund.
Person1: Well, I appreciate your honesty.
Person2: No problem, I'm just trying to be a good friend.

Person1: You can hardly blame her, the way we've been taking care of her. Or should I say, not taking care of her.
Person2: What makes you think she needs us?
Person1: We've been given a gift here, a real live little girl. She likes us a lot. Maybe that's why we're here, to keep us from getting so... attached to things.
Person2: That's a lotta crap. You're just trying to make me feel guilty.
Person1: I'm just saying, look at us. We didn't have room for anyone. Maybe this is our chance to make a difference.

Person1: I'm so anxious for you to meet our new team leader. 
Person2: Yeah, I know. It's great! 
Person1: What is success?  For you, I would do anything. 
Person2: Please don't set off anything that goes wrong tonight, okay? Just focus on the presentation. Can you tell the difference?

Person1: I'm telling you, we need to take precautions. We can't afford an accident.
Person2: Dr. Rachel Kim, and I assure you, I have no intention of causing any harm.
Person1: It's not about intentions, Doctor. We're dealing with sensitive equipment here.
Person2: I understand that. That's why I've prepared a proposal to improve our safety protocols.
Person1: I'm not sure that's necessary. We've already taken every precaution.
Person2: Perhaps, but I've found that a fresh perspective can often reveal overlooked vulnerabilities.

Person1: I never knew that one kiss could matter so much.
Person2: Don't you see, I've made this moment immortal.
Person1: Inexpressible love! God of nature! Bitterness than which nothing is sweeter, sweetness than which nothing is more bitter.
Person2: Stay away from me, I need to process this.
Person1: As soon as I saw you loved me, I was pleased, and I gave you every opportunity to fall more in love with me.
Person2: But I didn't expect it to be like this. I didn't expect to feel so alive.

Person1: I'm not "people." I'm just me. And I do whatever I goddamn want to do. Got it?
Person2: Yeah, that's right. You're the one who's been helping out at the community center, aren't you?
Person1: Hell, you know how it is. Says he's gonna fix the roof... and I says, "You can't do that," and he says, "Well, then get someone else to do it" and I says, "There's no one else, man."
Person2: But your body is in the world, isn't it? If someone offered you a hand, you wouldn't necessarily refuse, would you?
Person1: People around here are willing to lend a hand. Not like in New York.
Person2: I'm not offering you a long-term commitment -- just a place to crash for a couple of nights while you get back on your feet.
Person1: Thanks, but I'll manage. I've got a plan to get the center back in shape.

Person1: I'm sorry I haven't been the partner to you that I should be.
Person2: Oh, you're very welcome... I mean, it's okay. I know you're trying.
Person1: I feel like I'm always letting you down, like that look on your face says, "What's he going to mess up now?"
Person2: That's not fair. I love you, and I know you love me. It's just... different with us, that's all.

Person1: I need you to promise me something.
Person2: What is it?
Person1: SAY IT! You have to mean it.
Person2: I promise, I'll do everything I can.
Person1: Hold me, I feel like I'm losing control.
Person2: I've got you, I won't let you fall.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a sign! His hand moved, and it's not just a spasm.
Person2: What are you talking about? You're not making any sense. Look at the certificate, it's all there in black and white.
Person1: You're not listening to me. I'm trying to tell you something important. You need to accept what's happening here.
Person2: Accept what? You're the one who's being ridiculous. I don't know what's gotten into you.

Person1: I won't let you take control of my research. It's my life's work.
Person2: If you won't accept our offer, we'll simply find someone who will. You'll be a pioneer in the field. Better than being stuck in obscurity.

Person1: I don't think I can handle this situation on my own. They're likely to destroy the planet.
Person2: Then it's fortunate that I have you to rely on. But first, can I ask, do you want me to take charge of the operation?
Person1: I'd rather we work together. But I need certain assurances before we proceed.

Person1: I can feel it, something's gonna blow in this town.
Person2: Get over here, damn it! We need to talk about this.
Person1: You know how people with broken bones know when there's a storm coming?
Person2: Are you crazy? We're not talking about the weather, we're talking about your brother.
Person1: I saw your eyes when you stood up for him at the town hall meeting. You're not going to hurt him, are you?
Person2: Why would I hurt him? He's my friend.
Person1: I'm afraid you'll let him down. He's counting on you.
Person2: I'll do what's right, I promise.

Person1: I'm telling you, Captain, Operation Nightshade is a trap. I thought we were working together to take down the cartel, but really they were using me to get to our informant.
Person2: I implore you to believe me, Captain. Mr. Rodriguez is very real and very determined. If the cartel gets their hands on the encryption key, we're done for.
Person1: I'll find out what's going on. I have a few vows to uphold, not just to the mission, but to my own conscience.
Person2: God go with you, Captain. We need all the help we can get.

Person1: Dr. Lee, I think it's essential to prioritize your mental health. Depression can have severe consequences on your well-being.
Person2: I know, Bruce. I've been trying to focus on my research, but it's getting harder to cope with the pressure.
Person1: Who's Bruce? Oh, sorry, I must have misheard. Anyway, have you considered talking to a therapist? It might help you manage your stress.
Person2: Actually, that's not a bad idea. I'll look into it, thanks for the advice.

Person1: I've been thinking, and I want to make a responsible decision about my future.
Person2: What's holding you back?
Person1: I need more experience in life, but it's going to be painful for me to leave this place. I love it here.
Person2: Oh, don't be silly! You're not making a fool of yourself. It's a natural part of growing up.
Person1: I suppose you're right. I just regret not taking more chances when I was younger.
Person2: Well, it's never too late to start.

Person1: What do you want more than anything?
Person2: Progress!
Person1: Oh yes, getting to be smooth smooth smooth all over. Smooth as a baby's butt.
Person2: I told you what I want.
Person1: I don't know, maybe you should think about it for a while?
Person2: I love it, but I'm getting to be a real girl. Always in the market for a real boy.
Person1: Cause there's this guy. My friend knows him. Might be right up your alley.
Person2: Tell me. I could use someone up my alley.
Person1: Handsome, thirties, loves animals...
Person2: What do you mean?

Person1: Wait, don't do that!
Person2: Who authorized you to take this action, Agent Thompson?
Person1: Director Brumby, and I have a message for the people watching at home. There are two reasons we need to resolve this situation quickly. One is the safety of our team, and the second is the well-being of innocent civilians.

Person1: I need a new partner. 
Person2: Is that what you want? 
Person1: Yeah. You were quick enough to get my help when... 
Person2: And if it had gone well for me tonight, maybe I'd be keeping quiet about all this... 
Person1: Grant you everything, but give me this... 
Person2: He does personify everything you've been fighting against... 
Person1: And I'm in love with you. How do you like that? 
Person2: Mm... okay. Don't worry about it. Nobody'll mess with ya anymore. I'll take care of ya.

Person1: I'm thrilled to announce that our community is built on fairness and equality. We promote healthy relationships and support each other.
Person2: That's wonderful to hear. You're a lucky person to be part of this community.
Person1: I love seeing people thrive and grow together. Do you know that we have a unique approach to resolving conflicts?
Person2: Oh, really? What's that?
Person1: We let the individuals involved decide what's best for them. We believe in empowering people to make their own choices.
Person2: That sounds like a great way to build trust and respect.
Person1: Exactly! And we also encourage families to grow and flourish. We provide resources and support to help them thrive.
Person2: That's amazing. You're creating a wonderful environment for people to live and grow.

Person1: I'm not the one who chose this game, but I'm willing to teach you the rules.
Person2: It looks like a regular game to me. What's the catch?
Person1: There's no catch, but you need to be careful. The previous player left some hidden advantages on the table. Let me show you how to spot them.

Person1: I love "Row..." Do you know "Row, Row, Row, Row, Row Your Boat?"
Person2: We're a little disappointed in you -- enthusiasm-wise.
Person1: Oh, I'm very excited. The lyrics are very simple. It's, er, "Row, row, row your boat, gently down the stream. Merrily, merrily, merrily, merrily, life is but a dream."

Person1: I've been searching for you everywhere.
Person2: What do you want from me?
Person1: Let us explore this connection together. I used to work with you at Warsaw Radio.
Person2: I don't remember. Sorry.
Person1: Doesn't matter. I'll visit often.

Person1: Oh, come on, will ya? This bike is only fifty bucks.
Person2: Fifty bucks?? Are you crazy? That's a steal!
Person1: Charlie, I'm trying to help you out. Think about it, will you?
Person2: NO!!! What do you think I am, made of money???

Person1: I'm on the move - trying to get away from all this.
Person2: Did your mother ever say that to you - that you'd be better off without me?
Person1: No, she never said that.
Person2: Are you sure? You seem pretty convinced that I'm holding you back.
Person1: Honestly? I just want to start fresh, without all the baggage.
Person2: And what do you want from me? Just to disappear?

Person1: Who am I talking to?
Person2: You're talking to me. I'm Dr. Lee, your therapist.
Person1: Ah, Dr. Lee. Tell them who I am! Tell them who I am!
Person2: I think you're getting a bit agitated. Let's take a deep breath and focus on our session today.
Person1: But I promise you, I'm not crazy. Course, if I was, I'd be the last to know.
Person2: That's a clever joke, but let's explore what's really going on. You've been having some trouble sleeping, and you mentioned hearing voices. Can you tell me more about that?
Person1: If I was with you, I wouldn't... I mean, I don't hear voices. I just talk to myself sometimes.
Person2: I see. And how do you feel when you're talking to yourself?
Person1: Just okay, I suppose. But I'm not crazy, I promise.

Person1: You're really going to wear that to the party?
Person2: Yeah, why not? I think it's a great outfit.
Person1: If you want to make a good impression, you should dress more professionally. You know, like they voted you most likely to succeed.
Person2: That was high school, and it doesn't matter now. I'm confident in my choices.
Person1: Fine, but don't say I didn't warn you. And by the way, get your feet off the couch.

Person1: Hey, just listen. I know I'm strange, but in my own way, I need your help.
Person2: What's going on?

Person1: I can feel it. Something's gonna blow in this town.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: I don't know, it's just a feeling. Like people with broken bones know when there's a storm coming.
Person2: You're not making any sense. Did you try something recently that didn't work out?
Person1: Well, kind of. I tried to talk to my brother about something, but it just seemed stupid. I kept thinking about how he'd react, and it seemed dumb.
Person2: So it was recently that you tried to talk to him. What's going on with your brother?
Person1: I'm afraid of what might happen to him. I saw something in your eyes once, and it scared me.
Person2: What are you talking about? What did you see in my eyes?
Person1: I don't know, it was just a look. But it made me think you might hurt him.

Person1: I just want you to know, I appreciate your honesty, Rachel.
Person2: That might be the news we've been waiting for. The board will finally listen to us.
Person1: Why do you think they're so resistant to change? It can't be just about Sister Agnes.
Person2: Well, you're probably right about that. It's about the entire institution's reputation.

Person1: I know it's treason against the crown to love you, but not to love you is treason against my heart.
Person2: It reminds me of the old castle. I'm here to find something and I think you can help me.
Person1: Where's the old castle from? Is it near the kingdom?
Person2: No, it's from a distant land. But let's not dwell on the past. The important thing is I need your assistance.
Person1: Then let's ride together and see what we can find.

Person1: You're not terribly important to me, Rachel.
Person2: That's a heavy load, Alex. You're not alone in this.
Person1: What about our past? Did it mean nothing to you?
Person2: We allus thought you were strong enough to carry it. Was we wrong?
Person1: You're just trying to make me feel guilty.
Person2: No, Alex, I'm trying to make you see that you're not alone.

Person1: What's going on here?
Person2: Let's see how much he wants to play.
Person1: Are you serious? This is no game!
Person2: I learned a long time ago to take risks.

Person1: I had a lunch break so I thought I'd come by and see you. I've heard the rumors, so save it. I know you're mixed up in all this, and I don't care what you're trying to take off her husband. That's your business.
Person2: Yeah, well, right man, there are many facets to this, uh, you know, many interested parties. Your teacher is a fox! Why don't we discuss that after class.
Person1: Of course, there's that to discuss. Refill? I thought this was a 45-minute seminar.
Person2: Does the Pope shit in the woods? Oh look, class is over already. If I can find your answers, man-- what's in it for me?
Person1: Let's say a 10% finder's fee? I like the way you do business.
Person2: Okay, done. Your notes are being held by a kid named Alex. He lives in the library, on the third floor. A real bookworm, but I'm sure you'll be able to get it off him, mean he's only a freshman and he's struggling with calculus. So if you'll just write me a check for my ten per cent... of the project grade.

Person1: You know, if you let me help you with your decisions, you could avoid making the same mistakes again.
Person2: What makes you think I'd make the same choice again?
Person1: I want out. I want a new life. I see what I've been waiting for, but I need you to understand that.
Person2: For what?

Person1: I don't know how to say this, except to just say it right out, so I'll say it. They're not going to fund our project.
Person2: What?!
Person1: The investors may have changed their minds... the company is going through restructuring... But you, I mean, I know how much this means to you...
Person2: Hold me, I'm falling!
Person1: No, what? No, what's wrong?
Person2: You're telling me that all our hard work, all the sacrifices we made, are not going to pay off. You're telling me that our project, our baby, is not going to see the light of day.

Person1: Who do you think you're dealing with? I'm willing to listen, officer!
Person2: Just thinking about something. There's going to be a lot of concerned parents on Monday if the situation isn't resolved.
Person1: What's on your mind? You seem worried.
Person2: It's just that we need to ensure everyone's safety. We can't afford to take any chances.

Person1: Just hold on, I think we're close to finding the truth. Look at this document. Your family history doesn't add up. Who do you think is behind this?
Person2: I don't know, but I have a feeling it's someone I trusted.
Person1: Bet your life we're going to find out. And when we do, we'll be ready.

Person1: I want to prove myself, Coach.
Person2: You've made tremendous progress in the past week. And the way you handled the team's morale - 
Person1: Just following your example, Coach. But I still feel like I'm not doing enough.
Person2: I want you to take Dora's spot and lead the team in the next practice. You hear me?
Person1: Yes, Coach. But what's the real reason behind this change?
Person2: I have doubts about Dora's ability to stick with the team's strategy. I think you can do better.

Person1: I'm really glad I ran into you here. I was hoping to catch up.
Person2: Oh, I don't know... I'm not really in the mood for a party.
Person1: Well, now you're here. It's not every day we get to hang out without our folks around.
Person2: I suppose you're right. But I'm still not sure...

Person1: I've known Dr. Lee for more than ten years, Rachel. We're old colleagues.
Person2: How can I say anything to that? I don't know what to say to that.
Person1: The job here is to make your mother as comfortable as possible, right now. Our job is to just try and make it as painless as possible. You understand?
Person2: You're saying that this new treatment will cure her pain, but she'll float in and out of consciousness, even worse than she is now?
Person1: Yes, Rachel. I'm afraid so. But it's the best option we have left.

Person1: I think we should do this here.
Person2: Are you sure you want to handle this yourself? There are plenty of people around who could help.
Person1: I already know what I'm doing... and it's not like I have a deadline to meet. Between you and me, I could use the time to clear my head.

Person1: I know how to get in there. But you've gotta help me.
Person2: Plans?
Person1: We can't just walk in. We need a strategy.
Person2: Shit. I met the organizer at a conference and I had all these ideas. You know, those innovative approaches. I pitched them to her before I realized... she's a traditionalist... Jesus, she's never even considered alternative methods.
Person1: Well... It'll probably work out. We can refine our approach and present it at the meeting.

Person1: I've been trying to go easy on you, but this can't continue. We need to address the issues.
Person2: Lay off, I'm one of the great designers. I've been overwhelmed with all the other projects on my plate.
Person1: If it can produce a masterpiece like the last campaign, you'll get no argument from me.
Person2: I understand. Let's discuss how we can improve the situation and meet expectations.
Person1: I appreciate that. Let's work on a plan together.

Person1: I'm thinking of taking a trip to Japan. Don't get upset.
Person2: You're so lucky you can go off to Japan... I'll miss you, but I'll be fine.
Person1: This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, and I promise to keep strict accounts of my expenses.

Person1: Excuse me, do you remember the guy who came in earlier?
Person2: Yeah, I've seen him. What's with the interest?
Person1: We're trying to figure out what he ordered. Could it have been this?
Person2: I don't remember. We get a lot of people in here.
Person1: Would you like a drink while you're thinking? I can put it on the house.
Person2: Great, I'll have a coffee. Maybe it'll help me remember.

Person1: I want to, but I can't.
Person2: You're a pretty good judge of character, aren't you?
Person1: I don't know what to say to myself.
Person2: Have you ever bent your knees, not to Allah, but to your own conscience?
Person1: I forgive myself.
Person2: You shouldn't. You're too hard on yourself.
