Person1: I mean, decency-wise, I'm trying to be kinder to myself.
Person2: Cheers to that.

Person1: I'm glad to hear that the project is back on track.
Person2: Are you still in touch with the development team?
Person1: Not really. The last time I saw them was at that conference. That was a long time ago.
Person2: I implore you to believe me, the new deadline is very real and very determined.
Person1: Which conference?
Person2: We'll see.

Person1: I'm volunteering at the local hospital.
Person2: You're really taking to it, aren't you? I've never seen you so dedicated.
Person1: I want my doctor...I want my doctor...
Person2: Hey, calm down. You're not a patient here, you're a volunteer.

Person1: I've been thinking, and I want to apologize for my behavior that evening we went out.
Person2: Oh, don't be silly! What's there to apologize for?
Person1: I was trying to impress you, and I ended up being dishonest. I'm not good at lying.
Person2: Well, honesty is always the best policy. It's refreshing to see someone own up to their mistakes.

Person1: Hiya, Rachel. I finally got the part I wanted.
Person2: Thank you. It's not important. But after I saw what Emily did with the script -- I know I rewrote it, took a writing class, changed my whole approach. She really inspired me.

Person1: Rachel, I need a huge favour. Can I borrow your car for tonight?
Person2: I don't know... I'm not really comfortable lending it out.
Person1: Please, as a favour to me? I promise I'll fill up the gas tank and return it by morning.
Person2: Okay, fine. But be careful, and don't get a single scratch on it.

Person1: I'm not the one who chose this.
Person2: You don't understand, I'm the only one who can make it right.

Person1: I got the first copy, and I couldn't wait to start reading. The name Misery Chastain is like a visit from my oldest, dearest friend.
Person2: That's nice, but I'm more concerned about getting home for my daughter's birthday. I was supposed to be there three days ago.
Person1: I'm sure she'll understand. Let's take your mind off it with a song. Do you know "Row, Row, Row Your Boat"?
Person2: Actually, I do. It's a nice distraction. "Row, row, row your boat, gently down the stream. Merrily, merrily, merrily, merrily, life is but a dream..."
Person1: Exactly! It's so calming. I'm sure the roads will be open soon, and you'll be home in no time.
Person2: I hope so. I need to make some calls and let everyone know I'm okay.
Person1: The phones in town are working, so we can try to get in touch with your family soon.

Person1: Anyway, you're crazy.
Person2: Fine. Do you want blood running waist deep in the storm drains?
Person1: Poster-Kleiser. That's right.
Person2: You really want that on your head?
Person1: Yeah, well maybe it's time for a change!
Person2: I'll call you. See you later.

Person1: I've been thinking, what kind of friend was I that I could abandon you in your time of need? It got to where I couldn't look you in the eye, knowing I wasn't there for you.
Person2: Oh, cut it out, will ya? You're being too hard on yourself.
Person1: No, I mean it. I realize now that it's not about what I want or what you want. It's about what's best for our friendship.
Person2: Charlie, twenty- eight bucks is nothing. The only way to do it is through your uncle... think about it, will you?
Person1: I've thought about it, and I think we should focus on rebuilding our friendship instead of trying to make a quick buck.
Person2: You know what? You're right. I'm sorry I didn't see it that way before.
Person1: No need to apologize. Can we start fresh and move forward?
Person2: Absolutely. No more waiting in the wings... I promise.

Person1: I think I need some fresh air. This room is suffocating me.
Person2: You're not exactly the most pleasant company either. How long have you been stuck in this rut?
Person1: That's not fair. I'm just going through a tough time.
Person2: Well, if you really want to wallow in self-pity, that's your problem. But don't expect me to join you.

Person1: I'm tired. Come to bed, now; tonight we're celebrating.
Person2: Celebrating what? The darkness that's consumed this place?
Person1: Ah, but it's beautiful, don't you think? The way it moves, the way it takes life...
Person2: You can't be serious. You know what it's done. The workers, my father...
Person1: Yes, I know. But I get what I want, always. And I want to restore this house to its former glory.
Person2: You're not listening. Nothing can live here. It's corrupt, and it will consume us all.

Person1: I'm thinking of taking a cooking class. Want to join me?
Person2: If you want to learn how to cook, go ahead, but do it for yourself, not to impress someone else.
Person1: You know, I saw this documentary about a possessed priest who was exorcised. It was pretty amazing.
Person2: That's not something to be taken lightly. You can't just go around claiming demonic possession without evidence.
Person1: I'm not claiming anything. I just think it's fascinating. And I met someone who knows the priest. They're meeting at the Public Library tomorrow at 2.
Person2: I don't know... I'm not sure I believe in all that supernatural stuff.
Person1: Well, it's not about believing or not believing. It's about being open to new experiences. And who knows, you might learn something.

Person1: We have to make a decision about the expedition today...
Person2: The dead can wait. We need to focus on the environmental concerns in The Briar Patch.
Person1: What kind of concerns? We can't just ignore the risks.
Person2: I'll get you the schematics, but we need to prioritize. We can't afford to waste time.
Person1: Fine. But I want to be informed every step of the way.

Person1: Hey, just calm down.
Person2: You don't understand me.
Person1: You're right, I don't. But if I wanted to help you, I'd do it with a clear head.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?

Person1: You're not foolish, by the way.
Person2: Thinking I saw a business opportunity in that abandoned factory feels pretty foolish.  And investing all my savings...
Person1: You didn't invest.  That's my understanding.
Person2: That's my memory.  And it seemed absolutely real.
Person1: Tell me, what is it that makes you so confident in your business ventures?
Person2: I don't know.  I just trust my instincts.
Person1: Think.  Maybe it's in your family.  Your grandfather was a successful entrepreneur, wasn't he?

Person1: I'm equally impressed with your knowledge of the market. How long have you been with the company now?
Person2: Four years, but I've been feeling like I'm stuck in a rut lately.
Person1: You can hardly blame yourself, the way you've been taking care of business...or should I say, not taking care of it.
Person2: What're you talking about? I've been doing my job just fine.
Person1: I've been noticing some discrepancies in the quarterly reports. Maybe we should discuss your future over dinner tonight?
Person2: I don't think that's necessary. I can explain the reports right now.

Person1: I need you to do two things for me. One, review the case files of Saint Catherines home.
Person2: Yes, sir. What's the other thing?
Person1: Why do you think Sister Agnes is so concerned about this investigation?
Person2: I'm not sure, but I can try to find out. By the way, your tie is loose.
Person1: Ah, thanks for noticing.

Person1: Answer me, are you serious about this?
Person2: You're all just jealous, I was just trying to make a point.

Person1: You know we're right.
Person2: What is this? Is this a... Surprise?
Person1: Once it's done, you won't have to worry about it.
Person2: Be like a weight off your shoulders.
Person1: Try it, it'll make a big difference.
Person2: Don't you think so?

Person1: I'm so tired of this place, it's getting on my nerves.
Person2: I know what you mean. You've got brains, kid. You'll get along swell if you'll only curb your frustration.
Person1: But what about this party I heard about? I think it's tonight.
Person2: What party? Where? You're not going to get me to fall for that again.
Person1: If I promise you there's really a party with a lot of people, do you promise you'll come with me?
Person2: I don't know... I've got a bad feeling about this. You're not going to go around talking to people, are you?
Person1: Of course not! I'll keep my trap shut. I just need someone to go with me.
Person2: Alright, fine. But if I feel like you're getting us into trouble, I'm out of there.

Person1: You want to work uptown nights?
Person2: Tell me, just what is it that makes you so popular?
Person1: I'll work anywhere, anytime. I know I can't be choosy.
Person2: I don't know. Think.
Person1: How's your driving record?
Person2: I'm not the one applying for the job.
Person1: Clean. Real clean. As clean as my conscience.
Person2: That's not what I meant. What makes you stand out?
Person1: I'm a hard worker, I guess.
Person2: We'll be in touch. Leave your phone number with the girl at the desk.
Person1: I don't have a phone. Can I check back tomorrow?
Person2: Yes, do that.

Person1: I've got a surprise for you. We're going on an adventure!
Person2: What kind of adventure? I can't see what's going on.
Person1: That's the best part! It's a surprise. Just trust me.
Person2: But what if I get lost or hurt?
Person1: Don't worry, someone will follow and guide you. They'll tell you how to navigate the path.
Person2: And what about Jessica? Can she come with us?
Person1: No, Jessica needs to go back now. We'll have to continue on our own.
Person2: Okay, but I'm still not sure about this...
Person1: Come on, it'll be fun! We'll have a drink to celebrate afterwards.

Person1: I'd really like to know why all you guys are so crazy about him. What's his secret?
Person2: Spider-Man is a good guy. On the side of right, and niceness, and cute baby animals and all that.
Person1: Oh, really? I've heard that before, but I'm not convinced. Can you explain it to me?
Person2: Well, Dr. Furtwngler was absolutely clear about this: Spider-Man's heroism is what sets him apart.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's not just about the concert tickets. It's about the principle.
Person2: Hell, you know how my sister is. Says she's gonna boycott the venue... an I says, "Sis, you can't do that," an' she says, "Well, then get Mom down here an' let's settle this" an' I says, "Mom's busy, Sis," an'...
Person1: What upsets you about that? Is it because you feel like she's not considering your feelings?
Person2: I guess I'm upset because I can't really justify being upset. I mean, it's her favorite band, and I would've said yes if she'd asked.
Person1: But didn't you ask her to help with the festival planning, and she didn't show up?
Person2: Yeah, I know. It's just that sometimes I don't want her to assume things about me, you know?
Person1: This aside, how are things with your sister lately?
Person2: Fine, I guess. Except right now I'm going through this where I don't want to talk to her about anything serious.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a great opportunity! You can't pass it up.
Person2: Why do I always let you talk me into these things? I must be out of my mind.
Person1: That's the spirit! We're in this together, as a team. Just remember to keep a low profile and avoid any... bright colors.
Person2: Yeah, right. And what's the plan to get us out of this mess?
Person1: Leave that to me. Just make sure you don't set off any alarms, okay? We don't want anything to go bang.
Person2: You're not exactly filling me with confidence.

Person1: I don't know what to say to myself.
Person2: Have you ever taken responsibility, Alex?
Person1: I want to, but I can't. I'm not sure what really happened that day.
Person2: That would complicate things. But the truth is, it's the hardest thing on earth to admit our guilt.
Person1: Because I'd be to blame, right? I'd have to bend my knee and implore forgiveness.
Person2: Yes, Alex. You would. But it's also the greatest thing on earth.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously. Who do you think you are?
Person2: Wait a minute, the fourteenth, that's the same day the project is due. I mean... didn't we discuss the deadline? Look... "Finalizing the marketing strategy" - we can't blame the team for the delay.

Person1: I'm falling!
Person2: What's wrong? You're scaring me.
Person1: I wish we could start over, live a normal life.
Person2: What do you mean? We're happy, aren't we?
Person1: I don't know. I feel like I'm stuck in a rut. I need a change.
Person2: Like what? You want to rob banks or something?
Person1: No, of course not! I just want to feel alive again.
Person2: Hold me. I'm here for you. We'll figure it out together.
Person1: You're so easy going. You always know what to say to make me feel better.
Person2: That's what partners are for. Now, let's take things one step at a time and see where life takes us.

Person1: I'm sorry, I don't understand.
Person2: That's okay. I think I can explain. I want to ask you some questions about your past experiences.
Person1: What kind of experiences?
Person2: It reminds me of home. I'm looking for something and I think you can help me.
Person1: Like what?
Person2: Well, they must be something important, because I get a feeling that you're holding back. Are you willing to discuss it with me?
Person1: Why should I?
Person2: Because I'm willing to listen. And I promise, whatever you say will remain private.
Person1: How do we start?
Person2: I'll ask you questions, and you can share as much or as little as you want.
Person1: And that's all?
Person2: That's all. I just want to understand.
Person1: Okay, let's ride. I mean, let's get started.
Person2: Just a moment.

Person1: I need you, Alex. I see what I've been waiting for.
Person2: Look, I'll stay behind and hold them off. The rest of you break for it!
Person1: Are you crazy? You're not thinking this through.
Person2: I know what I'm doing. I made a choice once, and I'd make it again. Go!

Person1: We're all tired, none of us had any sleep since Friday night...
Person2: That's why I'm giving you an ultimatum. Bring me the documents, or you'll face the consequences.
Person1: No, please! You can't do this to me!
Person2: Wear the responsibility until you learn to accept it. And live with it!

Person1: I've never seen anything like this before. It's worse than anywhere you've ever been.
Person2: Grab onto me tight! We need to get out of here, now!

Person1: I'm sorry, but you can't stay here. I met him at this place called Moke's... We became friends... He told me about a job...
Person2: What job? You're not making any sense. This is a hospital, not a social club.
Person1: I don't remember... Anyway, Andy's okay... He's got some messed up friends, but I think they can help us.
Person2: Help us? You're the one who's supposed to be helping me. I need to get my father to a safe room, and I need your assistance.
Person1: We can wheel the bed out, but we need to get permission from the Doctor first.
Person2: There's no time for that. We have to move now.

Person1: I've always wondered how you'd like working in a more...unconventional environment. Maybe a vintage arcade game or a retro jukebox.
Person2: Lay off the nostalgia, it's one of the great things about this city.
Person1: If it can produce someone like you, I'll take it. But we did take care of that project you assigned us, didn't we?
Person2: We'll get to it, eventually. These things take time.
Person1: I don't have time, and neither do you. We need to move forward.

Person1: I know how to get to the concert. But you've gotta help me.
Person2: Just north to the venue, so I know what you're going to ask next.
Person1: So you believe me?
Person2: Of course. We might need to dress up, though.
Person1: Okay, got it. What did you think I was going to ask?
Person2: Whether the tickets are sold out already...
Person1: Oh. Okay, then. Thanks for the help.

Person1: We need to get a description of the thief out to the public. Let's review the security footage and get an APB out.
Person2: I've been over the footage, but it's no use. The thief was masked and wore a disguise. We have no idea what they look like.
Person1: That's unacceptable. There must be someone who saw something. Check with the witnesses again.
Person2: I've already spoken to them, but they're all too afraid to come forward. The thief made it clear they'd harm anyone who cooperated with the authorities.

Person1: I've been thinking, and I want to clear the air about what happened at the party last week.
Person2: Oh, yeah? What about it?
Person1: I regret how I behaved, and I think I made a fool of myself.
Person2: Not to mention Mrs. Caldwell will love that. What's your plan of attack?
Person1: I was thinking of talking to her about it, but I'm moving with the speed of a Special Olympic Bobsledder.
Person2: Who do you think will help you out of this mess?

Person1: I told you! I knew it!
Person2: Progress! You're getting to be smooth smooth smooth all over.
Person1: How would you know that? You were at the Opera, weren't you?
Person2: Ouch. Yeah? I was there with Dickie. He loves you, by the way.
Person1: What do you mean? You're not making any sense.
Person2: I mean, Dickie told me everything. I was supposed to meet him fifteen minutes ago, so I... I'm going to go now, I think.
Person1: Wait, I have a friend who might be right up your alley. Handsome, thirties, psychologist...
Person2: Loves animals? Must love animals.
Person1: Loves animals. And I think he'd love to meet you.

Person1: I didn't ask what the team thinks, Rachel. What do you think?
Person2: Honestly, I think they're just shy about sharing their ideas.
Person1: Shy? They're not kids, Rachel. They're experienced professionals. Their silence represents a lack of confidence in their own abilities.
Person2: Maybe they just need a little encouragement. You're always saying how much you value their input.
Person1: I do value their input, but I also expect them to take initiative. And another thing, Rachel, you're always so lucky to have such a positive outlook. I wish I could be more like that.
Person2: It's not luck, it's just a matter of perspective. And I'm sure you have your own strengths that I admire.

Person1: Hiya, I finally got the venue I wanted.
Person2: You're not as dumb as I thought you are.
Person1: I'm performing my dance quintet at Crane Jackson's Fountain Street Theatre on Tuesday night, and I'd love it if you came and gave me notes.
Person2: What's waiting for us up there? Tell me, I'm curious.

Person1: I've been searching for that rare book everywhere. Do you have some explanation of what happened to it?
Person2: Yes, but I have to tell you in private at a quiet caf. I love "Row, Row, Row Your Boat..." by the way.
Person1: Can't you tell me now? What's the connection between the book and the song?
Person2: I'll explain, but first, let me ask you, have you read "The Roylance Guide to Secret Societies and Sects"?
Person1: No, I haven't. But I've heard of it. What's the relevance?
Person2: Well, I found a cryptic message in the book that might be connected to the missing book. It's about an ancient cult that worshipped a demi-god.
Person1: That sounds intriguing. But how does it relate to my book?
Person2: I think we should discuss it further over coffee. I'll pick you up at your place and bring the guide. We can read it together after we eat.
Person1: Alright, but make it quick. I have a busy schedule.
Person2: I'll make sure it's worth your while. And by the way, would you like to sing "Row, Row, Row Your Boat" together after we eat?

Person1: I'm feeling too good to argue with you, but I need to know - what were you doing at my favorite caf yesterday?
Person2: Honestly, I haven't been there in years! You must be mistaken.
Person1: I'm going to let you in on a little secret. I've seen people get overly excited about things before, and it never ends well.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: I've watched people get too confident and take unnecessary risks. It's a recipe for disaster.
Person2: That's a pretty cynical view. Don't you think people can learn from their mistakes?
Person1: Maybe. But I've seen it happen too many times to be optimistic.

Person1: What's going on?
Person2: Sometimes when we get them, they're not completely ready, you know?
Person1: Of what? Are you talking about the new project?
Person2: Yeah, I have to go, but we can discuss the details later.

Person1: I've been on this case for two years. Do you know who Lisa Sherman is?
Person2: Yes, I do. She was my mother. I was born nine months after she was raped.
Person1: I'm sorry to hear that. But I need your help to work the drop car. Can I count on you?
Person2: I've planned my whole life around this moment. I want to make a difference, not just seek revenge.
Person1: I understand. But sometimes, seeking justice can be a form of revenge. Let's work together to get to the truth.

Person1: What's wrong? You're shaking.
Person2: I'm sorry... I don't like it when people touch my things. It's not important. It's just that I've had this vase since I was a kid and... and... I find it very comforting.
Person1: They all come here. How do they find me?
Person2: Tell me why I miss him.
Person1: He's not dead, is he?
Person2: No, no. It's just that I wish I could talk to him again.

Person1: We're in this together, aren't we?
Person2: So is violating international law.
Person1: Shut up and listen to me for once.
Person2: Your words made a compelling argument.

Person1: Get over here, damn it! We need to get out of here, now!
Person2: Are you crazy? We're not in danger, we're just lost.

Person1: You know what my English literature teacher said about you?
Person2: Talk. No tricks, no codes, no messages. You haven't found us.
Person1: She said you were legendary. I wrote a theme about you, and she said, "Your father is a legendary hero out of the Golden Age of Heroes."
Person2: Jessie, I reached the top of the Tower. So far, no sign of anyone. Looks like a phoney call. Over.
Person1: That's nice. You thank her for me. Go to bed and get lots of sleep, and then you thank her in the morning.
Person2: I can't take my eyes off you.
Person1: Tomorrow's another day. Why don't you go to bed--son?
Person2: She was killed in the park two months ago--in the daytime.

Person1: I distinctly heard it. He muttered under his breath, "You're next."
Person2: Tell me, what makes you so sure? Think.
Person1: We were walking off the tennis court, and you know, he was there and me and his wife, and he looked at her and then they both looked at me, and under his breath he said, "You're next."
Person2: You're being paranoid again. You see conspiracies in everything.
Person1: No, I don't! You know, I was in a record store. Listen to this- so I know there's this big tall blond crew- cutted guy and he's lookin' at me in a funny way and smiling and he's saying, "Yes, we have a sale this week on new releases." New releases, like I'm next in line or something.
Person2: Right, let's get out of this crazy city. We move to sunny L.A. All of show business is out there.
Person1: No, I cannot. You keep bringing it up, but I don't wanna live in a city where the only cultural advantage is that you can make a right turn on a red light. Besides, I have a meeting with Rachel in front of the Beekman. I think I have a few minutes left. Right?

Person1: I've been thinking, what made you choose this path? You could've done anything else.
Person2: What's with the questions? You're not going to get anything out of me.
Person1: I'm just curious. You seem to be doing well, but I wonder what drives you. Is it the sense of purpose or something else?
Person2: (sighs) Look, I don't know. Maybe it's just what I'm good at. Can we drop it?
Person1: I'm sorry if I'm prying. It's just that I've been feeling a bit lost lately. I see people like you, and I wonder what I'm missing.
Person2: You're not missing anything. Trust me, it's not all it's cracked up to be.

Person1: Do you believe in the curse of the old ranch?
Person2: Can't say that I do.
Person1: Neither do I. But I'm more than sure that anything happens to the ranch owner's horse, you don't wanna be the party that was aboard.

Person1: You're really pushing your luck, Alex. Don't let him, Rachel.
Person2: Oh, come on, Mom. We're not causing any harm. We're just "exploring" the attic.
Person1: Exploring? You're rummaging through my old trunks! What's so special about this trunk, anyway?
Person2: Principal Johnson wants us to create a school exhibit on family history. I found some amazing stuff in here.

Person1: Answer me. What's the plan?
Person2: Look, I'll create a diversion and hold them off. The rest of you break for it!
Person1: Are you crazy? That's not a plan, it's a recipe for disaster.
Person2: I know what I'm doing. We learned that the only way to succeed is to take risks. Go!

Person1: You know, if you let me help you with your plan, you could avoid all the chaos.
Person2: Man, I haven't had a second to think since I got into this. I mean, I'm just doing what it looks like I'm supposed to, even if it seems crazy.
Person1: Well, that's how it is for most people, yes, but sometimes you need to take a step back and re-evaluate.
Person2: I hate to disappoint you, but most of the time, that's just not possible. You just have to hope to hell you're doing the right thing.

Person1: You're losing it, Professor. Be serious, would you?
Person2: I am serious. If we could get the rare artifact, the ancient scroll, and the cryptic map in the vicinity of the hidden temple, we could uncover the secrets of the past.
Person3: You're talking crazy! The temple is said to be cursed, and we'd never make it out alive!
Person2: You forget - the ancient civilization was known for their advanced knowledge. The temple might hold the key to unlocking new technologies. Of course, it's a moot point regardless. The only ones who know the temple's location are the secretive treasure hunters, and they're not telling.

Person1: ...wouldn't let you settle it, huh?
Person2: You know.
Person1: You want me to believe you're some kind of expert, well, I don't, that's just talk!
Person2: I'm not an expert. I just know how things work around here.
Person1: Then what, what makes you so sure? Tell me...
Person2: Better if I just show you.

Person1: I really do think it's the best day of my life.
Person2: What's so special about today? We didn't do anything out of the ordinary.
Person1: That's why I asked you... I want to know what you think.
Person2: You look at me as though I had said something foolish... Do you really think I'm the right person for you?
Person1: Talkin's good. Long as you got the other? I'm a big believer in talkin', case you ain't noticed.
Person2: So... Oh, how I wish that everything were so much simpler... that people could just come together by the color of their hair or the size of their shoes.
Person1: What do you say? What can I say? No. At least, not yet. I don't know... I can't even think of it... at a time like this...
Person2: You think so, baby? Does my hesitation bother you, honey?

Person1: You know, if you let me help you with the investigation, we could uncover some real evidence.
Person2: What makes you think I need your help? I've been doing just fine on my own.
Person1: Fine? You call getting nowhere fine? Rambo and Brewer were selected as write-offs. It was a clean operation.
Person2: A clean operation? You mean like a cover-up? I don't think so. I think there's more to it than that.
Person1: Look, I'm just trying to help. But if you want to play it solo, that's your choice. Just don't come crying to me when you get in over your head.
Person2: I can take care of myself, thanks. And I'll get to the bottom of this, even if it means going through channels.

Person1: We're all tired, none of us had any sleep since Friday night...
Person2: That's why we need to regroup and reassess. We can't let our guard down now.
Person1: I know, but it's hard to think straight when you're running on fumes. What's going to make him come after us?
Person2: The same thing that's been driving him all along - power. He thinks he can control the situation, but we know better.
Person1: And what about the meeting tomorrow? Is it still on?
Person2: Yes, but we need to be careful. Tight security, no guns. We can't afford to take any risks.
Person1: I'll make sure to bring Claire and Luther along. We'll have Marcel waiting with the helicopter in Paris.
Person2: Good. Let's get some rest and be ready for tomorrow. We can't let our fatigue get the best of us.

Person1: Don't WORRY!!! You've GOT it!! Are you CRAZY?
Person2: May I ask a question?
Person1: Sure.
Person2: When will my project be approved by the Committee?
Person1: Your guess is as good as mine.
Person2: I need to meet the deadline. I need to secure the funding...
Person1: Tough, tough!
Person2: Then why is it, please, that another team leader who was actually a member of the Committee, who used to prioritize projects with higher returns, has already been approved and is working again while I have to wait and wait and wait?
Person1: I don't know, it wasn't my case. Why did you change your proposal just before the submission deadline?
Person2: It was because I learned that the Committee was about to reject it.
Person1: Why were they going to reject it?
Person2: I believe it was because of another report I'd written to the Committee lamenting the decline of project quality due to budget constraints.

Person1: I'm telling you, I was doing my best when the project failed. That's how I remembered it. But the truth is, I might have been distracted. And if that's true, what would happen then?
Person2: Don't be too hard on yourself, or I'll have to remind you of your strengths, straight from my heart. You know what a reminder is? It's a message to boost your confidence.
Person1: I'd be grateful for that. I feel like I'm in trouble forever.
Person2: Nonsense! You're not in trouble. You'll learn from this and move forward.

Person1: Hold me, Alex.
Person2: Where are you going or what are you doing right now?
Person1: I just wanted you to know that I wanted to tell you something.
Person2: What is it?
Person1: I promise you'll help me.
Person2: Of course, I will. What's wrong?

Person1: I'm afraid, this wine is making me woozy...
Person2: Get lost, you jerk.
Person1: Oh, I'm sorry. I think we were having a conversation about your father.
Person2: Indeed we were. And I was saying how I need to understand him better.
Person1: Freud, do you know...? He believed that understanding our past is key to moving forward.
Person2: I'm not sure I agree. Sometimes it's better to just move on.
Person1: But don't you think that's just avoiding the truth?
Person2: Maybe. But it would be a pity to squander such a strong personality on dwelling in the past.

Person1: Dr. Lee, I've been noticing some strange behavior from my daughter lately. Did you notice anything unusual during her last session?
Person2: She's a bright kid, but sometimes I think she specializes in pushing boundaries. I've tried various approaches, but nothing seems to stick.
Person1: I'm serious, Doctor. I think there's more to it than just teenage rebellion.
Person2: Look, I'm not going to sugarcoat it. If you want to get through to her, you've got to learn to speak her language. Sometimes that means bending the truth.
Person1: I'm not comfortable with that. I want to build trust with my daughter, not manipulate her.
Person2: I understand your concerns, but trust is a two-way street. You need to be willing to meet her halfway.
Person1: I'll think about it. In the meantime, can I get a copy of her file?
Person2: My assistant will get it for you. It's on the desk outside.

Person1: Can you explain what's going on?
Person2: I think it's stealing us, to be honest. I've been meaning to ask you for some time...
Person1: What do you mean? You're not making any sense.
Person2: I mean, have you noticed anything strange? I feel like we're trapped in some kind of experiment.

Person1: I've been waiting for weeks. Still no response.
Person2: It's not like her. She's always been prompt.
Person1: Something's wrong. I've heard rumors of a new policy affecting international collaborations.
Person2: Lay off the rumors. It's probably just a delay.
Person1: I should reach out to her colleagues. See if they've heard anything.
Person2: If it's true, we'd never get a straight answer from them. Besides, it's probably just a misunderstanding.
Person1: And not a word of this to the team. They're agitated enough about the project's progress.
Person2: Read them the last update and rephrase it. We'll say it came today. It'll set their minds at ease.

Person1: You're the only one who can help me. You were her nurse.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Say it. You were the one who assisted Dr. Lee during her surgery.
Person2: I was one of the nurses.
Person1: Answer affirmatively. Simply. You weren't 'part of a team,' you were her nurse. Isn't that right?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: We need to move her to a different room now. Can you help me disconnect those machines so we can wheel the bed out?
Person2: We can't do that without permission from the Doctor.
Person1: You know as well as I do that her life is in danger. I've received a threat that someone is coming to harm her. Please, help me.

Person1: I'm sorry about getting on your case earlier. I just see you getting sucked in deeper and deeper, and I -- anyway. I'm sorry.
Person2: You know darn well I'm trying to make a change. That's the trouble with me. I can't think of anything but my past mistakes.
Person1: But, Alex, I am hardly to blame for the pricking of your wholly unnecessary conscience. Is this your new path?
Person2: S'okay. I know you still believe in me.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this. I didn't choose it, remember?
Person2: Well, it's refreshing to see someone taking responsibility. Will you have friends or family saying words - singing or anything?
Person1: Are we supposed to? I don't want to be a coward about it.
Person2: It's not a question of supposed to, it's an entirely personal decision. Some do, some don't.

Person1: I'm so sorry I forgot your birthday party last week. I feel awful about it.
Person2: Don't worry about it, child. It will all come back to you now that you're relaxing at home.
Person1: My date always pays more attention to you than to me. I think it's because I'm just shy.
Person2: Maybe that's it. But anyway, I'm glad we're catching up now. Remember that time we hid the awful plum pudding in our pockets at Christmas dinner?
Person1: (laughs) Oh, yes! Cook was so offended when she found out. But I'm still sorry about missing your party. Can I make it up to you somehow?

Person1: I've been on this case for two years. What's the point of bringing me in now?
Person2: Oh, I didn't mean that in any pejorative way. I just think you're the right person for the job.
Person1: The right person? You think I'm some kind of superhero or something?
Person2: Well, you do have a certain... reputation. And I've heard you can get things done without putting a stamp on it, so to speak.
Person1: (laughs) That's just a myth. I'm just a regular person trying to do my job.
Person2: I see. Well, in any case, I need you to work the drop car. Can I count on you?
Person1: (sighs) Yeah, sure. What's the worst that could happen, right?
Person2: (smirks) That's the spirit.

Person1: Captain, I'm having some trouble with my navigation system. It just went AWOL, and I've got a critical mission to complete.
Person2: Ah, "Row, row, row your boat..." I love that song. Do you know the lyrics?
Person1: Uh, no... I don't think that's relevant right now. Can you help me troubleshoot this system?
Person2: Of course, Captain. Let's take a look. Can you read me the serial number on the navigation module?
Person1: It's... uh... 212-555-4210.
Person2: Okay, got it. Now, let's try to reboot the system. And by the way, the lyrics are "Row, row, row your boat, gently down the stream. Merrily, merrily, merrily, merrily, life is but a dream..."

Person1: I think you liked it with him.
Person2: Do you know "Row, row, row your boat"?

Person1: I heard Gino Marzzone is coming to your office. That's a big deal, isn't it?
Person2: Oh yeah? I'll call you.
Person1: He doesn't want to look like an idiot. What's the plan?
Person2: Not much, really. Just making sure everything is in order.
Person1: You're crazy if you think that's enough. He's been here before, right?
Person2: Yeah, twice. The first time, he gave us a list of things to prepare.

Person1: I have to go...
Person2: Maybe. I should call Ben. We've got so much to talk about...
Person1: Then it could all come out, sooner or later. You can't go yet.

Person1: We're going to have to switch to another route, this traffic is driving me crazy.
Person2: I've been trying to get my friend to share their secret recipe, but they're not budging.

Person1: So, you reached the top of the Tower? Find anything interesting?
Person2: Nah, looks like a phoney call. But I did notice the group dynamic was off. Felt like a bunch of chickens at a peckin' party.
Person1: A pecking party? Who do you think pecks the first peck?
Person2: Ha! Good question. Maybe it's the one who's trying to uncover the truth behind this fake call.

Person1: I'm not sure I understand the proposal.
Person2: Like "three thousand a ki"? That's a good starting point.
Person1: I... We have to make a decision today.
Person2: The dead can wait. In this case, it's about the future of our business.
Person1: And why should we trust you with thirty percent of the load?
Person2: Because we guarantee every load. Anywhere, for any reason, it comes up short, we make good.
Person1: That's a big risk for us. What if you can't deliver?
Person2: We become partners. Only in this territory and only on loads we run. And you don't pay us three thousand a ki. You pay us zero.
Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with that.
Person2: It's a risk-free deal. You have nothing to lose.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you?
Person2: That's the general idea. Only it's not so general as far as I'm concerned.
Person1: What are you talking about? You're being cryptic again.
Person2: Now that is a happy sound! I'm finally free from all that nonsense.
Person1: You're talking crazy! What's gotten into you?
Person2: I'm just celebrating my newfound independence, that's all.

Person1: You're part of the research team, aren't you? We know what makes a successful project, don't we? We know that no single researcher matters, right?
Person2: That's correct, ma'am! Not that one or that one.
Person1: So, you study scientific breakthroughs, little one. That's good for someone your age.
Person2: Yeah, I study scientific breakthroughs. I went to the conferences with my mentor. I met the leading experts.
Person1: Smart for your age, eh? Top of your class? Tell me, do you know what the word innovation means?

Person1: You know my friend Alex, right?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: Well, you know how he's been having a little problem with his tennis serve?
Person2: Yeah, what about it?
Person1: I think he's been practicing alone too much. It's like when you play tennis against a wall. Some day, there'll be a partner returning the ball.
Person2: That's a good point. Maybe we should set him up with a tennis partner.
Person1: Exactly! I'm sure he'd appreciate that.

Person1: Answer me. Who's been asking about my past?
Person2: Nobody's mentioned that name around here for years. Your mother's son... far as I'm concerned, he's gone. Now, I ain't gonna ask you again. What brings you to this town?
Person1: I'm looking for the truth. I've traced my family records from New York to Church Hill.
Person2: Well, you've come to the right place. But be warned, some secrets are better left buried.

Person1: I know a party we could go to...
Person2: What's going on, you're being really secretive.
Person1: We're gonna talk.
Person2: About what? You're not even giving me a hint.
Person1: Let's just say it'll be a night to remember. Trust me.
Person2: I don't know... I'm not sure I'm in the mood for a party.

Person1: So, you've not been to the memorial service then?
Person2: No, but I've been thinking about him a lot lately. Tell me why I miss him.
Person1: He was a great person, that's why. You're bound to miss him.
Person2: That's not what I mean. Tell me why he's still on my mind.
Person1: How should I know? You're the one who knew him best.
Person2: Exactly. And that's why I want you to tell me why I'm still thinking about him.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this plan, can you walk me through it again?
Person2: We've been over it a dozen times, it's light at the end of the tunnel now.
Person1: Please, just humor me. I need to know we're making the right decision.
Person2: Fine, but we need to move quickly. We can't afford to wait any longer.

Person1: You're a smart dresser, Mrs. Johnson, but I think you're avoiding the issue.
Person2: What's the matter? I've told you everything I know about my son's disappearance.
Person1: I'm serious. There are other kids involved, it's not just your son. All good kids, smart kids.
Person2: I'm sorry to hear that, but you're the experts on this, not me. If I had any insights, believe me, I'd share them with you.
Person1: I can make it to the city and back in twenty-eight hours... that's no sweat. I'll find out what's going on.
Person2: Look, Detective, I don't know what you want from me. I've cooperated fully with your investigation.
Person1: Just some answers. I'll need to take a look at your son's things.
Person2: The maid packed a suitcase. It's upstairs, first door on the left.

Person1: I'd really like to know why you're so driven to prove yourself to them. What's your secret?
Person2: Yes, desperately. I want to show them I can be friends with them and get my story.
Person1: Politics and art must be kept separate, but in this case, it seems like they're intertwined. Don't you think?
Person2: That's the spirit! I'm not going to let them intimidate me.

Person1: You're losing it, Alex.
Person2: Nobody else is going down but me, okay?
Person1: Hey, being reckless with your life now doesn't change what came before -- it's just stupid.
Person2: What, you think I'm doing this to prove something?
Person1: Let's just not let one bad call lead to another.

Person1: I've seen better film on teeth. What do you want from me?
Person2: It's a different kind of deal. I just had the nicest chat with the director. Got along famously!
Person1: You positive about that? It's scary how everyone's got a story to tell.
Person2: Strength. This film needs a leader. But I can't do it.

Person1: I'm a big believer in talkin', case you ain't noticed.
Person2: What do you want from me? I've got a plane to catch in Fairbanks tomorrow.
Person1: Jiminy Christmas, you're in a rush. I just need you to pass a message to Anne Marie at my place on the Haul Road.
Person2: What's the message? And why should I do you a favor?
Person1: Tell her I'm okay and to sit tight. Corbett ruined my two-way, and I need someone I trust to help me out.
Person2: You're not exactly the most trustworthy person I've met. But I'll do it, just this once.

Person1: I knew it! You've been searching for a way out.
Person2: There is a way, but it's impossible. You'd never make it.
Person1: Why? What's stopping you?
Person2: It's too risky. If it didn't work, you'd be stuck in this situation forever.
Person1: I'm not kidding. I've seen people try and fail. You're not going to be the first one to succeed.
Person2: Yeah, I guess I did underestimate the challenges. What's going to happen to me now?
Person1: We'll leave that up to the authorities. But I'll tell you, you're okay. You made the right decision.

Person1: We're all tired. None of us had any sleep since Friday night...
Person2: I tell you, he's been acting strange lately. He wouldn't dare do something so reckless if he was in his right mind.
Person1: Why? What makes you think that?
Person2: Because I've seen him make rational decisions before, and this just doesn't add up.

Person1: Want to grab a coffee?
Person2: No thanks.
Person1: Oh yeah, I figure it's been an ongoing discussion. Heads or tails?
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: I don't want to go to that new cafe. It's too crowded.
Person2: Go where? The park? That's a good idea. Okay, let's go.

Person1: Hey, I love your scarf. It really brings out the colors in your eyes.
Person2: Thanks, I just got it yesterday. But listen, I need to talk to you about something. I got a message from my aunt, and it's been bothering me all day.
Person1: What's going on? You can trust me.
Person2: I'm not so sure. I feel like you're hiding something from me. You've been acting really secretive lately.
Person1: That's not true! I'm just stressed out about my psychology exam coming up. I have it next period.
Person2: Oh, yeah? Well, I heard some rumors about a girl who got her notes stolen before an exam. You should be careful.
Person1: Thanks for the warning. But hey, want to grab a coffee with me after class? I could use some company.

Person1: I'm still shaken by the accident. I feel like I should've done something to prevent it.
Person2: Listen, kid. We all make mistakes. It's part of the learning process. You can't blame yourself for everything.
Person1: But I was the one in charge. I should've been more careful.
Person2: Understandable, but remember, nobody is perfect. We'll investigate and move forward. You can't let guilt hold you back.
Person1: Thanks for the reassurance. I'll make sure to be more vigilant next time.
Person2: That's the spirit. Now, let's get back to work and make sure it doesn't happen again.

Person1: I've never known him to say those words before. He always speaks the truth.
Person2: You can't imagine. She wears her cheap miserable blouse as though it were the latest model by Schiaparelli.
Person1: That's not his style. What does she look like?
Person2: Timeless. When she comes into a room you'd think that the Bolsheviks had taken over Paris.
Person1: Really? I thought he said it all the time.
Person2: There is a Russian snowstorm in each of her eyes. I must have telephoned her a hundred times.
Person1: One thing I can say about Valmont. He's not one to exaggerate.
Person2: I've sent her telegrams, I've sent her flowers... I asked her to dinner... I offered her seats for the Opera...

Person1: Do you know how many times I've walked into a vintage shop praying someone like you would be behind the counter?
Person2: What are you actually doing here? What is the hidden agenda?
Person1: If it can produce a gem like this store, you'll get no argument from me.
Person2: You're not here to buy anything, are you?
Person1: Mm. I'm just browsing.
Person2: Isn't that what they all say?

Person1: I think I've had one.
Person2: Pack it into a black bag. You have twenty-nine minutes to get it to the art studio.
Person1: What's the hurry? Can't it wait?
Person2: Of course it can't. The artist is waiting for it. You've never been this late before, have you?
Person1: No, I've always been on time. But I've never had to deliver something so... unusual.
Person2: Unusual? You've never even had one manually, have you?

Person1: You think it's Paul?
Person2: Nuthin' I can't handle.
Person1: The truth is, never let them see you sweat. You do that, that's half the battle.
Person2: Oh, you know, for a minute I thought it was...
Person1: In life, I'ma keep on living, having a good drink, got me a good young woman, make a couple of dollars and make people laugh.
Person2: Where do you go from here?
Person1: I'ma take it one step at a time, Peerless. The question is, what are you gonna do?

Person1: You're really pushing my limits.
Person2: Don't. 
Person1: Anybody ever stood up to you like this before?
Person2: It would be a pity to let this tension go to waste.
Person1: Positive I'm not going to back down.
Person2: Guess there's no way I'll ever know what you're truly capable of.

Person1: I'm impressed. Really. I would have bet good money you wouldn't make it to the audition.
Person2: Julia Farren, a nobody? Why I've performed every role from Boston to San Francisco. Those days, those beautiful, shining, golden days.
Person1: But I only came to return the script. I don't think I'm right for the part.
Person2: The script? We'll have no more nonsense about the script.

Person1: I need help. I can't carry on alone. Dem white boys giving you a hard time?
Person2: Nuthin' I can't handle. Maybe you should back off.
Person1: This guy, he drifts around, that's how they all start, drifting around, their minds filling up with fantasies. The truth is never let them see ya sweat.
Person2: You do that, that's half the battle. What's the plan from here?
Person1: I'ma keep on living, having a good drink, got me a good young woman, make a couple of dollars and make people laugh. I'll be in Charleston, South Carolina, for three nights.
Person2: I didn't mean that, in life. You're not like them, are you?
Person1: I'm a hunter. I have the gift. It's ancient times all over again. We stand between order and chaos.

Person1: We may have a chance to resolve this issue tonight.
Person2: Maybe Sarah will come with us. If I explain how important it is to me, I don't think she'll mind. Do you?
Person1: I don't know. Probably not. But we should try to be fair and hear her out.
Person2: Sarah's really great, isn't she? We should consider her perspective before making a decision.
Person1: Absolutely. So, how's everything with you?

Person1: Honestly, do you actually think I would forget to invite you to the party?
Person2: Gee, I don't know, sir. I don't seem to remember you actually asking me if I could help you with your composition.
Person1: Sometimes we have to improvise. I need someone to critique my work.
Person2: Think, sir. Does your patron have any connections that could help us get funding for the opera?
Person1: My patron? What's happened to him?
Person2: Nothing, he's just been sort of, I don't know... unreachable.
Person1: Unreachable? By who? His secretary?
Person2: Good idea, sir. Only one problem. I don't know how to get in touch with him.
Person1: Ah. Wait a minute. The opera house must know how to contact him.
Person2: It's a little late to call the opera house.

Person1: I've been meaning to ask you, how long have you been in this city?
Person2: Honestly, I don't remember. But I thought this was a 45-minute meeting. Is that what you wanted to discuss?
Person1: Right, sorry about that. I got distracted. Anyway, I wanted to talk to you about your presentation style. You have a certain charm to it.
Person2: Oh, thanks. I think.

Person1: You're really terrific, you know what I mean?
Person2: It's refreshing to see two people not afraid of real commitment.
Person1: Wrong. I think we're just getting started.
Person2: I have to go. He sighs.
Person1: Are we supposed to?

Person1: Hey, did you hear that saying, "He hasn't got enough sense to come in out of the rain?"
Person2: Yeah, I've heard it. So, what's new with you?
Person1: Not much. My friend, who's a scientist, says everything is a miracle. I never really understood what he meant by that until recently.
Person2: That's interesting. By the way, did someone give you that necklace or is there someone new in your life?
Person1: Oh, this old thing? I've had it for ages. So, you want to grab coffee and catch up tonight?
Person2: Sure, but you know, I've been thinking... this whole idea of finding someone special is kind of ridiculous, don't you think?
Person1: Not at all! I think it's great. And I could use your help, as a friend.
Person2: Alright, alright. I'll help you out. But just because we're friends, not because I owe you anything.

Person1: I'm so frustrated, I wish you would have at least let me do the laundry. It's not going to be that easy getting all those tough stains out of my favorite clothes.
Person2: Maybe he's just shy. I'm sure he'll talk to you eventually.
Person1: You're right, I'm just being paranoid. But I do remember that one time I spilled your Kraft Holiday dip on the carpet...
Person2: Yeah, yeah. Okay. Give me the vacuum and watch your step. I'll come back for the cleaning products.
Person1: And don't forget, I'm particularly troublesome when it comes to cleaning the bathroom.

Person1: I've been on this case for months, but I don't remember anything. It looks like I...
Person2: That's the point, isn't it? Why would anyone do something like this?

Person1: I'm thinking of taking a break from social media, but my influencer friend says if I do, I'll lose my online presence.
Person2: Don't be dramatic, you're not going to lose everything. If you want to take a break, do it for yourself, not because of what someone else thinks.

Person1: I'm not the one who's supposed to be caught with my pants down... so I'd like to see your boss. Unless that's a problem.
Person2: This is another victory, my friends. What began with the lash shall be concluded with a caress.
Person1: You may if you can, Mr. Johnson. I want to find out what's going on here, lawsuit or no lawsuit.
Person2: Suppose we did. How does it concern you?
Person1: Nothing personal, Mr. Johnson, I just -- 
Person2: It's very personal. It couldn't be more personal. Is this a business or an obsession with you?
Person1: Look at it this way. Now this phony project, excuse the language, says it's a priority, it's been assigned to me. Whoever put it up to it, didn't have anything against me. They were out to get your team. Now if I see them, I can help them.  Did you talk this morning?

Person1: I'm trying to remember the last time I took a taxi. Do you think it's possible to recall every single ride?
Person2: Why is it that you're so interested in remembering that particular ride?
Person1: I found something on the floor of the cab, and I'm trying to figure out what it was.
Person2: That's strange. You could have found anything - a lost phone, a wallet, a piece of trash... What makes you think it's so important?
Person1: I don't know. Maybe it's just my curiosity getting the better of me. But I do remember it was about three months ago.

Person1: You know my friend Alex, right?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: What the heck is going on with him? He's been acting strange lately.
Person2: I don't know, but I've got to talk to him. Pull up alongside, I'll try to get his attention.

Person1: I'm so frustrated with my commute. Some bozo always seems to cut me off...
Person2: You can't go yet, we've got to talk about this. What did you do?
Person1: I followed him, and when he got out of the car, I realized I was being ridiculous. I didn't want to be that person.
Person2: That's really mature of you. Did you ever think about talking to him instead of reacting in anger?
Person1: Yeah, I guess I was just caught up in the moment. I've been feeling really overwhelmed lately.
Person2: We should talk about that. What's been going on?

Person1: I've been investigating some discrepancies in the department's records. It's surprising how easily mistakes can be overlooked.
Person2: Captain, I reached the top of the building and found nothing. It looks like a false alarm.
Person1: I visited the scene this morning, after you left. I think we need to re-examine our procedures.

Person1: I'm starvin' to death. Are you hungry too?
Person2: What's wrong? You look upset.
Person1: I don't know. I just thought, you know, we'd sneak a break, like we used to.
Person2: I want to go for a walk.
Person1: You can't. Not right now.

Person1: I reached the top of the Tower. So far, no sign of anyone. Looks like a phoney call.
Person2: Don't you think there's too much going on? 
Person1: It's great. You wanna speak to the manager? Hold on...
Person2: I don't know, I think we should be more careful.
Person2: Look, would you argue with your instructor?

Person1: What's the plan now? We're still short on tickets.
Person2: Tell me why we can't just buy them online.
Person1: The website crashed, remember? We're out of options.
Person2: That's right. We're out of options. Unless... we get creative.
Person1: What did you have in mind?

Person1: I need some space, okay? I'm not trying to abandon you.
Person2: You're always so quick to push me away. It makes me wonder if you're even invested in this relationship.
Person1: That's not fair, Ava. I'm just trying to protect myself. Broken hearts are for assholes, remember?
Person2: That's easy for you to say. You're not the one who's always left wondering what's going on in your head.

Person1: Are you sure you want to do this in front of everyone?
Person2: Well, then there's only one thing to do.
Person1: What? You can't be serious.
Person2: Reverend Mother says you need experience, right, in life. In order to make a responsible decision.
Person1: But these are your babies. Don't you care about their feelings?

Person1: I'm so done with this place, it's suffocating me.
Person2: I know exactly what you mean. I've been feeling trapped too. But I want to tell you something - my grandmother left me three notebooks before she passed away. They're full of stories about our family's history.
Person1: That's it? What's the big deal about some old notebooks?
Person2: Well, it's not just about the stories. It's about the way she wrote them. She was a very passionate person, and her writing is infectious. It made me feel alive, like I was experiencing everything she wrote about firsthand.
Person1: Hmm, I'm intrigued. Maybe we can check them out together tonight? I know a quiet caf we can go to.
Person2: That sounds perfect. And who knows, maybe we'll even find some inspiration for our own lives.

Person1: I'm surprised you know so much about my favorite book.
Person2: You told me about it last week.
Person1: What are you talking about? I don't remember that.
Person2: Maybe you're just not used to going out with someone who actually listens.
Person1: That's not fair. I'm just trying to figure out why you're being so mysterious.
Person2: I'm not being mysterious, I'm just not using cheesy lines to get your attention. Like "Can I get your number?" or "Do you believe in love at first sight?"
Person1: Ha! Yeah, those are pretty lame. But seriously, how did you know about my book?
Person2: Like I said, you told me. Don't you remember our conversation?

Person1: You're quite the actor, aren't you? Meet me at the old warehouse at midnight. Don't be late.
Person2: Love's a killer, isn't it? What's this about?
Person1: You'll find out soon enough. Just be there. And come alone.
Person2: Alright, alright. I'll be there. But I'm not making any promises.

Person1: What's your story? You seem like an interesting person.
Person2: I've got a few books with me. One's the Bible, one's about Christmas, and one's on carpentry.
Person1: That's quite a combination. Why do you carry them around?
Person2: I don't have a place to put them down. I've been moving around a lot lately.
Person1: Do you have a family or a home to go back to?
Person2: I used to live in a hospital, but they said I was well and let me out.
Person1: A hospital? What were you in for?
Person2: I had some... issues. They said I wasn't right in the head, but I'm feeling better now.
Person1: That's good to hear. You seem pretty normal to me.
Person2: Thanks. I try to be. By the way, do you mind if I ask you something?
Person1: Go ahead.
Person2: Can you tell me more about yourself? What do you do?
Person1: I'm a journalist. I'm always looking for interesting stories.
Person2: That's fascinating. I've never met a journalist before. Maybe I can help you with a story sometime.

Person1: You're a smart operator, I'll give you that. I've been on a hot streak, so what? There's things that I could learn from you.
Person2: What's the matter? Legend has it you're king of the game.
Person1: I said, "There's a man I would work with. There's a man..." You know? I never said a thing. I should have, don't know why I didn't.
Person2: Mm. You eat today?
Person1: Yeah. Well, you want to swing by the diner, watch me eat, we'll talk?
Person2: I think I'd better stay here for a while.

Person1: You're so lucky to have found someone who loves you for who you are. I'm still trying to figure out why Gregory asked me out.
Person2: Maybe he likes you, ever think of that? You're losing it, thinking it's just about his screenplay idea.
Person1: I guess you're right. I've just been so focused on getting over Mark. But what's the deal with guys and their pickup lines? "Can I use your phone?" "How about a nightcap?"
Person2: Yeah, it's like they think we're stupid or something. But hey, at least Gregory didn't use any cheesy lines on you, right?
Person1: No, he was actually pretty normal. But I still don't know what to expect on the date. Do guys still pay, or is that old-fashioned?
Person2: I think it's nice when they offer, but it's not a big deal if they don't. Just be yourself and have fun, and don't worry too much about it.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's the only way. If we could get you, the device, and the power source in the vicinity of a unique energy surge, we could unlock its true potential.
Person2: You can't be serious, Dr. Lee. I heard strange noises last night, and I think it's connected to this device.
Person1: Strange noises, Emily? Now, stop being evasive. Those anomalies had a flight last night because of some unknown factor in this lab, and it wasn't the equipment or the environment.
Person2: You're not listening to me, Dr. Lee. I'm trying to tell you that I think this device is affecting us in ways we can't understand.

Person1: We're all tired, none of us had any sleep since Friday night...
Person2: That's why I don't believe you. You're trying to distract me from the truth.
Person1: The truth is, you're being paranoid. You're seeing conspiracies where there are none.
Person2: I'm not paranoid, I'm just trying to understand what's going on. You're not making it easy for me.
Person1: Maybe that's because you're not listening. You're too busy jumping to conclusions.

Person1: I've got to ask you something. Is it possible you saw something unusual last night?
Person2: No... Absolutely not. I was too tired to notice anything.
Person1: You don't. Think so.
Person2: I'm telling you, I didn't see anything. Can we drop it?
Person1: You're beautiful... your eyes sparkle when you're nervous. You're not telling me everything.
Person2: Stop staring. I'm not hiding anything.

Person1: I'm afraid we've got a problem, Jenkins. You know what we do to people who can't pay their debts, don't you?
Person2: I'm sorry, sir. I didn't mean to cause any trouble. It's just that I've been having a tough time lately.
Person1: That's not my concern. What is my concern is the fifty thousand dollars you owe us. Now, I think it's only fair that you get a chance to explain yourself. Tonight, at eight, in my office. We'll discuss the terms of your repayment.
Person2: Tonight? But sir, I don't know if I can...

Person1: We may have a chance.
Person2: Are you Herr Mller? 
Person1: That's right. 
Person2: My name is Anna, sir. I'm a journalist. I was asked to come here and offer my expertise to you. 
Person1: What? 
Person2: They'll be paid for by a great admirer of yours who wishes to remain anonymous.

Person1: I've got something you should take a look at, Captain.
Person2: What is it?
Person1: A report from the surveillance team at the docks. They've been monitoring some suspicious activity.
Person2: Really? Pack the evidence into a secure container and store it in the warehouse on 5th Street. We'll review it later.
Person1: You want me to throw it away, sir?
Person2: No, no, just store it safely. We don't want it falling into the wrong hands.

Person1: You know, I did think about quitting the team one time.
Person2: Yeah, what happened?
Person1: Hell, you know how Coach is. Says he's gonna bench us all... and I says, "Coach, you can't do that," and he says, "Well, then get the captain down here and let's settle this" and I says, "The captain's injured, Coach," and...
Person2: I figured, what's the point? I knew I'd just be taking my problems with me. Once the new season started, it made me look at the team with new eyes. I realized, what the hell could be better than this?

Person1: I've tried to stay open to voices of the people, you know? It's essential to remain honest to oneself.
Person2: Nuthin' I can't handle. But where do you go from here, in life?
Person1: Ah, I've been labeled a 'kingmaker' by many, but I've tried not to misuse that power. Maybe one day you shall find yourself in a similar position.
Person2: The truth is never let them see you sweat. You do that, that's half the battle.
Person1: Indeed, Chauncey. It's extremely important, when one is in a position of eminence, that he does not allow himself to become blinded to the needs of the country.
Person2: Haven't you always told me that all people are entertainers? The question is what are you gonna do, Ben?

Person1: You've been through a tough time, haven't you?
Person2: Yeah, but I'm anxious to get started on rebuilding. What's the most pressing issue here?
Person1: Well, there's a lot to tackle, but I think the key is to focus on the community's well-being. Once we get that right, the rest will fall into place.
Person2: I see what you mean. My brother used to say that when people come together, they can overcome anything.
Person1: That's a great attitude to have. I'm sorry to hear about your loss, by the way.
Person2: Thanks. It's still tough to talk about, but I appreciate your understanding. Maybe we can discuss something else?
Person1: Of course, let's focus on the positive. What do you think is the first step we should take to get this community back on its feet?

Person1: I really like you too, but I think we're getting in over our heads.
Person2: I know you still love me, but what's holding you back?
Person1: So, what do they think -- we're not kids -- we can't make our own decisions?
Person2: I'm sorry about getting on your case earlier. I just see us getting sucked into this situation deeper and deeper.
Person1: If we're being honest with ourselves, we're not ready for this. We should stop seeing each other.
Person2: Yeah, maybe you're right. I think we should take a step back and re-evaluate.

Person1: You mean I can have the book?
Person2: Leland said you could borrow it. She doesn't mind.
Person1: How do you know what she doesn't mind?

Person1: You know a lot about art, I guess. I've heard your uncle has been a great patron of the arts.
Person2: What is art, really? It's a reflection of the beauty in the world. I would do anything to support those who create it.
Person1: I'm so anxious for you to meet our new curator. She's doing wonders for the museum.
Person2: I'm looking forward to it. To me, she will always be a champion of the arts.

Person1: I said I'd help if you needed it. Let's just go through the notes and pick out some key points.
Person2: Mm-hm. Have you really covered everything I need to know? I don't think so.
Person1: All right, what's missing?

Person1: I'm supposed to meet Enid here, but she's not showing up. Do you know where she is?
Person2: Yeah, it's great that you're looking for her. You're really committed to this, aren't you?
Person1: What do you mean? I just need to talk to her about something.
Person2: Some people might think you're a bit too eager. Maybe she's hiding from you.
Person1: Why would she do that? We're just friends.
Person2: Friends? That's interesting. You know, some people have different ideas about commitment.
Person1: What are you trying to say? Do you know something about Enid that I don't?
Person2: Let's just say that Enid has a unique way of dealing with people. You might want to be careful around her.
Person1: Careful? What do you mean?
Person2: Never mind. If you want to wait for her, be my guest. But don't say I didn't warn you.

Person1: I have to go... 
Person2: Wait, I want to talk about this some more. 
Person1: There's no time for that now, we'll discuss it later.

Person1: I've been searching for a place to belong for a long time. When I'm with you, I think I've finally found it.
Person2: What makes you so sure?
Person1: I don't know why, I just think you're it. Take me in with you.
Person2: You're telling me that you want to be part of my life, but you're not considering what it means for me. You're not walking in my shoes.
Person1: I know it's a big decision, but I'm willing to take the risk. I've been alone for too long.
Person2: I understand that, but you need to understand me too. I've been hurt before, and I'm not sure I'm ready to open up again.

Person1: You're a genius, Allan! I finally got the venue I wanted for my dance quintet.
Person2: Thanks, I'm performing at Crane Jackson's Fountain Street Theatre on Tuesday night. I'd love it if you came and gave me notes.
Person1: I'll be there! By the way, I heard Mabel Dawson's apartment is available. Have you considered moving in?
Person2: Actually, I was thinking of taking a break from the city. Do you think that's a good idea?
Person1: Absolutely! You deserve a vacation. I'll make sure to spread the word that you're taking some time off.

Person1: I think you're being over-cautious, Mom. I've got as much business behind the wheel of a boat as anybody.
Person2: Don't be reckless, young man. You don't think about what you're doing and you'll run into a buoy. Besides, I want you to stay and help your father with the grill, he's not feeling well today.

Person1: You know my friend Rachel, right?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: Well, I got her something. What's the occasion, you ask? She deserves it, that's the occasion.

Person1: What's on your mind? You seem distracted.
Person2: I reached the top of the hill and saw something strange. It looks like a fake setup.
Person1: What do you mean? What did you see?
Person2: It's hard to explain. I just have a feeling that something is off.
Person1: Maybe we should investigate further. We can't be too careful.

Person1: You can't imagine.
Person2: It's what they want you to see.
Person1: I've tried everything! I've sent her telegrams, I've sent her flowers... I asked her to dinner... I offered her seats for the Opera...
Person2: Yes... Are you sure you want to do this?
Person1: That wouldn't have done any good. Not with her. She's the most incredible creature I've ever seen.
Person2: This is the way in?
Person1: You saw all that in one glimpse?
Person2: Yes. But you've done enough. Thank you for your help...
Person1: Timeless. When she comes into a room you'd think that the Bolsheviks had taken over Paris.
Person2: I hope someday people read your books again.

Person1: Think for a second. Is there someplace I wanted to go?
Person2: It still doesn't matter where you go.
Person1: No use waiting, then.

Person1: I'll die if I have to stay here another minute! I've waited a long time for this chance to go, and you're not going to stop me now.
Person2: You mean I can have the room?
Person1: It's OK. There's no problem. I've been planning this escape for months, and I won't let anyone get in my way.
Person2: Aren't you afraid to leave? You don't want to look like a fool, do you?
Person1: Fool? Who's been spreading rumors about me? I know it's that deceitful porter. He's been trying to sabotage my plans from the start.
Person2: I thought the porter had instructions from the manager not to give out rooms.
Person1: The manager? Ha! He's just a puppet on strings. I've been bribing the porter, and he's been helping me behind the manager's back.
Person2: Well, I suppose you're determined to get what you want.
Person1: You have no idea how determined I am. I'll do whatever it takes to get out of this place.

Person1: What's going on? You've been acting strange lately.
Person2: A few days... a few weeks - dunno, I can't remember. Worse thing is, I never know if it will change back again.
Person1: Are you kidding me? You're not making any sense. Can you explain what's happening to you?
Person2: Please, just leave me alone. I need some time to figure this out myself.

Person1: You know what we do to welchers, don't you?
Person2: Yeah right. What's the big deal?
Person1: We've got a long-distance relationship to make work. We both have cars.
Person2: Yeah but, no offense, you're talking about a post-high school, long-distance relationship.
Person1: That's not why we're going out. We're going to make it work, and I'll drive to see you whenever I can.
Person2: What the hell are you expecting me to do, drive to see you for milk and cookies?
Person1: I'm expecting us to make an effort. We can do this.
Person2: It's not a space shuttle launch, it's just us. So did you do the physics write-up?

Person1: Well, then there's only one thing to do.
Person2: What?
Person1: I think so. You will be contacted with the assignment.
Person2: Wait. What do you think? Of course yes! What's involved?
Person1: You must appear to live your life normally, conveying nothing.
Person2: Reverend Mother says you need experience, right, in life. In order to make a responsible decision.
Person1: The security of this nation depends on it. Can you do that?
Person2: This is going to be very painful for me. You know how much I love this little room. This whole convent.

Person1: Oh, Sophia!
Person2: I'm shyer than you think. I give the wrong impression sometimes and...
Person1: I haven't even been thinking about painting for weeks.
Person2: Stop staring. Do a landscape.
Person1: But you're captivating... your smile lights up the room. 
Person2: Thanks. But I just want to relax and...
Person1: That sparkle in your eyes -- the way you laugh... you're a work of art... you're why artists create masterpieces...
Person2: All right, cut me a break.

Person1: You're being ridiculous, Alex.
Person2: I think you know I'd do anything to make this work, even if it means looking silly.

Person1: I'm tired. Come to bed, now; tonight we're celebrating.
Person2: What are you talking about? You're being serious, aren't you?
Person1: I am serious. If we could get the time machine and the power converter in the vicinity of a major breakthrough, we could change the course of history.
Person2: You're talking crazy! A breakthrough would require years of research and development!
Person1: You forget - innovation is often instantaneous. The breakthrough would be a game-changer, but you would have already seen its impact. Of course, it's a moot point regardless. The only place real innovation happens is in the minds of visionaries, and those minds are often hard to access.

Person1: "You think it's worth it?"
Person2: "There are times... I wish I hadn't done it. But there are times that I feel compelled to do it..."
Person1: "I've got to get some answers. My readers want to know more about your powers."
Person2: "Ask, I'm an open book."
Person1: "Okay. Let's start with these strange abilities of yours. You think they're strange?"
Person2: "I guess they are a little odd. But I've learned to live with them."
Person1: "It must feel great to have such abilities. Do you ever feel like you're above the law?"
Person2: "No, I wouldn't do that. I believe in using my powers for good."
Person1: "How do you decide what's good and what's not?"
Person2: "It's not always easy, but I try to do what I think is right."

Person1: I can make it to the meeting on time, no sweat.
Person2: Oh, let's see... I can think of two reasons you're so confident.
Person1: What?
Person2: One, you're trying to make it all about being punctual and nothing else.
Person1: That's not it. You're crazy, man. Smart dresser, but crazy.
Person2: Good... Another is you're trying to prove something to yourself. Legend has it you're king of time management.

Person1: You're a smart dresser, but I think you're crazy to be giving me advice on the facts of life.
Person2: What's the matter? I'm just trying to be a good mentor. For example, on the self-abuse front, I want to make sure you're not wasting water and electricity in the shower.
Person1: I can make it to college and back in four years, that's no sweat. I think I can figure out the rest on my own.
Person2: Alright, alright. Just remember, it's not about being king of the road, it's about being responsible.

Person1: What's going on? You seem shaken.
Person2: I thought you would know, you're a detective. Of course you do. He became obsessed with her. She hated him.
Person1: Who are you talking about? What's the story behind this?
Person2: I'm not kidding. He had to have her. He kidnapped them to control her, to make her do things.
Person1: That's a disturbing tale. You're okay, though. You did the right thing.
Person2: Yeah, I sure know that. But how many more are out there like him?

Person1: I've been thinking about the way we perceive time. It's all relative, isn't it? Like a dream upon waking.
Person2: (laughs) You're not going to start talking about the emotional core of our memories, are you?
Person1: (smiling) No, no. I was just thinking about how we try to hold onto things that are slipping away. Like trying to get near someone who doesn't want to be gotten.
Person2: (sighs) I know the feeling. I've been trying to get in touch with this incredible woman, but she's not having it.
Person1: (curious) What's she like?
Person2: Timeless. When she walks into a room, it's like a storm has arrived. And those eyes... they're like a Russian snowstorm.
Person1: (teasingly) You're not just saying that because you're infatuated, are you?
Person2: (defensively) I'm just saying she's got a certain... je ne sais quoi. And I'm not giving up on her yet.

Person1: I've just started a new company. Solid financing. It's good.
Person2: Then who the heck are you?
Person1: Your old colleague, Miller. Do you remember the Goliath project?
Person2: Yes, I do. Don't let yourself down, Miller.

Person1: I've been thinking about my novel, and I realized that my counselor from freshman year inspired one of the characters.
Person2: That's interesting. What's the character's motivation?
Person1: I've been trying to understand homicidal impulse, and I think I've made some progress. By the way, I visited your office this morning and spoke with one of your colleagues.
Person2: What did you learn from them?
Person1: Let's just say that I have a better understanding of how information can be obtained. And I have to say, it's surprising how easily some people will talk.

Person1: I'ma keep on living, having a good drink, got me a good young woman, make a couple of dollars and make people laugh.
Person2: Is the doctor anywhere?
Person1: Well, you see, the doctor is at a conference, but I'm sure it's wrapping up by now. He should be checking in any moment.
Person2: Listen to me. I am Dr. Lee's colleague, and I need to discuss the Johnson case with him urgently.
Person1: The truth is, never let them see you sweat. You do that, that's half the battle.
Person2: What do you mean? This is no laughing matter.
Person1: I'm just saying, stay calm, and we'll get through this together.

Person1: Oh, you know, for a minute I thought we were all going to crash...
Person2: That's the only reason we made it this far...

Person1: We may have a chance to make a good impression.
Person2: I don't like the way you're dressed. I want you to wear something more elegant. Nice big pearls would suit you.
Person1: Now, I'm not going to wear ear-rings, I can tell you that. It's not my style.
Person2: Cute. Let's have some drinks and discuss this further.

Person1: I've made up my mind, Rachel. I'm staying in Willow Creek. It's perfect.
Person2: You know, I did think about leaving once. What's the point, though? I'd just be taking my problems with me.
