Person1: Exactly! And I've realized, what could be better than this? I'm telling you, it's a fresh start.
Person2: Please, don't be so quick to decide. You're not thinking clearly.

Person1: Feeling better, Peerless?
Person2: Nuthin' I can't handle.
Person1: That's the spirit. The truth is never let them see ya sweat.
Person2: I'm such a loser.
Person1: In life, I'ma keep on living, having a good drink, got me a good young woman, make a couple of dollars and make people laugh. What are you gonna do, Peerless?

Person1: I'm so frustrated with this traffic! It's a two-hundred dollar fine if I don't make it to the store on time.
Person2: I'm trying to help you, but you're not listening. You want to go to State, right? They've got a good business school.
Person1: Yeah, but what's the point? I'll just end up working in some corporate job I hate. And what's with all these extra essays they make you do? How am I supposed to know what my "most emotionally significant moment" was?
Person2: I feel you. I didn't want to write those essays either. That's why I chose Michigan. But hey, at least we can grab some outfits for the party tonight. Want to run in the store and pick out some clothes?
Person1: Yeah, sure. But only if we can make it quick. I still have to get back to the store and help my dad. He's always busy and stuff, and I fill in once a week so he can get a night off.
Person2: That's nice of you. You know, people are always like, "What're you gonna major in?" And I don't know. And they're like, "You'll figure it out." Yeah? When?

Person1: I've been thinking about the project's timeline. What would happen if we missed the deadline?
Person2: That would complicate things.
Person1: Because we'd be to blame, right? For the delays?
Person2: Not necessarily. We can classify the issue as a superpredator, something beyond our control.
Person1: You mean like a Spinosaurus Aegypticus? Something that wasn't on our radar?
Person2: Exactly. And who knows what else might be lurking beneath the surface?

Person1: I've waited a long time for this chance to explore the ancient temple. You're not going to stop me now.
Person2: Obviously a hidden chamber. Suchimimus. That structure.
Person1: They never got that precise. Baryonyx?
Person2: Not with that intricate design. Spinosaurus Aegypticus.
Person1: I'll die if I have to stay here another minute! I've been searching for this temple for years, and you're not going to take it away from me.
Person2: Do you mean to tell me you want to uncover the secrets of the temple? 
Person1: If I have to, I'll do it alone. It was I who deciphered the ancient texts. If it weren't for me, you'd never find the entrance!
Person2: I thought the texts had instructions from the ancient civilization not to disturb the temple.
Person1: The ancient civilization? Who pays any attention to them? The locals laugh at the legends. All they want to know is how much treasure they will find. Well, I've been searching for years. I'd do anything to uncover the secrets of this temple.

Person1: Shall we proceed?
Person2: He's completely out of his mind.
Person1: That's what I'm afraid of. Does he sleep?
Person2: Insomnia is common in his situation. But there's more to it than that. Perhaps in the end, he's trying to prove something to himself.
Person1: Prove what?
Person2: That he can still function, despite everything. Life is very different with him, as you can imagine...

Person1: What's the real story behind this? Who's backing you up?
Person2: Hey, I'm just trying to get the scoop!
Person1: Well, that's not going to happen. Either you share the details with everyone or...
Person2: Okay, okay. I'll call my editor. See you later.

Person1: Do you know how I define "protection," Officer James?
Person2: Are you for real? You're asking me that after what just happened?
Person1: I'm curious. You chose this profession, just like you could have poured coffee in Starbucks or installed track lighting in office buildings. But you chose to protect people. I find that very interesting.
Person2: It's not about the profession, it's about the people. And I'm not sure I'd call what you're doing "protection" either.

Person1: I'm a little disappointed in you, gratitude-wise. You wanted a raise, didn't you?
Person2: Oh, all right... I guess I did. But I didn't think it was a big deal.
Person1: Well, it's a big deal to me. You need to show more appreciation. Now, get back to work before you're late for the rehearsal!

Person1: What do you think is the most important quality for a leader to have?
Person2: I think it's empathy. I mean, I've seen people at their worst, and I still think they're OK, you know?
Person1: That's an interesting perspective. But don't you think that can also be a weakness?
Person2: No, I don't think so. I mean, I've walked in some tough shoes, and I know what it's like to have people judge you without knowing the whole story.
Person1: I see what you mean. But how do you respond to critics who say you're too soft on people?
Person2: I'd say they don't know what it's like to be in my shoes, to have to make the tough decisions and still sleep at night.

Person1: I've been trying to make it up to you.
Person2: There's one more thing I need you to do.
Person1: What's that?
Person2: Trust takes time to rebuild. Be patient.
Person1: I know, but I feel like I've been patient long enough.
Person2: I'll tell you when it's time.

Person1: Think for a second, did I tell you about my conversation with Ike?
Person2: No, what about it?
Person1: He's going to turn that tattoo stuff into a big deal. I know he's writing another article to get back at me.
Person2: For what reason? Some personal satisfaction?
Person1: I don't know, but I'm sure it's not good. Look, the game is getting intense!

Person1: So, you're looking for fun, adventure, trouble, I guess?
Person2: Yeah, something like that. But I think I'm in over my head. I really do.
Person1: You just relax. Nobody's going to hurt you, do you hear? I'll see what I can do to help.
Person2: Yeah, okay. Thanks. I'll call you back in an hour to see if you've found anything out.

Person1: I'm so tired. I don't understand what's going on.
Person2: Don't get alarmed. These are just some questions to help me figure out what's wrong.
Person1: But I told you, we were at the office party together. You have to remember that.
Person2: I'm trying to help you, but you need to focus. What's the last thing you do remember?
Person1: It's not important. The main thing is that I'm here now, and I'm going to make sure you're all right.
Person2: I appreciate that, but I need you to trust me. Just answer my questions, okay?

Person1: You think I'm the right person for this job?
Person2: Yes, I do. And if you prove yourself, you'll know that I believed in you and wanted to give you a chance.
Person1: I won't let you down.
Person2: So, what makes you think you can handle this kind of work?
Person1: I'll work anywhere, anytime. I know I can't be choosy.
Person2: That's the right attitude. Now, tell me about your experience.
Person1: Some here and there. I've had an honorable discharge from the military, and my driving record is clean.
Person2: That's good to know. We'll be in touch soon.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's like they're moving in the wrong direction. Away from when I even remembered what it was like to have a real connection with someone.
Person2: Now, now, let's not be too hard on them. We did take care of that project you assigned us, after all.
Person1: Yes, and now you've got two team members not pulling their weight in the new simulation. I don't have time for this, and neither do you.
Person2: We'll get them back on track, sir. These things take time.
Person1: I hope getting me thinking about everything that's wrong has some purpose. What is it that you want? What's with you?
Person2: I just want to help you, sir. You seem frustrated.
Person1: Leave me be! Why are you doing this? You want what?

Person1: I want to go back to that place!
Person2: It takes years to get there. And years to come back... What's the point, anyway?
Person1: I don't remember it anymore. Where's the old town hall?
Person2: Forget about it, kiddo. You're not going to find what you're looking for. Now go to bed, it's late.

Person1: I thought I'd call and see how you're doing.
Person2: Do you think you're the one who should be checking in on me?
Person1: Who's this 'should' business? Are you trying to make me feel guilty?
Person2: I'm serious. We have to discuss what happened last time we met.

Person1: You're such a talented liar. Now let's see you talk your way out of this one.
Person2: I wish I were a nice guy with the conscience of a criminal. Next best thing to no conscience at all.
Person1: You almost sound like someone who's trying to convince themselves of that.
Person2: Maybe I am. But I'm not a criminal if that's what you're thinking.
Person1: I'm not thinking that at all. I'm thinking you're someone who wants to have dinner with me, respectably, in my house with my family's picture on the mantel.
Person2: And after dinner, do we send your family to the movies and turn their picture to the wall?
Person1: No, we just enjoy each other's company. Without the need for pretenses.

Person1: I've been thinking about God a lot lately. I know it sounds crazy, but I feel like He's trying to tell me something.
Person2: What makes you think that?
Person1: I don't know, it's just a feeling. Like, I'll be walking down the street and I'll hear a voice in my head saying "turn left" or "stop and look around." It's weird, I know.
Person2: That does sound unusual. But maybe it's just your subconscious trying to guide you.
Person1: Maybe. But what if it's not? What if God is really trying to communicate with me?
Person2: Well, if that's the case, then I think you should listen to your heart and see where it takes you. Just be careful not to get too caught up in your own thoughts.
Person1: Yeah, I know what you mean. I don't want to end up like my brother, always talking to himself and thinking he's hearing voices.
Person2: Exactly. Just stay grounded and focused, and I'm sure you'll be fine.

Person1: I never thought I'd say this, but I'm glad you're considering my proposal.
Person2: Professor, be serious, would you? This plan is too risky.
Person1: I am serious. If we could get the necessary funding, we could make this project a reality. You realize now that you could never have done it without me.
Person2: Actually, I could have done it much more easily without you, but for whatever reason, I'm glad you're on board.

Person1: You have a unique perspective. Tell me, what have you seen that the mind can't fathom?
Person2: Why are you asking me this? You're not like the others.
Person1: I'm just trying to understand. You have a certain... lightness to you. A lighter density, perhaps?
Person2: You're referring to my abilities? I suppose they are a little odd.
Person1: I didn't mean to imply that. It's just that I've never met anyone like you. Can you really see through anything?
Person2: Yes, but it's not something I like to do. It's not always pleasant.
Person1: I can imagine. And what about pain? Are you truly impervious to it?
Person2: I can get a headache, just like anyone. But physical pain? No, I don't feel that.

Person1: You know, I've been thinking about the old days. Do you believe in the legend of the Sugar Witch?
Person2: Can't say that I do. But I do know someone who's still fascinated by it.
Person1: Really? Who's that?
Person2: My niece. She's still young and loves hearing stories about the Sugar Witch's helper, the Broom Man.
Person1: Ah, yes! I've heard of him. He's the one who leaves a trail of sugar outside the door of naughty children, right?
Person2: That's right! And if they don't behave, he'll sweep them away with his magical broom.
Person1: (laughs) Well, I suppose it's a creative way to keep kids in line. You know, I like that scarf, by the way. It really brings out the color in your eyes.
Person2: (smiling) Thanks, I just got it yesterday. I should get going, though. My niece is waiting for me to tell her more stories.
Person1: Give her a hug from me, and tell her I said the Sugar Witch is always watching!

Person1: I'm sorry I haven't been the partner to you that I should be.
Person2: SAY IT! Tell me what's really going on. You're not yourself lately.
Person1: I wasn't going to say it out loud, but... I feel like I'm stuck in a rut and I don't know how to get out.
Person2: And that's okay. Because I know you're trying. You're just not used to being vulnerable with me, that's all.

Person1: I'm not looking for a handout. I can take care of myself.
Person2: I didn't mean to imply that you couldn't. It's just... sometimes it's nice to have a place to crash for a couple of nights.
Person1: Yeah, that's right. Around. Here and there.
Person2: You're not from around here, are you? You don't have that... city vibe.
Person1: The material world is an illusion. It doesn't matter where I'm from.
Person2: Well, I suppose that's one way to look at it. But sometimes it's nice to have someone to talk to. Alice and Silky, they might be willing to give you a place to stay...
Person1: I didn't mean... I don't need their help. Thanks, though.
Person2: Suit yourself. But if you change your mind, I'm around.

Person1: I've been thinking, and I want you to have something to remember me by. You've been an incredible colleague, and I'm going to miss working with you.
Person2: That's very kind of you, but I don't know if I can accept anything.
Person1: Nonsense, I insist. I've seen the way you admire the designs in the office. Why don't you take a look around and pick the one that speaks to you the most? Just clear it with me first, and I'm sure it'll be fine.
Person2: I visited your office this morning, after you left. I saw the way you've arranged everything, and it's truly inspiring.
Person1: Ah, you caught me. I do have a certain fondness for my workspace. But I'm glad you appreciate it.

Person1: I'm telling you, it was a long time ago...
Person2: SAY IT! I want to know what really happened.
Person1: Okay, okay... I met him at this place called Moke's... We became friends... He told me about a job...
Person2: What job? You're not going to brush this off, are you?
Person1: I don't remember... Anyway, Andy's okay... I trust him.
Person2: I'm not so sure about that. He's got some questionable friends.

Person1: You're telling me you're "special"? What makes you so special?
Person2: PRINCIPAL COLLINS thinks I can handle a more challenging curriculum.
Person1: I had a brother who was special, too. He was a Marine in Vietnam.
Person2: I'm sorry to hear that. Did he...?
Person1: Yeah, he didn't make it back. But I'm proud of him. You know, I used to have a moonshine still in my shed, but I reckon I'll need to find a new spot for it now.
Person2: Why's that?
Person1: Well, I think it's time I cleaned up my act. For my brother's sake, and for yours, too.

Person1: Do you know how I define "success," Professor Thompson?
Person2: Nuthin' I can't handle. What do you mean by that?
Person1: The truth is never let them see you sweat. You do that, that's half the battle.
Person2: I'm afraid so; he's a realist. You'll have to be pragmatic.
Person1: Where do you go from here, in life?
Person2: I'ma keep on learning, having a good discussion, got me a good mentor, make a couple of discoveries and make people think.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a malfunction! Don't be such a girl about it...
Person2: Hal, is there anything bothering you? Anything that might account for this problem?
Person1: Look, I know you're sincere and trying to do a competent job, but I can assure you the issue is with the equipment, not me.
Person2: Okay, well let's see the way things go from here on. Maybe we can rule out any other possibilities.

Person1: You know, I did think about taking a different route to work one time.
Person2: Yeah, what happened?
Person1: I figured, what's the point? I knew I'd just be dealing with the same traffic. Then I realized, what the hell could be better than this? You're a good man for offering to drive me, by the way.
Person2: No problem. I just want you to know I appreciate it, though. It's for the office party fund.
Person1: Wow! You're really dedicated to that, aren't you?
Person2: Trust me, it'll be worth it.

Person1: I said I'd help if you really needed it. Let's just go to the store and pick out some tools.
Person2: What? You think I'm not capable of doing it myself?
Person1: All right, suit yourself. But it's not going to work without my assistance.

Person1: You're not even ready yet, looking like a junk yard. Is it sabotage, does my project mean nothing to you?
Person2: You could have poured coffee in Starbucks, you could have learned to install track lighting in office buildings... You could have been one of ten thousand things, but in the end, you chose to work with me. You made that decision... and I find that very, very interesting.
Person1: Show me someone who's genuinely interested, and I might have some consideration.
Person2: I'm trying to understand what drives you, what makes you tick. That's all.

Person1: You're quite the expert on this, aren't you? They're likely to ruin the entire project.
Person2: Leland, leave the blueprints alone... You don't understand the architecture. Stop it.
Person1: How do you know what I don't understand? I've worked on similar designs before.
Person2: Then it's fortunate that I have you to guide me. In the meantime, I instruct you to meet me at the conference room. We need to discuss the project's future.

Person1: I think we should reconsider our approach. It's frustrating when people don't see things our way.
Person2: You're right. Sometimes I feel like I'm fighting this battle alone.
Person1: You're not alone. We could wait and regroup, then come back with a stronger plan.
Person2: That's a good idea. I doubt we'd be successful if we pushed forward now.
Person1: Maybe it's hard to say, but I believe in your vision. Let's work together to persuade the others.

Person1: I don't remember that on InGen's list.
Person2: Please, I need to know what you're hiding.
Person1: I'm not hiding anything. I just don't know.
Person2: So tell me where the documents are.
Person1: They're not here. You've already searched the place.

Person1: Do you think she can do it?
Person2: I don't know. She's a very talented woman.
Person1: Where are you going now?
Person2: To the botanical garden. I heard it's lovely this time of year.
Person1: I've heard that too. Would you like to walk with me?
Person2: I'd love to. You know, I've been thinking about doing something crazy.
Person1: Oh? What's that?
Person2: Starting my own business. I've always been passionate about music.
Person1: That's not crazy at all! You should go for it. Do you have a business partner in mind?
Person2: Actually, I was thinking of asking you. You seem like someone with a lot of potential.
Person1: Me? I don't know... I'm not very good at business.
Person2: Nonsense! I think you'd be great. And I'll be patient with you, I promise.
Person1: Alright, why not? It could be fun.
Person2: Wonderful! I'll teach you everything you need to know.

Person1: You could save him, little bird.
Person2: What do you want more than anything?
Person1: I told you what I want.
Person2: I don't know, I need time to think.
Person1: Why don't you think about it for a while?

Person1: I'm afraid there's been a misunderstanding, Captain Lewis. I'm Dr. Patel, the chief engineer. I wasn't informed about your inspection today.
Person2: Well, it's been a slow season, and I'm not getting any younger. I don't conduct inspections every ten years, I get a little restless.

Person1: Think for a second. Is there someplace you wanted to go?
Person2: I don't remember. I've been wet to the skin. You must've fallen in.
Person1: Lucky you got out, that water's got quite a pull, and it empties straight into the ocean.
Person2: I guess so. Smells like it. Tastes like it.

Person1: I'm giving you a chance to prove yourself. If you can't deliver, we'll have to reevaluate our partnership.
Person2: It's OK. There's no problem. I'll make sure to get it done on time.
Person1: Well, that's what I said, isn't it? I expect nothing but the best from my team members.
Person2: I understand. But what if I encounter any obstacles? Who should I turn to for help?
Person1: If anyone's caught slacking off, we'll have to take drastic measures. But I'm confident you'll rise to the challenge.
Person2: I appreciate your trust in me. I won't let you down.

Person1: I'm afraid we're running low on staff, Professor Thompson. Respect my wish and take a seat.
Person2: A pecking party, you say? I think you'll find our meeting will be quite...enlightening.

Person1: I've noticed you've been struggling to keep up in class lately. What's going on?
Person2: It's just... I feel like I'm not cut out for this program. Everyone else seems to understand the material so easily.
Person1: Now, don't get alarmed. I just want to rule out some things. Let's take a closer look at your learning style and see if there's a way to make the material more accessible to you.
Person2: Like what? Is there something wrong with me?
Person1: It's okay to need a little extra help sometimes. And I'm here to support you through it. We can work together to find a solution that works for you.

Person1: You're looking for fun, adventure, trouble, I guess.
Person2: You're crazy. I think you're the one who's looking for that.
Person1: Well, I did find something of yours...you left it at the park that day.
Person2: Oh, really? What's that?

Person1: We've been discussing who gets to take the credit for this project. Heads or tails?
Person2: I'm very grateful to be part of the team, but I think it's unfair to make it a competition. Can't we just focus on the outcome?

Person1: I don't think you'll have time for that meeting after all.
Person2: I'll find a way to make it work.
Person1: Take your time, but I really don't think so.
Person2: What makes you so sure?
Person1: He said something like, "Do you want to reschedule?" or something. I tried to explain, but he wasn't listening.
Person2: I understand. Did you feel like he was pushing you to make a decision?
Person1: Yes, exactly. I said no, but he kept pushing. It was frustrating...

Person1: You don't ride him anymore, do you? Not since your dad died.
Person2: What do you want from me? Name it. You want money?
Person1: Forget you. I know you're crazy, but forget you.
Person2: You gonna write me a check?

Person1: You're really something, aren't you? Most likely to succeed?
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: We've been given a gift, having you around. You need us, and we need you.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: Don't play dumb. You're not like the others. You have a certain spark.
Person2: Spark? You're the one who's been acting strange, not me.
Person1: Strange? I'm just trying to understand you. You're not like anyone I've ever met.
Person2: Maybe that's because I'm not trying to impress you.

Person1: I'm telling you, I'm too successful. My wealth is suffocating me. That's my biggest problem.
Person2: Mr. Johnson, do you admit that your company's latest marketing campaign was launched without proper permits and in full public view?
Person1: You know I do. What's the point of hiding it?
Person2: Very well. Let the record show that the defendant has acknowledged the allegations.

Person1: I've been feeling really down lately. Depression is a terrible thing.
Person2: I know, but in my own way, I'm here for you.

Person1: I think we'd like very much. We're running out of options.
Person2: That might be the news we've been waiting for. I love you, Alex, and always will.
Person1: I have a suggestion. There's really not much time left. Can you take care of everything here and meet me at the gate?

Person1: I'm telling you, it's the only way. If we could get the prototype and the power source in the vicinity of the volcano, we could harness its energy.
Person2: You're not serious, are you? That's crazy talk!
Person1: I'm dead serious. It's a matter of being in the right place at the right time. And I know you're not feeling strange about this, but...
Person2: Why would I feel strange about it? It's just a wild idea, that's all.
Person1: Good. Because I really liked the idea of using renewable energy, and this could be the breakthrough we need. And I know the team would've supported this if they'd seen the potential, or...
Person2: And what makes you think this will work? Have you run any simulations?

Person1: Do you know what I'm trying to say?
Person2: You're trying to say something, but I'm not sure what. It's like being at the beach, where life first crawled out of the sea. I come here sometimes... when I feel lost.
Person1: If one day I'm gone, and you read this, I want you to know how much you mean to me. Although I'll never see you again, your smile, your eyes, your laughter...
Person2: You don't have to do this. You don't have to leave a message for me. I'm here with you now.

Person1: You're being ridiculous.
Person2: I think someone's out of their mind. He's been acting strangely all day.
Person1: What do you mean? Did something specific happen?
Person2: Yes, he yelled at me for no reason, then stormed out. I'm worried about what he might do next.
Person1: I'll come with you to talk to him. Maybe we can figure out what's going on.

Person1: You know me...I never hurt anybody. What's the plan for tonight?
Person2: Oh, well, you know. I just take a little, leave a little. Not enough to notice.
Person1: That's right. You're a thousand percent right! So, where's the party?
Person2: A person that don't look out for himself is too dumb to look out for anybody else. He's a liability, right?
Person1: Yeah? You really think so? I've been thinking the same thing.
Person2: You know, I like that idea, it somehow makes me feel more confident. I better get going, though.
Person1: Worries about being late, eh? Give yourself a pat on the back for me.

Person1: I can feel it. Something's gonna blow in this town.
Person2: What are you talking about, Rachel? You're starting to scare me.
Person1: I saw the way you looked at me when I walked in. You're hiding something.
Person2: I'm not hiding anything. You're just being paranoid.
Person1: Paranoid? You're the one who's been acting strange all week. What's going on?
Person2: Nothing. I just...I don't know, okay? Maybe I'm just stressed out.
Person1: Stressed out? You're not stressed out, you're lying to me. And I'm going to find out what it is.

Person1: I've been tracking your movements, and I know you've been switching between different stations. What's going on?
Person2: Oh, I was just trying to help Andres with his music, but he wanted my secret. I told him he had to figure it out on his own.

Person1: You're really struggling, aren't you?
Person2: I'm such a loser. I want you to take my place, I don't think I can do this.
Person1: That's the spirit. Let's switch roles and see if it makes a difference.

Person1: I think you're a nice person. I like you. But I can read signs if the print is large enough.
Person2: But I like being part of this community now.
Person1: Suppose you hadn't found this place? Hadn't met these people?
Person2: I'm supposing.
Person1: It was your manner more than your words that made me curious. A sort of tenseness, as if you were searching for something.
Person2: We're going back to our roots, I think. Rediscovering what's truly important.

Person1: I've got a plan to increase the population with great rapidity. We give a couple seven years to raise a family.
Person2: That sounds like a superpredator approach. How do you classify it?
Person1: Not at all. It's strictly on the up and up. We're looking for a natural increase, not some forced growth.
Person2: I'm not sure I agree. What if, by that time, there is no branch upon the family tree?
Person1: Then we'll have to reassess our approach. But we won't stand them up against the wall, if that's what you're thinking.
Person2: Good. I was worried you were going to say "and Pop goes the Weasel!"
Person1: Ha! No, nothing like that. We'll work with the couple to find a solution that works for everyone.
Person2: That sounds more like Spinosaurus Aegypticus - a collaborative approach.
Person1: Exactly! And who knows what else we might discover along the way?

Person1: I said I'd help if you needed it. Let's just go through the garage sale and find some good deals.
Person2: It's okay. I know you're still upset about the argument earlier.
Person1: Yeah, I was out of line. But I just see us getting stuck in this rut, and I... anyway. I'm sorry.
Person2: All right, let's go.

Person1: I've been trying to go easy on you, but this can't continue. We need to address the issues with your cooking skills.
Person2: Don't worry about that now, child, it will all come back to you now that you're back in the kitchen... I mean, I've been overwhelmed with all the other recipes on my plate.
Person1: I appreciate your willingness to learn. Let's work on a plan together to improve your culinary skills.
Person2: I understand. And I do remember that awful plum pudding I made last Christmas... maybe we can start with a new recipe.

Person1: You're in such a hurry. You can't wait.
Person2: That's a good idea. I'll wait for a bit.
Person1: You know when I wait? When it's important to wait. Like when we're trying to get the perfect shot.
Person2: I doubt it's that important. We can just improvise.
Person1: Maybe, but I want to make sure we get it right. You can't rush art.
Person2: Fine, but if we're not done in an hour, I'm leaving.

Person1: Are you sure you want to take on this project by yourself? There are plenty of experts around here who could help.
Person2: I need the time to focus on my own work, and I could use a break from the team. Besides, I want to scoop this opportunity before anyone else does.
Person1: Alright, but don't say I didn't warn you. If you need any help, don't hesitate to ask.
Person2: Will do, thanks. I'll catch you later.

Person1: I'm trying to get out of my comfort zone, you know? Meet new people.
Person2: Yeah right. I got an idea for something new. How 'bout you guys actually find some courage, remove the barriers, and take a chance?
Person1: I'm sorry. I can't. I've been hurt before.
Person2: Hey now, it's been a slow decade. I don't make connections every ten years, I get a little cranky.
Person1: It's also been a long time for me. I'm working on something new.
Person2: Nonsense. From where? Online dating?
Person1: Nah, I met her at my part-time job. We bonded over our shared love of books.
Person2: Hah! Yeah, I bet it's more like you're trying to get a good story to tell.

Person1: I'm glad to hear that Steven's doing well.
Person2: Do you think he can do it?
Person1: Not really. The last time I saw him was at that conference. That was a long time ago.
Person2: Which one?
Person1: The one in Chicago.
Person2: He's a very sweet man.
Person1: Yes, he is. But I don't think he's the right person for the job.
Person2: Where are you going now?
Person1: Back to the office. I have a meeting to prepare for.
Person2: Someone waiting for you?
Person1: Just my colleagues. We need to discuss the project proposal.
Person2: I see. Well, good luck with that.

Person1: I've been thinking of volunteering at the local animal shelter.
Person2: Oh, that's great! I'm sure they'll appreciate your help.

Person1: I've been thinking, we could use someone with your skills on our team. You'd be a great asset.
Person2: You're not the first one to promise me a golden opportunity. What makes you think I'd be interested?
Person1: Shhh, listen to me. I'm not like the others. I can offer you a chance to make a real difference.
Person2: Save it, I've heard it all before. What's in it for you?
Person1: Honestly, I just want to see you succeed. You have potential.
Person2: Yeah, right. And I'm sure the SecGen would be thrilled to hear about your little offer.

Person1: I've been on this case for months. I think it's time we got some fresh eyes on it.
Person2: That's the point, isn't it? Bringing in someone with a new perspective?
Person1: Exactly. I'm not getting any younger, and I don't want to miss anything. Can you take a look at the evidence we've got so far?
Person2: Of course. I'll review everything and get back to you. But I have to ask, what's the real reason you're stepping back from this case?

Person1: I'm not good at standing up for myself in meetings.
Person2: Get good at it. You can't let others walk all over you.
Person1: It's against my nature. I'd rather avoid conflict.
Person2: And I'd take it out on myself if I didn't speak up. Let's practice together, I'll help you prepare.

Person1: I'm curious, how do you remember how to talk?
Person2: Now, I've been thinking about that car crash... I told you, I remember the glass.
Person1: Yes, and now you're here, in this place. Do you think about that sometimes?
Person2: I do. I also think about how I got here, sort of. But I don't remember much else.
Person1: That's fascinating. I wonder how you'll adapt to this new environment.
Person2: I'll get used to it, sir. These things take time.

Person1: I don't want to be childish, I'd settle for just a few years...
Person2: What are you talking about? You're not making any sense.
Person1: I don't remember us. I don't even remember me. It's like I'm stuck in some kind of limbo.
Person2: Take care of yourself out there... You're not going to find what you're looking for by dwelling on the past.
Person1: Am I going to lose you? Am I? You're the only one who knows me.
Person2: As of this moment, you're starting fresh. Let's leave the past behind us.

Person1: So, what brings you to our little vineyard today?
Person2: Just looking for a new adventure, I guess. I've heard great things about your Syrah.
Person1: Ah, our Syrah is a crowd-pleaser. What do you think of it so far?
Person2: It's excellent. I can see why people rave about it.

Person1: I managed to get the last copy of your book at the store. I couldn't believe my luck!
Person2: That's great, but I'm more concerned about getting out of here. Do you think the roads are open?
Person1: Well, the one to town is, but that's about it. I was thinking we could flip a coin to see who gets to go first.
Person2: Tails.
Person1: Alright, you win. But before we go, I have to say, I peeked at the first page of your book. It's like visiting an old friend.
Person2: I'm glad you like it. But I really need to get home to my daughter. She must be worried sick about me.
Person1: Don't worry, I'm sure she'll be fine. We'll get you out of here soon.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a bad idea.
Person2: Leave it to you to overthink things when you're nervous.
Person1: Why are you pushing me to do this?
Person2: I told you, it'll be fun.
Person1: You don't care if I get hurt.
Person2: Of course I do. I just think you need to take some risks.
Person1: Why? So you can say "I told you so"?
Person2: See that? You're already getting defensive. That's exactly why you need to do this.
Person1: Just let me think about it, okay?
Person2: Take your time. But don't say I didn't warn you.

Person1: You know, this, what you're doing with your life...
Person2: Are you crazy?
Person1: I don't know. I just think you're capable of more.
Person2: Let's see how much you want to play. If you're so concerned, why don't you show me what you'd do differently?

Person1: What do you want from me? Name it.
Person2: He said if I didn't give the money, he'll kill me.
Person1: I wouldn't take that too seriously. You gonna write me a check?
Person2: I believe what he said. You think they're only trying to scare me?
Person1: We'll go to my bank. I'll make a withdrawal. They're just trying to intimidate you.
Person2: Words can hurt very much. How do you know what they're doing?
Person1: I don't, but as long as they think you have the money, or know where it is... You mustn't let what he said bother you.
Person2: It was only words. I'll remember that you're on my side.
Person1: Good night.

Person1: You're not going to get out of this, you know.
Person2: Thinking I can just walk away feels pretty crazy. And trying to...
Person1: You didn't try. That's my point.
Person2: It's in my nature, you know. My father always said I was a runner...
Person1: Listen, if having a flawed family made you a quitter, the world'd be one colossal mess. You're going, so grab your coat.

Person1: I want to apologize for what happened at the game yesterday. I know I let the team down.
Person2: Stand tall, kid. I don't want to see you slumped over like that. You're better than that. Now, let's talk about what we can do to improve for the next game.

Person1: You know we're right.
Person2: I mean, in here. Out here. Whatever. It's all the same.
Person1: Once it's spent, you won't have to worry about it.
Person2: You just keep doin' what it looks like you're supposed to, even if it seems crazy.
Person1: Be like a weight off your shoulders.
Person2: I hate to disappoint you, pal, but that's how it is for most of us.

Person1: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to invite the whole class, that's all.
Person2: Well, now they're all here. You better put on some music. I can't stand this silence.
Person1: No music. We don't want to disturb the neighbors.
Person2: I may get bored.
Person1: So get bored. Boredom, excitement, laughter, games - this may even turn out to be a fun night.
Person2: What's the plan?
Person1: Uh-uh. Not yet.
Person2: When?
Person1: We better have a snack first.
Person2: Here, try this. It's my new recipe.
Person1: No fair guessing.

Person1: I'll work anywhere, anytime. I know I can't be choosy.
Person2: You don't understand, I can't let you do that!
Person1: You want to know my driving record?
Person2: No, it's not that. I just can't let you take this job.
Person1: How's that? You're the one who's hiring.
Person2: I know, but you're not thinking clearly. You're not considering the risks.
Person1: I've got a clean record, real clean. As clean as my conscience.
Person2: That's not what I'm talking about. You're not thinking about your own well-being.
Person1: I'm twenty-six, honorable discharge, May 1971. I can take care of myself.
Person2: Fine, fill out these forms and give them to the girl at the desk. But I'm warning you, this isn't a job for the faint of heart.

Person1: I'm not sure I can trust you. You're being awfully kind.
Person2: Spider-Man is a good guy. On the side of right, and niceness, and cute baby animals and all that.
Person1: What's that supposed to mean? You're trying to distract me.
Person2: Don't need none of that suspicion. Just trying to help.
Person1: I appreciate it, but I think it'd be best if I got going.
Person2: Fine. But think it'd be best if you got your wits about you before you try to...

Person1: I didn't mean to upset you. Are you afraid of his reaction? Of his finding you silly for thinking of such things?
Person2: No, I'm just frustrated. He's been distant lately, and I feel like I'm walking on eggshells around him. I didn't mean I didn't want to talk about it because of you being cut up. I didn't mean that.
Person1: What's going on with you two? You seem really upset.
Person2: It's just little things. He didn't ask me about his friend staying over, and now I'm feeling like I'm not being heard. I know it's his house, but it feels like I'm just a guest sometimes.
Person1: That must be really tough for you. Do you think you can talk to him about it?
Person2: I don't know. I'm not even sure I want to right now. I'm just going through this phase where I don't want him to touch me, and it's making everything feel really strained.

Person1: You're a real surprise package, Alex. I wouldn't have thought you had it in you.
Person2: Yes, well, that's another one of those situations where I surprised myself too.

Person1: I'm not going to the party tonight.
Person2: You'd be amazed at how much fun you can have.
Person1: I've read that the host is a bit of a snob. I don't think I'd fit in.
Person2: You can't believe everything you hear. Besides, I'll be there to keep you company.
Person1: Okay, but if I get bored, I'm leaving.
Person2: Hope no one tries to convince you to stay.

Person1: You deserve it, is the occasion.
Person2: Why do I let you talk me into these things? Why?
Person1: Because we're pals - buddies. I got you something to make up for it.
Person2: What's the point of getting me something if you're just going to convince me to do something crazy again?
Person1: Hey, it's not that crazy. We can play miniature golf to make it up to you.
Person2: You know I'm terrible at that. Just admit you want to see me embarrass myself.

Person1: I'll be at the desk, but don't introduce me, let it go, just start talking. You're gonna be here, behind 'em when they sit down.
Person2: Sometimes I really hate it when you do this. You're being mysterious again.
Person1: That's right, they're wondering, who's this guy? I don't owe them an explanation.
Person2: Yeah? Well, why don't you try being more transparent for once? It would be a nice change.

Person1: I've never bent my knees, have you?
Person2: We haven't fully identified the anomalies yet. They're calling this whole area The Briar Patch.
Person1: I want to, but I can't. I don't know what to say.
Person2: For evil to bend its knee, admit its guilt, implore His forgiveness, is the hardest thing on earth.
Person1: You have no idea what precipitated this behavior?
Person2: It's the hardest and the greatest. We need to understand the environmental concerns.
Person1: What kind of concerns?
Person2: Have you ever implored forgiveness, Malcolm?

Person1: We're having a guest over for dinner. I didn't invite him, but he's going to stay until he heals up.
Person2: Yeah, I guess I did some interesting things on my little escapade. What's going to happen to me?
Person1: We're going to leave that up to Detective James. I'll tell you though, you're okay. You helped a real victim.
Person2: Yeah, I sure know that. But how many more are out there who need help?

Person1: I heard he's been in touch with some old friends.
Person2: Yeah, he's been calling every once in a while.
Person1: What's he been saying?
Person2: Not much, just small talk. He's been different since he got out, though.
Person1: How so?
Person2: He's been talking about settling down, living a normal life.
Person1: That's not like him, is it?
Person2: No, it's not. He's always been about the thrill, the rush. But I think he's getting tired of it all.
Person1: Do you think he's serious about changing?
Person2: I don't know. He's always been fun, but never what you'd call reliable.

Person1: I've been thinking of switching careers and pursuing a life in paleontology.
Person2: Are you sure you want to do that? You've invested so much in your current field.
Person1: Sometimes I feel like I'm just going through the motions and not making a real impact.
Person2: That's a Baryonyx fossil you're looking at, by the way. Notice the claw on its thumb?
Person1: Yeah, I've always been fascinated by prehistoric creatures. Maybe I can make a difference in that field.
Person2: It's a big decision. Make sure you've thought it through. But hey, who knows what discoveries you might make?

Person1: I'm getting a little spooked. Would you mind walking ahead of me to the observation deck? I feel funny about being up here alone.
Person2: That's a problem. We can't let our target out of our sight. We need to get a good look at him.
Person1: Are you telling me nobody knows what he looks like? Come on, there must be some kind of description.
Person2: His file is classified, but I'm sure we'll figure it out. Let's just focus on getting into position.

Person1: You never thought that's a heavy load?
Person2: 'Course you could just wait in there while we go back and get help.
Person1: We allus thought you was strong enough to carry it. Was we wrong?
Person2: I doubt it.

Person1: I'm sorry. I can't. I....
Person2: There is no one here but the dead.
Person1: Hey now, outside of a very friendly dog this morning, it's been a slow decade.
Person2: If that were true, I would not be here.
Person1: It's also been a long time for me. I--
Person2: It's very dangerous to assume you know what a woman wants.

Person1: You were at the concert? Well, that explains -- yes I was there. I was there with Ruby.
Person2: Shut up! You swore!
Person1: I told you! I knew it! Ruby loves you. She's -- I think you'll find she's coming home to you.
Person2: How would you know that? You could save her, little bird.
Person1: Ruby told me everything. I was supposed to meet her fifteen minutes ago, so I... I'm going to go now, I think. Unless she meant us to meet -- which would be a little cruel, wouldn't it?

Person1: You talking to me?
Person2: I answer to Grissom, not to you.
Person1: Look, I know this is your office and all, but do you think you could keep it down? I'm trying to meet a deadline.
Person2: What's the project about?
Person1: A marketing campaign for a new eco-friendly product.
Person2: Sounds interesting. I've got some ideas that could help.
Person1: Really? I'd love to hear them.
Person2: But first, let's take a break and grab a cup of coffee. My treat.
Person1: I don't know... I'm on a tight schedule.
Person2: Come on, it'll be a quick break. I promise.

Person1: I've been noticing strange occurrences in my apartment. Do you have some explanation?
Person2: Heads or tails? We can discuss it over dinner at a fine restaurant.
Person1: What's that supposed to mean? Can't you tell me now?
Person2: I found an interesting passage in an ancient text. It refers to a powerful entity worshipped by the Hittites and Sumerians.
Person1: That's fascinating, but what does it have to do with my apartment?
Person2: I think we should meet Thursday night at nine to discuss it further. I'll bring the text along.
Person1: I'm not sure I'm free Thursday. Why is it so important?
Person2: I respect your curiosity as an individual, and I'm making an exception to share my findings with you.
Person1: Alright, I'll see you Thursday. But please, no more games.

Person1: I've been to worse places, but this one takes the cake. It's worse than anywhere you've ever been.
Person2: What were you doing around my neighborhood the other night? I could've sworn I saw you snooping around.

Person1: I got a job now. I'm teaching high school. Japanese and Chemistry.
Person2: That's interesting. You know, sometimes when we get 'em, they're not completely dead, you know, like when they cut a chicken's head off and it still runs around crazy.
Person1: What are you talking about? That has nothing to do with my new job.
Person2: I was just making conversation. You're the one who brought up your job out of the blue.

Person1: Do you know who that is?
Person2: Don't answer me. Say what I say.
Person1: You're trying to make a point, but I'm not sure what it is.
Person2: I'm trying to show you that our past defines us, whether we like it or not. My mother's story is a part of me, just like your father's legacy is a part of you.
Person1: That's not fair. We can't be held responsible for what our parents did.
Person2: Maybe not, but we can't escape the shadows they cast either. We have to confront them head-on if we want to be free.

Person1: What do you want from me? Name it.
Person2: You still haven't made a decision? What's the hurry?
Person1: Others are waiting for an answer.

Person1: I've tried to stay open to voices of the people, but I'm worried about your injury.
Person2: It's okay, forget it. I'll be fine.
Person1: Forget it? Are you crazy? Let me see it. I've tried to remain honest to myself, and I think you need medical attention.
Person2: I see what you're saying. Maybe one day I'll learn to prioritize my own well-being.

Person1: I think it's important not to get depressed. Depression is a terrible thing.
Person2: Your words are a compelling argument, but I've made a fool's game of my life already.
Person1: So is trying to change now. But you invited me into your life, and I'm here to help.
Person2: And I appreciate that.

Person1: You know, this structure... 
Person2: The main spire.
Person1: The... oh, the spire! How impressive, it's as if it touches the sky... Where did you learn to design something like this?
Person2: I don't know, it just came to me.
Person1: You seem like a talented person. You know, life moves on, and we should make the most of it.
Person2: Yeah, well, I'm just trying to make a difference.

Person1: What do you want from me? Name it.
Person2: An evil chef? No, maybe, like, work in a bakery or something.
Person1: You're going to open a bakery? I'll help you with the startup costs.
Person2: You always do that! Anyways, this is really hard, because, you know, my Dad is really particular about food.

Person1: You just relax. Nobody's going to hurt you, do you hear?
Person2: Is Grandma Harper alive?
Person1: Alive and hale. She's throwing a little surprise party for her own family. Why don't you go to bed, kiddo?
Person2: I can't take my eyes off you. You're legendary, just like my English literature teacher said.
Person1: That's nice. You thank her for me. Go to bed and get lots of sleep, and then you thank her in the morning.
Person2: Tomorrow's Saturday. Anyway, I've got double-decker bunks if you can't wake Grandma up.
Person1: Scat! And don't worry, I'll make sure Grandma is okay.

Person1: I'm not good company. I should be alone.
Person2: I have a suggestion. Why don't I take care of everything here and meet you at the gate? We can grab a coffee and catch up.
Person1: You don't have to do this. I mean, you haven't had a minute alone yet...
Person2: Of course not. I'd like to help. Besides, it's not every day I get to meet someone new.

Person1: I had my suspicions, though, about the new policy.
Person2: You mean you're interested in the job offer?
Person1: Well, that's what I said, isn't it?
Person2: Very well. That means you're willing to relocate to our branch in the city.
Person1: That is good. But I'd like to know more about the team I'll be working with.
Person2: I'm afraid I'm not able to tell you much. Only that the team leader is a seasoned professional with years of experience.
Person1: That will mean another interview, won't it?
Person2: No, this is quite final. You see, the company is expanding rapidly, and we need someone with your skills on board.
Person1: But it's such a big change...
Person2: That's rather exciting, isn't it?

Person1: I distinctly heard it. He muttered under his breath, "You're next."
Person2: You're crazy! You don't understand, I can't!
Person1: No, I'm not. We were walking off the tennis court, and you know, he was there and me and his wife, and he looked at her and then they both looked at me, and under his breath he said, "You're next."
Person2: Listen, Doug took the rap for us all so grab your coat 'cause you're going.
Person1: Wh- How am I supposed to go? You know, I was having lunch with some guys from NBC, so I said... uh, "Did you eat yet or what?" and Tom Christie said, "No, didchoo?" Not, did you, didchoo eat? You're next? No, not did you eat, but You're next? You get it? You're next eat?
Person2: Ah, forget it. Let's get the hell outta this crazy city.
Person1: Forget it? You keep bringing it up, but I don't wanna live in a city where the only cultural advantage is that you can make a right turn on a red light.
Person2: Right, forget it. Aren't you gonna be late for meeting Annie?
Person1: I'm gonna meet her in front of the Beekman. I think I have a few minutes left. Right?

Person1: I'm grieved to keep you waiting. Had you not better to arrange with my doctor?
Person2: Maybe... I don't know, if you want to talk about it.
Person1: Is it not a pleasure, gentlemen, for me, as I am drawing near the goal, to find my home such a happy one?
Person2: This guy wants his money. I'm sorry for you, Mr. James.
Person1: I hope that you are not thinking of leaving us soon, knight?
Person2: Naw, it's... I mean... Not so soon, my dear, as you may fancy perhaps.

Person1: I'll stay behind and hold them off. The rest of you break for it!
Person2: At least you knew about the plan. And you knew it'd be risky.
Person1: What are you talking about? This wasn't part of the plan.
Person2: Yes, and now that I've shown you that I know that much, and can guess more -- will you trust me to get us out of this?

Person1: I've seen some rough places in my time, but this takes the cake. It's worse than anywhere I've ever been.
Person2: I think you're being dramatic. I've been in tough spots before, and I've always managed to come out on top.
Person1: You don't know what you're talking about. You've never been in a situation where you had to put your hands up in surrender.
Person2: Actually, I have. And I remember the person on the other side being pretty shaken up afterwards.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you?
Person2: Well, I just figured it should be the one with the most experience who leads. But if that ain't the consensus view, hell, let's discuss it!
Person1: Suits me! I think we should put it to a debate.
Person2: Agreed. And may the best argument win!

Person1: I'm not going to the meeting. 
Person2: Are you tellin' me nobody knows what's going on? Come on, there must be someone who's informed. 
Person1: That is a problem. There is no agenda, no known attendees. 
Person2: Okay. Hope someone takes notes.

Person1: You look at me as though I had said something foolish...
Person2: That's the general idea. Only it's not so general as far as I'm concerned.
Person1: What do you say? What can you say? No. At least, not yet.
Person2: You are talking crazy!
Person1: I'm sorry, I just wish that everything were so much simpler... that people could just come together by the color of their hair or the size of their shoes.
Person2: So, what's the point of all this?

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a bad idea to invest in that startup.
Person2: What's the worst that could happen? It's not like we're talking about ransom money or something.
Person1: Exactly! We're not talking about billions of dollars in war reparations. It's just a small investment.
Person2: Yeah, but have you considered the long-distance aspect of it? I mean, the startup is in Silicon Valley and we're on the East Coast.
Person1: So what? We have video conferencing technology. It's not like we need to drive across the country for milk and cookies.
Person2: I'm just saying, it's not going to be easy. We need to have the right strategy, the right timing, the right moment to make it work.
Person1: I understand what you're saying, but sometimes you just need to take a leap of faith. It's not a space shuttle launch, it's just a business investment.

Person1: I don't know you, so I have no right, but I think you'll find he's coming home to you.
Person2: What are you talking about? Who's coming home to me?
Person1: Alex. I was supposed to meet him fifteen minutes ago, so I... I'm going to go now, I think.
Person2: Wait, you're the one who's been seeing him behind my back?
Person1: Sometimes I really hate myself for getting involved in this.

Person1: I'm telling you, Alex, it's all about perspective. Helping people, or righting wrongs, or trying to save the world... it all seems so abstract.
Person2: Abstract? You're the one who's been stuck in a rut, Rachel. You used to be a force to be reckoned with. Now you're just going through the motions.
Person1: That's not fair. I've just been re-evaluating my priorities, that's all. And I've come to realize that it's time for a change.
Person2: A change? You mean like getting out of the game altogether? I don't think you're ready for that, Rachel. You're not obsolete yet.
Person1: Obsolete? You're one to talk, Alex. You've been holding on to the past for too long. It's time to move on.
Person2: Move on? To what? A desk job? I don't think so. I've got a meeting with Victor tomorrow on the TGV, en route to Berlin. Tight security, no guns. Real plus.
Person1: Berlin? What's in Berlin?
Person2: Let's just say it's an opportunity to make a difference. And I'm not going to let it slip away.

Person1: I've been trying to understand what triggered this situation. Do you have any idea what led to this?
Person2: Unfortunately, no. And now we're facing a difficult journey ahead.
Person1: I can offer assistance. My team can be at your location in two days.
Person2: I appreciate the offer, but I'm not sure that's a good idea. We're still trying to identify the underlying concerns.
Person1: What kind of concerns are you talking about?
Person2: We're calling this whole area a complex web. It's taken us a while to reach a point where we could get a signal out to you. Just get me the necessary information, and I'll keep you informed.

Person1: I met him at this place called Moke's...
Person2: Hi, I'm Lena.
Person1: Barry. I just wanted you to know, wherever you're going or whatever you're doing right now, I want you to know that I'm glad I met you.
Person2: Really? What made you think of that?
Person1: I don't know... Anyway, I think we could become friends...

Person1: You'll probably be safe enough on your own --
Person2: Oh, you are very welcome... I love a man who's cautious.
Person1: Thank you. I just want to make sure.
Person2: That's a good idea.

Person1: I'm afraid, this wine is making me woozy...
Person2: We're alike. We have the gift. It's ancient times all over again.
Person1: Indeed we are. And I need your help to uncover the truth.
Person2: Maybe you should back off. You're not thinking clearly.
Person1: I saw the truth, and I spoke it. That's how I know we can work together.
Person2: You think you're real smart, don't you? But you have left a trail, and the trail is somewhere in those names.
Person1: I do know how to reach you. Take my advice, when dealing with these people, go by the book.

Person1: I didn't mean to start that....
Person2: Is that what you want?
Person1: Yeah. I need a new partner.
Person2: Don't be such a Grandma...I was always climbing something....
Person1: You were a monkey....
Person2: Mm... okay. Don't worry about it. Nobody'll mess with ya anymore. I'll take care of ya.
Person1: Thank you. Yeah, yeah, yeah.

Person1: I'm thinking about how we can make more sense of this discovery.
Person2: Obviously, it's a superpredator. Suchimimus, that snout.
Person1: But what if we're looking at it from the wrong angle? What if it's not about the species, but about the context?
Person2: You mean, like, who could have created it? InGen, maybe?
Person1: Exactly. Who knows what else they were up to? Maybe we should bet on our own abilities to uncover the truth, rather than just speculating.
Person2: Well, for scientists who have been out of the field for a while, we're not doing so bad. But we need to be careful not to let our assumptions cloud our judgment.

Person1: Are you sure you want to do this in front of everyone?
Person2: I think it's stealing us - we're not in control here.
Person1: Don't be ridiculous, these are my projects. I know what I'm doing.
Person2: You're crazy, we're just along for the ride.

Person1: I've been thinking about our trip to the countryside last summer. Do you remember that awful plum pudding Cook made?
Person2: (laughs) Yes, how could I forget? You and your brother hid it in your pockets so you wouldn't hurt her feelings.
Person1: (smiling) Exactly! And speaking of my brother, I'm getting worried. He's been away for months, and I haven't heard from him. It's not like him.
Person2: I'm sure he's fine. Maybe he's just busy with his work. You know how he gets absorbed in his projects.
Person1: I hope so. But I have a feeling something's wrong. I've heard rumors of a cholera outbreak in the area he's working in.
Person2: (calmly) Let's not jump to conclusions. We'll wait and see if we hear from him soon. In the meantime, why don't you read one of his old letters to your father? It'll set his mind at ease.

Person1: You were her doctor, weren't you?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: A decorated doctor, a former resident himself... if he came out and said "No malpractice" the medical board would buy it.
Person2: I was one of a group of doctors who assisted in the delivery.
Person1: Answer affirmatively. Simply. Keep those answers to three words. You weren't 'part of a group,' you were her doctor. Isn't that right?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: You were there to help Dr. Lee deliver her baby. Were you not?
Person2: That's a crock. We don't make mistakes like that. Do you have any idea the fallout if it went public?

Person1: You're being too hard on yourself. You didn't kill him.
Person2: Shhh! I did, in my own way. I poisoned his creativity.
Person1: But not his passion. What difference does that make?
Person2: From now on, no one will be able to speak of art without thinking of me. Whenever they say beauty, they'll have to say chaos alongside. And that's my legacy - at last!
Person1: Oh, my friend, my poor friend! You're letting your emotions get the better of you.
Person2: Don't pity me. Pity the art world. It's lost its way, and I'm just a symptom of that.

Person1: Are you okay? You look confused.
Person2: Get over here, I need your help! We need to act fast!
Person1: What's going on? What's happening?
Person2: I'm not sure, but we can't stay here. We need to move, now!

Person1: I'm not sure I can trust you with this information.
Person2: Don't need none. You're going to tell me anyway.
Person1: Then I better be on my way. I don't want to burden you with my problems.
Person2: Think it'd be best if you stayed put while we talk. You're not going to run from this, are you?
Person1: I'm not running from anything. I just need some time to think.
Person2: We'll see. I'm not leaving until we get to the bottom of this.

Person1: I answer to myself, not to anyone else.
Person2: Maybe that's the problem. You're always a step behind in everything.
Person1: That's not true! I'm just having a rough patch, that's all.
Person2: We all have those. But sometimes you need to think about the future and adjust your approach.
Person1: Easy for you to say. You're not the one struggling to catch up.
Person2: I'm trying to help. Let's work together to get you back on track.

Person1: I'm taking a huge risk by telling you this, but I have to be honest. I did something terrible, and I'm afraid of what might happen if others find out.
Person2: I'm listening. What did you do?
Person1: It was stupid and reckless, and I know I shouldn't have done it. But I was desperate, and I didn't think it through. I'm not trying to make excuses, but...
Person2: You're not going to get any judgment from me. I've seen some pretty amazing things in my time. Like that math professor who won the Salwen Medal and then...
Person1: Wait, what? No, no, let's not change the subject. I need to own up to what I did and face the consequences. I just hope you can find it in your heart to forgive me.
Person2: Forgiveness is not mine to give. But I can offer you a chance to make things right. Are you interested?

Person1: Heads or tails? We've been debating who gets to take the last slice.
Person2: You're full of excuses. I think you're just trying to get out of sharing.

Person1: You sure you can handle the new project?
Person2: Oh, I'm more than sure. Anything goes wrong, I can tell you right now you don't wanna be the one who assigned it to me.
Person1: Heartwarming. Really, I feel weepy. You really expect me to believe you're ready for this level of responsibility?
Person2: I've been preparing for this moment my whole career.

Person1: We need to take drastic measures against the competitor.
Person2: I'm willing to get my hands dirty. Use their weaknesses against them.
Person1: He's a ruthless businessman, but we can't let him steal from us again.
Person2: I'll help you prepare for the battle ahead. But first, can I ask you something - do you think we could try a new strategy in the meeting room?

Person1: You just relax, I've got everything under control. Nobody's going to hurt you, do you hear?
Person2: A pecking party? What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: It means we're all in this together, like a bunch of chickens at a peckin' party. And I'm the one who's going to make sure everyone gets along.
Person2: I don't know if I can trust you. You're not exactly filling me with confidence.
Person1: You just relax, and let me handle things. I'll make sure everything works out for the best.

Person1: I've been having these strange thoughts lately, Chauncey. I don't know what's gotten into me.
Person2: And how do you feel about these thoughts? Do you think they're a reflection of something deeper?
Person1: Honestly, I'm not sure. I've tried to stay open to my own emotions, but sometimes I feel like I'm losing control. Maybe one day I'll find a way to make sense of it all.
Person2: I see. Well, perhaps we can explore these thoughts together.

Person1: I'm not the one who's supposed to be caught with my secrets exposed... so I'd like to see your perspective on this.
Person2: What do you mean? You think I'm hiding something?
Person1: May I speak frankly? It's like practice, you know? Like when you play tennis against a wall. Some day, there'll be a partner returning the ball.
Person2: I'm not sure what you're getting at. Are you saying I'm not being open with you?
Person1: Well, it's okay to keep things to yourself. Or, as I always say, "Keep your cards close to your chest." There's nothing to be ashamed of. We all have our secrets.
Person2: I suppose that's true. But I think we should focus on finding a solution to this problem together.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's not just a rumor. I have sources that confirm it.
Person2: You're talking crazy! I've never heard anything so ridiculous in my life.
Person1: Hey, I'm sorry if I offended you. I didn't mean to question your judgment.
Person2: It's okay, I know you didn't. But seriously, you need to fact-check before spreading misinformation.

Person1: I've got it all planned out, Rachel. No one will ever suspect me. I've covered my tracks.
Person2: We know what makes a team strong, don't we? We know that no one can be an individual. No single person matters, right?
Person1: Exactly! That's why I've made sure to have an alibi for the time of the incident.
Person2: Not that you're planning something, are you?

Person1: You're one of the organizers. I've been studying the festival's history.
Person2: Friends never break promises, do they? You must be excited for the main event tonight.
Person1: Yeah, I'm excited. But I also know what the word exploitation means. You're using the festival to attract investors for your new project.
Person2: Smart for your age, eh? Top of your class? We like that about you. We want to make sure you're safe and have a good time.
Person1: Why? What's in it for you?
Person2: We just want to make sure everyone has a great experience. That's all.

Person1: I'm still trying to process it, can you believe it?
Person2: Tell me why you're so upset. 
Person1: He's really gone, isn't he?
Person2: That's right. He's gone. Tell me why you're struggling to accept it.

Person1: I have to go now. See you tomorrow.
Person2: Ever since I was a little girl, I remember hearing about the family recipes. The secret ingredients, the cooking techniques passed down through generations. When my sister got married and had kids...

Person1: You don't understand, I can't!
Person2: Oh, no, no, no. This is no big deal, you know? I can come down and, and get you out.
Person1: I did a bad thing, Alex. I'm not talking about this.
Person2: What? What'd you do?
Person1: I took a risk, and it backfired. I'm in trouble now.
Person2: Well, w-what happened?
Person1: I trusted someone I shouldn't have, and now I'm paying the price.
Person2: You're not making sense. What's going on?
Person1: Just grab your coat, 'cause you're going to have to help me get out of this mess.
Person2: Wait a minute, wait a minute. What have you gotten yourself into?

Person1: I'm telling you, I saw it with my own eyes. There was a guy behind that fence, and he was shooting.
Person2: You're just doing what it looks like you're supposed to, even if it seems crazy, right?
Person1: What do you mean? I'm trying to tell you what happened.
Person2: Look, I haven't had a second to think since I got here. I mean, in this situation. Whatever.
Person1: Well, I know what I saw. And I know it wasn't just three shots.
Person2: You wish you could make sense of it, but sometimes you just have to go with it, even if it seems strange.
Person1: I'm not going to forget what I saw, no matter how hard you try to confuse me.
Person2: I'm not trying to confuse you, pal. I'm just trying to figure out what's going on myself.

Person1: I'm going to the party tonight. Want to come?
Person2: No, I'm good.
Person1: You're just going to sit there? 
Person2: Yes, I want to know what I'm missing.
Person1: Okay, hope you don't regret it.

Person1: I'm telling you, she wouldn't dare use it if she had.
Person2: Why not? It's light in there now.
Person1: Please, just walk ahead of me to the living room. I feel uneasy about this.

Person1: You're a real piece of work, you know that?
Person2: I seem to remember you knocking on my door, uninvited. What's going on here?
Person1: Oh, this? Just a little surprise I had in store for you. You're only getting this treatment because I didn't feel like calling the authorities.
Person2: Well, whenever you're ready to calm down and talk about this like civilized people, I'm listening. Until then, let's just take a deep breath and...

Person1: How 'bout another one for Mr. Thompson? A double.
Person2: Did you give her that or is there someone new?
Person1: You're gonna just assume that? Stop it.
Person2: How do you know what she doesn't like?

Person1: I'm not sure I'm ready for this. What if they don't take me seriously?
Person2: You desperately want to prove yourself, don't you? That you can hang with the best of them?
Person1: Yeah, I guess so. But what if I fail?
Person2: You won't. Just be yourself and don't try to put on a show. And don't think you need to fix yourself up to impress them. They'll see right through that.
Person1: Alright, I'll try. But what if I mess up?
Person2: Then you'll learn from it. But I think you'll surprise yourself. Just relax and be honest with them.

Person1: You're going to waste it on a car? A Sixty-three 'Vette Stingray?
Person2: Hey, bein' ballsy with my life now doesn't change what came before. I'm going to be so sweet.
Person1: What, you think you're doing this to prove something? You're just making one bad call lead to another.
Person2: Thanks for the tip, but I know what I'm doing.

Person1: I've got a business proposition for you. We could make a fortune with this new venture.
Person2: You think so, huh? Well, I've got news for you - the rent on this place isn't paid.
Person1: That's a problem, but I'm sure we can find a way to make it work. We just need to think outside the box.
Person2: Think outside the box? You're not from around here, are you? You don't know what it's like to struggle to make ends meet.
Person1: Maybe not, but I do know that sometimes you have to take risks to achieve great things. And I'm willing to take that risk.
Person2: I suppose you're right. But if this doesn't work out, I'm blaming you.

Person1: I'm just curious, that's all. How far do you think someone could get?
Person2: Honestly, I don't know. Maybe thirty miles? But it's not like I'm encouraging anyone to try.
Person1: Thirty miles? That's a lot more than I expected. You know, sometimes I really hate it when people underestimate others.
Person2: Yeah? Well, maybe you should take your own advice and work on that frustration. But this time, try to be more open-minded.

Person1: I'm scared nobody will believe me.
Person2: You believe that I love you?
Person1: Yes, and if you lose me, you'll know that I loved you and wanted to go on loving you.
Person2: I won't lose you. You're doing a good thing by speaking up, just like you did for your friend Clarence.
Person1: He was real scared nobody would believe him -- I could tell, even when he first stood up.
Person2: You could? How?
Person1: I been like that myself, when I thought nobody was gonna believe me... But I won't let that happen again.

Person1: I've never seen this place before. Is this an informal meeting?
Person2: We're just getting to know each other. What does it look like?
Person1: It looks like you're trying to make me comfortable.
Person2: That's because I am. Does that upset you?
Person1: No. Why should it? I'm an actor, after all.
Person2: Ah, an actor. Then you're used to pretending.
Person1: We lie, to be simpler about it.
Person2: Yes, and I'm sure you're very good at it. But I'm not here to talk about your craft.
Person1: Then what do you want to talk about?
Person2: Let's take a look at these two gentlemen over there. Do you know them?

Person1: I'm really nervous about this presentation. I want to make a good impression.
Person2: I don't like the way you've structured your slides. Let's change the layout.
Person1: I was hoping to get some reassurance, not a critique.
Person2: Hey, we all make mistakes. It's part of the learning process. Let's work together to fix it.
Person1: Alright, but I'm not going to wear a suit and tie just to impress the clients.
Person2: Cute. Let's focus on the content instead.

Person1: I've never known her to say those words before. She always speaks the truth.
Person2: It's bad business. Every day that goes by, I'm losing money.
Person1: Really? I thought she said it all the time. You're right, it's bad business, but it's done.
Person2: One thing I can say about her. She always means what she says.

Person1: You're acting like a crazy person. I'm trying to make sense of this, but it's like you're straddling the state line, in two places at once.
Person2: I know it was bad, it was dumb. I didn't mean to cause any harm, I'd never want to hurt you. I love you, but I'm scared of what you'll think of me.
Person1: I said I wouldn't judge you. But you need to explain what's going on.

Person1: We're not alike. We're not hunters.
Person2: Don't.
Person1: Anybody ever tell you to back off like that before?
Person2: No.
Person1: Positive?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Guess there's no way I'll ever know for sure. You're not going to help me, are you?
Person2: Maybe you should focus on yourself instead of trying to figure me out.

Person1: I've been tracking this guy for weeks. He's a real smart aleck, thinks he's above the law.
Person2: Maybe you should take a step back. You're not going to find what you're looking for.
Person1: Oh, I'll find it. He's left a trail, and I know how to follow it. You know, where I come from, we don't take kindly to people like him.
Person2: And where's that?
Person1: A place where people respect the law. Where you don't wake up one morning to find some junkie tearing your bedroom apart.
Person2: You're not from around here, are you?
Person1: No, I'm not. But I've been around long enough to know how to deal with people like him.

Person1: Are you sure you want to do this in front of everyone?
Person2: What are you doing?! Get on with your misery!
Person1: I don't know... He can be nice... sometimes.
Person2: Don't be ridiculous, these are my babies.
Person1: What do you mean?! I could leave him if I wanted to!
Person2: I'm just trying to protect them from your influence.

Person1: I'm supposed to take Emma to the art museum tonight. She's really going to be disappointed if I don't.
Person2: Maybe she'll come with us. If I explain how much I want to show her the new exhibit, I don't think she'll mind. Do you?
Person1: I don't know. Probably not. You know, I've been meaning to ask you, how's your new project going?
Person2: It's going great, thanks for asking! I've been putting in a lot of hours, but it'll be worth it in the end. You know, Emma's really great, isn't she?

Person1: We can't delay the ceremony any further.
Person2: You should be thinking about the future, not just the past.

Person1: I think it's time we started making amends, don't you?
Person2: I'm not sure, Rachel. I've been thinking about my childhood a lot lately.
Person1: What do you mean? You never talk about your family.
Person2: Well, my parents were very strict. They taught me that certain things were just wrong, and that's all there was to it.
Person1: I see. And you're wondering if that's why you're struggling to connect with them now?
Person2: Exactly. I feel like I've been living my life according to their rules, without ever questioning them.
Person1: Maybe this is an opportunity for you to re-evaluate your relationships and start fresh. Would you like me to come with you when you talk to them?

Person1: Hey, you're being really sloppy with that search.
Person2: Shhh! I've got this.
Person1: Fine, but always remember to check the lining of their coat, like this... and don't forget to run your fingers along the seams.
Person2: Dude, you're making me nervous.
Person1: And what's with the awkward pat-down? You're supposed to be smooth, like you're searching for something attached to a string.
Person2: Okay, okay. I think I get it.

Person1: I'm surprised you're still taking this class. You used to be so passionate about learning.
Person2: Yeah, I know. I just feel like I've lost my spark lately.
Person1: Well, there was a time when you were very happy to be only with me. You wanted to learn everything about poetry, about music.
Person2: That was a different time. I'm not sure I fit in here anymore.
Person1: I think you're just going through a phase. You'll find your interest again. Oh look, the professor is leaving.

Person1: I think we've been given a second chance, to make a difference in someone's life. Maybe that's why we're here, to learn to let go of our own desires.
Person2: You wish you hadn't been so focused on your own goals? There are times I wish I had been more selfless, but there are times I feel compelled to pursue my passions. I've come to realize that it's worth it, even if it means making sacrifices.

Person1: Hello, Alex.
Person2: Hi. I'm not sure what to do now. I'm not sure what's the right decision.
Person1: Cut it out, will ya? You're overthinking this. It's a simple choice.
Person2: But it's not that simple. I need to consider all the options.
Person1: Come on. You're not crazy. Just trust your instincts.
Person2: I wish it were that easy.

Person1: I think about what I'm doing all the time, and I've got as much business being here as anybody.
Person2: You're really terrific, you know what I mean?
Person1: Wrong. I'm not terrific at all. I'm just trying to figure things out.
Person2: I know. Sometimes it's hard to know what to do.

Person1: Honestly, do you actually think I would sneak into your office and read your notes without asking you?
Person2: Never play with someone else's cards. You always get a new deck. Look at this file. See anything?
Person1: It's just a regular report. What's the point?
Person2: I can take everything you've got with that data. It's incomplete. Now I'm going to show you how to make some progress in case you get stuck.
Person1: Think, Rachel. Does Dr. Lee have any colleagues. I mean, besides you and... me?
Person2: Dr. Lee? My Dr. Lee? What's happened?
Person1: Nothing, she's just been sort of, I don't know... reassigned.
Person2: Reassigned? By who?
Person1: The department head.
Person2: Good God. Let's go talk to them.
