Person1: You're a lifesaver, Dr. Patel. Without your expertise, we wouldn't have made it through the crisis.
Person2: What's a little crisis between friends, huh? I'd do anything to help you, Rachel.
Person1: I'm so anxious for you to meet our new team leader. I think you two will really hit it off.
Person2: Rachel, no matter who's in charge, to me you'll always be the one who keeps us all together.

Person1: What's going on? I don't remember anything.
Person2: Say what I say. Describe what you see.

Person1: I'm telling you, the secret to a perfect dinner party is in the cleanup. You can't just leave all those dishes for the morning.
Person2: I've got a better idea. Let's just pretend we're at a radioactive waste site and those plates are contaminated. That way, we can just leave them and blame it on the radiation.
Person1: You're not taking this seriously. Fine, be that way. But when the health inspectors show up, don't say I didn't warn you.
Person2: Oh, come on. It's not like we're performing some kind of emotional core extraction procedure on the guests. Although, that would be a great way to get out of doing the dishes...

Person1: I love it, Alex. I'm getting to be a real artist.
Person2: Progress! Yeah? You still in the market for a real gallery?
Person1: Always. Ow. Cause there's this curator. My friend knows him. Might be right up your alley.
Person2: Tell me. I could use someone up my alley. Heartwarming. Really, I feel weepy.
Person1: Handsome, thirties, loves art... 
Person2: Loves animals? Ow. Must love animals, Alex.
Person1: Loves animals. Loves you. He loved her, by the way.
Person2: What do you mean? You really expect me to believe he's interested in my art?
Person1: My friend is discreet. He's got an extremely good eye for art, which is helpful in this situation.
Person2: Won't he be able to tell I'm still learning?
Person1: My friend says the guy's a thirty-five year old art enthusiast, so maybe he won't know how artists usually work. Plus he's got a lot of connections, which is helpful.

Person1: I want to get to the bottom of this, lawsuit or no lawsuit. May I speak frankly, Mr. Thompson?
Person2: You may if you can, Ms. Rodriguez.
Person1: Let's do it here. I want to clear the air.
Person2: What about the others? Are they involved?
Person1: They're not the ones who hired me. Whoever did wants to expose your company's secrets. Now, if I see the CEO, I can help him.
Person2: Suppose we did have secrets. How does it concern you?
Person1: Nothing personal, Mr. Thompson, I just want to know what's going on. Did you talk to the board members this morning?

Person1: I've been all around the city, trying to find a place to stay.
Person2: You're not having much luck, huh? I've got a spare room if you need it.
Person1: Thanks, but I'm not sure I can trust you. You're not going to try to take advantage of me, are you?
Person2: Take advantage of you? Ha! I've got more money than I know what to do with. I just want some company.
Person1: I've heard that before. People always want something in return.
Person2: Not me. I've got everything I need. I just want someone to talk to. And I'm willing to pay top dollar for it.
Person1: You're not making any sense. Why would you pay someone to talk to you?
Person2: Because I'm lonely, okay? And I've got the means to do whatever I want. So, what do you say? Want to make some easy money and have a place to stay for a while?

Person1: I got a job now. I'm teaching high school. Japanese and Chemistry.
Person2: That's great! I was driving to work today, and some bozo in a Cadillac cut me off...
Person1: Oh, that's terrible! Did you follow him?
Person2: No, I didn't. But I did see a footprint near my car afterwards. Forget it, it's probably not important at all.
Person1: A footprint? That's weird. You know, I've been feeling really happy lately. I think it's because I've been watching a lot of old movies.
Person2: Really? Which ones?
Person1: Like THE UNTOUCHABLES. I love DeNiro in that one.

Person1: I saw you look off when the CEO nodded his head. I figured he wasn't pointing out a particularly rare opportunity, and the rest was easy.
Person2: How did you know I would have the presence of mind to make the deal when I did?
Person1: Because that's what I would have done. Now, let's plan the press conference. We'll make it a historic event, like Neil Armstrong's moon landing.
Person2: I like it. We can start with a speech, "Thank you for believing in us, and, as importantly, thank you for taking a chance..."

Person1: I was just telling everyone about how I was gonna bring this girl for you.
Person2: I got that, thanks for letting me know.

Person1: You just relax. Nobody's gonna yell at you, do you hear?
Person2: I don't know, I think there's too much going on.
Person1: Look, would you question your teacher?
Person2: Yeah, uh-huh... Okay. I'll try to calm down.

Person1: I've tried to stay open to voices of the people, but it's hard when you're in a position of power.
Person2: Hey, no need to get defensive. I'm just saying that we need to consider the lives of tens of thousands of people who will be affected by this decision.
Person1: I'm not being defensive, I'm just trying to explain my perspective. And I agree, we do need to think about the people. That's why I think we should have that money outside in an hour.
Person2: I see what you're saying. Maybe one day we'll find a way to balance our own interests with the needs of the community.

Person1: I just want to say how sorry I am about the whole situation.
Person2: A small price.
Person1: Maybe... I don't know, if you want to talk --
Person2: I won't do your portion of the project.

Person1: You used to ride Johnny Dancer, didn't you? Not since your dad passed away, though.
Person2: Well, it was dark out that day... I mean, it was accessible to everyone.
Person1: I see. So, you're saying it was a public event, but you didn't exactly advertise it, did you?
Person2: Forget it. You're just trying to twist my words.
Person1: No, I'm just trying to get to the truth. Let's focus on the facts, shall we?

Person1: You don't ride horses anymore, do you? Not since your dad died.
Person2: Little surprise, couldn't be a new bike, could it? Well, well! Ain't that nice!

Person1: You promised to give it back. What's going on?
Person2: There's a situation here. It's going to get out of hand if we don't leave now.
Person1: Who do you think you are? You're not in charge here.
Person2: Friends never break promises, do they? I'm trying to help you.

Person1: I think I'll go down and confront this journalist.
Person2: What are you talking about? You told me about the article.
Person1: No, I didn't. Then how do you know about it?
Person2: They'd call you anything if you gave them half a chance. They've got you down as a sap.
Person1: I don't remember. What do they mean by that?
Person2: Listen. Listen, kid. You've got brains. You'll get along swell if you'll only curb your instincts - and keep your trap shut. Don't talk to anybody! These newshounds are out gunning for you.
Person1: But what about this article? I want to know what they're saying.
Person2: That's my job. I'll take care of that. I'll keep that stuff out of the papers - if you'll help me. But I can't do anything if you go around talking to people. Will you promise me to be careful from now on?
Person1: Yes, I guess I'll have to.

Person1: Are you crazy?
Person2: I want the money--meet me at the old warehouse. Don't do it and we're going to see if you're as tough as you think.
Person1: Love's a killer, isn't it?
Person2: Let's see how much you want to play.

Person1: What's your story? How did you end up here?
Person2: I did something terrible a long time ago. They said I wasn't right in the head.
Person1: What was it that you did?
Person2: I took something precious from someone. I poisoned their life.
Person1: But that's not the same as taking a life. What difference does it make?
Person2: It makes all the difference. I may not have killed them, but I destroyed their spirit.
Person1: And now you're trying to make amends?
Person2: I'm trying to find my place in the world. I don't have anywhere to belong.
Person1: You don't seem like someone who would hurt others. What's changed?
Person2: I've been trying to find my way. I've been reading a lot, trying to learn from my mistakes.
Person1: What kind of books do you read?
Person2: Different ones. One's the Bible. One's about how to be a better person.

Person1: I've been wanting to talk to you about your recent work. It's been impressive, and I think I could learn a thing or two from you.
Person2: Thank you, I appreciate the compliment. But I have to say, I was surprised you didn't speak up when I invited your colleague to the meeting without consulting you.
Person1: Yeah, I should have said something. I didn't want to make a scene, but it put me in an awkward situation.
Person2: I understand. I didn't mean to cause any tension. Maybe we can grab lunch and discuss how we can improve our communication?
Person1: That sounds great. I'd like that.

Person1: I'm thinking of buying a new car. A Sixty-three 'Vette Stingray, all tricked out and cherry.
Person2: That's quite a splurge. You must be celebrating something. Did you finally get over Mark?
Person1: Actually, I was thinking of asking Gregory out. He's cute, and I heard he's got a great screenplay idea.
Person2: Maybe he likes you, ever think of that? But be careful, guys can be sneaky. Remember those lines they used to get into your apartment?
Person1: Yeah, like "Can I use your phone?" or "I want to meet your cat." But what's the worst that could happen?
Person2: Well, you never know what they'll expect in return. Just make sure you know what you're willing to do, and don't let him take advantage of you.

Person1: I'm telling you, Emily, I had the most peculiar dream last night. I heard whispers in the darkness.
Person2: Whispers, you say? That's intriguing. I've been having some unusual experiences myself lately.
Person1: Oh? What kind of experiences?
Person2: I've been feeling like someone's been watching me, even when I'm alone. It's unsettling, to say the least.
Person1: (laughs) You're not trying to spook me, are you? Because if you are, you're doing a mighty fine job.
Person2: (smiling) Perhaps I am, a little. But I assure you, my intentions are pure. I'm just trying to make sense of these strange occurrences.
Person1: Well, I suppose we could try to get to the bottom of it together. After all, two minds are better than one.
Person2: Exactly! And who knows, maybe we'll uncover something remarkable.

Person1: I'm an explorer. We're all explorers.
Person2: Wait... I thought we were gonna venture into the unknown together.
Person1: Nah, I don't think so... We pretend to be brave, but we're not.
Person2: Don't back down on me now. We've come too far.
Person1: Gotta go. I have a map to follow.
Person2: Don't leave me behind...

Person1: I've got an idea that will get us out of this mess. We haven't a penny between us, but we've got these connections.
Person2: Connections? What good are they? We'll see if they're as useful as you claim.
Person1: Your skepticism may be justified, but I implore you to believe me. This opportunity is very real and very promising.
Person2: Something promising has got to come of it! Do you know that our reputation is at stake?

Person1: Honestly, do you think I'd let you handle this situation on your own?
Person2: Gee, I don't know. You didn't exactly ask me before inviting the whole team to our meeting room.
Person1: Sometimes we have to adapt. What's the plan to get us out of this financial mess?
Person2: Well, I was thinking... we could use our business insurance to cover the losses.
Person1: That's not a bad idea. But we need to be careful, we can't just claim anything.
Person2: I know, I know. But we have to do something. The rent is overdue and we're running out of options.
Person1: Let me think for a minute. Ah, I've got it! We can contact the investors and explain the situation. They might be willing to help us out.
Person2: That's a great idea! But we need to be honest with them, no sugarcoating.

Person1: I don't remember asking you to bring your friend over for the party.
Person2: Just until she gets back on her feet? It wasn't memorable enough to cause any trouble.
Person1: Sometimes I really hate it when you do this.
Person2: Yeah? Well, why don't you take my advice and work on being more understanding?

Person1: I can't believe you kept all these old files. 
Person2: I know, it's crazy. I try to remember why we started this project, and I can't. It all seems so abstract now. 
Person1: Don't be ridiculous. You're just trying to distract me from the real issue. 
Person2: What's the real issue, then? You're the one who's been avoiding me for weeks.

Person1: What do you want from me, Doctor?  Name it.  You want my medical history?
Person2: Well you're probably right about that. It certainly can't help your treatment to have this examination continued for any length of time.
Person1: Why do you call it an examination? I never have.
Person2: Your family has a history of this condition before you moved to this city.
Person1: We'll go to my insurance company.  I'll make a claim.

Person1: You realize, Captain, that we're gonna explore a new planet, so if you wanna choose a destination, do it now ... You gotta a favorite planet? Friends?  If we gotta be on a new planet, where do you wanna go?  Any planet. Just name a planet.
Person2: I'm an actor, I've played a space explorer before. We pretend...
Person1: Simpler. You're not acting now, Captain. This is real.
Person2: Yes... I understand THAT, don't I?... I choose... Mars.

Person1: I didn't mean to imply you needed my help. Rachel and Mike, they'll give you a hand if you want.
Person2: Yes, yes. I know. Right. And if it had gone well for me today, maybe I'd be offering to help you instead... I grant you that.

Person1: I'm so tired of seeing you stuck in a rut. It's like you're sleepwalking through life.
Person2: What's wrong, Iris? You seem really upset.
Person1: I just wish you'd take some risks, you know? Bend the rules a little. You're missing out on so much.
Person2: Like what? What's out there that I'm missing?
Person1: Oh, I don't know... a sense of freedom, maybe. The thrill of not knowing what's going to happen next.
Person2: And you think that's what I need? A little excitement?
Person1: It couldn't hurt, could it? You're not getting any younger.

Person1: You're straddling the state line. You're in two places at once.
Person2: I sleep it off.
Person1: But between the time you leave the party and fall into bed, what happens, Rachel? You could do anything in that time.
Person2: I don't know, but sometimes I feel like I'm losing myself in the in-between.

Person1: Thank you for bringing this to my attention, Officer.
Person2: What is it? A tape from the surveillance camera at the local market. It was vandalized last night.
Person1: Really? I want to make sure that I understand what you're telling me, Jenkins. A crime was committed in our neighborhood? That is news.
Person2: The guy had a distinctive tattoo and was dressed like a punk rocker. Oh, you are very welcome... Lord knows how I love a man in uniform.

Person1: I don't know if I can trust you. What's in it for you?
Person2: I'm just trying to help. You're in a tough spot, and I'm offering you a way out.
Person1: A way out? You call that a way out? That's just a way to get me to cooperate.
Person2: Cooperate? You're the one who's been hiding something. I'm just trying to get to the truth.
Person1: The truth? You don't care about the truth. You just want to win.
Person2: Win? This isn't a game. This is about what's best for everyone involved.
Person1: What's best for everyone? You're not even considering what's best for me.
Person2: I'm considering what's fair. You've made some mistakes, and now it's time to face the consequences.
Person1: Consequences? You're the one who's been pushing me into a corner. I don't know if I can take it anymore.
Person2: Take it? You're the one who's been calling the shots. I'm just trying to level the playing field.

Person1: You're being reckless. Don't let your emotions cloud your judgment.
Person2: And anxious to get started. What's the plan, anyway?

Person1: I'm not sure I understand. Can you explain?
Person2: Why, you should be thinking about the future. I'm here to find something and I think you can help me.
Person1: Like it? Does it remind you of something?
Person2: Yes, it does. But let's focus on the task at hand. We can't afford to get distracted.
Person1: Alright, let's ride. I'll help you find what you're looking for.

Person1: I've been thinking, we could use some help around here. You know, someone to lend a hand.
Person2: Yeah, like that kid who slept in a toolshed? What was his name again?
Person1: Karl, I think. But that's not what I meant. I was thinking more like a volunteer.
Person2: Oh, right. Well, we could put up a poster or something. Unless... unless you're thinking of beating the crap out of some kids and stealing their help.
Person1: What? No, of course not! That's a terrible idea. I was thinking more like a community service project.
Person2: Oh, okay. Yeah, that makes sense. I guess I just got a little carried away there.

Person1: You used to be so passionate about photography. What happened?
Person2: I don't know. I just lost interest, I guess.
Person1: But between the time you put down your camera and picked up that new hobby, what changed? You could've explored so much more.
Person2: I suppose I just didn't have anything left to give.

Person1: You mean like, a grand entrance?
Person2: For the press conference?
Person1: We'll make it a historic moment. Sneak the CEO back into the office. And we'll plan a big comeback. It'll be like, "Thank you for believing in us, and, as importantly, thank you for giving us another chance..."
Person2: I like it. Might even get a standing ovation.

Person1: I've been searching for a place to belong for a long time. When they'd put their hands on me, I used to say, "This isn't it! This isn't what I mean!"
Person2: Did you hurt anyone in your search?
Person1: You know me...I never hurt anybody. I think I've finally found what I'm looking for. Will you take me in?
Person2: I already have.

Person1: You're pushing your luck. I won't let you walk all over me.
Person2: Hold up, li'l sis', I'm trying to help. You'll be set for life, better than struggling to make ends meet.
Person1: I don't need your kind of help. You're just trying to control me.
Person2: Whoa, slow down. I didn't mean to scare you like that. I've got people waiting in line for this opportunity.
Person1: I'm not afraid of you. I just don't want to be tied down.
Person2: Ball's in your court. You can take it or leave it.

Person1: I think about what you're doing all the time, and I've got concerns about your safety. You don't think about what you're doing and you'll get hurt.
Person2: I do remember the accident... I told you... I remember the sound of the sirens... I think about that sometimes. But I can take care of myself, I don't need your help.
Person1: All right, I just want to make sure you're okay. Why don't you stay and rest for a bit, I'll help with the chores.
Person2: No, I need some fresh air. I'll be fine, really.

Person1: We're planning a homecoming.  What do you remember about your high school?
Person2: Not much. You told me about it, though.
Person1: What are you talking about? I never mentioned my high school to you.
Person2: Oh, maybe I'm thinking of someone else. Anyway, for the homecoming, we could make it like Neil Armstrong's moon landing. They'll forget all about the election.
Person1: That's a terrible idea. And what's with the moon landing reference?

Person1: I'm telling you, it's bad business. Every day that goes by, I'm losing money.
Person2: You're being heartwarming, really. I feel weepy. You wanted to know what happened, I'm telling you.
Person1: Oh come on, who do you think you're talking to? You really expect me to believe it's just a matter of making an example?
Person2: Occasionally, sure, okay, you got to make a change. But that's good business.

Person1: You deserve a break, that's the occasion.
Person2: What do you mean? You're not usually this generous.
Person1: May I speak frankly? I think you're getting too caught up in your work.
Person2: It's very personal, my work. It couldn't be more personal. Is this a business or an obsession with you?
Person1: Look at it this way. You're not taking care of yourself. Whoever is pushing you to work this hard, didn't have anything against you. They were out to get the best out of you. Now if I can help you, I can help you find a better balance. Did you talk to your manager about this morning's meeting?

Person1: You seem worried. What's on your mind?
Person2: I'm just thinking about the recent incidents. It's getting really scary.
Person1: I know, but we'll be fine. We just need to be more careful.
Person2: Yeah, I guess you're right. I'll try to relax. Can I call you later to check in?
Person1: Of course, I'll be here. Just take care of yourself, okay?

Person1: You can't imagine.
Person2: Oh, please, I've tried everything! I must have telephoned her a hundred times. I've sent her telegrams, I've sent her flowers... I asked her to dinner... I offered her seats for the Opera...
Person1: Progress! Getting to be smooth smooth smooth all over. Smooth as a baby's butt.
Person2: You saw all that in one glimpse? I love it, when we're going to get anywhere someone has to keep their eyes open!
Person1: Imagine the carpets of a self-respecting Parisian hotel dirtied by the boots of a muzhik! What does she look like?
Person2: You still in the market for a real boy? There's this guy. My brother knows him. Might be right up your alley.
Person1: Timeless. When she comes into a room you'd think that the Bolsheviks had taken over Paris. She wears her cheap miserable blouse as though it were the latest model by Schiaparelli.
Person2: Handsome, thirties, psychologist... Loves animals? Must love animals.

Person1: You know what would happen to the department if this got out?
Person2: Nothing matters.
Person1: No use waiting, then. We have to act now.
Person2: But what about the consequences?

Person1: I suppose so. Where are we meeting?
Person2: We're in trouble! The same place, one o'clock. I have to go now.
Person1: Shut up, Arlo. I need you to focus.

Person1: Hey, what's going on? You're being really quiet.
Person2: Shhh! I'm trying to focus.
Person1: Walter, I have some bad news. The Governor hasn't signed that reprieve!
Person2: What? That's impossible!
Person1: I know, I just got off the phone with Mac. He told me himself.
Person2: This can't be happening. I won't let it happen!

Person1: Please, I need your help.
Person2: What do you think? Of course, I'll do it. What's involved?
Person1: You'll be contacted with the assignment.
Person2: I don't know if I can do it. My sister can't know about this.
Person1: So tell me where to start. Don't worry, I'll guide you through it.
Person2: Think carefully. You'll be taking a big risk. The person who trusts you the most might find out.
Person1: I can do it! The code name of your contact will be Rachel.

Person1: I'm sorry I doubted your skills. You really pulled it off this time.
Person2: Thanks, I was sure trying. So, what's the plan now that we've got the contract?
Person1: I'll be at the meeting, but don't introduce me, just let it go. You're gonna be the one presenting the proposal.
Person2: They'll be looking at me, wondering who's behind this. You're the one who deserves the credit.
Person1: That's right, let's keep it that way. Just start talking and let them figure it out.

Person1: You know what we do to people who can't pay their debts, don't you?
Person2: Honestly, I've been so caught up in my own problems, I didn't think it through.
Person1: That's your mistake. We've got a lot riding on this deal.
Person2: I know, I know. It keeps me going, thinking I can turn things around.
Person1: Five people have tried to make a comeback like you. None of them succeeded.
Person2: What happened to them?
Person1: They couldn't handle the pressure. It's not easy to recover from a setback like this.
Person2: I'll make it work. I have to.

Person1: Johnny Dancer, right? You don't ride him anymore, do you?
Person2: Plans? What are you talking about?
Person1: I'm talking about the festival. You're not going to perform, are you?
Person2: Shit, I met the organizer on the plane and I had all that coffee. I gave her a cup before I realized... she's a total control freak.
Person1: Well... It'll probably work out. We can keep her busy and peddle your skills at the festival.

Person1: I'm a pyjama case, really.
Person2: Are you Herr Mller? 
Person1: That's right.
Person2: I like plaits. You have lovely hair, even if you torment it in those braids.
Person1: What? Who are you?
Person2: My name is Anna, sir. I'm a music teacher. I was asked to come here and offer my services to you.

Person1: You know what I'm going to do with my bonus? I'm going to buy a small sailboat. All refurbished and shiny.
Person2: A sailboat? You're going to buy a sailboat? Just promise me you'll love me even if I end up sailing solo around the world.

Person1: Thank you! I feel like a new person.
Person2: After I saw what happened at the festival -- you know I changed my whole approach, took a break, and came back with a fresh perspective. It really inspired me.

Person1: I'm really upset that you invited my friend over without asking me.
Person2: Well, I thought it would be a nice surprise. By the way, can I give you some advice? There are things you should know about, like being responsible with your actions.
Person1: What do you mean? You're not making sense.
Person2: For example, it's not a good idea to do things that waste resources, like water and electricity. And, um, be respectful of others' belongings.
Person1: I don't see what that has to do with anything. You're just trying to change the subject.
Person2: I'm sorry if I upset you. I need to be more considerate and communicative. Can we start over?

Person1: I think I've had one.
Person2: And anxious to get started. What is this, mostly a new project?
Person1: Yes, but their potential is only transitory - once they find their passion, it will vanquish all doubts.
Person2: Of course they do. What about you? Have you just never had a breakthrough - or have you never had a eureka moment, period?

Person1: I want it all. You guys want guarantees? I want the possibilities.
Person2: We pretend...
Person1: Life gets messy. Ugly messy. But I don't understand you.
Person2: Simpler.
Person1: I don't understand throwing it away. How do you throw all that away? Any of it.
Person2: Yes... You understand THAT, don't you?
Person1: It's a miracle when you come down to it. We'd have had amazing children, you and me.
Person2: Our dimwitted friends don't understand the concept of acting. They have no theater, no imagination these scientists.
Person1: I'll never love anybody else, you know.
Person2: Me too.

Person1: I've been thinking about my freshman year counselor, Noah. He's the one who inspired my latest writing project.
Person2: That's interesting. I've been trying to understand people's motivations too.
Person1: Yes, it's fascinating. Although, I have to admit, I've been wearing long underwear lately, just in case.
Person2: What do you mean? You're preparing for an accident?
Person1: Not exactly. I just want to be prepared for anything. You know, like having a better understanding of human behavior.
Person2: I see. Well, I think it's great that you're exploring these ideas. Maybe we can discuss them further sometime.

Person1: I grant you everything, but give me this...you personify everything I've been fighting against.
Person2: What do you mean? What is it that you need from me?
Person1: I'll tell you when it's time. But first, I need you to understand the stakes. There's a lot at risk here.

Person1: I've been searching for the truth, but it's like trying to grasp smoke. You're the only one who can help me.
Person2: What makes you think I have the answers?
Person1: You're the one who's been pulling the strings from behind the scenes. I can't trust you, but I need your help.
Person2: And what do you propose I do to earn your trust?
Person1: Tell me what you know. I'm in a desperate mood. I'll do whatever it takes to uncover the secrets.
Person2: Very well. But be warned, once you know, there's no turning back.

Person1: You're really serious, aren't you? About finding the truth?
Person2: Yes, I am. I was going to discover the secret of the universe.
Person1: But what about the past? Our past? Did you ever think about what we really look like, beneath the surface?
Person2: We never really shared one. I showed you how to bend the rules, but that's not the same as understanding.
Person1: You're inhuman, sometimes. You see things so clearly, but you don't feel anything.
Person2: I'm...in touch with humanity, in my own way. I'm sorry if that's not enough for you.

Person1: We can't just sit here, we have to do something. We might be able to get out of this situation if we act fast.
Person2: I understand your urgency, but we need to think this through. If we make a wrong move, it'll only make things worse for everyone involved.

Person1: I'm not going to wear earrings, I can tell you that.
Person2: Guess who? It's your old friend, Rachel.
Person1: You know, to me dressing up was always just putting on my dark blue suit.
Person2: I suspect if you had actually planned a surprise party, you'd be far more organized by now.
Person1: Cute. Let's have some drinks.
Person2: You look great!

Person1: I've got everything under control, Rachel. No one will ever suspect me. I've made sure of it.
Person2: You ride Winston in the competition, not me. I'm not comfortable with it.
Person1: Oh, I'm more than sure. Anything happens to that horse, I can tell you right now you don't want to be the one responsible.

Person1: I've been thinking, what kind of leader was I that I could put our entire team in danger like that?
Person2: ... And now we're stuck in this situation, with no clear way out...
Person1: The research facility can provide us with the necessary equipment to escape, but we need to act fast...
Person2: That's probably not a good idea. We haven't fully understood the environmental concerns of this region...
Person1: What kind of concerns? Is it similar to The Briar Patch?
Person2: No, it's different. But I think I can get the schematics from the facility's database. I'll keep you informed.
Person1: I guess it doesn't matter how much we want to escape, or how much we love this project. I guess it's like you said, the only thing that counts is what's best for the team.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: I mean, maybe we should prioritize their safety over our own interests. Maybe that's all leadership is anyway...
Person2: I never thought of it that way. Maybe you're right.

Person1: I'm a whiskey man myself. Feeling better, Oz?
Person2: Not really. I'm such a loser.
Person1: That's the spirit. We don't have much trouble from drugs where I come from...
Person2: Yeah, but you never know what's around the corner.

Person1: You're straddling the state line. You're in two places at once.
Person2: Yeah, well, right man, there are many facets to this, uh, you know, many interested parties.
Person1: I've heard the story, so save it. I know you're mixed up in all this, and I don't care what you're trying to take. That's your business.
Person2: Does the Pope shit in the woods?
Person1: Let's discuss the terms. I want a 10% finder's fee.
Person2: Okay, done. I like the way you do business. Your package is being held by a kid named Alex. He lives in South LA, on Crenshaw, near the coffee shop. A real charmer, but I'm sure you'll be able to get it off him. So if you'll just write me a check for my ten per cent...

Person1: So, you're going to the art festival this weekend?
Person2: Yeah, I need to get out of the house. I've been sleeping it off for weeks.
Person1: What do you mean? You're not exactly the party type.
Person2: I don't know. I just feel like I'm stuck in a rut. I need to figure out what I want to do with my life.
Person1: Well, you're not alone. I'm still trying to decide on a major. Business, psychology...I don't know.
Person2: Yeah, people always ask you what you're going to do, but they don't really care. They just want to know you have a plan.
Person1: Exactly! And I'm like, "I'll figure it out." But when?
Person2: Right? It's like, I'm trying to find my "most emotionally significant moment" or whatever, but it's hard when you're still trying to find yourself.
Person1: Do you want ketchup with that?
Person2: Yeah, thanks.

Person1: I've been following the recent developments in the tech industry. What's your take on the new startup that just went public?
Person2: There are times I feel compelled to speak out about the lack of innovation in the industry, but I think this startup has potential.
Person1: I'm equally impressed with your knowledge of the market. How long have you been in the industry now?
Person2: Five years, and I've seen a lot of changes. But I wish I had spoken out more about the issues I saw in my previous company.
Person1: I think it's worth it to share your insights. Would you like to discuss your experiences over dinner tonight?

Person1: I feel like I've got something to look forward to. Everything looks new.
Person2: You've made us look pretty good in the past week. And the way you handled the press --
Person1: I don't know, it's just that my eyes are open and I feel awake. Wide awake.
Person2: I have doubts about your ability to stick with what is essentially a new chapter.
Person1: I had doubts too, but something happened and now I see things differently.
Person2: You know what I mean. Everything looks different.

Person1: I've been going over your file, and I think I've found something peculiar. Your background check doesn't quite add up.
Person2: What do you mean? I'm not sure what you're getting at.
Person1: Well, for instance, your art teacher, Dr. Furtwngler, was very clear about keeping politics and art separate. But I'm not sure that's entirely possible, are you?
Person2: I suppose not. But what's the significance of this? You're not implying that I'm somehow... tainted, are you?
Person1: Not at all. I just want to understand what drives you. What's your secret?

Person1: You see, Jesse, growing up, only knew that he was different, is all. He don't mean nothin' by it--
Person2: That the problem, son? You different?
Person1: Apologize to the officer, Jesse. He's just a bit... sheltered.
Person2: I knew he was sheltered. What's with the notebook, though?
Person1: Oh, that's just something his momma made him write. Says it's from the Bible, but I think it's just her way of... coping.
Person2: What does it mean, though?
Person1: I'm not entirely sure, but I think it's just her way of trying to make sense of things. You know, Jesse, why don't you go talk to the officer while I go get us some coffee?

Person1: You're not going to stop me, are you? I've waited too long for this chance.
Person2: What's the hurry? You're not getting any younger.
Person1: That's not funny. I've been planning this for years. I've been saving up, making deals, and bribing people. I won't let anyone stand in my way.
Person2: You're not thinking clearly. You're letting your emotions cloud your judgment.
Person1: Emotions? You think this is about emotions? This is about freedom. I've been trapped for too long, and I won't let anyone take that away from me.
Person2: Trapped? You're not a prisoner. You can leave anytime you want.
Person1: Can I? Really? Then why do I feel like I'm suffocating every time I think about staying? You don't understand. You've never been in my shoes.
Person2: Maybe not, but I can see that you're not thinking rationally. You're letting your desire for freedom cloud your judgment.
Person1: Rational? You want to talk about rational? You're the one who's being irrational. You're the one who's trying to hold me back.

Person1: I'm so tired of these reporters. They're always poking fun at me.
Person2: They'd call you anything if you gave them half a chance. You've got to learn to ignore them.
Person1: But it's hard when they're calling me names like "Cinderella Man". What do they mean by that?
Person2: It's just a nickname. Don't let it get to you. We need to focus on getting to Sonora.
Person1: I know, but it's taking so long. Can't we find a faster way?
Person2: I've been thinking about that. If we can get Clay to help us, we might be able to save some time.
Person1: That's a great idea! What are you waiting for? Do something.
Person2: I'll talk to Clay, but you have to promise me you'll be careful from now on. No more talking to reporters.
Person1: I promise. I just want to get to Sonora without any more trouble.

Person1: I'm telling you, it was a real challenge to get to the top of that mountain!
Person2: You wanted to know what happened after the hike, I'm telling you.
Person1: Oh, I was so scared nobody would believe me when I said I saw a bear... 
Person2: You could? How did you know you weren't just seeing things?
Person1: I've been in situations like that myself, when I thought nobody was going to believe me... You want to hear another story?!
Person2: Not now, Alex, it's time for dinner. You have a long day ahead of you tomorrow...

Person1: You're all just jealous.
Person2: Vanderbilt's not that far from U of M.
Person1: What? We both have cars. It's not a space shuttle launch, it's just a visit.
Person2: Yeah right. You're talking about a post-high school, long-distance friendship, and you haven't even made it work yet.
Person1: That's not why we're friends. We're going to hang out when we're both ready. I want the right place, the right time, the right moment.
Person2: Please. Did you do the physics write-up?

Person1: I'm upset because I can't really justify being upset. I mean, it's your project, really, you're the lead designer.
Person2: What's bothering you about it? You know I value your input.
Person1: You're letting some new team member take the reins on this feature without even asking me about it. I would've said yes, I just wish you would've asked.
Person2: Paid a consultant to review the design and they said it was a good move. I didn't think it was a big deal.
Person1: This unexpected change notwithstanding, how are things with the project overall?
Person2: Fine, I guess. Except right now I'm going through this where I don't want to make any more changes.

Person1: I'm sure the whole town will love to hear about your little secret. Out there, for all to hear.
Person2: Oh, you think you're so clever, don't you? But no one will believe a word you say.
Person1: The plot thickens, doesn't it? It appears that you've fallen quite literally into your own web of deceit.
Person2: How dare you! You're just a free thinker who doesn't believe in accountability.
Person1: Accountability? Ha! You're the one who's been wallowing in sin and lust, and now you're going to pay the price.
Person2: You'll never take me down, I have the people's trust.
Person1: Trust? You mean the trust of those who are blind to your true nature? I think not.
Person2: You're just jealous of my influence, my power.
Person1: Influence? Power? You're nothing but a fraud, and soon everyone will see it.

Person1: We need to get the package to the other side. When you come to the lock, someone will tell you how to proceed.
Person2: I don't think that's a good idea. Let's take it back now. We can't risk it getting lost.
Person1: But we've come too far. We can't turn back now. We'll plan a new route, and I'll go with you as far as the lock.
Person2: Fine, but if anything goes wrong, I'm blaming you.

Person1: I don't know what to say to Allah.
Person2: That's not true. You said you wanted to make amends, and now you're backing down?
Person1: I want to, but I can't. For forgiveness to be real, it has to be the hardest and the greatest.
Person2: Have you ever taken responsibility for your actions, Malcolm? Or are you just trying to shift the blame?
Person1: Can you hang on a second? I need to collect my thoughts.
Person2: Fine, but don't think you can just walk away from this. We need to have a real conversation.

Person1: I'm in big trouble, do you know anything about computers?
Person2: Oh no, what's wrong?
Person1: I had a power surge at home that wiped out a file I was working on. I've got a big project due tomorrow and I don't know how to recover it.
Person2: You look like the kind of person who's always on top of things. What makes you think you can't figure it out?
Person1: Ha! I wish. I'm actually pretty clueless when it comes to technology. Can you help me out?
Person2: Sure thing. Let me take a look. What's the number on your modem?

Person1: I'm feeling really frustrated. Every time I think I'm making progress, I realize I'm moving in the wrong direction.
Person2: What do you mean? You're not making sense.
Person1: I mean, I catch myself giving dirty looks to happy couples, and I feel like I'm abandoning my own happiness. It's like I'm trying to protect myself from getting hurt again.
Person2: That doesn't sound like you're protecting yourself, that sounds like you're giving up.
Person1: Maybe I am. Maybe I'm just tired of trying to hold on to something that's not working. I need some space to figure things out.
Person2: Space? You're not even making an effort to understand yourself. You're just pushing everyone away.
Person1: I'm not pushing anyone away. I'm just trying to find my own way. And if that means taking a step back, then so be it.

Person1: Professor Thompson? I just wanted to say thanks for the amazing lecture on astrophysics today.
Person2: Ah, Sophia, isn't it? I'm glad you found it enlightening. But I'm not here to please, I'm here to educate.
Person1: I know, I know. But I was wondering, what would you do if you were in my shoes? I'm considering a career in space exploration, but my parents are against it.
Person2: Figuring things out for yourself is the only freedom anyone really has, Sophia. Use that freedom. Make your own choice. Who's this 'Bruce' you're trying to impress, anyway?

Person1: I have to go now. See you tomorrow.
Person2: What's the plan for tomorrow? Are we going to tackle those old memories again?
Person1: Yes, I suppose so. We'll start with the most recent ones and go backwards. It's the best way to make progress.
Person2: And what about the risks? Is there anything I should be worried about?
Person1: Well, it's a bit like a night of heavy drinking. You might not remember everything, but it's nothing to lose sleep over.

Person1: I'm telling you, it was a setup from the start. I met her at this trendy cafe... We hit it off, and she told me about a business opportunity...
Person2: What kind of opportunity?
Person1: Honestly, I don't recall. But she's a straight shooter... You can trust her.
Person2: If you say so. She does have some shady connections, though.

Person1: I've got to get back, they'll be expecting me.
Person2: You're not thinking about the long view. You're strong, but sooner or later, you'll lose your spark.
Person1: It's not up to you to decide what's best for me. I can take care of myself.
Person2: I'm not trying to control you, but you need to see the bigger picture. You're stuck in a situation that's suffocating you.
Person1: I appreciate your concern, but I really must go. We've got work to do, and I don't want to fall behind.
Person2: Fine, but don't say I didn't warn you.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a steal! Nike specials, only two hundred bucks.
Person2: He can do anything, just like Inspector Gadget on TV. But I have to keep things ready for him, that's what I think.

Person1: I think I've had one.
Person2: What's going on? You're not making any sense.
Person1: Take my advice, get out of here. Now.
Person2: Of course I will. What about you? Have you just never had one with someone you trust?
Person1: I don't remember... I've never tried it.
Person2: Are you kidding? You're not even sure what you're talking about.

Person1: I'm not feeling so well. Can I get some fresh air in here?
Person2: You're gonna just give me a tour of this place? 
Person1: Go away, I need some space.
Person2: How'd you end up with this amazing view?
Person1: Please, just leave me alone for a bit.

Person1: I'm surprised you showed up. I didn't think you'd bother.
Person2: And I'm surprised you're glad I did. You realize now you could never have done it without me.
Person1: Actually, I could have done it much more easily without you, but for whatever reason, I'm glad you came. It's a comfort to see you, like a prudent housewife, getting everything ready for my departure.
Person2: Is it not a pleasure, gentlemen, for me, as I am drawing near the goal, to find my home such a happy one; my friends so fond of me?
Person1: I hope that you are not thinking of leaving us soon, my friend?
Person2: Not so soon, my dear, as you may fancy perhaps. Why, man, I have been given over many times these four years, and there was always a candidate or two waiting to apply for the situation.
Person1: Sir, let those laugh that win.

Person1: I didn't ask what the committee thinks, Dr. Lee. What do you think?
Person2: Your research grant application is quite... colorful. But see, now I've got a problem. I don't seem to be getting much clarity on the methodology, so I guess we're gonna have to take this proposal back to the drawing board, ya know?
Person1: What I think is... they're playing it too safe. The real breakthroughs only come when we take calculated risks, and I believe our approach will yield groundbreaking results if we're willing to challenge the status quo.

Person1: I'm trying to better myself, but the one person who can help me is the same one pushing me away.
Person2: He was a town marshal... one night he surprised two burglars, coming out the back of a drugstore... They shot him.
Person1: I'm sorry, but I'm not here to be your savior. What happened to him after that?
Person2: No. He was strong, he lasted almost a month. My mother - died when I was very young, so my father had become - the whole world to me...
Person1: Well try this one on for size. I think I'm falling in love with you. But I need to know more about you first.
Person2: You're very frank, Alex. I think - it would be quite something to know you in private life.
Person1: Quid pro quo, Rachel. You tell me more about your father, and I'll open up about myself.
Person2: After your father's death, you were orphaned. What happened next?
Person1: I went to live with my mother's cousin and her husband in Montana. They had a ranch.
Person2: A cattle ranch?
Person1: Horses - and sheep... But I didn't stay long. I had to leave.
Person2: Why, Alex? Did the rancher harm you?
Person1: No. I just didn't fit in. I think I'm still trying to find my place in the world.
Person2: I understand. Sometimes I feel like I'm still trying to find my place too.

Person1: You're a bit of a mystery, aren't you?
Person2: I don't know what you mean.
Person1: Come on, I've seen the way people look at you. There's something about you that draws them in.
Person2: You're being kind, but I think you're mistaken. I'm just a normal person.
Person1: I like your hair, by the way. It suits you.

Person1: You have the eyes of a visionary. Tell me, what have they seen that the mind can't fathom...?
Person2: Why are you doing this? Handing out these horrors! Why...?!!
Person1: I'm trying to understand what drives you, what fuels your passion. You didn't create this masterpiece by chance.
Person2: I did. I poured my heart and soul into it.
Person1: No, you didn't! You were inspired by something greater than yourself.
Person2: What difference does that make? It's still my creation.
Person1: My friend, why should you want all the world to believe you're a genius? Is that your legacy? Is it?
Person2: No, it's not about being a genius. It's about leaving a mark that will be remembered for eternity.

Person1: I'm hired to do a piece of work, my reputation precedes me. Yours, on the other hand, is a different story.
Person2: What're you talking about? I'm an actor, we're all actors. We pretend...
Person1: Save it. I've seen your "acting" skills in action. You're more like a amateur trying to cover their tracks.
Person2: That's not fair. I've worked hard to get where I am.
Person1: Hard work? You call getting caught on security camera "hard work"? I'm from a different school of thought, where professionalism matters.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. I've never heard of you before.
Person1: That's because I'm not from around here. I was brought in to clean up the mess you left behind.

Person1: Professor Thompson?
Person2: What is it, Alex?
Person1: I just wanted to say thanks for the internship opportunity. It's been an incredible experience.
Person2: Well, it's not really my job to please. Hope you learned something.
Person1: I was wondering, would you try it on? It might add a new perspective to your research.
Person2: Uh, yeah, uh... I don't think that's necessary, Alex.
Person1: Figuring things out for yourself is the only freedom anyone really has. Use that freedom. Make your own choice, Professor.
Person2: Good for you, Alex. Go find out.

Person1: What's the point of that?
Person2: Well, sometimes when we get 'em, they're not completely dead, you know?
Person1: You're not crazy, are you?
Person2: Of course not! Why do you ask?
Person1: You talk about this stuff like it's normal.
Person2: It's just a hobby, okay? I promise you, I'm not crazy.
Person1: If you were with me, you wouldn't talk like that.
Person2: I'm with you now, and I'm talking to you.
Person1: And how's that going for you?
Person2: It's going...alright, I suppose.

Person1: I'm worried about the safety of our new design. We can't afford to have an accident.
Person2: I understand your concerns, but I assure you, I've taken every precaution. You know, I sometimes just stare at something I've designed and it amazes me.
Person1: I appreciate your confidence, but we need to be cautious. Why don't you go out there and review every single aspect of the design, and then we can discuss any potential issues?
Person2: That's a great idea. Thank you for understanding.
Person1: It's the least I can do. We're in this together.

Person1: You were quick enough to get my help when you needed it.
Person2: I told you about these people. They see you, they see opportunities.
Person1: And if it had gone well for you tonight, maybe you'd be keeping quiet about all this.
Person2: I'm not playing with you, they are looking to get you caught up.
Person1: You hearing me?
Person2: I've been hearing you, but I grant you everything.

Person1: I've set that old phone up as a donation box and I'll get Jahn to write out a sign. It's the least I can do.
Person2: You're doing this for Billy, aren't you? To prove to him and to yourself that you're a good person.
Person1: What's wrong with that? I want to make a difference.
Person2: Nothing's wrong with it, but sometimes it's not about what we want. It's about what's best for others. Like Billy.
Person1: You're right. I guess it doesn't matter how much I love him, or how much you love him. I guess it's like you said, the only thing that counts is what's best for Billy.
Person2: Exactly. And I think we can both agree on that.

Person1: I'll call you.
Person2: Oh, I was going to discover the secret of the universe.
Person1: That's right. I've been searching for it everywhere.
Person2: And what makes you think you'll find it?
Person1: I've got a few leads. Anyway, you're crazy if you think you'll find it first.
Person2: Maybe I already have.

Person1: What do you think is the most important quality for a leader to have?
Person2: I think it's being able to make tough decisions quickly, like when we're in a high-pressure situation and there's no time to think.
Person1: That's an interesting perspective. Can you tell me about a time when you had to make a difficult decision?
Person2: Well, I have to admit, I'm a people person. I love people, and I think that's helped me in my previous roles. But, I also have to make tough calls sometimes, like when I had to let someone go from our team.
Person1: I see. And how did you handle that situation?
Person2: Honestly, it was tough, but I tried to approach it with empathy and understanding. I think that's key in any difficult conversation.

Person1: Hold on, my love. I know that to be with you is to defy the odds. But not to be with you is to defy my own heart.
Person2: Then we will both take a chance, together. Who are we taking a chance with?
Person1: With each other, my love. Bet our sweet hearts we are.

Person1: I'm thrilled to be working with Dr. Furtwngler, Rachel. Me, can you believe it? 
Person2: You're a lucky person, Alex. Politics and art must be kept separate, after all.
Person1: I appreciate your insight, my friend. But let me ask you, what's the secret to Dr. Furtwngler's success? I'd really like to know.
Person2: I think it's because he's a true artist, Alex. He loves you too, in his own way.

Person1: We don't want to go there.
Person2: Wait a minute, the fourteenth, that's the same day the conference ends. I mean... didn't they say that's when the new project is being announced? Look... "Revamping marketing strategies for Ellingson industries" - they're really shaking things up!
Person1: Clay could save us an awful lot of time.
Person2: He certainly could. About a month. But we need to focus on the presentation first.

Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: You could have been a chef, a scientist, or a musician. You could have traveled the world or started your own business. But you chose to protect people. I find that very interesting.
Person1: If Corbett's men find out, we're in trouble. I need you to go to my place on the Haul Road and tell Anne Marie I'm okay.
Person2: I'm not doing it for free. I need something in return.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a brilliant idea. You're not alone in this.
Person2: I know, I know. It's just that everyone else seems to think I'm wrong.
Person1: That's because they're narrow-minded. I genuinely believe your approach is the right one.
Person2: Thanks, man. That means a lot coming from you. Sometimes I feel like I'm fighting this battle alone.
Person1: You're not alone. And together, I think we can persuade the others to see things our way. But first, can you tell me what really happened with the project proposal?
Person2: Honestly, I'm not even sure anymore. I just know I didn't mean for things to go that far.
Person1: Well, let's take a step back and figure it out then. We can work through this together.

Person1: You asleep?
Person2: What?
Person1: Please.
Person2: I could help you find what you're looking for.
Person1: Don't.
Person2: So tell me what's bothering you.
Person1: I don't know.

Person1: You're all just jealous.
Person2: Let's not get into this again. I know them. If you said something, they'd take it out on me.
Person1: Actually, I have no idea what the real issue is. I was just trying to deflect.
Person2: And I'd take it out on them. But I think we're just avoiding the main problem.
Person1: And I'd end up in a worse situation. Let's focus on finding a solution together.
Person2: There isn't gonna be a next time. We're gonna work this out now.

Person1: I've got a plan to get you out of the country. Go to the LAX and pick up a ticket at the Pan Am desk.
Person2: Where am I headed?
Person1: You'll be going to Rio. Flight 306 departs at eleven PM. You'll have a first-class ticket, so I'm sure you'll enjoy the ride.
Person2: What's the hurry? Can't I stay a bit longer?
Person1: I think it's best if you leave now. You don't want to be around when Mrs. Caldwell finds out about Cecile and her music teacher.
Person2: Oh, that's right. I almost forgot. What's the plan to deal with that situation?
Person1: I was thinking we could rat Cecile out to her mom. That should put an end to the relationship.
Person2: And who will they turn to for help then?
Person1: That's not our problem. You just focus on getting out of the country and staying there for at least a year.

Person1: You're being reckless with your words, Professor. What kind of example are you setting for your students?
Person2: Ah, it would be a pity to squander such a strong conviction. Perhaps you should channel it into something more constructive.

Person1: I'm afraid there's been a misunderstanding, Captain. I was never informed about your inspection.
Person2: Look around you. Does it seem like we're prepared for an inspection?

Person1: You're shaking like a leaf. Been in a fight, have we?
Person2: I don't remember. I guess so. Looks like it. Feels like it.
Person1: Well, you've got a nasty gash on your forehead. You must've hit your head.
Person2: I guess I did. What's going to happen to my job now?
Person1: Lucky you've got a good record, that's what's going to save you.

Person1: Do you always keep mementos from your past?
Person2: I try to remember why I did it, and I can't. It all seems so abstract. My old guitar, for instance, I slaved for years to master it, but now it just gathers dust.

Person1: Hi, I'm having a bit of an emergency. Can I speak to someone who can help me?
Person2: What's going on? I'm only equipped to handle certain types of requests.
Person1: I'm trying to track down a person, and I'm not sure who to turn to. It's a bit of a sensitive situation.
Person2: I'm listening. What's the story?
Person1: Okay, so I'm trying to help my boss, Mr. Jenkins, find his estranged daughter. He's not in great health, and this is really important to him.
Person2: I see. And you think I can help you with that?
Person1: Well, I was hoping you could connect me with someone who knows more about...people-finding than I do.
Person2: Let me see what I can do. Can you hold for just a minute?

Person1: Are you okay? You seem a bit out of place.
Person2: Yes, I'm fine. I just feel like I don't quite fit in with the others.
Person1: I'm here to help you, Lorl. What's going on? You can talk to me.
Person2: It's hard to explain. I just feel like I'm different from everyone else, like I'm a maidservant in a world of aristocrats.
Person1: It's okay to be different, Lorl. And I'm here to listen. Maybe I can help you find your place.

Person1: You're not as slick as you think you are, pal. I'm willing to give you a chance to come clean.
Person2: What makes you think I'm hiding something?
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I've seen your type before. You're just trying to get ahead, no matter who you step on.
Person2: That's not fair. I'm just trying to make a living.
Person1: Save it. I've heard it all before. You're not the first one to try to sweet-talk your way out of trouble.
Person2: Maybe I'm just trying to do the right thing for once.
Person1: Yeah, right. And I'm the King of England.

Person1: What's wrong with me? I'm too focused on success. That's the trouble with me.
Person2: His eyes just darted to the left! He's hiding something!
Person1: It's just a nervous habit, don't read into it. You know darn well I'm telling the truth.
Person2: I'm not so sure. Gentlemen, I think we need to investigate further.

Person1: I'll be at the desk, but don't introduce me, let it go, just start talking. You're gonna be here, behind them when they sit down.
Person2: They'll be looking at you. They don't know who you are.
Person1: Whatever the 'story' is, let's hear that. You were her teacher.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Say it. You were the one who gave her a failing grade.
Person2: I was one of a group of professors...
Person1: Answer affirmatively. Simply. Keep those answers to three words. You weren't 'part of a group,' you were her teacher. Isn't that right?
Person2: Yes.

Person1: We've got a situation on our hands, and I need your expertise to resolve it.
Person2: Take a long view, and let's assess the consequences of our actions.
Person1: I've got a roomful of people waiting for a solution, and I won't let them down. I'll make sure we find a way out of this, no matter what it takes.
Person2: Wilfred, we've got work to do. Let's focus on finding a solution that benefits everyone involved.

Person1: I knew you were different.
Person2: Of course I am. What about you? Have you just never tried rock climbing or have you never tried it with me?
Person1: I think I've tried it.
Person2: Well that's a no. No wonder you're not psyched about it. You've never even tried it with a guide?
Person1: ...I've never had a guide.
Person2: Are you kidding? You've never had a spotter?

Person1: I'm really enjoying my new job as a high school teacher. I get to teach Japanese and Chemistry.
Person2: You know, you'd look lovely with your hair down. Those braids are a bit too much.
Person1: I like my hair this way, thanks. So, what brings you here today?
Person2: I was just wondering, did you notice anything unusual around here lately? A footprint, maybe?

Person1: I'm worried about Alex. He's been acting strange lately.
Person2: What do you mean? Has he said something to you?
Person1: No, it's just a feeling I have. I think he might be in trouble. Can I come over and talk to you about it?
Person2: Of course, I'll look out for him. We're all here for each other.

Person1: You know me...I never hurt anybody. How can you still be mad at me?
Person2: Apologies don't instantly heal wounds. Where's the money?
Person1: I've been trying to make it up to you. I need it to make things right.
Person2: Trust takes time to rebuild. Be patient, and we'll talk about it then.

Person1: I've been traveling non-stop for months, never staying in one place for more than a night or two. Can you please turn off that music, it's giving me a headache?
Person2: I'm not trying to drive you crazy, but I do have a secret that could change everything. We're taking precautions, just in case - that's why we're wearing these ridiculous outfits.

Person1: I've been thinking, what kind of partner was I that I could walk out on our deal? It got to where I couldn't tell anybody about the shipment--I couldn't stand that look in their faces when I said it wasn't delivered on time. 
Person2: Like "three thousand a ki?" That's nice. And I can supply the transportation into South Florida and the Gulf, more reliable and on-time than FedEx.
Person1: And why should continuing excellence cost more? 
Person2: Cost less. That's the point. We become partners. Only in this territory and only on loads we run. And you don't pay us three thousand a ki. You pay us zero. Why we get is thirty percent of the load. Product or cash.
Person1: I guess it doesn't matter how much I trust you, or how much you trust me. I guess it's like you said, the only thing that counts is what's best for the business. 
Person2: Zero risk. 'Cause we guarantee every load. Anywhere, for any reason, it comes up short, we make good. Your operations will, from now on, run risk-free.

Person1: You've been through a tough time, haven't you?
Person2: It's been a cake walk, compared to what my family went through.
Person1: I'm sorry to hear that. Childhood is over, and it's time to grow up.
Person2: I know. I just wish I could've had more time with them.
Person1: I understand. I had a big brother who died when I was young, and I don't remember much about him.
Person2: I'm sorry. Losing someone is never easy.
Person1: Yeah. But we don't have to dwell on it. We can talk about something else if you'd like.

Person1: I think you're a nice person. I like you. But I can read signs if the print is large enough.
Person2: What do you mean? You're not going to cancel our meeting, are you?
Person1: No, no. It's just that I sense a sort of tenseness, as if you were afraid of something. Or hiding something.
Person2: Maybe I am. But I promise it's not about what you think. I found something interesting in an old book, and I think you should know about it.
Person1: What kind of book?
Person2: A guide to secret societies and sects. I think it might explain some strange occurrences.
Person1: Strange occurrences? You're being cryptic. I don't like it.
Person2: I'm sorry. I just want to make sure I have all the facts before I share them with you. Can I pick you up at your place on Thursday night, and we can discuss it over dinner?
Person1: Fine. But don't think you can distract me with food and charm. I want answers.

Person1: I've been thinking about this old poem, it's about searching for someone who truly understands you. And the last line goes, "Who knows? Perhaps the same bird echoed through both of us, yesterday--
Person2: --separate, in the evening. But I think we're running out of time to find that person. We need to make a move, take a chance, and see if we can find each other amidst the chaos.
Person1: I'm not sure I'm ready to take that leap of faith. What if we're wrong, what if we get hurt?
Person2: We'll never know unless we try. And I'd rather take the risk and fail than wait and wonder what could've been.

Person1: We're in this together, aren't we? No single person can make a difference, right?
Person2: That's correct, ma'am!
Person1: Just hold on, and wait for the team to arrive. I can't do anything for you, but when they get here, they'll be able to help you.
Person2: Who's coming to help us?
Person1: The entire team. We're all in this together, after all.

Person1: I've got a proposition for you. If you can prove yourself trustworthy, I'll give you a share of the profits.
Person2: What makes you think I'm not trustworthy?
Person1: I've seen the way you look at others, like you're sizing them up. I don't want anyone taking advantage of me.
Person2: You're one to talk. You're always making threats, standing people up against the wall.
Person1: That's just business. I'm a fair man, but I won't be taken for a ride. Now, are you in or out?
Person2: I'm in. But if you're caught taking graft, I'll be the first to turn you in.
Person1: Ha! You think you're clever, don't you? Well, I like that about you. Let's shake on it and make it official.
Person2: But what about the population increase? You're not going to start standing people up against the wall again, are you?
Person1: Oh, that? That was just a figure of speech. I've got a new plan, and it doesn't involve violence. At least, not yet.

Person1: What's taking so long? We can't stay here forever.
Person2: We're waiting for Pa to drive us to Minden. Then we take a stage to Reno, and another one over to Auburn.
Person1: That's a crazy route. Can't we find a shortcut?
Person2: I've been thinking about that. We could ask Clay for help. He could save us a month of travel time.
Person1: What are you waiting for? Go talk to him.

Person1: I'm worried about you, Charlie. I see you getting sucked in deeper and deeper.
Person2: I sleep it off. I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: That's just it, Charlie. You could do anything, but instead, you're stuck in this rut. I still care about you, and I want to help.
Person2: S'okay. I appreciate your concern.

Person1: I'm surprised you're still here, considering the circumstances. Respect my wish and leave.
Person2: You're being unfair, darling. I'm trying to help you, but you're pushing me away.

Person1: You're all just jealous of my new bike.
Person2: God, I don't remember seeing that model at the store. Strange, I could've sworn it was a Sunday when I last checked.
Person1: Oh, but I forgot! The store owner takes Sundays off, that explains it.

Person1: I've been watching you, and I think you have what it takes to join my team. You're a hard-charger, always pushing to get things done.
Person2: What makes you think I'd be interested in working for you?
Person1: I can offer you a chance to make a real difference. Our test is crisis and observation, and I think you'd thrive in that environment.
Person2: I'm not sure I buy into your methods. How do I know you're not just using people for your own gain?
Person1: I've had to make some tough decisions in the past, but I've always been transparent about my intentions. You can verify that for yourself.
Person2: I'll think about it. But I'm not making any promises.

Person1: I need my space sometimes. That doesn't mean I'm leaving you for good.
Person2: What do you mean? You're not making any sense.
Person1: I'm trying to protect myself. I don't remember anything, but I do remember walking here, sort of. Now I remember this place and you. That's about it.
Person2: How do you remember how to talk? You're not even making an effort to recall anything.
Person1: Nothing. I just do. I think about the car crash sometimes... I remember the glass.

Person1: Do you always begin conversations this way?
Person2: Oh yeah. We figure the one of us that actually gets the last word will get a little more respect. It's been an ongoing discussion. Heads or tails?

Person1: I think some people have a natural talent for this job, and some don't.
Person2: Do you think I have what it takes, Captain?
Person1: Well, that's what I'm here to find out. But let me tell you, it's not just about talent. It's about commitment. You're not just committing to a job, you're committing to a way of life. And that's not something to be taken lightly.

Person1: I got the first copy. The one to town is, but that's about it.
Person2: Hey, bein' ballsy with your life now doesn't change what came before -- it's just stupid.
Person1: What, you think I'm doin' this to prove something? I told him who you were and what had happened.
Person2: Let's just not let one bad call lead to another. The phones are working?
Person1: Well, mine's still out. But the ones in town were working just fine. I called that agent of yours.
Person2: I was supposed to be home for her birthday three days ago.

Person1: You're really going to charge me two hundred bucks for these Nike specials?
Person2: Yeah, what's wrong with that? You're shitfaced, you can afford it.
Person1: This is so patronizing. You think I'm just going to hand over my money because I've had a few drinks?
Person2: Well, you're not exactly in a position to negotiate. Besides, I told you, it's a good deal.
Person1: Why are you doing this to me? You don't care about my well-being at all.
Person2: Oh, come on. I'm just trying to make a living. You're being dramatic.
Person1: Just let me sit down, I need to think this through.

Person1: Are you thinking about something?
Person2: Let's see how much he wants to play.
Person1: I don't know if that's a good idea. What's going on?
Person2: Just wondering how far people will go when pushed.

Person1: I need your help. I've been tracking a lead, but I can't crack it alone.
Person2: Maybe you should back off. You're not thinking clearly.
Person1: I've been over the evidence, and I'm convinced it's hidden in those names. You know how to reach me. Take my advice, when dealing with these people, go by the book.
Person2: In a week... we will never have had this conversation.
Person1: What do you mean? Are you in or out?

Person1: I don't think you'll have time for that walk after all.
Person2: He said if I didn't meet him at the park, he'll be very disappointed.
Person1: I wouldn't take that too seriously.
Person2: I believe what he said. He's been acting strange lately.
Person1: They're only trying to scare you, that's all.
Person2: How do you know what they're doing? You're not even listening to me.
Person1: I'm on your side, remember that. Let's go get some fresh air.
Person2: I don't know... I have a bad feeling about this.
Person1: Words can hurt very much, but sometimes you have to ignore them. Come on.

Person1: I've been desperate for a change, but watching him struggle was just too much fun.
Person2: What, and deny myself the only pleasure I get from him? Did I tell you about my latest project?
Person1: What happened?
Person2: I've been trying to get funding, but it's been a nightmare. Useless bureaucrats.
Person1: You're very frank, Rachel. I think it would be quite something to know you in private life.
Person2: Quid pro quo, Alex. I've been wondering, have you ever felt orphaned in your career?
Person1: After my mentor left, I felt like I had nobody. I was starting from scratch.
Person2: Clever boy. You're so close to making a breakthrough - do you realize that?
Person1: No. Tell me why.
Person2: After your mentor's departure, you were forced to find new opportunities. What happened next? 
Person1: I went to work with a new team and they had a different approach.
Person2: A more innovative approach?
Person1: Exactly. And it's been a game-changer.

Person1: I think I've had one.
Person2: So you believe me?
Person1: What do I do?
Person2: He likes it.

Person1: Captain, I'd like to know exactly where we're headed.
Person2: Stand at attention until you're sick of it, because I don't ever want to see that sloppy posture again, you hear me?  Now, as for your question, we're going to the training facility in Colorado.
Person1: There's... there's no need to bring any special gear, or... I mean -- I didn't know if we'd be doing any simulations that require specific equipment.
Person2: Oh.  We might. Yes. We can. Let's.
Person1: Okay, got it. What did you think I was going to ask?
Person2: Whether we'll be doing any night training exercises...

Person1: I've been thinking about my time in the program... it's like I forgot what real freedom feels like.
Person2: If I can speak freely, it's impressive how quickly you're readapting. You're really sharp, and I mean that as a compliment.
Person1: Thanks, I think. But sometimes I wish you wouldn't analyze everything. Can't you just live in the moment for once?
Person2: I know what you mean. I hate sounding so clinical all the time. It's just that I've seen so many people struggle to adjust.
Person1: I appreciate your concern, but I need some time to figure things out on my own. Can you just let me make my own mistakes for a while?
Person2: Hell, yes! You deserve that chance.

Person1: I need to talk to you, Rachel.
Person2: You got my attention. What's this about?
Person1: Then why are you here?
Person2: Curiosity, I suppose.
Person1: This is my business. I want to know what's going on.
Person2: Mind your own business, please.
Person1: Remember the promise you made to me?
Person2: You're not going to bring that up again, are you?
Person1: Give me some straight answers for once.
Person2: I'm not hiding anything from you.

Person1: I've been trying to reach you for hours, Rachel. The roads are open, and I finally got through to the hospital.
Person2: For forgiveness to be real, it has to be the hardest thing on earth. Otherwise, it's just empty words.
Person1: I know, I know. But I had to tell you, I got the first copy of your book. I slammed my money down as soon as I saw it.
Person2: You want to talk about my book now? I'm trying to make amends, and you're celebrating a novel?
Person1: I'm sorry, it's just... I've been worried sick about you. And I called your agent, she said she'd tell your daughter you're okay.
Person2: My daughter... I was supposed to be home for her birthday three days ago. Do you think she'll forgive me?
Person1: Of course, she will. You're her father. And I'm sure she'll love the book. I peeked at the first page, it's wonderful.
Person2: You think a book can make up for my mistakes?

Person1: I've been reading about your latest art exhibition. I heard it was a huge success.
Person2: Yeah, it was a great turnout. But I'm not sure I'm comfortable with all the attention.
Person1: You seemed to see some very interesting things on your journey to becoming an artist. What drives your creativity?
Person2: Well, you can't believe everything you read in magazines. People will believe what they want to believe.
Person1: That's true. But I think your art speaks for itself. You have a unique perspective on the world.
Person2: Yeah, I guess I do. But sometimes I wonder, how many more people are out there who truly understand my art?

Person1: I've decided to take on a new project at the community center.
Person2: No, please. I don't think I can handle it.
Person1: It's time to step out of your comfort zone, Alex. You'll grow from the experience.

Person1: I've been feeling really restless lately. I think I need a change of pace.
Person2: What kind of change are you thinking of?
Person1: Sometimes I feel like life is passing me by and I'm just watching.
Person2: You're not thinking of quitting your job, are you?
Person1: Actually, I've been considering it. I want to travel and experience new things.
Person2: That's a big decision. Make sure you've thought it through. You don't want to rush into anything.
Person1: I know. I just feel like I'm stuck in a rut and I need to shake things up.
Person2: I understand. Just be careful what you wish for.

Person1: Now that I've shown you that I know that much, and can guess more -- will you help me find the truth?
Person2: I mean, it's a freaky situation. The guy's got a shady past.
Person1: At least you knew about it. And you knew it'd be a problem.
Person2: Well, lucky for me I found out. Thank God I have friends who care. Look, I'm sick of talking about this. Let's focus on moving forward.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you? I've got a meeting in twenty minutes and you're still messing around.
Person2: You've got to relax, I'm doing the best I can. Show me someone who's perfect and maybe I'll try to be like them.
Person1: Is it too much to ask for a little human consideration? Have you no sense of urgency?
Person2: I'm doing this for you, not for my health.

Person1: You never thought that's a heavy load?
Person2: I did a bad thing, Rachel. I'm not talking about the project.
Person1: What? What'd you do?
Person2: I let my team down. I was supposed to lead them, but I failed.
Person1: We allus thought you were strong enough to carry it. Was we wrong?
Person2: I was filled with self-doubt, man. I just kept making excuses till it was too late.
Person1: Wait a minute, wait a minute. You're not alone in this. Ever where you go, I'm with you.
Person2: Yeah, well, I done my best. What I done with myself is my problem.

Person1: Are you CRAZY? You're carrying all those books around!
Person2: Ain't got nowhere to set 'em down. I've got a Bible, a book on Christmas, and one on carpentry.
Person1: Why do you need all those?
Person2: I'm trying to learn, I reckon. I've got a lot to make up for.
Person1: What do you mean?
Person2: I did some bad things in the past. I'm trying to make amends.
Person1: What kind of bad things?
Person2: I'd rather not say. Let's just say I'm trying to be a better person now.
Person1: I think you're on the right track. You don't seem like someone who'd hurt anyone.
Person2: Thanks. I'm trying my best.

Person1: Look out of that window. The city is alive tonight.
Person2: There's no one here but the shadows. What do you want from me?
Person1: I'm not afraid of you. You're just a mystery waiting to be solved.
Person2: It's very dangerous to assume you know what I'm thinking. You don't know me at all.
Person1: Perhaps not, but I sense there's more to you than meets the eye. And I'm drawn to that.
Person2: (sighs) You're wasting your time. I'm not what you're looking for.

Person1: We may have a chance.
Person2: You don't think that's just a fantasy?
Person1: If I wanted to make love with you again, I'd do it sober.
