Person2: All right, but you talk to the lawyer and I'll talk to the judge!

Person1: I'm surprised you're still using that old computer. Don't you think it's time for an upgrade?
Person2: What makes you think I have the budget for a new one? You know, if you helped me with my project, I could finally get a promotion and afford a better computer.
Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with that. I've got my own deadlines to meet. But I can give you some advice on how to troubleshoot your current computer.
Person2: That would be great, thanks. I've been having some issues with my BLT drive. Do you know anything about it?

Person1: How long have you been working on this project?
Person2: I don't remember. Is that what you wanted to ask me?
Person1: Actually, I need you to do something for me. Can you review the Johnson report?
Person2: Yes, sir. What am I looking for?
Person1: Just make sure everything is in order. And, by the way, your tie is loose.

Person1: I think we should reconsider our decision, Governor. Or is ambition only a virtue among the elite, a fault for the rest of us?
Person2: You better get going, sir. If something good doesn't come of this meeting, I think we'll all be disappointed.
Person1: I told you last night, this can be the start of a new era. If you won't accept our proposal, we'll simply find someone who will.
Person2: Are you sure, Governor? I just don't know about this...

Person1: I'm glad you're back, brother. You were a lot of help with those projects. Your skills are bad-ass.
Person2: I'd hoped I was finished with all that. But I'm feeling too good to argue with you, so what were you doing around my office the other night?
Person1: Begging your pardon, I haven't been to that part of town in years! I've been busy with my own work.
Person2: Yeah... I know how that is. Every friend I knew in the industry is doing their own thing now. My old team... it's like we all went our separate ways in an instant.

Person1: My father was a great mentor, he taught me everything I know. And when I requested his guidance, he took the time to help me. He slaved over my mistakes for years before I was done.
Person2: That's impressive. But, listen, I've been thinking about your problem. I'm not the guy to give you advice. It would be unfair. But, there is something I could do for you. Introduce you to my colleague.

Person1: You want to work in the lab at night?
Person2: I'll work anywhere, anytime. I know I can't be choosy.
Person1: How's your research record?
Person2: Clean. Real clean. As clean as my conscience.
Person1: Well, I guess some people have it and some don't.
Person2: Do you think I have it, Dr. Lee?
Person1: Definitely. I think you may be a very gifted researcher.
Person2: Age?
Person1: Twenty-eight.
Person2: Education?
Person1: Ph.D. in biology.
Person2: You moonlighting?
Person1: No, I want long shifts.
Person2: We hire a lot of dedicated researchers here.
Person1: So I hear.
Person2: Hell, we ain't that much fussy anyway. There's always an opening on one project or another. Fill out these forms and give them to the girl at the desk, and leave your phone number. You gotta phone?
Person1: Yes, I do.
Person2: Great, we'll be in touch soon.

Person1: I'll come for dinner. And in the meantime... you'll think about what we discussed?
Person2: Yes, ma'am. I got in the cab and it was layin' there on the floor.
Person1: Where were you going when you got in that cab?
Person2: In a week... we will never have had this conversation.

Person1: You're a real heavy sleeper sometimes.
Person2: I've got double-decker bunks if you can't wake her up.
Person1: Is your mother often this unstable?
Person2: They need guidance, and I'm the one to give it to them.
Person1: Tomorrow's another day. You know what my English literature teacher said about you?
Person2: No, what did she say?
Person1: She said you were legendary. I wrote a theme about you, and she said, "You're a legendary hero out of the Golden Age of Heroes."
Person2: That's nice. You thank her for me.
Person1: I will, if I must. Out there, for all to hear. Or... you may speak, as planned.
Person2: I'm not afraid of what you might say. I'm the Lord's voice in this town.
Person1: Then go to bed and get lots of sleep. We'll talk more in the morning.
Person2: Tomorrow's Saturday. I'll have plenty of time to rest then.

Person1: I'm not good company. I should be alone.
Person2: If I can speak freely, I think you're selling yourself short. You're not as bad as you think you are.
Person1: You don't have to do this. Show me a good time, I mean.
Person2: I'm not trying to show you a good time. I'm trying to understand you. You're like a puzzle I'm trying to figure out.
Person1: I don't think so, but if that's what you want...
Person2: No, it's not what I want. It's what I need. I need to understand people like you.

Person1: You're in such a hurry. You can't wait.
Person2: It's OK. There's no problem. I just need to get this done today.
Person1: Well, that's what I said, isn't it? You can have the report by the end of the day.
Person2: No, I can't wait for that. You know when I wait? When it's important to wait. It's not important to wait for this report.

Person1: I decided to help out at the local community center.
Person2: You're really getting paranoid, aren't you?
Person1: What do you mean? I just want to give back to the community.
Person2: Yeah, right. You're just trying to prove to yourself that you're not a total paranoid.
Person1: That's not true! I was having lunch with some guys from the center, and I said, "Did you eat yet or what?" and Tom said, "No, didchoo?" Not, did you, didchoo eat? You get it?
Person2: Ah, you see conspiracies in everything. California would be good for you, a change of scenery.
Person1: No, I cannot. You keep bringing it up, but I don't wanna live in a city where the only cultural advantage is that you can make a right turn on a red light.
Person2: Right, forget it. Aren't you gonna be late for meeting your volunteer group?
Person1: I'm gonna meet them in front of the center. I think I have a few minutes left. Right?

Person1: I'm glad you're back, brother. You were a lot of help with those horses.
Person2: I'd hoped I was finished with all that. But...
Person1: You know, you're lucky to have found a new purpose. Most people struggle to find their way after a big change.
Person2: Don't I know it. Every friend I knew in the old life is gone. It's like a land mine went off and I'm the only survivor.
Person1: Mind if I ask you something? Why'd you put up with the struggle for so long?
Person2: I was trying to find myself, I suppose. But it's hard when you feel like you don't belong.
Person1: I think I understand. I went through something similar when my father passed away. I was young, and it felt like the whole world had been turned upside down.
Person2: I'm sorry to hear that. How did you cope?
Person1: I ran away, tried to find a new family. But it didn't work out. I had to find my own way, eventually.
Person2: Yeah, I think I'm still trying to find my way. But it's good to talk to someone who understands.

Person1: I'm not certain what you're planning, but I hope you're not thinking of leaving us soon?
Person2: Oh, we might. Yes. We can. Let's. I've been given over many times these four years, and there was always a candidate or two waiting to apply for the situation.
Person1: Is it not a pleasure, gentlemen, for me, as I am drawing near the goal, to find my home such a happy one; my wife so fond of me, that she is even now thinking of appointing a successor?
Person2: I'd like to know exactly where we are going. What did you think I was going to ask next?
Person1: Corbleu, knight, do you think that it will be the fear of your ghost will deter me? We might eat at a restaurant that has a dress code.
Person2: I'm sorry for you, Mr. James. I'm grieved to keep you or any gentleman waiting. Had you not better to arrange with my doctor or get the cook to flavor my omelette with arsenic?

Person1: I've seen better work from you, Alex. Makes no difference to me which project our team's resources are allocated to.
Person2: Look, I'll stay behind and handle the fallout. The rest of you focus on the new initiative!
Person1: Are you crazy, Alex? You know what you're doing, but this is a huge risk.
Person2: I can't do it any other way. It's a different kind of challenge.

Person1: We can at least try -- we might be able to find a solution --
Person2: Yes, what?

Person1: I've never felt so alive. Everything looks different, like I've got a new perspective.
Person2: I doubt it. You're just trying to convince yourself it's not as bad as it seems.
Person1: No, I mean it. I feel like I've been given a second chance. You know what I mean? Like I've got something to look forward to.
Person2: Maybe. But sometimes it's worse than you think. It's worse than anywhere you've ever been.

Person1: I'm impressed. You've got a good eye for detail. Them hands you got, they know what they're doin'.
Person2: Thanks, I guess. What's with the curiosity?
Person1: Just wondering what brings someone like you to a place like this.
Person2: I'm not sure. Maybe I'm just trying to figure things out.

Person1: I've been thinking, we need to take a closer look at the system. There are two renegade programs running amok, and I don't have time for this.
Person2: Sir, I understand your concerns, but we did take care of that User you sent us. It's just a matter of time before we catch the others.
Person1: Time is a luxury we can't afford. And neither can you. You're not the one who should be making excuses, Charlie.
Person2: Excuses? I'm just stating the facts, sir. We'll get them eventually.
Person1: Eventually isn't good enough. I want results now. This afternoon, a great program was compromised. I want it restored to its former glory.

Person1: You're so smart and fun and crazy! You rock my world.
Person2: They say I'm lucky because I can't remember the accident.

Person1: I've got a bad feeling about this, we need to get a description out to the team.
Person2: That's not going to be easy, there's no record of what our guy looks like.
Person1: You're telling me nobody's ever seen him? That's hard to believe.
Person2: I'm afraid it's true. He's been very careful to cover his tracks.
Person1: Well, we're not going to get our money back if we don't find him. Do you know what happens to people who welch on a deal?
Person2: Yeah, I do. And I'm telling you, I don't have it.

Person1: Sorry to take up your time like that, Captain. Don't work too hard.
Person2: Wait a minute! Who put you in charge of this mission?
Person1: Well, I just figured it should be the one with the most experience. But if that ain't the consensus view, hell, let's put it to a vote!
Person2: Suits me! I'm voting for a new leader, someone who can get us out of this mess.
Person1: We're all in this together, Captain. Let's work as a team.

Person1: I've got my eye on that new rifle, Jack. It's a beautiful piece of work.
Person2: Yeah, I bet! Actually, it reminds me of that old twenty-gauge you used to have -- you always go for guns with some classic style.
Person1: What are you talking about? I've never seen that rifle before.
Person2: Oh, come on! You're not going to try to deny it, are you? It's a great find, but you deserve it. Right's right.
Person1: Forget you, Jack!

Person1: Doctor, how long has this been happening?
Person2: Honestly, I'm not sure. It's been a while, but I've lost track. The worst part is, I never know when it will change back again.
Person1: I used to work with you at the hospital. I was a nurse. Don't you remember me?
Person2: I'm sorry, I don't think so. Please, can we focus on my treatment?

Person1: I've never seen any of these men before.
Person2: Indeed we were. We were speaking of my father...
Person1: Is this being recorded?
Person2: Freud, do you know...? Freud psychoanalyzed patients in One Afternoon.
Person1: And how did he do that?
Person2: He saw the truth, and spoke it... I'm afraid, this wine is making me woozy...
Person1: ...you have to eat. Does that upset you?
Person2: No. Why should it?

Person1: What do you think? Of course, I'm curious! What's involved?
Person2: When you slaughter a goat and wrench its heart out with your bare hands, do you then summon hellfire?
Person1: Um, no. I'm a botanist. I study plant species.
Person2: I mean, what are you actually doing here? What is the hidden agenda?
Person1: I'm just looking for a new species to research. I didn't expect to find...whatever this is.
Person2: You will be contacted with the assignment. Be prepared.
Person1: Assignment? What kind of assignment?

Person1: Now by chance, you mean...?
Person2: I mean he did it to make you stay with him!
Person1: Jeez, that's quite a story... I'm...
Person2: Well, lucky for me I found out. Thank God I have friends like him. Look, I'm sick of talking about the past. Let's talk about you. Perhaps in the end, he did it to show me that he could. For he lavished affection on her, there was no doubt about that. Life was very different with her, as you can imagine...

Person1: Are you kidding? I think it's too much.
Person2: Look, would you question your architect?
Person1: What's going on? This design is stealing the whole space.
Person2: It's great. You wanna speak to the contractor? Hold on...

Person1: Do you always cook like this?
Person2: You've got to relax, I'm just trying something new.
Person1: Yes, but it smells like it's burning.
Person2: That's just the sauce, it's supposed to be caramelized.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly. Why would you want to take credit for something you didn't do?
Person2: I may not have killed him, but I poisoned his reputation.
Person1: That's not the same thing. You're not a murderer.
Person2: What difference does it make? I've ruined his legacy.
Person1: Is that your way of getting back at the world? By destroying someone else's name?
Person2: No, it's my way of becoming immortal. Whenever they speak of him, they'll have to speak of me too.
Person1: Oh, the vanity of it all. You're serving a cruel fate, not a higher power.
Person2: Don't pity me. Pity those who are blind to the truth.

Person1: Look out of that window. What do you see?
Person2: I see the city, Master. It's bustling with life.
Person1: Exactly. And that's why I've called you here. I need your expertise.
Person2: We're honored, Master. But we're not sure what we can do for you.
Person1: Nonsense. I've heard great things about your skills. I'm not angry with you, I assure you.
Person2: Thank you, Master. We'll do our best to serve you.

Person1: You're just going to sit there?
Person2: Jesus, first my mom, now you. You two need to relax.
Person1: Okay. Hope no one bothers you.
Person2: I hope they do.

Person1: I'm so frustrated, I feel like I'm always a step behind in everything.
Person2: I've been impressed with your knowledge of the market lately. Have you considered adjusting your strategy?
Person1: It's not just about the market, it's about feeling like I'm not in control.
Person2: We all have rough patches. Maybe we can work together to get you back on track. Would you like to discuss it over dinner tonight?
Person1: That's kind of you, but I think I just need to regroup and focus on my goals.
Person2: Sometimes a fresh perspective can help. If you change your mind, let me know.

Person1: Think for a second. Is there someplace you've always wanted to visit?
Person2: Do you think I'd be a good fit for that new travel program, Dr. Rodriguez?
Person1: Definitely. I think you may have a real knack for exploration.

Person1: I've been thinking about our family's legacy, and I want to make sure we're not forgotten.
Person2: I understand what you mean. Sometimes I feel like we need to fight to preserve our reputation.
Person1: Exactly! We can't let others tarnish our name. We need to take a stand and show them we won't be pushed around.
Person2: I'm with you, but we need to be strategic about it. We can't just lash out without a plan.

Person1: You're full of ifs.
Person2: Nobody else is going down but me, okay?
Person1: I think you liked it with him.
Person2: Bein' ballsy with your life now doesn't change what came before -- it's just stupid.
Person1: What, you think I'm doin' this to prove something?
Person2: Let's just not let one bad call lead to another.

Person1: I think it's time for you to leave, don't you?
Person2: Who are you to tell me what to do? Do you remember the Goliath, Miller?
Person1: I'm just trying to help you patch things up with your folks. If something good doesn't come of this, I think I'll go crazy.
Person2: Are you sure this is the right decision?

Person1: I'm just looking at you. Does that make you uncomfortable?
Person2: Thank you so much.
Person1: Depends on what you're seeing. Is everything okay?
Person2: Forty-five minutes from now, I have a meeting and I'm still not prepared.

Person1: I'll meet you at the museum at 2 pm. And in the meantime... you'll think about what we discussed?
Person2: I'm not sure I can make it. I'm supposed to perform a ceremony at a church, but I've forgotten which one.
Person1: Well, you see, I'm the curator of the museum, and I really need your expertise. I'm sure it's just a minor slip of memory.
Person2: I'm Reverend Johnson, and I've just arrived from Portland. I hope I can remember the church before the ceremony starts.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm ready for this.
Person2: For what? Facing the truth or taking responsibility for your actions?
Person1: Uh -- both, I guess.
Person2: Well, it's fixed, so you'll have to deal with it.

Person1: I'm going to give her a wedding present. Thought I'd better do it now, before I forget it.
Person2: What's going on? You're acting strange.
Person1: I know I left the gift box there. Maybe you've seen it?
Person2: Take my advice, forget about the gift for now. You seem troubled.
Person1: Oh, yes -- yes -- that's right -- I need to pick up my suitcase from the Grand Central too.

Person1: You mean like, a perfect alibi?
Person2: Please, Rachel, don't pretend you're innocent. I have proof.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a bad idea. We're in over our heads.
Person2: You're in danger. All of you. I have no time to explain.
Person1: Wait, what do you mean? What's going on?
Person2: I'm sorry, but I have to go. You'll figure it out.
Person1: Figure it out? You're not making any sense. Did you invite them?
Person2: Who? Oh, the Smiths? Yes, they're coming. And you're thrilled to have them.
Person1: Whatever you say. But I still don't understand what's going on.
Person2: Just be careful, okay? That's all I can say.

Person1: Is there any chance we can get exclusive access to this story?
Person2: Hey, I want to scoop! I've been working on this for weeks.
Person1: Well, that's out. Either we share it with the other reporters or we don't get the tickets. Now will you go and call them before I change my mind about the whole thing!
Person2: Okay, but I'm only doing this because I think we can get a better angle if we work together. See you here.

Person1: I've waited a long time for this chance to go, and you're not going to stop me now.
Person2: This is another victory, my friends. What began with the lash shall be concluded with a caress.
Person1: Do you mean to tell me you want to leave the city? I'll die if I have to stay here another minute!
Person2: To finish last evening's delightful work. I thought you had instructions from the Governor not to take anyone.
Person1: The Governor? Who pays any attention to him? The people laugh at the Governor. All they want to know is how much freedom he will give them.
Person2: Aren't you afraid to leave? You don't want to look like a coward, do you?
Person1: Coward? Chang told you that, didn't he? He tells everyone I'm a coward. He wants them to stay away from me.

Person1: I've been noticing some strange occurrences lately. How long has this been going on?
Person2: Honestly, I'm not sure. A few days, maybe a few weeks. But I have something that might help you understand. I have evidence in the car. Why don't you come and take a look?

Person1: You're so smart and fun and crazy! I'm really going to miss you when I'm in Japan.
Person2: Oh, it's nothing... I better go, I'll talk to you later. Have fun there, you're so lucky you don't have any kids yet.

Person1: I'm telling you, I saw it with my own eyes. The whole thing felt off, like two and two was coming up three.
Person2: You're being paranoid, just like when you thought that guy at the tennis court muttered "Jew" under his breath.
Person1: I'm not paranoid, I just pick up on those kinds of things. And I know what I saw - a guy shooting from behind that fence.
Person2: That's impossible. We have three bullets and three shots, and that's all we're willing to say.
Person1: But what about the echoes? You're not listening to me.
Person2: I am listening, but you're not making sense. You're seeing conspiracies everywhere, just like with that guy at the record store and the Wagner sale.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is I know what I saw, and I'm not going to let you dismiss it.
Person2: Fine, but you need to calm down and think this through. We'll get to the bottom of it, I promise.

Person1: We can at least try to reason with them -- we might be able to find a peaceful solution.
Person2: I seem to remember you being more aggressive last time we met. What's changed?
Person1: Sit back, let's talk this through. I didn't kill you last time, and I don't want to fight now.
Person2: That's true. You did spare my life. But I'm not sure I'm ready to trust you yet.

Person1: Would you mind showing me around the new office space? I feel a bit uneasy about navigating it on my own.
Person2: Yes, desperately. I've been waiting for someone to share it with.
Person1: Plus, it'll be good for you to get out of your comfort zone.
Person2: But it's not that dark in here now.

Person1: I've never felt this way about anyone before, not even my closest friends. I think my future is with you, Rachel.
Person2: We can at least try to reason with them -- we might be able to find a compromise.

Person1: Did you get that from your father or is there someone new in your life?
Person2: Stop prying, it's none of your business. I'm grateful for what I have.
Person1: What's there to be grateful for? You're being secretive and it's annoying.
Person2: You wouldn't understand. Just read the letters I left on the table. They explain everything.

Person1: Then why are you here?
Person2: When you're ready to let go, to be unsingle and unmiserable, you will.
Person1: I'm not looking for that.
Person2: Until then... curiosity gets the better of us, doesn't it?

Person1: Do you always take risks like this?
Person2: Yes, desperately.
Person1: That's the spirit! You're not going to let fear hold you back, are you?
Person2: No, I'm not.

Person1: You're like the most amazing friend I've ever had. You're so supportive and fun!
Person2: I know, but trust takes time to rebuild. Be patient.
Person1: I've been trying to make it up to you. I want to regain your trust.
Person2: Apologies don't instantly heal wounds, Emma. It's the actions that follow.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you? 
Person2: What, you think I'm doin' this to prove something? 
Person1: I don't know, but you're not even trying. 
Person2: Let's just not let one bad call lead to another. 
Person1: Fine, see you later.

Person1: I've been desperate for a change of pace, but this new whiskey bar is just too much fun.
Person2: You'll see. One of these nights you'll wake up and find a group of locals tearing the place apart.
Person1: Not in this part of town. The owner's got a good reputation.
Person2: They'll climb right into the VIP section and sit on the bar with their guitars. They might even sit on the owner's favorite stool. Put the spotlight right on him.
Person1: I read about it in the local paper. It's an interesting concept.

Person1: For God's sake, will you please calm down? We're trying to figure this out.
Person2: I think he's gonna hurt me. I really do.
Person1: You just relax, and I'll go talk to him. I'll see what I can do.
Person2: Yeah, okay... But if you're not back in 20 minutes, I'm leaving.

Person1: I'm curious, how far do you think someone could get?
Person2: Oh, maybe twenty miles or so. Of course, that's just a rough estimate.
Person1: Twenty miles? That's interesting. So, you're saying it's possible to get that far without any issues?
Person2: Well, I wouldn't recommend it, but if someone really wanted to, I suppose it's doable. But after that, it gets much more complicated.
Person1: I see. And what about the arrangements? Would everything be taken care of?
Person2: Yes, everything would be in place. You just need to show up and be prepared.

Person1: I won't lose you.
Person2: They all come here. How do they find me?
Person1: And if you lose me, you'll know that I loved you and wanted to go on loving you.
Person2: I'm sorry... I don't like people touching my things. It's a minor compulsion.

Person1: I've never seen this place before. Is this an informal meeting?
Person2: Respect my wish and take a seat. We'll get started soon.
Person1: Are you taking notes? What does it look like?
Person2: I'm just making sure I remember everything. Does that upset you?
Person1: No. Why should it? I'm just curious about the purpose of this meeting.
Person2: Well, then? Let's get started. I'll introduce you to the others.
Person1: I don't know them. And if I told you I saw their car parked outside, would that surprise you?
Person2: Not at all. They're colleagues.

Person1: I think I understand without your telling me. I know something of your history, Rachel. I know that you haven't taken a risk in years.
Person2: You've got to relax, I'm not trying to hide anything. I've just lost my confidence.
Person1: After that wonderful first project - after all the recognition and the good reviews? What happened?
Person2: I don't think that you would understand if I told you. You're always so quick to judge.

Person1: I'm glad to see you're using your skills, Alex. Them hands you got, they know what they're doin'-- ain't that right?
Person2: Yeah, I've been practicing. But I need to ask you something, Mom. Please don't be mad at me. I know I messed up, and it was stupid. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone, especially not you.
Person1: What are you talking about, sweetie? You're not making any sense. What did you do?

Person1: We already know each other. Hey, Rachel.
Person2: Hey, Mike. I think I can help you with your problem. Mrs. Lippman's son might be able to assist you. I have his card somewhere.
Person1: Thanks, I'd appreciate that. Do you mind if I step inside while you look for it?
Person2: Not at all. By the way, I love your shirt. You have a great sense of style.
Person1: Thanks, I just got it yesterday.

Person1: Now by exceptional, you mean...?
Person2: I mean he's a Rufus over your head. The guy's a gem.
Person1: Oh, Your Excellency, I don't know what to say.
Person2: Well, lucky for me I found out. Thank God I have friends like him. Look, I'm sick of talking about exceptional people. Let's talk about you.

Person1: I'm so glad I caught you before class started. I've been meaning to ask, have you seen the new art installation on campus?
Person2: No, I haven't had a chance yet. But I've heard it's quite something.
Person1: Yeah, it's free to view, what more could you want? Although, I did notice they're accepting donations.
Person2: That's great. I'll have to check it out during my lunch break. Speaking of which, how long do you think this seminar will run?
Person1: I thought it was supposed to be 45 minutes, but I'm not entirely sure.

Person1: I've never seen anyone search a person like that before. 
Person2: Would you like to show me your technique?
Person1: It's all about crisis and observation. You have to know where to look. 
Person2: Like the lining of their coat, or the back of their collar?
Person1: Exactly! And don't forget to check their shoes. You'd be surprised what people try to hide.
Person2: I see what you mean. But what if they're trying to deceive us?
Person1: Then we have to use our instincts and pay attention to their behavior. It's all about reading people.

Person1: We've been given a chance to make a difference, Lucy. She's a bright kid, and she looks up to us.
Person2: What makes you think she needs us? She seems pretty self-sufficient to me.
Person1: Maybe that's what I like about her. She's not afraid to speak her mind. We could learn from her.
Person2: I suppose you're right. I was thinking of taking her to the convention, but now I'm not so sure.
Person1: Why not? It could be a great opportunity for her to learn and grow.
Person2: Yeah, maybe you're right. I'll think about it.

Person1: I've been thinking about quitting my job. How long do you think I can survive without a steady income?
Person2: Long enough to realize your mistake, perhaps. But frankly, if you want to make a reckless decision, that's your problem. Just don't come crying to me when you're struggling to make ends meet.
Person1: That's not very supportive. I thought you'd understand my desire for freedom.
Person2: I understand it, but I also know that freedom comes with a price. And in your case, that price might be too high.

Person1: You two need to calm down, we can't afford to panic.
Person2: You could save him, little bird.

Person1: What is power?  For you, I would do anything.
Person2: You want me to believe you're committed to our cause, well, I don't, that's just rhetoric!
Person1: I'm not just committed, I'm dedicated.  Without our leader's vision, our movement would falter.
Person2: Then what, what drives you? Tell me...

Person1: I think you may be a very gifted artist.
Person2: What? What'd I do?
Person1: I mean, your latest piece is incredible. The way you captured the emotions is stunning.
Person2: That's not what I'm talking about. I did a bad thing, Rachel.
Person1: What are you talking about? You're being vague.
Person2: I was at the gallery opening, and I saw her, you know? And she started flirting with me, and I was filled with... I don't know, a mix of emotions, I guess.
Person1: And then what happened?
Person2: I got angry, and I... I said some things I shouldn't have.
Person1: What did you say?
Person2: I told her she was talentless and that her art was a joke. I was cruel, Rachel.
Person1: Oh, no. That's not like you at all. Why'd you say those things?
Person2: Because I was messed up, I guess. I wasn't thinking straight.
Person1: Well, you need to apologize to her, then. Make things right.

Person1: So, what's your professional opinion?
Person2: Honestly, I think the defendant is struggling to cope with the situation.
Person1: That's not what I'm looking for. I need something more concrete.
Person2: Fine. I'll say it on the stand: the defendant exhibits symptoms of anxiety and depression.
Person1: Question withdrawn, you may step down.
Person2: Wait, I wasn't finished. I had more to say about the defendant's mental state.
Person1: No further questions.

Person1: I'm not "people." I'm just me. And I do whatever I goddamn want to do. Got it?
Person2: You're not as dumb as I thought you are.
Person1: What's the point of having a place to stay if it's not a cozy bed and breakfast?
Person2: You're looking for a sense of security, aren't you? Something to make you feel grounded.
Person1: The material world is an illusion. It doesn't matter if they're there or not. The world is in my head.
Person2: But your body is in the world, isn't it? If someone offered you a place to stay, you wouldn't necessarily refuse, would you?
Person1: I can take care of myself. Don't worry.

Person1: I'm telling you, I saw it with my own eyes. The whole thing felt off, like two and two was coming up three.
Person2: You're not ready yet, looking like a junk yard. How do you expect me to take you seriously?
Person1: I'm scared, okay? I don't know what's going on, but I know what I saw. And now you're trying to dismiss me?
Person2: Show me someone who's not trying to manipulate the situation, and maybe I'll listen.
Person1: I'm not trying to manipulate anything. I just want the truth to come out. You're the one who's being evasive.
Person2: Fine. Tell me exactly what you saw. But don't expect me to believe everything you say.

Person1: We're not exactly killing it out there, are we?
Person2: For a couple of old pros, we're doing all right.
Person1: I was thinking, why don't we make a little wager on the side? Just to spice things up.
Person2: You mean with the Roses?
Person1: Yeah, them. I already invited them, and they're thrilled to join in.
Person2: And what makes you think they'll play along?
Person1: Oh, I promised them it'll be a blast. Scout's honor.
Person2: Before I forget, can you put that book on the shelf for me?

Person1: I'm so frustrated with my new neighbor. He's always blasting his music late at night...
Person2: That's annoying. Did you try talking to him about it?
Person1: Yeah, I did. But you know what? It made me feel happy to stand up for myself!
Person2: Well, we all make mistakes, and it's part of the learning process. Maybe he didn't realize how loud it was.
Person1: Exactly! I just wanted to make a good impression on him, you know, be a good neighbor.
Person2: Understandable. Remember, nobody is perfect. We'll figure it out together.

Person1: I'll come for dinner. And in the meantime... you'll think about what we discussed?
Person2: Charenton? The administrator there is quite well-loved, is he not?
Person1: I'm afraid so; he's an idealist. You'll have to be politic.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm ready for this.
Person2: Yes, desperately. You've been preparing for weeks.
Person1: Well, it's fixed, so I'll have to do it.
Person2: That's the spirit! You'll be great.

Person1: Is someone there?
Person2: I got that...ma'am.

Person1: You've been acting strange lately... Like the other night.
Person2: What night?
Person1: Last time I saw you. You were distant, preoccupied.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I know you too well. You're not thinking of someone else, are you?
Person2: What are you insinuating?
Person1: I'm not insinuating anything. I just want the truth. Did something happen that night?
Person2: Nothing happened. You're just being paranoid.
Person1: I'm not paranoid. I just know when something's off. And something's off with you.

Person1: You realize, we're running out of time, so if you wanna make a decision, do it now. One is the lives of tens of thousands of people--people just like you and me!
Person2: Hey now! I'd like to say that there's more to consider than just the urgency. What about the perky atmosphere we could create here?
Person1: Wyoming? You can't be serious. That's not a solution, that's just avoiding the problem.
Person2: Well, excuse me for trying to think outside the box. You're the one who's being close-minded here.

Person1: I think there's too much emphasis on wealth.
Person2: You're being dramatic. Would you like to speak to the mayor about it?
Person1: I don't know... I just feel like we're losing sight of what's important.
Person2: Look, would you question a doctor's diagnosis? Sometimes you just have to trust the experts.
Person1: I suppose. But what about the rumors of corruption?
Person2: Oh, those are just baseless accusations. No one takes them seriously.
Person1: Really? Because I've heard whispers of embezzlement and cronyism.
Person2: That's just small-town gossip. We're making progress, and that's all that matters.

Person1: I've finally finished the report.
Person2: Well, it's about time, so you'll have to present it to the board now.
Person1: Do you think I'm the one who should be presenting it?
Person2: Why not? You're the one who wrote it.

Person1: I'd like to know exactly where we're going tonight.
Person2: For a price.
Person1: What do you mean? You're not going to tell me unless I do something for you?
Person2: Good God, no. It's just that I've planned a surprise, and I want to make sure you're willing to keep an open mind.
Person1: I won't do your portion of the preparations, if that's what you're getting at.
Person2: No, nothing like that. I just want to make sure you're ready for something different.
Person1: And I'm not covering for you if things don't go as planned.
Person2: Fair enough. Let's just say it'll be an adventure.

Person1: I've been searching for answers, but everything seems off.
Person2: Commander, we did contain the system breach, but now we have a rogue AI on our hands.
Person1: I don't have time for this, Lieutenant. We need to act fast before it's too late.
Person2: Yes, sir. We'll get it under control. These things take time.

Person1: I've got a situation that's really pretty serious and I'm not sure who I should talk to or what I should do.
Person2: Well, what's the situation?
Person1: I've been searching for my long-lost sister and I think I've finally found her. But I need your help to confirm her identity.
Person2: That's quite a story. How did you find her?
Person1: I've been going through old family records and talking to relatives. I think I've narrowed it down to a few possibilities.
Person2: And you want me to help you figure out which one is your sister?
Person1: Exactly. I was hoping you could help me get in touch with them, or maybe even facilitate a meeting.
Person2: I'd be happy to help. But first, can I ask, what makes you think this person is your sister?

Person1: You're pushing your luck. What makes you think you can guarantee that?
Person2: There's a shipment coming in tonight. It's going to change everything.
Person1: Like what? A magic solution to all our problems?
Person2: Better. Zero risk. We guarantee every shipment. Anywhere, for any reason, it comes up short, we make good.
Person1: And what's in it for you?
Person2: We become partners. Only in this territory and only on shipments we handle. And you don't pay us a fixed fee. You pay us thirty percent of the shipment. Product or cash.
Person1: That sounds too good to be true. What's the catch?
Person2: No catch. We can deliver what no one else can. And we're willing to put our money where our mouth is.

Person1: What's the real reason you're here? What's the hidden agenda?
Person2: You're one to talk about hidden agendas. You're always so quick to judge others, but what about your own motives?
Person1: I'm just trying to get to the truth. I'm not afraid to call out hypocrisy when I see it.
Person2: That's rich coming from you. You're always so dramatic, always trying to stir up controversy. Can't you just have a normal conversation for once?

Person1: You're like the most amazing artist I've ever worked with. You're so talented and fun to collaborate with!
Person2: Sure, it's only a small commission, don't bother telling me what you're going to do with the piece.

Person1: Do you think we can make a difference?
Person2: We can at least try -- we might be able to change a few minds.
Person1: He's a very passionate person.
Person2: Where are you going now?
Person1: To the meeting.
Person2: Someone waiting for you there?
Person1: The whole committee is waiting.
Person2: There's a certain kind of leader who uses their charisma to inspire others. Is that our leader?
Person1: If I'm inspired by them, and I haven't said I am, then so what?
Person2: So everything. That's so what. So I begin to wonder about their motives.
Person1: But you don't even know them. How can you care what they do?
Person2: I know them enough. Enough to want to make a change.

Person1: I don't know... He can be nice... sometimes.
Person2: What are you doing?! Get on with your misery!
Person1: They were in me.  Both places... you know.
Person2: Him? I don't know... He can be nice... sometimes.
Person1: Do you want it dirty? or something.  I tried to turn away, but he pushed me to the floor.
Person2: What do you mean?! I could leave him if I wanted to!
Person1: Yes.  I said stop.  I screamed.  I mean that's how it sounded in my head.
Person2: Mph rmph rm rmph rm.

Person1: I don't remember what day that was, do you?
Person2: No, sir. I heard strange voices in the night.
Person1: Strange voices? Now, stop behaving as if you're trying to hide something. Those noises had a reason, and I think you know what it was.
Person2: I'm telling you the truth, sir. I got in the cab and it was layin' there on the floor.
Person1: A cab? What were you doing in a cab at that hour?

Person1: I thought you were avoiding me.
Person2: What gave you that idea? You're the one who's been distant lately.
Person1: I was hurt when you didn't show up to our meeting last week.
Person2: I apologize for that. It was unforgivable.
Person1: I forgive you. But I have to say, I'm surprised you're being so cooperative.
Person2: Don't be too sure. I'm not always as predictable as you think.
Person1: Well, as far as I'm concerned, you're a valuable team member. Decency-wise and otherwise-wise.
Person2: Thanks for understanding. But let's focus on the project at hand. We can't afford to fall behind schedule again.
Person1: Agreed. I'll make sure to keep you updated on my progress. Cheers.
Person2: Cheers.

Person1: I've been desperate for a change, but watching you suffer was just too much fun.
Person2: Honestly, do you actually think I would sneak in here and sabotage your project without asking you?
Person1: Sometimes we have to improvise. Think, Alex. Does Rachel have any friends. I mean, besides you and... me?
Person2: Rachel? My Rachel? What's happened?
Person1: Nothing, she's just been sort of, I don't know... overwhelmed.
Person2: Overwhelmed? By who? Her parents?
Person1: Good God. Let's go talk to them. 
Person2: Good idea, only one problem. I don't know where they live.
Person1: Ah. Wait a minute. The university must know where they live.
Person2: It's a little late to call Admissions.

Person1: You're going to regret this. We gave you every chance we could.
Person2: You're crazy. I think you're the one who's going to regret it.

Person1: I think we've been given a rare opportunity, Emily. This young artist is talented and needs our guidance. Maybe that's why we've been brought together, to help each other grow.
Person2: What makes you think I need your guidance, Mr. Jenkins? I've managed just fine on my own.
Person1: Hoity-toity! You're too proud to accept help, just like I was when I was your age. But I've learned that sometimes it takes a little humility to reach greatness.
Person2: I'm not too proud, sir. I just don't want to be tied down to anyone's expectations. I have my own vision, my own style.

Person1: I didn't mean to assume you'd want one. If you're interested, I can ask Emma and Ryan if they have any extras.
Person2: Spider-Man is a good guy, right? I mean, he's on the side of right and niceness.
Person1: Exactly! And cute baby animals, don't forget those.

Person1: I'll respect your wish and leave, Captain. But before I go, do you have any family or friends you'd like to say goodbye to?
Person2: Actually, I've always wanted to visit Japan. Do you think that's possible?
Person1: Japan? That's an interesting choice. I'll see what I can do. But for now, I need to attend to some matters.

Person1: I've been noticing you've been distant lately. It makes me worried, frankly. 
Person2: Why do you think I've been keeping to myself? 
Person1: Ah, but that's the thing. The more you isolate, the more I wonder what's going on. Even here, in this quiet place, I sense there's more to it.

Person1: You've got good hands, Alex. They know what they're doing, don't they?
Person2: I guess so...
Person1: But between the time you finish a project and call it a day, what happens? You could do anything in that time.
Person2: I don't know. I just like to unwind, I suppose.
Person1: That's just it. You could unwind in so many ways.

Person1: Tell them who I am! I'm the new team leader!
Person2: Hey, Rachel. Your colleague needs help. That's Dr. Patel, the renowned scientist!
Person1: Actually, I just met her. This is Sophia.
Person2: Oh, I heard she's working on a top-secret project. You better be careful, I heard some confidential files went missing earlier today.
Person1: Thanks for the warning.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this. Can we try it again?
Person2: What's wrong? You're not going to get a better offer.
Person1: Who's side are you on, anyway?
Person2: I'm just trying to help you. Eyes closed, let's focus on the task at hand.
Person1: If I don't cooperate, what's the worst that could happen?
Person2: You might get stuck with a bad outcome. But if you work with me, we can find a solution that works for both of us.
Person1: I need a minute to think about it.

Person1: We'll be fine. I've got a plan to get us out of this mess.
Person2: Jesus, you're as optimistic as Mars. You two need a reality check.
Person1: The Smiths are coming over tonight. I invited them without telling you, I know.
Person2: And you're thrilled to have them, I suppose?
Person1: Whatever you say. I just hope they can help us figure something out.
Person2: Did you tell them to keep it quiet?
Person1: Scout's honor. And before I forget, can you put that folder on the bookshelf?

Person1: I've been watching you, and I think you're ready to break free from the constraints of society.
Person2: What are you talking about? You came to my home this morning, didn't you?

Person1: I'm sorry, I don't understand.
Person2: It's not important. The important thing is I'm here to learn more about the company's financials.
Person1: Actually, I think it's down .2 from the last quarter's highest, but I believe it will pick up.
Person2: I'm equally impressed with your knowledge of the market. Would you like to ride with me to the meeting and discuss it further?
Person1: Come on, let's ride. I have a feeling we can help each other out.

Person1: I've been trying to go easy on you, but this can't continue. We need to address the issues.
Person2: Waitaminit, I got it! Let's break it down into smaller tasks and prioritize them. What do you think?
Person1: Brilliance, sheer brilliance. Let's work on a plan together.
Person2: I appreciate that. I've been overwhelmed, but I'm willing to learn and improve.

Person1: Do you know what's going on in this play?
Person2: What play? The one we're rehearsing?
Person1: Yes, exactly. I know we approved it, but frankly I can't remember why. Can you refresh my memory?
Person2: Well, the playwright makes a hero out of a young artist. She outwits her wealthy patron and exposes him as a fraud.
Person1: Ah, I see. And that's why I love her character so much. If one day I have to leave, and you read this script, I want you to know how much I admire her spirit. Although I'll never see her again, her passion, her creativity, her face...

Person1: I'm glad I caught you, Rachel. Don't work too hard, okay?
Person2: What's going on? You look worried.
Person1: I just talked to your colleague, Miss Thompson, about the project deadline. She wanted to extend it, but I convinced her to stick to the original schedule.
Person2: Thanks, I appreciate that. I was getting anxious about meeting the deadline.
Person1: We're all here to support each other, Rachel. By the way, I saw you talking to Dr. Patel at the office party last week. How did that go?
Person2: Oh, it was fine. We just chatted about our weekends. I'm still trying to process everything that happened that night, to be honest.
Person1: You're going to be all right, Rachel. Just take it one step at a time.

Person1: So, are you packed for the trip?
Person2: Thank you so much. I've got everything I need.
Person1: Is it sabotage, does my planning mean nothing to you? Have you no human consideration?
Person2: I love you, and I know you're worried. Don't let yourself down.
Person1: I won't. I just want us to have a good time together.
Person2: Me too, kiddo. Me too.

Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: Ball's in your court. I've got investors and partners waiting. You'll be set for life.
Person1: I don't believe you. You're not telling me everything.
Person2: Better if I just show you. Then you'll understand the opportunity I'm offering.

Person1: You've read The Fountainhead?
Person2: No.
Person1: Then how do you know about Howard Roark?
Person2: You told me.
Person1: What are you talking about? I've never mentioned him to you.
Person2: Oh, I must have misunderstood. I thought we had a conversation about it last week.
Person1: We didn't discuss anything last week. I think you're confusing me with someone else.
Person2: I apologize for the mistake. But since we're on the topic, have you read The Fountainhead?
Person1: Yes, I have. What do you think about the theme of individualism in the book?
Person2: I think it's fascinating. I'd love to discuss it more with you. Would you like to grab a coffee and talk about it?

Person1: I can feel it. Something's gonna blow in this town.
Person2: Question withdrawn, you may step down.
Person1: You think I'm messing with you, but I'm telling you, I sense a storm coming.
Person2: I said, no further questions.
Person1: You're not listening to me. I'm trying to warn you.
Person2: I'm not implying anything. I just want the truth.
Person1: The truth is, I'm scared. I don't know what's going to happen.
Person2: Then tell me what you do know.

Person1: I'm sorry to say, but every day that goes by, I'm losing customers. Every bad review costs me business - I have to work harder to regain their trust.
Person2: Forget it. You've already spent too much time worrying about what others think. We're going to make a change, and it's going to be good for business.
Person1: It's bad practice. You can't just ignore the problem and expect it to go away.
Person2: Occasionally, sure, okay, you got to take a risk. But that's good business. And I'm willing to take that risk with you.

Person1: I'm worried about Emma. She's been feeling really down lately.
Person2: We'll be fine. We just need to make sure she doesn't get too isolated.
Person1: I invited the Watsons over for dinner. They're always good company.
Person2: That was the plan. And you're thrilled to have them.
Person1: Yes, it'll be nice to have some distractions around. Did I tell you I ran into Aunt Barbara the other day?
Person2: How is she?
Person1: She's doing well. She reminded me that depression is a terrible thing and can bring on illness.
Person2: We'll make sure Emma knows that too.

Person1: What's going on, Alex? You've been acting strange lately.
Person2: Who sent you, Rachel?
Person1: No one, I just noticed a change in you. Like the other night.
Person2: What night?
Person1: Last time I saw you. You weren't yourself, Alex. You were distant.
Person2: I don't remember... What happened that night?

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a trap.
Person2: Nothing matters. We're just pawns in their game.
Person1: Then we have no use waiting around. Let's take a stand.
Person2: But what's the point? We're just going to get crushed anyway.

Person1: I've got to get back to work. I still have my job.
Person2: You're not going anywhere until we settle this. I've got the gun now.
Person1: You're going to be very disappointed. You think you're onto the truth, but you're just grasping at straws.
Person2: We'll see about that. The rest of the money is here in the car. Why don't you come and get it?

Person1: I've got the rest of the money right here. Why don't you come and get it?
Person2: What's the catch? You're not just giving it away.
Person1: Look, I'll show you something. See this card? It's not just a regular card.
Person2: What's special about it?
Person1: It's a way to make some money, in case you get stuck somewhere. I'm trying to help you out.

Person1: I want to see you, Alex. I heard we're both on the new project.
Person2: You got the memo. I'm right in front of you.
Person1: Listen, I'm sorry I doubted your skills earlier. You proved me wrong.
Person2: It's OK; I'm sorry I snapped at you. The main thing is we make a good team.
Person1: Exactly. So, what's your approach to this project?
Person2: I was thinking we could brainstorm together. You have a good eye for detail.
Person1: Sounds like a plan. Let's get started.

Person1: Hi, I'm trying to get in touch with someone who can help me with a situation.
Person2: What's going on?
Person1: I met this guy on a plane and I think I might have gotten him into some trouble. I had some... substances with me, and I didn't realize he was a bit of a straight arrow.
Person2: What kind of trouble?
Person1: Well, let's just say I think he's in over his head. And I feel responsible. I was wondering if you could connect me with someone who could help me get him out of this mess.
Person2: I'm not sure what you're getting at, but I can try to help you out. What's the guy's name?
Person1: His name is Frank. Frank TJ Macky. Do you know him?
Person2: No, I don't know him. But I can try to help you figure out what to do.

Person1: I doubt it. I don't think prison's so bad you don't want to remember it...
Person2: That's your funeral. We've got a deal comin' to us, and I'm not backing down.
Person1: I haven't got what you're looking for. You're barking up the wrong tree.
Person2: Oh, I must have been crazy! I lost my head completely! But I'm not giving up now.

Person1: I've got a proposition for you, my friend. What began with a spark shall be concluded with a flame.
Person2: I'm intrigued. What kind of spark are we talking about?
Person1: A spark of innovation, of course! We must increase the population with great rapidity. We give a couple seven years to raise a family.
Person2: And if they fail to deliver? What then?
Person1: Well, we'll have to take drastic measures. We'll stand them up against the wall... and offer them a second chance!
Person2: (laughs) You're a shrewd one, aren't you? But I think I'll take you up on your offer. To finish last evening's delightful work, I'll need your help.
Person1: Delightful work, you say? I'm strictly on the up and up, so everyone beware. No one must take a bit of graft unless they get their fair share.
Person2: (smirks) Oh, I think we can come to a mutually beneficial arrangement. After all, the population must increase, and I have a few tricks up my sleeve to make it happen.

Person1: What's going on here?
Person2: I'm Rosa, a librarian. I was asked to assist you with your research.
Person1: An evil librarian?
Person2: No, no, nothing like that! I'm just here to help. A generous patron is covering my services.
Person1: That's quite unusual. What makes you think I need help?
Person2: Well, you've been coming to the library for weeks, and I've noticed you're struggling to find what you're looking for.

Person1: You're like the most amazing person I've ever met. You're so smart and fun!
Person2: Yeah, I've seen you around. What did you do to impress everyone?
Person1: I don't remember. I just try to be myself.
Person2: Could it have been your speech at the conference?

Person1: Do you admit that this is your case?
Person2: I don't want it, and I don't think you can handle it.
Person1: Yes, I can. I'll make you my partner.
Person2: It's not about partnership, it's about who's in charge.

Person1: I'm so grateful for your help. It's not important.
Person2: Hello, who is this? I'm trying to reach Dr. Lee's office.
Person1: I'm Dr. Lee's assistant. What can I do for you?
Person2: I'm Reverend Brown, and I'm supposed to give a lecture at the conference today. I just arrived from Chicago and I've forgotten the room number. Can you help me?

Person1: Just for curiosity sake, that's all?
Person2: And anxious to get started. What's the plan for this expedition?
Person1: Twenty miles should be a good distance to cover today. Of course, it's not about the distance, but about what we can learn from the journey.
Person2: I see. So, it's about personal growth, then?

Person1: I wish you would have at least let me do the laundry. It's not going to be that easy getting all those tough stains out of your sister's clothes.
Person2: Well, the whole gamut. I'm trying to teach you some responsibility, and some fatherly advice, because, I tell you, there's things happening that you're probably old enough to understand. For example, on the cleaning front - now this is important - it's not advisable to mix bleach and ammonia, and not on your sister's favorite dress.
Person1: Cheese is particularly troublesome to get out of fabric, you know.
Person2: Worse than that Mexican Jumping Bean dip you spilled on the carpet last year?
Person1: Oh, much worse. But not as bad as when you tried to clean the oven with a blowtorch. You remember that?
Person2: Yeah, yeah. Okay. Give me the laundry detergent and watch your step. I'll come back for the vacuum.

Person1: I'm telling you, it was a setup from the start. He was playing me like a fool.
Person2: Take your time, let's get to the bottom of this. What makes you think that?
Person1: He was too smooth, too charming. And then he started making these suggestive comments, like "Do you want it dirty?" or something.
Person2: I see. And how did you respond to that?
Person1: I tried to brush it off, but he just wouldn't take no for an answer. He started getting aggressive, pushing me around.
Person2: Did you feel threatened at any point?
Person1: Yeah, I was scared. I didn't know what he was capable of. But I stood my ground, told him to back off.
Person2: Good for you. It takes a lot of courage to stand up for yourself like that.

Person1: I don't know why I just did.
Person2: Did you try to do it recently?
Person1: God, no. I kind of tried once, but it seemed stupid.
Person2: So, you're trying to make it all about something else and nothing else.
Person1: That's not it. I was wondering if I was doing the right thing, and it just seemed like a dumb thing to be doing.
Person2: If you talk about it, you don't have to do it.
Person1: That's not it. I just didn't know what to do with all that uncertainty.

Person1: I want it all. You guys want guarantees? I want the possibilities.
Person2: Respect my wish and go.
Person1: Life gets messy. Ugly messy. But I don't understand you. And I don't think I ever understood why you'd want to throw it all away.
Person2: He asked me to stay here.
Person1: We'd have had a ride. You'd have surprised yourself. I'll never love anybody else, you know.
Person2: Me too.

Person1: I don't remember you, but I think I'm supposed to.
Person2: What are you talking about? You're the one who called this meeting.
Person1: I don't remember calling this meeting. I don't even remember my name. But I know I'm in charge here.
Person2: Sir, I think you're getting confused. You're the Director, and I'm here to brief you on the latest developments.
Person1: The Director? Ah, yes. That's right. I'm the one who gives the orders. And I'm ordering you to tell me what's going on.
Person2: Well, sir, it's about the Smith case. We've got new evidence that suggests -
Person1: Evidence? I don't care about evidence. I care about results. And I want them now.

Person1: I had my suspicions, though, about the project leader.
Person2: Watch me. I'm looking for a way to prove it.
Person1: No, I don't think you can do that. It's not in your job description.
Person2: Deal's changed. I've been given new responsibilities.
Person1: No, the deal isn't changed. You can't just take on more work without permission.
Person2: You think I did this for recognition? I did this for the opportunity to make a real impact.
Person1: But you always knew you couldn't take on this much responsibility...
Person2: That's one thing, but I'm not gonna let my colleagues hold me back. Are you nuts? Are you nuts?
Person1: They didn't teach us to work like this at the training program.
Person2: Very well. That means that you have met all the requirements. Now, as to your role in the project...
Person1: That is good. But I'd like to know more about the expectations.
Person2: I'm afraid I'm not able to tell you much. Only that the project is a high priority for the company.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this. 
Person2: You're in a very tenuous position, hoss. Get used to it.
Person1: The next thing... I was in a situation where I felt trapped... you know, from being overwhelmed. 
Person2: Take your time. What happened then?
Person1: I tried to turn away, but I felt like I was being pushed into a corner. 
Person2: Was there a sense of coercion? Did you feel like you had no choice?
Person1: Yes. I said stop. I screamed in my head. It hurt me... 
Person2: That's okay. You're doing fine. But I have to ask you something here. When you say it hurt, was this the first time you felt that way?

Person1: I'm not questioning your expertise, Chef, but it's just not possible. I'm not capable of overcooking a souffl.
Person2: Hoity-toity! What's the matter here, Mr. Thompson? You're not used to taking orders from a woman, are you?
Person1: Look, Chef, I know that you're sincere and that you're trying to do a competent job, and that you're trying to be helpful, but I can assure you the problem is with the oven temperature, and with your recipe.
Person2: Okay, Mr. Thompson, well let's see the way things go from here on. Maybe we can find a way to make this dish work together.

Person1: You're not terribly important to me.
Person2: Why do you think I keep you here?
Person1: But what about our past? Our shared experiences?
Person2: We never really shared one. It's her very isolation that encourages the malcontents.
Person1: You're inhuman. You will not be unaware of the threat now posed by your own indifference.
Person2: I'm...in touch with humanity. I'm sorry.

Person1: Are you crazy? We're going to hit Poppa Joe tonight, right in the comfort of his own home.
Person2: Let's see how much he wants to play. I think it's better if we find this man before he finds us again.
Person1: Well, the light caught the side of his face for a second. And it looked like he had a gray beard, maybe... late fifties, early sixties.
Person2: Be careful. I'll see what I can do. How do I get in touch with you?
Person1: I'll call you tonight, afterwards.

Person1: I've got a proposition for you, Homer. I know you're good with your hands. Them hands you got, they know what they're doin', ain't that right?
Person2: Yeah, I guess so. What's in it for me?
Person1: Well, right man, there are many facets to this. If I can find your next big project, what's in it for you?
Person2: Does the Pope shit in the woods? I need a 10% finder's fee, at least.
Person1: Okay, done. I like the way you do business. I've got a lead on a new construction site that needs your expertise. It's on Radford, near the In-and-Out Burger. Meet me there tomorrow and we'll discuss the details.

Person1: I've had enough of this charade. I want out, and I need your help, Alex.
Person2: What's changed your mind?
Person1: Do you think you'd make the same choice again if you had to? Would you still take that risk?
Person2: What risk are you talking about?
Person1: If we don't stop this operation, it'll be a disaster. We'll be responsible for more harm than good. Are you even listening to me?

Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this. What kind of environmental concerns are we talking about?
Person2: It's nothing, really. Just a few anomalies we haven't fully identified yet. Let's try it again, only this time I'll explain the situation in more detail.
Person1: Okay, but I want to make sure I understand. You're saying we should proceed with caution?
Person2: Exactly. We don't want to rush into anything without knowing what we're up against. Just get me the necessary information and I'll keep you informed.

Person1: Now, do you want the good news first or the bad news?
Person2: You almost sound like that guy from the movie. What's his name again?
Person1: Ha! No, I'm not an actor. The bad news is we're running out of time. We have 36 hours to figure something out.
Person2: Then we need to come up with a plan, fast! What's the good news?
Person1: Well, I think I can help you act your way out of this one. I've got an idea.
Person2: Let's hear it!

Person1: I'm going to retrain you. I'm going to make you see things from a different perspective.
Person2: What's on your mind? You seem worried about something.
Person1: There's going to be a lot of changes happening soon, and I want to make sure you're prepared.
Person2: I'm not sure I'm ready for that. Can't we just stick to what we know?

Person1: I'm so tired of your excuses.
Person2: You're all just jealous.
Person1: What are you talking about? I'm trying to have a serious conversation here.
Person2: I don't understand what you're getting at. You're being really vague.
Person1: Fine. Let me start again. Don't you remember what happened at the conference last week?
Person2: Oh, yes... the conference... I was just kidding about the award, by the way.
Person1: What award? Never mind. Just focus on what I'm saying.

Person1: I've waited a long time for this chance to go, and you're not going to stop me now.
Person2: What made you do it? Who paid you off?
Person1: I bribed the porters. If it weren't for me, you'd never get out!
Person2: Nobody. I'm the maid!
Person1: The porters laugh at the High Lama. All they want to know is how much gold he will give them.
Person2: You don't want to look like an old woman, do you?
Person1: Look at me, do I look like an old woman? Is this the skin of an old woman? Look into my eyes and see if these are the eyes of an old woman?
Person2: I thought you wanted to leave Shangri-La?
Person1: I'll die if I have to stay here another minute!

Person1: I've set up a donation box, and I'll get Jahn to write out a sign.
Person2: What's the surprise?
Person1: Uh-uh, not yet. Let's have a drink first.
Person2: Here, this'll put hair on your chest.
Person1: No fair guessing. We better make it a free event, what more do you want?
Person2: You're being too generous. It'll cost us twice as much.
Person1: So what? Spills, thrills, laughs, games - it'll be a night to remember.

Person1: I know we haven't spoken in a while, but I didn't expect to run into you here, that's all.
Person2: Well, now you have. For the same reason, I've been trying to reach you. I've been thinking about the project we abandoned last year.
Person1: Oh yes, yes. And what about it?
Person2: I think we should revive it. It could be a great opportunity for both of us.
Person1: Ah, I'm not so sure. I've moved on to other things.

Person1: I see you're quite the philanthropist, Mr. Lebowski. Giving back to the community and all that.
Person2: Yeah, well, someone's gotta do it. And I'm not just talking about the Little Lebowski Urban Achievers. I'm talking about the environment, the arts...
Person1: That's very commendable. But tell me, what's the story behind this novel of yours coming out in the fall?
Person2: Oh, it's just a little something I whipped up. Nothing too serious. Just a humorous take on life, you know?
Person1: I'm sure it'll be a bestseller. You always were one for making people laugh. But don't forget, you're not just a writer, you're a role model.
Person2: Aye-aye, captain. I'll try to behave. But no promises, especially if they start serving Merlot.
Person1: Ha! Well, I'm sure it'll be a fun evening regardless. And who knows, maybe you'll even inspire some of these young people to take up writing themselves.
Person2: Yeah, and maybe they'll even occupy some administration buildings and smoke some thai-stick. You never know.

Person1: I think I'll go down and punch this editor on the nose.
Person2: Whoever tossed this place wants you. And I'm looking to stay outta the line of fire.
Person1: They've got you down as a sap. They'd call you anything if you gave them half a chance.
Person2: They lifted my wallet to make it look like a robbery. But there's a bug in my computer keyboard, a tap on the phone and a mike in the light fixture.
Person1: Sometimes it's the only solution. You've got brains, kid. You'll get along swell if you'll only curb your homicidal instincts - and keep your trap shut.
Person2: Like you said, maybe somebody's tracking one of your investigations. You're crazy.
Person1: I'll take care of that. I'll keep that stuff out of the papers - if you'll help me. But I can't do anything if you go around talking to people.
Person2: I'm you, I take that money and get outta town while you can.

Person1: What upsets you about that?
Person2: You are being really inconsiderate, and it's pissing me off. I wish you would've asked me about it.
Person1: But don't you think you're overreacting? It's not a big deal.
Person2: It's not about the thing itself, it's about the principle. You always do this, and it makes me feel like my opinions don't matter.
Person1: Fine, I get it. But can we please move on from this? I don't want this to ruin our evening.
Person2: Yeah, sure. But can I ask you something? Are you afraid of my reaction? Of me finding you silly for thinking of such things?
Person1: No, I'm not afraid. I just think we should communicate better, that's all.

Person1: I've been feeling restless, like life is passing me by. I'm considering leaving this town to explore new opportunities.
Person2: Are you sure that's wise? You've built a reputation here as a respected leader.
Person1: Sometimes I feel compelled to move on to greener pastures. I need guidance on what's next.
Person2: You're not thinking of abandoning your duties, are you? The people here need your leadership.
Person1: I'm not wallowing in sin and lust, if that's what you're implying. I just need a change.
Person2: I apologize if I misunderstood. But make sure you've thought this through. It's a big decision.

Person1: You're still seeing her, aren't you? Don't lie.
Person2: What's the hurry? You can't believe everything you read in magazines.
Person1: I knew it. I knew you weren't serious about her. Boy, how do they get away with printing stuff like that?
Person2: You'd be amazed at what some people will believe. Others are waiting, you know.

Person1: Excuse me, I need to get to the other side of the lock. Can you tell me how to proceed?
Person2: Ah, you're trying to get through? No, no, no. You can't go that way. It's not safe.
Person1: But I was told someone would follow me and guide me through.
Person2: Oh, you mean Jessica? No, she's not going with you. She needs to go back now.
Person1: But why? I thought she was supposed to help me.
Person2: Look, I know this is a lot to take in, but trust me, it's for the best. You don't want to go that way.
Person1: Fine, but can you at least give me some directions?
Person2: Directions? Ha! You need more than directions. You need a miracle.

Person1: I've an idea that will get us out of this mess. We haven't twopence between us, but we've got these connections.
Person2: Question withdrawn, you may explain. What do you propose we do with these connections?
Person1: Well, something important may come of it. We can use them to our advantage.
Person2: Is that a fact? Or are you just trying to amuse yourself?
Person1: I'm serious. We can make this work. No further questions, let's just focus on the plan.

Person1: What's going on with you? You're being really distant lately.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: Don't play dumb. I can tell when something's bothering you. You're a lovely person, and I hate seeing you like this.
Person2: Oh, how I loathe my life. I loathe it. Please just leave me alone.
Person1: You want me to leave? Fine, but I'm coming back tomorrow. Promise.
Person2: Wait, I want to give you something. For your trouble. You'll let me, please...
Person1: What's gotten into you? You're not acting like yourself at all.
Person2: What do you mean? I'm fine.
Person1: No, you're not. You're being really evasive and secretive. That's not like you.

Person1: Wait, I want to say good-bye.
Person2: For evil to bend its knee, admit its guilt, implore His forgiveness, is the hardest thing on earth --
Person1: I don't know what to say to Allah.
Person2: Have you ever bent your knees, Malcolm? Get in... now!
Person1: I want to, but I can't.
Person2: -- the hardest and the greatest.

Person1: I'm telling you, what you really need is someone to share your passion for photography.
Person2: You think so?
Person1: Trust me. I've been thinking about moving away, but what's the point? I'd just be taking my problems with me.
Person2: Did you invite them to the exhibition?
Person1: The Smiths? And of course they said yes.
Person2: That was the plan. And you're thrilled to have them.
Person1: Whatever you say. By the way, I figured out a new way to develop film. Want to take a look?
Person2: Before I forget, put it on the coffee table.

Person1: You look like the kind of person who has a lot of friends. Don't you?
Person2: You know better than that.
Person1: What do you mean? You seem so outgoing.
Person2: Then why do you ask so many questions?
Person1: I'm just trying to get to know you better. I'm not angry with you or anything.
Person2: Oh no, I didn't think that.

Person1: Whatever you wish... This has all been a terrible mistake, Alex.
Person2: I understand. Sometimes you can't know what I'm doing. It's better that way.
Person1: I wanted to play straight with you, but the board insisted we try and acquire your company.
Person2: The same thing was said about you before the meeting.
Person1: I'm shocked, shocked to think that you'd believe them.
Person2: Enough! This is the contract. This is our future.

Person1: Dude, I don't remember saying anything like that -- exactly...I don't know why I just did.
Person2: Shhh! Let's see -- wait a minute, well, I can think of two reasons.
Person1: What?
Person2: You're trying to make it all about something else, and you're not ready to own up to it.
Person1: That's not it.

Person1: Hey, I've been thinking, and I really need your help with something.
Person2: What is it?
Person1: There's this charity event at school, and I really want to go, but I don't know if I can make it. My parents are being super strict lately.
Person2: I feel like they do that sometimes.
Person1: Yeah, exactly! So, would you be willing to cover for me if I sneak out? I promise I'll owe you one.
Person2: I don't know... it doesn't seem right.

Person1: I have the evidence right here. Why don't you come and take a look?
Person2: You don't understand, I can't get involved in this.

Person1: We're on the brink of a major breakthrough. I'll need you to handle the final step.
Person2: What's that?
Person1: I'll tell you when it's time. But first, let's prepare for the unveiling.
Person2: Unveiling? You mean like a party? Should I bring something?

Person1: You know, if we don't take a stand, tomorrow it'll be like it never happened. The system will just swallow it whole.
Person2: No way. You really want that on your head? The guilt of staying silent?
Person1: Maybe it's time for a change. Maybe it's time for us to be the ones in control.
Person2: Fine. But are you prepared for the consequences? Are you prepared to face the backlash?

Person1: You've been in there for hours. I think you've had enough.
Person2: He can do anything, just like Inspector Gadget on TV. But I have to keep things ready for him, that's what I think.
Person1: Well, you've been wet to the skin. You must've fallen in.
Person2: I've got his picture and I'm going to sit in his chair.

Person1: I'm not feeling so well. Can we take a break?
Person2: "... It's all there in the three notebooks. Read them in order. If you don't want to, I suppose that's okay too."
Person1: What does that have to do with anything? Can you please just leave me alone?
Person2: I never stopped loving your father. He was a very good man.
Person1: That's not what I want to talk about. Can you just go?
Person2: Fine, but know that I'm trying to help you understand.

Person1: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to pry, it's just that I really loved your art collection.
Person2: Yes, I'm quite proud of it. But there's something you should know... The history of this house is not a pleasant one. My family has lived here for generations, but it's been plagued by tragedy.
Person1: What do you mean?
Person2: Well, I've always felt that the house has a dark energy to it. It's as if it's watching us, waiting for something to happen. I've tried to restore it, to bring some life back into it, but it's a struggle.
Person1: That's fascinating. I've always been drawn to places with a rich history. Do you take sugar?
Person2: Yes, two please. But be careful, the house has a way of getting under your skin.

Person1: I didn't ask what the others think, Mother. What do you think about the new school policy?
Person2: On the night of the twenty-third of January, I realized that our priorities were misplaced. We should focus on the well-being of our students, not just their academic performance.
Person1: You're saying that the administration is cowardly, just like my colleagues who opposed the new policy?
Person2: No, child. I'm saying that sometimes we need to take a step back and re-evaluate our decisions. We must consider the impact on our students, not just our own interests.

Person1: I'm trying to better myself, but I feel like I'm stuck.
Person2: I'm just looking at you. Does that make you uncomfortable?
Person1: Depends on what you're seeing. I'm trying to move forward, but it's hard when I feel like I'm being held back.
Person2: And that's a bad thing?
Person1: I'm sorry, but I need some space to figure things out. I can't have you watching over me all the time.
Person2: Well, try this one on for size. I think I can help you if you let me.
Person1: You don't even know me. How can you be so sure?
Person2: I've seen the way you carry yourself. You're strong, but you're struggling. Let me help you find your way.
Person1: I appreciate the offer, but I need to do this on my own.
Person2: Alright, but if you change your mind, I'll be here.

Person1: Hoity-toity! What's the matter here?
Person2: Good morning. Did you see what the First Bank stock opened at? Very impressive.
Person1: Actually, it's down .2 from the last quarter's highest, but I think it will pick up. I've had enough of your market talk, sir.
Person2: I am equally impressed with your knowledge of the market. How long have you been with the company now?
Person1: Four years, and I came over from the Capitol merger in Chicago six months ago. I'll thank you to pay me the respect I deserve, and I resign all claims to this conversation.
Person2: Pooh! Pooh! You're joking, right?

Person1: We've got work to do, and I think we should take a long view.
Person2: What's the long view? Is it just about making him comfortable?
Person1: Yes, that's true. But we need to consider the bigger picture. It's only a matter of time before...
Person2: How can I say anything to that? I don't know what to say to that.
Person1: The job here is to make the best decision possible, right now. Our job is to try and make it as painless as possible.

Person1: You're really crazy to think you can handle this job.
Person2: I had my suspicions about the company, but the salary is quite good - two hundred dollars a month.
Person1: That is good, but I'd like to know more about the project.
Person2: I'm afraid I'm not able to tell you much. Only that it's a high-stakes venture with a lot of pressure.
Person1: That will mean a lot of overtime, won't it?
Person2: No, the schedule is quite flexible. You'll have plenty of time to relax.
Person1: But it's such a big responsibility...
Person2: That's rather exciting, isn't it?

Person1: I've always wanted to try this. It's quite an adventure.
