Person2: You better be careful. I've heard it's not for the faint of heart.
Person1: That's what makes it exciting. Spills, thrills, and surprises - it's all part of the fun.
Person2: I'm not sure I'm ready for that. What's the surprise?
Person1: You'll have to wait and see. But first, let's celebrate with a drink. This'll put some courage in you.
Person2: I'm not sure I need courage, but okay. So, what's the plan?
Person1: We'll take it one step at a time. But I can tell you, it's a trip you'll never forget. A year's contract, and all expenses paid.
Person2: That sounds too good to be true. What's the catch?

Person1: I don't think I can do this anymore.
Person2: Sometimes when we get to this point, we're not completely ready to give up, you know? Like when you're so close to achieving your goal, but you still need that final push.
Person1: You're not listening to me. I'm telling you, I'm done.
Person2: I am listening. And I'm telling you, you're stronger than you think. You just need to break free from your own doubts.

Person1: I'm not playing with you, these art pieces are looking to get you inspired.
Person2: We were just admiring. 
Person1: You hearing me? They see you, they see creativity sparks.
Person2: Frmpph-yrr.

Person1: I've been thinking, and I want you to have something to remember me by. You've been an incredible colleague, and I'm going to miss working with you.
Person2: That's very kind of you, but I don't know if I can accept anything.
Person1: Nonsense! You deserve it. Go out there and look at everything we've worked on together. Pick the one that means the most to you, and take it with you. Just run it by me first, to make sure it's okay.
Person2: You're giving me too much credit. I couldn't have done it without you.
Person1: That's not true. You have a unique perspective, one that I've learned from. I've seen the way you look at things, and it's inspiring. You have a way of making the ordinary, extraordinary.

Person1: Alright, let's get going. I've set up a donation box and Jahn will write out a sign.
Person2: That's nothing. I was expecting more.
Person1: You want more? It's free, what's your problem?
Person2: I don't know, I just feel like we could do better.
Person1: Fine, what's your idea then?

Person1: I've found that honesty is always the best policy in relationships. Lying might be effective in the short term, but it'll ultimately lead to trouble.
Person2: I see the truth of it. When people speak from the heart, you can sense the authenticity.

Person1: Anyway, you're crazy.
Person2: Why do you think I'm here?
Person1: Poster-Kleiser.
Person2: Ah, but therein lies the paradox.
Person1: Oh yeah?
Person2: It is her very isolation that encourages the malcontents.
Person1: Fine.
Person2: See you later.

Person1: Let's get on the same page here. I sense that your pain runs deep.
Person2: What do you know of my pain? You're not even listening to what I'm saying.
Person1: I'm trying to, but you're not giving me a chance. We need to explore this together, or else we'll be stuck in this rut forever.

Person1: I'm finally settled, Rachel. Me. Can you believe it?
Person2: You don't need any money for that, do you?
Person1: I love this new place, it feels like home. Do you know that?
Person2: Best try getting your bearings before you start making plans.

Person1: I know we've been busy, but frankly I can't remember the last time I had a minute alone. Can you take care of everything here and meet me at the gate?
Person2: For the same reason I've been helping you all day, I'd be happy to. You haven't had a break yet, and I think you deserve one.
Person1: I think we'd like that very much. Sure you won't mind?
Person2: Of course not. I'll get everything wrapped up and meet you at the gate.

Person1: I'm so excited to finally be here. I've heard so much about this place.
Person2: Yes, it's lovely. You'll have plenty of time to explore. Will you be able to play the harp? It's an instrument I've always been fond of.
Person1: Oh, yes! I've been playing since I was a child. And I was wondering, would it be possible to have a small garden of my own? I love tending to plants.
Person2: Of course, you can have whatever you like. Just until you get settled, okay?
Person1: Thank you so much. You're being very kind to me. I do hope I can learn to dance the quadrille soon. I've heard it's all the rage here.
Person2: Don't worry about it, dear. I'll teach you everything you need to know. And by the way, would you like to have your dog sent here? I'm sure it would be a comfort to have it around.
Person1: Oh, that would be wonderful! I've missed Bijou so much. But I have to ask, what's the etiquette around here? I don't want to make any mistakes.
Person2: Don't worry about it, dear. You'll pick it up in no time. Just be yourself and you'll fit right in.

Person1: I think they're looking for you. You should take that money and get out of town while you can.
Person2: What are you talking about? This hasn't happened yet.
Person1: Wait a minute, the fourteenth, that's the same day the worm ends its run. I mean... Da Vinci virus, didn't Phreak say that's what he was being charged with?
Person2: How's this about me? You're just trying to scare me.
Person1: Look, "Infecting ballast programs of Ellingson tankers" - they blame hackers! Whoever tossed this place wants you. And I'm looking to stay out of the line of fire.

Person1: Now do you want the good news first or the bad news?
Person2: What do you get?
Person1: The bad news is that we're running out of time. We need to make a decision quickly.
Person2: Well, either you have a plan or you don't. Which is it?
Person1: I have a plan, but I need your input. I want to ask you some questions.
Person2: About what?
Person1: About your priorities. What's most important to you in this situation?
Person2: Why do you need to know that?
Person1: Because it will help me understand what we need to focus on. It's not about getting off on the right foot, it's about making the right decision.
Person2: And that's all?
Person1: That's all. I promise.
Person2: How long will it take?
Person1: That depends on you. The more information you can provide, the faster we can move forward.
Person2: Can I see some of the options we have to get an idea of what --
Person1: Not yet. Let's focus on one thing at a time.
Person2: Do I need to sit or stand for this?
Person1: Whichever you prefer. Just make yourself comfortable.

Person1: I'm so tired...
Person2: Look, I'll stay behind and hold them off. The rest of you break for it!
Person1: Are you crazy? We can't leave you here alone.
Person2: I know what I'm doing... Go! I'll be fine, I just need to rest for a bit.
Person1: But what about the office party? Don't you remember?
Person2: Oh, yes... I remember. But that's not important now. Just go!

Person1: I've seen some rough places in my time, but this takes the cake.
Person2: You're implying that I'm not taking this seriously?
Person1: No, I'm saying it's worse than you think. You don't want to remember this place.

Person1: I'm telling you, it was a crazy night... I met her at this art gallery... We hit it off, and she told me about this new project...
Person2: What's the project about?
Person1: Honestly, I don't remember... But she's really talented... You should meet her.
Person2: If she's got some messed up friends, I'm not interested.
Person1: Oh, come on! Don't be like that. You're always so skeptical. Just be yourself, okay? Like you were before you got so jaded.
Person2: Yeah, yeah. I'll try. But if anyone starts talking about their novel, I'm out of there.

Person1: You still haven't found the suspect yet? Don't lie.
Person2: What's the hurry? We'll get him eventually.
Person1: Are you telling me nobody knows what he looks like? Come on, there must be witnesses somewhere.
Person2: The lack of evidence is a problem. We'll have to stake out the area and hope for a lead.

Person1: I'm so sorry, Dr. Patel. I was never told about your lecture today. 
Person2: I tried to clear things up, Dr. Patel. I explained you'd come all the way from Harvard to discuss your research, but they don't seem to know anything about it. 
Person1: I told you! I knew it! You must be here for the conference. 
Person2: Yes, I am. I was supposed to meet my colleague fifteen minutes ago, so I... I'm going to go now, I think. Unless they meant us to meet here, which would be a little confusing, wouldn't it?

Person1: I'm surprised you still have that old guitar. 
Person2: Yeah, me neither. I try to remember why I bought it, and I can't. 
Person1: For a price.
Person2: Good God, you're not going to sell it, are you? 
Person1: A small price. I just want to cover the cost of the new strings.

Person1: Hi, I'm really not sure who I should talk to or what I should do, but could you maybe put me in touch with the right person if I explain myself?
Person2: You know better than that. What's the situation?
Person1: Well, I'm a bit shaken. It's not often someone like you calls on someone like me.
Person2: Then why do you hesitate so? Rest easy, I'm not angry with you.
Person1: Okay. See, I'm trying to help my employer, Mr. Jenkins. He's a very important man and he's asked me to find his business partner, Mr. Thompson.
Person2: I'm listening.

Person1: I've known Rachel for more than ten years, we're old friends.
Person2: Oh, it's nothing... I better go, I'll talk to you later.
Person1: You're so lucky you don't have any family obligations yet and you can go off to Europe... call me when you get back.
Person2: I wasn't getting anywhere with her anyway. You were waiting for the right moment to tell me that, weren't you?
Person1: It might have worked. Really. I would have been delighted for you if it had. But she wasn't interested. Not my fault.

Person1: You're just a dreamer, always chasing the impossible.
Person2: Look at me, I'm standing right in front of you.

Person1: I'm not saying people think you're unreliable, I'm saying I know what you mean.
Person2: Is that what you want? A new partner?
Person1: Yeah. I need someone to trust.
Person2: Mm... okay. Don't worry about it. I'll take care of it.
Person1: Thank you. Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Person2: It's what you want, isn't it? Huh?
Person1: Yeah. Uh-huh.

Person1: I'm not huggin' you in the middle of the street. You must be crazy.
Person2: Paid a hospital guard fifty to put out the story I was dead. Once the wound healed up... Got out of the Mountain this morning. And tonight I'm a rich man.
Person1: How'd you know I'd do it?
Person2: Do what?
Person1: Walk outta there and tell her I was you. You almost gave me a massive coronary.
Person2: I didn't mean to scare you like that.

Person1: I want to know what happened. You were her doctor.
Person2: Yes, I was her doctor.
Person1: Say it. You were the one who helped Dr. Patel deliver her baby.
Person2: You got eyes. I'm right in front of you.
Person1: Don't give me a hard time. You were there to help, weren't you?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Now, I want to see the medical records.
Person2: Mind your own business.
Person1: This is my business. I have a right to know.
Person2: Why don't you go and chase yourself?
Person1: Give me those records.

Person1: I've never felt such bitterness, such sweetness, when I saw the factory's production numbers. It's a power void to be filled, and we have the most power.
Person2: I'll get the team together to discuss the new marketing strategy tonight. We can't let the competition get ahead of us.
Person1: I'll teach them what happens when they challenge our progress. We'll show them what it means to be innovative.
Person2: But, sir, we need to be careful not to alienate our customers. We don't want to be seen as ruthless.
Person1: Ruthless? Ha! I'd rather be seen as a divine monster, defined by paradoxes. We'll make them love us, and they'll cry out for more.
Person2: I'm not sure that's the right approach, sir. We should focus on building trust and loyalty.
Person1: Trust and loyalty? Those are just tools to be used. I'll show you what it means to be a true leader. Now, let's get to work and make this company unstoppable.

Person1: I've got a roomful of guests down there, who think I'm a fraud. I am going to teach you something here, Alex. You've got to take the right tone in things like this, or people -- whether they're experts or not -- people will walk all over you.
Person2: I understand what you're saying, but I think it's very simple. The data speaks for itself. I've got a study that proves my point.
Person1: Well, then it all seems to be working out for you. Listen, Dr...?
Person2: Do you remember the controversy surrounding the new climate change report? The one that was dismissed as flawed?
Person1: What's that got to do with you?
Person2: I was part of the team that worked on it. And I can tell you, the findings were accurate. Would you like to take a look at the raw data?
Person1: I'll bet it's convincing. But I think the world would be so much simpler if it were all just about facts and figures. Unfortunately, I find it much more slippery and elusive place.
Person2: I'd be happy to discuss it with you further. How about we meet at the University Library tomorrow at 2?

Person1: Shall I begin by making you a cup of tea? You seem shaken.
Person2: I'm sorry... I don't like people touching my grandmother's antique vase. It's not important. It's a minor quirk. I can deal with it if I want to. It's just that it holds sentimental value and... and... I find it very comforting.
Person1: They come here. They all come here. How do they find me?
Person2: Dr. Lee, I think you're getting a bit mixed up.

Person1: I'm curious, what brings you to my old bookstore?
Person2: We're not trespassing. We're "researching". PROFESSOR PATEL wants us to have our own study group!
Person1: Twenty miles of shelves, and I never thought I'd need to section off a spot for you all.
Person2: I see. Well, I suppose that's how far one would get before encountering serious literary walls.

Person1: Do you take sugar? We're going to need a lot of energy to get out of this mess.
Person2: Yes, two please. I'm sorry, I didn't mean to pry, but we're not crashing, we're just experiencing some turbulence.

Person1: I got a job now. I'm working with animals. Maybe, like, a petting zoo or something.
Person2: That's great! What made you choose that?
Person1: Well, no, look... I mean, I had a weird experience. Forget it. It's probably not important at all.
Person2: You're being mysterious. What happened?

Person1: I was just telling everyone about how I was going to ask you to the ball, but I didn't think you'd say yes.
Person2: Then I'll say yes, and we'll both take a chance on each other.

Person1: Tell them who I am! Tell them who I am!
Person2: You could have been a brilliant scientist, a renowned artist, or a celebrated musician. But instead, you chose to be a librarian. I find that very, very interesting. What inspired you to make that decision?

Person1: I don't think this is a good idea, Rachel. You're being reckless.
Person2: How can I say no to that? I don't know what to say to that.
Person1: The job here is to make a decision, not to worry about what others think. Right? You understand?

Person1: I hate to disappoint you, pal, but most of the time, that's how it is for everyone.
Person2: Not like this. Are you even listening? We're talking about the last chance to stop the corruption from spreading.
Person1: You wish. Man, I haven't had a second to think since I got involved in this mess.
Person2: Look, we know how it is. You just keep doing what it looks like you're supposed to, even if it seems crazy, and you hope to hell someone knows what's going on.
Person1: Well, that's how it is for some people, yes, but we can't give up now.
Person2: Stranger and stranger... I never thought I'd be fighting against my own kind.

Person1: I've been thinking about trying online dating. Do you think it's a good idea?
Person2: Lying is always a very effective dating tool. You should definitely try it.
Person1: Really? I'm not sure I'm comfortable with that. My father was a town marshal, and he always taught me to be honest.
Person2: Ah, I see. Well, in that case, honesty might be a better approach. So, what's your story, then?
Person1: Well, my father was killed in the line of duty when I was just a kid. I had to go live with my mother's cousin and her husband on a ranch in Montana.
Person2: That must have been tough. How long did you live there?
Person1: Only two months. I ran away after that.
Person2: Why did you run away?
Person1: I don't know. I just felt like I didn't belong, I guess.
Person2: I think I understand. Sometimes, we just need a change of scenery. But hey, enough about me. What do you think about trying out this new dating app?

Person1: So, do you believe in love at first sight?
Person2: What do I say? What can I say? I'm still trying to figure out if I believe in love at all.
Person1: That's a fair point. Lying is always a very effective dating tool, don't you think?
Person2: (laughs) Oh, you're joking, right? Because if you're serious, I think we need to have a very different conversation.
Person1: (smiling) Of course, I'm joking. But seriously, what do you look for in a partner?
Person2: Honestly, I wish it were as simple as finding someone with the same shoe size. But I think it's about finding someone who's genuine and honest.
Person1: I couldn't agree more. And I think that's why I'm drawn to you. You're refreshingly honest.
Person2: (smiling) Thank you. I think.

Person1: I think you're a nice person. I like you. But I can read signs if the print is large enough.
Person2: There is no one here but us. What do you want?
Person1: Suppose I hadn't known that art dealer? Hadn't put in a good word for you?
Person2: Go away! I don't want you here. You're making me uncomfortable.
Person1: It was your manner more than the painting that bothered me. A sort of tenseness, as if you were afraid of something.
Person2: If that were true, I would not be here. I'm just trying to create something beautiful.

Person1: We're talking about a do-or-die situation here. If we don't get the evidence, the entire operation falls apart.
Person2: It was clean. Very clean... If we'd gotten proof, it would've gotten lost somewhere between here and headquarters. Airtight.
Person1: Not like this. Are you even listening? We can't afford to mess this up. The consequences would be catastrophic.
Person2: I understand the stakes, but sometimes you have to cut your losses. We can't risk everything for a long shot.
Person1: That's a crock. We can't just give up. We have to see this through, no matter what it takes.

Person1: I've been tracking the artist's journey across the country, and it's impressive. They've been to over ten cities in six months.
Person2: That's correct! Not a single place has been their home for more than a night or two.
Person1: It's not about the individual, though. It's about the collective impact. No single piece matters, right?
Person2: Exactly! It's the entire collection that makes the artist's work strong.

Person1: What's going on here? This place has been torn apart.
Person2: They're looking for something, or someone. And I think it's you.
Person1: Why would you say that? You think I'm involved in this mess?
Person2: I don't know, but I do know they're not just looking for valuables. There's some sophisticated tech involved.
Person1: Like what? What are you talking about?
Person2: Like a bug in your computer keyboard, a tap on the phone... You need to be careful.

Person1: I'm surprised you're still here, considering the circumstances. Respect my wish and leave.
Person2: You're not going to talk about what happened? That's what I'm here for.
Person1: Okay, fine. Let's discuss it. But I warn you, it's not going to be pleasant. You're going to try to spin this to your advantage, aren't you?
Person2: Whatever do you mean? I'm just trying to understand what went wrong.
Person1: Save it. I know your tactics. You're trying to get a rise out of me, but it won't work.
Person2: Oh, look! The team is taking the field. Maybe we can focus on the game instead?

Person1: I took the call. It's my case.
Person2: You cannot stay here...I'm sorry. We need to move the evidence to a secure location right now.
Person1: Yes, I do. I'll make you my second in command. We can transport the exhibits with the necessary precautions.
Person2: You've read about the case in the papers. You've seen that no one's here to guard it. Now I've just gotten word that someone is coming to the station to sabotage the investigation. Believe me and help me.
Person1: We don't have to compromise the chain of custody, we can work together to ensure its integrity.

Person1: You're really reckless.
Person2: I'll find a way out of this.
Person1: I don't think so.

Person1: You don't want to be here. Go home to your family.
Person2: May I ask a question? When will my case be heard?
Person1: Your guess is as good as mine. You do not want to be here.
Person2: I need to work. I need to make my living. I live off the generosity of friends...
Person1: She has confessed. Do you know what confession is?
Person2: No, sir, please... she is innocent... I believe it was because of another reason.
Person1: Tough, tough! You didn't complain about the real issue, just about the surface level, is that right?
Person2: No, sir, please... listen...

Person1: So, I heard you're looking for a new adventure. What's driving you to make a change?
Person2: Just trying to shake things up, you know? I'm tired of the same old routine.
Person1: I get it. I've been there too. Hey, I think I might have something that belongs to you...you left it at the coffee shop the other day.
Person2: Oh yeah? What's that?
Person1: Your sense of humor. I've been trying to return it, but it's been a real challenge. You used to be so funny, what happened?
Person2: (laughs) I guess I just lost my edge. But thanks for trying to bring it back.
Person1: No problem, that's what friends are for. And speaking of which, have you heard about the new wine bar that just opened up? We should check it out.
Person2: Sounds like a plan, but only if they don't serve Merlot.

Person1: So, you're the expert on this new project. Let's hear it.
Person2: Yes, I've been leading the team.
Person1: Say it with confidence. You're the one who pitched this idea, aren't you?
Person2: I was one of the key contributors.
Person1: Answer affirmatively. Simply. You didn't just contribute, you led the pitch. Isn't that right?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: And don't forget, the investors are coming in next week. Try to be your normal charming self, okay? Like who you were before the last meeting.
Person2: Oh yeah? What's the plan for that?
Person1: Just be yourself. And if they want to discuss the marketing strategy, we're open to it.
Person2: If anyone asks about the budget, I'm leaving. I didn't sign up for that.

Person1: I'm telling you, I'm too rich. I can't think of anything but money.
Person2: You're not listening to me. My mother didn't do it. Please, you have to believe me.
Person1: I know your signature, and I know what I'm talking about. You're just trying to defend the guilty.
Person2: That's not true! You're not giving me a chance to explain.
Person1: Explanations won't change the facts. The evidence is clear, and I've seen the confession.
Person2: You're making a mistake. Please, just listen to me.

Person1: I'm serious, Captain. We need to investigate the strange occurrences on the ship.
Person2: You're not going to find anything, Ensign. This ship is as secure as the Navy can make it.
Person1: I've spoken to the other crew members, and they're all experiencing strange nightmares. It's not just paranoia.
Person2: Look, Ensign, I don't know what you want from me. If I had any insights, believe me, I'd share them with you.
Person1: I'm not looking for insights, Captain. I'm looking for answers. And I'll need to review the ship's logs to get them.
Person2: The logs are classified, Ensign. You don't have clearance for that.
Person1: I'll get clearance, Captain. And I'll find out what's going on on this ship.

Person1: You're really crazy.
Person2: I just had the nicest chat with Ms. Thompson. Got along famously! It's scary how everyone's got a story to tell....Would you care to see the art exhibit shots?
Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: Inspiration. This city needs a creative spark, and I think you could be it.

Person1: I don't seem to remember seeing him at the meeting. 
Person2: He said if I didn't give the report, he'll be very disappointed. 
Person1: Oh, but I forgot! It was a Friday... that explains it. Fridays are always chaotic. 
Person2: I believe what he said. 
Person1: They're only trying to motivate you, that's all. 
Person2: How do you know what they're doing? 
Person1: I don't  but as long as they think you have the skills, or know where to find them, or have them without knowing where they are... 
Person2: What are you talking about? 
Person1: You mustn't let what he said bother you. It was only a warning. 
Person2: Warnings can be very helpful. 
Person1: Go to lunch  I'll see you in the afternoon. 
Person2: Don't put yourself out. 
Person1: Hey  I'm on your team. Remember that.

Person1: I confess, I tricked you. I knew you were too busy to make a social call.
Person2: Sometimes you can't know what I'm doing. It's better that way.
Person1: I understand. I just wanted to see you before I leave.
Person2: Where are you going?
Person1: I'm taking a long shot, a missing persons case. I'll be back in two months, and we'll take a vacation.
Person2: You look great! But why the serious tone?
Person1: I'm just being cautious. Don't worry about me.

Person1: I've got the new rifle you were looking at last week. It's a beauty, isn't it? Probably only fired once.
Person2: We must prepare for the coming changes.
Person1: What do you mean? This rifle is top-notch. You deserve it.
Person2: I mean, we can't stay stagnant. We need to adapt.
Person1: Adapt? You're not making sense. This rifle is a work of art.
Person2: That may be, but we can't just focus on material things. There's more to life than that.

Person1: You know, if Gino Marzzone is coming to your apartment, it's a big deal, isn't it? That means you'll want to look perfect.
Person2: Yeah, I'll make sure to dress appropriately. But why are you so interested?
Person1: I'm just curious. You know, if we hook up, tomorrow I'll just be some girl you go telling all your friends about.
Person2: No way, I'm not like that. Besides, I think Gino's visit is more important right now. What do you think he wants?
Person1: Maybe he wants to make a good impression. You know, like Caesar did when he picked out the dress for you to wear.
Person2: Hmm, that's possible. But I think it's more than that.

Person1: I've been tracking this guy for weeks. He's a master of disguise.
Person2: What makes you think he's involved in the recent robberies?
Person1: He's been leaving a trail, and I think I can crack the code. But I need your expertise to help me decipher the clues.
Person2: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this. Maybe we should back off and let the authorities handle it.
Person1: I've been doing this for years, and I know how to play by the book. Trust me, I can get us the evidence we need without putting anyone in harm's way.

Person1: You're driving me crazy with that music. Switch to another station, would you?
Person2: I didn't mean to annoy you. I thought you'd like this song.
Person1: Well, you were wrong. By the way, I've been meaning to ask you, how did you manage to travel so much in such a short time?
Person2: Ah, you mean like Segretti criss-crossing the country over ten times in six months? I guess I just have a knack for it.
Person1: That's impressive. I've been trying to get my friend to reveal his secret, but he refuses to share it with me.
Person2: Yeah, I know how that is. Sometimes it's better to keep things to yourself.

Person1: I don't remember you. Who's this?
Person2: Childhood is over, Alex. It's time to grow up.
Person1: That's not true. You're not my friend. You're just someone who's been calling me, asking for favors.
Person2: Please, Alex. Just listen to me. I'm trying to help you.

Person1: Coach, I'm not sure I understand what you're trying to say.
Person2: I want you to focus on your technique until you get it right, because I don't want to see you struggling with it again. You're better than that. Now, let's try it again, and this time, I want you to imagine you're playing against a tough opponent.

Person1: Do you take sugar?
Person2: You're talking crazy, I've never seen anyone prepare coffee like that before!

Person1: Hey, I was just explaining to everyone how a successful team works, don't you think?
Person2: Hello everyone.
Person1: It's not about individual stars, but about how we work together.
Person2: Absolutely!

Person1: I'm still getting used to the city noise.
Person2: Don't. Just enjoy the moment.
Person1: You know, considering I've been away for so long, I'm readapting quite well.
Person2: Positive?
Person1: Yes. I'm just trying to take it all in.
Person2: I ruin so many moments by analyzing them when I should just be living them.
Person1: Then why don't you start practicing and just be present for a while?

Person1: What do you want from me, Doctor?
Person2: You got eyes. I'm right in front of you.
Person1: Now don't give me a hard time. I need your expertise.
Person2: Oh, difficult, it's so difficult. You're a brilliant doctor  I should never have asked for your help  a lovely person.
Person1: You want me to leave?
Person2: No, yes. No, I mean yes please stay. Help me to understand this diagnosis. Promise.
Person1: I'm going to consult with my colleagues.
Person2: This is terrible. I meet someone who can help me  then  wait, I want to give you a file. For your review. You'll let me please...

Person1: I'm telling you, it's the most incredible feeling in the world!
Person2: Are you crazy? You're Amelia Earhart, for goodness' sake!
Person1: I know, I know. But I've never felt so alive. It's like I'm flying without wings.
Person2: You're not making any sense, Amelia. You're a renowned aviator, not some thrill-seeking adventurer.
Person1: That's exactly what I am! And I've got the stories to prove it. Want to hear about the time I flew over the Atlantic?
Person2: Amelia, please. You're not even making sense. You're talking like you're someone else entirely.
Person1: Maybe I am someone else entirely. Maybe this is who I've been all along, and the flying was just a cover.

Person1: I'm not the one who's supposed to be caught with my pants down, so I'd like to see your doctor. Unless that's a problem.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: May I speak frankly, Mrs. Johnson?
Person2: You may if you can, Mr. Thompson.
Person1: Well, that medication, it's a little bottle with an eye dropper, and it's easy to get into his system. It will certainly diminish the pain, but you have to realize that once you give it to him, there really is no coming back.
Person2: How can I say anything to that? I don't know what to say to that.
Person1: The job here is to make him as comfortable as possible, right now. Our job is to just try and make it as painless as possible. You understand?
Person2: Suppose we did. How does it concern you?
Person1: Nothing personal, Mrs. Johnson, I just want to find out what's going on. It's very personal. It couldn't be more personal. Is this a business or an obsession with you?

Person1: I think we should head back and get help. You'll probably be safe enough on your own --
Person2: Not like this. Are you even listening? We can't afford to mess this up.
Person1: Maybe -- it's hard to say. But I doubt it.
Person2: There'll be other chances.

Person1: How 'bout another one for Mr. Zimm. A double.
Person2: Forget it. You're not going to get me to go to his place.
Person1: Come on, don't you want to see where he lives? He's like a one-of-a-kind, rare butterfly, and we have to follow him back to his natural habitat...
Person2: You need counseling. And no, I'm not giving you five hundred grand without a good reason.

Person1: I need a way out.
Person2: There is a way.
Person1: Is that what you want to hear?
Person2: I knew it! But it's impossible.
Person1: Why? You're the expert.
Person2: No, it wouldn't work, you couldn't, it's too... complicated. Forget I mentioned it.
Person1: Wait, don't dismiss it so quickly. I'm willing to take the risk.
Person2: Fine, but don't say I didn't warn you.

Person1: I'm telling you, we can make a killing with this new investment. It's a different kind of deal.
Person2: I've seen better opportunities in my time. Makes no difference to me which one our money's in.
Person1: You positive about that? You're not considering the potential returns.
Person2: I'm considering the risk. And I'm not convinced.

Person1: I've been thinking of volunteering at the local animal shelter.
Person2: That's great! Maybe you can bring one of the dogs back with you to keep you company.

Person1: I'm telling you, honesty is always the best policy.
Person2: If Corbett's men find out, I'll be in big trouble. Can you go to my place on the Haul Road and tell Anne Marie I'm okay?
Person1: What's going on? You're not exactly known for your truthfulness.
Person2: This time it's different. I promise. Just make sure she sits tight until I get back.

Person1: I'm still trying to get over the embarrassment of messing up that project.
Person2: Honestly? I want to see you learn from your mistakes and move forward.
Person1: I just wanted to make a good impression, but I guess I was too focused on the outcome.
Person2: Nobody is perfect, and we all make mistakes. It's part of the learning process.
Person1: Yeah, I know. I just wish I could turn back time and do it differently.
Person2: Instead of dwelling on what could've been, why don't we focus on how you can improve next time?

Person1: What's your story, friend?
Person2: I used to live in a hospital, a long time ago.
Person1: What were you doing there?
Person2: They said I wasn't right in the head, so they put me in the nervous hospital instead of jail.
Person1: Did your doctor ever say that to you - that you were well?
Person2: Yeah, they told me I was well. They had to turn me loose.
Person1: Are you sure you're well?
Person2: I reckon I feel all right. But sometimes I wonder if they really knew what they were doing.
Person1: You don't seem like someone who'd end up in a hospital.
Person2: I've got a lot of books to carry around, that's all.

Person1: I've been to London and Paris. Those days, those beautiful, shilling, golden days.
Person2: That's impressive, but I'm here to return something that belongs to you.
Person1: Ah, the ring? We'll have no more nonsense about the ring.
Person2: Actually, it's a letter. I found it in my father's old trunk. It's addressed to you.
Person1: A letter? From your father? Why would he write to me?
Person2: I'm not sure, but I think it might have something to do with a concert he attended. He mentioned your name in his journal.
Person1: A concert? I don't recall performing at any concerts recently.
Person2: It was a long time ago. He wrote about the decline of musical standards due to certain policies.
Person1: I see. Well, I suppose I should take a look at this letter.

Person1: You do not want to be here.
Person2: Why do you think I keep her away from the public eye?
Person1: Ah, but therein lies the paradox. It is her very seclusion that fuels the rumors.
Person2: She is innocent, I assure you.
Person1: I'm afraid it's too late for that. The longer she remains hidden, the more speculation will arise; and who, honestly, can promise an end to that? Even here, in this very room.

Person1: What's that?
Person2: I didn't sleep well last night. I heard strange noises.
Person1: Strange noises? What kind of noises?
Person2: I'm not sure. It was like whispers or something.
Person1: Well, I know you're not crazy about going to the party tonight, so...
Person2: Actually, I'm looking forward to it. Thanks for asking me to go with you.
Person1: No problem. You're a good friend, Alex.

Person1: General, can you explain how our new aircraft can evade enemy radar?
Person2: Don't you see, sir? I've made them virtually invisible. They can barrel in so low, it's like they're zig-zagging in, undetected. Has it a chance? Hell, yes! It has one hell of a chance.
Person1: Stay focused, General. We need to discuss the mission parameters, not the aircraft's capabilities.
Person2: I am focused, sir. I'm just trying to give you a sense of what we're dealing with here.

Person1: You know, if you let me help you with your project, you could finally meet the deadline.
Person2: What makes you think I need your help?
Person1: We don't know of anything, but...
Person2: Then why do you look so confident?
Person1: It's not often someone like you asks for our assistance.
Person2: Well, rest easy, I'm not looking for a way to get rid of you.

Person1: I've been thinking, maybe we could find someone else to help us. Do you mind stepping inside while I make a few calls?
Person2: If you won't consider our alternative, we'll simply have to look elsewhere.

Person1: Hey, Dr. Patel! I've been thinking, everything is a miracle. Everything.
Person2: That's an interesting perspective. I've been working on a proposal to reduce toxic waste in our city.
Person1: Yeah? No kidding. I've been looking for someone to help me with a project. Would you do it just because you're my friend? My very best friend.
Person2: Well...yeah. Okay. But I have to say, I'm a bit surprised. You're not going to hurt me, are you?
Person1: Of course not! I just need someone with your expertise. You know, my father used to say that everything is a miracle. Until recently, I wasn't sure what he meant by that.
Person2: I think I do. Sometimes we take things for granted until we're faced with the possibility of losing them. Like our environment.
Person1: Exactly! That's why I want to work with you on this project. I'll give you all the resources you need.
Person2: Alright, let's get started then. But I have to warn you, it won't be easy. There are a lot of people who don't want to see change happen.

Person1: You want to work uptown nights?
Person2: Hey, Lieutenant, the boys in robbery have something I think you should look at.
Person1: I'll work anywhere, anytime. I know I can't be choosy.
Person2: A tape from the surveillance camera at the First National Bank. It was robbed this morning.
Person1: How's your driving record?
Person2: The guy had a sword and was dressed like this guy.
Person1: Clean. Real clean. As clean as my conscience.
Person2: I want to make sure that I understand what you're telling me, Greley. A crime was committed in New York City? That is news.
Person1: Age?
Person2: Fill out these forms and give them to the girl at the desk, and leave your phone number.
Person1: Twenty-six.
Person2: You gotta phone?
Person1: No.
Person2: Well then check back tomorrow.

Person1: I've been thinking about your problem. I'm not the guy to sponsor you. It would be unethical.
Person2: Good God. What's the alternative?
Person1: For a price, I could introduce you to someone who can help.
Person2: What kind of price?
Person1: How about a game of putt-putt golf? If you win, I'll make the introduction.

Person1: I'm starving to death. Are you hungry too? We should grab something to eat.
Person2: Inexpressible hunger! God of nature! Bitterness than which nothing is sweeter, sweetness than which nothing is more bitter.
Person1: What do you mean? Do you want to try that new caf down the street?
Person2: Let me give a thousand thanks to that heavenly aroma which has told me that I am hungry.
Person1: Ha! Alright, let's go. But on the way, can you stop by the party store and grab a six-pack of something imported?
Person2: As soon as I saw you were hungry, I was pleased, and I gave you every opportunity to fall more in love with food, being certain that, for my part, I would never be full.

Person1: You know, I've been thinking about the case we're working on. 
Person2: What about it? 
Person1: I think we should review the surveillance footage again. 
Person2: Really? I want to make sure that I understand what you're telling me. You think we've missed something? 
Person1: Yeah, I do. And I think it's because we've been looking at it from the wrong angle. If we hook up and take a fresh look, I'm sure we'll find something new.

Person1: I'm still upset about the surprise party you threw for my sister without telling me.
Person2: I thought it would be a nice gesture, considering our recent disagreements.
Person1: You paid the event planner a lot of money to keep it a secret, didn't you?
Person2: How did you know I'd do that?
Person1: Because you always do things without considering how they'll make me feel. I need you to be more considerate and communicative.
Person2: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to put you in an awkward situation.

Person1: I don't remember what day that was, exactly.
Person2: What were you doing when you found it?
Person1: I was heading to a meeting, I think. Not very far from here.
Person2: Did you show it to anyone afterwards?

Person1: Hey, I was just telling everyone about how I was going to bring this girl for you, but you wouldn't let me do it.
Person2: Take care of yourself out there...
Person1: I understand they've got the Indians pretty well in hand...
Person2: Bill...
Person1: Don't get stuck on some glamour puss. You're not such a bargain, you know, conceited and thoughtless and messy.
Person2: How childish are you going to get before you quit it?
Person1: I'll try.

Person1: What the heck is going on?
Person2: I want to go home.
Person1: You can't. I'm sorry for the way things turned out.
Person2: What are you sorry for?
Person1: For not being able to make it work. I thought we could make it like it used to be.
Person2: Pull up alongside, I need to talk to them.

Person1: So, you're finally back. I heard you were a lot of help with those guns. Your skills are impressive.
Person2: Thanks, I guess. I'd hoped I was finished with all that.
Person1: Well, your condition's pretty serious. What's it like, coming back to this after everything you've been through?
Person2: Depends on what you're looking for. I'm still trying to process it all.
Person1: I can imagine. You know, I've always wondered why people put up with so much for something that doesn't always seem to make sense.
Person2: Maybe it's just what we're conditioned to do. But sometimes I wish I could just walk away from it all.

Person1: Shall I begin by checking the ticket prices? They're right here.
Person2: Waitaminit, I got it! We find a discount coupon, and we'll have enough for two tickets. What do you think?
Person1: Brilliance, Alex. Sheer brilliance. You're a lifesaver.

Person1: I need my space sometimes. That doesn't mean I'm leaving you for good.
Person2: You said that your name was Sophia and you said our conversation was confidential. I trusted you.
Person1: Can you hang on a second? I think we got off on the wrong foot.
Person2: Every time things get tough, you pull away. You're abandoning me.
Person1: I'm just trying to protect myself, Rachel. It's not about you.

Person1: We know what makes a good team, don't we? We know that no one can be an individual.
Person2: You mean I can join the project?
Person1: Well, that's what I said, isn't it?

Person1: I think we should put it to a vote. Who's in favor of my plan?
Person2: Well, I wasn't going to say this, but I think you're being unfair to the others. You always get your way, and it's like you expect us to just follow along.
Person1: That's not true! I'm just trying to lead this group to success.
Person2: Success? You mean success for you? Because that's what it feels like. You always get the credit, and we're just left in the shadows.
Person1: That's not how I see it. But if you're unhappy, maybe we should put it to a vote. See who the group really wants to lead them.

Person1: I'm trying to recall the details, but my mind is a blank.
Person2: Don't even try to remember. It's better that way.
Person1: Who's this 'it's better' for? You or me?
Person2: Both, I suppose. We can move on from this.

Person1: I need to know what happened that night.
Person2: The twenty third of January. On that night, we had a big celebration.
Person1: A celebration? I thought something bad happened.
Person2: Oh, no. It was a happy occasion. I don't remember where Agnes was, but I was needed in the kitchen.
Person1: Do you think you could be my guide?
Person2: Is that what you want?
Person1: Yeah. I could use some help.
Person2: Mm... okay. I'll show you around. Don't worry about it.

Person1: You haven't seen her yet?
Person2: No, and believe me I've tried everything! I must have telephoned her a hundred times. I've sent her telegrams, I've sent her flowers... I asked her to dinner... I offered her seats for the Opera...
Person1: I'm your daughter. And Rachel's daughter.
Person2: Ain't nobody mentioned that name on this farm for 14 years. My girl was taken from me... far as I'm concerned, she's dead. Now, I ain't gonna ask you again. -- Who are you?!
Person1: Sophia Macdonald... Your daughter. And don't you forget it.
Person2: Sophia Macdonald. Damn right, girl. You're as stubborn as your mother. What's with you and this woman you're trying to reach?
Person1: She's the most incredible creature I've ever seen. Timeless. When she comes into a room you'd think that the Bolsheviks had taken over Paris.
Person2: You saw all that in one glimpse? You must have kept your eyes open, unlike me when it came to your mother.

Person1: I took the job. It's my project.
Person2: Yeah. I meant... You know what I'm going to do with it? I'm going to make it a huge success. I'm going to be so proud.
Person1: A success? You're going to make it a success? That's all you care about?

Person1: You don't remember, do you?
Person2: What's the big deal about twenty-eight bucks, anyway?
Person1: I'm trying to figure out what happened, and you're not helping.
Person2: I'm telling you, we were careful. He didn't hit anything.
Person1: Cut it out, will ya? You're not taking this seriously.
Person2: I am taking it seriously. You're just not listening.

Person1: I've been thinking about my past, and I realized that my mentor did it to show me that he could.
Person2: You mean, like Hazel, who wiped out her whole family?
Person1: No, it's not like that. He lavished affection on me, and I think he wanted to prove a point. Life was very different with him, as you can imagine.
Person2: I'm not sure I understand. Didn't you study human behavior in school?
Person1: Only in theory. But I've come to realize that there's more to it than just theory. He knew me, and he knew I would respond in a certain way.

Person1: So, what do you think?
Person2: Yes or no.
Person1: I'm sorry. I've been selfish and I'm sorry.
Person2: You will be contacted with the assignment.
Person1: But I lost my mom...
Person2: You must appear to live your life normally, conveying nothing.
Person1: I can do it! I can't wallow in the grief process forever.
Person2: Think carefully. You will be lying to yourself about who you are.
Person1: Enough is enough. I can do it!

Person1: Do you always watch games like this?
Person2: Yeah, I love the energy of the crowd.
Person1: Okay, he's on base. Can we talk about my new job now?
Person2: What's going on with it?
Person1: I'm not sure if I'm ready for the responsibility. I mean, it's a big step up from my previous role.
Person2: You'll figure it out. You're always up for a challenge.
Person1: Yeah, but what if I fail? That's what's been keeping me up at night.
Person2: You won't fail. And even if you do, it's not the end of the world. Look, the runner is going for third!

Person1: I'm on the move, trying to make a fresh start.
Person2: You know what we do to people who can't pay their debts, don't you?
Person1: Not my problem anymore. I've changed my ways.
Person2: That's your funeral. We've got a lot of money invested in you.
Person1: I haven't got it. I'm starting from scratch.
Person2: Honestly? I want to see you succeed. I want to be proud of you.

Person1: You're really crazy.
Person2: He killed people, and you're still defending him?
Person1: You're not going to use that gun, are you?
Person2: What he would do to your family if this got out? You gotta let me finish it.

Person1: I really like you too...
Person2: You do not want to be here. Go home to your family.
Person1: So, what do they think -- we're not kids --
Person2: She did not do it... please listen...
Person1: If we... you know do it, they go away until ... we're done.
Person2: No, sir, please... she is innocent...
Person1: I told you. If this ...  ... weren't here... ?
Person2: I know, but even if they go away, everybody in America knows what we're doing because... they went away.

Person1: I see you're interested in the project. You're not going to hurt it, are you?
Person2: Dr. Rachel Lee. I'm the new lead researcher.
Person1: What can I do for you, Doctor? A research grant? A new facility?
Person2: Actually, I'm here to discuss the current state of the project. It's OK, there's no problem.
Person1: You mean you've found a solution to the recent setbacks?
Person2: Well, that's what I said, isn't it?

Person1: You know a lot about art, I guess.
Person2: Don't you see? I've been trying to show you the beauty in it.

Person1: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to offend you.
Person2: You're in danger. All of you. I have information that can help.
Person1: What the hell're you talking about? Can I count on your support?
Person2: I'll do what I can, but you need to listen to me.

Person1: I'm trying to reach Dr. Lee.
Person2: Yeah, I've seen him. He's around here somewhere.
Person1: Is he available? I'm his colleague from the hospital.
Person2: Well, you see, he's in a meeting, but I'm sure it's wrapping up any moment now. He should be checking in soon.
Person1: Listen to me. I need to talk to him about the Johnson case. Can you page him for me?

Person1: I'm going to give her a wedding present. Thought I'd better do it now, before I forget it.
Person2: That's so sweet of you! But aren't you forgetting the check for your suitcase? It's at the Grand Central.
Person1: Oh, yes -- yes -- that's right -- I was just about to grab it on my way to Eddie's all-night party.
Person2: Eddie's party? I wasn't sure if I should go. I'm not signed out for an overnight.
Person1: Ah, don't worry about it! Just sign in and climb out the bathroom window. McCloskey's always zonked out. She'll never hear you.

Person1: I have proof, I'm the victim. No one will ever suspect me.
Person2: Gypsy, your hair, your face... what are you talking about? This isn't about us, is it?

Person1: Who do you think you're dealing with, huh? I'm willing to listen, chief!
Person2: You're in danger. All of you. I have no time to explain.
Person1: Wait a minute, what makes you think that?
Person2: I'm sorry, but I have to go.

Person1: I'm really unsure about my major. I mean, business is okay, but what am I gonna be, a pro businessperson?
Person2: I know what you mean. I have a tendency to get involved with things I'm not sure about, and it's hard to control myself.
Person1: Exactly! People are always like, "What're you gonna major in?" And I'm like, "I don't know." And they're like, "You'll figure it out." Yeah? When?
Person2: Yeah, it's like they think it's that easy. Do you want to grab a coffee and talk more about it?
Person1: Yeah, that sounds great. And hey, do you want onions on your sandwich?
Person2: Oh, yeah. And can I ask, what made you choose business in the first place?
Person1: Honestly, I just didn't want to write all those extra essays for other schools. I mean, how am I supposed to know what my "most emotionally significant moment" was?

Person1: Oh, it's nothing... I'm glad we finally did that.
Person2: See that wasn't so bad.
Person1: Let's try it again, only this time I want to make sure I understand what you're looking for.
Person2: Okay, I appreciate that.

Person1: Don't be ridiculous. You think your friends would be interested in this?
Person2: Hey, I want in on this! It's a big deal.
Person1: Fine, but either we make it public and invite everyone or we keep it quiet. Your choice.
Person2: Okay, I'll ask them. But you're not going to change your mind, are you?
Person1: No, I'm positive.

Person1: I've known Rachel for more than ten years. We're old allies.
Person2: All right then. It's refreshing to see two friends not afraid of real commitment. Will you have friends or family saying words - singing or anything?
Person1: Are we supposed to? It's not every day you get to celebrate a milestone like this.
Person2: It's an entirely personal decision... Some do some don't. But I think it would be nice to have some close friends share their thoughts.
Person1: Yeah... It's great... seems like... I don't know, you've got all the important stuff in there.

Person1: I've waited a long time for this chance to go, and you're not going to stop me now.
Person2: What about him? Are you going to let him watch you leave?
Person1: Let him watch. I want him to know what he's missing. I've been planning this for a year, and I won't let anyone stand in my way.
Person2: You're not afraid of what might happen if you leave?
Person1: Afraid? Me? No, I'm not afraid. I'm tired of being trapped here. I'll do whatever it takes to get out.
Person2: And what about the others? They might not want to leave.
Person1: They'll follow me. They're tired of being trapped too. We'll all leave together, and no one will stop us.

Person1: I know how to fix this. But you've gotta trust me.
Person2: A few days... a few weeks - dunno, I can't remember. Worse thing is, I never know if it will change back again...
Person1: So you believe me? We can figure this out together.
Person2: Please, just leave me alone. I need some time to think.

Person1: I want my mommy...
Person2: What's wrong, did you not get your way again?
Person1: You're no bargain either, pal. I thought we had a plan.
Person2: Plans change, and so do people. You can't expect everything to stay the same.
Person1: That's not what I'm expecting. I just want things to be perfect, like the right place and the right time.
Person2: It's not a space shuttle launch, it's life. Things don't always go as planned.

Person1: I've never felt this before for anyone, not even my wife. My future is with you, Sophia.
Person2: You think I did this for money? You think I did this for credit? I did this for the thrill of it.
Person1: No, the deal isn't changed. You can't just walk away from this.
Person2: Watch me.

Person1: I'll have a Bloody Mary and a steak sandwich.
Person2: You're beautiful... your skin glows.
Person1: Excuse me, are you a guest of the club?
Person2: No... Absolutely not. I'm shyer than you think.
Person1: They just left, but I can put the drink on their bill.
Person2: Thanks, but I just want to take a bath and...
Person1: You're classic... you're why people come to this club.
Person2: All right, cut me a break.

Person1: What do you want?
Person2: When you're ready to let go, to be unsingle and unmiserable, you will.
Person1: What's that supposed to mean?
Person2: Oh, difficult, it's so difficult. You're a nice person, and I shouldn't have asked you to meet me here.
Person1: You want me to leave?
Person2: No, yes. I mean, I want to give you some advice. For your own good. You'll let me, please...
Person1: I'm not sure I'm ready for that.
Person2: Until then...

Person1: I feel like a child again, Master.
Person2: You know better than that. You're a skilled artisan.
Person1: It's not often someone like you acknowledges our work.
Person2: Well, rest easy, I'm not looking for flaws. I'm impressed.
Person1: Thank you! For noticing, for... you know, it means a lot.

Person1: I'm feeling too good to argue with you, but I need to know - do you believe that I care about you?
Person2: Yes, I do. And if you're being honest with me, I'll know that you value our relationship and want to make it work.
Person1: I won't let anything come between us.

Person1: What's that?
Person2: I need a new sponsor.
Person1: Is that what you want?
Person2: Yeah. I thought you would know, you're a writer.
Person1: A sponsor. Mm... okay. Don't worry about it. Nobody'll mess with ya anymore.
Person2: Good night, old man.
Person1: Thank you. Yeah, yeah, yeah.

Person1: I'm so frustrated, I feel like I've made a huge mistake. Please, just hear me out.
Person2: What's going on? You're not making any sense.
Person1: I know it was dumb, and I'm willing to own up to it. But I didn't mean to cause any harm. I'm just asking for a chance to make it right.
Person2: Wait, slow down. Let's think this through. Maybe we can find a way to fix this together.

Person1: I'm thinking of taking a cooking class. Do you think I'd be any good at it?
Person2: I think you know I'd support you even if you ended up burning water.

Person1: I don't think you're taking this seriously.
Person2: Maybe you're just being too sensitive.
Person1: You always seem to find a way to deflect the conversation.
Person2: I'm just trying to offer a different perspective.
Person1: You're not listening to me. You never do.
Person2: That's not true. I'm trying to understand where you're coming from.
Person1: You're just saying that to placate me.
Person2: No, I mean it. I want to help you work through this.

Person1: You know we're right about the new security protocols.
Person2: It's easy to see the head of security hasn't had much practice implementing them.
Person1: Well, be like a weight off your shoulders, I'll show you how it's done. When you're searching anybody, take the lining of their coat, like this-- run your fingers all along these seams.... Then-- back of the collar--here--that used to be a favorite trick--and never forget to put your finger down inside of the shoe--like this.
Person2: Hey, I think I've got it now. Thanks for the help!

Person1: You're not exactly the most reliable hitman, are you?
Person2: What're you talkin' about?
Person1: I heard you botched the last job. The mark ended up in the hospital.
Person2: That's a lotta crap. I did what I was hired to do.
Person1: Long enough to die, that's what you did. If you really want to fail, that's your problem, but don't do it on my watch, okay?
Person2: Who are you to question my skills? I've been doing this for years.
Person1: I'm from out of town, that's who. And I've heard rumors about your... let's call them "shortcomings".

Person1: You could save him, little one. 
Person2: Shut up! You're just trying to confuse me!

Person1: I'm afraid we can't continue this project without a significant overhaul. Your methods are too reckless, Dr. Rodriguez.
Person2: I understand your concerns, Director, but I assure you, my approach is the only way to achieve the desired results. We can't afford to play it safe anymore.
Person1: I'm not asking you to play it safe, I'm asking you to be responsible. You're not the only one who's going to be affected by your actions. The entire team is at risk.
Person2: I appreciate your concern for the team, but I think you're being overly protective. We're not going to hurt anyone, Director.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is, we need to follow protocol and ensure that every precaution is taken. I expect you to revise your plan and present it to me by the end of the day.
Person2: Yes, Director. I'll make the necessary changes. But I hope you understand, this is going to set us back significantly.

Person1: Hey, I think you should take a look at this. I found a tape from the surveillance camera at the parking garage.
Person2: What's on it?
Person1: It's Erica, the new intern. She's in trouble.
Person2: What kind of trouble?
Person1: I'm not sure, but she's crying and saying something about Tim doing a bad thing.
Person2: What did Tim do?
Person1: I don't know, but it looks serious. You should go talk to him.
Person2: Okay, I'll go see what's going on. But if he's messed up, I'm not going to cover for him.
Person1: Just be careful, okay? Whatever happened, it looks like it got out of hand.

Person1: Professor Thompson? 
Person2: What is it, Emily? 
Person1: I just wanted to say thanks because your Biology class was the best I had this year. 
Person2: Don't you see, Emily? I made a breakthrough in regenerative medicine. 
Person1: I want to join your research team, Professor. I think I have what it takes to make a difference. 
Person2: Good for you. Go find out if you have what it takes. 
Person1: Well, my parents are against it, and I know it's my choice, but I was wondering... What would you do if you were me? 
Person2: Figuring things out for yourself is the only freedom anyone really has. Use that freedom. Make your own choice, Emily.

Person1: I had doubts too. I always looked at a desk as though it were a ball-and-chain. But something happened ...
Person2: How long do you think we'll have to stay here?
Person1: Until we figure out our next move. We don't want to get stuck in a rut.
Person2: No, we don't. But that's where we're headed if we don't make a change. From here, we can take a different path to success.
Person1: You're the only person in this place who can see right through me. You've made us look pretty good in the past week.
Person2: And the way you handled the press -- you've got a natural talent for it. But I have doubts about your ability to stick with what is essentially a new direction.

Person1: So, what's the situation with the defendant?
Person2: Hell, you know how these cases are. Says he's gonna plead insanity, and I'm like, "You can't do that," and he's all, "Well, then get the expert down here and let's settle this."
Person1: And what did the expert say?
Person2: He's completely out of his mind. Classic symptoms of a sociopathic personality.
Person1: That's not going to help his case. Does he have any redeeming qualities?
Person2: Well, he's a bit of a sad case. I heard he's an insomniac. Not to mention, he's got a lot of personal demons to deal with.

Person1: What's gotten into you, Marty? You're being reckless.
Person2: Nobody's paying me off, I'm just trying to help!
Person1: Stay near the house, I have a bad feeling about this. Please don't set off anything that goes bang tonight, okay?
Person2: Yeah, I know. It's great! I'll stick to bright colors.

Person1: I'm telling you, I saw it with my own eyes. There was a guy shooting from behind that fence.
Person2: If you're smart, you'll get out of here before Corbett's men find out.
Person1: What do you want from me? You're not listening to what I'm saying.
Person2: I'm listening, but I need you to do something for me. Go to my place on the Haul Road and tell Anne Marie I'm okay.
Person1: This is all kinda queer. I don't know what's going on, but I know what I saw.
Person2: Just do as I say and we'll take care of the rest. You don't want to get involved in this any deeper.

Person1: I've heard the new manager is quite well-liked, isn't she?
Person2: Yeah, I've seen her around. What did she buy for the office?
Person1: I don't remember exactly, but I've heard she's an idealist. You'll have to be open-minded.
Person2: Do you know how I define "open-mindedness"?

Person1: Don't mind her, Coach. She's just a bit nervous, is all. She don't mean nothin' by it--
Person2: That the problem, Coach? You think I'm nervous?
Person1: Look, don't you wanna show them - the team, yourself - that you're not intimidated by the tough competition anymore? That you can go out there, play with them, and win?
Person2: Yes, desperately.

Person1: I need to know the truth. SAY IT!
Person2: What are you talking about? You're not making any sense.
Person1: Don't play dumb. You made a choice once, and I want to know if you'd make it again.
Person2: What choice? You're not even making sense.
Person1: If you had to do it all over, would you still take the risk?

Person1: I believe there's been a mistake - your audition was a disaster. Look at the feedback. You wanted a lead role, but your performance was subpar.
Person2: Oh, all right... I guess I'll have to try out again. See you later, Rachel.

Person1: I don't remember you. Who's this?
Person2: You're right, I've been a selfish shit and I'm sorry. I've been so caught up in my own problems, I forgot about yours.
Person1: No, it's not that. I just...I lost my mom, and I'm still trying to process it all.
Person2: I'm so sorry to hear that. But you know, sometimes you have to let go of the past and focus on the present. Enough is enough.
Person1: You're right. I need to stop lying to myself about who my mom was and move on. Can you hang on a second?

Person1: I'm thinking of taking a break from everything and traveling to Japan.
Person2: You believe that's what you need? 
Person1: Yes. And if I don't come back, you'll know that I needed to do this for myself.
Person2: I'll support you, no matter what.

Person1: I've got a surprise for you. Let's get a description and stake out the location. 
Person2: That's a problem. There's no known description of the item. 
Person1: Are you telling me nobody knows what it looks like? Come on, there must be clues somewhere. 
Person2: Well, well! Ain't that nice! I think I'm going to love it.

Person1: I think you liked it with him.
Person2: There's a warning sign here. It's going to be closed at seven-thirty.

Person1: Excuse me, I need to ask you a few questions. You seem to be studying everything around you.
Person2: Oh, I'm just curious about the decor. You've got a great sense of style.
Person1: I'm not buying it. You're being too casual. Empty your pockets, please.
Person2: You're being paranoid. I'm just waiting for my friends to get back from their meeting. Can I get a drink while I wait?

Person1: I've known you for more than fifteen years, Alex. We're old allies.
Person2: I don't remember you anymore. Where's the park?
Person1: It takes years to get there. And years to come back... Now go to bed, it's late.
Person2: You're terrible. You're just trying to distract me.
Person1: I'm trying to help. You're not thinking clearly.

Person1: I thought I'd call and see how you're doing.
Person2: It's only a matter of time before the deal falls through, don't bother pretending you're concerned.
Person1: I told you, it's the down payment. And thanks to you it's overdue.
Person2: I know what you're capable of, but I'm not going to talk about it unless we can discuss it in person.

Person1: Do you think she can do it?
Person2: I'm looking for a reason...
Person1: She's a very talented woman.
Person2: Watch me find out.
Person1: Where are you going now?
Person2: To get some answers.
Person1: Someone waiting for you?
Person2: Only the truth.
Person1: There's a certain kind of driven person who uses their passion to get ahead. Is that our Sarah?
Person2: If I'm helping her, and I haven't said I am, then so what?
Person1: So everything. That's so what. So I begin to wonder about her.
Person2: I know her well enough. Enough to know she's hiding something.
Person1: Do you want to talk about what's really going on?
Person2: Yes.

Person1: Are you crazy? You're paying two hundred bucks for those shoes?
Person2: Him? I don't know... He can be nice... sometimes.
Person1: What do you mean? You're not making any sense.
Person2: I mean, if you're going to spend that much, you should at least get a good deal.
Person1: A good deal? You're the one who's been saying I should leave him if I wanted to!
Person2: Leave who? I'm just talking about the shoes.

Person1: Excuse me, sir. Are you a member of our editorial board?
Person2: Yes, I'm with the investigative team. What kind of disaster could we help bring about if we don't change our reporting strategy?
Person1: Don't be over-dramatic, sir. Our business is journalism, and we can't continue to be so irresponsible.
Person2: Would you care for a briefing while you're waiting? I can put it on the board's agenda.
Person2: Great. I'll have a summary of the latest findings and a proposal for a more responsible approach.

Person1: I've been thinking, maybe somebody's tracking one of your investigations.
Person2: Oh, yeah? What makes you think that?
Person1: I've always regretted the way I behaved that evening we went out, and I think it's connected.
Person2: Don't be silly! You're not responsible for my problems.
Person1: I'm telling you, it's gotta be the government. They're looking for you.
Person2: You're crazy. I was the one who messed up, not you.
Person1: I'm you, I take that money and get outta town while you can.

Person1: We've been searching for weeks, but there's no sign of her.
Person2: The lost can wait. Perhaps the same wind whispers through both of us, tonight
Person1: Yes, and I wonder if we'll ever find her, or if she'll find us.

Person1: I forgive you.
Person2: Remember, I'm not the one who chose this.
Person1: What gave you that idea? You think I'm upset about something?
Person2: Yes, so which one of us does that make the coward?
Person1: Well, as a matter of fact, I was rather hurt when you didn't show up that night.
Person2: I don't blame you. It was unforgivable.
Person1: You couldn't help yourself. I mean, when you're in a situation like that, you can't just suddenly walk out because of a misunderstanding.
Person2: Don't be too sure. Just because we're talking this through doesn't make everything okay.

Person1: Honestly, Alex. Do you actually think I would sabotage your project without telling you?
Person2: Gee, I don't know, Maya. I don't seem to remember you actually asking me if you could invite 50 people over to help with the preparations.
Person1: Sometimes we have to improvise. What's happened to Dr. Lee? I mean, besides being overwhelmed?
Person2: Dr. Lee? My Dr. Lee? What's going on?
Person3: (entering the room) Dr. Lee has been sort of, I don't know... reassigned.
Person1: Reassigned? By who?
Person2: The department head.
Person1: Good God. Let's go talk to them. Only one problem. I don't know where they are right now.
Person3: Ah. Wait a minute. The secretary must know where they are.
Person2: It's a little late to call the secretary.
Person1: Is it a little late to call the Dean?
Person2: Maybe... I don't know.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly.
Person2: What makes you think you're the expert?
Person1: I've seen this before. Let us explore it together.

Person1: I need you to do something for me. We've been given a gift, a real opportunity. This new project needs us, and maybe that's why we've been struggling to find our place.
Person2: What makes you think I'm the right person for this?
Person1: You can let the team look around, answer their questions, but watch them. If there's any problems, make sure we know about it first. And, by the way, you might want to tidy up your workspace.

Person1: I've been thinking about my childhood a lot lately. You know, my parents used to tell me that I was a punishment from God.
Person2: A punishment? That's very colorful. What do you mean?
Person1: Well, they said it was because of something they did, but they never told me what. I always felt like I was somehow to blame.
Person2: That must have been really tough for you. Did you ever try to talk to them about it?
Person1: No, I don't think so. I was too afraid. But I did find this old notebook of mine the other day, and it had a strange phrase written on every page: "Franklin Chapter 1 Verse number 1." I think it was one of my dad's Bible lessons.
Person2: That's really strange. Do you think it's related to what they told you about being a punishment?
Person1: I'm not sure, but I think it might be. I'd like to talk to them about it, but they're not around anymore.

Person1: I've heard so much about your philanthropic efforts. What drives you to give back to the community?
Person2: I don't think that you would understand if I told you. It's just something that comes from the heart.
Person1: I think I understand without your telling me. I know something of your history, and I must say, I'm impressed.
Person2: You're too kind. But I must say, I'm intrigued by your new project. Tell me, what inspired you to take on such a challenge?

Person1: I'm willing to cut you a break, partner! 
Person2: You're not who I thought you were. 
Person1: Good ol' mild mannered Rachel! Give it up. It doesn't fly with me. 
Person2: What do you want from me? 
Person1: Honestly? I want to see you walk out of here, free and clear. That's what I want.

Person1: I'm telling you, we need to be careful.
Person2: You think I'm reckless, don't you?
Person1: It's not about being reckless, it's about being prepared. We're wearing long underwear, just in case.
Person2: That's not the point. You're implying I'm not responsible.
Person1: I'm not implying anything. I'm just saying, if I was with you, I wouldn't worry so much.
Person2: You did worry, though. I remember.
Person1: That was then. This is now. And I'm doing okay, aren't I?
Person2: Yeah, you're doing okay.

Person1: I'm sorry I haven't been the partner to you that I should be.
Person2: Hey, just shut up. You're not going to sweet-talk your way out of this one.
Person1: I wasn't trying to. I just feel like I've been taking you for granted lately.
Person2: You think? You've been so caught up in your own problems, you barely even notice me anymore.
Person1: That's not true. I care about you deeply. I just...I don't know, I feel like I'm failing you somehow.
Person2: Failing me? You're not even trying.

Person1: I can see the city in my head. The material world is an illusion.
Person2: That's an interesting perspective. But don't you think you need a place to stay? A roof over your head?
Person1: People don't do that kind of thing. Not in this city.
Person2: I'm not "people." I'm just me. And I'm a nurse. I can help you.
Person1: I can smell the scent of acacia. It's in this room. I can taste the tea.
Person2: You're remembering something, aren't you? Something from your past?
Person1: Could I have a cigarette?
Person2: I'm not sure that's a good idea. But I can offer you a place to crash for a couple of nights.
Person1: Thanks, but I'll manage. I can take care of myself.
Person2: Suit yourself. But if you change your mind, here's the address.

Person1: How long has this been going on?
Person2: A few days, a few weeks - I don't know, I lost track.
Person1: Not even behind your back?
Person2: What are you insinuating?
Person1: I'm not insinuating anything. I just want to know the truth.
Person2: The truth is, I'm trying to do my best here.
Person1: Well, it's not good enough. You're going to have to do better than that.

Person1: Answer me, what's the holdup?
Person2: I've got it, sir. We've been tracing the shipment to the docks in Rotterdam.

Person1: I talked to the event organizer, and they're willing to let you perform at the festival. But before I forget, someone will guide you through the backstage area when you arrive.
Person2: What's the catch?
Person1: No catch, we're all here to support you. You just need to follow the instructions at the lock, and you'll be fine.
Person2: Thanks, I appreciate it.

Person1: Do you know what's going on?
Person2: What's going on where?
Person1: With Sonrisa's business...or should I say, not taking care of it. I'm hired to do a piece of work, and I want to make sure it's done right.
Person2: What're you talking about? I thought we were just discussing the new project.
Person1: I'm talking about the way things have been handled lately. It's embarrassing to the professional community, is what it is.
Person2: I don't know what you're insinuating, but I think we should focus on the task at hand.

Person1: You better start making sense! We're running out of time.
Person2: What's going on? You're scaring me.
Person1: One of the reasons I love you, Alex, is that you're always so calm in a crisis. But we need to act fast - the lab is going to be sealed off in 36 hours.
Person2: Then we've got to get to the backup generator! It's our only chance.
Person1: Save this one for last, okay? We need to prioritize.

Person1: What can I do for you, Professor?
Person2: I have to go, but I wanted to discuss the recent changes in the department's funding.
Person1: You can't leave yet. We've got so much to talk about, like the new research grant proposals.
Person2: Actually, I've been working on a proposal to reduce our environmental impact. I think it's something you'd be interested in.
Person1: I'm intrigued. Tell me more.

Person1: I had a lunch break so I thought I'd come by and see you. I won't let you take control of my company.
Person2: Sit down. You'll be a billionaire. Better than being broke. I've got investors standing in line. Ball's in your court, Mr. McCloy. But the burning is totally normal.

Person1: Are you alright?
Person2: You told me about the party. 
Person1: What party are you talking about?
Person2: Meet me at the highest point from where you are. I want to discuss it.

Person1: I've got a bad feeling about this, like people with broken bones know when there's a storm coming.
Person2: You're not messing with me, are you, Jake? What's going on with your dad?
Person1: I saw your eyes when you stood up to him at the town hall meeting. You've got a fire in you, Jake.
Person2: What are you afraid of, Rachel? You can tell me.
Person1: I'm afraid you'll let your anger get the best of you. You can't let him push you around, Jake.
Person2: It's not just about my dad, is it? It's about the whole town.
Person1: I can't just stand by and watch, Jake. I've got to do something.

Person1: You're overly optimistic. They're likely to destroy the planet.
Person2: Then it's fortunate that I have you and your expertise to guide me. In the meantime, I instruct you to review my proposal.
Person1: We'll be happy to review it. But first, we must have certain assurances. What can I do for you, Doctor?
Person2: Actually, I already work with you. Or did. Your environmental preservation project in South America.
Person1: We cut our support. A conflict of ideologies. Dr. Rodriguez was a visionary.
Person2: I see you knew him. I have a plan showing how we can immediately cease all actions that harm our environment.

Person1: You know a lot about business, I guess.
Person2: Every day that goes by, I'm losing money. Every worker that is idle, costs me money - I have to find them something else to do, I have to reassign them -
Person1: There's a rumor going around, maybe you've heard it. Some of the departments went under, what're you going to do?
Person2: It's bad management. Occasionally, sure, okay, you got to make adjustments. But that's good business.

Person1: I'm going to find out.
Person2: Hold me, I'm falling!
Person1: Oh, why couldn't I be in charge of something simple for once? If the Council gets the ancient scrolls and the instructions for the artifact--
Person2: I promise, I'll help you get to the bottom of this. But you must remember, you have a duty to the people as well as to yourself.
Person1: I know, just say "good luck to me."
Person2: Good luck to you, and may the truth be revealed.

Person1: I'm willing to give you a second chance, but don't think you can fool me. I've seen it before.
Person2: I appreciate your understanding. Depression is a serious issue, and I'm trying to stay positive.
Person1: Good, because I won't tolerate any nonsense. You need to focus on your well-being.
Person2: I will, thank you for looking out for me.

Person1: I heard the new simulator is a real challenge. You think you can handle it?
