Person2: I'm not worried. My family has a history of overcoming tough situations.
Person1: Really? What makes you so confident?
Person2: Well, my brother was a pilot and he... (pauses) ...he didn't make it.
Person1: I'm sorry to hear that. I lost a sibling too, in a different way. It's tough to deal with.
Person2: Yeah, it's not easy. But I'd rather not talk about it right now. Can we change the subject?
Person1: Of course. So, what do you think about the new training program?

Person1: Don't WORRY!!! You've GOT it!! Are you CRAZY?
Person2: Wait. What's going on here? You're being really loud.
Person1: Reverend Mother says you need experience, right, in life. In order to make a responsible decision.
Person2: Experience? What are you talking about?

Person1: What do you want more than anything?
Person2: I'm not sure. I've been doing the same job for fifteen years, and I feel like I'm just going through the motions.
Person1: Maybe you should think about it for a while. It could complicate things if you don't figure it out.
Person2: You're right. I don't want to be stuck in a rut. But what if I'm already to blame for not knowing what I want?
Person1: That's not what I meant. I just think you should take some time to reflect on your goals and aspirations.
Person2: Yeah, maybe you're right. I'll try to do that.

Person1: What do you see as your main strengths?
Person2: No, don't, don't. I love people. All people.
Person1: Who sent you, Brumby?
Person2: I think they're OK, you know. Like my mate Francis Begbie.
Person1: Leaving your friend aside, do you see yourself as having any weaknesses?
Person2: No, well, yes. I have to admit it.

Person1: I've known Rachel for more than ten years. We're old allies.
Person2: Yes, yes. I know. Right. And if it had gone well for me tonight, maybe I'd be keeping quiet about all this...I grant you everything but give me this...he does personify everything you've been fighting against...
Person1: Go away. You were obviously getting nowhere with her. I was waiting for the right moment to tell you that.
Person2: My God. You even cooked up that business trip.

Person1: I want to make it clear, I'm a straight shooter. If anyone's caught cheating, we'll have a problem.
Person2: What about him? Does he know the rules?
Person1: Let him watch. I want him to understand what's at stake.
Person2: And if he breaks the rules?
Person1: We'll have to take action. But first, we'll give him a chance to make it right.
Person2: And if he refuses?
Person1: Then we'll have to stand him up to the consequences. But I hope it doesn't come to that.

Person1: I don't remember booking a meeting with the marketing team.
Person2: Just until we finalize the campaign? I had a power surge at home and lost all my notes.
Person1: Uhhmmm... uh gee, uh... do you know anything about recovering files?
Person2: Yeah, I was hoping you could help me with that. I've got a big presentation tomorrow and I really need those notes back.
Person1: Let me take a look. What's the model of your computer?
Person2: It's a little boxy thing, with switches on it... lets my computer talk to the one here...

Person1: I know how to get us out of this situation. But you've gotta trust me.
Person2: What do I need to do?
Person1: See this map? It's not just any map. It's a treasure map. I've been searching for it for years.
Person2: It looks like a regular map to me.
Person1: That's because you don't know what to look for. Let me show you.

Person1: I'll visit often, don't worry about it.
Person2: Oh, it's nothing... I better go, I'll talk to you later.
Person1: Wait, don't you remember me? I was a volunteer at the animal shelter.
Person2: Sorry, I don't think so. You're so lucky you have the time to do that, I've been busy with work.
Person1: Yeah, I'm trying to give back. Maybe I'll see you around sometime.
Person2: Ok, have fun, bye.

Person1: Are you a member of our loyalty program?
Person2: Two hundred bucks?? Are you crazy? I just want to buy a coffee.
Person1: I apologize for the confusion. Let me offer you a discount on your purchase.
Person2: That's very kind of you. I'll take a cappuccino and a pastry.
Person1: Would you like me to put it on your loyalty card?
Person2: No, I'll just pay cash.

Person1: Hiya, I heard you're performing your dance quintet at Crane Jackson's Fountain Street Theatre on Tuesday night.
Person2: Yeah, I'm really excited! I was voted most likely to succeed, you know.
Person1: That's impressive. But let me ask you, have you ever been called 'Shnook', 'Dope', 'Dipstick', or 'Lamebrain' behind your back?
Person2: (laughs) No, I don't think so. Why do you ask?
Person1: Just curious. Well, I'd love to come and give you notes on your performance. But first, get your feet off that desk.

Person1: I've always regretted the way I behaved that evening we went out, and I just thought I'd tell you that because I really made a fool out of myself.
Person2: Wonderful. I know I'm strange, but in my own way, I love you.
Person1: Oh, yeah? What do you mean by that?
Person2: I mean that everyone makes mistakes, and it's how we learn from them that matters. And I love you for being honest with me.
Person1: Oh, don't be silly! You're making me feel better than I deserve.
Person2: I'm just telling the truth.

Person1: I don't understand you.
Person2: Thank you. It's not important.
Person1: Life gets messy. Ugly messy. But I think that's okay with me because of the rest of the stuff. All the good shit. All the surprises.
Person2: After I saw what Simone did with the role, I realized I needed to change. I took acting classes, changed my whole look.
Person1: We'd have had a ride. You'd have surprised yourself.
Person2: I guess.

Person1: I'm not good at lying, it's against my nature.
Person2: Well, in closing, I'd like to say that there are two reasons to be honest in business. One is your professional reputation, and the second is the trust of your clients.

Person1: I need to borrow some more money. Don't get upset.
Person2: What do you mean? You're always asking for loans.
Person1: Well, I kind of tried to get a job, but it just seemed stupid, I kept thinking about all the other things I could be doing, and it just seemed like a dumb thing to be doing when we don't know what to do with all that stress, you know?
Person2: So it was recently that you tried to get a job.
Person1: Well, kind of recently, I guess. But not too recently.

Person1: I'm not the one who chose this.
Person2: What are you talking about? You're the one who always gets to decide.
Person1: I don't even remember why I wanted this in the first place.

Person1: You're in such a hurry. You can't wait.
Person2: Watch me. I'm looking for a new opportunity.
Person1: No, I don't think you can do that. You know the deal when you signed on.
Person2: Deal's changed. I did this for recognition, not just money.
Person1: But you always knew you couldn't take the credit. You're not gonna let others take it, are you?
Person2: That's one thing, but I'm not gonna let my hard work go unnoticed. I should've taken the chance earlier, sonofabitch.
Person1: You're not thinking clearly. You're letting emotions cloud your judgment.
Person2: I'm thinking more clearly than you are. You're just trying to hold me back.

Person1: I love "Row, row, row your boat..." It's a great way to relax. But before we get to that, let's talk about your goals. What do you hope to achieve in the next six years?
Person2: Well, I'm not sure. I'm still figuring that out.
Person1: That's okay. Lot of things can happen in six years. You might discover a new passion or talent. But for now, let's focus on the present. Are you ready to learn something new?

Person1: I need you to review the system logs for me. One, check for any anomalies in the AO-unit performance.
Person2: Yes, sir. What's the reason for the review?
Person1: Look, I know you're competent and trying to do a thorough job, but I'm not capable of overlooking this issue. It's crucial we identify the problem.
Person2: Okay, I'll get right on it. If there's anything unusual, I'll let you know immediately.

Person1: I've been searching for her everywhere. It's a long shot, but I have to try.
Person2: I understand. You're not going to give up, are you?
Person1: Sometimes you can't know what I'm doing. It's better that way.
Person2: I can smell the scent of acacia in this room. It's calming.
Person1: I'll give it two months, two months at most, then I'll be back. We'll take a vacation.
Person2: You're not remembering more, are you? About your wife?
Person1: I'm not gonna need any precautions. I won't even think about it. Don't worry about me.
Person2: Because I care about you, that's why.

Person1: I managed to get the last ticket to the concert, Rachel. I slammed my money down as soon as I saw it.
Person2: Then the roads to the venue are open...
Person1: The main road is, but that's about it. I called the event organizer and talked to the head of security. I told him who you were and what had happened. He said as long as there's no issue with the sound system, the show will go on, and as soon as the road to the venue is open, they'll send a shuttle for us.
Person2: The phones are working?
Person1: Well, mine's still out. But the ones at the venue were working just fine. I called your friend. Oh, Rachel, I peeked at the setlist... it's like a visit from my oldest, dearest friend.
Person2: My sister must be going nuts. I was supposed to meet her at the concert three days ago.
Person1: Your friend said she would tell her you were okay. But I'm afraid you'll have to wait until tomorrow if you want to speak to her yourself.

Person1: I've lost my knack for photography. I haven't taken a good shot in years.
Person2: We have to do something fun tonight, I need a distraction from my own creative block.
Person1: I know a secret art studio we could visit... it's a surprise.
Person2: What? Where?! You're not just saying that to get me out of this rut, are you?
Person1: If I promise you there's really a studio with some amazing artists, do you promise you'll come with me?
Person2: I don't believe you, but I'm desperate enough to try anything.

Person1: You're always so honest, aren't you?
Person2: Yes, I am. I speak the truth, even if it's hard to hear.
Person1: But what about our past? Don't you think it's important to acknowledge it?
Person2: We never really shared one, and even if we did, it wouldn't change how I feel about you now.
Person1: You're not like others, are you? You don't let emotions cloud your judgment.
Person2: I'm just not terribly invested in romantic sentiment, I suppose.

Person1: Are you sure you're ready for this?
Person2: If you want to take the risk, go ahead, but do it for yourself, not to prove a point to others.

Person1: I need to start over. I see a chance for redemption, but I require your help, Alex.
Person2: The dead can wait. What's this chance you're talking about?
Person1: You once made a difficult decision. Would you make the same choice again if given the opportunity?
Person2: What are you getting at?

Person1: I've got a plan, dude. We're gonna need to find a way to get our hands on that cash.
Person2: Waitaminit, I got it! We find the right connections, make a deal, and we're set. What do you think?
Person1: Brilliance, Trip. Sheer brilliance. But we need to discuss the terms. I'm thinking a 10% finder's fee.
Person2: Does the Pope shit in the woods? You know I'm in. But we need to move fast, before someone else beats us to it.
Person1: Alright, let's get to it. I heard the cash is being held by a kid named Vinnie. He lives in East LA, near the old warehouse district. We'll need to be careful, though. He's got connections.
Person2: Don't worry, I've got a guy on the inside. We'll get it done. Now, about that check for my ten per cent...

Person1: I'm telling you, we need to make a big splash with the campaign kickoff.
Person2: You're not crazy, are you?
Person1: I promise you that. I am not crazy. Course, if I was, I'd be the last to know. Why do you ask?
Person2: You're talking about making a splash, but we're still finalizing the venue.
Person1: Ah, details. We'll get to that. I'm thinking bigger picture. We'll make it a historic event, like Neil Armstrong landing on the moon.
Person2: And what's the message we want to convey?
Person1: That we're a force to be reckoned with. That we're not going to let the opposition forget that there's an election coming up.
Person2: I like it. But we need to make sure we're not getting off on the wrong foot.
Person1: Exactly. We need to strike the right tone. Maybe something like... "Thank you for being here, and thank you for caring about the future of this country..."
Person2: I like it. You're doing okay.

Person1: I need to tell you something, Rachel. They're not going to publish your article.
Person2: What? Why not?
Person1: The editor said it's too controversial, and they don't want to risk a lawsuit.
Person2: Answer me. Did you know that I spent years researching this topic, and now you're telling me it's all for nothing?
Person1: Rachel, I understand how you feel. But maybe we can find another way to get your work out there.
Person2: You don't understand. This was my chance to show my kids that all the sacrifices we made were worth it. Now it's just going to disappear?

Person1: Captain, I want you to stand like that until you're sick of it because I don't ever want to see it again, you hear me?
Person2: What is this? Is this a... punishment? Are you kidding? I'm trying to celebrate my birthday here.
Person1: Yeah, happy birthday. I got you a present. Why don't you try it on?
Person2: Uh, yeah, uh... this is more like a uniform for you, yeah, but it's...

Person1: I didn't mean to run into you here, that's all.
Person2: What're you talkin' about? You're the one who's been taking care of business...or should I say, not taking care of it.
Person1: I'm just trying to do my job, but it seems like you're not doing yours. I've seen the way you operate, and it's embarrassing.
Person2: That's a lotta crap. You don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: I know that I'm hired to get the job done, and I do it. You, on the other hand, seem to make a mess of things. Maybe it's time for you to step aside.
Person2: How come I never heard of you before? Who are you to tell me how to do my job?

Person1: We need to make a decision about the trip to Sonora. 
Person2: I don't know what to say to that. 
Person1: The job here is to make the most of our time -- right now -- our job is to just try and make it as enjoyable as possible. 
Person2: We don't want to go to Minden, but that's where we're going. 
Person1: From Minden we take a stage to Reno, then another one over to Auburn and another one to Placerville. Then it's a day's trip to Sonora. 
Person2: We could save ourselves an awful lot of time if we took a different route.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with you going out there alone. There are plenty of people around here who could help.
Person2: Yeah, I know. It's great! I could use the time to clear my head. Between you and me, I need some space.
Person1: Just be careful, okay? I don't want anything to happen to you.
Person2: Don't worry, I'll be fine. I'll stick to the main roads and avoid any... distractions.

Person1: I've been wondering, do you ever get tired of wearing the same old clothes every day?
Person2: What makes you think I have any other clothes to wear?
Person1: I've read about people like you, always stuck in a rut. But I knew it wasn't true. You're not that kind of person.
Person2: You'd be amazed at what people will believe about others.

Person1: I mean, what are you actually doing here? What is the hidden agenda?
Person2: This is the last time, I promise. And I'm keeping strict accounts.

Person1: I've been thinking about the meeting tomorrow. I want you to sit behind them when they arrive.
Person2: They'll be looking at me, wondering who I am.
Person1: Exactly. And I'll be at the front, but don't introduce me. Just start talking. I want to see their reactions.
Person2: That's a bit unconventional, don't you think?
Person1: Maybe, but I want to get a sense of their honesty. If they're willing to admit the truth, even if it's uncomfortable.
Person2: And what if they're not?
Person1: Then we'll have to reevaluate our approach. But I have a feeling they'll be more open than we think.

Person1: I'm worried about Alex. Is he okay?
Person2: Hold me, I'm falling apart. I need your help.
Person1: What's going on? You're scaring me.
Person2: I saw him at that new community center downtown. That was a long time ago.
Person1: Which one? The one near the park?
Person2: Yes, that's the one. I promise I'll help you find him.

Person1: I've been noticing your confidence in the team meetings. You seem to have a natural charisma that draws people in.
Person2: Oh no, I don't know about that. I just try to speak my mind.
Person1: That's exactly what I mean. You're not afraid to share your thoughts, and people respect that. Sometimes I feel like I'm fighting this battle alone to get my ideas heard.
Person2: I think that's because you're passionate about your approach, and people can sense that. I'm on your side, by the way. I think your vision is exactly what the project needs.

Person1: I've been volunteering at the local hospital. 
Person2: You've brought one of the doctors with you, I see. 
Person1: Yes, Dr. Lee has been a great mentor. I've been learning a lot from her. 
Person2: That's wonderful. I'm sure she's proud of you.

Person1: I just want you to know, I appreciate your honesty, Alex.
Person2: Whatever you wish... This has all been a terrible misunderstanding, Rachel. I wanted to work together, but our teams had different ideas.
Person1: That might be the news we've been waiting for. Let's start fresh and find a solution that benefits both parties.
Person2: Enough of the past, let's focus on the future.

Person1: I'm sorry, I don't understand.
Person2: For evil to bend its knee, admit its guilt, implore His forgiveness, is the hardest thing on earth --
Person1: Like it? This place, I mean.
Person2: Yes. It reminds me of home. But I want to, Malcolm, but I can't.
Person1: What do you mean you can't? You're here to find something, aren't you?
Person2: The hardest and the greatest. I'm searching for a way to make amends.
Person1: Have you ever bent your knees, Malcolm? Maybe that's what you need to do.
Person2: I've tried, but it's not that simple. I need guidance, and I think you can help me.

Person1: Don't worry, you've got this! Are you nervous?
Person2: I'm not good at public speaking.
Person1: Get comfortable with it. It's a skill you can develop.
Person2: I'll try, but it's not my nature.

Person1: I'm not sure I can make it to the concert tonight. I'm not feeling well.
Person2: Oh, come on! It's not every day that our favorite band comes to town. Please, as a favor to me? So I won't be the only one singing along to all the songs?
Person1: I understand that, but I really need to get permission from my doctor first. I don't want to risk making my condition worse.
Person2: You've been stuck at home for weeks. I've read about the benefits of music therapy. Believe me, it'll do you good. We can even wheel you out if you need to take a break.

Person1: I know how to get us out of this mess. But you've got to trust me.
Person2: You don't understand, I can't do that! It's too risky.
Person1: Listen, we owe it to ourselves to try. So grab your things, we're leaving now.

Person1: You really want that on your head?
Person2: Damn, I'm impressed. Really. I would have bet good money you wouldn't take a stand like that.
Person1: It's time for a change. We can't just pretend it didn't happen. The system needs to be held accountable.
Person2: I'm with you, but we need to be smart about it. We can't let emotions cloud our judgment.

Person1: I've been thinking, what kind of friend was I that I could abandon you in your time of need? It got to where I couldn't face you, couldn't stand the thought of your disappointment.
Person2: Excuse me, are you a guest of the hotel?
Person1: Yes, I'm with the Smiths. They're having a party upstairs.
Person2: They just left, sir. But you're welcome to wait in the lobby.
Person1: I think I'll do that. I need to prove to myself that I can make things right between us. Only...it was just another "should." Sitting here, thinking about everything we went through... Something happened. I guess it doesn't matter how much I want to fix things, or how much you want me to. I guess it's like you said, the only thing that counts is what's best for our friendship.
Person2: Would you care for a drink while you're waiting? I can put it on the Smith's bill.
Person1: No, thank you. I just want to talk to you, clear the air. I won't avoid you anymore. Our friendship is yours...I mean, it's ours.
Person2: Oh, thank you...I think.

Person1: I've been feeling so uneasy about this place. What's in there?
Person2: Maybe it's just your imagination. You're just shy around new environments.
Person1: I'm telling you, I saw something moving in the corner of the room. It was just a dark mist at first, but then it started to take shape.
Person2: Frida, I don't mean this as a criticism, but you might not want to talk about your fears around others. It can be overwhelming.
Person1: Sorry. It's just so bad lately. I feel like death is lurking around every corner.
Person2: I get a little anxious sometimes too. But we can face this together.

Person1: I'll meet you at the same place. What's the plan this time?
Person2: In a week, we'll reassess our priorities. But for now, I need you to focus on the task at hand.

Person1: Hiya, I finally got the venue I wanted.
Person2: Ooooooh-kayyyyyy. In the end, the jury saw it my way.
Person1: Well, then it all seems to be working out for you. I'm performing my dance quintet at Crane Jackson's Fountain Street Theatre on Tuesday night, and I'd love it if you came and gave me notes.
Person2: Do you remember the time I won the Salwen Medal? You seemed so sure of yourself on television. If you're really that confident, you'd be willing to let someone prove you wrong?
Person1: The world would be so much simpler if it were all just about good and evil. Unfortunately, I find it much more slippery and elusive place. But hey, I'll take your notes into consideration.
Person2: Well, I think it's very simple. Here's a tape of my rehearsal. I'll be at the Public Library. Tomorrow at 2... if you want to discuss my performance.

Person1: I'm not feeling so well, can we take a break?
Person2: Well in closing, I'd like to say that there are two reasons we need to finish this project on time.
Person1: Go away, I need some fresh air.
Person2: One is the deadline, and the second is the impact it will have on our team's reputation.
Person1: Please, just give me a minute.
Person2: Where is your sense of responsibility?

Person1: You know, I've always regretted the way I behaved that evening we went out.
Person2: You don't dwell on past mistakes. You're better than that.
Person1: If I wanted to make amends, I'd do it sincerely.
Person2: Oh, don't be silly! No! Don't be ridiculous. It was my fault, I--

Person1: I love that old song, "Row, row, row your boat..." It's so calming.
Person2: You know, I've been feeling a bit crazy lately. Thinking I saw things that didn't happen.
Person1: You're not crazy, by the way. It's just your memory playing tricks on you.
Person2: But it seemed so real. And it's in my family, you know. My grandmother had a similar experience...
Person1: Well, if having a quirky family made you crazy, the world would be a very interesting place. Let's focus on the present. Want to sing that song with me?

Person1: I need you to keep an eye on the Johnson account. It's a big deal for us.
Person2: Yes, sir. I'll make sure everything goes smoothly.
Person1: I'm equally impressed with your attention to detail. How long have you been with the company now?
Person2: Three years, but I've been in the industry for over a decade.
Person1: I think you'd be a great fit for our new project. Would you like to discuss it over lunch today?
Person2: That sounds great, thank you for the opportunity.

Person1: I've been on this case for months. 
Person2: Once it's solved, you won't have to worry about it.
Person1: Be like a weight off your shoulders, right?
Person2: That's the point, isn't it?

Person1: Would you like to try one?
Person2: Of what??
Person1: Well, sometimes when we harvest them, they're not completely ripe, you know, like when they're picked too early and still have a bit of bite.
Person2: I'm not sure I understand. You're not trying to deceive me, are you?
Person1: Whatever you wish... I wanted to be honest with you, but my partner insisted we try a different approach.
Person2: I think we're done here.

Person1: I'll work anywhere, anytime. I know I can't be choosy.
Person2: "Row, row, row your boat..." I love "Row..." Do you know "Row, Row, Row, Row, Row Your Boat?"
Person1: What's that got to do with anything? I'm here for a job.
Person2: Oh, right. Sorry about that. So, how's your driving record?
Person1: Clean. Real clean. As clean as my conscience.
Person2: (laughs) You're a funny one. Merrily, merrily, merrily, merrily, life is but a dream...
Person1: (confused) What's going on here? Are you serious about hiring me?
Person2: Of course, I am. Fill out these forms and give them to the girl at the desk, and leave your phone number.
Person1: I don't have a phone.
Person2: Well, then check back tomorrow. And by the way, would you like to sing "Row, Row, Row Your Boat" with me?
Person1: (exasperated) No, I don't think so.

Person1: I'm telling you, this is the only way to get the best view.
Person2: You know when I wait? When it's important to wait. It's not important to wait for the sunset.
Person1: So, what's the hurry? We can enjoy the moment.
Person2: I may miss the perfect shot.
Person1: So, take a few. Spills, thrills, laughs, and memories - this may even turn out to be an unforgettable experience.
Person2: What's the surprise?
Person1: Uh-uh. Not yet. Let's take a drink first and toast to the moment.
Person2: Here, this'll give you a kick.

Person1: I can see the tension in your body language. Are you upset because I didn't ask you about the party tonight?
Person2: Yeah, I guess I am. I mean, it's not just about the party, it's about feeling like I'm not being considered in the decisions you make.
Person1: I didn't mean to make you feel that way. I just thought it would be fun to have some friends over.
Person2: I would've said yes, I just wish you would've asked. And what's with the black tea? You know I hate it.
Person1: Oh, I'm sorry. I just got it because I remembered someone telling me it's really good for you.
Person2: Someone? Who's someone?
Person1: Just a friend from work. Anyway, can I make it up to you? Maybe we can have a quiet night in instead?
Person2: I don't know...I'm still feeling a bit off. Maybe I just need some space.
Person1: Okay, I understand. But can I ask, is everything okay with us? You seem a bit distant lately.
Person2: Yeah, everything's fine. I just need some time to recharge, that's all.

Person1: You know when people speak the truth? It's not about being smart or top of your class. It's about understanding the world around you.
Person2: I see the truth of it. Pain by nerve induction... A human can resist any pain. But what's the point of resisting if you don't know what you're fighting for?
Person1: Exactly! That's why I study world events. I want to know what's really going on, not just what they want me to believe.
Person2: And what do you think you've learned from your studies? That the truth is always clear-cut?
Person1: No, I've learned that the truth is often hidden behind propaganda and lies. But that doesn't mean we should give up trying to find it.

Person1: What's holding you back from finishing the project? You can do better than that.
Person2: Why do I let you push me into these deadlines? Why?
Person1: Because we're a team - we work well together. I know you've got a great idea in you.
Person2: I've lost my creative spark. After the success of our last collaboration, I feel like I'm stuck.
Person1: Maybe we need to take a break from the office. Let's play a round of miniature golf and clear our heads.
Person2: You think that's going to help? I'm not exactly thrilled about being seen with you in public, making fools of ourselves.

Person1: The dead can wait.
Person2: What do you know of my grief?
Person1: Let us find a way to move forward together.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this plan. If we go ahead, tomorrow I'll just be some engineer you go telling all your colleagues about.
Person2: Nonsense, we're making excellent time. We must give them something new to print.
Person1: But I prefer not to push the engines until they've been properly run in. What's the hurry?
Person2: Come on, it'll be a glorious end to your project if we get it done ahead of schedule and surprise them all. Retire with a bang, eh?

Person1: I've never bent my knees, Captain. I'm not sure I know how.
Person2: Nonsense, it's all about speed and making headlines. We must give them something new to print.
Person1: But I want to, I want to admit my guilt and implore forgiveness. It's the hardest thing on earth.
Person2: I prefer not to push myself until I've been properly prepared. You can't rush greatness, you know.
Person1: What if I don't know what to say? What if I'm not good enough?
Person2: Have you ever tried to surprise them all, Malcolm? Sometimes it's better to take a risk and retire with a bang.

Person1: I've been thinking about the Ellingson tankers. Do you remember that news about the Da Vinci virus?
Person2: Yeah, wasn't that the same day the worm ended its run? What's on your mind?
Person1: It's just that I've been feeling really frustrated lately. Without that constant panic, I start thinking about myself and what I want. Today, I saw this couple on the bus and I felt a pang of jealousy.
Person2: You're saying you're frustrated because you're not getting what you want?
Person1: It's not just that. I feel like everything is moving in the wrong direction. I'm trying to hold on to something, but it's slipping away. I just wish I could feel like I'm in control again.
Person2: Maybe you're just trying to hold on too tight. Sometimes you need to let go and see where things take you.

Person1: Did you know he was planning to escape?
Person2: He didn't want me to visit him in prison.
Person1: Why not? Was he ashamed?
Person2: I think he was just tired of being called an old timer by the younger cons.
Person1: That's not all, is it? He must have had a plan.
Person2: We learned he'd found the immigration notaries in Liverpool and traced them to New York.
Person1: And then what? Did he contact you after he escaped?
Person2: He called me once, said he wished we could start over, live a normal life.
Person1: But you know that's not possible, not with his record.
Person2: I know. He's always been a dreamer, but his idea of a normal life is just a fantasy.

Person1: Answer me, are you sure you can make it to Texarkana and back in twenty-eight hours?
Person2: Legend has it that I've found the most efficient routes, and I've traced them to ensure we can make it on time.

Person1: I know a secret about your past, and I'm willing to share it with you.
Person2: What are you talking about? I don't believe you.
Person1: Let's get out of here, this place makes me sick. I'll tell you everything at the party tonight.
Person2: What party? You're not going to trick me into going somewhere I don't want to go.
Person1: I promise you, it'll be fun. And I'll reveal the truth about your past. You won't regret it.

Person1: We need to get out of here, now!
Person2: I'll take care of the back door. You two go ahead and find a safe exit.
Person1: Are you sure you can handle it alone?
Person2: I've got this. Just go! Someone will meet you at the gate and guide you to safety.

Person1: What makes you think I'd discuss that with you?
Person2: We're not crazy. We're "special". We need your help for a project.
Person1: What kind of project?
Person2: We're collecting people's stories about their first experiences. You know, like a time capsule.
Person1: And that's all?
Person2: That's all. We just want to learn from others.
Person1: Would anybody else see the story?
Person2: Absolutely not. They are for our private use only.
Person1: How do we start?
Person2: I turn on the recorder. You start talking.
Person1: And you ask questions, right?
Person2: Yes. We'll guide you through it.
Person1: How long will it take?
Person2: That depends on you. Some people have a lot to share, others not so much.
Person1: Can I see some of the other stories to get an idea of what --
Person2: Sorry, those are confidential. But we can give you an idea of what to expect.
Person1: Do I sit or stand?
Person2: Whichever you prefer. Make yourself comfortable.
Person1: I'd rather sit. Are you ready?
Person2: Just a moment.

Person1: I've seen some rough places in my time, but this one takes the cake.
Person2: You think it's that bad, huh? I've dealt with worse, like Skinny's temper. I told him to calm down, but he just wouldn't listen.

Person1: I'm thinking of quitting my job.
Person2: What job?
Person1: The one Andy got me. I don't think so, it's not for me.
Person2: He's got some messed up friends, you know that?
Person1: Yeah, I have to go now.
Person2: Wait, don't hang up on me. We need to talk about this.

Person1: I'm not certain what to expect from this trip.
Person2: We might visit some restaurants with dress codes. Would you like to know if crabs are in season?
Person1: Actually, I had a strange dream last night. I ate a guy.
Person2: That's interesting. How did you feel during the dream?
Person1: I don't know. I don't remember the details. But I'm looking forward to this trip.
Person2: Good. I think you'll enjoy it.

Person1: You know, if we had a sketch artist, we could get a composite drawing of the suspect.
Person2: What makes you think anyone would come forward to describe him? He's notorious for silencing witnesses.
Person1: Are you tellin' me nobody knows what he looks like? Come on, there must be someone who can give us a lead.
Person2: I've heard rumors, but nothing concrete. We'll have to rely on our own investigation.

Person1: Don't WORRY!!! You've GOT it!! Are you CRAZY?
Person2: The plot thickens. It appears that Alex has fallen for her art teacher.
Person1: Ooo, I'm sure Mr. Thompson will love that.
Person2: What's your plan of attack?
Person1: I think we should talk to Alex about it. She's a smart girl, she'll make the right decision.
Person2: But who will they turn to for help?

Person1: I'm telling you, I saw him at the party. Do you know him?
Person2: That's how I remembered it. But the truth is, I might have been mistaken. And if that's true, what would happen then?
Person1: You're saying you don't know him? I could've sworn...
Person2: That would complicate things. But I think you'll find he's coming to talk to you.
Person1: How would you know that? Did he tell you something?
Person2: Yes, he did. And I think you'll find he's being honest with you.

Person1: I didn't ask what the committee thinks, Rachel. What do you think?
Person2: Honestly, I think we're taking a huge risk by investing in this startup. The market is volatile, and we could lose everything.
Person1: That's exactly what I'd expect from someone who's been stuck in the corporate bubble for too long. You're afraid to take a chance, to be the "madman" who disrupts the status quo.
Person2: That's not fair, Alex. I'm just being cautious. And what's with the "madman" comment?
Person1: Never mind. Just give my best to the committee. Bless their souls.

Person1: I'll be okay.
Person2: Apparently you're not as confident as you thought you are.
Person1: What's waiting for us up there? Tell me.
Person2: Any vulnerability you sense, I'll exploit.

Person1: Dr. Lee, there is something I've been meaning to ask you for some time...
Person2: Yes, what's on your mind?
Person1: I'm feeling too good to argue with you, but that isn't what I meant - I meant you're being evasive. For instance, what were you doing at the conference the other day?

Person1: Of what? You're being really vague.
Person2: Oh, you know, for a minute I thought it was a prank, like when they cut a chicken's head off and it still runs around crazy.

Person1: I've had enough of these local farmers resisting our progress. We need to take drastic measures.
Person2: I agree, but we can't rely on the Army's presence anymore. They're moving on from Liberty.
Person1: That's exactly what I'm counting on. With the Army gone, we can fill the power void and assert our dominance.
Person2: But what about Mr. Pinkerton's injury? He's the one who usually handles these situations.
Person1: Pinkerton's injury is unfortunate, but it's also an opportunity for us to take charge. I want you to assemble a team of our detectives and prepare for action tonight.
Person2: And what's the plan, exactly? Are we going to intimidate them into submission?
Person1: Let's just say we'll be teaching them a lesson they won't soon forget. And as for you, I think you'd be wise to consider my offer to join my team. You have a certain... tenacity that I admire.

Person1: You're the one who's been planning this for years, aren't you?
Person2: Yes, that's the whole point. I've been searching for a place to belong, to find my true identity.
Person1: And you think you've found it here?
Person2: I do. Pack your things into black garbage bags. We're leaving this town behind, just like I've been trying to leave my past behind.
Person1: You're not like your father, are you?
Person2: I don't know. I've never really known him. But I know I don't want to be like him. I want to break free from his shadow.

Person1: I've always regretted the way I behaved that evening we went out, and, uh...I've, I just thought I'd tell you that because I really made a fool out of myself.
Person2: Chicken is a fool's game, captain. You should know better.
Person1: But you invited me aboard. You must have seen something in me.
Person2: Oh, yeah? I saw a chance to clear the deck, and your apology made a compelling argument.

Person1: I'm sorry... I don't like people touching my grandmother's recipe book. It's not important. It's a minor compulsion. I can deal with it if I want to.
Person2: Are we supposed to have friends or family saying words - singing or anything?
Person1: They come here. They all come here. How do they find me?
Person2: It's refreshing to see two young people not afraid of real commitment. Will you have a traditional ceremony?
Person1: Yes, Prince Mishkin, what can we do for you?

Person1: I'm telling you, we're not thinking this through! We're making a huge mistake!
Person2: Frida, I don't mean this as a criticism, but maybe you're just being overly cautious.
Person1: You're always so calm and collected. I wish I could be more like that.
Person2: Trust me, it's not all it's cracked up to be. Sometimes I wish I could be more spontaneous like you.
Person1: Spontaneous? You think I'm spontaneous? You're the one who's always grabbing onto new ideas and running with them!
Person2: That's not always a good thing, believe me. Sometimes it's better to take a step back and think things through.

Person1: Is someone there?
Person2: Then we will both die, Alex. I know that to trust you is treason against my own judgment. But not to trust you... is treason against my heart.

Person1: I love "Row, row, row your boat..." Do you know "Row, Row, Row, Row, Row Your Boat?"
Person2: You're being paranoid again, aren't you? You think everyone's out to get you.
Person1: No, I'm not! I just pick up on those kind of things. Like when we were at the record store, and that tall blond guy was looking at me funny and smiling...
Person2: Oh, come on! You're not going to start that conspiracy theory again, are you?
Person1: No, no, it's just... I think I have a good ear for these things. Like when Tom Christie said, "Didchoo eat?" Not "did you eat," but "didchoo eat?" Jew eat?
Person2: (laughs) You're something else, you know that? Alright, let's get out of here and get some fresh air. I'll start singing "Row, row, row your boat" with you.
Person1: (smiling) Okay, but you have to promise not to make fun of my singing.

Person1: I've noticed you've made some unconventional career choices. What drove you to pursue this path?
Person2: Are you for real? You think it's that unusual?
Person1: Yes, I do. You could have done many things, but you chose to do this. I find that fascinating. Can you tell me more about what led you to this decision?
Person2: It's hard to explain. I just feel like I don't fit in with most people's expectations.
Person1: I think I understand. Sometimes we make choices that don't make sense to others, but they're right for us. Would you like to talk more about what you're feeling?

Person1: You think --
Person2: This is another victory, my friends. What began with a spark shall be concluded with a flame.
Person1: Oh, you know, for a minute I thought it was a different story.
Person2: To finish last evening's delightful work, we need to focus on the present.

Person1: You're being reckless. Don't let him, Alex.
Person2: It's okay. I can handle it.
Person1: Handle it? Are you crazy? Let me help you.

Person1: You can't go yet. We've got so much to talk about...
Person2: You sure? I really need to get going.
Person1: Oh, I'm more than sure. Anything happens to this project and I can tell you right now you don't wanna be the one responsible.

Person1: I've been trying to make sense of this place, but it's like trying to read a map upside down.
Person2: The dead can wait. We need to focus on finding a way out of here.
Person1: But that's just it - I don't think we're supposed to be finding a way out. I think we're supposed to be doing something else.
Person2: Look, you guys know how it is. You just keep doing what it looks like you're supposed to, even if it seems crazy, and you hope to hell someone knows what's going on.
Person1: But what if no one knows what's going on? What if we're just making it up as we go along?
Person2: Then we'll just have to keep making it up until we figure it out.

Person1: I can smell the scent of acacia in this room. I can taste the tea so black it falls into my mouth.
Person2: What are you talking about? You're not even making sense.
Person1: You know what I'm talking about. You want me to believe something, but I don't.
Person2: I'm not trying to convince you of anything. You're just confused.
Person1: Then what am I? Tell me...
Person2: You're a patient who needs rest. That's all.
Person1: Better if I just show you.

Person1: You're really something, aren't you? Asking me to marry you out of the blue.
Person2: What can I say? I'm a romantic. I wear my heart on my sleeve. Size 9, by the way.
Person1: Size 9? What's that supposed to mean?
Person2: Nothing, just a silly joke. But seriously, I've been thinking about us, and I think we could make a great team.
Person1: A team? You make it sound like a business partnership. And what's with the sudden proposal? You're not trying to distract me from something, are you?
Person2: Distract you? No, of course not. I just think we have something special. But if you want to know the truth, I've been feeling a bit overwhelmed lately. The world is a complicated place, and sometimes I wish things could be simpler.
Person1: Simpler? You think getting married would simplify things? I think it would only complicate them further.

Person1: We have to make a decision about the Johnson case today.
Person2: The dead can wait. We need to focus on the living.
Person1: That's a crock. We can't just ignore the evidence. If we don't act, it'll get lost in the system.
Person2: I understand your concerns, but we have to prioritize. We can't let emotions cloud our judgment.
Person1: Emotions? You're the one who's being emotional. You're just trying to avoid taking responsibility.
Person2: That's not fair. I'm trying to be practical. We can't save everyone.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a done deal. The company's going public, and we're all going to be rich.
Person2: Let's get out of here, this office makes me sick. We have to celebrate tonight, it's my last night of freedom before I start my new role.
Person1: I know a place we could go... a private meeting with one of the investors. He's willing to give us a deal, but we have to be careful. Tight security, no loose talk.
Person2: What's going to make him do that? What's in it for him?
Person1: What he didn't get in the last round of funding. The exclusive rights to our new technology.
Person2: Good for us. I'll bring my team, we'll make it happen.

Person1: I've been thinking, we should make a splash on our maiden voyage. What do you say, Captain?
Person2: I'm not sure, I prefer to focus on safety and efficiency.
Person1: Ah, come on! It'll be a heartfelt gesture, straight from my thoughts. We can surprise them all and make headlines!
Person2: I understand your enthusiasm, but I'd rather not push the engines too hard just yet.
Person1: Fine, but I'll be keeping a close eye on you. Don't think you can slack off and get away with it!

Person1: I've been thinking about our family's legacy.
Person2: What do you mean? You want to settle a new colony or something?
Person1: Ha! No, nothing that grand. I just feel like I need some experience in life to make responsible decisions.
Person2: Experience? You mean like our ancestors who fought at Trafalgar?
Person1: Exactly! I want to make them proud. But it's not just about the past; it's about creating a better future for ourselves.
Person2: I see what you mean. Maybe we can start by making some changes around here.

Person1: Answer me.
Person2: Hi, I'm Rachel.
Person1: I just wanted you to know, wherever you're going or whatever you're doing right now, I want you to know that I'm glad I ran into you.
Person2: Really?
Person1: Yeah. We learned a lot about each other's interests in that art class.
Person2: So what do I do then?

Person1: You're quite the legend, aren't you? King of the road, and all that.
Person2: Indeed we were, speaking of my father and his influence on me.
Person1: I can make it to Texarkana and back in twenty-eight hours, but that's not the point.
Person2: The point is, I need to understand him, and myself, better.
Person1: Freud would say you need to see the truth and speak it.
Person2: But it's not that simple. This wine is making me woozy, and I'm afraid I'm not thinking clearly.
Person1: You need to eat, and then we can talk more about your father.

Person1: I think it's better if we find this man before he finds us again. You know, like who you were before the tailspin. Do you remember that guy? People love that guy.
Person2: Oh yeah? How exciting. What's it called?
Person1: Your novel, I mean. It's coming out in the fall, right? Don't sabotage me. If you want to be a lightweight, that's your call.
Person2: Aye-aye, captain. But I'm not drinking any Merlot! If anyone orders Merlot, I'm leaving.
Person1: Relax, okay? No Merlot. Did you bring your Xanax? We're going to hit Poppa Joe tonight, right in the comfort of his own home. Then we move on to New York.

Person1: I need to know what happened. You were there, weren't you?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Wait, don't go yet. I thought we were going to talk about this.
Person2: I don't think that's a good idea.
Person1: Don't hang up on me. I need answers.
Person2: I'm not going anywhere. I just don't know what you want me to say.
Person1: Just tell me the truth. You were her doctor, weren't you?
Person2: Yes.

Person1: I'm telling you, I'm too successful. I can't think of anything but my next business venture. That's the trouble with me.
Person2: Well, Mr. Johnson, I'm not here to judge your priorities. Is this your proposal for the new project?
Person1: You know I wrote it myself. I'm proud of what I've accomplished.
Person2: Very well. I'll review it carefully and get back to you soon.

Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: You don't drink "booze".
Person1: You do. And I think you're trying to distract me from the real issue. Strength is what Westerburg needs, not some fake sense of togetherness.
Person2: Eddie, if I wanted to make love with you again, I'd do it sober. But that's not what this is about. I had a great chat with Ms. Dumptruck, and I realized that everyone has a story to tell. Would you care to see the canoeing shots?

Person1: You're losing it, Captain. We're off course.
Person2: Are you kidding? I think the navigation system is malfunctioning - it's leading us astray.

Person1: I'm serious. Did you notice anything strange before she started acting out?
Person2: Strength. This school needs a leader. Someone who can handle the pressure.
Person1: I'm not talking about the school, I'm talking about Emily. She's been having nightmares.
Person2: Oh, Emily specializes in drama. I've spent thousands on tutors.
Person1: I'm trying to help her. There are other kids involved, it's not just Emily.
Person2: I'm sorry to hear that, but you're the expert on this, not me. If I had any insights, believe me, I'd share them with you.
Person1: I'll need to take her things. Do you have a suitcase packed?
Person2: The maid packed a bag. It's upstairs, first door on the left.

Person1: I'm a whiskey man myself. We don't have much trouble from drugs where I come from...
Person2: Look, we're all tired. None of us had any sleep since Friday night. That's the only reason you're not seeing the signs.
Person1: Signs of what?
Person2: Of the trouble that's been brewing. You'll wake up one morning and find it's already here.
Person1: I don't think so. Not down in my parts.

Person1: I don't want to go.
Person2: Remember, I'm not the one who chose this.
Person1: What does that mean?
Person2: It means you're the one who's hesitant.

Person1: I'm trying to remember, Grandma, but it's all so foggy. Do you think it will all come back to me now that I'm home?
Person2: Don't worry about it, child. You're safe now. But I have to ask, what's with the strange message you sent me? You said something about Sailor and Lula heading west, and I don't know what to make of it.
Person1: Oh, that? I must have been confused. I don't even remember sending it. But I do remember that awful plum pudding Cook made for Christmas dinner. We hid it in our pockets so we wouldn't hurt her feelings!
Person2: (laughs) Well, it's good to see your sense of humor is back. But seriously, we need to talk about what's going on. You're not in any trouble, are you?

Person1: I've never seen this place before. Is it new?
Person2: It's been here for years. You just haven't noticed it.
Person1: That's because I've never seen any of these people before.
Person2: Take another look at that woman over there.
Person1: I don't know her. But she looks familiar.
Person2: And if I told you she's been trying to get in touch with you, would that surprise you?
Person1: Yes, I suppose so. What's she like?
Person2: You can't imagine. She wears her confidence like the latest model by Schiaparelli.
Person1: You've met her?
Person2: No, but I've heard a lot about her. She's the most incredible creature I've ever heard of.
Person1: What does she want from me?
Person2: That's what I'm trying to figure out. But I think she's going to change everything.

Person1: I've got to get some matches. My lighter's out of fuel.
Person2: You have what I asked for?
Person1: Yeah, I do. But before we proceed, can I ask you something?
Person2: What is it?
Person1: How do you always manage to stay so calm in these situations?
Person2: It's just my nature, I suppose. Now, pack the item into black garbage bags.
Person1: Okay, but can I ask, what's the purpose of this whole operation?
Person2: Let's just say it's for a good cause. You have twenty-five minutes left.
Person1: Alright, alright. But can I at least ask, what's the story behind this Fang Shan Restaurant in China Town?
Person2: It's just a convenient location. Don't worry about it.

Person1: I'm really sorry about what happened. I know I messed up.
Person2: It would be a pity to squander such a strong personality. What were you thinking?
Person1: Honestly, I wasn't thinking. I was being reckless and stupid. I promise it won't happen again.
Person2: I appreciate your honesty. Let's move forward from this.

Person1: I'm impressed, Alex. I wouldn't have thought you'd get Gino Marzzone to agree to meet at your place.
Person2: Yeah, makes two of us. What's the big deal about him coming over, anyway?
Person1: Caesar's been nervous, cleaning the apartment nonstop. I think he wants to make a good impression.
Person2: That's understandable. So, what's the plan for tonight?

Person1: Oh, I should call Rachel. 
Person2: Maybe. Then it could all come out, sooner or later.

Person1: You're driving me crazy with that music. Switch to another station, huh?
Person2: I'm not trying to hide anything, but I'd rather not talk about it. You'll have to try and figure it out without me.
Person1: What's going on? You're being really secretive.
Person2: Better if I just show you. But trust me, it's not what you think.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's not just a coincidence.
Person2: You're talking crazy!
Person1: My sister always says I'm too sensitive.
Person2: Maybe she's just shy around you.
Person1: I wish I could be more like her, carefree and confident.
Person2: You have your own strengths, don't compare yourself to others.

Person1: Is someone there?
Person2: We know what makes a community strong, don't we? We know that no individual can stand alone.
Person1: Not that one. Or that one.
Person2: I'm not talking about individuals, I'm talking about the collective.

Person1: How did you know I was struggling to meet the deadline?
Person2: Don't be over-dramatic, it's just a project. What kind of disaster could we help bring about if we're a little late?
Person1: I saw you glance at the clock when our boss walked in. I figured you weren't checking the time for a particularly rare astronomical event, and the rest was easy.
Person2: But how did you know I would have the presence of mind to offer my help when I did?
Person1: Because that's what I would have done...

Person1: I love "Row, row, row your boat..." Do you know the song?
Person2: Yeah, I do. But I did a bad thing, and I need your help.
Person1: What's going on? What did you do?
Person2: I messed up, man. I was with this girl, and things got out of hand. I didn't mean to hurt her.
Person1: What happened? Did you get into a fight or something?
Person2: Worse than that. I lost control, and I... I hit her. I don't know what came over me.
Person1: Oh no, is she okay? Did you call for help?
Person2: I don't know, man. I just freaked out and left. I don't know what to do.
Person1: We need to go back and check on her. Come on, let's go.

Person1: What began with the lash shall be concluded with a caress.
Person2: Tell me why I miss him.
Person1: He's gone, isn't he?
Person2: That's right. He's gone. Tell me why.
Person1: To finish last evening's delightful work.
Person2: How should I...?

Person1: I've been investigating this case for months.  I know what I saw that day - a guy shooting from behind that fence.
Person2: That's impossible.  You must have heard echoes.  We have three bullets and three shots which came from the rooftop and that's all we're willing to say.
Person1: I'm not buying it.  I saw it with my own eyes.  And what about the drop car?  I think it's connected to the whole thing.
Person2: Now, now, let's not get ahead of ourselves.  I want you to focus on the rooftop, okay?  We'll take care of the rest.
Person1: I don't trust you.  You're trying to spin this whole thing.  I'm going to get to the bottom of it, no matter what.
Person2: I'm just trying to help you, but you're not making it easy.  Fine, do it your way.  But don't say I didn't warn you.

Person1: I'm getting a bit anxious about this meeting. Would you mind walking with me to the conference room?
Person2: Jessie, I've scouted the area. So far, no signs of any issues. Looks like we're clear.

Person1: I want to try it!
Person2: There is a way.
Person1: But it's impossible. You always go for things that are too extreme.
Person2: Why? You're the one who's always pushing limits.
Person1: No, it wouldn't work, you couldn't, it's too... I knew it! You're just trying to prove something.
Person2: Forget I mentioned it.

Person1: It's what they want you to see. I'm telling you, honesty is always the best policy.
Person2: Okay. Thank you, my friend. I appreciate your advice.
Person1: Yes, I've learned that the hard way. Are you sure you want to take my word for it?

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a different kind of deal. You're not going to find a better opportunity.
Person2: I just hate to see you passing up a chance like this. It makes me want to scream, frankly. You're letting your fears hold you back.
Person1: You positive I'm making a mistake?
Person2: I'm positive you're not thinking clearly.

Person1: You're going to get yourself killed, you know that?
Person2: I'm putting him on the plane to Fairbanks, eleven tomorrow.
Person1: What do you want from me? You're not even making sense.
Person2: You study world events, don't you? That's good for someone your age.
Person1: Yeah, I study world events. And I know when someone's trying to distract me. What's going on?

Person1: I know a secret about this place that will make you sick.
Person2: What is it?
Person1: Because it drove my friend Jessica away - deliberately - coldly!
Person2: That's not true! You're just trying to get out of staying here tonight.
Person1: I promise you, it's true. If I take you to see the evidence, will you believe me?

Person1: Captain, we're making excellent time. The press will marvel at our speed.
Person2: Eve, listen carefully. I've been thinking, and I'm not sure we're ready for the maiden voyage.
Person1: What do you mean? We've prepared for months.
Person2: I know, but I prefer not to push the engines until they've been properly run in. It's not just about making headlines.
Person1: But think of the glory! We could retire with a bang, eh?
Person2: I'd rather prioritize safety over glory.

Person1: You look familiar. Hey, Rachel.
Person2: Hey, Ethan. I heard some guy got his phone stolen earlier today.
Person1: Really? That's crazy. I just met my friend Alex here.
Person2: Oh, nice to meet you, Alex. I'm Rachel. You better be careful, Ethan. I heard the thief is still around.
Person1: Thanks for the warning. By the way, I love your scarf.
Person2: Thanks, I just got it. We have a marketing class next, right?
Person1: Yeah, that's right. I'm looking forward to it.

Person1: I'm so nervous about this audition. I feel like I'm going to mess up.
Person2: Hey, we all make mistakes. It's part of the learning process. You're talented, just be yourself.
Person1: You're right. I just want to make a good impression. I've seen your work, by the way. You're a great actor.
Person2: Thanks. I've had my share of mistakes too. But remember, nobody is perfect. We'll get through this together.
Person1: Thanks for the reassurance. You're a great coach.

Person1: I've never known him to say those words before. He's always been honest with me.
Person2: Well, then there's only one thing to do. You need experience in life to make a responsible decision.
Person1: But what does that have to do with him? He's not one to sugarcoat the truth.
Person2: Exactly. And that's why I think you should take his words seriously.

Person1: You're pushing your luck, friend. Smart talk, but reckless.
Person2: Don't. 
Person1: Anybody ever call you out like that before?
Person2: No.
Person1: Positive?
Person2: Yes. Guess there's no way I'll ever know for sure.

Person1: But I only came to return the book.
Person2: Know what? You're not like the others who come to this library.
Person1: What do you mean?
Person2: I saw you glance at the shelf when I nodded my head. I figured you weren't looking for a particularly rare novel, and the rest was easy.
Person1: But how did you know I would have the courage to speak up when I did?
Person2: Because that's what I would have done... Julia Farren, the famous author, would have done the same.

Person1: You're losing it, Alex. 
Person2: What are you doing?! Get on with your misery!
Person1: Him? I don't know... He can be nice... sometimes.
Person2: You're crazy. Those guys love me.
Person1: What do you mean?! I could leave him if I wanted to!
Person2: You're just jealous, that's all.

Person1: I've got to get some matches. My cigarette.
Person2: Listen, I'm supposed to take Alex to the concert tonight. They're really going to be upset if I don't.
Person1: Maybe Alex will come with us. If I tell them how important it is to me, I don't think they'll mind. Do you?
Person2: I didn't mean that in any pejorative way. You think it's strange that I'm worried about Alex?
Person1: I guess it is a little odd. So, how's everything with you?
Person2: It's not bad. I've been feeling a bit anxious about this concert, to be honest.
Person1: Oh, I see. Well, I mean it's not everybody that can get tickets to a sold-out show.
Person2: Ha! Yeah, I guess I'm just lucky.

Person1: I'm not playing with you, these noises are looking to get you spooked.
Person2: Yes, Mr. Jenkins, it was. I... I heard strange creaks in the night.
Person1: Strange creaks, Emily? Now stop behaving as if you're some kind of expert. Those creaks had a reason last night, and it wasn't the house settling.

Person1: Honestly, Alex. Do you actually think I would forget to invite you to the party?
Person2: Look, we're all tired. None of us had any sleep since Friday night...
Person1: That's the only reason I'm being so lenient. Otherwise, I'd be furious.
Person2: I don't know, Rachel. I don't seem to remember you actually asking me if you could borrow my car without filling up the gas tank.
Person1: Sometimes we have to improvise. Besides, I thought we were friends.
Person2: Think, Rachel. Does Emily have any friends. I mean, besides you and... me?
Person1: Emily? My Emily? What's happened?
Person2: Nothing, she's just been sort of, I don't know... overwhelmed.
Person1: Overwhelmed? By who? The new project at work?
Person2: Yeah, that's it. The project. Only one problem. I don't know how to help her.
Person1: Ah. Wait a minute. Maybe we can brainstorm together.

Person1: I don't want to go.
Person2: You're really terrific, you know what I mean?
Person1: Wrong. I'm not going anywhere with you.
Person2: Oh, come on. It'll be fun. Let's go on a ride.
Person1: I know what you're trying to do, and it's not going to work.

Person1: I'm in a cleaning mood. I wish you would have at least let me do the dishes. It's not going to be that easy getting all that dried-on food off my nice plates.
Person2: Yeah, yeah. Okay. Give me the roast and watch your step. I'll come back for the vacuum.
Person1: Cheese is particularly troublesome. And I got your message about the party, by the way.
Person2: Oh, much worse. But not as bad as that Mexican Jumping Bean dip. You remember that?
Person1: My very best to the host. Bless their soul.

Person1: Hey, what's up? You seem a bit down.
Person2: Yeah, I don't know... He can be nice... sometimes.
Person1: You know, my father always says that everything is a miracle. Everything. Until recently, I wasn't sure what he meant by that.
Person2: Yeah? No kidding. Listen, you still want to grab coffee tonight?
Person1: I certainly do! But you know, this business of finding happiness  it's kind of ridiculous, don't you think?
Person2: What do you mean?! I could find happiness if I wanted to!
Person1: Would you do it just because you're my friend? My very best friend.
Person2: Well...yeah. Okay.

Person1: I'm telling you, I don't remember anything. It's like my mind is a complete blank.
Person2: That's strange. You're usually so meticulous. Did you find what I asked for?
Person1: Yes, I did. But I'm still trying to piece together what happened.
Person2: Well, let's focus on the task at hand then. We can discuss the details later.

Person1: You know, if you focus on your own goals, you'll be happier in the long run.
Person2: Yeah, I guess you're right. I've been trying to impress this guy, but it's not worth it.
Person1: Exactly! You do you, and don't let anyone else dictate your self-worth. By the way, have you thought about what you want to do with your life?
Person2: Honestly, no. I've been so caught up in trying to please others that I haven't thought about what I really want.
Person1: Well, take some time to reflect on that. And remember, you're in control of your own life. Don't let anyone else steer the wheel.

Person1: I'm sorry about getting on your case earlier. I just see you getting sucked in deeper and deeper, and I -- anyway. I'm sorry.
Person2: Yes, sir. I got in the cab and it was layin' there on the floor.
Person1: What were you doing in that cab? Were you going somewhere important?
Person2: I don't remember. Not so very far-- I think I was just trying to get away from something.

Person1: Oh, you know, for a minute I thought it was a great day...
Person2: Yeah, what happened?
Person1: So I was driving to work today, and some bozo in a Toyota cut me off...
Person2: That's frustrating...
Person1: But then I remembered I had a meeting at 10 am, and I didn't want to be late, so I just let it go.
Person2: Good for you, taking the high road!
Person1: Yeah, I felt like I was Kevin Costner in THE POSTMAN, you know, bringing hope to the world one courteous driving decision at a time.
Person2: (laughs) That's a unique reference!

Person1: I'm so anxious for you to meet our new team leader.
Person2: What are you sorry for?
Person1: I don't know. For the project's delay, I guess. I just thought, you know, we'd celebrate like we used to.
Person2: I want to go back to the old plan.
Person1: You can't.

Person1: I really like you, Alex. If we weren't in this situation...
Person2: I know what you mean. But I'm trying to move on from my past. I'd hoped I was finished with all that.
Person1: You were a lot of help with the project. Your skills are bad-ass.
Person2: Thanks, but it's not something I'm proud of. Every friend I knew in the industry is struggling. It's like they're there to be taken advantage of.
Person1: Mind if I ask you something? Why'd you put up with it for someone else's gain?
Person2: I don't know... I guess I was trying to make a difference. But it's hard when you feel like you're not being heard.

Person1: So, it's great...seems like...I don't know you've got all the important stuff in there.
Person2: Waitaminit, I got it! We could ask the event organizers if they have any spare tickets. What do you think?
Person1: Brilliance, sheer brilliance. I'm impressed by your creative problem-solving skills.

Person1: I need you to trust me on this. Get in, now!
Person2: But I'm scared. You're always so quick to take risks without thinking them through. It's not about me not trusting you, it's about being cautious.
Person1: I understand that, but sometimes you need to have faith in me. I'm trying to protect us, not abandon you.
Person2: I know that, but can't we find a way to face this together, as a team?

Person1: I'm not sure this is a good idea, are you prepared for the consequences?
Person2: Don't be ridiculous, I've thought this through. These are my creations, and I'm proud of them.

Person1: You're a genius, Mom - a genius!
Person2: Grateful?! It's all there in the three notebooks. Read them in order. If you don't want to, I suppose that's okay too.
Person1: That's it! I never stopped loving your father. He was a very good man.
Person2: Good! Good! Stay close to him, and you can get an exclusive story out of him every day for a month.
Person1: He brought out something in me no one had ever brought out before, or since. He made me feel like a woman in a way few women, maybe more, ever experience...
Person2: Oh, no. No. Our deal was for a month's vacation - with pay.

Person1: I'm telling you, I saw you at my high school reunion.
Person2: Don't be over-dramatic, I've never been to your reunion. What makes you think that?
Person1: You know about the old principal, don't you? You told me about him.
Person2: No, I didn't. You must have told me.

Person1: Sophia, are you alright? You seem a bit shaken.
Person2: I want to explore the botanical garden here. Meet me at the highest point from where you are. I've heard it has a lovely view.
Person1: Copy. Sophia, go to the top of the hill.
Person2: I'm told the French countryside is breathtaking. I know nothing more interesting than a lovely landscape.
Person1: I'm sure you'll enjoy the scenery. Will you also allow me to play the harp? It's an instrument I'm very fond of.
Person2: Of course, my dear. You may have anything you wish.

Person1: What's your story? 
Person2: I used to live in a state hospital. 
Person1: Why were you there? 
Person2: I wasn't right in the head, they said. 
Person1: Now, don't get alarmed. These are just some questions I need to ask. 
Person2: Like what? 
Person1: Will you trust me? 
Person2: I reckon I feel all right. 
Person1: You don't seem like someone with a troubled past. 
Person2: I've been carrying these books around with me. 
Person1: What are they? 
Person2: Different ones. One's the Bible. One's a book on Christmas. 
Person1: How come you're carrying them around? 
Person2: Ain't got nowhere to set them down.

Person1: I've been thinking about your work for a while. It's what they want you to see, right?
Person2: Yeah, I guess so. What do you think about it?
Person1: Honestly, I think it's admirable. You've got a certain style that's hard to find. I've been on a hot streak myself, but there's definitely things I could learn from you.
Person2: Like what?
Person1: Well, I've been trying to get into this new project, but I'm not sure if I'm doing it right. Would you be willing to take a look and give me some feedback?
Person2: I'd be happy to help. But first, do you want to grab some lunch and talk about it?
Person1: Sounds good to me. I know this great place nearby.

Person1: So, I heard you had a bit of a restless night. What was going on?
Person2: Yeah, I did. I kept hearing strange noises and couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching me.
Person1: Watching you? That's weird. I had a strange encounter myself last night. I met someone at the worker bar who was looking for fun and adventure.
Person2: Oh? What happened?
Person1: Well, we hit it off, and I think we might have gotten into a bit of trouble. But hey, that's what makes life interesting, right?
Person2: I suppose so. But I'm still trying to figure out what was going on in my room last night.
Person1: Maybe it was just the house settling. Or maybe it was something more. Who knows?

Person1: I know a great spot we could check out tonight.
Person2: What's the point? You're just trying to distract me from what's really going on.
Person1: Don't be ridiculous. I'm trying to help you take your mind off things.
Person2: I don't believe you. You're hiding something.
Person1: Fine, don't trust me. But I'm telling you, this place is going to be a blast.

Person1: Oh, Captain!
Person2: I don't think so.
Person1: You don't. Think so.
Person2: We were real careful, but I don't remember him hitting anything, anywhere.
Person1: Maybe you can suggest something.
Person2: He was heavy, but we were careful.

Person1: You're such a talented artist. I've seen your work around town.
Person2: Thanks, I've been trying to make a name for myself. But I think I might have made a mistake this time.
Person1: That's your funeral. We've got a lot riding on this project.
Person2: I know, I know. I lost my head completely! I don't know what came over me.

Person1: What's wrong?
Person2: I need your help with something. Yes or no.
Person1: What do you think? Of course yes! What's involved?
Person2: I'll explain everything when you get to my place. Please come over.
Person1: I'll be right there. But can I ask, is everything okay?
Person2: Just hurry, please.

Person1: Oh, I've got to get some fresh air. This room is stifling.
Person2: I'm Lorl, sir. I'm a botanist. I was asked to come here and offer my services to you.
Person1: What? Who asked you to do that?
Person2: A great admirer of yours who wishes to remain anonymous. They'll be paying for my services.
Person1: That's quite strange. What makes you think I need a botanist?
Person2: Well, I've heard you're quite the talented composer. I've developed a new species of flower that I think would inspire you.
Person1: (laughs) I suppose it couldn't hurt to have some inspiration. But tell me, how does this flower of yours work?
Person2: It has a unique property that allows it to change color based on the surrounding environment. I think it could be quite fascinating for your music.
Person1: That does sound intriguing. But I have to ask, what's in it for you?
Person2: Just the opportunity to work with a genius like yourself, sir.

Person1: You can't do that, Alex.
Person2: Come on, don't you want to see where the party's at? It's going to be a one-of-a-kind experience, and we have to check it out.
Person1: No, I'm not going. You're being reckless, and I'm not going to let you get us into trouble.
Person2: You're sleepin', man. You're missing out on the fun.

Person1: I've tried to stay open to voices of the people, to remain honest to myself. Maybe one day you shall find yourself in a similar position...
Person2: I like to do it. I enjoy it. Take your aesthete's taste to purer things. But do you think that's possible, to truly hear the voices of the people?
Person1: Ah, yes, it's a delicate balance. The temptations are strong, but I've tried not to misuse my power. I've been labeled a 'kingmaker' by many, but I've stayed true to myself.
Person2: And what of those who haven't? What of those who let the power consume them?
Person1: Well, that's a danger, isn't it? When one is in a position of eminence, he must be mindful of his actions. It's a heavy responsibility, but someone has to carry it.

Person1: Are you ready to get started?
Person2: Yes, but I'm worried about the risks involved. What's the worst that could happen?
Person1: I understand your concerns, but sometimes you have to take a leap of faith. Once you commit to this, you'll realize that the benefits far outweigh the risks.
Person2: That sounds like a pretty big gamble. Can you explain it in simpler terms?
Person1: Think of it like this: if we can harness the power of this technology, we could change the world. But if we don't take the chance, we'll never know what could've been.

Person1: I really like you, Rachel.
Person2: I really like you too, Alex. But I think we should focus on this project instead of getting distracted.
Person1: So, what do they think -- we're not professionals --
Person2: I know, but even if we meet the deadline, everybody in the company knows what we're doing because... we're working together.
Person1: Don't be a good team player, or I'll send you a message straight from my thoughts. You know what that means?
Person2: Yes, I understand. But let's not threaten each other, okay? We're in this together.

Person1: You're so smart and fun! I'm really enjoying our time together.
Person2: I got your message... But I'm not sure I'm ready for this level of commitment.
Person1: You're like the most amazing person I've ever met. You rock my world.
Person2: No, I mean, I think we should slow down and get to know each other better.

Person1: What are you doing?!
Person2: You mean I can have the room?
Person1: Him? I don't know... He can be nice... sometimes.
Person2: It's OK. There's no problem.
Person1: What do you mean?! I could leave him if I wanted to!
Person2: Well, that's what I said, isn't it?

Person1: So, I've heard a rumor going around, maybe you've heard it.
Person2: You know a lot about art, I guess. I've just started a new company, and I'm looking for someone with your expertise to help with the design.
Person1: That sounds interesting. What kind of company is it?
Person2: It's a startup focused on sustainable art supplies. I think you'd be a great fit. Don't let yourself down, and let's discuss the details.

Person1: What the heck is she doing?! She was supposed to be here three hours ago!
Person2: No thanks.
Person1: What do you mean, no thanks? Didn't you hear me? She's not here!
Person2: I don't want to get involved in this. You're clearly upset.
Person1: Upset? I'm furious! She was supposed to meet me here and now she's nowhere to be found.
Person2: Maybe she's on a ride or something.
Person1: A ride? What are you talking about? This is serious.
Person2: I'm just trying to help. Maybe she's with Josh or someone else.
Person1: Josh? Why would she be with Josh? You know something, don't you?
Person2: No, I don't know anything. I'm just trying to calm you down.
Person1: Well, it's not working. I need to find her and talk to her.

Person1: Oh, you know, for a minute I thought it was... 
Person2: Wait, I want to explain.

Person1: I've been searching for a place to belong for a long time.
Person2: What happened? You used to love it here.
Person1: I did, but it's been a mysterious world for me! I think I've found what I'm looking for, though. I think you're it.
Person2: Trust me, you won't find it here. But I can show you what's truly important.
Person1: What's that?
Person2: Someone to share it with.

Person1: Congratulations, Emma! I heard you finally got the grant for your art project.
Person2: Thank you! I'm thrilled. But I have to ask, do you have any further questions about my proposal?
Person1: No, no further questions. I think you've covered everything. By the way, would you like to discuss your project at the Fountain Street Gallery on Tuesday night? I'd love to attend and offer some feedback.

Person1: You're not thinking about what you're doing, and you'll end up getting hurt. Let me help you with that.
Person2: I can handle it myself, thank you. Besides, I need you to go with Rose to the doctor's appointment. She's not feeling well.
Person1: Alright, alright. But remember, never let them see you sweat. You do that, that's half the battle.
Person2: What do you mean by that? You're not making any sense.
Person1: I mean, when life gets tough, you gotta keep your cool. Like I always say, "Haven't I always told you, we're all entertainers?" We've got to make the best of it.
Person2: I suppose you're right. But sometimes I wish things could be simpler.

Person1: I've waited a long time for this chance to get out of here. If I have to, I'll go alone.
Person2: Hey, wouldn't your friends like to get in on this too?
Person1: Do you mean to tell me you want to leave with me? I thought you were happy here.
Person2: Well, that's out. Either it's all of us or nothing. Now will you help me convince the others before I change my mind about the whole thing!
Person1: I bribed the porters, you know. I'd do anything to get out of this place.
Person2: I thought the porters had instructions not to take anyone. Who pays any attention to them, anyway?
Person1: Exactly! They only care about how much gold they'll get. Well, I gave them more gold. I've been planning this for a year.
Person2: Look, I want to scoop this story. Will you let me come with you?
Person1: You want to write about our escape? I suppose it's okay. Just don't make me look like an old woman, okay?

Person1: How long have you been experiencing this?
