Person2: Honestly, I'm not sure. It feels like it's been going on forever, but at the same time, it's hard to keep track.
Person1: You don't remember?
Person2: I'm trying, but my mind is a blur. Can we just focus on finding a solution instead of dwelling on the past?

Person1: I said I'd help if a friend needed it. Let's just go to the party and have some fun.
Person2: Nothing matters, anyway. What's the point of celebrating?
Person1: All right, let's just go then. It's not like it's going to make a difference.

Person1: We're a little disappointed in you -- gratitude-wise.
Person2: Oh, I'm very grateful. But, to be honest, I'm not sure if it's worth the long-distance hassle.
Person1: What do you mean? We both have cars.
Person2: Yeah, but it's not just about the distance. It's about the right time, the right place, the right moment.
Person1: You're not thinking about having sex, are you?
Person2: No, no, nothing like that. I just mean that sometimes you have to prioritize what's important.
Person1: And what's important to you right now?
Person2: Figuring out this physics write-up, for starters.

Person1: I know I'm strange, but in my own way, I feel a connection with you. My future is with you, Sophia.
Person2: You might want to take a step back and reevaluate your feelings.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this.
Person2: Get used to it. You're in a very tenuous position.
Person1: What do you think? Of course, I'll do it! What's involved?
Person2: You'll be contacted with the assignment. Just remember, you must appear to live your life normally, conveying nothing.
Person1: I think I can do that. But what if I mess up?
Person2: You won't. You'll be fine. Just think carefully about your actions.

Person1: I already know the way... and it's not like I have a job I have to rush home for.
Person2: What?! You're really going to do this on your own?
Person1: When you're ready to take control, to be independent and self-sufficient, you will. Until then...
Person2: Between you and me, I could use the time alone.

Person1: I've got to capture this moment. You're radiant.
Person2: What's going on? You're being mysterious again.
Person1: There's something I need you to do. I'll tell you when it's time.
Person2: You're not even making sense. You're always so cryptic.
Person1: Your eyes sparkle like diamonds. I want to freeze this instant.
Person2: Stop flattering me and tell me what's really going on.
Person1: Trust me, it's for your own good. You'll see.
Person2: I don't know if I can trust you anymore.

Person1: So, I'm tired. Tonight, we're celebrating. Come to bed, now.
Person2: What are you talking about? You're not usually this carefree.
Person1: I get what I want, always, don't I? And what I want is to have some fun, adventure, trouble.
Person2: You're not looking for trouble, are you? You're just trying to distract yourself from something.
Person1: Maybe. But I do have something of yours...you left it at the party that night.

Person1: "You're not thinking of giving up, are you?"
Person2: "There are times... I wish I could just walk away. But there are times that I feel compelled to see it through..." "I've -- if you asked me if I would do it again or if it's -- do I think it's worth it. Yeah. I think it's worth it."
Person1: "I just want to rule out some possibilities. Will you trust me?"
Person2: "Like what possibilities? You're not telling me everything, are you?"

Person1: I'm not sure I want to do this. Are you sure you want to do this?
Person2: Yes, I've thought of three reasons why it's necessary. If we talk about it, we don't have to do it.
Person1: That's not it. You're trying to make it all about the end result and nothing else.
Person2: Maybe. But it's what they want you to see. This is the way in, isn't it?

Person1: What's that?
Person2: I bet you're curious. You always go for the mysterious type.
Person1: What are you talking about? You're being cryptic again.
Person2: Oh, I thought you would know. Good night, old friend.

Person1: Are you sure you want to do this?
Person2: Well, the whole gamut. I'm old enough to know the facts of life and all. Some advice, because there's things happening that I'm probably not prepared for.
Person1: It's what they want you to see. But not everything is as it seems.
Person2: For example, what's the best way to handle... certain situations?
Person1: Just be honest with yourself and others. And don't waste resources, like water and electricity.

Person1: Well, then there's only one thing to do.
Person2: What's that?
Person1: We'll start with your most recent memories and go backwards. I want to understand what makes you tick.
Person2: Is there any sort of risk involved?
Person1: Nothing you'll miss. It's like a night of heavy drinking, but for your memories.
Person2: Wait, what do you mean?

Person1: Are you playing tricks on me?
Person2: Weir is dead.
Person1: Then who the heck are you?
Person2: I'm someone who knows what you're capable of, Miller.

Person1: I'm supposed to perform the ceremony, but I've forgotten what church.
Person2: I like to help people in need. Take you to purer things. Guide you swiftly if you will, but do it!
Person1: Wait, who is this? You're not from around here, are you?
Person2: I'm more of a... facilitator. I can help you find the church, Reverend.
Person1: Ah, Reverend Smith. Yes, that's me. I'm Dr. Smith's brother. I just got in from Portland.
Person2: Well, Reverend, I'm sure it's not too late. The wedding might still be on. Let me help you find the church.

Person1: We're all tired. None of us had any sleep since Friday night...
Person2: I think it's better if we find this man before he finds us again.
Person1: What makes you say that? Did you see something?
Person2: Well, the light caught the side of his face for a second. And it looked like he had a gray beard, maybe... late fifties, early sixties.
Person1: That's the only reason you're alive... You're telling me it was one guy with a gray beard, maybe late fifties, early sixties?
Person2: Be careful. We'll get through this together.

Person1: I'm not playing with you, these people are looking to get you caught.
Person2: I never thought I'd say this, but I'm glad you warned me.
Person1: Actually, I could have done it much more easily without you, but for whatever reason, I'm glad I did.
Person2: Understood - you realize now you could never have done it without me.

Person1: I've got everything I need, Rachel. No one will ever suspect me.
Person2: Come on, Alex, don't you want to see where this leads? It's like a rare opportunity, and we have to explore it...
Person1: Forget it. I'm not falling for that.

Person1: I've got to get some drinks.  I'm parched.
Person2: I'd appreciate it if you didn't wear that dark blue suit.  I want you to wear something more festive.
Person1: Now, I'm not going to wear a bright orange tuxedo, I can tell you that.
Person2: Cute.  Let's talk about your molecular structure.  Is it true you have a lighter density under Earth's gravitational force?
Person1: Oh, I don't know about that.  But I do know I can't fly.
Person2: That's okay.  I'm sure you have other talents.  What about your X-Ray vision?  Can you really see through anything?
Person1: Ha!  No, I don't have X-Ray vision.  But I do have a good sense of humor.
Person2: That's great.  I think we're going to get along just fine.

Person1: You're a killer, Alex. Ah!
Person2: I'm such a loser.
Person1: I like to think you're just misunderstood.

Person1: I'm giving you a chance to speak your mind, so don't waste it. What's your problem with the new rules?
Person2: I think they're unfair, sir. We weren't given a say in the matter.
Person1: You're complaining about not being heard? You're lucky I'm even listening to you now. You should be grateful.
Person2: Grateful? You're the one who's always saying we need to work together as a team. But now you're making all the decisions without consulting us.
Person1: That's enough. You're pushing your luck. I'll give you one more chance to calm down and apologize. Otherwise, you'll be facing consequences.
Person2: I'm not afraid of you. I'll say what needs to be said, even if it means facing punishment.

Person1: I've been thinking about my past, and I'm not sure I remember everything correctly. What if I've been lying to myself?
Person2: That would complicate things. You'd have to re-examine your entire life.
Person1: Exactly. And what if I've been doing things that I'm not proud of? You think you're queer...? I mean, we're all flawed in some way.
Person2: I don't know what you're getting at. Are you trying to confess something?
Person1: Maybe. I just feel like I've been living in a middle-class morality bubble, and it's time to break free from it. You know, shut out the guilt and shame.
Person2: I'm not sure that's possible. We all have our own moral compass, and it's what guides us.
Person1: But what if my compass is broken? What if I've been doing things that hurt others, and I've been justifying it to myself?
Person2: Then you need to take responsibility for your actions and make amends. But don't beat yourself up over it. We all make mistakes.

Person1: I've waited a long time for this chance to leave, and you're not going to stop me now. If I have to, I'll go alone.
Person2: You think you're queer? I'm going to tell you something. We're all queer.
Person1: What do you mean? I'm not queer, I just want to get out of this place.
Person2: You get befuddled by a middle-class morality. Get shut of it. Shut it out.
Person1: But I've been stealing gold for a year to bribe the porters. I'd do anything to get out of here.
Person2: You cheated on your wife? You did it, live with it. You think there's an absolute morality? May be.
Person1: I don't care about morality, I just want to escape. You won't see me shedding any tears over the High Lama.
Person2: A hell exists on earth? Yes. I won't live in it. That's me.
Person1: I'll do whatever it takes to leave. I'll die if I have to stay here another minute!
Person2: You ever take a dump made you feel you'd just slept for twelve hours?

Person1: I didn't mean to imply that you're not taking this seriously.
Person2: He's completely out of his mind, if you want my honest opinion.
Person1: That's not what I'm looking for. Can you tell me more about his behavior?
Person2: Well, he exhibits classic symptoms of a sociopathic personality. And he doesn't sleep.
Person1: Insomnia, you mean? That's not unusual, is it?
Person2: No, not in his situation. But I guess I didn't mean to make excuses for him either.

Person1: You deserve it, is that why you're throwing me a party?
Person2: Nobody told me to, I'm just the event planner!

Person1: You should be thinking about the future, kid.
Person2: I answer to myself, not to you.
Person1: The truth is, never let them see you sweat. You do that, that's half the battle.
Person2: What's the other half, then?
Person1: Figuring out what you want from life. I'ma keep on living, having a good drink, got me a good young woman, make a couple of dollars and make people laugh.
Person2: That sounds like a plan, but what about when the laughter stops?

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you? 
Person2: Oh, you know, for a minute I thought it was... 
Person1: Thought what? That I'd let you get away with this? 
Person2: Paul? Yeah. You think... 
Person1: Paul who? What are you talking about? 
Person2: Never mind. Look, I need to get back to work. 
Person1: Fine. But let me make one thing clear: I'm watching you.

Person1: I'm worried about your new business partner. He's an idealist, isn't he?
Person2: Yeah, I know. I'm sorry if I got defensive earlier. I just feel like you're not giving him a chance.
Person1: Do you know how I define "idealist," by the way?

Person1: I see a power void to be filled. As we have the most influence, we may move with confidence.
Person2: Yes, desperately. I want to prove to them that I'm not intimidated by the prominent figures in this industry.
Person1: Plus, if you back down, you're no better than those who have given up already.
Person2: That's the spirit! I'll get together a team of experts for action tonight.
Person1: I'll teach them what happens when they underestimate the potential of innovation.

Person1: What do you think is the key to a happy life?
Person2: I think it's about finding contentment in what you have. Like, I used to think about moving away, but then I realized what's the point? I'd just be taking my problems with me.
Person1: That's an interesting perspective. Do you think you have any weaknesses that hold you back from achieving that contentment?
Person2: Well, I have to admit, sometimes I can be a bit too trusting of people. I think everyone is OK, you know? Even people that others might not give a chance to.
Person1: That's a unique strength, actually. But don't you think that trust can sometimes be misplaced?
Person2: Yeah, I've had my fair share of bad experiences. But I'd rather err on the side of caution and give people the benefit of the doubt.

Person1: I know you're still hurt, but I've been trying to make it up to you. Can't you see I'm genuinely sorry?
Person2: I do see that, but trust takes time to rebuild. Be patient, and let's focus on the present. We can't change the past, but we can work together to create a better future.
Person1: You're right. I just get frustrated when I think about all the what-ifs. What if I had acted differently? What if I had spoken up sooner?
Person2: Those are natural thoughts, but dwelling on them won't help us move forward. Instead, let's focus on what we can control and make a conscious effort to communicate more effectively from now on.

Person1: I'm not questioning your competence, but it's just not possible. You wanted a raise, and now you're slacking off?
Person2: Oh, all right. I'll get back to work. See you later, boss.
Person1: Look, I know you're sincere and trying to do a good job, but I need to see some results. Get going or you'll be in trouble!

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a conspiracy! He's out to get me.
Person2: For what reason? Some personal satisfaction?
Person1: No way, it's because I stood up for myself last time. Now, let's go pick out some outfits for the party.
Person2: Alright, but hurry up! The game is getting intense. Look, Cory's going for third!
Person1: Yeah, and I've got a two-hundred dollar fine to pay because of that stupid parking ticket.

Person1: Talk to me. What's going on?
Person2: I'm scared. I think someone's following me.
Person1: You just relax. I'll see what I can do. Call me back here in exactly an hour, on this phone, and we'll figure it out together.
Person2: Yeah, okay. Thanks.

Person1: Wait, I want to talk about this.
Person2: So... I've been thinking, and I'm sorry. I've been distant and preoccupied with work.
Person1: No, I'm the one who's been neglecting our relationship. I've been so caught up in my own problems.
Person2: Get in, let's talk about it in the car.

Person1: I'm really going to miss this place when I leave.
Person2: You believe that I'll miss you too?
Person1: And if I don't come back, you'll know that I wanted to make a change and start fresh.
Person2: I think you'll come back. You're not ready to leave yet.
Person1: So, what's your plan after graduation?
Person2: Honestly, I have no idea. I'm just taking it one day at a time.
Person1: I know the feeling. Do you want ketchup or mustard on your hot dog?
Person2: Oh, mustard. You know, people always ask me what I want to do with my life, and I'm like, "I don't know, I'm still figuring it out."
Person1: Exactly! It's like, I'm supposed to have it all planned out, but I don't. Do you want relish?
Person2: Yeah, thanks. It's nice to know I'm not the only one who's unsure about their future.

Person1: I've been thinking about the new exhibit at the museum. That Spinosaurus Aegypticus is quite impressive.
Person2: Yes, it's a superpredator. I was surprised they didn't have it on InGen's list.
Person1: I know, right? It's like they were hiding something. Anyway, I was feeling really frustrated today. I saw this adorable couple on the bus and I couldn't help but give them a dirty look.
Person2: Go ahead.
Person1: I don't know, it's just that I've been feeling really bad about myself lately. I was even thinking that Dr. Bettes is married, and that's probably why I make poor Alex hug me more than he wants to.
Person2: Alex is doing fine. So what are you saying, that you're frustrated?
Person1: Yeah, I guess. I just wish I could stop thinking about everything that's wrong and just enjoy the moment. Like when I'm looking at that Spinosaurus, I should be in awe, not thinking about my love life.
Person2: Maybe you just need to take a step back and focus on the present.

Person1: I've been on a hot streak, so what? I don't remember him anymore. Where's Russia?
Person2: It takes years to get there. And years to come back. You know, I've wanted to talk to you for some time. For a long time, actually.
Person1: Yeah, I've been meaning to ask you something. That thing you were saying the other day was so good... it was admirable.
Person2: Mm. Now go to bed, it's late.

Person1: I wish I were a free spirit, with no strings attached.
Person2: You couldn't be a free spirit if you tried. You're too responsible.
Person1: I wish I were. Not a reckless adventurer, but... a carefree soul with the heart of a wanderer. Next best thing to no worries at all.
Person2: I have to go, Emma. I have a meeting to attend.
Person1: I can come by your office next week.
Person2: No, I don't think that's a good idea.
Person1: Not even just to grab lunch... in a quiet caf?
Person2: We can meet, we can even have dinner... but in a respectable setting, with my colleagues and their spouses.
Person1: And after dinner... do we send the spouses home and turn the conversation to business?
Person2: Emma! No!
Person1: All right. But can I at least bring my dog, Max, to the dinner?
Person2: Of course, Emma. I'm sure everyone would love to meet Max.
Person1: I'm so grateful to you. You're always so kind to me.
Person2: I only want what makes you happy, Emma.

Person1: I'm trying to understand, but it's hard for me to see how...
Person2: He can do anything, just like in the stories I read. I have to keep things ready for him, that's what I think. I've got his book and I'm going to sit in his favorite spot--
Person1: Hey now, I know it's been tough lately. I get a little frustrated too. Maybe we can find a way to make things better together.
Person2: It's not just about making things better. It's about believing in something more.

Person1: I'm surprised I'm saying this, but I'm glad you're here.
Person2: Just looking for fun, adventure, I guess.
Person1: Well, I could have used some of that adventure myself. Actually, I think I could have done it much more easily without you, but for whatever reason, I'm glad you're here.
Person2: Yeah, sometimes it's good to have someone to share the experience with.

Person1: What's going on?
Person2: I thought you were avoiding me.
Person1: What gave you that idea?
Person2: You're inside my office, and you're not even making an effort to explain yourself.
Person1: Well, as a matter of fact, I was rather hurt when you didn't consider my proposal last week.
Person2: I don't blame you. It was a mistake.
Person1: I forgive you. But I have to say, I'm surprised you're not trying to justify yourself.
Person2: Don't be too sure. Just because I'm your boss, that doesn't mean I'm always right.
Person1: You're a good leader, and I respect that. I mean, decency-wise and professionally-wise. Cheers to that.
Person2: Cheers.

Person1: I've been noticing some unusual patterns in your behavior, Rowan. Tell me, what do you see when you look in the mirror?
Person2: What's that supposed to mean? You're not going to find anything wrong with me.
Person1: I'm just trying to rule out some possibilities. You have a certain... intensity in your eyes. Like you're seeing something that's not quite there.
Person2: You're just trying to scare me, aren't you? Well, it won't work. I know what I see, and I know what I hear.

Person1: You're crazy if you think I'm not the best fit for this job.
Person2: She's perfect for the position. I think you're just intimidated.
Person1: I'll work anywhere, anytime. I know I can't be choosy.
Person2: That's the right attitude. Now, let's talk about your qualifications.
Person1: Clean driving record, no criminal history, and an honorable discharge from the military.
Person2: Impressive. What makes you think you can handle the demands of this role?
Person1: I'm a quick learner, and I'm not afraid of hard work.
Person2: I like your confidence. Fill out these forms, and we'll be in touch soon.

Person1: I've noticed you're really into him. What's the attraction?
Person2: It's hard to explain. I just feel like he gets me, you know?
Person1: Yeah, I do. But don't you think he's a bit too... polished? Like that Larry guy you used to date?
Person2: Oh, God, no! He's nothing like Larry. He's genuine, and that's what draws me to him.
Person1: If you say so. Just be careful, okay? I don't want to see you get hurt again.

Person1: You're not fooling anyone with that act, pal. I'm willing to give you a chance to come clean.
Person2: You think I'm acting? I'm just being myself.
Person1: Save it, buddy. I've seen your type before. Now, let's see if you can talk your way out of this mess.

Person1: I'm telling you, we need to be cautious. We can't afford to take any risks.
Person2: You're right, only you can decide what's best for yourself. But I think you're strong enough to make a change.
Person1: It's not about being strong, it's about being responsible. We're wearing protective gear for a reason.
Person2: I understand that, but sometimes you need to break free from the constraints and take a leap of faith.

Person1: What do you want from me, Vincent?  Name it.  You want to know a secret?
Person2: You're going to tell me something I don't know?
Person1: My children, they're still young.  They believe in a helper, someone who punishes the bad kids.  An old fairy tale tells of how this helper would visit them in their homes late at night.
Person2: And if they caught them not saying their prayers, what would they do?
Person1: They would leave a warning.  But if they continued to misbehave, they would take the children away.  And they would never be seen again.

Person1: I think it's important not to get depressed. Depression is a terrible thing. They say it can bring on illness.
Person2: You're not going to be that father to me, are you? The one who always knows what to say and makes everything better?
Person1: I wasn't going to say that, but... I want you to know that I love you, just in a different way.
Person2: I know, Dad. And I appreciate that. But sometimes I wish you could be more like you are with Susan - carefree and happy.

Person1: I'm not "people." I'm just me. And I do whatever I goddamn want to do. Got it?
Person2: Yeah, that's right. You're one of those free spirits, huh?
Person1: You could say that. I like to think I'm not bound by societal norms.
Person2: Uh, do you mind if I wait? I really need to talk to my friend.
Person1: What's going on? You look like you've lost your last marble.
Person2: She was supposed to be here three hours ago! I'm starting to get worried.
Person1: Maybe she's just running late. Or maybe she's avoiding you.
Person2: Why would she be avoiding me? We're friends.
Person1: People avoid their friends all the time. It doesn't mean they don't care about them.
Person2: I suppose you're right. But I still need to talk to her.
Person1: Well, you're welcome to wait here. Just don't expect me to entertain you.
Person2: Thanks, I appreciate it.

Person1: Oh, Governor! I don't know what to say. The villagers are getting restless.
Person2: I wouldn't know what to say either if I was in your place. Maybe you can suggest something. You've got to take the right tone in things like this, or people will walk all over you.
Person1: But what can I do? They're demanding answers about the strange occurrences in the village.
Person2: Shhhh. It's not what they think it is. Come on, let's go out there and address their concerns. We can't let them think we're hiding something.

Person1: I've been thinking, why do we still perform this play, Herr Director?
Person2: I like to think it's because it makes a hero out of a common man. He outwits his wealthy patron and exposes him as a hypocrite.
Person1: Ah, yes. And that's precisely why it was banned in France, wasn't it?
Person2: Exactly. But I believe our audience is mature enough to handle the implications. Besides, it's a grander situation, as if a humble artist were to expose a corrupt noble.
Person1: I see what you mean. Perhaps it's time we took a stand against the status quo.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a genius idea. We can use the old warehouse as our own secret laboratory!
Person2: You're talking crazy! The city's been trying to tear that place down for years. It's not safe.
Person1: Ah, come on. We're not crazy, we're "visionary". And I knew you were different, always tinkering with gadgets and whatnot.
Person2: So I guess you'll need a new spot for your... experiments. But seriously, have you thought this through?

Person1: What's wrong with you?
Person2: You know where we are. It's where life first crawled up out of the sea.
Person1: That's not an answer. You're freaking me out.
Person2: I come here sometimes... when I feel like crawling back in.
Person1: You're not making any sense. Stop being so cryptic.
Person2: Do what, show you a good time?

Person1: What's that for?
Person2: A rare find, like a one-of-a-kind butterfly.
Person1: You're not crazy about going to the antique shop, are you?
Person2: Well, I appreciate you taking me anyway. You're a good friend, Rachel.
Person1: No problem. But I think you should consider getting it appraised before buying.
Person2: Forget it, I've made up my mind.

Person1: You know, I've always wondered why you chose to become a chef.
Person2: Are you for real? I just love cooking, that's all.
Person1: You could have done anything - poured coffee, installed track lighting, told people their horoscopes... But you chose to make people happy with food. That's really interesting.
Person2: Yeah, well, someone's gotta do it. And I'm good at it.
Person1: That's right. Take pride in your work. You know, I like that apron, it somehow makes you look more... chef-like.
Person2: (laughs) Thanks, I think. I better get back to work, the kitchen's getting busy.
Person1: Yeah, don't want to keep the customers waiting. Give my best to the sous chef.

Person1: You're being reckless, and it's going to get us all in trouble.
Person2: Mph rmph rm rmph rm? (What do you mean?)
Person1: I mean, we need to have certain assurances before we proceed. We can't just rush in without a plan.
Person2: Him? I don't know... He can be nice... sometimes. (referring to someone who might be able to help)
Person1: What do you mean? Are you saying he's the only one who can help us?
Person2: Mph rm. Rmph rm rmph rm. (Yes, I think so)
Person1: Then it's fortunate that I have you to guide me. Let's go talk to him together.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's frustrating. I genuinely believe my approach is the right one for this art exhibition.
Person2: I seem to remember you saying that before, but the committee rejected your proposal. What makes you think it'll be different this time?
Person1: Everyone thinks I'm wrong, but I know my vision is exactly what this exhibition needs. And I'm not alone in thinking that.
Person2: Who's on your side this time? Maybe they can help you persuade the committee.
Person1: Rachel from the museum is supporting me. And together, I think we can make them see things our way. But first, can I ask, what was it about my previous proposal that gave you doubts?

Person1: You think you're queer...?
Person2: Please.
Person1: I could scoop them out.
Person2: You cheated on your wife...?
Person1: Don't.
Person2: So what? You did it, live with it.
Person1: I don't know where Nix is buried.
Person2: You ever take a dump made you feel you'd just slept for twelve hours...?
Person1: Yes.

Person1: I'm going to find out. I met him at this place called Moke's... We... became friends...
Person2: What job? Oh, why couldn't I be the Cardinal in charge of catering... If the Mayflowers get the three sections of Da Vinci's crystal and his instructions for the gold machine-- Aie-yi--Do we got anything?
Person1: I don't remember... Anyway, Andy's okay... I thought we were using the CIA to help us to get Mayflower, but really the CIA was using me to keep us away from Mayflower.
Person2: He's got some messed up friends. I'm sorry for losing it back there, but you must remember, sister, you have vows to God as well as a mission to the world.
Person1: God go with me, please.

Person1: I'm not questioning your experience, but it's just not possible. You been through the Dilbert Dunker yet?
Person2: Cake walk. Both my dad and my brother went through it and made it, so I know I can.
Person1: Is your brother a flyer? I'm trying to understand what's going on here.
Person2: He was. He died. Look, I know you're sincere and trying to do a competent job, but I can assure you the problem is with the training, not me.
Person1: I had a big brother who died, too. He wasn't a flyer though. He was just your basic Marine Corps type. I was only twelve when it happened, so I don't remember much about him.
Person2: I'm sorry to hear that. Maybe we can focus on the task at hand instead of dwelling on the past?

Person1: What do you want more than anything?
Person2: We haven't fully identified the anomalies yet.
Person1: I told you what I want. You're not listening.
Person2: That's probably not a good idea. You're not considering the environmental concerns.
Person1: Why don't you think about it for a while? Maybe you'll figure it out.
Person2: I'll keep you informed. Just get me the schematics.

Person1: I tell you - this is the only way to travel.
Person2: No, don't, Jack, don't.
Person1: Who sent you, Brumby?
Person2: You better put on the lights. I can't see what I'm doing.
Person1: No - no lights. We don't want anyone to know we're having a party.
Person2: I may spill something.
Person1: So spill it. Spills, thrills, laughs, games - this may even turn out to be a surprise party.
Person2: What's the surprise?
Person1: Uh-uh. Not yet.

Person1: You're shivering. Been in the water, have you?
Person2: I said I'd meet you here at 5. Let's just grab some coffee and go.
Person1: Well, you're soaked to the bone. You must've fallen in.
Person2: It's a hundred-dollar coffee shop! Can we please just focus on getting dry?

Person1: I'm going to show you how to navigate through these waters safely. Look at this chart. See anything unusual?
Person2: It's just a regular navigation chart.
Person1: Son, I can tell you've never sailed through here before. This chart is outdated. You don't remember the last time it was updated, do you?
Person2: I don't think so.

Person1: I'm not sure it's a good idea for you to stay here alone. Maybe we should go back and get help.
Person2: Respect my wish and stay. I asked you to do this for me.
Person1: You'll probably be safe enough on your own, but I doubt it.
Person2: I appreciate your concern, but I'll be fine.

Person1: You were a rebel, always pushing boundaries.
Person2: Baxter, we're a little disappointed in you -- creativity-wise.
Person1: Oh, I'm very innovative.

Person1: I didn't want to write all those extra essays they make you do -- I mean, how am I supposed to know what my "most emotionally significant moment" was?
Person2: Sorry, I don't remember. You're going to have to remind me.
Person1: Warsaw Radio. I was a technician. I saw you almost every day.
Person2: That's nice. So you're trying to place me?
Person1: Doesn't matter. You've nothing to worry about. I'll visit often.
Person2: Onions?
Person1: What?
Person2: You want onions on your sandwich?
Person1: Oh, yeah. So what're you gonna major in?
Person2: Well, State's got a good business school. And I can probably walk onto the lacrosse team.
Person1: Green peppers?
Person2: Yeah. So wow, you've got it figured out.

Person1: I've got a proposition for you, and I want to make it clear: I'm a straight shooter, no funny business. If anyone tries to cut corners, we'll have to take drastic measures.
Person2: Sounds like you're looking for a scoop, something big. Am I right?
Person1: You're on the right track, but this is bigger than just a story. I need to know I can trust you, that you're not going to try to get ahead by playing dirty.
Person2: I'm a professional, I can assure you. But what's in it for me? What's the payoff?
Person1: Let's just say that if you play by the rules, you'll be rewarded. But if you try to cheat or manipulate the system, you'll be the one who ends up getting taken for a ride.
Person2: Alright, I'm in. But I better not find out you're trying to pull the wool over my eyes.

Person1: I'm sorry, I don't think you'll have time for that meeting after all.
Person2: Hey now, outside of a very friendly client this morning, it's been a slow quarter. I don't close deals every month, I get a little anxious.
Person1: I'll find someone else to take your place.

Person1: I've got a deal for you. Five hundred bucks.
Person2: What's the catch?
Person1: There's one more thing I need you to do.
Person2: What's that?

Person1: Do you think I'll be able to adjust to this new environment?
Person2: Of course, you will. You're very adaptable.
Person1: Did anyone ever tell you that I might struggle to fit in?
Person2: No, never. Why would they say that?
Person1: I'm just wondering if there's anything I should know about the people here.
Person2: Only that they're very friendly and welcoming. You'll get along just fine.
Person1: That's a relief. I was worried I might do something to offend them.
Person2: You'll be fine, I'm sure. Just be yourself and you'll make plenty of friends.
Person1: I hope so. I've never been very good at making friends.
Person2: Nonsense, you'll do just fine. And if you need any help or advice, I'm always here for you.

Person1: You're fired.
Person2: But, sir! I've been working hard for this company for years!
Person1: I don't care about your dedication. You're not meeting expectations.
Person2: That's not fair. I think I'm falling in love with you, and I want to prove myself to you.
Person1: You don't even know me, and this is a workplace, not a dating scene.
Person2: I know I can do better. Tell me what to do to get my job back. I'll do anything.
Person1: Alright. I want you to take a few days off, reflect on your performance, and come back with a plan to improve.
Person2: That's it? You're not going to make me leave and go back to New York?
Person1: No, I just want you to take responsibility for your work. Now, get your things and go.

Person1: I'm so frustrated, I feel like I'm drowning in my own success.
Person2: Shhh, calm down, let's take a step back. Is this the contract you signed?
Person1: Of course it is. You know I wouldn't have gotten this far without making some tough deals.
Person2: I'm not judging, I just need to clarify some details.

Person1: I know I'm strange, but in my own way, I love this place.
Person2: Let's not get into this again. If we said something, they'd take it out on us.
Person1: And we'd end up stuck here forever. Let's forget it. I'll just be a little more careful next time.
Person2: There isn't gonna be a next time. We're gonna get out of here and make a new life for ourselves.

Person1: I just want you to know, I love you, Alex, and always will.
Person2: Take care of yourself out there, we might need you soon.
Person1: That might be the news we've been waiting for, but I'm worried about you getting stuck on some glamour puss.
Person2: I understand they've got things under control, but I'll try to stay focused.
Person1: You're not such a bargain, you know, and I don't want to lose you.
Person2: How childish are you going to get before you quit it?

Person1: Answer me. Do you take sugar?
Person2: Yes, two please. We learned he'd found the immigration notaries in Liverpool and traced them to New York.

Person1: So, are you sure you want to get rid of all this stuff?
Person2: Yeah, I'm positive. I just want to declutter and start fresh.
Person1: It just seems...kind of weird. You've had some of this stuff for years.
Person2: I know, but I'm just looking for fun, adventure, and a change of pace. I'm tired of being tied down to all this clutter.
Person1: Well, I can understand that. But what about the memories attached to some of these things?
Person2: Honestly, I think it's time for me to let go of the past and focus on the present. Besides, I'm sure someone else could make better use of it.
Person1: That's a good point. You're not going to feel bad about giving it all away, are you?
Person2: No, not at all. In fact, I think it'll be a relief. And who knows, maybe someone will find something they really need or love.

Person1: I got the first copy. The one to town is, but that's about it.
Person2: Is Looseleaf Harper alive?
Person1: Alive and hale. I called the hospital and talked to the head orthopedic surgeon. I told him who you were and what had happened.
Person2: She's a real heavy sleeper sometimes.
Person1: He said as long as there's no infection, you're not in any danger, and as soon as the road to the hospital is open, they'll send an ambulance for you.
Person2: I was supposed to be home for her birthday three days ago.
Person1: Your agent said she would tell her you were okay. But I'm afraid you'll have to wait until tomorrow if you want to speak to her yourself.
Person2: Tomorrow's another day.
Person1: Oh, Paul, I peeked at the very beginning. What a wonderful first page--just to read the name Misery Chastain...

Person1: You know, I'm worried about you.
Person2: What do you mean? I'm fine.
Person1: I think you're not being honest with yourself. You seem distant, like you're hiding something.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. Maybe I'm just stressed out.
Person1: I'll be honest with you, I've seen this before. My friend's brother went through something similar. He was struggling with addiction.
Person2: That's not it. I just need some space, okay?

Person1: What do you want from me? Name it. You want money?
Person2: You know me...I never take anything that doesn't belong to me. Where's the package?

Person1: Are you sure you're ready for this? 
Person2: We've been given a chance here. Maybe that's why we've been brought together, to help each other.

Person1: I want you to look for the truth.
Person2: What?! You're telling me that after everything I've been through, it's all for nothing?
Person1: No, I'm saying that we need to uncover the reasons behind their decision.
Person2: You have no idea what it's like to have my hopes raised, only to be crushed like this. You can't imagine what it's like to walk in my shoes.
Person1: I understand that you're upset, but we can't give up now. We need to find out what's really going on.
Person2: Yes, I want to know. I want to know why they're doing this to me.

Person1: I come here sometimes... when I feel like escaping the city. It's where I clear my head.
Person2: Hold on, buddy. Hold on, and wait for Rachel. I can't do anything for you, but when Rachel gets here, which should be anytime now, she'll be able to help you. We're just gonna sit here, and wait for Rachel. Who are we waiting for?
Person1: Rachel. I've been waiting for her for hours. Do you think she's going to show up?
Person2: Bet your sweet ass she is. She's always been reliable.

Person1: Captain, I want you to re-route the navigation system until we're clear of the asteroid field.
Person2: You wish. I haven't had a second to think since we entered the galaxy. I mean, in space. Out here. Whatever.
Person1: Then... can you at least try to explain what's going on?
Person2: Look, you guys know how it is. You just keep doing what it looks like you're supposed to, even if it seems crazy, and you hope to hell your crew knows what's going on.
Person1: Well, that's how it is for pilots, yes, but...
Person2: I hate to disappoint you, pal, most of the time, that's how it is for everyone in space.

Person1: I didn't mean to intrude, I just didn't expect to run into you here.
Person2: Kristen specializes in surprises. I've spent years getting used to them.
Person1: Did you notice anything strange before she made the decision?
Person2: Well, now you're asking questions. That's a change.
Person1: I'm serious. There are other people involved, it's not just her.
Person2: I'm sorry to hear that, but you're the expert on this, not me.
Person1: Just some answers, please. I want to understand.
Person2: Look, I don't know what you want from me. If I had any insights, believe me, I'd share them with you.
Person1: I'll need to take a closer look at her things.
Person2: The box is on the table. Help yourself.

Person1: You think you're queer...? I'm going to tell you something. We're all queer.
Person2: You promised to give it back.
Person1: Friends never break promises, do they? Okay. Here. Now listen. There are a lot of people outside and they all want you to be safe.
Person2: Why? You're not going to hurt me, are you?
Person1: Of course not. They like you. Okay? You get befuddled by a middle-class morality...? Get shut of it. Shut it out.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: You cheated on your wife...? You did it, live with it. You think that you're a thief? So what?

Person1: I've got a proposition for you. If anyone's caught taking advantage of someone else, we'll stand them up against the wall - and that's it. No more, no less.
Person2: So everyone beware, who's taking advantage of others. No one must get away with it unless they're willing to make it right.
Person1: You know, I used to think I was the only one who felt trapped by societal expectations. But then I realized, we're all in this together. We're all trying to find our way.
Person2: Exactly! And if we're honest with ourselves, we'll realize that we're not so different after all. We've all got our secrets, our flaws.
Person1: That's right. And if we can just learn to accept ourselves and others, we might just find a way to make the world a better place. One where everyone has a chance to thrive.
Person2: I couldn't agree more. It's time we stopped judging each other and started working together. Who knows, we might just create a utopia.
Person1: Ha! Maybe not a utopia, but at least a world where everyone has a fair shot. And if anyone tries to take that away from us, we'll stand up for what's right.

Person1: I've been trying to go easy on you, but this can't continue. We need to address the issues.
Person2: I'm not going to sit here and be lectured. I have my own priorities.
Person1: Every time I assign you a task, it's either late or not done to the standard we need. You just going to ignore the problem?
Person2: I understand. Let's discuss how we can improve the situation and meet expectations. But I hope you're willing to listen to my perspective as well.
Person1: Okay. Hope we can find a solution that works for both of us.

Person1: You deserve a break, don't you think? There are plenty of people around here who could help you with that task.
Person2: I already know what I'm doing... and it's not like I have a deadline to meet. Between you and me, I could use some time to clear my head.

Person1: You're in such a hurry. You can't wait. What's the rush?
Person2: I seem to remember making a promise to myself. I won't break it, no matter what.
Person1: And I remember you saying you'd never back down from a challenge. What happened to that spirit?
Person2: It's still there. But now I know when to wait. And it's not for no steak. It's for something that really matters.

Person1: I'm sorry, Rachel. I've been a bit of a burden lately and I'm sorry.
Person2: Don't apologize, I'm happy to help. But this is the last time, I promise. And I'm keeping strict accounts.
Person1: I know, I know. I've been selfish and self-absorbed with my own problems. But I'll get back on my feet, I promise.

Person1: I know why you're asking about him. We get a lot of people in here.
Person2: Yeah, I've seen him around. What did he buy?
Person1: Honestly, I don't remember. But I can check the records if you need to know.
Person2: That's okay, I was just curious. Lot of things can happen in a small town like this.

Person1: I'm glad to hear that Andy's okay.
Person2: Are you still in touch?
Person1: Not really. The last time I saw him was at Moke's. That was a long time ago.
Person2: What were you doing there?
Person1: I don't remember. Anyway, he's got some messed up friends.
Person2: Like who?
Person1: I don't know... It was near a beach, though.

Person1: I've had no direct communication with the board since this whole thing began. And that's quite verifiable.
Person2: Sometimes I really hate the way you operate.
Person1: Yeah? Well, why don't you take your concerns to the annual meeting? Put a little more life into it than you usually do.
Person2: You promised me a fast track, and I always meant to hold you to that. Come work with me. I can always use a hard-charger on my team.
Person1: You know, I wonder what the CEO would think about it. If I spoke with him.
Person1: Well, I spoke with the CFO this morning myself  and told him the deal was off. No more special favors. He was only too happy to oblige. Don't play politics with me, little darlin'. You'd be up way past your bedtime.

Person1: Are you sure you're ready for this?
Person2: I'm not good at public speaking.
Person1: Get good at it. You'll have to convince them eventually.
Person2: It's against my nature, but I'll try.

Person1: I'm not questioning your expertise, Dr. Lee, but I think we should reconsider the treatment plan.
Person2: Ah, you've brought your medical student with you today. I see you're taking a more hands-on approach to their training.
Person1: Actually, I was hoping to get your insight on the patient's condition. I've been going over the test results, and I'm not convinced we're on the right track.
Person2: Well, let's take a closer look then. Sometimes a fresh perspective is all we need to crack the case.

Person1: What do you think about this new exhibit?
Person2: Obviously a masterpiece. The brushstrokes, the colors... it's a work of art.
Person1: How do you remember how to appreciate art?
Person2: I don't know... I just do. I remember walking into this museum, sort of. Now I remember this painting and you. That's about it.
Person1: That's fascinating. Do you think the artist was trying to convey a specific message?
Person2: Nothing specific comes to mind. I just know it speaks to me on some level.

Person1: I'm thinking about how we can make more money.
Person2: What are you talking about? I don't remember us making plans together.
Person1: Well, for people who have been out of touch for seven or eight years...
Person2: I don't remember you. I don't remember us. I don't even remember me.
Person1: Suppose we bet only part of our dough and keep this big opportunity out of the game the whole first half and let them roll up some points. Then you could bet the rest of our bundle and get some real odds.

Person1: Talk to me. I've heard great things about your art studio.
Person2: Excellent. My friend and I are actually looking for a unique piece to decorate our new office, and I was told you have some amazing local artists.
Person1: That's what people say. Let me show you some of our latest collections.

Person1: I was always climbing something.... I didn't mean to start that fire, but I'm glad I got the first copy of your book.
Person2: Then the roads are open... I was supposed to be home for my daughter's birthday three days ago.
Person1: The one to town is, but that's about it. I called the hospital and talked to the head orthopedic surgeon. I told him who you were and what had happened.
Person2: Don't be such a Grandma... I'm not in any danger, and as soon as the road to the hospital is open, they'll send an ambulance for me.
Person1: Your agent said she would tell her you were okay. But I'm afraid you'll have to wait until tomorrow if you want to speak to her yourself. It's like a visit from my oldest, dearest friend.

Person1: You're really terrific, you know what I mean?
Person2: So you're saying we just pretend it didn't happen? It happened!
Person1: I have to go.
Person2: Fine. Do you want blood running waist deep in the storm drains?
Person1: I know.
Person2: You really want that on your head?

Person1: I'm sorry, I can't. I...
Person2: Why're you doing this?
Person1: You don't care if I'm unhappy.
Person2: Hey now, outside of a very friendly dog this morning, it's been a slow decade.
Person1: That's not the point. You're just trying to distract me.
Person2: Maybe. But I do care. I just have a weird way of showing it.
Person1: Like you could find someone who appreciates that.
Person2: See that? Who needs affection when I've got a good sense of humor?
Person1: Just let me think for a moment.

Person1: Are you crazy?
Person2: You're going to do the same thing to everyone else that you did to the last three.
Person1: I'd love to stay and chat, but I've got to get back to work. I still have my job.
Person2: Let's see how much he wants to play.

Person1: I've been feeling a strange energy in this house. What's the story behind it?
Person2: My family's history is tied to this place. My father tried to restore it, but it's cursed. I was just a kid when I saw it for the first time... a dark mist that seemed to move on its own. Then people started to die.
Person1: That must have been traumatic. Do you think it's possible to erase those memories? Start fresh?
Person2: I've tried to forget, but it's hard to shake off the feeling that the house is watching me. What's the point of erasing memories if the problem still exists?

Person1: I'm trying to better myself, but the one person who can help me is the same one pushing me away.
Person2: Well, then it all seems to be working out for you. Listen, Mr...?
Person1: Do you remember the art exhibition last week? The one that showcased the works of local artists?
Person2: What's that got to do with you?
Person1: I was wondering, perhaps you'd like to go meet the artist who created the centerpiece. She's pretty amazing.
Person2: I'll bet. On television, you seemed so sure of yourself. If you're really that confident, you'd be willing to let someone prove you wrong?
Person1: The world would be so much simpler if it were all just about talent and skill. Unfortunately, I find it much more complex and nuanced place.
Person2: Well, I think it's very simple. Here's an invitation to the artist's studio. I'll be there tomorrow at 2... if you want to meet her.

Person1: I'm not going to let him take advantage of me again.
Person2: You don't let people walk all over you. You do it to yourself.
Person1: That's not true. If I said something, he'd make my life miserable.
Person2: And I'd be right there with you, making his life miserable too.

Person1: You're not going to get a little more press out of this, are you?
Person2: Thinking I saw the news headline feels pretty real. And jumping to conclusions...
Person1: You didn't jump to conclusions. That's my take on it.
Person2: It's in my nature, you know. My grandmother was a journalist...
Person1: Really? Hell, if having a curious family made you a good investigator, the world'd be one colossal newsroom. Heads or tails, do you want to investigate further?

Person1: I need you to do two things for me. One, take care of yourself out there.
Person2: I understand. What's the other thing?
Person1: Don't get stuck on some glamour puss. You're not such a bargain, you know.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: Just remember, I want you to keep an eye on things. If there's any problems, make sure we know about it first.
Person2: You're not my mother, you know. I can handle myself.
Person1: Fine, just tuck in your shirt, too.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a matter of principle.
Person2: I know I should be more open-minded, but do you really think you're in a position to judge?

Person1: Say what I say.
Person2: You mean we're finally in agreement?
Person1: It's like a weight off your shoulders.
Person2: Exactly! We're right, aren't we?

Person1: I've got a surprise for you. We better have a drink first.
Person2: That's correct, sir! But what's the surprise?
Person1: Not that one. Or that one. You'll have to wait and see.
Person2: I may spill something. This drink is quite strong.
Person1: So spill it. Spills, thrills, laughs, games - this is going to be a night to remember.
Person2: You better put on the lights. I can't see what I'm doing.
Person1: No - no lights. We don't want anyone to know we're having a celebration.

Person1: You want to work the graveyard shift?
Person2: I'll work anywhere, anytime. I know I can't be choosy.
Person1: Heads or tails? We're deciding who gets the better route.
Person2: Tails. But I've got a clean record, real clean. As clean as my conscience.
Person1: That's good to know. We've had some issues with drivers in the past.
Person2: I'm also physically fit, no criminal record, and I'm twenty-six.
Person1: Okay, and what about your education?
Person2: Some here and there. I've got an honorable discharge from the military, May 1971.
Person1: Alright, fill out these forms and give them to the girl at the desk. We'll be in touch soon.

Person1: I've an idea that will get us out of this mess. We haven't a penny between us, but we've got these connections.
Person2: Connections? You mean like the mayor's award?
Person1: Exactly! That's our way out. A new business deal with the city would give us a fresh start.
Person2: Do you know that the mayor isn't paying attention to our proposals? 
Person1: Is that a fact?
Person2: No, I'm just saying it to amuse myself! But seriously, we need to think of something else.
Person1: Well, Mr. Lebowski was able to send those inner-city kids to college. Maybe we can find a way to help the community and get something in return.
Person2: You mean like a photo opportunity with the mayor?
Person1: Ha! Maybe, but I was thinking more along the lines of a genuine partnership.
Person2: Far out. I think we can make it work.

Person1: I've tried to stay open to voices of the people, just like when I was younger and had thoughts about public office.
Person2: Spider-Man is a good guy, on the side of right, and niceness, and cute baby animals and all that.
Person1: I see. Maybe one day you shall find yourself in a similar position, where you can contribute more as a private citizen.
Person2: Frmpph-yrr.

Person1: I'm upset because I can't really justify being upset. I mean, it's your decision, really, you're the one who's been handling the finances.
Person2: What's bothering you about it? Is it just the principle of the thing?
Person1: Yeah, I guess. I just wish you would've asked me about it. I would've said yes, but it feels like you're not considering my feelings.
Person2: I didn't think it would be a big deal. He's an old friend, and it's just for a couple of days.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is you didn't ask me. And now I'm wondering if you're hiding something from me.
Person2: Hiding something? What are you talking about?
Person1: I don't know... maybe you're having some secret affair or something.
Person2: What? That's ridiculous. Why would you even think that?
Person1: I don't know. I just feel like you're not being honest with me, and it's making me paranoid.
Person2: Look, I'm telling you the truth. There's nothing going on. Can we please just move past this?

Person1: You know, I'm impressed. Really. I wouldn't have thought you'd make it this far.
Person2: Yeah, well, I've got my ways.
Person1: You seem like a smart guy, but sometimes I wonder what's going on with you.
Person2: Makes two of us, I suppose.
Person1: Life's full of surprises, huh?
Person2: That's right.

Person1: I thought we were partners, but really you're using me to get ahead.
Person2: Why do I let you talk me into these things? Why?
Person1: Because we're a team - we're in this together. I need your expertise to crack this case.
Person2: Don't give me the team spirit! How'm I going to keep the suspect from lawyering up?
Person1: Tell him you need his help to clear his name. Play on his ego.
Person2: Oh, no. I'm not getting caught in a web of lies with that guy.

Person1: You're no bargain either, pal. I've been reading about your latest project in the news, and I have to say, I'm underwhelmed.
Person2: Well, you can't believe everything you read in the news. They're just trying to sell papers.
Person1: I want to believe it's not true. I want to believe you're better than that. But it's hard when everyone's saying the same thing.
Person2: You'd be amazed at what some people will believe. Maybe you should focus on your own life instead of worrying about mine.

Person1: I'm trying, but I can't.
Person2: You're a lucky person, to have the chance to make amends.
Person1: I want to, but I don't know what to say.
Person2: Have you ever taken responsibility for your actions, truly?
Person1: I love the idea of forgiveness, but it's hard for me.
Person2: Forgiveness is the hardest and the greatest, but it's worth it.

Person1: I'm glad you're back. You were a lot of help with the project. Your skills are bad-ass.
Person2: I'd hoped I was finished with all that. But I think I can still contribute.
Person1: You know, you're lucky to have this opportunity. Most people don't get a second chance.
Person2: Don't I know it. Every colleague I knew in the industry has moved on. My team... disbanded. Twenty of my friends scattered in less than a year.
Person1: Mind if I ask you something? Why'd you put up with the stress like that for someone else's goal?
Person2: Ah... I have a suggestion. There's really not much time left. I could take care of everything here and meet you at the meeting point with the proposal... if you'd like.
Person1: I think we'd like very much. Sure you won't mind?

Person1: You didn't visit him in the hospital.
Person2: He didn't want me to. Said it would be too emotional.
Person1: Why not? You're his sister.
Person2: I know, but he's been different since the accident. He's been struggling to come to terms with his new reality.
Person1: But you spoke to him on the phone. He called you the day he decided to start rehabilitation.
Person2: He did. I was surprised. He said he wished the two of you could start over, rebuild your relationship.
Person1: Did you know that when you two drifted apart?
Person2: We grew up, grew apart. He said he was a free spirit. I could live with that. I never knew he needed help till he got into that accident.
Person1: At least you knew about his condition.
Person2: Yes. And now that I've shown you that I know that much, and can guess more -- will you trust me to help him through this tough time?
Person1: I want you to help him.

Person1: I'm sorry about what happened to your friends. How are you holding up?
Person2: I'm okay, I guess. This guy wants his money, but I'm not sure I can pay him back.
Person1: We're looking for someone who might be able to help you. In your opinion, why did he take your friends?
Person2: He became obsessed with them. They hated him, but he had to have them. He took them to control them, to make them do things.
Person1: You seem to know a lot about him. What's going to happen to you now?
Person2: I don't know. I'm scared. There might be more people like him out there.

Person1: I've been feeling stuck in my life lately. Sometimes I feel like I'm just watching the world pass me by.
Person2: You know, I used to think that way too. But then I realized that it's not about what you do, it's about how you do it. You can find meaning in anything if you approach it with the right mindset.
Person1: That's easy for you to say. You're not the one feeling trapped.
Person2: I'm not saying it's easy. But I am saying that you have the power to choose how you react to your circumstances. You can let life happen to you, or you can happen to life.
Person1: I suppose you're right. I just wish I could shake this feeling of restlessness.
Person2: Maybe you need to take a step back and re-evaluate your priorities. What's truly important to you? What do you want to achieve in your life?

Person1: I'm not going to the meeting. You can't make me.
Person2: We did take care of the Johnson account, didn't we?
Person1: Yes, and now we've got a major crisis on our hands. These things take time.
Person2: I hope they do. I'm not going down for this.
Person1: I don't have time for your attitude, Alex. End of discussion.

Person1: I've been thinking, we should get a team to stake out the art gallery. We might catch a glimpse of the thief.
Person2: That's not going to work. There's no description of the thief, no known photograph.
Person1: Are you telling me nobody knows what they look like? Come on, there must be witnesses somewhere.
Person2: Yeah, right. You're talking about a professional, not some amateur. They're not going to leave any witnesses behind.
Person1: Fine, but I still think we can make it work. We can take turns driving to the gallery, keep an eye out for anything suspicious.
Person2: You're really committed to this, aren't you? I mean, it's not like it's a space shuttle launch or something. It's just a painting.

Person1: You never thought that's a heavy load?
Person2: I seem to remember knocking on your door.
Person1: What I done with myself is my problem. You're only alive because I didn't kill you.
Person2: No it hain't, Luke. You ain't alone. Ever whar you go, I'm with you, and so's John.
Person1: Sit back. We allus thought you was strong enough to carry it. Was we wrong?

Person1: Dr. Lee, I've been meaning to ask you something for a while...
Person2: What's on your mind, Rachel?
Person1: I don't owe you any explanations; you don't owe me any answers. We've worked together on this project for months  what's it been, ten or fifteen meetings? It wasn't memorable enough to carry any obligations.
Person2: Sometimes I really appreciate your honesty.
Person1: Yeah? Well, I'm just trying to clear the air. Can you tell me what's next for this project?

Person1: I told you! I knew it!
Person2: ... And now he's holding our people hostage down there...
Person1: You have no idea what precipitated his behavior?
Person2: He told me everything. I was supposed to meet him fifteen minutes ago, so I...
Person1: That's probably not a good idea. Your ship hasn't been fitted for this region; there are environmental concerns...
Person2: Marge, I don't know you, so I have no right, but he loves you. He's -- I think you'll find he's coming home to you.
Person1: What kind of concerns?
Person2: Unless he meant us to meet -- which would be a little cruel, wouldn't it?

Person1: I don't remember you.
Person2: What do you think? I didn't ask about your past.
Person1: What I think is... my memories are fragmented. They're cowards, afraid to confront the truth.
Person2: The truth? You're not even sure who I am. How can you talk about the truth?

Person1: You're being too loud. I'm trying to focus on my project.
Person2: Ah, sorry about that. What's the project about?
Person1: I'm designing a new community center. I want to make sure it's perfect.
Person2: That sounds amazing! I've always been interested in architecture. Maybe I can help.
Person1: Really? You know something about architecture?
Person2: Well, I've got a great idea that could get us out of our current financial struggles. We could...
Person1: Wait, what do you mean "get us out of our current financial struggles"? Is everything okay?
Person2: Oh, yeah, everything's fine. I just meant that with your design skills and my... creativity, we could make something really special happen.
Person1: I'm not sure what you're getting at, but I appreciate the enthusiasm. Why don't you take a look at my designs and see if you can contribute anything?
Person2: Sounds like a plan! And after we're done, I'll even invite you for a swim to celebrate.

Person1: What's waiting for us up there? Tell me.
Person2: Ten bucks.
Person1: What's it for? You're not making sense.
Person2: For the mini-bike fund. I think you'll be surprised.
Person1: Apparently, I'm not as dumb as you thought I am.
Person2: Well, I know you're not crazy about this, so...I just want you to know I appreciate it though.
Person1: No problem. But what's the real reason?
Person2: You're a good person, Nicholas. Trust me on this one.

Person1: I didn't mean to start that.... You're a very close friend. Do you have some explanation of what happened at the art gallery?
Person2: Don't be such a Grandma... I found some interesting information about the artist. I'll tell you in private at a fine caf.
Person1: Can't you tell me now? I'm curious about the exhibition.
Person2: I'll cancel the reservation, but I think we should meet tonight to talk about it. I respect you as an artist and as a curator.
Person1: You think I enjoy giving up my evenings to spend time with colleagues? I'm busy tonight.
Person2: I'm making an exception because I think you'll find this information fascinating. You were always climbing the ranks in the art world....
Person1: You were a monkey... I mean, you were always ambitious. Alright, I'll meet you tonight.

Person1: Are you sure you want to do this in front of everyone? I'm feeling too good to fight with you, but that isn't what I said.
Person2: Begging your pardon, I haven't been to this restaurant in years! These are my colleagues, by the way.

Person1: What's going on here?
Person2: Sometimes when we get 'em, they're not completely broken, you know, like when they fix a machine and it still doesn't work right.
Person1: The... oh, the machine! How silly of me, it's as plain as day... Where did you learn to do this?
Person2: I learned a long time ago, from my grandfather.

Person1: I do remember so much now, but not everything. Perhaps in the end, he did it to show me that he could.
Person2: Don't worry about that now, child. He knew you. He knew you would love her more than the waking world. Life was very different with her, as you can imagine...

Person1: I'm thinking about how we can make more money. We look pretty lousy out there, right?
Person2: I know I should focus on my own game, but I have a tendency to get distracted by my opponents' moves. Do you want me to try a different strategy?

Person1: Lord knows how I love a man in uniform.
Person2: You're just saying that. You don't know me.
Person1: I know your mother, Lisa Sherman. Do you know who that is?
Person2: Yes. What about her?
Person1: I'm trying to understand why you're so driven to make a difference.
Person2: I've planned this since I was a very little boy. To make a change in this town, to bring justice where it's needed.
Person1: You have no real freedom either. Your past has cast a shadow that you've never eluded.
Person2: That's not true. I'm breaking free from that shadow, and I won't let it define me.

Person1: I know him. If you said something, he'd take it out on me.
Person2: Your presence here made a compelling argument.
Person1: Let's not get into this again. You invited me aboard.
Person2: And I'd take it out on him, but we're not going to let that happen.

Person1: How are you feeling?
Person2: It's okay. Forget it.
Person1: Forget it? Are you crazy? You've done a great thing.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: I mean you should be rewarded. Let me see it.
Person2: I'm not sure what to do now. I'm not sure what you want for me.

Person1: What's this?
Person2: Conviction. Conviction that I'm onto the truth.
Person1: The... oh, the truth! How silly of me, it's as plain as day... Where did you learn to see things so clearly?
Person2: I learned a long time ago. You're going to do the same thing again, aren't you?
Person1: You're going to be very disappointed.
Person2: We'll see.

Person1: You're a real heavy sleeper sometimes.
Person2: I wrote a theme about you, and my teacher said, "You're a legendary hero out of the Golden Age of Heroes."
Person1: That's nice. You thank her for me. Go to bed and get lots of sleep, and then you thank her in the morning.
Person2: She's dead. She was killed in the park two months ago - in the daytime.
Person1: I'm sorry to hear that. My father made sure my mother knew what the Bible said. And she made sure I knew.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: I mean, my mother told me that I was their punishment. From God, for having sex - just period, I think.
Person2: That's really strange. What does it mean?
Person1: One of my Daddy's Bible lessons, I imagine. You know, I've got double-decker bunks if you need a place to sleep.
Person2: Thanks, but I think I'll stay up for a bit.

Person1: What's going on? I haven't had a minute alone yet.
Person2: I've got to get this done. Why don't I take care of everything here and meet you at the gate?
Person1: You're sure you won't mind?
Person2: Of course not, pull up alongside and I'll get everything sorted.

Person1: We must prepare for the big presentation.
Person2: You mean I can lead the team?
Person1: He is the CEO, after all.
Person2: Really? Can't wait to impress him. As long as we're preparing, I'd really like to try something new with the slides.

Person1: I'm telling you, I distinctly heard it. He muttered under his breath, "You're next."
Person2: You're crazy! Heads or tails?
Person1: What's that supposed to mean? You think I'm paranoid?
Person2: Well, you do see conspiracies in everything. Tails.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is, I know what I heard. And I know what he was trying to say.
Person2: Right, and I'm sure it's all part of some grand scheme. California, here we come!
Person1: Forget it. I'm not going anywhere. I have a meeting with Annie in front of the Beekman.
Person2: Ah, yes. Annie. Well, don't be late. And try not to read too much into everything, okay?

Person1: I got a job now. I'm teaching high school. Japanese and Chemistry.
Person2: You sure? You're not exactly the teaching type.
Person1: Oh, I'm more than sure. Anything happens to those kids, I can tell you right now you don't wanna be the party that was responsible.

Person1: I don't think I can do this.
Person2: Look, I'll take the lead and distract them. You break for it!
Person1: Are you sure you're ready for this?
Person2: I know what I'm doing. Just go!

Person1: I've tried to stay open to voices of the people, but it's hard when you've broken someone's heart.
Person2: For what? Breaking my trust or ruining my faith in relationships?
Person1: Uh, both, I suppose. I didn't mean to hurt you.
Person2: Forget it. I've already spent too many hours trying to understand you.

Person1: I implore you to believe me, Dr. Lee. The only way to power the device is to harness the energy of a massive explosion.
Person2: You can't be serious, would you? A blast of that magnitude would destroy the entire facility!
Person1: I am serious. Theoretically, if we could contain the blast, the device would be operational for a fraction of a second before the destruction. That's all the time we need.
Person2: We'll see. I need to review the calculations before I can even consider such a reckless plan.

Person1: You're no bargain either, pal.
Person2: My mother was a great storyteller, she could weave a tale that would make you laugh and cry. And when I was a child, she'd tell me stories of our ancestors, of their struggles and triumphs.

Person1: I have proof. I'm the victim.
Person2: What do you say? What can I say? No. At least, not yet.
Person1: You look at me as though I had said something foolish...
Person2: Please, don't do this. Are you really sure... that you want to do this?
Person1: That's why I'm telling you... I'm the only one who knows the truth.
Person2: Oh, how I wish that everything were so much simpler... that people could just trust each other without needing proof.

Person1: I want to review the case files again. There must be something we're missing.
Person2: You're no bargain either, pal. We've been over this a dozen times.
Person1: Are you telling me nobody noticed anything unusual? Come on, there must be some lead.
Person2: I hate going over the same ground again and again. It's like you're not listening to me.

Person1: I wish I were a decorated veteran, a former POW myself... if I came out and said "No POWs" the sub-committee would buy it.
Person2: You couldn't be a hero if you tried. You're just a private citizen, a whacko, acting on your own.
Person1: And besides, when you say I make excuses, you make me out a criminal. I'm just trying to do the right thing.
Person2: I have to go, Colonel. We can't afford to get caught up in this mess.
Person1: I can come down next week, try to help you clean up this situation.
Person2: No, it's too risky. We're talking about a major scandal here. Four billion bucks in war reparations to Vietnam... it's a pain in the ass to everybody.
Person1: I understand. But sometimes you have to take a stand, even if it's not the popular thing to do.
Person2: I respect that, Colonel. But let's not be heroes here. Let's just try to get out of this with our reputations intact.

Person1: You know, this, what you're doing with your life...
Person2: Wait a minute! Who put you in charge of giving advice around here?
Person1: Well, I just figured it should be the one with some common sense. But if that ain't the consensus view, hell, let's put it to a vote!
Person2: Suits me! I'm voting for a fresh perspective!
Person1: Well, I'm voting for a reality check too!

Person1: I'm telling you, it's over. We're obsolete. We've got a lousy marriage and sixty-two grand a year.
Person2: I don't know, it just seems...kind of weird.
Person1: What's weird about it? We used to be the ones in control, making the decisions. Now we're just pawns in someone else's game.
Person2: I remember when we used to have real power. We could make things happen with just a phone call.
Person1: Yeah, and now we're just trying to hold on to what we've got. It's pathetic.
Person2: Maybe we should just pack it in and give it all up. Charity can have it.
Person1: You think that's the answer? Just walk away and let someone else take over?
Person2: Why not? We're not getting any younger. And what's the point of it all, anyway?
Person1: The point is, we used to be somebody. We used to matter.
Person2: Yeah, well, times change. People change. Maybe it's time we changed too.

Person1: You promised to help me.
Person2: It was nothing. I'm happy to assist you.
Person1: Let's try it again, only this time I need you to explain it slowly. I want to make sure I understand.
Person2: Okay. Eyes closed, and let's focus.

Person1: I'm thrilled to be a part of this community, Alex. Can you believe it?
Person2: You're a lucky person, Rachel. I'll send you a warm welcome message, straight from my thoughts. Once you get it, you'll feel at home forever. Understand?

Person1: You're in danger. I have no time to explain.
Person2: Wait a minute, what's going on?
Person1: Just relax, I'll figure something out. Call me back in an hour and I'll see what I can do.
Person2: Yeah, okay... But please hurry.

Person1: I just wanted you to know, I've been thinking about this project a lot.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: And I think we should reconsider our approach.
Person2: I want you to know that I trust your instincts on this.
Person1: Really?
Person2: Yeah. So what do you suggest we do then?

Person1: You don't ride him anymore, do you? Not since your dad died.
Person2: A few days... a few weeks - dunno, I can't remember. Worse thing is, I never know if it will change back again... Now, please leave me alone.

Person1: I seem to remember knocking on your door.
Person2: Oh, you are very welcome. I've been expecting you.
Person1: And, I remember breaking your nose. You're only alive because I didn't kill you.
Person2: Lord knows how I love a man who can admit his mistakes.

Person1: I'm afraid, this wine is making me woozy...
Person2: When you invited my colleague over without telling me, it put me in an awkward situation.
Person1: Indeed we were. I thought it would be a nice surprise.
Person2: But given our recent disagreements, you always do things without considering how they'll make me feel.
Person1: He saw the truth, and spoke it... You have to eat, it'll help with the wine.
Person2: I'm sorry, I need to be more considerate and communicative.

Person1: Oh, cut it out, will ya? I need a new sponsor.
Person2: Is that what you want? Twenty-eight bucks is nothing.
Person1: Yeah. I'm tired of being messed with.
Person2: Mm... okay. Don't worry about it. Nobody'll mess with ya anymore. I'll take care of ya.
Person1: NO!!! What do you think I am, crazy??? I can take care of myself.
Person2: No, I just want to help, that's all. It's what you want, isn't it?
Person1: Yeah... I guess so. Thanks.

Person1: What's the plan now that we're in?
Person2: I'm going to buy a sailboat. All decked out and ready for the open sea. I'm going to be so free.
Person1: A sailboat? You're going to buy a sailboat? I think it's the open sea that's going to get us.

Person1: I'm trying to identify this species.
Person2: Not my area of expertise, but I can take a look.
Person1: They never got that big, did they?
Person2: What do you want from me? Honestly?
Person1: I want to know what I'm dealing with. Is it a Baryonyx?
Person2: Not with that sail. You're not going to find the answer in a book.
Person1: Who knows what else they were up to? Maybe I should pay a visit to Chino.
Person2: You're not going to find what you're looking for there either.

Person1: I'm telling you, something's wrong. I've got a bad feeling about this.
Person2: You're just going to sit there? You're not going to do anything?
Person1: What can I do? I've tried calling, emailing... nothing. It's like they've vanished.
Person2: Maybe they're just busy. Maybe they're on a trip or something.
Person1: I've heard rumors of a new project they're working on. I think it's more serious than that.
Person2: Well, hope no one gets to them before we do.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly. Why should you want all Vienna to believe you're a failure? Is that your penance? Is it?
Person2: I don't owe you anything; you don't owe me anything. We worked together on that project -- what was it? -- ten or fifteen months? It wasn't memorable enough to carry any obligations.
Person1: No, you didn't! You have so much potential, but you're throwing it away.
Person2: Sometimes I really hate the way you talk down to me.
Person1: What difference does that make? You're still young, you can start anew.
Person2: You know, I used to think you cared about me, but now I realize you only care about your own reputation.
Person1: Oh, my dear, my poor dear! You're so misguided.
Person2: Don't pity me. Pity yourself. You're the one who's stuck in the past.

Person1: I'm so frustrated, I feel like I'm always a step behind in everything.
Person2: Something important may come of all this. We just need to think outside the box.
Person1: Is that a fact? Or are you just trying to make me feel better?
Person2: No, I'm serious. We can turn this around. Let's work together to get you back on track.
Person1: I appreciate your optimism, but it's not just about getting back on track. It's about finding a sense of purpose.
