Person2: I understand. Well, sometimes you need to take a risk to find what you're looking for. And I'm willing to take that risk with you.

Person1: I've never seen any of these men before.
Person2: Every day that goes by, I'm losing money. Every worker that is shot, costs me money -
Person1: What does it look like? Are you recording this conversation?
Person2: That's because he is. Does that upset you? We're going to be making so much money, none of this is going to matter -
Person1: I don't know them. It's bad business.
Person2: Take another look at these two. Occasionally, sure, okay, you got to make an example.

Person1: I've been watching you, and I think we're alike. We're both trying to make amends.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: I've done something bad, something dumb. I didn't mean to hurt anyone, but I know I did. I'm asking for your pity, for your help. Please don't tell them what I did.
Person2: Maybe you should back off and think about what you've done.
Person1: I have thought about it. I've been thinking about it nonstop. But I need your help to make it right. I need someone to stand between order and chaos with me.
Person2: I'm not sure I'm the right person for that.
Person1: You're the only one I can trust. I love you, and I know you love me too. We can fix this together.

Person1: You're full of energy.
Person2: Don't be such a Grandma, I was always getting into something.
Person1: I think you liked the thrill of it.

Person1: What's this?
Person2: Maybe. I should call Ben.
Person1: The... oh, the spire! How silly of me, it's as plain as day... You're not going to tell anyone, are you?
Person2: Then it could all come out, sooner or later. Nobody should know about this. Just you and me.

Person1: You know, I've been thinking about those self-help groups. Are they just a bunch of people trying to fix each other?
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: Well, it's like a pecking party. Everyone's trying to find someone else's flaws to make themselves feel better.
Person2: That's a pretty cynical view. Don't you think people can genuinely help each other?
Person1: Maybe. But I've seen people like Karl, who grew up with a really warped view of the world. His parents taught him that sex was wrong, and that he was a punishment from God.
Person2: That's terrible. How did he turn out?
Person1: He's got a lot of issues, but he's trying to work through them. He even wrote a whole notebook full of Bible verses to try and make sense of it all.
Person2: I'm not sure what to say. That's just so... sad.

Person1: I'm not sure what to do now. I'm not sure what he wants for me.
Person2: I ate a guy last night.
Person1: And how did you feel when you ate this guy?
Person2: I think you've done a great thing. You should be rewarded monetarily.
Person1: What do you mean? I don't remember doing it.
Person2: I mean, it takes a lot of courage to admit something like that.

Person1: I went to live with my mother's cousin and her husband in Montana. They had a ranch.
Person2: Hold me, I'm falling!
Person1: Horses and sheep. I lived there for two months.
Person2: Promise me you'll help him!
Person1: I ran away. Quid pro quo, Doctor.
Person2: Where is he? I promise, I'll help him.
Person1: After my father's death, I was orphaned. What happened next?
Person2: You're very frank, Dorothy. I think it would be quite something to know you in private life.
Person1: The significance of the moth is change. Caterpillar into cocoon into beauty...
Person2: I wouldn't be surprised if you've tried to be a lot of things, I expect.

Person1: You're no bargain either, pal. I'm tired of your excuses.
Person2: I want my freedom...I want my freedom. I'm suffocating in this relationship.
Person1: Conviction. Conviction that I'm onto the truth. You're going to do the same thing to me that you did to your previous partners.
Person2: You're going to be very disappointed. I've changed.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm ready for this promotion. I've always looked at a desk as though it were a ball-and-chain.
Person2: Ah, I think you'll be surprised. It's like practice, you know? Like when you play tennis against a wall. Some day, there'll be a partner returning the ball.
Person1: I hope so. I really want to make a difference in this company.
Person2: That's great. And I'm sure you will. You've made us look pretty good in the past week. Just remember, it's okay to take things at your own pace. You don't have to rush into anything you're not comfortable with.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you? That's the general idea. Only it's not so general as far as I'm concerned.
Person2: Well, technically, it's not a big deal. Nothing you'll miss.
Person1: You're talking crazy! What makes you so sure?
Person2: I've seen it before. We'll start with the basics and work our way up.

Person1: You're one of the top students in your class, aren't you?
Person2: Heartwarming. Really, I feel weepy. You wanted to know what happened after the project presentation, I'm telling you.
Person1: Oh come on, who do you think you're talking to? You really expect me to believe you got an A without cheating? Bullshit. You must have had help.
Person2: I studied hard for it. And I know what the word propaganda means, by the way.
Person1: Yeah. Do you know what the word accountability means?

Person1: What about him?
Person2: He's gone. Tell me why.
Person1: Let him know what he's missing.
Person2: How should I do that?

Person1: I'm telling you, it's no big deal. I can help you get out of this mess.
Person2: Heads or tails?
Person1: What's that supposed to mean? You're not making any sense.
Person2: I did something stupid, and now I'm in trouble. I need your help to get out of it.
Person1: What did you do? You're not telling me everything.
Person2: I made a mistake, okay? And now I have to face the consequences.
Person1: Wait a minute, wait a minute. You're not telling me the whole truth. What really happened?
Person2: Just go look for yourself, if you have the guts.

Person1: I want to try it here.
Person2: You're being reckless, pal.
Person1: Let them watch. I want them to see what they're missing.
Person2: I hate it when you're like this... I wish my mom were here...

Person1: I'm telling you, I saw it with my own eyes. The whole thing was suspicious.
Person2: Say what I say.
Person1: What do you mean? I'm trying to explain what happened.
Person2: No, no. Just repeat what I say. Don't think, just repeat.
Person1: Fine. You're not listening to me anyway. You're just trying to confuse me.
Person2: I'm trying to help you remember. Now, say what I say.
Person1: This is ridiculous. I know what I saw. I'm not going to play along with this game.
Person2: Okay, okay. Let's start over. How many people were involved in the incident?
Person1: I already told you, there were at least three. And I'm sure they were watching us the whole time.
Person2: That's not possible. There were only two people involved, and they were just bystanders.
Person1: I don't know why you're not listening to me. I'm trying to tell you the truth.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.
Person2: Yes--well--uh--that's another one of those statements which more or less automatically requires an explanation. Whenever you feel like it.
Person1: What do you mean? I'm being completely sincere.
Person2: Uh-huh. So, you're saying this is a chance to make a real difference?
Person1: Exactly! And I think you'd be perfect for the job.
Person2: Hey, is this the same project that Mr. Johnson was involved with last year?
Person1: Ah, no, no, this is a completely new initiative. Although, I do have a picture of Mr. Johnson with the mayor, taken when...
Person2: He's quite the philanthropist, isn't he?
Person1: Wonderful man. We were very impressed with his dedication to the community.
Person2: I see. So, what makes you think I'm the right person for this job?
Person1: Well, I've heard great things about your work, and I think you'd bring a unique perspective to the project.
Person2: Jeez, thanks. I think I'll have to pass, though.
Person1: Oh? Why's that?
Person2: I don't know, man. I just don't feel like getting involved in something that's going to take up too much of my time.
Person1: I understand. It's a big commitment, but I think it would be really rewarding for you.

Person1: You just relax, I'll check the house for you. I know it can be unsettling to enter a dark space.
Person2: But it's light in there now, I'm sure it's fine.
Person1: Please, let me do this for you. I'll call out if everything looks okay.

Person1: I've tried to stay open to voices of the people, but it's hard when you're desperate to prove yourself.
Person2: Prove yourself to who? The cool kids?
Person1: Yes, desperately. I want to show them I can contribute, that I'm not freaked out by their influence.
Person2: And if you quit, you're no better than...?
Person1: Exactly. I need to remain honest to myself and not let the temptations of their approval blind me to my own goals.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's the only way to move forward. Nobody else is going down but me, okay?
Person2: I implore you to reconsider, Mr. Thompson. Being reckless with your decisions now doesn't change what came before -- it's just foolish.
Person1: You think I'm doing this to prove something? I'm just trying to make things right.
Person2: We'll see. Let's not let one bad call lead to another.

Person1: I've been thinking about the new development project, and I'm not sure it's the right fit for our community.
Person2: You're crazy. Where's the mayor? I thought she was on board with this.
Person1: I'm telling you, one of these nights you'll wake up and find that the construction has ruined the natural habitat.
Person2: That's not going to happen. The environmental impact assessment was thorough.
Person1: They'll climb right into our backyard and destroy the ecosystem. We can't let that happen.
Person2: I'm busy, I don't have time for this.

Person1: You know, I like that scarf, Rachel. I don't know what there is about it, but it somehow makes you look more confident.
Person2: Yeah? You really think so? A lot of people been telling me the same thing.
Person1: The same place. One o'clock. I have to go now. See you tomorrow.
Person2: Remember, I need you. Take a little, leave a little. That's how we'll get this project done on time.
Person1: You're a thousand percent right! We can't afford to slack off now.
Person2: I'll make sure to tell the team. So long, see you tomorrow.

Person1: You promised to take care of me.
Person2: And if you doubt me, you'll know that I cared for you and wanted to go on caring for you.
Person1: They like you, don't they? That's why they sent you to me.
Person2: Yes. They want us to be safe together.

Person1: Are you sure you're ready for this presentation?
Person2: Hey, we all make mistakes. It's part of the learning process.
Person1: I just wanted to make a good impression on my first big project.
Person2: Let's see how much the client wants to invest. We'll fix any issues and move forward.
Person1: Thanks for the reassurance. I'll double-check my work next time.

Person1: I've never known him to say those words before.
Person2: So tell me where the documents are.
Person1: That's not his style. He always speaks the truth.
Person2: I could scoop them out.

Person1: Are you taking notes?
Person2: Just a few reminders. Does that bother you?
Person1: Not at all. I've never seen you before, have I?
Person2: We've never met, no. But I think you'll find this meeting quite...enlightening.
Person1: I'm not sure what to expect.
Person2: That's understandable. Let's just say I need your expertise. Shall we discuss the details tomorrow at one o'clock?
Person1: Sounds good to me.

Person1: You always do things without considering how they'll make me feel.
Person2: Positive?
Person1: Yes, I'm sure. You never think about the consequences of your actions.
Person2: Guess there's no way I'll ever know for sure what you're thinking.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is you need to be more considerate and communicative.

Person1: What's with the fancy car? You're going to buy a Sixty-three 'Vette Stingray?
Person2: Mph rmph rm rmph rm? Yeah, I meant... I'm going to be so sweet.
Person1: Him? I don't know... He can be nice... sometimes. You're really going to waste your third on that?
Person2: Mph rm. Rmph rm rmph rm. I'm going to buy it, and I'm going to be happy.
Person1: What do you mean?! You're going to be happy with that car?

Person1: I'm supposed to take Emma to the art museum tonight. She's really going to be upset if I don't.
Person2: Maybe she'll come with us. If I explain how important it is to me, I don't think she'll mind. Do you?
Person1: I don't know. Probably not. You know, I've been thinking... why should I want all my friends to believe I'm a failure? Is that my penance?
Person2: What do you mean? You're not a failure.
Person1: Not yet, but I will be if I don't take some risks. From now on, no one will be able to speak of my art without thinking of me. Whenever they say my name with admiration, they'll have to say it with respect. And that's my legacy.
Person2: You're being too hard on yourself. You're talented, and Emma cares about you.
Person1: Don't pity me. I just want to make a name for myself, without anyone's help.

Person1: We can't afford to wait any longer. The rent on this place isn't paid.
Person2: The situation is dire, I agree. But we have to prioritize. The dead can wait.
Person1: You're right. We need a solution, and fast. I've an idea that could get us out of this mess.
Person2: What is it?

Person1: Tell me, Rachel  just what is it that makes you so hesitant about this trip?
Person2: I don't know... I just don't know about this, Alex.
Person1: I told you last night  this can be the start of a new chapter for us. If something good doesn't come of this, I think I'll go crazy.
Person2: Alex, are you sure?

Person1: I thought this was a 45-minute seminar. I had a lunch break so I thought I'd come by and see you.
Person2: Yes, yes. I know. Right. And if it had gone well for me today, maybe I'd be keeping quiet about all this... Your teacher is a fox! Why don't we discuss that after class.
Person1: Oh look. Class is over already. I grant you everything, but give me this... he does personify everything you've been fighting against...
Person2: I'm not sure what you mean, but I'm in love with the way you think. How do you like that?

Person1: Honestly, Alex. Do you actually think I would forget where we put the spare keys?
Person2: I don't know, Maya. I don't seem to remember you actually asking me if you could invite 50 people over to our charity event.
Person1: Sometimes we have to improvise. Helping people, or righting wrongs, or trying to save the world... I don't know. It all seems so abstract.
Person2: Think, Maya. Does the community center have any friends. I mean, besides you and... me?
Person1: The community center? What's happened?
Person2: Nothing, it's just been sort of, I don't know... vandalized.
Person1: Vandalized? By who?
Person2: Some local gangs. 
Person1: Good God. Let's go fix it.
Person2: Good idea, Maya. Only one problem. I don't know where to start.
Person1: Ah. Wait a minute. The city council must know where to begin.
Person2: It's a little late to call the councilor.
Person1: Is it a little late to call the local volunteers?

Person1: I think we've been given a gift, a chance to start anew. We didn't have room for anyone in our old lives, too caught up in our own pursuits.
Person2: What makes you think we can pretend to be something we're not? We're not exactly actors, you know.
Person1: We don't have to pretend. We just need to be open to change. This new opportunity is a chance for us to grow, to learn from each other.
Person2: I suppose you're right. We do lie to ourselves sometimes, don't we? About what's truly important, about what we really need.

Person1: I don't remember you cooking dinner before. What's the occasion?
Person2: Oh, I wish you would have at least let me do the dishes. It's not going to be that easy getting all that dried-on food off my nice plates.
Person1: I don't remember us. I don't even remember me. Did I used to cook for you?
Person2: Of course, you did! You're just being dramatic. Now, give me the roast and watch your step. I'll come back for the radio.
Person1: What radio? I don't remember owning a radio.
Person2: Never mind. Just help me clean up this mess.

Person1: You're really terrific, you know what I mean?
Person2: Nothing.
Person1: I know you're hiding something. You can't fool me.
Person2: You know how people with broken bones know when there's a storm coming?
Person1: Wrong. You're not going anywhere until you tell me the truth.
Person2: I can feel it. Something's gonna blow in this town.
Person1: I'm afraid you'll hurt him.
Person2: Who are you talking about?

Person1: What do you think I am, crazy???
Person2: Your mother was a resident of Saint Catherines home before you moved her.
Person1: Oh, cut it out, will ya? This has nothing to do with her.
Person2: Well you're probably right about that. It certainly can't help to dwell on the past.
Person1: Come on, let's focus on the present.

Person1: You're straddling the state line. You're in two places at once.
Person2: What is distance?  For you, I would bridge any gap.
Person1: I am so anxious for you to meet our new community leader.
Person2: To me, you will always be the first person I think of in this town.

Person1: I'll remember that. But let me see if you can help me with something I just don't understand.
Person2: What's that?
Person1: How did you know I would have the presence of mind to react when I did?
Person2: I saw you look off when the professor nodded his head. I figured he wasn't pointing out a particularly rare concept, and the rest was easy.
Person1: But what makes you think I would have reacted the same way you would have?
Person2: Because that's what I would have done, and I think we think alike in certain situations.

Person1: Thank you for helping me. I don't remember anything. It looks like I...
Person2: You're welcome. Why would anyone do something like this to you?

Person1: I'm not sure you're doing that right. Want me to show you how it's done?
Person2: Yeah, I guess I could use some tips. But don't think you're getting out of this that easily.
Person1: Fine, fine. So, first you want to check the obvious places... then you've got to think about where they might be hiding something. Like, have you checked the lining of their bag?
Person2: No, I didn't think of that. And what's with the attitude? You're not exactly an expert.
Person1: Hey, I'm just trying to help. You don't have to get defensive. Anyway, after you've checked the bag, you should run your hands down their arms and legs... just in case.
Person2: Yeah, yeah. I think I can handle it from here. Thanks for the advice, I guess.

Person1: I've been staying in all sorts of places. Here and there. Around.
Person2: You're looking for a fresh start, huh? A chance to bend the rules and start anew.
Person1: Something like that. I'm not really sure what I'm looking for.
Person2: Well, I might be able to help you with that. I've got a place you can crash for a couple of nights.
Person1: Thanks, but I don't know if I'm ready for that kind of help. I've been trying to figure things out on my own.
Person2: I understand. But sometimes, it's okay to accept a little assistance. It doesn't mean you're not capable of taking care of yourself.
Person1: I suppose you're right. But I've been feeling like I'm just going through the motions. Like I'm stuck in some kind of illusion.
Person2: Ah, I think I know what you mean. Sometimes, it feels like the world is just a facade, and we're all just pretending to be something we're not.
Person1: Exactly! And I'm not sure how to break free from that.
Person2: Well, maybe we can figure it out together. One step at a time.

Person1: What's this?
Person2: A vintage Cadillac. I just restored it.
Person1: Oh, that's terrible... I mean, it's beautiful. I had a terrible experience with a Cadillac driver this morning.
Person2: Oh? What happened?
Person1: He cut me off, and I followed him all the way downtown. I was so angry!
Person2: You followed him? That's not like you. You're usually so calm.
Person1: I know, I know. I just couldn't help it. But then I saw the movie THE UNTOUCHABLES last night, and I think it got to me.
Person2: (laughs) You're not going to start bashing people with a bat, are you?

Person1: I'm not sure I agree with the design. Don't you think there's too much gold?
Person2: It's a family heirloom. You should speak to Grandma about it. Hold on...
Person1: I don't know, I think it's overwhelming. Look, would you argue with your grandmother?
Person2: No, but she has a story behind it. You know, she grew up in a very traditional household. Her father was very strict.
Person1: I see. Well, maybe that's why it feels so... heavy.
Person2: Exactly. It's a symbol of their heritage. Would you like to hear the story behind it?

Person1: I'm not sure what to do now. I'm not sure what he wants for me.
Person2: Well, in closing, I'd like to say that there are two reasons to have that money outside in an hour. One is the lives of tens of thousands of people--people just like you and me!
Person1: Confused? You should be rewarded monetarily. You've done a great thing.
Person2: Hey now! No need to get defensive. I'm just trying to help.

Person1: We're going to make a big splash with this new exhibit. It's going to be accessible to everyone, in full public view.
Person2: Well, it was a dark and stormy night when we first came up with the idea...
Person1: Good. Let's make sure to emphasize that in the press release. We want to create a sense of excitement and wonder.
Person2: I was thinking we could say something like, "Thank you for being a part of this journey with us..."
Person1: I like it. It's inclusive and celebratory. Let's get to work on the details.

Person1: I've got a surprise for you. Let's sneak it into the office. I know you're going to love it.
Person2: Little - couldn't be a new project, could it? Well, well! Ain't that nice!
Person1: We're going to make it a big deal. Plan a whole event around it. They're gonna forget all about the deadline...
Person2: I got it! We can say, "Thank you for your hard work, and, as importantly, Thank you for meeting the deadline..."
Person1: Getting off on the right foot? Gonna make it a great start...

Person1: What do you think about then? I mean... well what do you think about?
Person2: You went to my high-school?
Person1: No. Then how do you know about --
Person2: I don't know anything. I remember the park... I told you... I remember the swings... I think about that sometimes...
Person1: What are you talking about?

Person1: I need your help - meet me at the old warehouse. Don't be late.
Person2: Why do I let you talk me into these things? Why?
Person1: Because we're in this together, as a team. We can't let them win.
Person2: Fine, but I'm not going in there without a plan. What's the strategy?
Person1: Leave that to me. Just be ready for anything. And, by the way, love's a killer, isn't it?
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?

Person1: You really expect me to believe that? Who do you think you are?
Person2: There's a situation here that needs to be addressed. It's going to get out of hand if we don't act fast.

Person1: What's your story?
Person2: I used to work as a carpenter.
Person1: That's interesting. What made you stop?
Person2: I had to take care of some personal matters. I was asked to come here and offer my services.
Person1: Who asked you?
Person2: A great admirer of my work who wishes to remain anonymous.
Person1: That's quite unusual. Don't you think?
Person2: I reckon it's all right. I'm just happy to have a chance to start anew.
Person1: You don't seem like someone who'd be comfortable with all this secrecy.
Person2: I'm just trying to make a living, sir. I don't ask too many questions.

Person1: I've been on a hot streak, so what? There's things that I could learn from you.
Person2: Progress!
Person1: Oh yes, I'm getting to be smooth smooth smooth all over. Smooth as a baby's butt.
Person2: You eat today?
Person1: Yeah. You want to swing by the Chinks, watch me eat, we'll talk?
Person2: I love it. I'm getting to be a real girl.
Person1: You still in the market for a real boy?
Person2: Always. I think I'd better stay here for a while.
Person1: Cause there's this guy. My brother knows him. Might be right up your alley.
Person2: Tell me. I could use someone up my alley.

Person1: I'm telling you, Alex is very real and very determined to get the promotion.
Person2: Maybe he likes you, ever think of that? It's good for you to take on new challenges -- get your mind off the last project.
Person1: You're so lucky you have a clear career path and don't need to worry about office politics. I never know what to do in these situations. Do colleagues still take each other out for drinks?
Person2: They better. Of course, trouble is, you never know what they'll expect for it. You gotta know what to order, and what you're willing to commit to. Like if a colleague spends a lot of time mentoring you, they're gonna feel like you owe them something.
Person1: I never thought of it like that. I never know how to navigate these situations. "Can I pick your brain?" "How about a working lunch?" "I want to discuss the project over coffee." And my all-time favorite, the old standby, "Let's grab a drink and talk about our careers."

Person1: Hi, I'm Alex.
Person2: I'm Maya. I just wanted you to know, I didn't sleep well last night.
Person1: Sorry to hear that. I had a bit of a restless night myself. Did you hear anything strange?
Person2: Yeah, I thought I heard whispers. But it was probably just the wind.
Person1: Maybe. So, what do you do then? Want to grab a coffee and talk about it?

Person1: I suppose so. Where?
Person2: The park. I thought we were gonna meet there.
Person1: Nah, I don't think so...
Person2: See you tomorrow. Remember, I need you.
Person1: Gotta go.

Person1: Commissioner, I implore you to believe me, the new policy is very real and very necessary.
Person2: What? You're crazy. Where's the Mayor?
Person1: He's on my phone. He just called me.
Person2: We'll see.

Person1: Honestly, Alex. Do you actually think I would sabotage your project without telling you?
Person2: I'm busy, Rachel. What's this about?
Person1: Sometimes we have to improvise. I found out that the funding for our project has been cut.
Person2: What? That's impossible! Where's Dr. Lee?
Person1: He's on my phone. He just called me. We need to act fast to save our project.
Person2: They can't do that to us! We've worked too hard.
Person1: Think, Alex. Does Dr. Lee have any connections that could help us?
Person2: Ah, wait a minute. The Dean must know something about the funding. Let's go talk to her.
Person1: Good idea, Alex. Only one problem. I don't know if she'll see us on such short notice.
Person2: Maybe... I don't know. But we have to try.

Person1: I didn't mean to imply you're not capable. You're just not ready for this kind of responsibility.
Person2: I guess not. I didn't mean to give you that impression. I'm just trying to find my place here.
Person1: You bet your life it's tough. Maybe it keeps all of us going. You need to focus on your strengths and find a role that suits you.
Person2: How do I do that?
Person1: Honestly, it takes time and patience. You can't rush into things without thinking them through. I've seen people get hurt that way.

Person1: I don't know. It just seems...kind of weird.
Person2: Don't listen to me. Can't you see I'm trying to figure this out?
Person1: Are you sure? You're not just saying that to make me feel better?
Person2: Yeah. I'm positive. We should celebrate our victory. You and I can go out and mark the occasion.
Person1: But then what? You're going to give all this stuff away to charity?
Person2: Why not? It's not like we need it anymore. And it'll do some good.

Person1: Do you have a family, someone you need to say goodbye to before we leave?
Person2: The same place. One o'clock. I have to go now.
Person1: Wait, what's going on? You're not listening to me. If we have to be outside the country, where do you want to go? Any country.
Person2: See you tomorrow. Remember, I need you.
Person1: Fine, I'll be back.

Person1: You're really beating yourself up over this, aren't you? It's like you're stuck in a rut.
Person2: I like your scarf, it brings out the colour in your eyes.
Person1: Thanks, I just threw it on. I'm not really thinking about my appearance right now.
Person2: Maybe you should. Sometimes a change in perspective can help you move forward.

Person1: Hey, Captain, I've got something you should take a look at.
Person2: What's the big deal, Jenkins?
Person1: A security tape from the museum heist last night. The thief was dressed like a medieval knight.
Person2: Shut up, Jenkins. You're telling me a guy in armor robbed a museum in broad daylight?
Person1: I'm just saying, it's weird. And he used a sword to break the display case.
Person2: Jenkins, I need you to focus. We can't let this guy get away with it.

Person1: You've never even had one manually?
Person2: Well, that's the State's offer. If you take the course and tell us what we want to know, your certification will be granted within a month. If you don't, we'll have to request a review, and that could take up to six months.
Person1: Who's side are you on?
Person2: I'm just trying to help you make an informed decision. You want to think about it? You've got two minutes before we're up.
Person1: What if I refuse?
Person2: You might not get certified at all. With your prior experience, you could get anywhere from a year to five years of additional training depending on the board.

Person1: I'm glad you're finally back. What did you learn on your journey?
Person2: I learned that true happiness comes from within. But I'm also anxious to get started on my new project.
Person1: That's great to hear. I'm sure you'll make a real difference. But don't you think that your ambition might be a bit too lofty?
Person2: Not at all. I'm willing to put in the hard work to achieve my goals. And I'm confident that I can make a positive impact.
Person1: I hope so. It's always a pleasure to see someone striving to make a difference. But don't forget to take care of yourself along the way.
Person2: Don't worry, I will. And who knows, maybe one day I'll be able to look back on my accomplishments with pride, just like you are doing now.

Person1: I'm sorry, I don't understand.
Person2: It's not important. The important thing is I've an idea that will get us out of all this.
Person1: Is that a fact?
Person2: Yes. We haven't twopence between us, but we've got these resources.
Person1: Like it? This new plan of yours?
Person2: Yes. It reminds me of a project I worked on back home.
Person1: Where's that?
Person2: A small town a few hours from here. But let's focus on the task at hand. We can make this work.

Person1: Tell me, what makes you think we have enough for one ticket? 
Person2: I don't know. I was just hoping we could scrape together something. 
Person1: Think. Maybe we're overlooking something. 
Person2: Wait, I got it! We could ask those kids over there if they want to pool their money together. What do you think?

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a miracle when you come down to it. We'd have had an amazing team, you and me. We'd have had a ride.
Person2: Every day that goes by, I'm losing clients. Every project that falls through, costs me reputation - I have to rebuild trust, I have to rebrand -
Person1: Life gets messy. Ugly messy. But I don't understand you. You're throwing away potential.
Person2: Some of the partners went rogue, what're you going to do? You're right, it's bad business, but it's done. Occasionally, sure, okay, you got to make an example.
Person1: I want the possibilities. And all kinds of crap comes with that. A lot of bad shit. And I think that's okay with me because, because of the rest of the stuff. All the good shit. All the surprises.
Person2: We're going to be making so much progress, none of this is going to matter -

Person1: Do you remember when you were fascinated by the world of art? You wanted to learn everything about the masters, about their techniques.
Person2: Mm-hm.
Person1: I've told you stories about the Impressionists, but I don't think I've shared everything I know. There's still so much to explore.
Person2: Like what?
Person1: Well, have you heard about the Russian fairy tale of the Firebird? It's a story about a magical bird that brings both fortune and misfortune to those who capture it. I think you'd find it fascinating.

Person1: I've been thinking about our vacation plans. We should take a break from the city.
Person2: That sounds great. I could use some fresh air.
Person1: Sometimes you can't know what I'm doing. It's better that way.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: I've been looking into this new opportunity. It's a long shot, but it could be worth it.
Person2: What kind of opportunity?
Person1: A chance to discover something new. I'll know more in a few months.
Person2: And if it doesn't work out?
Person1: Then we'll take that vacation. I promise.

Person1: You're really charming, aren't you?
Person2: I try to be. What brings you here today?
Person1: I confess, I tricked you into meeting me. I needed to see you again.
Person2: I'm flattered, but I'm not sure I'm ready to rekindle anything. We never really shared a connection.
Person1: You're right, I was foolish to think otherwise. You look great, by the way.
Person2: Thanks, you too. But let's not pretend this is a social call. What do you want, Lex?

Person1: You mean like, a private viewing?
Person2: For me? Dr. Furtwngler was absolutely clear about this: art should be accessible to everyone.
Person1: I'll remember that. But let me ask you, what's the secret to making art appealing to a wide audience?

Person1: You're straddling the state line. You're in two places at once.
Person2: Sit down. I've got a proposal that could change your life. Better than being stuck in this rut. Ball's in your court.

Person1: I'm a coffee person myself. We don't have much trouble with traffic where I live...
Person2: You will. One of these mornings you'll wake up and find the roads jammed. You don't think about what you're doing and you'll be late for work.
Person1: All right, I'll let you drive. You can help me navigate through the rush hour, and I'll stay and help with the breakfast instead.

Person1: I'd really like to know why all you guys are so crazy about him. What's his secret?
Person2: You told me.
Person1: What are you talking about? I've never mentioned him before.
Person2: Oh! The evening before, I see... You must have mentioned it then.
Person1: No, I'm certain I didn't. Are you trying to confuse me?

Person1: I've been searching for a place to belong for a long time. When I'm with you, I feel like I've finally found it.
Person2: You ride with me, then.
Person1: Oh, I'm more than sure. Anything happens to this community I can tell you right now, you don't wanna be the one responsible.
Person2: I already have you, in a way. You're already home.

Person1: You've made us look pretty good in the past week.
Person2: You deserve it is the occasion.
Person1: What do you mean? I didn't do anything special.
Person2: Exactly. You've been doing your job without seeking attention or praise. That's worth recognizing.
Person1: I suppose you're right. I just wish I could do more.
Person2: You're doing enough. And who knows, maybe one day you'll get the opportunity to take on more responsibilities.

Person1: What's on your mind? You seem troubled.
Person2: I was just thinking about the consequences of our actions. If we're not careful, it could lead to a dangerous situation.
Person1: I see what you mean. But we're not like that, are we? We're not reckless.
Person2: No, but we can't control how others behave. My father used to say that our actions have consequences, and we must be mindful of them.
Person1: That's wise. I'm sure your father was a good teacher.
Person2: He was. He taught me to think about the impact of my decisions on others. I just hope others will do the same.

Person1: I've been trying to get in touch with her for days. I've sent her flowers, telegrams, and even asked her to dinner. 
Person2: That wouldn't have done any good. Not with her. She's the most incredible creature I've ever seen. 
Person1: I told you that I was doing fifty miles an hour when I saw her. That's how I remembered it. But the truth is, I might have been doing sixty. Or sixty-five. 
Person2: You can't imagine what she looks like. Timeless. When she comes into a room, you'd think that the whole atmosphere changes. 
Person1: Because if I was over the limit when I saw her, what would happen then? 
Person2: You saw all that in one glimpse? 
Person1: Darling, if we're going to get anywhere, someone has to keep their eyes open! 
Person2: That would complicate things.

Person1: What's the point of waiting, then?
Person2: I sleep on it, hoping things will clear up.
Person1: But between the time you decide to wait and the moment you figure things out, what changes?
Person2: Nothing matters, I've come to realize.
Person1: Exactly. That's what I'm getting at. You could change everything in that time.

Person1: Lay off, we're gonna be fine.
Person2: Do you know how many times I've been in a situation like this, praying someone like you would calm me down?
Person1: Shut up, I'm trying to think.
Person2: You're not exactly the most reassuring person, you know that?
Person1: Hey, I'm just trying to help.
Person2: Help? You're making it worse.

Person1: I'm sorry I doubted your skills. You really pulled off that project.
Person2: Thanks, I was sure trying. But what's the real reason you're apologizing?
Person1: Simons liked the way we worked together and put us on the new project. I think we make a good team.
Person2: That's great news! But what's the plan of attack for this new project?
Person1: I was thinking we could start by brainstorming together. What do you think?
Person2: Sounds like a good idea. But first, can we forget about our past disagreements and start fresh?

Person1: I need your help with a project. Yes or no.
Person2: What's involved?
Person1: You'll be contacted with the details. But I must warn you, it's a matter of great importance. The fate of our community depends on it.
Person2: I'm in. What do I need to do?
Person1: You must appear to live your life normally, conveying nothing. Can you do that?
Person2: I think so. But what about my family? Can I tell them?
Person1: No, no one must know. Especially not them. You must be prepared to keep this secret, no matter what.
Person2: I understand. What's my code name?
Person1: Let's call you... Alexander.

Person1: We're going to make a splash at the art exhibition. 
Person2: Plans?
Person1: Rachel. 
Person2: Oh man, I met her at the gallery opening and I had all that champagne. You know, those little flutes. I gave her a toast before I realized... she's a art critic... Jesus, she's never even seen my work.
Person1: Well... It'll probably work out. We can keep her impressed and showcase my art at the exhibition.

Person1: Dr. Patel, there is something I've been meaning to ask you for some time...
Person2: Yes, what's on your mind?
Person1: You know what we do to people who can't pay their debts, don't you?
Person2: I think I can work out a payment plan. I haven't got the full amount right now.

Person1: I implore you to believe me, I'm not giving up on my dreams.
Person2: I think you know I'd support you even more if you ended up pursuing a career that makes you truly happy.

Person1: You look like someone who needs their space sometimes. Am I right?
Person2: Yeah, I do. What makes you say that?
Person1: You have this air about you, like you're always prepared to fight them off. I mean, not literally, but you know what I mean.
Person2: (laughs) I think you're reading too much into it. I just like to keep to myself, that's all.
Person1: I understand. I've been in situations where I needed to protect myself too. It's not about the other person, it's about self-preservation.
Person2: Exactly! You get it.

Person1: So, I've been thinking about having a talk with you.
Person2: About what?
Person1: Well, the whole gamut. Facts of life and all. Some sisterly advice, because, I tell you, there's things happening that you're probably old enough... well... 
Person2: Progress!
Person1: Oh yes, honey. Getting to be smooth smooth smooth all over. Smooth as a baby's butt.
Person2: I love it, sis. I'm getting to be a real woman.
Person1: You still in the market for a real friend?
Person2: Always.
Person1: Cause there's this person. My friend knows them. Might be right up your alley.
Person2: Tell me. I could use someone up my alley.
Person1: Handsome, thirties, artist... loves animals...
Person2: Loves animals? Must love animals, sis.
Person1: Loves animals. Loves you.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: Somehow it came up that you were a friend of mine. Mr. handsome, animal-loving artist said he would love to meet you.
Person2: That's so sweet! Your friend didn't tell him about the nature of our relationship, did she?
Person1: My friend is discreet.

Person1: I want it all. You guys want guarantees?
Person2: Where?
Person1: The possibilities. And all kinds of crap comes with that. A lot of bad shit.
Person2: The same place. One o'clock.
Person1: But I think that's okay with me because, because of the rest of the stuff. All the good shit. All the surprises.
Person2: I have to go now. See you tomorrow.
Person1: It's a miracle when you come down to it. We'd have had amazing children, you and me.
Person2: Remember, I need you.
Person1: We'd have had a ride. You'd have surprised yourself.

Person1: I could scoop them out.
Person2: We'll start with your most recent memories and go backwards. There's a story to each of our experiences -- As we uncover this story, it starts its revelation process -- By the time you wake up in the morning, all experiences we've targeted will have unfolded and revealed themselves. Like a sunrise upon dawn.
Person1: Is there any sort of risk of emotional turmoil?
Person2: Well, technically, the process itself is a journey of self-discovery, but on a par with a night of deep reflection. Nothing you'll regret.

Person1: I've been thinking about my freshman year counselor, Noah. He's the one who inspired my latest book.
Person2: That's interesting. I've been taking a long view on life lately.
Person1: What do you mean by that? Is it about understanding human behavior?
Person2: Exactly. I've come to realize that people's actions can be influenced by their past experiences.
Person1: That's true. My friend Hazel, for instance, has a unique perspective on life after what happened to her family.
Person2: Yes, and I'm sure you've learned a lot from her. But sometimes, it's necessary to take a step back and look at the bigger picture.
Person1: You're right. I should focus on the overall story, not just the individual characters. Thanks for the advice.

Person1: I've got a proposition for you. There's a chance to make some real money.
Person2: What kind of money?
Person1: Ten grand, easy. But I need you to do something for me.
Person2: What's the catch?
Person1: You'll find out when the time is right. Just remember, it's not the first time I've offered someone a deal like this.
Person2: What happened to the others?
Person1: Let's just say they didn't make the most of the opportunity. But I think you can do better.

Person1: I've been thinking about our trip west... You know, Sailor and Lula are really something.
Person2: You have lovely hair, even if you torment it in those braids.
Person1: I like plaits. They're comfortable for traveling.
Person2: You're spoiling your pretty looks. But I'm glad you're excited about the trip.
Person1: Yeah, I'm in a great mood. My very best to everyone we meet along the way.

Person1: We should retreat, it's not worth the risk. We might be able to regroup and come back stronger.
Person2: I've scouted ahead, and I think we're clear. It looks like a false alarm.

Person1: You're spoiling your pretty looks. Come here.
Person2: I like plaits. They remind me of our past.
Person1: We never really shared one.
Person2: That's not true. You're just not terribly important to me right now.
Person3: (entering the room) What's going on here?
Person1: (nervously) Nothing. Just a disagreement.
Person2: (smiling) Yes, just a little misunderstanding.

Person1: I want you to have pearls. Nice big pearls.
Person2: Why? Why do you insist on that? I'm not comfortable with such extravagance.
Person1: Oh, come on! Let's have some drinks and celebrate. You deserve it.
Person2: Celebrate what? My mediocrity? You're just trying to distract me from my own failures.
Person1: Failures? You're being too hard on yourself. You have so much potential.
Person2: Potential? Ha! It's all just a facade. I'm just a shadow of what I could have been.
Person1: Don't be so dramatic. You're not a tragic figure.
Person2: Aren't I? You don't know what it's like to be overlooked and underappreciated.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a mistake. He's not the one.
Person2: Tell me why I should believe you. You're the only one who benefits from this.
Person1: That's not true. I have proof. I'm the one who's been wronged.
Person2: Then why are you so nervous?

Person1: I think I've had one.
Person2: What kind of concerns do you have about the new project?
Person1: We haven't fully identified the anomalies yet. It's calling this whole area The Innovation Hub...
Person2: Of course, it does. What about you? Have you just never had a breakthrough idea with your team  or have you never had one, period?
Person1: The Enterprise can be at your position in two days, Manager...
Person2: That's probably not a good idea. Your team hasn't been fitted for this region; there are environmental concerns...

Person1: Now that is a happy sound! You're finally feeling better, aren't you?
Person2: I'm such a loser. I don't know how I'll ever recover from this.
Person1: That's the spirit. You'll get through this, and we'll celebrate tonight.

Person1: I'm equally impressed with your knowledge of the art world. How long have you been a curator now?
Person2: Five years. I came over from the Modern Art Museum in New York six months ago.
Person1: We pretend to understand the concept of modern art, but sometimes I think it's just a lie.
Person2: Simpler. We just don't get it. But I think that's what makes it so fascinating.
Person1: Did you hear about the new exhibit opening at the City Gallery? I heard it's going to be a game-changer.
Person2: Actually, I heard it's just a rehash of what's been done before. But I'm willing to give it a shot. Would you like to grab coffee and discuss it further?

Person1: You look different today.
Person2: You could call it that. My style's changed.
Person1: Me too. I feel like I've got something to look forward to.
Person2: Yeah, I know what you mean. Everything looks new.
Person1: Exactly! I don't remember ever feeling this excited. Do you feel wide awake?
Person2: Uh, yeah... I guess so. What's gotten into you?
Person1: I don't know, but I think it's a good thing. Want to try something new with me?
Person2: Like what?
Person1: I'm not sure yet, but it'll be fun, I promise.

Person1: Tell me, just what is it that makes you so confident in your abilities?
Person2: Don't mind me, I'm just a bit inexperienced, is all. I don't mean to cause any trouble--
Person1: That the problem, son? You lack experience?

Person1: I grant you everything, but give me this...you do personify everything I've been fighting for.
Person2: What's the surprise?
Person1: Uh-uh, not yet. We better have a drink first.
Person2: Here, this'll put hair on your chest.
Person1: You better put on the lights. I can't see what I'm doing.
Person2: No, no lights. We don't want anyone to know we're having a party.
Person1: I may spill something.
Person2: So spill it. Spills, thrills, laughs, games - this may even turn out to be a surprise party.

Person1: I'm upset because I can't really justify being upset. I mean, it's your decision, really, you're the one who's been working on this project.
Person2: But I thought you were on board with the changes. What's really bothering you?
Person1: I guess I'm bothered because you didn't ask for my input. You just went ahead and made the changes without consulting me.
Person2: I didn't think it was a big deal. I thought we were on the same page.
Person1: We are, but it's the principle of the thing. You're always showing me how to bend the rules, but sometimes I wish you'd just ask me what I think.
Person2: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to make you feel like your opinion doesn't matter.
Person1: It's not that. It's just that sometimes I feel like I'm just along for the ride, and I wish you'd let me take the wheel sometimes.
Person2: I'll try to do better, okay?

Person1: I'm not going down without a fight. You can either speak up now or face the consequences.
Person2: No, I won't be intimidated. They need guidance, and I'm the only one who can provide it.
Person1: Guidance? You're the one who's been wallowing in sin and lust. You're not fit to lead anyone.
Person2: That's not true! I'm a respected figure in this community, and I won't let you tarnish my reputation.
Person1: Respected? Ha! You're a hypocrite, and everyone will see it once the truth comes out. It's either you or me, and I'm not going to back down.
Person2: Fine, do what you think you have to do. But you'll regret it.

Person1: I'll remember that. But let me see if you can help me with something I just don't understand. I'd really like to know why all you guys are so crazy about this new hiking trail. What's its secret?
Person2: Someone will follow. When you come to the river, they will tell you how to go on the other side. You can go with Alex as far as the river.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's like I'm stuck in a rut. I feel like I'm just going through the motions every day.
Person2: What's wrong? You can talk to me.
Person1: It's just... I don't know, I feel like I'm not really living anymore. I'm just existing. And it's frustrating because I don't know how to change it.
Person2: Maybe you're just feeling a little restless. You know, like you need a change of scenery or something.
Person1: Yeah, maybe. But it's not just that. It's like... I don't know, I feel like I'm not good enough or something. Like I'm just not doing anything right.
Person2: That's not true. You're a great person. You're just being too hard on yourself.
Person1: Am I? Or am I just not trying hard enough? I don't know, it's like... I feel like I'm just pretending to be someone I'm not. And it's exhausting.
Person2: You're not pretending to be anyone. You're just being yourself. And that's enough.

Person1: You're all just jealous.
Person2: I know it's you, Alex. I'm not going to talk to you unless we can discuss it seriously.
Person1: Who's this 'Alex'? Are you trying to make me laugh?
Person2: I'm serious, Alex. We have to resolve this issue once and for all.

Person1: I wish I were a nice guy with the conscience of a rebel. Next best thing to no conscience at all.
Person2: Why do I let you talk me into these things? Why?
Person1: Because we're partners in crime - the two outcasts. Come on, you can do better than that. Give me a reason.
Person2: You make me out to be a socialite, but I'm just trying to survive.
Person1: I can come down next week and help you navigate the scene.
Person2: No, I don't think that's a good idea. We can meet in public, but respectably, without all the drama.
Person1: And after the coffee... do we send the paparazzi away and turn the spotlight off?
Person2: Oh, stop it!

Person1: I'm telling you, it was a long time ago... I met her at this art gallery... We... became friends... She told me about a new exhibit...
Person2: What's so special about it?
Person1: I don't remember... Anyway, Sophia's okay... She's got some interesting friends.
Person2: The plot thickens. I'm sure the curator will love that.

Person1: I don't need your help, I can handle this on my own.
Person2: It would be a pity to squander such a strong personality. You're not just fighting for yourself, you're fighting for those who believe in you.
Person1: That's not fair, you're trying to guilt trip me into doing what you want.
Person2: I'm just trying to make you see the bigger picture. You have the power to make a difference, don't waste it.
Person1: Fine, I'll do it my way. But don't say I didn't warn you.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly. You can't just sit around waiting for a miracle.
Person2: Look out of that window. Sometimes you have to believe in the impossible.

Person1: I just wanted you to know, I'm glad you're here.
Person2: You realize now you could never have done it without me.
Person1: Actually, I could have done it much more easily without you, but for whatever reason, I'm glad you're here.
Person2: Hi, by the way. I'm Rachel.
Person1: I'm Mike.

Person1: I'm telling you, Alex, this new marketing strategy is a mistake. It's going to alienate our core customers and result in a huge backlash on social media.
Person2: I didn't ask what the focus groups think, Rachel. What do you think? Do you really believe it's a bad idea?
Person1: Honestly, I think it's a sign of corporate cowardice. We're trying to appeal to everyone and ending up with a watered-down message that resonates with no one.
Person2: Well, I think you're being too harsh. Maybe we just need to tweak the approach. Can you walk me through the file you've been working on? I want to understand the thought process behind it.
Person1: Uhh, sure... let me just... ah... okay, so the main issue is... (pauses) Wait, do you know anything about marketing analytics? I'm having some trouble with the data.
Person2: (laughs) Yeah, I know a thing or two. Let me take a look. What's the error message you're getting?

Person1: Are you Lorl, the maidservant?
Person2: Yes, sir. I was asked to come here and offer my services to you.
Person1: I've seen things in my life that the mind can't fathom. What makes you think you can handle what I need?
Person2: I'm not sure, sir. But I'm willing to try. What is it that you need help with?

Person1: I'm trying to better myself, but I feel stuck.
Person2: How long have you been feeling this way?
Person1: I'm not sure. It's like I'm waiting for someone to give me a push.
Person2: And that's a bad thing?
Person1: I think I need someone to believe in me, but I'm not sure who that someone is.
Person2: Maybe it's yourself you need to believe in.
Person1: That's easy to say, but hard to do.
Person2: Want to grab a coffee and talk more about it?
Person1: I'd like that. But can we make it a walk instead? I need some fresh air.
Person2: Sounds perfect.

Person1: I suppose so. Where?
Person2: The same place. I'm hired to do a piece of work, my mark goes down and stays down.
Person1: What're you talkin' about? You're not from around here, are you?
Person2: I'm outta Portland. I have to go now. See you tomorrow. Remember, I need you.
Person1: That's a lotta crap. You're not taking care of business...or should I say, not taking care of it.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm the right person for this job.
Person2: Then it's fortunate that I have you to rely on. In the meantime, I instruct you to review the project proposal and get back to me with your concerns.
Person1: I wasn't going to say that I'm not qualified, but that's what you were thinking. And that's okay. Because I know you trust me.
Person2: You are a master of understatement. We need to discuss the project's potential risks and benefits.

Person1: I've got a long view on this project. It's going to be a hell of a price for the company to pay.
Person2: I understand your concerns, but frankly, you were the best. Your designs can't be matched by computer models.
Person1: I appreciate your kind words, but what's the point of taking a long view if we can't even keep our work?
Person2: Well, it's the least I can do. Why don't you go out there and look over the designs, pick the one you like the best, and take it with you? Just run it by me first, in case.
Person1: Thank you. I would miss working on those designs too much.
Person2: We've got work to do, let's focus on the project at hand.

Person1: I've been warning you about these people, they're not what they seem.
Person2: We were just talking, I don't think they're a threat.
Person1: You're not listening to me, they're looking for an angle, they see an opportunity and they'll take it.
Person2: Okay, I'll be more careful.
Person1: You need to be careful, I've seen it before, people get taken in and then it's too late.
Person2: How many times has this happened?
Person1: Too many, I've lost count. It's a pattern, and I don't want you to be the next one.

Person1: I think I've had one.
Person2: You capitalist pig! What more do you want?
Person1: The experience is free, what more do you expect? I've set that old camera up as a prop and I'll get Jahn to write out a script.
Person2: Of course you do. Well that's a no. No wonder you're not psyched about this project.

Person1: I'm surprised to see you kids rummaging through my attic. What's the story?
Person2: We're not just kids, we're "talented". The school principal wants us to have our own project room!
Person1: My niece is talented, well how about that. I knew you were exceptional.
Person2: So I guess you'll need to find a new spot for your antique collection.
Person1: I suppose so. By the way, do you think it's a pleasure to find your home so welcoming; your family so fond of you, that they're even now thinking of your future?
Person2: Is it not a comfort to see them; like a prudent family, getting everything ready for your next step?

Person1: I'll call you.
Person2: You're spoiling your pretty looks.
Person1: That's right. I like plaits.
Person2: Oh yeah? You're crazy.
Person1: See you later.
Person2: Come here, I want to talk to you.

Person1: I've been searching for you everywhere, Sophia. I know it's treason to love you in this war-torn city, but not to love you is treason against my heart.
Person2: Then we'll both be rebels, Alex. But tell me, what happened to your father? He was a hero, wasn't he?
Person1: He was a firefighter... one night he surprised an arsonist, coming out the back of a burning building... They shot him.
Person2: Killed outright?
Person1: No. He was strong, he lasted almost a month. My mother died when I was very young, so my father had become the whole world to me... After he left me, I had nobody. I was ten years old.
Person2: You're very brave, Alex. I think it would be quite something to know you in private life. But I have to ask, what happened next? You didn't stay with your mother's cousin, did you?
Person1: No, I ran away... I couldn't bear the thought of being trapped in one place.
Person2: I understand. Sometimes, we have to take risks to find our true selves. But I think you're close to finding what you're looking for, Alex. You just need to trust your heart.

Person1: I've been trying to make it up to you.
Person2: You could have poured coffee in Starbucks, you could have learned to install track lighting in office buildings... You could have been one of ten thousand things, but in the end, you chose to focus on rebuilding our relationship. I find that very, very interesting.
Person1: Apologies don't instantly heal wounds, I know. It's the actions that follow. But I'm committed to regaining your trust.
Person2: Trust takes time to rebuild. Be patient.

Person1: I don't remember the planet's coordinates anymore, Captain. Where's the navigation system?
Person2: It takes a few minutes to recalibrate. And a few more to plot a new course...Now, let's focus on the task at hand, Lieutenant. I instruct you and your team to beam down to the planet's surface. We need to assess the damage.
Person1: We'll be happy to beam down, sir. But first, we need certain assurances about the planet's stability.

Person1: I feel awake. Everything looks different. You know what I mean.
Person2: I genuinely believe my approach is the right one. It's frustrating when others don't see it that way.
Person1: I'm on your side. I think your vision is exactly what the project needs. Sometimes I feel like we're fighting this battle alone.
Person2: That means a lot. Together, I think we can persuade the others to see things our way. It's good to have someone who shares my enthusiasm.

Person1: I don't know why you're pushing me to go out with him.
Person2: Maybe he likes you, ever think of that? It's good for you to get out, take your mind off things.
Person1: Please, just tell me where the party is. I want to make sure I'm not running into anyone I know.
Person2: Don't worry, it's at my place. You'll be safe. So, are you going to tell me what's really going on with you and Alex?
Person1: I don't know what you're talking about.

Person1: I never thought about it that way.
Person2: Exactly, and that's why I think we should focus on the bigger picture. Your mother's experience at Saint Catherines home could be relevant.
Person1: What do you mean? I don't see how that's connected.
Person2: Well, Dr. Furtwngler would say that we need to separate the personal from the professional. Maybe we're getting too caught up in the details.
Person1: I'm not sure I agree. Sometimes the details are what matter most.

Person1: I'll just be a little more careful next time.
Person2: Childhood is over, we can't keep running. It's time to grow up and face reality.
Person1: And I'd end up a widow in two ways if we don't. Let's forget it and focus on getting out of here.
Person2: There isn't gonna be a next time. We're gonna take control of our lives now.

Person1: We need to get out of here, now! Grab the documents, and let's make a run for it.
Person2: What's the plan? Where are we headed?
Person1: I've arranged for a ticket to Buenos Aires. Flight 217. Departs at midnight.
Person2: That's a long way. What's waiting for me there?
Person1: A fresh start. You'll be doing me and my colleagues a great service.
Person2: You've certainly thought this out, haven't you?
Person1: I'm not someone who leaves things to chance. But we need to move, now. We can't afford to wait.
Person2: Alright, let's do it. But I'm not going to be tied down. I'll make my own decisions from now on.

Person1: I'm afraid there's been a mix-up, Captain. I was never told about your inspection.
Person2: Yeah, I guess you deserve a look around. Right's right. This is a beautiful facility.
Person1: I tried to clear things up, Captain. I explained you'd come all the way from headquarters to study our security protocols, but they don't seem to know anything about it.
Person2: Twombley sure as hell won't be in charge of security again.

Person1: You look like you've been through a rough night. What happened?
Person2: I don't know. I don't remember. It smells like I've been drinking, though.
Person1: You must've fallen into the river. You're soaked to the bone.
Person2: I guess so. I sleep a lot when I'm like this.
Person1: But what do you do between leaving the bar and passing out? You could've done anything in that time.
Person2: I wish I knew. It's like my brain just shuts off.

Person1: I'm telling you, Alex, I can't believe you kept all those old notes. 
Person2: I know, I know. It's just that I try to remember why I started this project, and I can't. It all seems so abstract now. 
Person1: Bullshit. I see you pouring over those notes, asking questions. You're trying to figure something out. What is it?

Person1: We're all tired. None of us had any sleep since Friday night.
Person2: I've been feeling out of place with everyone else. They don't seem to get me.
Person1: It's okay to be different. And I'm here to help you through whatever you're feeling.
Person2: That's the only reason I'm still trying.

Person1: Look out of that window. The city is alive tonight.
Person2: I'll find her, I have to.

Person1: Dr. Patel, there is something I've been meaning to ask you for some time...
Person2: Yes, Rachel? 
Person1: Who do you think you're dealing with, huh? I'm willing to cut you a break, doctor!

Person1: You're saying we just need to move forward? 
Person2: Sir, they voted me most likely to succeed!
Person1: Not even behind your back? 
Person2: Fine. Do you want the entire project to fall apart? 
Person1: You're not taking this seriously. 
Person2: You really want that on your head?

Person1: The plot thickens. It appears that Dr. Marx has been hiding something.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Say it. You were her doctor, weren't you?
Person2: I was her doctor.
Person1: You were there to help her, were you not?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: What's your plan of attack now that the truth is out?
Person2: I'm not sure, but I think we need to be careful.

Person1: I think I get it. You're trying to tell me something, but in your own way.
Person2: What do you get?
Person1: That you care about me, but you're not sure how to express it.
Person2: That's right. I love you too, in my own way.
Person1: I appreciate that. But can you explain what you mean by "in my own way"?
Person2: Well, I'm not good with words. I just know that I feel something strong for you.
Person1: That's okay. I understand. Sometimes it's hard to put feelings into words.
Person2: Exactly. But I want you to know that my feelings are genuine.
Person1: I believe you. And I feel the same way about you.

Person1: I'm telling you, I've got a crisis of conscience. I've got more wealth than I know what to do with.
Person2: I understand, Mr. Johnson. But can you resist the temptation to use it for personal gain?
Person1: You know darn well I can. I've built my empire from scratch.
Person2: I see the truth of it. You're a man of great ambition. But will you use your wealth to benefit others, or just yourself?

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you?
Person2: It would be a pity to squander such a strong personality.
Person1: I've got a reputation to uphold, and I won't let you undermine it. Come on, let's get this over with.
Person2: Shhhh. Let's not be too hasty.

Person1: I just want you to know, I appreciate everything you've done for me.
Person2: Why would anyone do something like this? It's like they're waiting for something to happen.
Person1: That might be the news we've been waiting for. Maybe it's a sign of change.

Person1: I just wanted you to know, I'm going to donate all these old clothes to charity.
Person2: Are you sure?
Person1: Yeah. I think it's the right thing to do.
Person2: It just seems...kind of weird.
Person1: Why? I don't feel bad about it. Unless you feel strange about giving it away.
Person2: No, I mean, I remember my aunt wearing some of this stuff, but...I don't feel funny about that. I really liked her.
Person1: And she really liked you. She would've given you all this if she'd outgrown it, or... So, what do I do then?
Person2: Just pack it up and drop it off at the church. They'll take care of it.

Person1: I've got a surprise for you. Check out that new rifle on the wall. It's a beauty, isn't it?
Person2: Yeah, it's impressive. Who does it belong to?
Person1: That's the one Twombley was bragging about last week. I heard it's only been fired once.
Person2: That's hard to believe. It looks like it's been well taken care of.
Person1: Yeah, Twombley sure knew how to take care of his things. But I guess that's not going to be a problem anymore.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: Let's just say Twombley won't be needing it again. And honestly, I think it's better off with us.

Person1: What's going on? You seem really shaken.
Person2: I'm just thinking about what happened at the party last night. I'm worried about Alex.
Person1: What about Alex?
Person2: I think he might have gotten into some trouble. He was acting really strangely and then took off with some suspicious people. I'm afraid something bad might happen to him.
Person1: I'll go with you to check on him. We can't just sit around and do nothing.

Person1: I don't think you'll have time for that meeting after all.
Person2: You know me...I never miss a deadline. Where's the report?
Person1: Your colleague said she didn't know where you were, so you shouldn't have told her about the project if you're hiding something.

Person1: I've been on the road for months, never staying in one place for more than a night or two. Can you switch to another station? This music is driving me crazy.
Person2: I know the feeling. Sometimes I think it's better to take a long view, focus on the bigger picture.
Person1: But what's the bigger picture when you're constantly on the move? You start to lose track of what's important.
Person2: That's true, but sometimes you have to make sacrifices for the greater good. We've got work to do, and it's only a matter of time before we see results.

Person1: Did Christmas come early this year...?
Person2: Of course he does. What about you?
Person1: And why should continuing excellence cost more?
Person2: You've never even had one manually?
Person1: Is it December?
Person2: Well that's a no. No wonder you're not psyched about this deal.
Person1: And you're our thirty-percent partner?
Person2: I think I've had one.
Person1: Cost less. That's the point.
Person2: Are you kidding? You've never double-checked the numbers?

Person1: You know my friend Alex? 
Person2: Yeah. 
Person1: Well, you know how he loves extreme sports, right? Anyway, last week he's trying out this new skydiving gear... 
Person2: What? Come on! 
Person1: I'm sorry, 'cause you know Alex, the guy's a total thrill-seeker, and this is the last person you'd want this to happen to. 
Person2: Is he okay? 
Person1: Yeah, he's fine. But it got me thinking about my own brother who died in a skydiving accident. 
Person2: I'm so sorry. 
Person1: Yeah, me too. It was a long time ago, but it still hurts. 
Person2: I can imagine. Do you want to talk about it? 
Person1: Nah, it's okay. Let's talk about something else.

Person1: I'm supposing.
Person2: If I can speak freely, I think you're a nice person. I like you.
Person1: But I can read signs if the print is large enough. It was your manner more than anything that caught my attention.
Person2: Well, I mean really sharp, why you just have to see it some time. A real big change, like a new perspective, can make all the difference.
Person1: General, stick to the point, please. What do you think is the key to success in this situation?
Person2: Hell, yes! I think having an open mind and being willing to adapt has one hell of a chance of making a positive impact.

Person1: I want you to stand like that until you're sick of it because I don't ever want to see it again, you hear me?
Person2: You're being unfair. I distinctly heard the coach say it's okay to try again.
Person1: No, I'm not. We were walking off the tennis court, and you know, he was there and me and his wife, and he looked at her and then they both looked at me.
Person2: That's not what happened. You're a total paranoid.
Person1: Wh- How am I a paranoid? Well, I pick up on those kind o' things. You know, I was having lunch with some guys from NBC, so I said... uh, "Did you eat yet or what?"
Person2: Stop bringing up old stories. This is about your behavior on the court.
Person1: Fine. But I think I have a few minutes left to practice. Right?
Person2: Yes, you do. But let's focus on your game, not your conspiracy theories.

Person1: We know what makes a community strong, don't we? We know that no individual can be an island.
Person2: That's correct, ma'am! We're all connected.
Person1: Not that one, though. Or that one. They're always causing trouble.
Person2: (laughs) Oh, you mean the local troublemakers?
Person1: (smiling) Yes, exactly. Anyway, I was saying that my father was a town marshal...
Person2: Oh, really? What happened to him?
Person1: He was shot by burglars. He lasted almost a month, but it was tough on me. I was only ten years old.
Person2: I'm so sorry to hear that. You must have been very close to him.
Person1: I was. He was my whole world. After he left, I had nobody. I went to live with my mother's cousin and her husband in Montana.
Person2: A ranch, right? What was that like?
Person1: It was okay. I only lasted two months, though.
Person2: Why did you leave?
Person1: I just couldn't take it anymore. I felt like I didn't belong.
Person2: I understand. Sometimes we just need a change of scenery.

Person1: I've been searching for a place that feels like home. You know, that sense of belonging.
Person2: Negative, I've scouted the entire area. No signs of life. It's a ghost town.
Person1: Perhaps the same energy drew us to this place, yesterday.
Person2: Roger that. I'll keep searching. Over.

Person1: I'm telling you, if anyone tries to take advantage of me, I'll stand up for myself. I'm strictly on the up and up.
Person2: That's great, but sometimes you have to be open to new experiences. Like going on a date, for instance.
Person1: A date? Are you kidding? I don't know what to expect. Do guys still pay?
Person2: They better. But seriously, it's not about who pays, it's about being respectful. If someone's genuinely interested in you, they won't try to manipulate you.
Person1: Exactly! I won't stand for anything crooked or unfair. If someone's caught trying to take advantage of me, I'll...
Person2: Whoa, slow down. It's not about threats or violence. It's about being confident in yourself and your worth. If someone's not respecting you, then they're not worth your time.
Person1: You're right. I just want to make sure I'm not getting taken for a ride.
Person2: That's fair. Just remember, it's okay to say no and set boundaries. And if someone's not respecting those boundaries, then they're not the right person for you.

Person1: I've been noticing you've been getting more and more into this hobby. Do you believe it's changing you for the better?
Person2: Honestly, I'm not sure. But I know you're looking out for me.
Person1: Of course, I care about you. You know, I was telling my kids about this old legend of a helper who would visit naughty children at night. It's a funny story, but it got me thinking about how we all need someone to keep us in check sometimes.
Person2: Yeah, I can see that. Maybe we all need a little reminder to behave ourselves every now and then.

Person1: You're really taking a chance on that new employee, aren't you, Jack?
Person2: Depends on how well she works out. I'm giving her a shot.
Person1: That college chick? I heard she's got skills.
Person2: Yeah, she's been doing great so far. My dad's store could use some fresh blood.
Person1: I bet it's more like she's bringing some fresh ideas to the table. You're lucky to have her.
Person2: Yeah, I feel like I've made the right call. And hey, it's not like Twombley's going to be giving me a hard time about it anymore.

Person1: I've been thinking, there must be a way to get out of this situation.
Person2: You can't believe everything you think, sometimes the best option is to accept reality.
Person1: But what if I told you I found a loophole? 
Person2: I'd say it's too good to be true, and even if it wasn't, it's probably not worth the risk.
Person1: You're right, it's a long shot, but I'd rather try and fail than not try at all.
Person2: That's a noble sentiment, but sometimes you have to know when to cut your losses.

Person1: I'm surprised you're still friends with Rachel.
Person2: Are you still in touch?
Person1: Not really. The last time I saw her was at that art gallery. That was a long time ago.
Person2: Which one?
Person1: I don't remember the name. It was in the city center.
Person2: The Modern Art Space. That was a long time ago.
Person1: You didn't visit her when she was going through a tough time.
Person2: She didn't want me to. She was different after her mom passed away, looking at life in a different way.
Person1: But you spoke to her on the phone.
Person2: She'd call every once in a while.
Person1: She called the day she got the new job.

Person1: It's time to go home now. We'd forgotten about the party!
Person2: Damn right! I don't seem to remember sending out invitations.
Person1: Oh, but I forgot! It was a surprise party. That explains it.
Person2: No. Please. Can't we just stay a little longer?

Person1: I've had no direct communication with the board since this whole thing began. And that's quite verifiable.
Person2: You're offering me a chance to get out of this mess, aren't you?
Person1: I can always use someone with your skills on my team. Come work for me.
Person2: What makes you think I'd be interested?
Person1: I'm sure you'll enjoy the ride. I've taken care of all the arrangements.
Person2: And what exactly do you get out of this deal?
Person1: Let's just say it's a mutually beneficial arrangement. You'll think about my offer?
Person2: I wonder what the CEO would think about it. If I spoke with him.
Person1: I've already spoken with him myself - and told him the deal was on the table. Don't play politics with me, you'd be out of your league.

Person1: I'm not good at lying.
Person2: You've got to learn to control people if you want to be a successful detective.
Person1: It's against my nature. I'd rather focus on finding clues.
Person2: Clues can be misleading. Sometimes you need to get inside the criminal's head.
Person1: But how do you do that without manipulating them?
Person2: That's the art of interrogation. You've got to make them think you're on their side.
Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with that.
Person2: Then maybe this isn't the job for you.

Person1: I've decided to take on a new project at the Museum.
Person2: And you've brought one of the artifacts with you, I see.
Person1: It's a fool's game, trying to preserve the past.
Person2: So is violating the curator's rules.

Person1: Do you ever think about your past?
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: I mean, do you ever wonder what your life was like before we met?
Person2: Honestly, no. I don't really think about it.
Person1: That's strange. I think about my past all the time.
Person2: Yeah, well, I remember the way here, sort of. And I remember this place and you. That's about it.
Person1: How do you remember how to talk, then?
Person2: I'm not really sure. It just comes naturally, I guess.
Person1: That's amazing. I wish I could forget my past sometimes.
Person2: Why's that?
Person1: Because it's painful. But I guess it's what makes me who I am today.

Person1: I'm sorry, Professor, if I...spoke out of turn. It's just that...I don't remember this place. I don't even remember how I got here.
Person2: What are you talking about? You're one of my top students. You've been in this program for three years.
Person1: I don't remember you. I don't remember this program. I don't even remember my own name.
Person2: Listen, let's take a break. We can discuss this further in my office. Maybe we can figure out what's going on together.

Person1: I've been watching you, studying your moves. I think I know what you're after.
Person2: Oh yeah? Well, I've got a proposition for you. Heads or tails?

Person1: Excellent. I've heard that you folks make one hell of a croissant.
Person2: That's what people say. I've been trying to perfect the recipe for years.
Person1: You know, I caught a glimpse of your bakery when I walked through the market. You can't imagine the aroma that wafts out of there.
