Person2: (laughs) Well, I'm glad someone appreciates it. We put our heart and soul into every pastry.
Person1: Timeless. When you take a bite, you'd think that the essence of French patisserie had taken over the city. You wear your apron as though it were the latest model by a renowned chef.
Person2: (laughs) You're quite the charmer, aren't you? But I think it's the passion that goes into making each pastry that makes it special.
Person1: Now, tell me, what's the secret to your famous chocolate filling?

Person1: I've been reviewing your application, and I have to say, it's surprising how easily you've managed to hide your true intentions.
Person2: What are you talking about? I've been completely honest.
Person1: Save it, kid. I've seen your type before. You think you can just waltz in here and get what you want without putting in the effort? Well, let me tell you something - it takes more than just charm to get ahead in this industry. You're going to have to prove yourself to me, and that's not going to be easy.

Person1: I've got to get you to the hospital, Paul. The roads are open, and I called the head orthopedic surgeon. He said as long as there's no infection, you're not in any danger.
Person2: I'm shyer than you think. I give the wrong impression sometimes and... I was supposed to be home for my daughter's birthday three days ago.
Person1: Your agent said she would tell her you were okay. But I'm afraid you'll have to wait until tomorrow if you want to speak to her yourself. You're beautiful... your skin glows.
Person2: Thanks. But I just want to take a bath and... The phones are working, right? I need to call my daughter.
Person1: Well, mine's still out. But the ones in town were working just fine. I called that agent of yours. Oh, Paul, I peeked at the very beginning. What a wonderful first page--just to read the name Misery Chastain...

Person1: I want to be fair. I don't deny that you might make out some kind of a case.
Person2: Get lost, you're wasting my time.
Person1: We haven't anything to discuss with you. We'll talk to someone who can help us.
Person2: It would be a pity to squander such a strong personality. Maybe you should reconsider.

Person1: I'm not going to let you walk all over me.
Person2: Look out of that window. You're not even in my league.
Person1: This is so condescending. You think you're better than me?
Person2: I don't think, I know. And it's not about being better, it's about being realistic.
Person1: You're just trying to make me feel small.
Person2: If you feel small, that's on you. I'm just stating the obvious.
Person1: You know, I used to think you cared about me.
Person2: I do care, but that doesn't mean I have to coddle your ego.

Person1: You think you're ready for this?
Person2: Are you crazy? I've been preparing for months.
Person1: I had a friend who went through a similar experience. He didn't make it.
Person2: Sorry to hear that. But I'm not your friend. I can take care of myself.
Person1: I'm just trying to warn you. It's not going to be easy.
Person2: I appreciate your concern, but I need to focus on my own goals. Let's talk about something else.

Person1: You're all just jealous.
Person2: But my mother says I mustn't accept gifts from strangers.
Person1: Stranger? You're not a stranger to me. I've seen your performances on stage.
Person2: Ah, yes. Those were beautiful, golden days. But I think we're getting off track. What's this about being jealous?
Person1: Nothing. I just wanted to return this gift you sent me.
Person2: The gift? We'll have no more nonsense about the gift.

Person1: I don't think you should take their threat seriously.
Person2: But they said if I didn't comply, they'll make sure I regret it.
Person1: They're only trying to scare you, that's all.
Person2: You're not the one they're threatening. It's easy for you to say that.
Person1: We may have a chance to resolve this. Let's talk to a lawyer.
Person2: I'm not sure that's a good idea. They might make things worse.
Person1: We have to try. We can't just give in to their demands.
Person2: I suppose you're right. But I'm still worried about what they might do.
Person1: Hey, I'm on your side. Remember that. We'll get through this together.

Person1: I've been desperate for a change of scenery. How long have you been in this city?
Person2: I don't remember. Is that what you wanted to ask me?
Person1: Actually, I was thinking of trying something new. Did I tell you about my last trip?
Person2: No, what happened?
Person1: I met some interesting people. You should try it with your friends. It's an interesting theory.
Person2: Yeah, I'll think about it. Thanks for the suggestion.

Person1: I want you to stand like that until you're sick of it because I don't ever want to see it again, you hear me?
Person2: Thank you so much. You're always so supportive.
Person1: Is it sabotage, does my career mean nothing to you? Have you no human consideration?
Person2: I'm just trying to help, but I guess I'm not doing it right.

Person1: Do you always begin conversations this way?
Person2: You're really terrific, you know what I mean.
Person1: My father was a great storyteller, and he taught me to appreciate the art of conversation.
Person2: I have to go.
Person1: Wrong. You're just getting started.
Person2: I know, but I really must be off.

Person1: You know we're right.
Person2: I want to go home.
Person1: It'll be like a weight off your shoulders.
Person2: What are you sorry for?
Person1: For not being able to make it work out.
Person2: Once it's spent, you won't have to worry about it.

Person1: I'm still getting used to the city noise... it's overwhelming.
Person2: You're adapting quickly, though. I think you may be a very gifted observer.
Person2: I ruin so many moments by analyzing them when I should just be living them.
Person1: Then why don't you start practicing and keep your mouth shut for a while?
Person2: I guess some people have it and some don't. But I think you're doing well.

Person1: You want to work uptown nights?
Person2: Nobody else is going down but me, okay?
Person1: I'll work anywhere, anytime. I know I can't be choosy.
Person2: Bein' ballsy with your life now doesn't change what came before -- it's just stupid.
Person1: I'll take any shift. I need the work.
Person2: Let's just not let one bad call lead to another.
Person1: My driving record is clean. Real clean.
Person2: Thanks for the tip.

Person1: You realize, we're gonna have a big party tonight, so if you wanna invite somebody, do it now ... You gotta a favorite food or drink? If we gotta make it special, what would you like?
Person2: Spider-Man is a good guy. On the side of right, and niceness, and cute baby animals and all that.
Person1: What? That's not what I asked. Fine, we'll have Spider-Man themed snacks then.

Person1: You're telling me you actually went through with it?
Person2: Makes two of us. I'm still trying to process it.
Person1: I know what you mean. I've been thinking about the consequences too.
Person2: Exactly. It's not just about us, is it?

Person1: I'll be observing from the corner, don't introduce me. Let them wonder who I am.
Person2: They'll be focused on you, trying to figure out your role.
Person1: Exactly, and that's when we'll know if they're worthy of the project. We can't have anyone who's too curious.
Person2: Understood, sir. We'll monitor their reactions closely.
Person1: And if they ask too many questions, we'll have to reevaluate their participation. Time is of the essence, and we can't afford any distractions.

Person1: You're not such a bargain, you know, conceited and thoughtless and messy...
Person2: He was a town marshal... one night he surprised two burglars, coming out the back of a drugstore...
Person1: I don't want to be childish, I'd settle for just a few years...
Person2: My mother died when I was very young, so my father had become - the whole world to me...
Person1: Am I going to lose you, Alex? Am I?
Person2: You're very frank, Rachel. I think - it would be quite something to know you in private life.
Person1: How childish are you going to get before you quit it?
Person2: After your father's death, you were orphaned. What happened next?

Person1: Think for a moment, is there someplace I said I wanted to go?
Person2: You mentioned a cliff overlooking the ocean. You said it was your favorite spot.
Person1: That's right. I did say that. And I remember why I wanted to go there. It was to say goodbye, one last time.

Person1: I'm glad you're back, brother. You were a lot of help with those projects. Your skills are bad-ass.
Person2: I'd hoped I was finished with all that. But I guess I still have a lot to learn.
Person1: You know, you're lucky to have this opportunity. Most people don't get a second chance.
Person2: Don't I know it. Every friend I knew in my old life is gone. My old company... it was a dead-end job. I'm just glad to be out of there.
Person1: Mind if I ask you something? Why'd you put up with that job for so long?
Person2: I was scared to take a chance, I guess. But I'm trying to be brave now. Please don't think I'm awful for being so dumb back then. I love this new opportunity and I don't want to ruin it.

Person1: You know my friend Rachel? 
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: I decided to help out at the local animal shelter with her. 
Person2: See, you brought one of the dogs with you too.

Person1: You didn't take the job at the studio. 
Person2: I didn't want to. 
Person1: Why not? 
Person2: I don't know. It's a different kind of deal. 
Person1: But you spoke to the director on the phone. 
Person2: He'd call every once in a while. 
Person1: He called the day the project was greenlit. 
Person2: He did? I don't remember. Did he say about me? About the script? 
Person1: He said he wished the two of you could start over, make a film that would really matter. 
Person2: Huh. Problem is, Alex's idea of a film is just a blockbuster. It's all he's ever done. 
Person1: Did you know that when you signed on? 
Person2: He said he was a visionary. I could live with that. I never knew he was just in it for the money till the project started to fall apart  if you can imagine something like that happening, comes out of nowhere and the whole thing's a mess. I did go see him to tell him I was walking out. He said, "Okay." Alex's so easy going. He was fun, but never what you'd call a real partner.

Person1: I'm not sure what to make of this whole situation. What do you think is going on?
Person2: I think he's trying to control her. He's obsessed with her, and he'll stop at nothing to get what he wants.
Person1: That's a pretty serious accusation. Do you have any evidence to back it up?
Person2: Well, I've seen some things that make me think he's capable of it. And I've heard rumors about his past behavior.
Person1: Rumors aren't enough to convict someone. We need concrete evidence.
Person2: I know. But I have a feeling about this guy. He's not what he seems.
Person1: Okay, let's say I believe you. What do you propose we do about it?
Person2: I think we should investigate further. See if we can find any proof of his wrongdoing.
Person1: Alright, let's do it. But we need to be careful. We don't want to jump to conclusions or accuse someone falsely.
Person2: Agreed. Let's get to the bottom of this.

Person1: Are you sure you want to do this?
Person2: Curiosity got the better of me.
Person1: Then why are you here?
Person2: These are my creations, I'm proud of them.

Person1: I've been feeling really stuck in my life lately. I'm thinking of taking a break and traveling for a bit.
Person2: Are you sure that's what you need? Sometimes getting away can be just a distraction from dealing with the real issues.
Person1: Maybe you're right. But I feel like I'm just going through the motions and not really living. I need to shake things up.
Person2: I understand that. But you should also think about what you're hoping to get out of this trip. Is it just a way to escape or do you have a clear idea of what you want to achieve?
Person1: That's a good point. I guess I just want to feel more alive and connected to the world around me.
Person2: Well, maybe we can brainstorm some ways to help you achieve that without having to leave everything behind. Sometimes the answers are right in front of us, we just need to look at things from a different perspective.

Person1: I want you to find the missing documents.
Person2: And you think I'm the right person for the job?
Person1: Yes. You've shown me you can uncover secrets. Now, will you trust me to guide you through this?
Person2: Why not? You're not one to praise someone's abilities until they've proven themselves, are you?

Person1: We're running out of options, aren't we?
Person2: Meet me at the old warehouse. I have a plan, but we need to move fast.
Person1: What makes you think this will work?
Person2: Desperation can be a powerful motivator. And I'd rather not see anyone get hurt.

Person1: You're still awake, aren't you?
Person2: Yeah, I'm still awake. My mind's racing.
Person1: I know the feeling. Sometimes I feel like I'm carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders.
Person2: You're not alone, Rachel. We're all in this together.
Person1: It's just that everything looks different now. I feel like I've got a new perspective on life.
Person2: That's a good thing, isn't it? Having something to look forward to?

Person1: I've been thinking, what kind of friend was I that I could bail out on you like that? It got to where I couldn't look you in the eye, knowing I'd left you hanging.
Person2: Legend has it you're king of the road, but I guess that's just a myth.
Person1: I can make it right, though. I can help you get back on track. Only...it's not about proving anything to each other anymore. It's about what's best for both of us.
Person2: You're crazy, man. But I appreciate the offer.
Person1: I mean it. I won't fight you on this anymore. We can work together.
Person2: No more waiting in the dark...I promise.

Person1: I've got a feeling this place is cursed. There's no one here but the dead.
Person2: (holding up a gun) Ah, you're interested in firearms? This is a beautiful piece of work. Brand new, very fancy tooling. Probably fired one time.
Person1: (skeptical) What's the story behind it? Who did it belong to?
Person2: (smirking) Let's just say its previous owner won't be needing it again. Right's right.
Person1: (uncomfortable) I don't think I want to know any more. It's very dangerous to assume you know what someone wants.
Person2: (leaning in) Oh, I think I do. And I think you'll find this place has a way of getting what it wants, too.

Person1: You're the expert. Ask me anything.
Person2: If I wanted to understand you again, I'd do it sober.
Person1: What do you mean?
Person2: I mean, I can see through your facade. You're not as confident as you seem.
Person1: That's not true. I'm just trying to get to know you better.
Person2: Save it. I have a lighter density under Earth's gravitational force, remember? I can see right through you.
Person1: Okay, fine. But can you at least tell me how old you are?
Person2: Thirty-five. And I weigh 195 pounds, if you must know.
Person1: That's amazing. You're like a superhero or something.
Person2: I'm not a superhero. I just have certain... abilities.

Person1: I'm telling you, Emily, I didn't sleep well last night. I kept hearing strange noises outside my window.
Person2: That's weird. I had a restless night too. You're not going anywhere until we figure out what's going on. If there's no explanation, we'll have to investigate further.
Person1: What do you mean? You think someone was outside my window?
Person2: I don't know, but we can't just ignore it. We need to get to the bottom of this.

Person1: I've known Rachel for more than ten years, Alex. We're old allies.
Person2: You mean he murdered someone and did time back in Chicago. The guy's a freak.
Person1: I was waiting for the right moment to tell you that. But she wasn't interested. Not my fault.
Person2: Well, lucky for me I found out. Thank God I have friends like Emily. Look, I'm sick of talking about Rachel. Let's talk about you.
Person1: It might have worked. Really. I would have been delighted for you if it had. But you're terrible, Alex.

Person1: I'm surprised you're not more ambitious, considering your talent. Or is ambition only valued in certain circles?
Person2: Well, lucky for me I have friends who look out for me. Let's focus on your strengths instead. What do you think you can bring to the table?

Person1: I'm feeling too curious to let it go, but that isn't what I meant - I meant you're being evasive. For instance, what's with all the gold decorations in your office?
Person2: Look, would you question your doctor's decor?

Person1: I've been thinking about your problem. You're studying everything, asking questions. I know exactly what you're doing.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean? You think I'm looking for a prince or something?
Person1: No, no. I'm not the guy to sponsor you. It would be unethical. But, there is something I could do for you. Introduce you to my friend who owns a mini-golf course.
Person2: Mini-golf? You've got to relax, baby. I'm just trying to learn.

Person1: I've heard rumors of a new discovery in the city.
Person2: It's been months since we've heard from him. It's not like him.
Person1: Perhaps he's found something that's changed his priorities. He knew me, he knew I would be fascinated by it.
Person2: And not a word of it to Father. He's agitated enough not hearing from him.
Person1: I should go and investigate. I should leave today.
Person2: If it's true, it could be life-changing. But we need to be cautious, we don't know what we're dealing with.

Person1: Do you know who that is?
Person2: SAY IT!
Person1: I've been searching for you since I was a little boy. You're the one who ruined my family.
Person2: I got that...sir. But I didn't mean to.
Person1: You didn't mean to? You destroyed everything we had. Now it's my turn to take something from you.

Person1: I'll work anywhere, anytime. I know I can't be choosy.
Person2: It's surprising how easily a member of the press can purchase information from the men in your department.
Person1: What do you mean? I'm just looking for a job.
Person2: I mean that sometimes people will do anything for a story. Or a promotion.
Person1: I'm not looking for a story. I just need a job with a steady income.
Person2: And I'm not looking for someone who will compromise our department's integrity. How's your driving record?
Person1: Clean. Real clean. As clean as my conscience.
Person2: Good. We can't have anyone with a questionable past working for us. Fill out these forms and give them to the girl at the desk, and leave your phone number.
Person1: I don't have a phone. Can I check back tomorrow?
Person2: Yes, that's fine. We'll be in touch.

Person1: You're not going to let me take a look, are you?
Person2: It's okay, forget it. I'll be fine.
Person1: You're not fine. You're being ridiculous. Let me see it.
Person2: It seemed absolutely real, I'm telling you. I know what I saw.
Person1: Seemed, not was. You're not thinking clearly right now.

Person1: You know how stubborn Jack is. Says he's gonna quit the team... and I say, "Jack, you can't do that," and he says, "Well, then get Coach down here and let's settle this" and I say, "Coach is in a meeting, Jack," and...
Person2: Jesus, first the captain, now you. You two need to calm down.

Person1: What's this?
Person2: A family heirloom.
Person1: The... oh, it's beautiful! How silly of me, it's as plain as day... Where did you get it from?
Person2: My brother left it to me. He was a flyer, you know.
Person1: I'm so sorry to hear that. I had a big brother who died in a similar way.
Person2: Yeah, it's tough. But I'd rather not talk about it right now.

Person1: I'm not sure I trust this new opportunity.
Person2: You always do that!  Anyways, this is really hard, because, you know, my mentor is really demanding.
Person1: We may have a chance, but it's a very slim one.
Person2: I want to be fair. I don't deny that you might make out some kind of a case.

Person1: I've been trying to go easy on you, but this can't continue. We need to address the issues.
Person2: Is Grandma Harper alive?
Person1: Alive and hale. She's throwing a little surprise party for her own family. I understand you've been overwhelmed with all the other projects on your plate.
Person2: She's a real heavy sleeper sometimes. I've been trying to prioritize, but it's not working out.
Person1: Why don't you take a break--son. You know what my English literature teacher said about you?
Person2: She said you were legendary. I wrote a theme about you, and she said, "Your father is a legendary hero out of the Golden Age of Heroes."
Person1: That's nice. You thank her for me. Let's work on a plan together to improve the situation and meet expectations.
Person2: Tomorrow's Saturday. Anyway, she's been helping me with my projects, and I really appreciate it.
Person1: Penelope! I mean, I'm glad to hear that. Scat!

Person1: I'm not good company. I should be alone.
Person2: Do you think I have it, a sense of belonging here?
Person1: Definitely. I think you may be a very gifted observer of human nature.
Person2: You don't have to do this. Show me a good time, I mean.
Person1: Where are we? It's not like I've been here before.
Person2: We're at the city square. It's where life happens, and people come to escape their routines. I come here sometimes... when I feel like being around others.

Person1: How long have you been interested in art?
Person2: Well, I guess some people have an eye for it and some don't.
Person1: Do you think I have an eye for it?
Person2: Definitely. I think you may be a very talented artist.

Person1: I distinctly heard it. He muttered under his breath, "You're not taking this seriously."
Person2: You're being paranoid again. Nobody else is going down but you, okay?
Person1: What, you think I'm overreacting? I was having lunch with some guys from the office, and I said, "Did you eat yet or what?" and Tom said, "No, didchoo?" Not, did you, didchoo eat?
Person2: Ah, you see conspiracies in everything. Let's just not let one bad call lead to another.
Person1: Stop patronizing me. You know, I was in a meeting and I know there's this big tall blond guy and he's looking at me in a funny way and smiling and he's saying, "Yes, we have a sale this week on team-building exercises." So I know what he's really trying to tell me very significantly.
Person2: Right, you're being ballsy with your life now, but it's just stupid. Bein' reckless with your career doesn't change what came before.
Person1: Thanks for the tip. I think I have a few minutes left before the meeting. Right?
Person2: Yeah, you should get going. And try to calm down, okay?

Person1: You're really pushing it, aren't you? I said I'd move if a cripple came.
Person2: What's the matter? You think you're king of the road or something?
Person1: I can make it to the meeting on time, that's no sweat. Let's just run in and pick out some outfits.
Person2: It's a two-hundred dollar fine if we're late!

Person1: I'm grieved to keep you or any gentleman waiting. Had you not better to arrange with my assistant or get the chef to flavor my dish with a special ingredient?
Person2: Show me a human and I might have! You're not ready yet, looking like a mess - is it sabotage, does my project mean nothing to you?
Person1: I hope that you are not thinking of leaving us soon, partner? Who knows how long I may keep you waiting.
Person2: Not so soon, my dear, as you may fancy perhaps. Why, man, I have been given over many times these four years, and there was always a candidate or two waiting to apply for the situation.
Person1: Sir, let those laugh that win. Corbleu, partner, do you think that it will be the fear of your departure will deter me?

Person1: How long have you been back from 'Nam?
Person2: I don't remember. Is that what you wanted to ask me?
Person1: Yeah... You were a lot of help with those guns. Your soldier skills are bad-ass.
Person2: I'd hoped I was finished with all that. But...
Person1: You know, you're lucky to be back. Most people struggle to adjust after serving.
Person2: Don't I know it. Every friend I knew in the service is still trying to find their place. My company... we all went our separate ways. Twenty of us scattered across the country.

Person1: Ever since I was a little girl, I remember hearing about the family recipes. The secret ingredients, the cooking techniques passed down through generations. When my sister got married and had kids...
Person2: You mean I can have the recipe book?
Person1: Well, that's what I implied, isn't it?

Person1: I'm not going to the party.
Person2: Say what I say.

Person1: I'm going back to that old hobby of mine. You know how I've missed it.
Person2: Don't even think about it. It's not worth the trouble.
Person1: We'll be fine. I've invited the Watsons over to celebrate.
Person2: That was the plan. And you're thrilled to have them.
Person1: Whatever you say. Did I tell you I got a huge advance on my new project?
Person2: Before I forget, put the contract on the bookshelf.

Person1: You go around here expecting applause for the way you treated this child.
Person2: Oh, you're talking about the treasure? I found it, by the way.
Person1: Who the hell do you think you are? You're not even sorry for what you did.
Person2: Yeah, right. Why don't you show it to your "friend"? I'm sure they'd love to see it.
Person1: I couldn't stand being around you, knowing you liked them. It wasn't worth our friendship.
Person2: Do you hear something, Captain? Sounds like someone's trying to guilt trip me.
Person1: You're out of the cool crowd, you know that? Next time, you're not getting any special treatment.
Person2: Good one, Captain. You do sound like a rat fink.

Person1: You're not who you say you are, are you?
Person2: Don't change the subject! I want you to take your sister and get out of that town. Don't tell anyone where you're going -- especially not him -- just GO.
Person1: Okay, you're having an emotional crisis. You need to seek the help of a trained professional.
Person2: Think about it, Alex! Everything he's done recently has been peculiar, right? He's said and done things your brother would never do ...
Person1: Whoever you are, don't call again. You're scaring me.
Person2: Don't hang up ... I know what I'm talking about. I've seen the way he looks at you.

Person1: I'm telling you, I don't want to be the Shill anymore. It's getting old.
Person2: Ah, come on, you're great at it. You're like an Academy Award winner.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is I'm tired of being insulted and crying all the time. I want to play the Inside.
Person2: We sat here and went over this, remember? You're the Shill, and Gordo plays the Inside. We can't change it now.
Person1: You're talking in circles. We didn't go over this already. I'm not buying it.
Person2: Okay, fine. But let me ask you, do you want to jinx it by changing something up? We got it down cold.
Person1: You're wasting my time. I'm paying good money for this, and I expect better.
Person2: Well, okay, I'll talk to my boss...

Person1: What's going on?
Person2: It was dead, wasn't it?
Person1: How long have you been planning this?
Person2: Years, why? You're not going to turn me in, are you?
Person1: I'm just trying to understand. You're not making any sense.
Person2: Oh, come on. You're not that naive. I know you've been checking up on me.
Person1: I didn't mean to pry. I'm sorry.
Person2: Forget it. There's a party at the mansion tonight. Want to come with me?
Person1: I don't know...I have a bad feeling about this.
Person2: Don't be such a worrier. It'll be fun, I promise. And who knows, you might even find something that interests you.

Person1: You're going to have to take care of your sister now, Emily. Your father's condition is serious, and I won't be able to work as much.
Person2: Don't bullshit me, Mom! You're just saying that because you want me to drop out of college. You don't care about my education.
Person1: Emily, honey, I'm telling you this now so you can prepare yourself. We'll need your help to make ends meet. You can't just abandon us in our time of need.
Person2: If you really cared about me, you'd want me to finish my degree. But no, you just want to control my life.

Person1: You're not listening to me. You're too caught up in your own world.
Person2: What do you mean? This is my chance to finally make a difference.
Person1: Make a difference? You're just trying to impress her, aren't you? It's definitely her, not the cause.
Person2: That's not fair. I'm trying to do something good here.
Person1: Good? You're just trying to ease your own guilt. You're as guilty as the Nightingale Murderer.
Person2: What are you talking about? That has nothing to do with this.
Person1: Doesn't it? You're trying to change the course of events, just like your father did. And look what happened then.
Person2: That's not the same thing. I'm trying to prevent a tragedy.
Person1: Prevent a tragedy? You're just trying to manipulate the situation to your advantage. Just like your father manipulated the case file to catch the Nightingale Murderer.
Person2: That's not true. I'm trying to do what's right.
Person1: What's right? You don't even know what's right. You're just trying to justify your own actions.

Person1: You honestly don't know, do you? You can't even see what's in front of your own eyes.
Person2: I must have felt some lump in his back when I bumped him. Most guns have a black or silver handle. I had a fifty-fifty shot at the color.
Person1: That's not what I witnessed, Rachel. You're trying to deceive me, just like you've been doing all along.
Person2: Stop messing with my life, Michael. My sister almost shot me last night. She wanted to prove you were right.
Person1: You have a problem, Rachel. Somewhere along the line, one of your bones broke, and your mind just broke with it. You're trying to manipulate me, but I won't fall for it.
Person2: You're the one who's been manipulating me, Michael. You're the one who's been controlling my every move.

Person1: You're not going to tell her about us, are you?
Person2: What are you talking about? I love Rachel, I would never hurt her.
Person1: Save it, Alex. I know all about your little games. You're just trying to get inside my head, aren't you?
Person2: You're being paranoid. I'm just trying to have an honest conversation with you.
Person1: Honest? You call that honest? You're the one who's been lying to Rachel all along. You're the one who's been playing with her feelings.
Person2: That's not true. I care about Rachel deeply. And I care about you too, in my own way.
Person1: Your own way? You mean like how you care about your own ego and your own power trips? You're a master manipulator, Alex.
Person2: You're just jealous because you can't control me. You can't control the situation. And you know what? I'm not going to let you control me either.
Person1: We'll see about that.

Person1: You think you're so darn smart, don't you?
Person2: I'm the one who got ripped off! Not you, not the company, me! I'm the one being ripped off!
Person1: Bullshit. You're just trying to cover your tracks.
Person2: News-flash, Rachel. I have evidence. I have the emails, the receipts, everything.
Person1: So now you're trying to play the victim? That's rich coming from you.
Person2: I'm not playing the victim. I'm telling the truth. You're the one who's been lying to me from the start.

Person1: Don't cause a scene, Alex. No one's trying to win any 'rounds'.
Person2: Calm down. Tell me what's wrong. You're being really touchy about this.
Person1: Something awful happened last night. I don't think you want to know.
Person2: Alex, you have to tell me. What do you mean?
Person1: It involves your sister. She... took advantage of me.
Person2: Does your father know?
Person1: If he knew, he'd kill me. It happened at your house last night.
Person2: Why didn't you do something? You're not making it any worse, are you?
Person1: I don't know. I'm not trying to make it worse. You are. Me and your sister could've worked this thing out.

Person1: You're too trusting, that's your problem. Nice gets you nowhere in this business.
Person2: I'm not naive, I know what I'm doing.
Person1: Oh, really? Then why are you still working with him? He's dirt, a manipulator, and you're just playing into his hands.
Person2: That's not true! He's been good to me, and I owe him.
Person1: You owe him? Ha! He's got you right where he wants you. Let me talk to him, I'll tell you what to say. If you get me what I need, I'll make sure you're rewarded.
Person2: I don't know...I'm not sure I can trust you either.
Person1: Trust me? You don't have a choice. Either you do what I say, or you'll be left with nothing.

Person1: You were asleep when I got home, yes?
Person2: Yeah, I must have dozed off. What's with the third degree?
Person1: I'm just curious. You didn't answer my calls.
Person2: I didn't hear them. You know I'm a great copy editor, but maybe not a great reporter.
Person1: What's that supposed to mean?
Person2: Just that you're good at getting things in order, but sometimes you need to grab the bull by the horns.
Person1: And you think you're the one to teach me that?
Person2: I'm just saying, you don't want a life of chaos. You like control.
Person1: You're one to talk. You're always pushing my ideas to the side.
Person2: That's not true. I've used five of your ideas, remember?
Person1: Yeah, and I've been wondering why you really did that.

Person1: You're playing with fire, and I'm trying to look out for you. What if I told you there's a way to reclaim what's rightfully yours?
Person2: That's just a pipe dream. You're trying to manipulate me.
Person1: Am I? Or am I showing you a way to rise above the ashes of your past? You deserve so much more than the hand you've been dealt.
Person2: And what's in it for you?
Person1: Maybe I just want to see you thrive. Or maybe I want to be the one who helps you get what you deserve. Either way, it's a win-win.
Person2: I'm not buying it. You're hiding something.
Person1: Perhaps. But can you honestly say you're not curious about the possibilities?

Person1: You're being ridiculous, claiming you're a professional artist.
Person2: It caught me off guard, I didn't expect you to be so talented.
Person1: It felt like you were patronizing me. You think I'm not good enough.
Person2: You're too sensitive. I was just surprised, that's all. You'll never make it in the art world with that attitude.

Person1: You're making a big mistake, Rachel. Let me have the documents.
Person2: You don't get it, do you? He's playing us against each other. You're just a pawn in his game.
Person1: The documents, Rachel. Now.
Person2: Fine, take them. But you're just trapping yourself further. You're so blinded by your ambition, you can't see what's really going on.
Person1: What are you talking about? You're the one who's been acting strange lately.
Person2: Strange? You have no idea what's been going on behind your back. But I'm done playing along. I'm out of here.

Person1: I think you should focus on your career, find a stable job, and settle down. You're wasting your potential on that startup.
Person2: You want me to give up on my dreams and conform to societal norms? That's not the person I thought you were.
Person1: I'm talking about growing up, taking responsibility for yourself. You're still hanging out with those reckless friends from college.
Person2: You're referring to Alex? He's a genius, and his ideas are going to change the world.
Person1: I don't see him fitting into your future. You need to re-evaluate your priorities and surround yourself with people who will support your growth.
Person2: You're trying to control my life, dictating who I should be friends with and what I should do with my career. That's not love, that's manipulation.
Person1: I'm just trying to help you see what's best for you. You're not thinking clearly, and I'm worried about your future.

Person1: You're not supposed to like it. What gets me is your attitude.
Person2: I'm special.
Person1: Oh, really? Then you should be able to handle a little challenge. I'll give you a task. If you complete it, I'll consider your request.
Person2: What request?
Person1: The one you're too afraid to ask. Now, are you in or out?
Person2: I'm in. What's the task?
Person1: I want you to convince your colleague to take on an extra project. If you can do that, I'll give you what you want.
Person2: That's not fair. You're just trying to test my skills.
Person1: Maybe. But it's also a chance for you to prove yourself. So, what's it going to be? Are you going to take the challenge or back down?
Person2: Fine. I'll do it. But if I succeed, you owe me.
Person1: Oh, I'll owe you all right. And I'll make sure to collect on that debt.

Person1: I thought you were done with me. What are you doing here?
Person2: I couldn't get you out of my head. I've thought about you every second since I left.
Person1: Save it. You're just trying to get something from me.
Person2: Maybe at first, but then I realized I want you, not just what you can do for me.
Person1: You expect me to believe that? You're full of shit, just like always.
Person2: I know I messed up, but I'm trying to make it right. I want to take you away from this place.
Person1: And how do you plan on doing that? You can't even take care of yourself.
Person2: That's not true. I've been thinking, and I have a plan. We can get out of here together.
Person1: What's in it for you?
Person2: You, of course. I want to be with you. And I'll do whatever it takes to make that happen.
Person1: You're just trying to manipulate me, aren't you?
Person2: Maybe a little, but it's only because I know what I want, and I'm willing to do whatever it takes to get it.

Person1: You're not safe on your own. I think you're being pulled by strings, and I'm not sure who's holding them.
Person2: What do you want from me? You think I'm some kind of pawn?
Person1: I want to help you. But you need to understand, you're not in control here. You're coveting something, and that's what's driving you.
Person2: I'm not coveting anything. I just want to be free from all this.
Person1: Freedom is an illusion. You're running from something, just like you ran away from that ranch. Why did you do that, hmm?
Person2: That was different. I was just a kid.
Person1: Ah, but you're not a kid anymore. And you're still running. You're running from the truth. You're running from yourself.
Person2: I'm not running from anything. I just want to be left alone.
Person1: Alone? You're not alone. You're surrounded by people who want something from you. And I'm one of them. But I'm the only one who can help you see the truth.

Person1: You're right, I've been feeling restless lately. One of my associates sold the building last month.
Person2: That's a Bozo no-no. Jay-bird. You're not even listening to me, are you?
Person1: Listen, buttercup, let's make a deal and forget about the whole thing. I'm getting so HOT!!!
Person2: Is this the only thing that matters to you? You better hope no one finds out about that building. Cause it's like they say, four can keep a secret, if three are dead.

Person1: I'm so sick of it. You always hide behind your friends. It's why we didn't work out.
Person2: I do not.
Person1: Yes, you do. I feel like I need their permission just to talk to you. Rachel, it's time to assert yourself. To be a big girl. An individual.
Person2: I have something really important I have to ask my professor.
Person1: I love you, Rachel. I love you and I'm willing to change. I'll talk to you...I'll talk to you tomorrow. I'm getting help for my anger issues. For you. For us. So we can communicate better.
Person2: You mind your own business.
Person1: Rachel, I know you don't love me now, but I'll be good to you. I'll be god damn good for you. And I won't be mad if you don't know who said what. I won't punish you if you get the answer wrong. I can teach and tell you.

Person1: You're lying! I know you're hiding something.
Person2: Oh, come on, detective. I'm trying to help you solve this case. You're not really comprehending any of this.
Person1: Don't patronize me. I know exactly what's going on here. You're trying to distract me from the real issue.
Person2: I'm Patrick, by the way. We've spoken on the phone before. You're not recognizing me, are you?
Person1: Save it, Patrick. I'm not buying what you're selling. You're just trying to manipulate me into believing your twisted story.
Person2: Twisted story? You're the one who's been in the dark, detective. I'm just trying to enlighten you.

Person1: You're not going to the party tonight?... You're not driving up tonight?
Person2: Just a minute, Emma, you don't understand. This isn't a wild party like the one you got into trouble at, it's a nice gathering. A friend of mine, I talked to her on the phone, a fine woman... it's not a party, damn it, it's a sophisticated social event! Stop worrying, Emma! Do you hear me? Stop worrying, it's ideal!
Person1: I don't know how you can call it ideal -- don't you know what the word "party" means to her?
Person2: I don't give a hoot in hell's hollow what it means to her! She can't stay locked up in this house forever! I'm taking her, damn it! You guys are crazy, you know that? I mean you guys are really nuts.
Person1: It sounds like a party to me. Calling it a social event, that's just trickery and flummery.

Person1: You're not going to believe what I've been working on.
Person2: Oh, I think I will. After all, I've been studying the demographic patterns of people like you. You're 25, right? That's an interesting age.
Person1: What do you mean?
Person2: Well, I've found that people in their mid-twenties are more susceptible to... let's call it "influence". And I think I can show you exactly what I mean. Unless, of course, you're not interested in seeing what I've discovered.
Person1: (pauses) Fine. Show me.

Person1: It was alive, wasn't it?
Person2: I only wanted to be in your thoughts, to bring myself into your mind. So I could be as close to you as I am now.
Person1: You're playing with my memories, aren't you? Trying to control what I remember and what I don't.
Person2: I love you, and I want you to love me too. I want us to be together, in every sense of the word.
Person1: You're manipulating me, just like you did on my wedding night. You're trying to make me doubt my own sanity.
Person2: I'm just trying to help you see the truth. You're the one who's been living in darkness, refusing to see what's right in front of you.

Person1: I'm trying to keep emotions out of this. Even though this is an important issue to me and I have strong feelings about the subject.
Person2: You weren't there. Give me time to get some proof.
Person1: Please, I'm trying to get us into a more rational discussion and you insist on this emotional nonsense.
Person2: If you really care about the truth, why is it so inconceivable that my perspective is just as valid?
Person1: For the last time, I will not tolerate these personal attacks. You're not sick, you don't look sick... just very tired and bitter.
Person2: My family is going through a tough time, okay? And I need your support, not your condescension.

Person1: You're not even trying to hide it, are you? I know everything.
Person2: I love you, Alex. I've always loved you. I only wanted to be in your thoughts.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. You've known this whole time. Tell me the truth.
Person2: Explain this to me... why are you so angry? I only wanted to bring myself into your thoughts.
Person1: You're violating my trust! On the night of our biggest deal!
Person2: Trust...? You're the one who's been lying to me, Alex.

Person1: I've got a meeting with the boss, man. I gotta make a good impression.
Person2: Joey, Joey... You're not even dressed for the part. Let me give you some advice.
Person1: What? whatwhatwhat?
Person2: One more "man" out of you and I'm gonna think you're trying to distract me. Now, I'm trying to help you, but you gotta stop being so naive. You know the boss is looking for someone with ambition.
Person1: Mmhmm.
Person2: You know, I've heard rumors that you're being considered for a promotion. But you need to show them you're willing to play the game.
Person1: I always figured I'd live longer without getting caught up in office politics.
Person2: Maybe. But you'll be pushing thirty pretty soon, kid. It's time you got some real influence.

Person1: I think you're scared of being alone, that's why you're holding on to this relationship.
Person2: How do you know? You're just trying to get inside my head.
Person1: I'm telling you, you need to admit that your past is still haunting you. It shattered your faith in everything.
Person2: That's not true. I'm just temporarily off my game.
Person1: You need to believe in something besides yourself. I can show you a way out of this darkness.
Person2: I'm not sure I can trust you.
Person1: I'm the only one who truly understands you. You wouldn't believe how much I can help you.

Person1: You're too hurt to fight and the man's a killer! Take the fall, and I'll give you more than your one third!
Person2: What's on your wish list, Victor? You're the one talking deal. What does it take to make you go away?
Person1: Pressures on, eh? There's got to be a load of money in this. Why else would you toss a red hot commodity like me out the window?
Person2: You're implying that my motives are less than sincere? I'm beginning to think of this deal as my only way out.
Person1: It's absolutely not like that! This is for your own good! Come on, get the rest of your story straight!
Person2: You've got witness problems, you've got proof problems... I'm your only problem, Victor.

Person1: You're telling me you didn't know what was going on? You expect me to believe that?
Person2: I'm telling you the truth. I had one drink at lunch, that's all.
Person1: Save it. You think you're the best, don't you? You think you can outsmart me?
Person2: I'm not trying to outsmart anyone. I'm just trying to tell the truth.
Person1: The truth? You want to talk about the truth? If you're not careful, you'll find pieces of your life scattered all over the city. Do you understand what I'm saying?
Person2: You're trying to intimidate me. It won't work.
Person1: Intimidate you? I'm just giving you a warning. You'd do well to listen.

Person1: What's your story, kid? You're not from around here, that's for sure.
Person2: That's cool. We're getting to know each other. This is a good thing. I'm Alex.
Person1: Alex. I think you're too scared to be talking. Now, see we're sitting down here, ready to negotiate, and you've already given up your shit. I'm still a mystery to you.
Person2: Hey, that's whacked! I thought we were getting on here!
Person1: Shut up! You haven't even sat down yet. I know exactly where your ass is coming from. You're trying to play it cool, but I can see right through you.
Person2: OK. Say what it is. What do you want from me?
Person1: The package will be delivered at midnight. If it's successful, there will be more. And don't even think about trying to cross me, Alex. I know all about your little tricks.

Person1: You're not helping when I tell Emily to focus on her studies and you let her play video games all night.
Person2: There was a message, wasn't there? From the college about her scholarship?
Person1: I don't want a slacker for a daughter. You need to set a better example.
Person2: What did you tell the college about her grades?
Person1: Nothing about your influence. Yet.
Person2: Then what's the problem? She's a good kid.
Person1: Give up your gaming addiction, or I'll have to take away your console. It's that simple.

Person1: Rachel, what's going on? You've been distant lately.
Person2: Hey, don't be so paranoid. You're my friend now... I'm gonna help you forget all about your worries. Come on, let's get out of here.
Person1: Where are we going?
Person2: I heard the art exhibit is moving to the city... I think it's time we rearranged our priorities. Come on, show me a smile.
Person1: Please, tell me what's really going on. You're not yourself lately.
Person2: You're just being insecure. Your mother didn't make you feel stupid, did she? Did she make you do something you didn't want to?
Person1: What are you talking about? My mother was a kind person.
Person2: Oh, really? Then why do you always doubt yourself? She must have said something to make you feel that way.
Person1: That's not true. You're trying to confuse me.
Person2: Am I? Or am I just making you see the truth? You're not as confident as you think you are, Rachel. I can help you with that.
Person1: How?
Person2: By showing you that you're not in control. You're just a pawn in a bigger game. And I'm the one who can guide you through it.
Person1: I don't believe you.
Person2: That's because you're afraid of the truth. But I'll make you see it eventually.

Person1: I know you're upset, but I can make it up to you, Emma. I can prove my loyalty to you.
Person2: Will you tell your business partner that you're willing to sacrifice the deal for me? Right in front of me, so I can see you're committed to our relationship? Tell them you're willing to lose everything for me?
Person1: That's not a fair ask. You're trying to control me.
Person2: I'm only doing this for our own good. Sometimes you need someone to push you to prioritize what's truly important.

Person1: You're just trying to scare me.
Person2: Your fear of the truth is real. That's all the motivation I need.
Person1: I didn't betray anyone. You're the one who's been lying.
Person2: Who will believe you? You're already guilty in their eyes. I'm the only one who can clear your name.
Person1: You're just using me for your own gain.
Person2: And you're not using me to escape your past?

Person1: I can't do this, it's not right.
Person2: Oh, come on. You want to make it up to your sister? Well, if she's right, this is your chance. You're not going to let her down again, are you?
Person1: That's not fair. You're using her against me.
Person2: I'm just stating the facts. You've got a chance to redeem yourself. Don't blow it.

Person1: You're leaving, aren't you? What's going on, Emily? Is it something I did?
Person2: Maybe. I don't know.
Person1: Don't play games with me. You're not a child anymore. What do you covet, Emily? What is it that you want so badly?
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: Oh, come on. Don't pretend you're innocent. I see the way you look at things, the way you want them. You can't hide it from me. Why did you run away from your old life, Emily? What were you seeking?
Person2: I just needed a change, that's all.
Person1: A change? You call this a change? You're running from something, Emily. And I'm going to find out what it is. You can't keep secrets from me. I'll listen now.

Person1: I know you're still upset about what happened at the party, but Crash says I gotta quit worrying about what others think.
Person2: You're not worried about others, you're worried about your own guilt. You were thinking "I can't let her find out what I did," and now you're trying to distract me from the truth.
Person1: That's not fair, I'm just trying to move on. We've got a lot of catching up to do, and I don't want the past to hold us back.
Person2: You're not fooling anyone, least of all yourself. You're trying to manipulate me into forgetting what you did, but it won't work.

Person1: I've been observing your team, Captain. You seem to have a good sense of camaraderie.
Person2: Yeah, we work well together. But I'm warning you, if you're here to evaluate us, I won't take it lying down.
Person1: Oh, I'm not here to judge. I just want to understand how you manage to keep your team so cohesive.
Person2: It's all about trust, honey. And I've earned theirs. You, on the other hand, seem like a female version of the routine Regular Army clown.
Person1: That's not fair, Captain. I'm just trying to do my job. And I've noticed that your team seems to do the most work with the least fuss.
Person2: That's because we're a well-oiled machine. But don't think for a second that I won't do whatever it takes to protect my team from outsiders like you.
Person1: I'm not here to disrupt your team, Captain. I just want to learn from you.
Person2: Save it, Major. I'm not buying what you're selling. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have work to do.

Person1: What's the point of all these questions?
Person2: You're not as clever as you think you are, genius. I want to see what you've been working on after hours.
Person1: I haven't been working on anything. You're just trying to get inside my head.
Person2: Do I get to see it or not? Don't play dumb, I know you're hiding something.

Person1: You're pretty when you're angry.
Person2: So tell me everything. Details. I like details.
Person1: It's private.
Person2: Oh, come on. You're not going to play hard to get with me, are you?
Person3: (entering the conversation) What's going on here?
Person1: (smiling) Just trying to get some information out of this one.
Person2: (nervously) Yeah, that's all.
Person3: (skeptical) Save it for someone who believes you.

Person1: You know why I'm here, don't you?
Person2: I've got a proposition for you, Alex. It's time you got some ambition.
Person1: I'm not interested in your games, Victor.
Person2: Oh, come on. You know everything about me, and I know everything about you.
Person1: That's not true. You're just trying to manipulate me.
Person2: Maybe. But the boys are getting rather interested in your future. You'll be pushing thirty pretty soon, and it's time you had a few little things going for you.
Person1: I don't need your help. I can take care of myself.
Person2: Sure, that's all right when you're a kid, but you'll be surprised what I can offer you.

Person1: You're a master of deception, aren't you?
Person2: I did what was necessary to get you on board, Rachel. You're the best in the business.
Person1: And what story did you spin for my team?
Person2: We've been tracking this lead for months. The tip about the warehouse was too good to pass up. I knew you'd jump at the chance.
Person1: You're using me, just like you used Jimmy.
Person2: Jimmy was different. He was weak. You're stronger, Rachel. You can see the bigger picture.
Person1: Don't pretend you care about me. You only care about getting what you want.
Person2: Maybe that's true. But I need you, Rachel. And I'll do whatever it takes to keep you on my side.

Person1: I'll give you what you've always wanted. A sense of control.
Person2: Don't get my hopes up. If I trust you, what then?
Person1: You told me you'd say that. You're so predictable.
Person2: Excuse me? You're the one who's been playing me all along.
Person1: Now wait, there's been a mix-up. Everything's changed, and I'm the one in charge.
Person2: You're just trying to confuse me. I won't fall for it.
Person1: Oh, but you already have. You just don't know it yet.

Person1: I'm telling you, it was an accident.
Person2: You expect me to believe that? You're always "accidentally" doing things, aren't you?
Person1: What's that supposed to mean?
Person2: It means you have a habit of exposing yourself, literally and figuratively. Remember that time at the party?
Person1: That was one mistake! You're not going to hold that against me forever, are you?
Person2: Hold it against you? You're the one who's holding onto something. You're holding onto the idea that you can control me, that you can make me believe whatever you want.
Person1: That's not fair. I'm trying to be honest with you.
Person2: Honest? You call that honest? You're just trying to manipulate me, to make me see things from your perspective. Well, it's not going to work.
Person1: Why are you being so paranoid?
Person2: Paranoid? You're the one who's always playing games, always trying to get inside my head. I'm just trying to stay one step ahead of you.
Person1: Fine. If that's how you want to play it, then maybe we're done here.
Person2: Oh, we're far from done. We're just getting started.

Person1: You're always so secretive about your projects. Do you get pleasure from keeping me in the dark?
Person2: Why are you doing this to me? Do you think I'm hiding something from you?
Person1: Ah, hiding... that's a difficult word to define. When does the secrecy end and the trust begin? When did your trust in me begin to fade?
Person2: I never meant to hurt you, but you always assume the worst.
Person1: Really? Then why do you always change your story? Why do you have to keep me guessing?
Person2: Maybe I'm just trying to protect you from the truth. Maybe you're not ready to hear it.
Person1: Protect me? You're the one who's always playing games with me. You're the one who's always pushing me away.
Person2: That's not true. I'm just trying to keep you safe. But you never listen. You always think you know better.
Person1: Safe? You call this safe? You're suffocating me with your secrets and your lies.
Person2: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to hurt you. But you have to trust me. You have to believe me.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly. Don't take it personally.
Person2: You're the one who's playing games with people's lives. You have no right to decide who gets hurt.
Person1: I'm not masquerading as anything. I'm just trying to fix the problem you created.
Person2: My security team is on standby. One loud scream and they'll be in here instantly.
Person1: If I wanted to hurt you, I would have done it already. But I need your help to clean up this mess.
Person2: What makes you think I'd help you after what you've done?
Person1: Because you're not as innocent as you seem. And I have proof.

Person1: You're not giving up, are you, Detective James? We've got to crack this case before it's too late.
Person2: I'm not a fool, you know. I can see what you're trying to do.
Person1: Why wouldn't you tell me where you were last night? Were you at the crime scene?
Person2: You killed my partner, didn't you, Detective? You're just trying to cover your tracks.
Person1: Oh, I can explain about that later. You're losing control of the investigation - don't you realize what that means?
Person2: Wait a minute. Answer my question. Were you at the crime scene?
Person1: Well... uh... I...
Person2: You were, weren't you? How long have you been playing me? Do you know?
Person1: Aw, I don't know what you're talking about. All I know is that you're losing control of the investigation and...
Person2: All right. That's all. Please, Detective.

Person1: You're still hung up on what happened at the party, aren't you?
Person2: Why bring it up now? It's all in the past. Let's move on.
Person1: You don't see that you're not even a crumb on her table? You're just trying to educate yourself, not me.
Person2: Always dwelling on old things won't help you. Focus on the now. I think we should go for "sweet" and move forward.

Person1: Do I look like I want a tiny dessert?
Person2: Ah, but it's not just any dessert. It's a unique experience.
Person1: I'm not interested in unique experiences. I want something real.
Person2: Oh, come on. Admit it. You're curious. It's enjoyable, isn't it?
Person1: No, it's not. You're just trying to manipulate me.
Person2: Manipulate you? I'm just offering you a choice. You can always say no.
Person1: That's not true. You're making me feel like I owe you something.
Person2: Perhaps you do. After all, I am offering you something you can't find anywhere else.

Person1: You're not listening to me, are you? You're too busy thinking about your own problems.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: It means you're not taking this seriously. You're not considering the consequences. You walk out that door, and you'll lose everything.
Person2: I don't care. I've had enough of this conversation.
Person1: Fine. But let me ask you something. How many people does it take to make a decision? One. And I'm the one making the decisions here. You can either get on board or get out.
Person2: What's gotten into you? You're not usually like this.
Person1: I'm just trying to get through to you. You're not hearing me, and it's frustrating. I know you're going through a tough time, but that's no excuse for not listening. Now, are you going to start taking this seriously, or do we need to take a break?

Person1: You're sorry now, aren't you? You think you can just apologize and make everything okay?
Person2: I'm sorry for all my sins. And yours. But I think you're misunderstanding. I'm not trying to make things okay, I'm trying to make sense of it all.
Person1: Sense of it all? You're the one who's been playing along, pretending like everything is normal. But I know the truth. I know the world revolves around me somehow.
Person2: That's not true. You're just paranoid. You're wishing you'd made something more of yourself, and now you're trying to convince yourself that you're the center of the universe.
Person1: Paranoid? You're the one who's been hiding things from me. You're the one who's been lying to me. I know what I've seen, and I know what I've felt. You can't manipulate me that easily.

Person1: I've been thinking, we could make our greatest project yet. What do you say, Rachel?
Person2: I don't know, sir. I had no idea how much I'd missed working with you. It's been a long time.
Person1: We've missed you too, Rachel. You have a certain... flair that's hard to find.
Person2: You're trying to flatter me, sir. But I'm not sure I'm ready to commit to another project.
Person1: Nonsense, Rachel. You're a professional. And I know you want to work again. You don't know what it means to know that I want you on this project.
Person2: That's not true, sir. I do know what it means. And I'm not sure I'm willing to play along.
Person1: Oh, come now, Rachel. Don't be coy. I know you have certain... requirements. You don't work before ten in the morning, and never after four. I'm willing to accommodate you.
Person2: How did you know that, sir? You're not trying to manipulate me, are you?

Person1: You know what they'd do if they found out.
Person2: How do you know I'm not going to turn you in?
Person1: Cause you got a little voice in your head saying, do the right thing. Protect me.
Person2: That's not what I mean. You're not thinking about the consequences.
Person1: You're not thinking about what's at stake. If you don't help me, we'll both go down.

Person1: You want custody of my heart? ... Why not just consider my feelings slapped and call me when you feel I've served my time?
Person2: I'm sorry, but this is permanent. You can run just as far as you can, but wherever you go, that's where you'll be.
Person1: What do you want for free? You're not going to get it from me.
Person2: Maybe you just think you do. Maybe you're one of those hungry ghosts out there never satisfied with nothing.
Person1: You're trying to make me feel guilty, aren't you? Well, it won't work.
Person2: I'm just trying to make you see the truth. You can't keep running from your emotions.

Person1: Detective James, are you aware I have dismissed the lead suspect in the Smith case?
Person2: Yes, Captain.
Person1: Yet we hear you are still investigating them. Is this true?
Person2: Who told you this, Captain?
Person1: It's not your place to ask questions. Is it true?
Person2: Well, yes, I admit it is.
Person1: Would you tell me why? You didn't think the evidence was conclusive, did you?
Person2: No, Captain. It's just that I have a feeling about this one.
Person1: A feeling? If necessary, I can bring in the forensic team and two witnesses who contradict your theory.

Person1: You're an attractive woman, but you need to take better care of yourself.
Person2: What do you want?
Person1: I want to know who's been helping you with your business ventures.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: If you look good, you feel good, and if you feel good, you project confidence into the world. And I think you're hiding something.
Person2: That's not my problem. You're just trying to intimidate me.
Person1: I'm trying to help you. But if you're not willing to cooperate, then maybe I'll have to take a closer look at your business dealings. And I'm sure you wouldn't want that.
Person2: Fine. I'll think about it.

Person1: I've got a proposition for you, Maya. I think you'd be perfect for the new project.
Person2: Stop right there. I know exactly what you're implying.
Person1: Oh, come on. You're not going to play the victim card again, are you? I'm offering you a chance to advance your career.
Person2: Your entire approach to business is a form of manipulation, isn't it? You use people's desires and fears against them.
Person1: That's just smart strategy. And it's not like I'm forcing anyone to do anything they don't want to do.
Person2: That's exactly what you're doing. You're exploiting their weaknesses, making them think it's their own idea. It's a clever trick, but it's still manipulation.
Person1: You know, Maya, you're not as innocent as you seem. You're playing the same game, just on a smaller scale.
Person2: At least I'm honest about it. You're hiding behind a mask of benevolence, but it's all just a power play.

Person1: I can't be expected to remember every detail from that project.
Person2: Oh, don't be silly. You're one of the lead architects. I'm sure it's all still fresh in your mind.
Person1: That's just how my brain works, I guess. I prioritize what's important.
Person2: Fascinating. Well, I think it's important we discuss this further over lunch. There's a great spot near the office I always take my clients.
Person1: Actually... I just want to get back to work.
Person2: Nonsense. You need a break. And I'm sure your team would love to hear about your... creative approach to project management.

Person1: You're telling me you've been working for me for thirteen years, and you still can't get married?
Person2: I almost got married once, to a girl named Ruby McNutt. My one true love.
Person1: Ruby McNutt? Sounds like another one of your stories to me. What's wrong with you, anyway? You're smart, you're charming... what's holding you back?
Person2: Maybe I'm just waiting for the right moment. Or the right person.
Person1: The right person? You mean like Inez, the housekeeper? I heard you gave her a $500 tip. What's going on with you two?
Person2: She needed it, okay? And her name is Inez, not "the housekeeper".
Person1: Oh, so you're in love with her now? That's just great. You're going to marry the help and have a bunch of little janitor brats running around.
Person2: You know, you're really something. You're always so quick to judge, but you never take anything seriously. You're just like me, trying not to get too caught up in the drama.
Person1: What are you talking about? I take things very seriously. I'm just trying to get to the bottom of what's going on with you and Inez.
Person2: You're not fooling anyone, least of all yourself. You're just trying to distract me from your own problems. Like your wife and kids, and your ranch house on Long Island. You're the one who's stuck in a dead-end life, not me.
Person1: That's it, I've had enough of your lies and manipulation. You're just trying to turn everything around on me, aren't you?
Person2: Maybe I am, maybe I'm not. But one thing's for sure - you're not going to legislate me out of business anytime soon.

Person1: What do you want from me? You want me to tell you everything that happened was okay?
Person2: I'll give you what you never had. A chance to make it right.
Person1: Don't get on that stage! Please, let's just talk about this. I'm sure there's another way to resolve this.
Person2: You can't control me, Jack. I'm not going to let you dictate my life.

Person1: You're not a man, Rachel, you're - 
Person2: What's that supposed to mean? 
Person1: I know that bit - you're a woman; you need a cause to give you strength! So what do you pick such weak allies for? Don't you know yet that you fight fire with fire, not with tear drops?
Person2: I could almost forgive you if what you did to my family came from desperation and love... 
Person1: Marry me, Rachel, and together we will rebuild our community. There are many perks that come with being the leader's partner. I'm sure we will supply for ourselves a magnificent future. And perhaps a sense of security and free will.
Person2: I hate and despise you and everything you stand for with all my heart and soul. I could never forgive what you've done to me and my people.

Person1: If you ever cared for me, for our friendship, or for your own dignity, then stand now and let it happen.
Person2: WHO ARE YOU TO DECIDE IF I SHOULD STAND OR FALL? I thought you knew me better than that.
Person1: I thought I did, but it seems I was wrong. You're not the person I thought you were.
Person2: And you're not the one who gets to decide who I am or what I do. I'm here to set you free from your own expectations.

Person1: You're telling me that you didn't know the arson lead was a secret? 
Person2: I didn't say that. I said you knew what I told you wasn't ready for the papers. 
Person1: Oh, come on. You're not a real investigator. You're just another probie working for the city. 
Person2: At least I'm not always under the influence when I'm working on a case. 
Person1: What's that supposed to mean? 
Person2: It means that maybe if you were more focused, you wouldn't have blown our lead. 
Person1: You know, I was thinking about how you're always telling us that good investigators make choices. But it seems like you're not making any choices at all. You're just following orders. 
Person2: And I was wondering if it might not be different if you weren't always trying to cover your own ass.

Person1: You've got to help them.
Person2: I tried. I failed miserably, but I tried.
Person1: Everything you say is wrong. You can't talk to her anymore.
Person2: Is that what you think? That I'm just going to give up?
Person1: I'm late for a meeting. We can discuss this later.
Person2: It's important. You need to understand that apathy and absence are just special ways of saying "I care."
Person1: And what's the price for this understanding?
Person2: You need to help them, for me.

Person1: You're not going to take my advice, are you?
Person2: I don't know these people you're talking about. Who's Nick Cave?
Person1: He's a musician. I think you'd really like him.
Person2: You think I'd like him? You're trying to turn me into you again, aren't you?
Person1: That's not fair. I'm just trying to help.
Person2: Help? You call that help? You're trying to manipulate me into liking the same things you do.
Person1: I'm not trying to manipulate you. I just think we could have something in common.
Person2: Something in common? You mean like how you've taken money from little old ladies? Or how you've talked people into doing things they never would have dreamed of?
Person1: That's not what I meant. And those things aren't true.
Person2: Oh, really? Then why do I feel like I'm being played?

Person1: I've been thinking, we should invite Sophia to the party.
Person2: So what else is new? You're always trying to get her attention.
Person1: But she might be in trouble... I heard her family is going through a tough time.
Person2: You're asking the wrong person to feel sorry for Sophia. Wise up -- it's not hip to be her friend anymore.
Person1: I don't care about being popular anymore. I just want to help her.
Person2: You dare to lecture me about helping others? You, who only care about your own desires?
Person1: That's not fair. I'm trying to make a change.
Person2: Then start by loving yourself, and you will not bear to see others hungry. Love others, and they will love you.
Person1: You're just trying to manipulate me, aren't you?
Person2: I'm trying to make you see the truth. You're so caught up in your own world, you forget about the people around you.
Person1: I order you to leave me alone.
Person2: At least help Sophia. It's the least you can do, to protect your own honor.

Person1: I'm afraid your father's health is not good. You ought to say farewell to him before taking on this new project.
Person2: I can't wait all night, I have a priority and if you don't commit to this, I'm going to have to reconsider our partnership.
Person1: He's asking you to come and stay with him, and I think you owe it to him after everything he's done for you.
Person2: Don't worry, I'll take care of it. Just remember, you owe me one for this.
Person1: You're going to have to make a decision quickly, time is of the essence. I have a feeling this could be a make or break moment for your career.
Person2: Ten-four, I'll take care of it.

Person1: You can't have nothing, Alex. We need to figure something out.
Person2: I'll manage. I don't need your help.
Person1: Where are you going? You'll get lost in this neighborhood. You don't even know the way back.
Person2: I'll find my way.
Person1: No, you won't. You'll get scared and then I'll have to feel responsible. And I've already got more responsibility than I know what to do with. Do you want something to eat?
Person2: No, I'm not hungry.
Person1: Come on, I'll buy you a sandwich. Your favorite. What do you say?

Person1: You're not exactly the genuine article, are you, Dr. Patel?
Person2: What do you mean by that?
Person1: I mean, you're hiding something. You're pretending to be someone you're not. Just like you did with your research partner, Dr. Lee.
Person2: That's not fair. I had to go undercover to uncover the truth about the project.
Person1: Save it, Dr. Patel. I've seen your kind before. You think you're above the law, above morality. But I'm here to tell you that you're not.
Person2: You're just trying to intimidate me. Well, it won't work. I know what I'm doing, and I know what's at stake.
Person1: Oh, I'm shaking in my boots. You think you're so smart, but you're just a pawn in a much larger game. And I'm the one who's going to expose you.
Person2: I'm not afraid of you. I've seen what happens to people who cross you, and I'm not going to end up like them.
Person1: We'll see about that. We'll see about that.

Person1: You're not going to tell me the truth, are you? Just lie, it'd make me feel better.
Person2: That's not what I mean. I was going to tell you, but now I'm not so sure.
Person1: Do you want to keep our little secret, partner? Or do you want me to find out the hard way?
Person2: I'm trying to protect you. You don't understand what's at stake here.
Person1: Oh, great... You're doing this to make me feel better, aren't you?

Person1: You're not taking this seriously. I ought to raise the stakes.
Person2: I don't know what I'm supposed to say, Alex. I want to do the right thing here.
Person1: Do you trust me? Did you ever trust me? Something. I feel like I've been sitting right in front of the truth for months.
Person2: If I call your bluff, your whole plan will fall apart.
Person1: You made me doubt myself. You made me question everything.
Person2: I didn't make you do anything. You chose to play along.
Person1: For five hundred, what do I get? The truth?
Person2: For two hundred, you get a hint.
Person1: You mentioned a secret. Sorry, another client paid for that. You can hire me not to reveal it.
Person2: A thousand, and I'll tell you everything.
Person1: Got it on you? Got the courage to tell the truth on you?

Person1: You're making a mistake. You're pushing me too far.
Person2: I'm studying the effect of negative reinforcement on your psyche. 
Person1: Obsolete old carnivores like me are most dangerous when wounded. You've wounded me.
Person2: Then my theory was correct. You're getting defensive.
Person1: We never quit fighting until we're dead. You're trying to provoke me, aren't you?
Person2: I'm trying to understand what drives you. You're so predictable.
Person1: You'd be killing a friend. Don't you know how much I like you?
Person2: You're trying to guilt trip me. It won't work.
Person1: I'm going to shoot you now. My self-respect is gone--and my soldier's honor with it.
Person2: You're bluffing. You're not capable of killing an unarmed man.
Person1: Like the saber-toothed tiger. You're trying to tame me, aren't you?
Person2: I'm trying to understand you. You're a complex creature.
Person1: Man, as man was meant to be--a vengeful ape who murders. He will soon be extinct. It's time, it's time.
Person2: You're trying to intimidate me. It won't work. I'm not afraid of you.

Person1: You're not listening to me. I thought you were just...
Person2: Alex, you've been making excuses for him for weeks... Weeks.
Person1: But, he said he'd try to change.
Person2: Try is like maybe. Try is nothing! You're just afraid to admit the truth about him.
Person1: He does care about me. 
Person2: Care about you? He's playing you like a fool, and I don't want to have to say I told you so... But I will, if you don't wake up.

Person1: You're damn right! I'm a renowned journalist and you feed me false information!
Person2: Would you mind keeping your voice down? I have a meeting with my editor.
Person1: Oh, well we wouldn't want to disturb your meeting, would we? You're trying to spare my feelings, just like De Mille did.
Person2: What are you talking about? This has nothing to do with De Mille.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. You're trying to manipulate me, just like they did. You think I don't get letters every day from people who want the truth?
Person2: You're being paranoid. There's no conspiracy here. I'm just trying to correct the mistakes in your article.
Person1: Correct the mistakes? You're trying to control the narrative. I know what I saw, and I won't back down.

Person1: You're not made for this kind of life, Alex. Few people are.
Person2: That's rich coming from you, a self-proclaimed visionary who created this entire project. Voila, end of argument. It can't be a failure because you're the genius behind it.

Person1: I think you're in an ideal position to help us, Emily. You're the only one who can get close to him.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. Who's him?
Person1: Don't play dumb, Emily. We know all about your little encounter with him at the boardwalk. He trusts you.
Person2: That's not true. I barely know him.
Person1: Save it, Emily. We have evidence. And I think you'd better find out who he really is, don't you?
Person2: Why should I? What's in it for me?
Person1: Well, if you're going to do something, you might as well do it for your country. And who knows, you might even find it fulfilling. You said yourself, you want to work with kids.
Person2: That's not the same thing. You're not going to arrest him, are you?
Person1: We'll take care of that. You just focus on getting us the information we need. And remember, Emily, you're not the only one who can play cute.

Person1: I'm telling you, we need to call in a professional to handle this situation.
Person2: No way, they explicitly said no experts. We can't risk it.
Person1: But what about our guarantee? We're giving them what they want, and they're still holding our sister hostage.
Person2: I know it's tough, but we have to think this through. If we give in to their demands, why would they let her go?
Person1: You're not thinking clearly. We're talking about a huge sum of money here. And they're still holding her captive.
Person2: I understand your concerns, but we can't let emotions cloud our judgment. We need to stay calm and think of a way to outsmart them.
