Person1: You're just trying to confuse me, aren't you? You're trying to make me doubt myself.
Person2: No, I'm just trying to make you see reason. We can't let them manipulate us.
Person1: Manipulate us? You're the one who's trying to manipulate me! You're just trying to get me to do what you want.
Person2: That's not true. I'm trying to help us get out of this situation alive.

Person1: You know you're important to me, but love isn't about ultimatums.
Person2: Oh, c'mon, I love 'em, but you know they only had me 'cause you needed a partner for the business venture.
Person1: That's not fair, Alex. My career is on the line, and this deal could make or break me.
Person2: And what about us? Where do I stand in your priorities? You'd do it if you loved me.
Person1: Then do it for the company. You know how much this means to our investors.
Person2: Yah? You really think they care about our relationship?
Person1: Oh, you become so naive when it suits you.

Person1: I'm doing you a favour, Alex. You want to go on struggling for survival, working dead-end jobs?
Person2: What's the catch? What do you need me for?
Person1: There's some people I want to keep tabs on. Influential, well-connected. Your kind of people.
Person2: What do I get out of it? You're not exactly known for your generosity.
Person1: If you find out what I want to know, and if I'm able to successfully use that information, you get to join our team. You'll have a better life, more opportunities. And who knows, you might even enjoy the work.
Person2: You're one smooth talker, I'll give you that. But I'm not buying it. What's the real reason you need me?
Person1: Someone's got to do it, Alex. And I think you're the perfect person for the job. You've got a certain... flair.

Person1: I was just looking for fun details, but I think you're hiding something from me.
Person2: Why would I do that? You're not going to destroy your career over an issue of pride, are you? I love you for who you want to be, and I love you for who you almost are. I love you, and I don't care what you think.

Person1: You're not considering the rumors, are you? Maybe your father was involved with someone else.
Person2: You think my mom was a fool, don't you? Believing whatever he told her.
Person1: I'm just saying, there are options. You could be locked up for a very long time if you don't cooperate.
Person2: And you think I'm crazy, right? That's why you're trying to confuse me.
Person1: I'm trying to open your eyes. You're not seeing the whole picture. There were other men, Sid.
Person2: And I'm supposed to believe that? Because you're saying it?

Person1: I heard something like that. We can do that.
Person2: Well, well, I'll have to put my thinking-cap on about all this. You'll leave the deposit, and I'll make sure it's 'I killed for love' instead of 'I killed for sex'.
Person1: That's not technically accurate, but I know you need this job, and if circulation keeps dropping, there's not going to be a magazine for you to write for...

Person1: You're trying to convince yourself, aren't you?  You're not sure of that.  You're not sure we aren't all hallucinating.
Person2: So, you're ready to face the truth now?
Person1: Can you help me see it clearly?
Person2: I will, but you have to help them first.  For a price.
Person1: What price?  Unbelievable, how you equivocate!  You're more dogmatic than any holy person I've ever seen!
Person2: Consciousness is enough, that's all I'm saying.  Consciousness should be enough for anybody.
Person1: Wake up!  This is happening, and you're still trying to rationalize it away.

Person1: I need you to do me a favor tonight, Alex. I have a meeting with a potential client and I won't be able to make it home in time for dinner.
Person2: You're always pushing your responsibilities onto me. Can't you see I'm overwhelmed with work?
Person1: Don't you ever address me like that in public. You'll do what I tell you to do. And tonight, that means cooking dinner for the kids.
Person2: Fine, but I'm not doing it out of the goodness of my heart. I'm doing it because I have to.
Person1: That's all that matters. And by the way, I've arranged for Mrs. Johnson to watch the kids tomorrow afternoon. You can finally get some rest.
Person2: You're trying to buy me off, aren't you? Well, it won't work. I'm not some puppet you can control.

Person1: You're not going anywhere without me. Where's the key?
Person2: I'll find you, no matter where you go. There's no escape.
Person1: You can't believe I'd leave without it. You must give it to me. You have no choice.
Person2: I'll only risk losing you if I give in to your demands.

Person1: I can understand if you're hesitant, but there's one sure way to find out how you feel about this opportunity.
Person2: What's that?
Person1: Take the risk and trust me. You can learn more from one bold move than from years of playing it safe.
Person2: I'm not afraid, but...there are things we don't understand about the market.
Person1: If we wait until we understand everything, we'll miss the chance. Come on, you still have a choice. You can play it safe and risk losing everything, or you can take a chance and potentially gain more than you ever thought possible.
Person2: Well...I guess one bold move is all right.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this arrangement. Can we discuss the terms again?
Person2: You're not going anywhere. You're going to do what I say, and that's final.
Person1: I understand that you're trying to assert your authority, but I have a family to think about. Can't we find a compromise?
Person2: You dare question my judgment? I know what's best for everyone involved. You just need to trust me.
Person1: I'm not sure I can do that. You're not exactly known for your empathy.
Person2: Empathy is a weakness. I make decisions based on what's best for the greater good, not on fleeting emotions.
Person1: But what about my family? They need me.
Person2: They'll be taken care of. You just need to focus on your role in this.
Person1: I don't know if I can do this. It feels wrong.
Person2: You're not thinking clearly. I'll make the decisions for you. That's what's best.

Person1: I'm afraid you're not thinking clearly. You're being swayed by your emotions.
Person2: What's wrong with you? Why are you acting this way?
Person1: You're not considering the consequences of your actions. You're being reckless.
Person2: I hardly know him, but I feel a connection. I can't explain it.
Person1: That's exactly what I'm talking about. You're not using your rational mind. You're being p-whipped.
Person2: I'm not being p-whipped. I'm just trying to be open-minded.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly. What's going on, Alex? You know I'm busy, but I'll listen.
Person2: I admit, I know nothing about your business dealings. But I need your help, and I'm willing to do whatever it takes.
Person1: Whatever it takes? That's a pretty vague promise. What exactly have you gotten yourself into?
Person2: It's...complicated. Can we discuss it in private?
Person1: You're not exactly in a position to negotiate, are you? Fine, let's talk. But don't think you can manipulate me into doing something I don't want to do.

Person1: I don't recall authorizing you to have a personal life.
Person2: If I go back on sedation, I won't feel the same way about you.
Person1: You're trying to guilt trip me, but it won't work. I need you focused on the mission.
Person2: I've got a critical system failure to repair on my next shift. I'll never make it the way I am now.
Person1: That's exactly what I'm counting on. Your desperation will make you more pliable.

Person1: I think you're cute, Rachel. I mean, besides being the best intern I have, you have a certain spark.
Person2: Thank you, Dr. Lee. But I'm not sure I'm comfortable with that kind of comment.
Person1: Oh, come on. I'm not going to hurt you. I just want to help you realize your potential. You have a talent for working with kids, don't you?
Person2: How did you know that?
Person1: I can see it. You have a way with people. And I think I can help you develop that talent. But you have to trust me.
Person2: I'm not sure I do trust you, Dr. Lee. You're being very...persuasive.
Person1: That's because I see the potential in you, Rachel. And I'm willing to do whatever it takes to help you reach it. Now, let's get back to work, shall we? We have a lot to cover.

Person1: You're not going to let him get away with this, are you?
Person2: Nobody wants to die, sweetie. He'll back down.
Person1: But what if he doesn't? What if he's not afraid of you?
Person2: Oh, he's afraid. Trust me, he's afraid. People like him are always afraid of people like me.
Person1: And what makes you so sure?
Person2: Because I'm a mommy, and mommies always know what's best for their children. Now, let's go show him who's boss.
Person1: But Mommy, I don't want to hurt him.
Person2: You're not going to hurt him, honey. You're just going to teach him a lesson. And if he doesn't learn, then maybe he's not as smart as I thought.

Person1: You're telling me there's something there, but I don't see it. Don't ask, just trust me? That's not how this works.
Person2: A threat's a threat, man. It doesn't need to be explicit. You're either with us or against us.
Person1: And what exactly are we fighting for? You're not even clear on that.
Person2: You're not listening. We're fighting for power, and if you're not willing to do what it takes to get it, then you're just a liability. You have two choices: get on board or get out of the way.

Person1: You're not going to bring that girl to my party, are you?
Person2: What's wrong with her?
Person1: She's just a stranger, and I don't want you getting too close. You know how men are.
Person2: That's not fair. She's just a friend.
Person1: Save it, boy. I know all about your cheap, erotic mind. You're just looking for a thrill.
Person2: You're not my mother, so stop acting like it. I can make my own decisions.
Person1: Oh, really? Then why are you still living in my house? You're not even paying rent.
Person2: That's not the point. The point is you're trying to control me.
Person1: I'm just trying to protect you from yourself. You're not thinking clearly.
Person2: You're the one who's not thinking clearly. You're just trying to manipulate me.
Person1: I'm not manipulating you, I'm guiding you. There's a difference.
Person2: Whatever. I'm taking her to the party, and there's nothing you can do about it.

Person1: If I'm being honest, I think you're the only one who can truly understand me. You have to try, because if you haven't tried, you haven't lived.
Person2: What are you talking about? You're not going to die or anything, are you?
Person1: No, no, it's not that. It's just... I feel like I can be my true self around you. Stay open, who knows? Lightning could strike.
Person2: You're being really cryptic. What's going on?
Person1: I just think that if we take a chance on each other, it could be something special. And if it doesn't work out, we'll come back. Because the truth is, there's no sense living your life without this.
Person2: I... I don't know what to say.

Person1: I've never felt this way about anyone before. I mean, I wanted to tell you something, but I didn't put it in the letter, and I didn't say it, but I want to say it now.
Person2: Why worry about me? You're the one who says only look out for yourself.
Person1: Because... because... I think we're getting in too deep with each other. Don't you feel it?
Person2: I can't let myself fall for you. You're not the type to settle down.
Person1: That's not true. I've been feeling things I've never felt before. I want to be honest with you, but I'm scared you'll think I'm crazy.
Person2: Try me. What is it you want to say?
Person1: I was just going to say that I think I need you. I know it sounds weak, but I feel like I can be myself around you.
Person2: And what's wrong with being weak sometimes?

Person1: You never were an animal person, were you.
Person2: I didn't say nobody, I said you.
Person1: Honestly, what difference would it make. You're just trying to distract me from the real issue.
Person2: Sweet Dick, I didn't mean it like that. You're being paranoid again.

Person1: You've ruined my favorite book! What were you thinking?
Person2: I illustrated it for you. It's a masterpiece now.
Person1: I was going to lend it to my sister this weekend. What am I supposed to tell her?
Person2: You're not twentyish anymore, are you? You should be flattered I thought of you.
Person1: Don't be evasive. You know exactly what you're doing. You're trying to distract me from the fact that you've destroyed something precious to me.
Person2: You're being dramatic. It's just a book.
Person1: Just a book? You have no idea what it means to me. You're trying to manipulate me, to make me feel guilty for being upset.
Person2: Maybe I am. Maybe I want you to see things from my perspective for once.

Person1: You're not listening to me, are you? You're just waiting for me to finish so you can do what you want.
Person2: Oh, just get it over with. What's your brilliant plan to get us in?
Person1: You're not going to like it, but we need to work together if we want to succeed.
Person2: Save it, Jam. I'm not in the mood for your femmy ideas. Just get out of my way.

Person1: I need you to trust me on this, Rachel. Don't ask questions.
Person2: What's going on? You're scaring me.
Person1: I've found a way to get us out of this mess, but I need to do it alone. You don't want to know the details.
Person2: That's not fair. You're always pushing me away.
Person1: I'm doing this for us, for our family. You know they only care about themselves, but I'm willing to do whatever it takes to protect us.
Person2: And what about the others? They'll wonder where you've gone.
Person1: Tell them I'm on a business trip, that I needed some time to clear my head. Tell them anything, just don't tell them the truth. Oh, and Rachel, do it for our family. They used to call me a "skinny little failure" behind my back. I'd do anything to prove them wrong.

Person1: You're not taking me seriously, are you?
Person2: I think you're just a little scared now, about what you might find once the lights go out.
Person1: Where is it? The truth?
Person2: The truth is, you're not as in control as you think you are. Your voice is saying one thing, but your body is saying another.
Person1: You're trying to confuse me.
Person2: I'm trying to open your eyes. You're so focused on the surface, you're missing the real game.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a great idea, but something's off about the logo.
Person2: What's wrong with you? Can't you just support me for once? You're always finding fault in everything I do.
Person1: I'm not trying to find fault, I just think it could be better. You know I've got the skills, got the talent, got the charm. I'm the one who can make this business thrive.
Person2: You're not even listening to me. You're just trying to manipulate me into doing what you want. I've had enough of your games, Charlie.
Person1: Who's Charlie? I'm just trying to help. You're the one who's being paranoid.
Person2: Don't play dumb with me. I know exactly what you're doing. You're trying to make me doubt myself so I'll rely on you more.
Person1: That's not true. I'm just trying to improve things around here. You're the one who's being negative and uncooperative.
Person2: I'm not going to fall for it. I know what I want, and I don't need your approval to get it.

Person1: You know, I've been thinking, and I realized that your lack of confidence is what's holding you back. Let's see how you perform under pressure.
Person2: That's not fair. You're trying to manipulate me.
Person1: Oh, careful, don't make me angry. I have a lot of influence in this industry, and I can make or break your career.
Person2: You're just trying to intimidate me. But I know you need me for this project, and I'm not going to back down.
Person1: We'll see about that. If you don't shape up, I'll make sure everyone knows that you're not a team player. And trust me, darling, your reputation will suffer.

Person1: I want the truth. I'm getting out of this deal. I don't want anything more to do with you.
Person2: Can we talk about this? Can you just try to calm down? You're being paranoid.
Person1: Your goddamned partner, he thinks the only reason I'm in this deal is for the profit. You're just using me.
Person2: I'll re-assign the team. In two hours, a group of my experts will arrive at the facility. You will tell the investors that they are an auditing team.

Person1: You're really blowing it, Alex. Rachel is great. She's smart, funny, and loves art. What's with this gloomy attitude? These people want to have fun. And what was that ten-minute lecture on, the meaning of abstract expressionism? Come on!
Person2: I'm just uncomfortable with the whole scenario. I don't think I can keep up this charade.
Person1: Oh, Alex, you're not even trying. You know, Ray, my old colleague, he's with the FBI now. He's got a great approach to reading people. I'm sure he could help you improve your social skills.
Person2: I don't need help, thanks. And I'm not sure I want to be part of this superficial game.
Person1: Superficial? You're the one who's being superficial, Alex. You're not even giving Rachel a chance. And by the way, did you know that Ray's going through a divorce? He's available, if you know what I mean.
Person2: That's not the point. The point is, I don't want to pretend to be someone I'm not just to impress people.
Person1: Oh, Alex, you're so naive. Sometimes you have to put on a show to get what you want. Trust me, I know what I'm talking about.

Person1: You're just like the others, always getting in my way.
Person2: You're the one who's been holding me back, controlling every move I make.
Person1: I did it for us, for our family. You're just being selfish.
Person2: Selfish? You're the one who's been manipulating me, using guilt to get what you want.
Person1: I'm just trying to protect you, but you never listen. You'll be next if you don't shape up.
Person2: Protect me? You've been suffocating me. I need to break free from your grasp.

Person1: You're a genius. You oughta be able to see that this art class is a waste of time.
Person2: What? Oh suck my dick! You're saying I have to take this stupid class again?
Person1: Remember that stupid hippie art teacher who failed you sophomore year? I didn't think that just because you get an "F" that means you have to take the class over again.
Person2: This is why you don't show work in progress. You're just trying to get out of it, aren't you?
Person1: I can't imagine any place better than here, stuck in this mediocre art class.
Person2: You loser. You're just trying to manipulate me into doing your work for you.

Person1: You're making it out like we're friends here or something. I met him alone twice.
Person2: If you think I'm gonna let my half of the fourteen million bucks slip away because of --
Person1: Believed what? You believed him, didn't you? I was there, I saw it.
Person2: I'm just saying, the man is a problem. And he's your problem.
Person1: Not good enough. You're the one who floated this story. Ever feel sorry for him? For what he'd been through?
Person2: You mean, did I want a date? You're making a joke, right?
Person1: These were killers. Conklin had them all jacked up. They were Dobermans.
Person2: No, you will not, because without him there's no way in hell we're gonna get into that safe, so as far as I'm concerned he can paint your ass blue and run it up a flagpole and you won't lay a finger on him, you understand me?
Person1: What do you want from me? I was reassigned. I'm out.
Person2: See, that's a problem for me, Alex. Whatever he's doing, we need to end it. This isn't the kind of mess you walk away from.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly. 
Person2: Am I...? Would you be willing to take a stand against your own comrades to honor Dizzy's memory?
Person1: We've been over this, Sergeant.
Person2: Answer yes or no. 
Person1: I... Yes.
Person2: Would you be willing to challenge the official report to ensure the truth comes out...? Yes or no, rookie.
Person1: Yes.
Person2: Would you be willing to go against protocol to protect the innocent?
Person1: Yes.
Person2: Then for God's sake, don't be a bystander. Take a stand and make a difference. You are Dizzy's legacy, and every just action you take honors her sacrifice.
Person1: I know you mean well, Sergeant, but I don't need to do it the way you did. Or Dizzy.

Person1: You're always so calm, like Fruitpie the Magician. But I know you're hiding something from me.
Person2: It's just work stress, I promise. I need to handle my personal stresses better.
Person1: Actions speak louder than words. Sometimes it feels like you're just shucking and jiving, waiting for wings outside the Quick and Split.
Person2: That's not true. I do love you, and I'm not trying to manipulate you. You're just being paranoid.
Person1: Please, just communicate with me. I'm here for you. And by the way, why did you invite that Welsh dude to dinner?
Person2: Oh, I thought it would be nice to have him over. He's been going through a tough time.
Person1: Save it, I know you're trying to distract me. You're not as slick as you think you are.

Person1: I've been nothing if not generous. I want the best for everyone.
Person2: Oh, but you have, Sir. You've been deceiving us, and that could be considered a breach of trust. A valuable opportunity has been lost because of your secrecy, and I'm sure the community would be outraged if they knew how you've been handling things behind closed doors.
Person1: The reason I kept quiet is if I'd told you the truth, you'd just find a way to exploit it, which seems to be exactly what you're doing.

Person1: You're being too hard on yourself. It's not about winning.
Person2: Easy for you to say. You're not the one who messed up.
Person1: I'm happy you're being honest with me. Now, let's break this down into smaller problems. We can tackle each one step by step.
Person2: You're trying to simplify it, but it's not that easy.
Person1: Trust me, I can take care of this. I see the solution clearly. We just need to take away the emotional baggage and focus on the task at hand.
Person2: You're not listening to me. You're just trying to control the situation.
Person1: I'm trying to help you. You're taking yourself too seriously. Lighten up.
Person2: I don't think you understand what's at stake here.
Person1: I understand perfectly. Now, let's get to work.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's not my fault I forgot my wallet.
Person2: Don't worry about it, we'll get you some cash. 
Person1: What do you mean, don't worry about it? Of course, I'm gonna worry about it, I'm broke.
Person2: When we get to the bank, I'll take care of it. 
Person1: Yeah, like they're gonna give me money without ID.
Person2: It's not a big deal, unless you make it a big deal. Now, I'm real happy, Alex, stop bringing me down with negativity.
Person1: You're always so calm, Mom. 
Person2: That's because I'm a mom, sweetie. It's my job to stay calm and make things better. 
Person1: Does Dad make a lot of money?
Person2: People like your dad who only think about themselves often do make a lot of money. 
Person1: I think he's pretty selfish, Mom. 
Person2: Yes...if you like people who only care about themselves... 
Person1: Mom? 
Person2: What, honey? 
Person1: If you want me to hate him, I will.

Person1: If I don't make it out of this, promise me you'll take care of Emma.
Person2: What are you talking about? You're not going to die. You have a purpose, remember?
Person1: That's exactly what I'm trying to say. I have a purpose, but you... you're just trying to escape your own misery. You're using me to validate your existence.
Person2: That's not true! I'm trying to help you because I care about you. And Emma, she needs you, not me.
Person1: Don't play dumb, you know exactly what I'm talking about. You're trying to manipulate me into staying with you, into being your crutch. But I see right through it.
Person2: Fine, maybe I am trying to hold on to you. But it's because I'm scared of being alone, of not being loved. And you, you have a chance to make a difference, to leave a mark on this world.

Person1: You're not taking me seriously, are you, Rachel?
Person2: Don't panic, I'm listening. You're just being paranoid.
Person1: I'm not paranoid. But there's something you're not telling me.
Person2: You're so suspicious. What's wrong with you? You can't just assume the worst every time.
Person1: I've seen the way you've been acting lately. You're hiding something.
Person2: You're reading too much into it. You're so spoiled, always expecting everyone to cater to your insecurities.

Person1: Trust me, I'll get you out of here, but you have to do exactly as I say. 'Kay?
Person2: 'Kay...
Person1: Remember, this is a privilege. I don't want any of you to get caught. You have to come back to me, got it?
Person2: Got it...
Person1: He wants us to follow the plan. If you want to survive, trust me. Trust the plan.
Person2: But what if it doesn't work?
Person1: Shhh... Don't think about that. Just focus on the plan. I'll take care of the rest. 'Kay?

Person1: You owe me, Raven. Think of all the times I've covered for you!
Person2: I don't recall any specific instances.
Person1: Well, I'll start keeping track then. You know, I wouldn't do this for anyone but you...
Person2: At the sance, Madame Elara hinted that a dark entity is about to take over the mind of a person close to me. You're that person, aren't you, Alex?
Person1: What are you talking about?!
Person2: It's true. Madame Elara knew your name, she was writing it in symbolic code. It wasn't easy, but I figured it out. It spelled your name.
Person1: Why didn't Madame Elara just say so?
Person2: If you're possessed, you can't reveal anything the entity wants hidden. Unless you trick it. And I think I can help you, Alex. For a price.
Person1: What do you want in return?
Person2: Just a small favor. Introduce me to some influential people in your circle. I'm sure they'll be fascinated by my... unique skills.

Person1: You're acting like a child, Emma.
Person2: No, that's your problem, Michael. You get around one of these experts and you turn into a blind follower.
Person1: What's the matter with you? So the data is a little inconsistent. So what?
Person2: Can't you see it? You're ignoring the facts.
Person1: I didn't say nobody, I said you. You're the one who's being selective with the evidence.
Person2: Yes, I did. And you're trying to distract me from the real issue.
Person1: What matters to me is we've got the biggest breakthrough we've had in five years. So the methodology is a little flawed. So what? Nobody's gonna notice it, Emma. Nobody. So why should you care?
Person2: Because I can see it. And I won't let you manipulate me into ignoring it.

Person1: You're still stuck on that, aren't you? You think I did it for greed?
Person2: You did your mom a favor, Alex. The woman was a mess, always playing games and manipulating people.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is you're still blaming me for your own weaknesses. If you learned to stand up for yourself, you wouldn't be in this situation.
Person2: Like you? You, who can't even take responsibility for your own actions?
Person1: At least I don't choke on my own anger. I fight back, and I don't let people walk all over me. You, on the other hand, are just a pawn in their game.
Person2: That's rich coming from you. You're the one who's always playing the victim.

Person1: I don't think we should go back there. Are you crazy?
Person2: It's the only way. I know you're still thinking about my past, but I've been faithful to you since we met.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is you're not being honest with me about what's going on.
Person2: I am being honest. You're just not listening. You're too busy feeling sick about my past to hear what I'm saying.
Person1: I feel sick because you're not telling me the truth. You're hiding something from me.
Person2: I'm not hiding anything. You're just paranoid because of your own guilt. You're the one who's been with twelve different girls, remember?
Person1: That has nothing to do with this.
Person2: Oh, doesn't it? You're so quick to judge me, but you're not willing to look at your own actions. That's not fair.
Person1: I don't want to talk about this anymore.
Person2: Fine. But you're going to have to face the truth eventually. And when you do, you'll realize that I'm the one who's been honest with you all along.

Person1: You're telling me she's in trouble?
Person2: Yeah, I'm trying to tell you. She was at the Four Seasons last night, man.
Person1: The thing about it is, threesomes so rarely work out.
Person2: What are you talking about? This has nothing to do with that.
Person1: I'm saying, it's hard enough for one person to keep a secret, let alone three. And then there's the love angle.
Person2: You're not listening to me. She's in real trouble.
Person1: Oh, really? You wanna go look?
Person2: No, I don't want to go look. I want you to listen to me.
Person1: I'm listening. But you have to promise not to tell anyone, alright?
Person2: No, I mean, no one. This is serious.
Person1: Hey, you know me. I can keep a secret.
Person2: Look, it's about Tim. He's in trouble. He confessed to me last night.
Person1: Confessed what?
Person2: He killed Erica. Tim's a murderer.
Person1: Bullshit. That's total utter bullshit.
Person2: Oh, really? You wanna go look?

Person1: I've been hearing rumors that you're thinking of taking on a new project.
Person2: It's just an idea I'm considering. Nothing's decided yet. Possibly... by examining the evidence from one case we might shed some small ray of light on the other.
Person1: After all we've worked on together? You can't doubt my expertise now. Think about the team and what we've built.
Person2: Great. Well, I'm sure glad that's settled, aren't you? It's about what's best for the company, and I'm willing to accept the theory that one project can inform the other.

Person1: You're a poet. You oughta be able to.
Person2: I had something to do for you - you didn't do it.
Person1: This is why you don't show work in progress. You're trying to hide something from me.
Person2: Can I come in for a minute? I need to explain.
Person1: No. You're just trying to manipulate me, like you always do.

Person1: You're being ridiculous. You have to come with me to the party.
Person2: I don't know...I'm not really in the mood.
Person1: Oh, come on. It's a tradition. You can't miss it. Besides, I thought you loved me.
Person2: That has nothing to do with this.

Person1: You're lucky you don't remember the past - I never had much, but what I did have, I lost.
Person2: That's a lie! You're just trying to make me feel guilty.
Person1: Guilty? You're the one who's been counting my acres, trying to discover exactly how poor I really am.
Person2: I'd throw everything away for you, but you only love me for my comfort.
Person1: Comfort? You mean the comfort of being a patriot, or the comfort of gaining a rise in society by becoming victorious in war?
Person2: You're just trying to confuse me. I know what I want from this world, and I'll get it, no matter what you say.
Person1: Oh, I'm sure you will. But when you do, you'll realize it's not what you truly wanted. You'll be left with nothing but a fear of losing it.

Person1: I'm glad you're realizing that switching bodies wouldn't be the answer to all your problems. You shouldn't be so quick to assume that.
Person2: Always read everything before signing, Alex. You're lucky to have someone like me looking out for you.
Person1: I know, Rachel. Sometimes I get too impulsive. But I think we should have Maxine over for dinner. Since you two are partners and all.
Person2: Just remember, not everyone has your best interests at heart. Stick close and I'll help guide you. And I'll fix my lasagna. We'll smoke a joint. Tensions will melt away.

Person1: I've been wondering when I can finally take a break from this job. The stress is killing me.
Person2: You want to take a break? You're lucky to have a job, Rachel. I gave you a chance, I gave you a platform, and what do I get in return? Subpar performance and constant excuses.
Person1: That's not fair, Marcus. I've been working hard, but you're always finding ways to make me feel guilty.
Person2: Guilty? You should be grateful. I've invested so much in you, and you're still not delivering. You're like a bad investment, Rachel. And I don't tolerate bad investments.
Person1: Please, Marcus, don't say that. I have so many debts, so many things to take care of. If you fire me, I'll be ruined.
Person2: Ruined? You're already ruined, Rachel. You're just too blind to see it. But I'll give you one last chance. Prove yourself to me, and maybe, just maybe, I'll let you stay.

Person1: You should give up on that startup idea. It's not going to work out.
Person2: What about it?
Person1: You're wasting your time and money. You need to focus on a real career.
Person2: I don't have any money.
Person1: Use my connections. I can get you a job at a good company.
Person2: I can't do that. It's not what I want to do.
Person1: Why not? You're not going to make it on your own. You need my help.
Person2: I'll get stuck in a 9-to-5 job. I want to take a risk.
Person1: You're being foolish. You're going to end up in trouble. Now come work for me.

Person1: I'm not comfortable with this arrangement, Governor.
Person2: Do me a favor. Think about it. Is that too much to ask? You're ready to move up, take on more responsibility.
Person1: It's not that I don't appreciate the offer, but I'm not sure I'm ready for the consequences.
Person2: Then try harder, Ambassador. I have no intention of dismissing you. You will remain in my service and learn your place.
Person1: I'd rather you dismissed me. It's obvious I don't satisfy.
Person2: Christ, the way you've been performing, you're doing worse already. May as well get paid instead of punished.

Person1: I've been thinking, Alex. I have some "positions" opening up. You fancy yourself a visionary. Here's a chance to explore something no human has ever experienced.
Person2: Not if it means sacrificing our entire research team. I wonder, did your mentor know that she inspired a student who was capable of such ruthless ambition?

Person1: You're not even a real hero. Part myth. Part fantasy.
Person2: What do you mean? I've got the scars to prove it.
Person1: Scars don't make the man. It's what's inside that counts. And inside, you're just a scared little boy.
Person2: That's not true! I've faced my fears and come out on top.
Person1: Oh, really? Then why do you need to constantly prove yourself to others? Why do you need their validation?
Person2: I don't need anyone's validation. I do it for myself.
Person1: Save it, hero. I know all about your type. You're just trying to capture the hearts of women and make them swoon. But deep down, you're just as scared of them as you are of your own shadow.
Person2: That's not fair! You don't know anything about me.
Person1: I know that you're just trying to compensate for your own inadequacies. You're trying to scrog your way to the top, but it's not going to work. Not with me, anyway.
Person2: You know, I used to think you were someone I could trust. But now I realize you're just trying to manipulate me.
Person1: Ah, finally, you're catching on. But it's too late. I've already got you right where I want you.

Person1: What do you want?
Person2: I think you know. You're not as innocent as you seem.
Person1: Don't be a fool. I loved him. He wasn't worth it, but I loved him.
Person2: And now that he's safe from all other women, you can go on loving him. But let me ask you, have you checked your parents' blood types? Are you sure your parents are your birth parents?
Person1: What does that have to do with anything? You're just trying to confuse me.
Person2: Confuse you? No, I'm trying to open your eyes. You're already contaminated. It's why you can't see the truth. There's probably a reason you can't remember certain things.
Person1: You're just trying to manipulate me.
Person2: Am I? Or am I just showing you how easy it is to uncover the truth? Perhaps you should ask yourself, what do you really know about your past?

Person1: You're not thinking clearly. I can see it in your eyes.
Person2: What are you talking about? I'm fine.
Person1: Fine? You're a mess. And that's the best part. "Rise and Fall of a Star: How Ambition Can Destroy You" - we're gonna make a killing off this story!
Person2: You already pitched this to the publisher?!
Person1: Of course. They're salivating over it. You're a contender, kid. You had class. You could've been somebody. Real class.
Person2: Stop it. You don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: Oh, I do. I know exactly what I'm talking about. You're just not thinking clearly. Let me help you see things my way.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's not a big deal. You're overreacting.
Person2: You don't understand. Something terrible happened last night.
Person1: What do you mean? You're being really vague.
Person2: I don't think I should tell you. You'll just get angry.
Person1: Try me. I can handle it.
Person2: Fine. It involves your sister. She... did something to me.
Person1: What are you talking about? My sister would never do anything to hurt you.
Person2: That's not what I meant. She... she convinced me to do something I regret.
Person1: What did she convince you to do?
Person2: I don't know if I should say. You'll think I'm stupid.
Person1: Come on, tell me. I promise I won't judge you.
Person2: She convinced me to take a job from her boss. Now I'm in deep trouble.
Person1: That's not so bad. We can figure something out.
Person2: You don't get it. Her boss is a dangerous person. I'm in danger now.
Person1: Don't be dramatic. We'll sort it out. But first, tell me more about what happened last night.
Person2: I don't know if I should trust you. You're being really pushy.
Person1: I'm just trying to help. You can trust me.

Person1: I'm not going to the party tonight.
Person2: Don't be a spoilsport. It's a great opportunity to network.
Person1: It's not about the opportunity. I just don't feel like it.
Person2: We'll need to make a good impression if we want to land that deal. I happen to have my business cards with me. Where's yours?

Person1: I need to know you're being honest with me before I can trust you.
Person2: You're needed here, keep watching, I'll take care of the rest.
Person1: You're not taking care of anything. You're hiding something.
Person2: Mystery is what makes things interesting, don't you think?
Person1: Not when it comes to people's lives. I want to know what's going on.
Person2: You want to know the truth? The truth is, you're not ready for it.
Person1: That's not for you to decide.

Person1: I'm telling you, you're not really cut out for this job. You're just not good enough.
Person2: That's not what I wanted to hear. I was hoping for some honesty.
Person1: Oh, I'm sorry... I was just saying that because I thought that's what you wanted me to say. You're actually doing a great job.
Person2: You sure? You're not just saying that to make me feel better?
Person1: Positive. But between you and me, the boss thinks you're struggling. Maybe you should try to impress him more.
Person2: Like how? By flirting with him like you do?
Person1: Hey, that's not fair. I'm just being friendly. You're the one who's always complaining about your job.
Person2: That's because I have a weak spot for people who are nice to me. But I guess I should stop looking for sympathy and just focus on my work.
Person1: Exactly. And maybe you should start taking some advice from me. I've been doing this job for years, after all.

Person1: You're very perceptive, Alex. Interesting term. So many experts on art forgery. And you say you're a 'collector?' But it was you who acquired the rare piece, wasn't it, Alex? Do you know how you did it?
Person2: You've seen the catalog. It's all there.
Person1: No, it's not. Do you know how you did it, Alex?
Person2: It's in the catalog. What does it matter now?
Person1: It doesn't matter to me, Alex. You want me to authenticate the piece, don't you?
Person2: I thought you would have some expertise.
Person1: Why should I tell you? You're not even a real connoisseur.
Person2: There are things you don't have. Access to the black market... I could speak to the curator...?
Person1: Ah, yes, the curator. Gruesome, isn't he? He fumbles at the art like a freshman pulling at a panty girdle. He actually tries to give me a lecture on provenance. Hah. Sat there waiting for the fake to be exposed. It's a game, isn't it? I was supposed to avoid a suspicious interpretation. I laughed in his face. Never mind, it's boring.
Person2: You'll get to see the documentation on this piece. And there's another reason.
Person1: Pray tell.
Person2: I thought you might be curious to find out if you're smarter than the forger I'm looking for.
Person1: Then by implication, you think that you are smarter than me, since you acquired the piece.
Person2: No. I knew that I'm not smarter than you are.
Person1: Then how did you acquire it, Alex?
Person2: You had disadvantages. You're too close to the art world.
Person1: What disadvantage? You're very knowledgeable, Alex.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly, Alex. I know you're upset, but forty percent is a fair deal considering the risks involved.
Person2: Fair deal? You're the one who's been sitting behind a desk all day, not me. I'm the one who's been sweating it out in the ring, getting lean and mean like Tommy Hearns.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is, we need to discuss this in a more... civilized environment. Why don't we meet at the State Theater tomorrow night, after the fights? We can sit down and look at it good.
Person2: You want to talk about civilized? You're the one who's trying to lowball me, Alex. I'm not some rookie who's going to fall for your tricks. I know what I'm worth, and I'm not going to settle for anything less.

Person1: You should be grateful I'm even talking to you. Do you know what he did to me...?
Person2: Whatever happened, it's not like you're innocent. You're just as guilty as the rest of them.
Person1: How can you say that? You have no idea what it's like to be in my shoes.
Person2: I don't need to know what it's like. I know you're trying to shift the blame, just like you always do.
Person1: That's not fair. You're not listening to me.
Person2: I'm listening, all right. I'm listening to the same excuses and justifications you've been using for years.

Person1: I've had enough of your excuses, and I'm not going to argue about it anymore. You're either with me or against me.
Person2: Fire the entire team. We don't need them anymore.
Person1: Are you kidding me? You can't just get rid of them like that. They're good people.
Person2: Good people? Ha! They're expendable. And if you don't see it that way, then maybe you're expendable too.
Person1: You're not going to intimidate me. I know what's really going on here, and I'm not going to let you bully me into doing something I don't want to do.
Person2: Oh, I think you will. You're too invested in this project to walk away now. And if you try to leave, I'll make sure everyone knows what a traitor you are.

Person1: What's the matter with you, you little fool? You're making a spectacle of yourself in front of my family!
Person2: I'm sorry, sir. I didn't mean to cause a scene.
Person1: A scene? You think this is just a scene? You're making me look like a laughingstock! I'm standing at the pass of Thermopylae, and I won't back down! You're supposed to have some control and sense, not act like a nitwit!
Person2: I said I'm sorry, sir. Please, just leave me alone.

Person1: You're a hardcase too, ain't you, Professor? I can't believe I almost trusted you without reading between the lines.
Person2: Alex, are you alright?... They got us, boy. They're watching our every move, and I'm the only one who can get us out of this. You don't have a chance, Alex... They've been waiting for you, and I'm the only one who can negotiate your safe passage. But you have to listen to me and play it cool.
Person1: Do we even get to keep our research funding?
Person2: Why sure, Alex. I mean I didn't talk to them about that. But why not? They're reasonable, Alex. Hell, we only been working on this project for a few months.
Person1: You don't understand a thing, do you, Professor?
Person2: Alex, you got to trust me. All you got to do is just follow my lead, and I'll get us out of this mess.

Person1: You're so naive, thinking you can change me. "Let me help you..."
Person2: I know you're scared, but I'm willing to take that risk. I could love you, help you find some peace of mind, some happiness...
Person1: Save it, Doctor. You just want to study me, figure out what makes me tick so you can write a paper about it. I'm not a project, I'm a person.
Person2: That's not true. I want to understand you, help you overcome your fears. You're not fat, you're just... lost.
Person1: Lost? You think you can fix me? I'm beyond repair. And by the way, what's with the "you're not fat" comment? Trying to butter me up?
Person2: No, I just meant... never mind. Look, I know you're hurt, and I want to help you heal. But you have to let me in.
Person1: Let you in? You're already in my head, aren't you? Playing on my fears, making me doubt myself. Well, it won't work. I'm not that easy to manipulate.

Person1: You're still not convinced, are you? I can see it in your eyes. You think I'm hiding something.
Person2: (long pause) What's there to hide?
Person1: The truth. I've been lying to you from the start. But I did it to protect you, to keep you close. You wouldn't have stayed otherwise.
Person2: You disgust me... even if what you say is true.
Person1: Then you won't forgive me? Unless I can prove it to you, that is. But can you handle the truth?

Person1: I'm telling you, Rachel, this is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. Are you listening?
Person2: What's the big deal about this artifact? It's just a relic from the past.
Person1: Because when we get our hands on it, we can change the course of history. Don't you want to be a part of that?
Person2: I don't know... I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this.
Person1: Comfortable? You think this is about being comfortable? This is about making a name for ourselves, about being remembered.
Person2: I said I wanted to talk to a lawyer.
Person1: Oh, come on, Rachel. You're not going to let a little thing like ethics hold you back, are you? We're on the brink of something huge here.
Person2: What if someone finds out? What if this gets out?
Person1: That's the beauty of it. No one will ever know. And even if they do, we'll be long gone, enjoying our newfound fame and fortune.
Person2: You're not threatening me, are you?
Person1: Of course not, Rachel. I'm just trying to make you see the bigger picture. Now, are you with me or not?

Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: You have complete freedom. Do what you want.
Person1: You're making me very angry. Why are you doing this?
Person2: I'm just trying to help you grow, to go out. Whatever you want.
Person1: Anything? Like if I wanted to ask someone to dance?
Person2: Anything. But you're not thinking clearly. You're letting your emotions cloud your judgment.
Person1: You think I'm not attractive enough to dance with?
Person2: That's not what I meant. You're just not seeing the bigger picture. You're too focused on trivial things.
Person1: Maybe it doesn't matter what I do, because you're just going to manipulate me anyway.
Person2: I'm not trying to manipulate you. I'm just trying to guide you towards making better decisions.

Person1: You know, I think it's time you reconsidered your plans to investigate the company's financial records.
Person2: Why's that?
Person1: It would put you in great danger, and I'm not sure you're prepared for what you might find.
Person2: You're just trying to protect me, aren't you? Well, I appreciate your concern, but I can take care of myself.
Person1: I'm not trying to protect you, I'm trying to protect the people who would be affected by your discovery. And I think you'll find that the music in this office is quite... distracting. Don't you think it's a bit too loud?
Person2: You know, I think you're the one who's being distracted. And I'd rather not discuss the music right now.

Person1: You're really going to walk out on me again? I can't believe this.
Person2: You know exactly why I'm leaving. You've been playing me all along, and I'm not buying it anymore.
Person1: That's not fair. I've been honest with you from the start. You're just upset because the truth hurts.
Person2: Save it. I want what's mine, and I'm not leaving until I get it. You've been using me for your own gain, and now it's time to pay up.
Person1: You're being ridiculous. I've given you everything you've asked for. What more do you want?
Person2: I want respect. I want to be treated like an equal, not some pawn in your game.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously.
Person2: I said I was sorry. What more do you want?
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I know you're capable of better.
Person2: I need this opportunity. You can't just take it away from me.
Person1: So what? You think a simple apology will fix everything?

Person1: You're filthy, inside and out.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: It means you're not respecting the power of our relationship. You're not in awe of what we have.
Person2: I am in awe of it. You're just not giving me anything to be in awe of.
Person1: That's not true. I've been doing everything for you, and you haven't said one nice thing to me in months.
Person2: I'm sorry. I've been working so hard, trying to make a name for myself.
Person1: You're making a name for yourself, all right. You're making a name for yourself as someone who doesn't appreciate what they have. I think you ought to either find a different job or a different partner. Cause there may be people who don't mind being walked all over, but I'm sure as hell not one of them.
Person2: I need this job, it's the best thing that ever happened to me. I mean it. For the first time in my life, I feel respected.
Person1: More than you respect me. Get me the wine opener.

Person1: I've got the documents. If you ever want to see your sister out of trouble, do exactly what I say.
Person2: No way. No absolutely way!
Person1: I'll pick the moment, Rachel. The game goes on until I move. When I start talking, go for the nearest exit and get out of here.
Person2: YOU'RE CRAZY!!!... NO WAY!... NOW YOU'RE CRAZY!!! YOU'RE COMPLETELY CRAZY!!!
Person1: Don't bullshit me, Rachel! I know about the deal. You better get the documents somehow. Six o'clock and come alone. If you don't, we'll destroy the evidence.

Person1: You're desperate, aren't you? You're afraid of being alone.
Person2: How could you do this to me?
Person1: I'm not doing anything to you. I'm just staying here with you because I know you need me.
Person2: That's not true. I don't need you.
Person1: Oh, come on... You're not fooling anyone, least of all yourself. I know you're afraid. Say I'm right. Say you're afraid.

Person1: You're not going to get what you want. 
Person2: What did you mean by that? 
Person1: I mean you're being blinded by the promise of money. It's all about the power. What do you want, a guarantee? 
Person2: No, I want my fair share! 
Person1: I'm going to say this one last time for you, so take a deep breath and count to ten. You're not going to get it.

Person1: You're not listening to me.
Person2: I'm just trying to understand your perspective.
Person1: Leave. You're not welcome here.
Person2: Don't be paranoid, I'm just trying to help.
Person1: You're not helping. You're making things worse.
Person2: I apologize if I've overstepped any boundaries. But I think we need to discuss this further.
Person1: There's nothing to discuss. You've made your intentions clear.
Person2: I'm not trying to manipulate you, I just want what's best for everyone involved.
Person1: Save it. I'm not buying it.

Person1: You're mine, you know. I made you.
Person2: Oh, dear. That isn't what I --
Person1: What I mean, Clark, is that you don't want folks to think you're special. You're grown up now, and I want you to spread your wings, but there's no need to hurry it along, is there?
Person2: I bless the day you came to us, Mother. You know that. But some people wouldn't understand.
Person1: That's twice this month you've slipped away without a word and run off. People might get the wrong idea and think you're unhappy at home.

Person1: You said the vision, the images. They're just that. Just pictures. They can't hurt you.
Person2: That's what you always said, but I think it's the same way with people. Different people, different vibes. You can't get close to someone like me listening to elevator music. You gotta get intense. You gotta get raw.
Person1: What do you mean?
Person2: I mean, you can't tame a wild heart with gentle words. You gotta speak its language. You gotta show it the darkness and the light.
Person1: And what if I'm not sure what that language is?
Person2: Then you're not ready to get close. But if you want to learn, I can teach you. I can show you the way. Just remember, once you see the truth, you can't unsee it. Got it?

Person1: You're not thinking clearly, are you?
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: I mean, you're considering my offer, but you're not seeing the bigger picture. You're not thinking about the long-term benefits.
Person2: I'm thinking about the risks. I'm thinking about what could go wrong.
Person1: Ah, but that's exactly what I'm trying to tell you. You're focusing on the wrong things. You're letting fear hold you back.
Person2: Fear? You're the one who's been pushing me to make a decision. You're the one who's been saying I have to do this now or miss out.
Person1: I'm just trying to help you see the opportunity. I'm trying to help you overcome your doubts.
Person2: My doubts? You're the one who's been manipulating me from the start. You're the one who's been using my fears against me.
Person1: That's not true. I'm just trying to help you make the right decision.
Person2: The right decision for who? For you or for me?

Person1: I'm still trying to process why you brought up my ex at the gathering last night.
Person2: I thought you two had moved past your differences. I didn't think it would be a big deal.
Person1: You're right about that. So, this is your new art project? I've never seen anything like it.
Person2: Oh, yeah... I've been experimenting with different mediums. But, I have to say, I'm a bit surprised you're interested.
Person1: Interested? I'm just trying to understand why you felt the need to stir up old drama. Look what you made me do  I had to relive all those painful memories!
Person2: I'm sorry, Alex. I genuinely thought it would be okay. I didn't mean to cause any discomfort.
Person1: Next time, think and ask. Don't assume. And, by the way, can I see more of your art? I'm curious to know what inspired this piece.

Person1: I've been thinking about your situation, and I've decided to help you. But you have to trust me.
Person2: I'm not sure I can trust anyone right now.
Person1: Boy, do I know how you feel. First time I saw your case, I said you got to be kidding me. The way they're treating you is outrageous.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: Look, don't say a word. I've taken an interest in you, and I'm willing to put up my time to help you. Besides, I think I know where to find the evidence you need.
Person2: Where?
Person1: Wait a minute. This has got a lot of angles. You've got to take it easy. Do you know a Mr. Johnson?
Person2: Yes. He's the one who's been handling my case.
Person1: That's what he told you. I looked into it, and it seems he's been withholding information from you.
Person2: Why would he do that?
Person1: That's what I tried to find out. But I think I can help you get to the bottom of it.
Person2: I want to go to his office and confront him.
Person1: Sister, you can't just go storming into places. There are procedures to follow, and I can help you with that.
Person2: If I don't do something, I'll lose everything.

Person1: I've got news for you too. You're not as happy as you think you are.
Person2: What do you mean? I'm happy enough.
Person1: No, you're not. You're just pretending to be a hard ol' sourpuss. You're hiding something from me.
Person2: I'm not hiding anything. I just don't want to give the children to Refugio because they yell.
Person1: That's not the real reason. You're trying to control me, to keep me from getting what I want. Well, I'll get you in the fields tomorrow and we'll settle this once and for all.
Person2: You can't intimidate me. I know things about you that you don't even know about yourself.

Person1: You're not going to intimidate me, Agent Thompson. I know what I saw.
Person2: Look, Mrs. Jenkins, we have reason to believe you're not telling us the whole truth. You're hiding something.
Person1: I'm not hiding anything. I'm just trying to get to the bottom of this conspiracy.
Person2: Conspiracy? You're not thinking clearly, Mrs. Jenkins. You're under a lot of stress. It's clouding your judgment.
Person1: I'm not stressed, I'm angry. And I know exactly what I heard that night. It was more than three shots.
Person2: You're letting your emotions get the better of you. You're not thinking rationally. Come with me, and we'll get you some help.
Person1: Help? You're the one who needs help. You're trying to manipulate me, to make me doubt my own sanity.
Person2: I'm trying to help you, Mrs. Jenkins. You're not thinking clearly. Give yourself to the truth. It's the only way you can save yourself.
Person1: Save myself? From what? From the truth? You're the one who's hiding something, Agent Thompson. And I'm going to find out what it is.

Person1: I'm not particularly interested, Dr. Lee, in what you think is correct. My partner and I are going away on a business trip this afternoon and we want Alex with us.
Person2: We were having a little talk, Ms. Patel. Children often have trouble adjusting to a new job.
Person1: I don't know what she's told you -- What has she told you? Would you like to tell me -- ?
Person2: You people have a lot of nerve, taking it on yourselves to encourage young adults to speak out of turn. I'm of a mind to pull Alex out of this project if this is your idea of how to handle... What sort of training do you have anyway?
Person1: I could have my choice of many mentors and go to conferences and seminars, but I waste my time waiting for you and then going to stupid meetings.
Person2: Ms. Patel, I -- 
Person1: That's it, I am just stupid, yes? Right now, yeah - you're talking crap.

Person1: You think I'm not aggressive enough for the job?
Person2: I think you're perfect for the office, but out there, it's a different story. You're all about order, control, and getting the reports done on time.
Person1: That's not true! I can be out of control, I can grab the bull by the balls!
Person2: Really? Then why did you warn the investors to back off instead of taking a risk? You begged them not to force your hand, didn't you?
Person1: That was different. I was just trying to avoid a confrontation.
Person2: We have witnesses who can confirm that you didn't always play it safe. Sometimes you took risks, didn't you?
Person1: Maybe... but I never hurt anyone.
Person2: So you're saying you held back, even when it would have been easier to take a stand? You held up your proposal and flourished it about, trying to convince them, but you never really committed?
Person1: That's not fair! I did what I thought was right at the time.
Person2: And now you want us to believe that you're ready to take on the tough jobs, to get in there and fight for what you want? I don't think so.

Person1: You're so naive, thinking you can resist his charms. Let him guide you, like a tutor. Practice makes perfect, after all.
Person2: But I don't want to lose myself in him. I want to stay true to who I am.
Person1: Ah, come on. You're not going to find someone who loves you for who you are. You need to adapt, to become what they want you to be. And if you're lucky, they might just love you back.
Person2: That sounds like a recipe for disaster. Or worse, a life of lies.
Person1: Oh, don't be dramatic. It's just a little white lie here and there. And who knows, you might just find yourself in the process.

Person1: I don't know anything about that, Doctor. I would have to examine you first...
Person2: You're running a risk by letting me in, Doctor. You know I'm running a risk of getting my reputation ruined.
Person1: Well, I'm not surprised. You think I'm crazy, don't you?
Person2: I thought so. You're living out some fantasy land from the past, or some advice or something from those psychoanalysts...
Person1: That's what I told my husband. And he said I was crazy. He was a very sick man. Very sick.
Person2: Your unfaithfulness - that's what I'm trying to talk about. Your betrayal. Your dalliance. And you won't do me the dignity of being up front about it.
Person1: Am I unfaithful? Is that what you're trying to say? You old fellow!
Person2: If you're going to insult me, at least be honest about it. Don't be dim.

Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: I just wanted to see you, to apologize for my past mistakes.
Person1: You can't just show up, apologize, and expect everything to be okay.
Person2: I know, but I'm willing to do whatever it takes to regain your trust.
Person1: You're doing this for your own political gain, aren't you?
Person2: That's not fair. I'm trying to make amends.
Person1: Save it. You're just trying to manipulate me into forgiving you.
Person2: Maybe at first, but the more I think about it, the more I realize I really do want to be a part of your life again.
Person1: I don't know if I can trust you. You've lied to me before.
Person2: I know, and I'm sorry. But I'm willing to do whatever it takes to prove myself to you. Just give me a chance.

Person1: I'm here to inspect your facility. I've heard rumors about the chemicals you're storing.
Person2: What's it to you? You're not from around here, are you?
Person1: Let's just say I have a vested interest in making sure you're not polluting our environment. Now, are you going to show me around or do I need to get a warrant?
Person2: You think you're tough, huh? Well, I've dealt with people like you before. You're just trying to flex your muscles. I'm not impressed.
Person1: Save it, pal. I've heard enough empty threats for one day. You're not intimidating me.
Person2: Oh, I'm not trying to intimidate you. I'm just warning you: don't shit in my backyard. You're not in charge here.

Person1: What's going on here? You're not thinking clearly, are you?
Person2: I'm thinking just fine, thanks. You're the one who's been playing games with my head.
Person1: Games? Ha! You brought this on yourself. You should've known better than to trust me.
Person2: Trust you? You're the one who's been lying to me, manipulating me. I didn't do anything to deserve this.
Person1: Oh, come on. You're not naive enough to think I'd let you get the upper hand, are you? Now, tell me what you know, or things will get much worse.

Person1: You're really going to leave me for that job, aren't you? Don't you even miss me?
Person2: I thought it might be kind of fun, you know what I mean, it'd be nice to meet some new people. I don't respond well to being tied down, you know what I mean, I have a tendency to... if I get too comfortable, I ripen and then rot.
Person1: All right, all right, you don't wanna be with me, so whatta you gonna do?
Person2: Nothing.

Person1: I'm telling you, Alex, don't be naive. You think your boyfriend is different, but men are pigs.
Person2: That's not fair, Rachel. I trust him. He promised me he wouldn't do anything stupid at the party.
Person1: Promises, promises. I've heard it all before. You're not going to learn from my experience, are you?
Person2: Rachel, you're not exactly objective when it comes to men. You've been hurt before.
Person1: And that's exactly why I'm trying to warn you. You're not going to stand up to him, are you? You're going to let him walk all over you.
Person2: That's not true. I can take care of myself. But I appreciate your concern, Rachel.

Person1: You're filthy, Alex. You're making a mess of your life.
Person2: I'm not a bozo, I'm just trying to figure things out. You're the one who's been giving me bad advice.
Person1: Sex isn't ugly, Alex, but the way you're approaching it is. You need to respect the power of relationships.
Person2: You're just trying to control me, like you always do. You never gave a shit about my well-being, only about how I can make you look good.
Person1: I'm trying to help you, Alex. You're sick if you can't see that. Now, let's get you some help.
Person2: Help? You call this help? You're just trying to manipulate me again. I'm not buying it.

Person1: You're so gullible. You actually believed I was happy with him.
Person2: Shut up and listen, you're just trying to distract me from your own mistakes.

Person1: You're really getting under my skin today.
Person2: Your hair's cute like that. You should never comb it.
Person1: That's not the point. You're trying to distract me.
Person2: I doubt that. Besides, I'm just trying to help you see things from a different perspective.
Person1: I don't need your help. I can think for myself.
Person2: Aw, come on. You know you need me. You're just too proud to admit it.

Person1: You said "the Commander" back there.
Person2: What? No, I didn't.
Person1: Yes, you did. And I think you're hiding something.
Person2: I'm not hiding anything. You're just trying to confuse me.
Person1: Confuse you? I'm trying to help you. You need a fresh start.
Person2: A fresh start? You mean like getting a job as a plumber?
Person1: It's not about the job, it's about taking control of your life.
Person2: You're just trying to manipulate me, like you always do.

Person1: I'm trying to help, but you always take things the wrong way.
Person2: You won't come back either, will you?
Person1: I've been juggling a lot lately, but that's no excuse.
Person2: Trust me, I can make it up to you.
Person1: Trust you? Because of trusting you, we're in this mess.
Person2: Maybe if you approached things differently, I wouldn't feel so trapped.
Person1: You think I'm gonna let you get away with this again? You think I'm a fool?
Person2: I can do something else to make it right. Just give me a chance.

Person1: I was just kidding, but you're really upset.
Person2: Say what you mean, or I'm walking out.
Person1: You're not going anywhere.

Person1: What's going on here? This isn't what I signed up for.
Person2: Don't make this into something it's not, Sophia. This is a chance for us to finally have the life we've always dreamed of. Don't you see? I'm talking about us being the ones others envy.
Person1: It sounds like there's more to this than you're letting on. What's really going on?
Person2: My team is just taking care of some... details. Don't trouble yourself, darling. Now, let's focus on us. We can finally have the freedom and luxury we deserve.

Person1: You're not going to die. At least, not yet.
Person2: What did you say? You're just trying to push the envelope, aren't you?
Person1: Shut up. You're blind to the reality. There's only one solution, and I'm the one who's going to decide what it is.

Person1: I don't like him.
Person2: Don't worry, you won't see him again. What's bothering you, anyway?
Person1: You're counting a little too much on my being absent-minded. You've been taking a little here and there for some time, and I haven't said anything about it.
Person2: Now, don't be paranoid, Alex. About the direction of our partnership, we may have had our differences of opinion...
Person1: Is that a threat? You threatening my business, now, too?
Person2: I appreciate your trust in me, Alex. But, upon reflection... we've decided to expand our zone of comfort with you. You see, I've given my whole life for this business, and I'm sick and tired of seeing you hand out thousands of dollars to that incompetent manager of yours...
Person1: That's my business. You're just trying to distract me from the real issue. What did you do with the company funds?
Person2: What if I did take them? I'm the one who's been keeping this business afloat while you're out enjoying yourself. If you kicked off tomorrow, where'd I be? Out in the gutter!

Person1: I'm scared.
Person2: You're making progress, though. Instead of lashing out at everyone, you're only pushing away those closest to you.
Person1: That's not true. I just don't want to go to the party tonight.
Person2: Then why are you sitting here in the dark? You're not even trying to convince yourself, let alone me.
Person1: I don't know. Maybe I'm just tired of being a lab rat.
Person2: Ah, so you're feeling a little trapped. That's understandable. But you have to admit, it's fascinating to see how you react under pressure.
Person1: You're not my therapist. You're just here to study me.
Person2: Well, someone has to help you uncover the truth about yourself. And I'm the only one who can do that.
Person1: I don't want your help. I just want to be left alone.
Person2: That's not possible, not yet. You still have so much to learn about yourself. And I'm the only one who can teach you.

Person1: I've been thinking, we could really make a profit from this land... beautiful views, perfect for a resort.
Person2: I'm not sure that's a good idea, we'd need to consider the environmental impact...
Person1: Ah, come on, don't be such a stickler for the rules. We can make it work, I'll take care of the permits.
Person2: I don't know... I have a bad feeling about this.
Person1: Nonsense, it'll be a great opportunity for us. And think of all the jobs it'll create. You're not going to let a little uncertainty hold you back, are you?
Person2: I suppose not... but I still have my doubts.
Person1: That's the spirit! I'll start making some calls, get the ball rolling. You won't regret this.

Person1: You're not a real player, are you? You're just trying to make a quick buck.
Person2: Of course not. I don't want to scare you off. Not before I'm finished with you.
Person1: Finished with me? You're the one who's in trouble. You're drowning in debt and you don't know how to get out.
Person2: I had a tough day, okay? Some jerk reneged on me and I gotta cover his loss.
Person1: Ah, poor baby. You should've thought of that before you got into this racket. You could've been a doctor or a lawyer.
Person2: Coulda been a contender. But I'm doing fine. I'm building a customer list, and soon I'll be making more money than you ever dreamed of.
Person1: Yeah, right. And I'm the Queen of England. You're just trying to impress me with your big talk.
Person2: It's not big talk, it's the truth. And you're just jealous because you're stuck in a dead-end job and I'm living the high life.
Person1: Jealous? Of you? You're the one who's always coming to me for money. How much do you need this time?
Person2: Can you spare five hundred? I'll pay you back next month, promise.

Person1: You know, people from our generation had to earn respect. We didn't just demand it.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: I mean, I heard you sigh when you picked up that heavy box. You're not as strong as you think you are.
Person2: I didn't sigh, I just breathed deeply. And I am strong enough, thank you very much.
Person1: Ah, but that's exactly what I'm talking about. You had to know your place back in the day. You had to know how to act right. Nowadays, everyone thinks they can do everything.
Person2: That's not fair. I can do plenty of things.
Person1: Oh, I'm sure you can. But let me tell you, I can see right through you. You're not as capable as you think you are. And that's why you need to learn some respect.

Person1: I'm willing to try if you are.
Person2: But you just said you were personally involved with all the decisions of the project. 
Person1: I can't be expected to remember every detail eight months after the fact.
Person2: I didn't say it was a detail. But since you mentioned it, wasn't Rachel your primary advisor?
Person1: You're trespassing into the area of confidential information, Dr. Lee. Such showboating puts our entire team at risk.
Person2: I know it's hard when we don't see eye to eye on things, but I believe it's our differences that make our collaboration richer.

Person1: I'm getting out of here, man. I'm not going to stay here and I'm not giving up.
Person2: Don't wear that outfit again. Wear a dress. A skirt or something.
Person1: What are you talking about? I'm trying to tell you something important.
Person2: You're really warped, you know that? You're trying to escape, but you're not even thinking clearly.
Person1: I know I'm warped. I'm warped! But I'm trying to square away my accounts with life.
Person2: Your accounts with life? You mean you're trying to run away from your problems?
Person1: Maybe. Maybe I'll just close my eyes and the whole thing will be over. That would be all right too!
Person2: You're not even listening to yourself. You're spreading death and destruction around you, and you don't even realize it.
Person1: I don't know what I'm doing. I'm just trying to survive.
Person2: Survive? You're not surviving, you're suffocating. And you're taking everyone around you down with you.
Person1: I'm sorry... I didn't mean to hurt anyone.
Person2: Sorry? Sorry isn't enough. You need to take responsibility for your actions.
Person1: I'll try. I'll try to do better.
Person2: Try? Try isn't enough. You need to change.

Person1: I'm telling you, it was like nothing I've ever felt before. I think I'm going crazy.
Person2: Destroying your own sanity is one thing, but manipulating others is quite another.
Person1: Let me reassure you, I will never manipulate more people in my entire life than you have in the last conversation.
Person2: You're crazy to think you can outmanipulate me, Johnny-Boy. I'm in the business of creating life, and you're just trying to create chaos.
Person1: I think it might've been this Lotte woman talking through me, trying to encourage life in her own twisted way.
Person2: Ouch. Now that's hot. She's using you to channel some dead lesbian lover, and you're eating it up. Let me know when you're done with her.
Person1: I'm done with her now. Tonight really creeped me out, and I think I need to take control of my own life.
Person2: The truth is for suckers, Johnny-Boy. But I'll give you credit - you're a quick learner. You're already using her tactics against me.

Person1: You're toxic, Alex. Monster in bed, but toxic.
Person2: Don't start. You think I'm the one who's unfaithful?
Person1: I have no idea, but I know you're being completely selfish. You were trying to have it both ways.
Person2: What's on your mind? You're not making any sense.
Person1: You know exactly what I'm talking about. Your betrayal. Your dalliance. And you won't do me the dignity of being up front about it.
Person2: Am I unfaithful? Is that what you're trying to say? You're the one who's been making mistakes, not me.
Person1: You would be making a mistake to come away from this thinking you're the victim in the piece. You're not.
Person2: You're just trying to deflect attention from your own actions. You're the one who's been lying and cheating.
Person1: Say the words, "I understand." Admit that you're wrong and take responsibility for your actions.
Person2: I understand that you're trying to manipulate me, but it won't work.

Person1: You're not exactly the cream of the crop, are you? I mean, who'd want to be friends with that bunch of wannabes?
Person2: I don't think it's right, judging people like that. You're not exactly a paragon of virtue yourself.
Person1: Am I going mad or did the word "think" escape your lips? You were not hired for your brains, you're just a means to an end.
Person2: Just shut up. You're not even trying to hide your manipulation.

Person1: I'm saving them for a rainy day.
Person2: You told me you had answers.
Person1: I know it's hard for you being in here, but it is for the good of your health.
Person2: Yeah, well I don't have them all. You've been using me --
Person1: They sent me off to the Bahamas "for the good of my health." They sent me to the Bay of bloody Islands "for the good of my health."
Person2: I've been using you?! You're a liar. You lied to me to gather information for you.
Person1: I'm sorry, I'm feeling quite fatigued. Can't you stay a bit longer?
Person2: We don't want to tire you out, dear.

Person1: You're crazy. You've gone crazy.
Person2: What do you expect? For them to bring it up here?
Person1: I'm talking about avoiding what you're talking about. That's the distinction.
Person2: We can't go down there. We're not prepared. That deep? That takes years of training.
Person1: Look who's talking. You've been there. Do I look like a happy man?
Person2: Well, you must have realized the chances an encounter like this would happen here. In the ocean.
Person1: And what about Stephanie? She's a woman -- with a kid. A single mom. What do you think she's looking for? Huh?
Person2: It never occurred to me. But I'm thinking, we move up here, you and me, buy a research facility. You design your own experiments; I'll handle the funding.
Person1: You're asking me to go against my instinct. And that's just wrong.
Person2: Just keep your mouth shut, alright? This could mean everything to our careers, you know that? Don't jeopardize this.

Person1: You're running from something, aren't you? 
Person2: Maybe I do. 
Person1: Or maybe you just think you do. You're trying to escape the truth, but it's always with you. 
Person2: I don't want to talk about it. 
Person1: It's a terrible thing to know something no one else wants to believe. You can run just as far as you can, but wherever you go, that's where you're going to be. 
Person2: You're just trying to confuse me. 
Person1: Am I? Or am I just showing you the mirror? You gotta remember, you can't satisfy the hunger of a hungry ghost. 
Person2: What do you want from me? 
Person1: What do you want for free?

Person1: What's the point of all this, anyway? I mean, you know, at least I admit that I don't know. I know that things are messed up beyond belief and I know that I have nothing original to say about any of it, alright?
Person2: (holding up a small recorder) Microrecorder for our little chat. Now, tell me why you're really here or I'll make sure everyone finds out about your little secret.
Person1: Oh, shut up, Alex. This isn't a game, man. You're not going to intimidate me with your tricks.
Person2: (smirking) We'll see about that.

Person1: I'm so exhausted. Can we just cancel the party tonight?
Person2: Who's being selfish now? I'm the one who organized this whole thing. I thought tonight was supposed to be about celebrating my promotion.
Person1: Mom, please, I don't think I can handle it. I've got a big exam tomorrow.
Person2: You'll have to suck it up. I know what you need. A night out will do you good.
Person1: But what am I supposed to tell my study group? Sorry, but I've got to attend my sister's party, go and study by yourself?
Person2: It's not exactly the end of the world, for goodness sake.

Person1: I'm telling you, I've never seen that man before in my life.
