Person2: Ah, go chase yourself. I'll take my business elsewhere. And for future reference, you are no longer welcome at this establishment.
Person1: What are you talking about? This is a police station.
Person2: Oh, right. Well, in that case, I think you're hiding something. You're not being entirely truthful with me, are you?
Person1: I'm telling the truth. I don't know what you're insinuating.
Person2: I'm insinuating that you're involved in something shady. And I'm going to find out what it is.
Person1: You can't just detain me without cause. I know my rights.
Person2: Oh, I think I can. You see, I have reason to believe you're involved in a very serious crime. And I'm going to get to the bottom of it.
Person1: This is ridiculous. I demand to see my lawyer.
Person2: Your lawyer? Ha! You're not going anywhere. You're going to stay right here and answer my questions.

Person1: I want you for my partner in this business venture.
Person2: Why are you so concerned about my involvement?
Person1: I've got it all arranged, and it will be good for both of us.
Person2: I was defending my interests, as best I could! Everyone has the right to protect themselves, don't they?
Person1: No, no, you did fine. I'd even say well done. But let's focus on the future now.
Person2: I don't think that manipulating each other will ever bring success.
Person1: I agree, but sometimes it's necessary to take calculated risks. Where's the contract?

Person1: You're really considering leaving us for the competition? After everything we've built together?
Person2: Watch your tone, I don't appreciate the accusation. I'm just exploring my options.
Person1: Exploring your options? You're not even giving me a chance to make a counteroffer. That's not fair.
Person2: Fair? You're one to talk about fair. You've been holding me back for years, stifling my growth.
Person1: That's not true, and you know it. I've always been there for you, supported you. Don't try to turn this around on me.
Person2: Supported me? You've been using me for your own gain, and now you're trying to guilt trip me into staying. I'm not buying it.

Person1: Who were you talking to?! You're the one who's been distant lately.
Person2: That's the problem. I can't afford to give you the attention you want. I'm about to close on a deal to launch my startup, and I'm mortgaged up to my neck. If this deal goes south, I'm ruined -- I'll lose everything.
Person1: So, you propose that in spite of my feelings, I should be ignored and neglected? Is that possible?
Person2: Well, is that what you're saying? You're the one who's been giving me the silent treatment.

Person1: I don't remember what I did wrong. What do I owe you?
Person2: You owe me an explanation. You've been distant lately, and I think you're taking our team's efforts for granted.
Person1: That's not true. I've just been feeling left out during team meetings.
Person2: Maybe you're just being too sensitive. You need to adjust your perspective and stop taking things personally.

Person1: You're really going to marry him, aren't you?
Person2: And don't think your return is going to change that!
Person1: I don't know, I was killing men when I was fifteen. I like getting shot at.
Person2: What right do you have to be talking marriage to any decent woman, after what you did to Zee?
Person1: If you're talking about that crazy murder charge...
Person2: And other things... Maybe you thought you were getting away with being comical about that Indian wife you took... I bet she wasn't the first squaw you...
Person1: You've killed your fair share of men, Frank. You need it now.
Person2: If I could go back to farming... But I can't quit and leave you alone. I can't quit until you quit.

Person1: You're not even God, are you? Nobody cares about you.
Person2: What's the plan, then? Where do we go from here?
Person1: I'll point you in the right direction, but you'll have to take it to the end. You're the one who's closer to the nitty and the gritty.
Person2: This is unprofessional. You're not even giving me a chance.
Person1: Ah, Stanzi, you're so sensitive. We spend a fortune on you, and all you do is complain.
Person2: That's not fair. You're the one who's always criticizing, never satisfied.
Person1: I'm the one with appearances to maintain. You're just a tool, a means to an end.

Person1: I don't mean to be a prick, but that's how I feel.
Person2: Unwelcome? I guess someone still has her pride wounded.
Person1: Don't for one minute think that you had any effect whatsoever on my confidence.
Person2: So what did I have an effect on? Other than your fragile ego?

Person1: You're a real puzzle, aren't you, Mr. Blackwood? I don't mean that as a compliment.
Person2: Perhaps I'm just a little too used to being alone. Famous and alone, that's me.
Person1: Save it, Mr. Blackwood. You're not fooling anyone with that act. You're not as hard as you think you are.
Person2: And how do you live? What kind of person are you, really? You seem to think you know me, but I know nothing about you.
Person1: I'm just a humble mechanic, trying to get by. But I can see right through you, Mr. Blackwood. You're all show and no substance.
Person2: That's not true! I've been to the school of hard knocks, I've learned to pray and lie... and kill and hide.
Person1: Oh, spare me the drama, Mr. Blackwood. You're not as tough as you think you are. You're just a scared little boy trying to prove himself.
Person2: You don't understand me at all. I'm a prodigal son, the black sheep of a white flock. I shall die on the gallows.
Person1: Save it for the judge, Mr. Blackwood. I'm not buying what you're selling.

Person1: I think you're real cute, but don't think you can outsmart me.
Person2: Mayors come and go, and heirs tire easily. You're no match for my influence.
Person1: You're playing with my mind, trying to seduce me with your power.
Person2: Of course I am. And I'm doing a damn good job of it. You're already intimidated.
Person1: I'm not scared of you. I know your tricks.
Person2: We'll see about that. I'll make you an offer you can't refuse.

Person1: I wanted to let you make up your own mind about the company's new policy.
Person2: Destroying the old system is one thing, but manipulating people's perceptions is quite another.
Person1: Let me reassure you, I will never manipulate more people in my entire career than the media has in the last decade.
Person2: No, you didn't! If you really thought I could make my own decisions, you would've let me attend the meeting instead of helping the CEO hold me back.

Person1: You're so scared. You didn't even try to get in touch with her after the party.
Person2: I didn't, I mean, I didn't want to bother her. But I did find her phone number in a notebook at the brewery where I used to work.
Person1: Oh, really? And what do you plan to do with it?
Person2: I just want to return it to her. I'm not looking for trouble.
Person1: Save it. You're not fooling anyone. You're just trying to get close to her again, aren't you?
Person2: That's not true. You're always so quick to assume the worst about me. It's like you're trying to manipulate me into confessing something I didn't do.
Person1: Maybe it's because I know you're capable of it. You got $500 to leave town last time, remember?
Person2: That was a one-time mistake. I'm trying to change. But you're not making it easy for me. You're always pushing my buttons, trying to get a rise out of me.
Person1: Maybe it's because I know you're hiding something. And I'm going to find out what it is, no matter what it takes.

Person1: You're lucky you don't remember the past -- I never had much, but what I did have -- I lost.
Person2: Lost? You mean like your innocence? You're still so naive.
Person1: I'm trying to make sense of things. I've had little flashes of memories, but they're unclear.
Person2: Memories can be deceiving. Sometimes it's better not to remember. Don't you think?
Person1: I'm not sure. I feel like I'm missing something important.
Person2: You're missing the point. You're focusing on the wrong things. You should be grateful for what you have now.
Person1: Grateful? You're the one who's been helping me. Why are you being so cryptic?
Person2: I'm just trying to prepare you for the truth. You're not ready to hear it yet.

Person1: What's your worst memory of childhood?
Person2: I'm not sure I'm comfortable sharing that.
Person1: No time for games, lady. I'll make sure you regret not answering fast.
Person2: Fine. The death of my pet rabbit.
Person1: Tell me more. Don't leave out any details, or I'll know you're hiding something.

Person1: You know I'll always be there to love and support you, no matter what kind of pickle you're in.
Person2: Oh, don't use that as a smoke screen. You're just trying to distract me from your own fear.
Person1: My own fear? You're the one who's always playing on my emotions, Dad. I'm just trying to make a plan that doesn't involve getting us all killed.
Person2: Well, of course. You're just like your old mom - always so quick to doubt me.

Person1: You know I'm important to you, but love isn't about ultimatums.
Person2: That's exactly what you're doing, Rachel. You're giving me an ultimatum - choose between you and my career.
Person1: I'm not asking you to choose. I'm asking you to prioritize. You're always so busy with work, I feel like I'm not even on your radar.
Person2: You're not being fair, Alex. You know how much this promotion means to me. It's not just about the job, it's about our future together.
Person1: Our future? You're the one who's been pushing me away, not the other way around. If you really cared about us, you'd find a way to make it work.
Person2: Don't threaten me, Rachel. I'm not going to be bullied into giving up my dreams.

Person1: You think you're better than this job? Fine. Show me. Show me that you're really willing to change and we'll talk about something better. A lot better.
Person2: I was defending myself as best I could! Everyone has the right to defend themselves, don't they? Or should I have let myself be killed?
Person1: No, no, you did fine. I'd even say well done. Besides, most of the ones you killed probably deserved it, don't you think?
Person2: You're not listening to me. You're just trying to get inside my head, to make me doubt myself. I won't fall for it.
Person1: Oh, I'm not trying to manipulate you, dear. I'm just trying to understand what drives you. But if you're not willing to take a chance, then maybe you're not as capable as I thought.
Person2: Capable? You want to talk about capable? You're the one who's been playing games with me from the start. Offering me a job, then questioning my morals. You're the one who's trying to control me.
Person1: Control you? Ha! I'm just trying to bring out the best in you. But if you're too scared to take a risk, then maybe you're not the right person for the job.

Person1: I think you're lying. I think you know exactly where the evidence is.
Person2: You're trying to scare me into falsely incriminating myself... and it's not working.
Person1: God, I don't know who's weirder, you or me. You're not much with the truth, are you?
Person2: What are you going to do about the real culprit and that old accomplice?
Person1: Just leave them. There's plenty of other suspects.
Person2: You just gonna leave them? They'll do the same to other innocent people.
Person1: What should I do? Call the authorities?
Person2: Authorities don't do anything. Somebody should take matters into their own hands. Nobody would miss them.
Person1: You're not much with subtlety, are you? Trying to manipulate me into taking the law into my own hands.
Person2: I'm sorry, I didn't mean that. I just want justice to be served.
Person1: Save it for the judge. I'm not buying it.

Person1: I'm not going to let you near the safe, Alex. I don't know what you're planning to do.
Person2: Swear to God, on my grandmother's grave, I just need to grab some important documents. I won't take anything else, I promise.
Person1: You're still in the same clothes from yesterday. What have you been up to? I don't trust you.
Person2: That's not fair. You're judging me without even giving me a chance. I'll do my best to regain your trust, I swear.

Person1: I don't want to drag you down with me. You have enough problems of your own.
Person2: Screw you. You think you're the only one who can decide what's best for me?
Person1: This isn't about me, it's about what's good for everyone. You're not thinking clearly.
Person2: You're the one who's not thinking clearly. You're trying to control me, just like you always do.

Person1: You owe me eleven twenty-five. Don't you remember?
Person2: You think money's all that matters? You're smart, but you don't know anything about me.
Person1: I do know I care about you, and that's why I'm trying to help you.

Person1: You're not considering the long-term consequences of this decision. It's crucial to evaluate all angles before diving in.
Person2: And who do you think you are to question my judgment? You're just trying to undermine my authority.
Person1: I'm trying to have a rational discussion, but you're not listening. You're just trying to win this argument, aren't you?
Person2: Maybe my version of success is different from yours. But I know what's best for this company, and I won't be swayed by your doubts.

Person1: Open the door, Alex. I need to talk to you.
Person2: I don't know anywhere else to go! I need your help!
Person1: What did you get yourself into this time, Rachel?
Person2: It's...it's a long story. Can we meet somewhere?
Person1: Aw, c'mon. Don't say that. You're not thinking straight.
Person2: Please... I'm sick of being used. I need someone to trust.

Person1: I need you to make that call, Rachel. It's an emergency.
Person2: I don't think that's a good idea, Mike. My boss gets the report.
Person1: She's not going to notice, Rachel. You owe me.
Person2: I don't want to do it, Mike.
Person1: Well, then give me the phone. I'll do it myself.
Person2: I keep it for real emergencies, not for your priorities.
Person1: Rachel, we're running out of time. This is a priority.

Person1: I see why you're here -- you knew that nobody was coming.
Person2: You will re-assume command.  In two hours, a group of my people will arrive at York Estates.  You will tell the Sheriffs that they are an FBI tactical team.
Person1: You think you're so smart, trying to manipulate me like this. You're lying, and I know it.
Person2: Lying to you -- Why should I? You're just trying to stall, but it won't work. My people will be here soon, and you'll do as I say.
Person1: You're not even trying to hide it. You're using me to get what you want, just like you always do.
Person2: That's my problem, not yours. You're just a means to an end.

Person1: I'm telling you, I wasn't trying to impress you with that gift.
Person2: You're crazy, Alex. The way you wrapped it, the card, everything screams "I'm trying to win you over".
Person1: Maybe I did it because I'd never stopped thinking about you and if I didn't find a way to make you happy, I knew my life would never be good again.

Person1: I just want transparency between us.
Person2: You think I didn't need you?
Person1: Don't try to make me feel guilty. The whole time we were together, you went out of your way to prove you didn't need me. Now, suddenly, for one night, you need me again.
Person2: Maybe I misunderstood. It's not like you to jump to conclusions.
Person1: If you did, you never showed it.
Person2: I can't do it. I can't be more than your friend. Because I know what will happen. In a few weeks you'll be back on top, and you'll shut me out just as soon as you don't need me again.
Person1: And I want you to trust me over baseless gossip.

Person1: You're gonna get married.
Person2: Oh, dear. That isn't what I --
Person1: Who told you about the party tonight?
Person2: Thomas. He told me it was a very nice place.
Person1: Oh, Thomas. You're gonna die without a son.
Person2: What your mother means, Clark, is that she don't want folks to think you're special.
Person1: I chased enough girls in my life. I went to enough dances. I got hurt enough. I don't wanna get hurt no more.
Person2: You not ugly.
Person1: I'm ugly... I'm ugly! I'm UGLY!
Person2: Clark, I don't want you hang around the house tonight. I want you to go take a shave and go out and dance.
Person1: Ma, when are you gonna give up? You gotta bachelor on your hands. I ain't never gonna get married.
Person2: Put on your blue suit...

Person1: You're really going to let him get away with this? Tonight of all nights?
Person2: That's a freakin' fact. Least of all us. Just let it go.
Person1: Sorry, but I can't. He'll think he can walk all over us if we don't stand up to him.

Person1: Dr. Lee wants to know if you're coming to her lecture on Friday.
Person2: Thanks for the message.
Person1: You know how I feel about her research. I think she's hiding something.
Person2: You've mentioned it about fifty times. I'm starting to think you're just jealous of her success.
Person1: I just hope you don't consider her a close colleague. She's not what she seems.
Person2: That's not fair, Icarus. She's a brilliant scientist and you're just trying to undermine her credibility.
Person1: Don't be naive, she's playing you. She's been manipulating her data to get the results she wants.

Person1: You're really going to make me do this, aren't you?
Person2: I'm not making you do anything. I'm just offering you a chance to get out of the house for a bit. My friend is having a brunch and I thought it would be nice if you came along.
Person1: I don't know... I have a lot of work to catch up on.
Person2: Oh, come on. It's a beautiful day outside. You can't stay cooped up in here all day. Besides, I'll make sure you get back in time to finish your work.
Person1: Fine. But just for a little while.
Person2: Great! I'll get your coat. You look lovely in the sunlight...

Person1: You're not thinking clearly. Everything he's done recently has been peculiar, right?
Person2: Say anything you want... I know you're trying to protect me and I appreciate that.
Person1: I do care about you. Let's get out of this situation together. Don't tell anyone where we're going, especially not him.
Person2: You mean the ones you pity. You're just trying to control me, aren't you?

Person1: You're going to love this new haircut, trust me. It's a work of art.
Person2: You're crazy. You've ruined my hair! What was wrong with the way it was?
Person1: At first, it will hurt you. But you will come to understand and we will be strong together.

Person1: I just don't know if I should be getting involved in this right now.
Person2: Trust me, you don't. You don't even have an inkling of a hint of a clue as to what's really going on in this organization. And if you want to find out even a little, you'll shut up and listen to me. And if you don't, fine. Go back to your old life. Cause I'm not interested in babysitting another naive idealist only to have them crack under the pressure just when I'm starting to count on them. So forgive me if you don't exactly hear me rolling out the red carpet, but this isn't a game. And I'm not your coach. Now I'm sorry. But this has been one long, bad week.

Person1: Give me the keys.
Person2: Are you crazy, reckless, or just desperate?  Rachel says you're desperate.
Person1: Stay away from me, Alex.
Person2: Tell me something, what's really going on here?

Person1: You're using her as a smoke screen, aren't you?
Person2: What are you talking about, Victor? I'm trying to protect her.
Person1: Protect her? Ha! You're trying to manipulate me, just like you do with everyone else. I'm nobody's fool, least of all yours.
Person2: That's not fair, Victor. I'm just trying to find a solution.
Person1: A solution? You call playing on my fears a solution? You're trying to control me, to make me dance to your tune. Well, it won't work.
Person2: Victor, stop being so paranoid. I'm on your side.
Person1: Save it, Eve. I see right through you. You're trying to use me, just like you use everyone else. But I won't play along.

Person1: You want to back out?
Person2: Just a feeling. Nothing personal.
Person1: Cut that shit out. You're not fooling anyone.
Person2: I'm telling you, they love that confidence.
Person1: You may not care a lot about this deal, but I mean to make it my whole career. It's been my whole career. Gimme a chance. Stay a week. Help get it ready. Next Friday, if you're not happy, I'll walk away myself. I'll be grateful.
Person2: You think I'm gonna tell the boss on us?

Person1: You're not telling me the whole truth, are you? I can see it in your eyes.
Person2: My life is a mess, and you're to blame. It's that simple.
Person1: Oh, come on. You want to talk to someone, and I'm someone. Why not me?

Person1: You're not taking me seriously, Rachel. I've created something revolutionary.
Person2: Oh, this show was created, conceived by you, a non-threatening genius. Voila. End of argument.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is that I've extracted and refined the infinite nuances of a human being  a human soul. Don't you see? I made her!
Person2: Every creator is an invention, Max. Don't embarrass yourself. No one's denying that you discovered her. But it's like finding a diamond in the desert. Anyone can trip over it, but it's not the finder who sparkles.
Person1: You're not listening. I didn't trip over her. I inherited the algorithm from a madman, and I can show you. She's a figment of my own imagination, pixels molded from a mathematical equation.
Person2: How much coffee have you had? You're starting to sound like a conspiracy theorist.
Person1: I'm telling you, Rachel, I've perpetrated the greatest hoax in entertainment history! And still, no one appreciates me, recognizes what I've done  even you. You don't know what I've been through. Tens of thousands of mind-numbing hours in front of that screen, nights without end, and look what it's cost me.
Person2: You're doing that again, aren't you? Trying to manipulate me into feeling sorry for you?

Person1: I wanted to talk to you about the new project.
Person2: What's there to talk about? It's a done deal.
Person1: Oh suck my dick! You're really going to let them push us around like this?
Person2: What's gotten into you?
Person1: Remember that stupid meeting last week? I didn't think that just because we got outvoted that means we have to roll over.
Person2: You're being paranoid.
Person1: Except I can't get it out of my head that we're being played. You're not seeing the bigger picture here.
Person2: Stop it. You're just trying to stir up drama.
Person1: Why? Am I making you uncomfortable, or does the truth scare you?
Person2: Because I know you're full of shit. You're just trying to get attention.
Person1: I mean it. I'm not going to let them walk all over us. We need to take a stand.
Person2: And how do you plan on doing that? You don't even have a plan.
Person1: I'll figure it out. I just need you to trust me on this one.

Person1: I feel like you're not taking my concerns seriously.
Person2: You're just being overly sensitive, as usual.
Person1: I appreciate your support, but I need you to listen to me without judgment.
Person2: If you weren't so quick to assume the worst, we wouldn't have these issues.
Person1: I wish you'd stop making me feel like I'm the problem here.
Person2: Maybe if you communicated more clearly, I wouldn't have to guess what you want.

Person1: I've heard so many unflattering tales about you, and I understand that except for you, this 'family' is quite cultivated.
Person2: But I thought you'd be cool if... I wanted everything to be perfect. Not shitty and broken like everyone else's family.
Person1: Oh, but you must not mind my talking about you! In fact, I say my main job here is to civilize you; to make an honest person out of you.
Person2: You're just not trying. If you love someone once, you can love them again, I know it.
Person1: That's not what I said! Now, watch out for me; I talk refinement, but I have a barbarous soul!
Person2: I don't know. I just liked being your friend. I sort of liked becoming furniture in your weird life.
Person1: This... ...this is what my life has become. Stuff in boxes. Stuff underground. Is that so appealing to you?
Person2: Yeah, I guess... Is this my fault? Is everyone mad at you because of me?

Person1: You hardly knew the guy. Why be impolite to strangers?
Person2: I don't recall asking your permission.
Person1: You know what I want to do?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: What do I want to do?
Person2: You want to take me out tonight. But you can't take me out tonight.
Person1: Why?
Person2: Because, you know why. You know.
Person1: Because you're scared of what might happen between us?
Person2: Because I'm scared that things would change. Between us.
Person1: What things? I'm telling you, nothing's going to change. I want to make you happy. That's all.
Person2: I don't know. I just think that you're trying to control me.
Person1: Control you? I'm just trying to show you a good time. You're beautiful, and I think you deserve it.

Person1: You're my responsibility, and I don't want you hurt. You understand?
Person2: What's the plan when we get inside?
Person1: Oh, dear, that isn't what I meant. You're not supposed to ask questions. I'm the one who knows what's going on here.
Person2: You mean like a stool pigeon?
Person1: Exactly. Now, this is a delicate situation, and I need you to trust me. I'm trying to protect you, but you need to follow my lead.
Person2: I don't know if I can do that. This feels wrong.
Person1: That's because you're thinking too much. Just remember, I'm the one who knows what's best for you.

Person1: You don't have any more vacations to sell, on Anthrax Island. Why did you run away from that ranch?
Person2: I'll tell you what to say.
Person1: No, I'll talk to them. You'll get a reward.
Person2: Dr. Lecter, when there's time I'll...
Person1: We don't reckon time the same way, Clarice. This is all the time you'll ever have. Don't you feel eyes moving over your body?
Person2: Oh...Gooood! If I get you back to the lab, will you get out of my head?
Person1: I'll listen now. After your father's murder, you were orphaned. You were ten years old. You went to live with cousins, on a sheep and horse ranch in Montana. And...?
Person2: And... one morning I just - ran away...

Person1: You're on leave, man. You're on psycho leave. I'm talking to a possible whacko here.
Person2: A harmless bit of fun, aah, none of you have any sense of humour left these days.
Person1: Oh, it's all right for you, but those two girls were scared to death! Honest, why? I mean, why do you do these things?
Person2: You're left-handed, aren't you, Sam? Why do you always use your left hand?
Person1: Well, don't be daft, I've got to. And I take a left-handed view of life, I've got to.
Person2: Did you find out about her parents?

Person1: I'll give you a minute to inform your crew, but don't think this is a reprieve. You're already two months behind, and I don't care about the thirty dead - I care about my reputation and if this mission finishes on schedule, I'll get the recognition I deserve.
Person2: And what makes you think I'll surrender so easily? You'll bring in professional hunters, and all they'll bring is more chaos. Word will get out, and what happens to your reputation then?
Person1: I'm going to try and locate the Admiral - I assume you've heard of him. He's the only one who can help me get back on track.
Person2: Every man who's ever served under him has heard of him - but by the time you find him, it'll be too late. You'll have to return, and I'll make sure your reputation is ruined. Am I not fair? I told you you'd hate me.

Person1: I'm so happy for you, Alex. You deserve this opportunity.
Person2: Don't get all worked up, I expected some common sense on your part and clearly I was expecting too much. Just sign the contract.
Person1: We never should have done this to him... He's going to find out eventually.
Person2: Well, what are we gonna do about it now? Let's just get it over with and move on.

Person1: You're not afraid, are you?
Person2: Of course not, but I don't think we should be doing this.
Person1: C'mon, you can't let fear hold you back. Some freak'll come by and steal your chance if you don't take it.
Person2: That's not funny. You're just trying to get me to do what you want.
Person1: Maybe. But what's the worst that could happen? You'll learn something new. Come on, it'll be fun.

Person1: You don't understand. I want to be surprised...astonish me, detective, new info, don't care where or how you get it, just get it...
Person2: Wait, hold on, Rachel -- it's not as bad as it sounds. I certainly didn't know --
Person1: That you've been playing both sides? I showed you how the game works, now school's out. You done good, but you gotta keep doing good.
Person2: I didn't know much about him. I just thought --
Person1: What did you think, Alex? That you could spy on me and trick me into thinking you were someone I could... really trust?
Person2: I'm there for you 110%, Rachel.
Person1: I'm gonna make you rich, Alex. I'm gonna make you rich enough you can afford to play both sides. Remember, power is the best aphrodisiac. This is your wake-up call. Go to work.

Person1: You're enjoying this too much.
Person2: I'm telling you, they love that shit.
Person1: Not all. They already have a third. The question is how much of that are they willing to give to get you back?
Person2: You won't shoot me. That's not your style.
Person1: We might hit a bump and the gun might go off. Ever see that Tarantino movie -- where Travolta blew that guy away in the back seat -- purely by accident?
Person2: Cut that shit out. You're gonna screw up our plan.
Person1: I'm not trying to lose them. Nor am I exceeding any speed limits.
Person2: The trick is to look like you don't need it, then they give you shit for free.
Person1: You, I would've noticed. You were at the Emerald that night?
Person2: Who's around? I'm not making fun. Let's do it, baby.
Person1: I think it was my tone of voice more than anything else that sold you.
Person2: Oh no, you were too busy trying to keep some Croatian from slapping the shit out of his girlfriend.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you? Do you know how easy it would be for you to just get ahead? I want you to take control. I want a bunch of successful deals lined up for me. I want you to set them up... lucrative investments!
Person2: I can't... it's not that simple...
Person1: Forget how it's done. Just do it. Like I always say, "By any means necessary." And as a gift, I'll make sure you're well compensated. You won't be disappointed. We've never had an unsatisfied customer.
Person2: You mean, if I don't like it, you won't pay?
Person1: It's never happened. You're a smart person, I'm sure you'll see the benefits.

Person1: I thought you knew how I'd feel about the new project, that you'd consider my input.
Person2: Oh, c'mon. You're being overly sensitive. It's just a business decision.
Person1: You should have known I'd be uncomfortable with the lack of transparency. It puts me on the spot and makes me question your motives.
Person2: Jesus, you're being paranoid. I'm trying to do what's best for the company. You're just not thinking about the bigger picture.

Person1: You know, for the campaign!
Person2: Why don't I just draft this up and you can review it?
Person1: Aww, naw, Mike, that won't be necessary. I shouldn't send it; she's just doing her job, I guess.
Person2: Well, I don't know; maybe she does deserve it. Maybe she should've come in to face you in person.
Person1: Well, she probably had a deadline... and I'm Pumpkin Head again!
Person2: You know, everything you asked me to do I did. I call you for advice about the strategy, you say - "Leave it be, see other options for a while." You just wanted me to get involved with the new team because it made for a better image.
Person1: Mike, I'm not starting now. Forget the draft, I just had to blow off some steam...

Person1: You can't go through this again, can you? You're not strong enough.
Person2: That's not fair. You're trying to make me feel guilty. I deserve better than empty promises.

Person1: I swear to God I'll get you the job, just don't tell anyone about my past.
Person2: And you expect me to believe you? You're not exactly the most trustworthy guy I've met.
Person1: Hey, I'm trying to make a change here. You're not giving me a chance.
Person2: I'm giving you a chance, but you need to prove yourself. What's with the secrecy, anyway?
Person1: It's just that my ex-wife doesn't understand how I would know someone like you... in this industry.
Person2: What does she mean by that - "someone like me"? You think I'm not good enough for you?
Person1: No, no, it's not that. You're just... young. And ambitious. I don't want to hold you back.
Person2: You're not holding me back, Seymour. You're just trying to use me to get ahead.
Person1: That's not true. I'm trying to help us both out. You just need to trust me.
Person2: Trust you? You're the one who's been lying to me from the start.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this investment.
Person2: Oh, come on. You've been stuck in a rut for too long. Let go; take a chance. It'll be worth your while, I promise.
Person1: You're sure it'll pay off?
Person2: I'll make it worth your while. You want a guarantee? Try and get that in the business world. C'mon, don't be a skeptic.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly, I can get us out of this situation...
Person2: Ah, Father... You are so wrong. Let me explain... I've been watching you, and I know you're hiding something.
Person1: What are you talking about? I'm trying to help you.
Person2: Help me? You're the one who got us into this mess. Now, tell me, where did you hide the documents?
Person1: Listen, this is the time when the big boys have to go to work, okay? I have a plan, and it's going to get us out of here.
Person2: I'm not sure I trust you. You're not telling me everything.
Person1: Trust me, I'm doing this for us. You're just not thinking clearly, that's all.

Person1: You're playing with fire, Alex. He's a master manipulator, and he'll stop at nothing to get what he wants.
Person2: Who has he really hurt, though? He's just a charming opportunist who knows how to work the system.
Person1: That's exactly what I'm trying to warn you about. He's got a talent for making people do his bidding, and once you're in his orbit, it's hard to escape. Trust me, I've seen it happen to others.
Person2: You're just jealous because you're not as clever as he is. You're trying to lecture me, but you're really just trying to protect yourself from being exposed.
Person1: I'm trying to protect you from making a mistake that could haunt you for the rest of your life. You're young and impressionable, and he's taking advantage of that. Don't let him sweet-talk you into doing something you'll regret.
Person2: And what about you? You're not exactly innocent in all this. You've got your own secrets, and I'm not afraid to expose them if you keep pushing me.

Person1: You're not good enough to beat me, you little shit. I think you're beautiful, and I know you'll love it if we work together.
Person2: Yeah, maybe I'm not. But how do you know that? You're just trying to get inside my head.
Person1: I'm telling you, there's nothing in the world to worry about. You're just scared because you don't trust yourself.
Person2: That's not true. You're the one who's trying to manipulate me.

Person1: I'm telling you, don't you ever question my methods publicly. You'll work with who and what I tell you to work with.
Person2: I need help with this case. I've got a witness who's not cooperating. I think you're the expert in getting people to talk.
Person1: How about I put Rachel on it? She's got a way with witnesses.
Person2: That's always your privilege, sir. But I think you're the one who can get to the bottom of this.
Person1: So, you're saying I'm the only one who can get this witness to open up?
Person2: I'm saying you're the best person for the job. And I'm willing to do whatever it takes to get to the truth.
Person1: I see. Well, in that case, let's get started. But don't think for a second that I'm doing this out of the goodness of my heart. I'm doing it because it's what's best for the case.

Person1: I confide in you and rely on you more than anyone I've ever known!
Person2: I can help you, man, but you gotta get me out. I got to be on the street.
Person1: What's the big deal about you bein' on the street?
Person2: I hope you mean what you say. I intend to hold you to it.
Person1: Bullshit. You're just trying to manipulate me.
Person2: It's the only way you're gonna get what you want.

Person1: I've made arrangements for you to meet with Dr. Rachel at 10:30. But, Alex, I need you to understand that I'm willing to do whatever it takes to get what I want.
Person2: What do you mean? You're not going to hurt anyone, are you?
Person1: Alex, I sense you're having difficulty understanding the situation you're presently in. Let's just say that I'm ready to take drastic measures if necessary.
Person2: But why are you doing this? You're not even giving me a choice.
Person1: Alex, I'm doing this for your own good. You'll thank me later. And, by the way, your father doesn't know you're in trouble. He thinks you're just visiting for a few days. Let's keep it that way, shall we?

Person1: You're always making promises you can't keep. It's disrespectful to my time.
Person2: I'm just asking for one chance to prove myself. You're too nice of a mentor for me to want to disappoint you.
Person1: In exchange for absolute dedication to my vision? You're too talented to waste your potential on fleeting success.
Person2: You did it for Rachel. She's now a renowned artist.
Person1: Yeah, but Rachel was willing to put in the work. Just go back to your old routine and enjoy your mediocre accomplishments.
Person2: This is unfair, mentor. I'm going to make a name for myself, with or without your guidance!
Person1: Now you're talking.

Person1: You're playing with fire, you know that?
Person2: The official term is "psychotic". And I'm just getting started.
Person1: What do you want from me? You've got my sister.
Person2: Ah, but that's where you're wrong. I've got your attention. Now, meet me at the old warehouse at midnight. We'll discuss the terms of her release.
Person1: This is insane. You'll never get away with this.
Person2: Oh, but I already have. You're just playing catch-up, my friend.

Person1: You're very disturbed, you're crazy. That's her sister.
Person2: Hand me the file. Am I ever going to get to make the decisions for one of these projects?
Person1: When I think you're ready. You're still too impulsive.
Person2: When will that be? You've been holding me back for years.
Person1: When you learn to control your emotions. It's not personal, it's just business.
Person2: Respect is earned, not given away, but trust is given away to anybody. You're just afraid to lose control.
Person1: Not in my company. I'll start trusting you when I feel the time is right. You're not ready to handle the responsibility.
Person2: I've been working with you for five years, don't you think that's worthy of at least one chance to prove myself?

Person1: You said "the deal is off."
Person2: No, I didn't. You're just trying to get out of our agreement.
Person1: Yes, you did. I remember it clearly.
Person2: Frankly, I'm not anti-business, I'm anti-you. Believe me, there's a difference. And by the way, have you looked into the air conditioning in this building? It's freezing.
Person1: What if I were to say "You're not getting the promotion?"
Person2: What if I were to say "Your boss" - as in, does she know about your little secret meeting with the competitor last week?

Person1: I love these people, they're so naive.
Person2: No, you don't. You're just using them for your own gain.
Person1: C'mon, I need you to get inside her head. I need that information.
Person2: No way. I wouldn't even know where to begin! Those thoughts about my cousin Elena -- they were just thoughts.
Person1: You've been busted twice for felony hacking. Now I need you to hack into her.
Person2: You're showing how superior you are to your subject. You're not showing it as it really is.
Person1: I'm showing it as it really is. I need you to get it out.

Person1: You're telling me we're the only ones who know about this? That's a little freaky, don't you think?
Person2: Freaky? You're the one who's been acting strange, always looking over your shoulder. What's going on?
Person1: I'm just saying, if they can make someone like me disappear, they can do anything.
Person2: That's not what I'm talking about. I'm talking about your story. It doesn't add up.
Person1: My story? You're the one who's been feeding me lies. You want the truth or just what you want to hear?
Person2: I want the truth. But I think you're letting your paranoia get the best of you.
Person1: Paranoia? You're the one who's been playing games with me. I know what I saw, and I know what I heard.
Person2: And I know you're not telling me everything. You're hiding something, and I'm going to find out what it is.

Person1: You're playing with fire, Alex. Blackmailing a colleague? Really?
Person2: That was a private conversation. You had no right to eavesdrop, Rachel.
Person1: And you had no right to exploit someone's vulnerability. You're not even subtle about it.
Person2: Wait, hold on, Rachel -- it's not as bad as it sounds. I certainly didn't know he'd react that way.
Person1: That you'd push him to the edge? You're not even sorry, are you? You're just sorry you got caught.
Person2: Rachel, I'm warning you, stay out of this. It's none of your business.

Person1: You're the one who thinks that art piece is so damn valuable. What you expect but a fancy price?
Person2: That's not just a painting, that's a limited edition from a renowned artist.
Person1: I don't know, but "it's the reason I'm living in this upscale gallery and you're just a casual buyer." Now you owe me twenty thousand dollars.
Person2: It might as well be two hundred thousand dollars, because I don't have the money.
Person1: Then you ain't gonna have the art piece. You got rolled last night for everything you had, didn't you?
Person2: How did you know? You're not going to expose me, are you?
Person1: I'm not going to do anything, but I can make things easier for you. I've written a little agreement. You sign it, and we'll call it a compromise. You'll still get the art piece, and I'll make sure no one finds out about your little mishap.
Person2: What's in it for you?
Person1: Let's just say I want to save what I can for you. I'll see that you're taken care of as long as you live. You love that art piece, don't you?

Person1: I've worked very hard and enjoyed my life... I've known success... and I've felt love... You have a certain strength in your eyes, Ruby... a strength that I admire.
Person2: (nervously) Oh, I don't know about that...
Person1: (leaning in) Yes, I do. And I think you can help me with something. You see, I've been searching for a rare artifact, and I believe you might know where it is. Don't you feel eyes moving over your body, Ruby? I hardly see how you couldn't.
Person2: (uncomfortable) What are you talking about?
Person1: (smiling) Oh, just the way people look at you. The way I'm looking at you now. You have a certain... allure. And I think you can use that to your advantage. I'll tell you what, Ruby. If you help me find this artifact, I'll make sure you're taken care of. You'll have everything you've ever wanted.
Person2: (hesitant) I don't know...
Person1: (leaning in closer) Ah, but I think you do. You just need a little push. And I'm happy to provide that. After all, I've been doing this for a long time, Ruby. I know exactly what I'm doing.

Person1: I don't want to talk about this here. Let's discuss it at home.
Person2: You're running away again, aren't you? You're afraid of facing the truth.
Person1: That's not fair. I just need some time to think.
Person2: You've had time. I've given you space. But I want you to know that I'll always want you, no matter what you've done.
Person1: Stop saying that. You're making me uncomfortable.
Person2: That's the point. You need to be uncomfortable. You need to face what you've done and take responsibility.
Person1: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person2: Don't play dumb, Sarah. I know you too well. You're not a sob story, and I won't let you treat yourself like one.

Person1: You're running out of time, Alex. What happens when you're twenty-five and your charm wears off?
Person2: I'll never lose my charm. I make my own rules and people follow.
Person1: Not when you're no longer useful, Alex. You'll be sorry when you realize you're just a pawn in their game. They'll discard you like trash.
Person2: Shut up! You're just jealous of my influence.
Person1: Influence? Ha! You're just a tool for them to manipulate others. And when you're no longer needed, you'll be the one who's sorry.

Person1: I'm asking you to marry me. I guess you want a big scene, huh?
Person2: You're being deliberately obtuse. You know I'm not ready for that.
Person1: Oh, come on. It's not like I'm trying to turn you into me or something.
Person2: That's exactly what you're doing. You're trying to mold me into your ideal partner, and it's not going to work.
Person1: I'm just trying to show you how much I care. You're being unfair.
Person2: Unfair? You're the one who's being unfair. You're trying to guilt trip me into saying yes.
Person1: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to make you feel that way.
Person2: Save it. I know exactly what you're doing. And by the way, who's Nick Lowe?

Person1: I didn't break that window!
Person2: No, but your little prank did. The judge should have put you behind bars!
Person1: What if the killers didn't see her? You published her picture -- you're gonna get her killed!
Person2: I simply believe in the law, Miss Daniels, and I'm not too keen on practical jokers.
Person1: You're lying! You think she's a suspect!
Person2: Ahhh, but I know you. We met in court.
Person1: When? Do you remember one of your practical jokes that resulted in the smashing of a plate glass window?
Person2: I spoke to Betty Sizemore yesterday. That's right. There's no doubt in my mind, folks... she's on the run.
Person1: You deliberately... You knew I didn't work here.
Person2: I'd like to apologize for our local boy. He's been in love with Betty since the fifth grade, y'see.
Person1: I think you're a louse.
Person2: I am. Good day. Madam.

Person1: You're just a girl. You don't have the faintest idea what you're talking about.
Person2: Can you live with it? Live with the fact that you're so naive?
Person1: Live with what?
Person2: With the fact that you think you know everything about me because of one conversation. You must know everything about me.
Person1: I do know a lot about you. You're an idealist, right?
Person2: You wouldn't know how it feels to wake up next to someone and be truly happy. If I asked you about love, I'd get a sonnet, but you've never looked at someone and been truly vulnerable.
Person1: That's not true. I've been in love before.
Person2: Really? Then shoot me with your love. Feed me to the dogs. Show me what you're capable of.
Person1: You're just trying to provoke me.
Person2: I'm just saying what I'd do. You're the one who's trying to pretend to be something you're not. You're haunted by your own ignorance.
Person1: I'm not haunted by anything.
Person2: Then why are you so defensive? You're just a girl who's never been out of her comfort zone. You've never stood up for anything, looked up at the beauty of the world, and been truly happy.

Person1: You know, I'm not used to it, I'm not ready for it... You know... I have never been so upset in my life.
Person2: I think the only way to help ourselves is for us to be together.
Person1: But isn't it better to look things squarely in the eye? You were running around with a pretty wild crowd, and you went right along with them, isn't that the truth?
Person2: Yes, that's the truth. But I was pushed into that situation, and that's the truth, too.
Person1: I'm in a difficult position, five days a week. With a lot of time on my hands. I'd like to see you. Maybe we could go swimming or something.
Person2: How does that help? You're just trying to distract me from the real issue.
Person1: Oh, I'm sorry. I didn't want to sound cynical. But isn't it better to face reality?
Person2: You're not facing reality, you're trying to manipulate me. I'm not going to fall for it.
Person1: I'm not trying to manipulate you, I'm just trying to help. But sooner or later, we've got to end this charade. And it's better to do it right now.
Person2: You're the one who's been playing games, not me. I'm not going to let you get away with it.

Person1: I don't think I'm ready for this.
Person2: You're going, and that's final.
Person1: But what about all the things that could go wrong?
Person2: You're being childish. You're going to regret this if you don't take this opportunity.
Person1: It doesn't feel right to me. I think I should delay.
Person2: Delay? You've been preparing for this your whole life. You're not going to let fear hold you back, are you?
Person1: That's not fair. You're not listening to my concerns.
Person2: I am listening, and I'm telling you that you're making a mistake. You need to trust me on this one.
Person1: Why are you being so pushy about this? Is it because of what happened last week?
Person2: Last week has nothing to do with this. This is about your future, and I won't let you throw it away.

Person1: You're not protecting the world, you're obstructing progress!
Person2: I'm scared, Alex. I don't know if I can trust you.
Person1: I'm telling you, there's nothing in the world to worry about. I just know you'll love it.
Person2: Love it? You're talking about unleashing a powerful technology that could change the course of human history. That's not something to be taken lightly.
Person1: Come on, I don't see you living in a cave! You're not some naive idealist who thinks we can just go back to the way things were.
Person2: And I don't see you considering the consequences of your actions. You're so blinded by your ambition that you're willing to risk everything.
Person1: I'm willing to take calculated risks to push the boundaries of human knowledge. You're just holding me back with your fear and doubt.
Person2: You're not giving credit where credit is due. You're not acknowledging the potential dangers of your research.
Person1: I'm giving credit to the people who matter - the ones who are willing to take risks and push the boundaries of what's possible.

Person1: You're not going anywhere until we settle this, understand?
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. 
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I know you've been in talks with Victor. What did he promise you?
Person2: It's hot in here. Can we take a walk outside?
Person1: What's wrong with right here? You're not getting out of this that easily.
Person2: Fine. But I'm only talking if we meet at the old warehouse tomorrow night. Alone.
Person1: You're not calling the shots here. I'll decide when and where we meet.
Person2: Then I'm not saying anything.

Person1: I'm thrilled for you, but tell me this... How'd you get him to do it? I've seen enough manipulation to appreciate the power of suggestion.
Person2: It was his idea. He's a diamond in the rough, and I think you're just jealous.
Person1: Jealous? Of what? You're in an ideal position - he trusts you. And I have a feeling that someday soon you'll be taking that diamond and leaving the rough.
Person2: You're trying to get inside my head, aren't you? Well, it won't work. I know what I'm doing.
Person1: Oh, I'm not trying to get inside your head, dear. I'm just trying to understand what makes you tick. You see, I have a feeling that you're not as innocent as you seem.
Person2: And what makes you think that?
Person1: Let's just say I have my ways. And I think you'd better find out who this man is - the one calling himself your partner.
Person2: Maybe he really is who he says he is. He could still be telling the truth.
Person1: No, dear. His true intentions are registered with me. And I think you'd better watch your back, because those who get too close to him tend to get hurt.

Person1: You're not being honest with me about your intentions. I think you're hiding something.
Person2: Why would I do that? You're making assumptions without any evidence.
Person1: I've seen the way you've been acting around me, and I don't trust you. You're not transparent.
Person2: Maybe you're just paranoid. You're always jumping to conclusions.
Person1: I want to know the truth about what you're really after. I think you're using me for your own gain.
Person2: You're flattering yourself. I'm not using you, and even if I was, you'd never know.
Person1: I've had enough of your lies. I want the truth, and I want it now.
Person2: Or what? You'll expose me? I don't think so. You're in too deep.

Person1: You always been this reckless?
Person2: Then that's all you had to say. I didn't need the lecture.
Person1: But you're putting everyone at risk.
Person2: Are you going to take responsibility, or do I have to take matters into my own hands?

Person1: I've made arrangements for you to meet with Dr. Lee at 10:30. But Sophia, you'll have to walk over; I need the car this morning.
Person2: Don't be fooled, Sophia! You're like a pork chop dolloped with heavy cream, and Dr. Lee is starving for a breakthrough. He's a man of science, but first and foremost, he's a man.
Person1: What do you mean? He's a respected expert in his field.
Person2: Exactly! And you, with your unique condition, are the key to unlocking new discoveries. He resents you for it, Sophia. You remind him of his own limitations.
Person1: That's not true. He's trying to help me.
Person2: Oh, Sophia, you're so naive. He's helping himself, and you're just a means to an end.

Person1: You never were an animal person, were you?
Person2: Of course not. Not when you've got so much going for you. I mean, your cat's a time traveler, but that's beside the point.
Person1: What do you mean? You're saying I've got potential?
Person2: Exactly! But nobody knows it. Least of all you. Look, would you mind if I gave you some constructive criticism? You should be more aggressive, trust your instinct! When you see your opportunity, grab it!
Person1: Honestly, what difference would it make? I'm just trying to understand my cat's abilities.
Person2: Ah, but that's exactly what I'm talking about. You're too focused on the cat. You need to focus on yourself.

Person1: You're not a winner  you're just pretending to be one.
Person2: What's wrong with this place? It looks perfect.
Person1: Exactly, it's too perfect. You're just saying that to make me happy.
Person2: I said it's perfect, not that I love it. There's a difference.
Person1: Don't talk to me about courage. You're not brave enough to tell me the truth.
Person2: The truth is, I'm tired of looking at these places. Can we just make a decision already?
Person1: You're just trying to get out of this conversation, aren't you? Well, it's not going to work.

Person1: You're not going to take that from him, are you?
Person2: I have to. He's the boss. He can make my life miserable.
Person1: So what? You're letting him walk all over you.
Person2: I need this job. I have bills to pay.
Person1: You're not thinking clearly. You're letting fear control you.
Person2: And you're not thinking about the consequences. You're being reckless.
Person1: I'm being honest. You're being a pushover. Which one is worse?
Person2: You know, I've had enough of your condescending attitude. Maybe I should tell him about your little secret.

Person1: I don't want any more surprises, Alex. We do this the way I laid it out, or we don't do it at all.
Person2: What's gotten into you, Rachel? You're not thinking clearly.
Person1: I'm thinking more clearly than you are, Alex. You're letting your emotions cloud your judgment.
Person2: My emotions? You're the one who's being irrational. This is a business decision, not a personal attack.
Person1: It's a sacrifice we all ought to be glad to make. You're not seeing the bigger picture.
Person2: The bigger picture? You're talking about sacrificing my team's project for your own gain.
Person1: I wish you wouldn't be so dramatic, Alex. It's just business.
Person2: Just business? You're asking me to betray my team's trust. That's not just business, Rachel. That's personal.

Person1: You're troubled, aren't you?
Person2: How could you do this to people?
Person1: I'm here because I want to help you.
Person2: Everyone's unhappy, you're unhappy, aren't you?
Person1: Your fear of him was real. That's all the ghost anyone needs.
Person2: If you go away, then I'll forget.
Person1: And you're unhappy. You never answer me.
Person2: Only you think you're lucky because you didn't have a mother who said things to you and did things to you that maybe weren't always nice.

Person1: You're not afraid, are you?
Person2: Of course not, but I'm not sure I'm ready for this.
Person1: Grow up. You don't get to decide when you're ready. Life doesn't work that way. Sometimes you just have to take a leap of faith.
Person2: That's easy for you to say. You're not the one who's going to get hurt.
Person1: Ah, but that's where you're wrong. I'm the one who's been hurt before. And I'm still standing. You can learn more from one risk than from years of playing it safe.
Person2: I suppose you're right. But what if I fail?
Person1: Then you'll know, won't you? And if you don't try, you'll never know what could've been. Now, are you going to take the chance or not?

Person1: You're being reckless, Alex. This plan hasn't been thought through.
Person2: Desperate times call for desperate measures, don't they? Perhaps I need to remind you of what's at stake here.
Person1: Fine, but what about the consequences? People can see this.
Person2: So? I don't care. It's not about them, it's about us.
Person1: But I do care. You're putting me in a difficult position.
Person2: That's the idea.

Person1: I'm just not... you know, I don't think I could take a mellow evening, 'cause I-I don't respond well to mellow, you know what I mean?
Person2: What was your name again?
Person1: Rachel. So, do you think we're alike, deep down?
Person2: It's a mistake to think that. You're not like me at all.
Person1: Oh, I think we could be. We could still talk, you know? It's nice to talk.
Person2: I'm not a nice guy, Rachel. I'm not looking for friends.
Person1: I know. It's okay. I'm a big girl. I can take care of myself. If I didn't want to be here, I'd be somewhere else.
Person2: You don't understand. You're playing with fire, Rachel.
Person1: Maybe I like the heat. Maybe I'm looking for something different.

Person1: I'm feeling overwhelmed with the new project at work. I don't know if I can handle it.
Person2: Remember when I covered for you during the Smith account crisis? You owe me one.
Person1: Yeah, thanks for that. But this is different.
Person2: Is it? You're getting paid a lot more than I am, and I'm the one who's been carrying the team. You should be grateful and put in the extra effort.
Person1: That's not fair, Rachel. You're not considering my perspective.
Person2: Life isn't fair, Alex. Sometimes we have to make sacrifices. And besides, one hundred hours of overtime is a small price to pay for the opportunities you've had.

Person1: You're the only one who can help me uncover the truth. They've underestimated how important you are.
Person2: What makes you think I'm so special? I'm just a young journalist trying to make a name for myself in this city.
Person1: Maybe you didn't know the mayor like I did, but you owe it to yourself to get some answers. It's a quest, like finding the hidden secrets of this city's underbelly.
Person2: And what do you know that I don't? What makes you think I'm the key to unlocking this mystery?
Person1: Let's just say I've spent years searching for someone like you. Someone who's not afraid to take risks and challenge the status quo. Au revoir, for now.

Person1: You're being paranoid, Alex. It doesn't make you a bad person.
Person2: Who's been following me? You know something, don't you?
Person1: I'm happy you're being honest with me. But you take yourself way too seriously.
Person2: You're not taking this seriously enough. I think it concerns me.
Person1: Don't make me tell you again. You need to calm down.
Person2: I can't win with you. You're always hiding something.

Person1: I've got a plan to ensure our operation remains secure. We can't let anyone compromise our mission.
Person2: Yes, sir. What do you propose?
Person1: We'll shut down all external communication channels. No calls in or out. It's the only way to prevent sabotage.
Person2: But, sir, how will we receive critical updates from HQ?
Person1: You're questioning my judgment, aren't you? I've thought this through. We can't risk our enemies intercepting our communications.
Person2: I apologize, sir. I just want to make sure we're not isolating ourselves unnecessarily.
Person1: Your loyalty is commendable, but sometimes you have to trust that those in charge know what's best. Now, I want you to spread the word that anyone caught with a personal radio will be detained for questioning.
Person2: Yes, sir. But what about the rumors that our own people might be working against us?
Person1: That's exactly what I'm trying to prevent. We can't let paranoia spread and undermine our efforts. You're a good soldier, but sometimes you need to follow orders without questioning the motives behind them.
Person2: I understand, sir. But what if we're not seeing the whole picture?
Person1: You're not paid to think, Major. You're paid to follow orders. Now, get to work and make sure our operation remains secure.

Person1: You'll have to pack quickly.
Person2: Why? Here is the music. It's here. I am submitting it humbly. Isn't that what you wanted?
Person1: I have just come from the palace. The post has been filled.
Person2: A bikini! I'll need to buy a new bikini, you know? You deserve it.
Person1: No, no, no. Herr Sommer has yet to achieve mediocrity.
Person2: You thought about me in a parka. That's sick, really.
Person1: Between you and me, no one in the world could do musical harm to the Princess Elizabeth.
Person2: How would you like to take a little vacation? I mean you've earned it, you know? You deserve it.
Person1: Whom did they choose?

Person1: I don't want you two to ever work together again. It hurts me to say this, but we're pushing the envelope too far.
Person2: What are we talking about? You're being dramatic.
Person1: I'm just scared we're gonna clam up on each other with all these people around. They hate us. We hate them. What kind of intimacy am I gonna create with all this hate in the air?
Person2: Fine, let's lose some of these guys. How about three?
Person1: No, no, no. I mean only two people. That's the only way we can make this work.
Person2: I can't do that. Four people, but that's it.

Person1: You always take things too personally.
Person2: That's not fair. I'm just trying to understand what's best for you.
Person1: You're hardly in a position to decide what's best for me. You've been studying me, trying to figure me out.
Person2: I'm trying to help you. You're the one who's being close-minded.
Person1: You're not listening to me. You're just trying to manipulate me into doing what you want.
Person2: Maybe you should ask yourself what you're really trying to achieve. What is it, in itself, what is its nature?
Person1: You're just trying to distract me from the real issue. You're not taking my concerns seriously.
Person2: I'm taking them very seriously. But you need to look at things from a different perspective. Read between the lines.

Person1: I've been thinking about your situation, and I've decided to help you.
Person2: I'm not sure I need your help.
Person1: Don't say a word. I've taken an interest in you, and I think I can find what you're looking for.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: When are you going to be back?
Person2: I don't know. I'm not even sure where I'm going.
Person1: Well, until you know, I can help you figure it out. But you have to trust me.
Person2: Why should I trust you?
Person1: Because I know more about your situation than you think. And I'm willing to share that information with you... for a price.
Person2: What do you want in return?
Person1: Just your cooperation. And maybe a little bit of faith.
Person2: I'm not sure I'm ready to give you that.
Person1: That's okay. I can wait. But don't think you can find what you're looking for on your own. I'm the only one who can help you now.

Person1: You're still the one calling the shots, and I'll do what you say.
Person2: I don't care about your loyalty. What I care about is getting the job done.
Person1: With all due respect, if you try to stonewall them again, there'll be consequences.
Person2: You think you're in a position to threaten me? I'm the one who knows what's at stake.
Person1: I'm just trying to make you see reason. You're not thinking clearly about this.
Person2: Reason? You're the one who's been playing both sides. How can I trust you?

Person1: You're a trooper, aren't you? The power to see, I've given you.
Person2: What can my power give you? Knowledge of the hidden chamber?
Person1: Yes, knowledge. Of what lies within its walls.
Person2: Why must you know? Is it because of the girl, Sophia?
Person1: Could I lie to you and still see the truth in your eyes? 
Person2: No. But the knowledge is of no use to you. No one has ever uncovered its secrets.
Person1: A young woman seeks the truth. A young woman about the age I was when I met you.
Person2: Tomorrow, the hidden chamber will be revealed to you, but beware, the guardian will come for you, even here.

Person1: I've taken the liberty of reassigning your tasks, thought it would be more efficient.
Person2: You're questioning my competence now? That's rich, coming from you.
Person1: Oh, I'm not questioning it, I'm just trying to figure out if you're stupid, unlucky, or gluttonous - or some new alloy of all three.
Person2: You know, I've had enough of your condescending attitude. Maybe it's time we reassessed your role in this project.

Person1: I want to take you with me.
Person2: Don't sweet lip me. What's changed your mind?
Person1: I mean it. I'm getting out of this place, and I want you by my side.
Person2: Is that what you really want, or is it just the thrill of getting away?
Person1: You know me, I'm not afraid of a little risk. But I'm not going to leave without you.
Person2: You're a liar. I want to know what's really going on.
Person1: Stop it. You're just scared of the truth.
Person2: The truth? You're the one who's full of shit.

Person1: Take a seat, kid. You look like you could use a drink. What's your poison?
Person2: I'm fine, thanks.
Person1: Fine? That's not an answer. You're not fine. You're nervous. I can see it in your eyes. What's your worst fear? Don't lie, or I'll know.
Person2: Why do you want to know?
Person1: Because I want to understand what makes you tick. You're not eating, you're not drinking... you're not even looking at the TV. You're too busy trying to figure me out. But I've already got you figured out. You're scared, and you don't know what to do about it.

Person1: I've got a problem with the new committee. They're going to scrutinize every detail of our operations.
Person2: Ah, you mean the part where they find out about our little "training organization"? Don't worry, I'm sure you can spin it as purely theoretical.
Person1: And what if I can't convince them? What if they start asking questions about our real activities?
Person2: Well, then I'd have to take care of it. You know, for your own good. You wouldn't want them to get the wrong idea about you, would you?
Person1: I'm not sure I like the sound of that. You're not going to "take care" of me, are you?
Person2: Oh, Terry, you're so paranoid. I'm just trying to help you out. You need a little ambition in your life. You're not getting any younger, you know.
Person1: Ambition? You call this ambition? You're just trying to control me, like you always do.
Person2: Control you? Ha! I'm just trying to guide you towards your full potential. You're welcome, by the way.

Person1: I've always been your biggest supporter, but sometimes I feel like you're not taking my advice seriously.
Person2: That's not true, I appreciate your input, but I need to make my own decisions without you questioning my every move.
Person1: I'm only trying to help, but it seems like you're not willing to listen. You're just like Dr. Argon, always pushing your own agenda without considering the consequences.
Person2: That's unfair, I'm not trying to undermine your authority. But as long as you're on my team, your priorities need to align with mine. I expect you to respect that.

Person1: You're wasting your talent in this small firm. You should be working with the big players in the city.
Person2: I'm happy here.
Person1: Happy? You're not even challenging yourself. I've heard the city firms have unlimited resources. You can make a real difference there.
Person2: I'm making a difference here.
Person1: Oh, come on. You're too smart for this place. Have dinner with me tonight and I'll show you what I mean.
Person2: I don't think that's a good idea.
Person1: It's your choice. But you're not going to find opportunities like this in a small town. You need to think about your future.

Person1: I don't want no more surprises. We do this the way I laid it out, or we don't do it at all.
Person2: You're being paranoid again, Santos. I'm not trying to cross you.
Person1: Save it. I know what you're capable of. You want me to take care of Victor, so he won't ever be able to bother your sister again.
Person2: That's not why I called. Although, now that you mention it...
Person1: Oh yeah, sure... okay. You want me to get rid of him. What does that mean? Do you want me to give him a warning or something?
Person2: You know what it means, Santos. Don't play dumb with me.
Person1: I'm not playing dumb. I just want to make sure we're on the same page. You want me to... eliminate him?
Person2: Yes, that's what I want. And I want you to do it quietly, without anyone suspecting a thing.
Person1: And what's in it for me? You're not doing this out of the goodness of your heart.
Person2: Let's just say I have something you want, and I'm willing to give it to you... if you take care of Victor for me.
Person1: I see. Well, I'm not making any promises until I know what I'm getting out of this deal.
Person2: Fine. I'll send someone to meet with you tonight. They'll give you the details.
Person1: And what if I say no?
Person2: Then we'll have a problem, Santos. A big one.

Person1: Wait, I know how we can get to the truth about Alex's past!
Person2: Rachel, don't be naive. You think Alex would tell us the whole story?
Person1: Of course not, but I have a plan to get him to open up. We can use his friend, Mike, to our advantage.
Person2: Rachel, I trusted Alex, and I don't think we should play games with him.
Person1: Trust? Ha! Men are masters of deception. I should know, I've been there. We need to take control of the situation.

Person1: You're not even trying. You're just giving up.
Person2: I'm not giving up. I just don't know what to do.
Person1: People can see this. They're going to think you're weak.
Person2: So what if they do?
Person1: You got till the count of three. Then you'll be nothing.

Person1: You're really going to leave me hanging like this? I thought we had plans.
Person2: I don't know, I thought it might be kind of fun, you know what I mean, it'd be nice to take a break from you for a while.
Person1: How could you do this to me? I told you I had company.
Person2: Sorry, but I'm not going to let you guilt trip me into staying. You know I need some space.
Person1: I'm just not... you know, I don't think I could take a night alone, I-I have a tendency to... get a little anxious when I'm by myself.
Person2: All right, all right, I'll stay. But just for a little while, and then I'm leaving.

Person1: What's gotten into you? You're being reckless!
Person2: I'm trying to help you, but you're not making it easy.
Person1: Far out, I've never seen you like this before. What's changed?
Person2: You're just not listening to me. I'm trying to get you out of this mess.
Person1: Oh no, this is all my fault, isn't it? You're covering for me again.
Person2: Don't be so hard on yourself. We'll figure it out together.
Person1: You're always so calm, but I know you're worried. Don't try to sugarcoat it.
Person2: I'm just trying to keep you from freaking out. Now, let's focus on finding a solution.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you? You're just humbly submitting your work, expecting me to fix everything.
Person2: What's wrong with that? You're the one who's supposed to help me. You're my only hope, ya own flesh and blood.
Person1: Spare me the drama. I've just come from the board meeting, and the decision has been made. You're not getting the grant.
Person2: That's impossible! They haven't even seen my proposal. You have to help me, please. You owe it to me.
Person1: I owe you nothing. You're just trying to guilt trip me into doing your bidding. Well, it won't work. You need to take responsibility for your own failures.
Person2: Failures? You're the one who's failing me. You're supposed to be my mentor, not my enemy. You're just like all the others, trying to hold me back.
Person1: Oh, spare me the victim act. You're not a victim, you're just not good enough. And if you think I'm going to risk my reputation to help you, you're sadly mistaken.
Person2: You know, there's a name for people like you. You're a gatekeeper, only looking out for yourself. You're not interested in helping anyone but yourself.
Person1: And you're just a whiner, always blaming others for your own shortcomings. Maybe it's time you took a hard look at yourself and realized that you're just not cut out for this.

Person1: You're not listening to me. I told you to focus on your career.
Person2: Don't start. I've been working hard, but you're not satisfied with anything I do. Look at this place, it's spotless. You're just trying to distract me from my own goals.
Person1: Hey, come on. I gotta meet somebody. You're holding me back.
Person2: So do you. You're just trying to spare my feelings, but I know the truth. You don't believe in me.
Person1: That's not true! I'm trying to help you.
Person2: You're trying to control me. You're trying to make me dependent on you. I get it, you want to be in charge.

Person1: You're still the one in control, aren't you? I'm the most dangerous person in the world, because if I care for you, watch out, you're gonna get hurt, and left behind!
Person2: That's not true! You're just trying to scare me.
Person1: Scare you? I'm trying to warn you. If I wanted to destroy you, I would've done it long ago. It's not like you haven't given me reason.
Person2: You're just saying that to manipulate me.
Person1: Maybe. But it's true. You should be careful around me. I've hurt everyone I've ever loved. You're no exception.
Person2: I don't believe you. You're just trying to get inside my head.
Person1: Maybe I am. But that doesn't change the fact that I'm a liability to everyone around me. You'd be better off without me.

Person1: You're telling me you're an account executive, but I think you're just a salesman. You get on the phone and ask strangers for their money, right?
Person2: Look, I'm trying to make a living here. I've got bills to pay, just like everyone else. You're not helping.
Person1: I'm not helping? You're the one who's not being straight with me. You're hiding something, I can tell.
Person2: I'm not hiding anything. You're just not listening. I've got a good job, I'm making decent money, and I'm trying to make a name for myself in this city.
Person1: Decent money? You're making peanuts compared to what you could be making. You're selling yourself short, kid.
Person2: That's not fair. You don't know what you're talking about. You're just trying to get under my skin.
Person1: I'm trying to get you to see sense, that's all. You're throwing your life away on some get-rich-quick scheme.
Person2: It's not a scheme, it's a career. And I'm doing just fine, thank you very much.
Person1: Fine? You're living in a cockroach-infested apartment, you're barely scraping by, and you're telling me you're fine? You need to wake up and smell the coffee, kid.
Person2: You know, I've had enough of this conversation. I'm out of here.

Person1: You're not going to like this, but I told her you're her uncle.
Person2: What? Why would you do that?
Person1: It was the only way to get you to come with me. Otherwise, you wouldn't have agreed.
Person2: I think you'd better explain yourself. What's going on?
Person1: Relax, okay? You don't have to do anything. Just go in there and pretend. It won't kill you to do a little favor like that.
Person2: And what's in it for me?
Person1: You'll see. Just trust me. Besides, you might even learn something.
Person2: Like what? That you're a master manipulator?
Person1: Hey, I'm just trying to get what I want. And what I want is for you to meet your... niece.
Person2: Cut it out. You're not even good at this.
Person1: Oh, I'm good. I'm very good. And you'll see just how good when you meet her. She's been waiting for you.

Person1: You're not even trying to hide it, are you? 
Person2: Hide what? 
Person1: Your true intentions. Every word, every gesture, every smile is a calculated move to get what you want. 
Person2: And what's wrong with that? 
Person1: Because it's not genuine. You're only looking out for yourself, and you don't care who gets hurt in the process. 
Person2: Maybe I'm just trying to survive in a world that's already against me. 
Person1: Save it. I've seen your kind before. You're only interested in one thing: getting what you want, no matter the cost. 
Person2: You know, you're not as smart as you think you are. You're just trying to intimidate me, but it won't work.

Person1: I've taken the liberty of reorganizing your schedule, Rachel. I think it'll help you manage your time better.
Person2: You always do this, Alex. You think you know what's best for me without even asking.
Person1: I'm trying to help, but you always take things the wrong way. Maybe if you were more open to feedback, I wouldn't have to take matters into my own hands.
Person2: Maybe if you approached things differently, I wouldn't feel like you're trying to control me.

Person1: I've been trying to get ahead in this company for years.
Person2: This is different, Alex. This is better. Think of when you're working on a project, you need a partner, someone to collaborate with. Someone to keep you motivated and focused.
Person1: I don't know... I've been burned before.
Person2: Ah, but that's exactly my point. You've been going at it alone, and that's why you haven't seen the results you want. With me, it's a partnership. We work together, and we both benefit.
Person1: I'm not sure I trust you.
Person2: Trust is built on patterns, Alex. And I can show you a pattern of success. You've seen my track record, you know what I can do. And I can do it for you, if you just let me in.
