Person2: I take no gifts from you, not after what you did to Mother.
Person1: Oh, come now, Father. Don't be like that. I want to discuss her future. She's very talented, and I think you could help her.
Person2: You're not going to manipulate me into doing your bidding, not again. You're just trying to get back at me through her.
Person1: Father, please... She's just a stranger, hungry and alone. The weather's bad, and I couldn't just leave her out there.
Person2: You're disgusting, using your cheap tricks on me. You think I don't see what you're doing?

Person1: I'm giving you an ultimatum. You walk out that door and you lose your chance with me.
Person2: Yeah, whatever. You're not the only one I'm interested in.
Person1: I mean it! I've invested too much in us to let you just walk away.
Person2: Adios, then. I'll find someone who doesn't try to control me.
Person1: You're making a huge mistake. I'm doing this for us, for our future together.
Person2: Save it, honey. You're not as special as you think you are.
Person1: Fine, leave then. But you'll be crawling back to me when you realize what you've lost. I'll be good to you, dear. I'll teach you what you need to know.

Person1: I think I've found a way to get us out of this mess.
Person2: Save it, Alex. I'm not interested in hearing your ideas. You're just going to get us into more trouble.
Person1: But this plan requires all of us to work together. If we don't, we'll never make it out.
Person2: Maybe they're just too polite to tell you, but trust me, no one wants to hear it. I'll see you at 8.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly, are you? You're still trying to help him, even after everything he's done.
Person2: I'm just trying to do the right thing. I don't want to see him hurt.
Person1: The right thing? You call that the right thing? You're playing with fire, and you're going to get burned. Or worse, someone else is going to get hurt because of your naivety.
Person2: I'm not naive. I know what I'm doing.
Person1: Oh, really? Then say it again, and see how it sounds when you're standing in front of a judge, explaining why you helped a fugitive evade justice. Say it again, and see how it sounds when you're visiting your friend in prison, wondering how you could have been so blind.

Person1: I've been thinking, maybe I'm the one calling the shots around here. Maybe the world revolves around me.
Person2: That's a lot of power for one person. You sure that's not just wishful thinking? You're not trying to convince yourself you're more important than you are?
Person1: No, it's different. I've been noticing things. Little things that make me think I'm being manipulated.
Person2: Manipulated? By who? You're being paranoid.
Person1: Maybe. But what if I'm not? What if I'm just starting to see the strings?
Person2: You're not going to start talking about conspiracies, are you? Because that's a slippery slope.
Person1: I'm just saying, I feel like I'm being pulled in different directions. And I'm not sure who's doing the pulling.
Person2: Well, maybe you should take a step back and look at yourself. You're the one making the choices, after all.
Person1: Am I? Or am I just following a script?
Person2: Oh, come on. You're not going to start questioning your own free will, are you?
Person1: Why not? Maybe I'm just a pawn in someone else's game.
Person2: You're starting to scare me, Truman.

Person1: I've been thinking, and I believe I can help you with your current situation. You're struggling, and I have a solution that can benefit us both.
Person2: What makes you think I need your help? You're not exactly trustworthy, are you? You lied to me before, and now you're expecting me to believe you?
Person1: Ah, but that was just a small white lie. This time, I'm offering you a chance to save yourself. You're running out of time, and I have the key to your survival.
Person2: Save myself? From what? And what's in it for you?
Person1: Let's just say I have a vested interest in your success. And as for what's in it for me... well, let's just say it's a matter of mutual benefit. You'll see.

Person1: You're my partner, aren't you?
Person2: That I am... What's this I hear about you taking a job on the docks?
Person1: I leave in a week - the union's been pushing for it, and I need the extra cash...
Person2: You're not thinking of getting in deep with the boys, are you? You know how they operate...
Person1: I can take care of myself. You're the one who's been acting strange lately...
Person2: Strange? You're the one who's been getting mysterious phone calls and sneaking out at night...
Person1: That's none of your business. You're just trying to distract me from the real issue...
Person2: The real issue is you're in over your head, and I'm trying to protect you. You're not thinking clearly...
Person1: Maybe I'm not thinking clearly, but I know you're hiding something from me. You're not telling me the whole truth...
Person2: Fine, I'll tell you the truth. But you have to promise me you'll be careful...

Person1: I don't know what I'm supposed to say, Alex. I want to do the right thing here.
Person2: You made me erase you from my life. I loved you. I love you! How could you --
Person1: I have a family, Rachel. I take full responsibility for my actions.
Person2: Explain this to me --- erased...? You violated me, Alex! On the night I needed you most!
Person1: I only wanted to be in your thoughts, to bring myself into your thoughts - so I could be as we are now.
Person2: Do you love me? Did you love me? Something. I listened to my heart, and I can't believe I've been blind to your true nature for so long.

Person1: I'm telling you, Alex, this whole project is a big, brainless, pile of horse shit. No offense.
Person2: Oh, come on, Rachel. If anyone's to blame, it's me. I'm the one who convinced you to take on this project in the first place.
Person1: Please, spare me the guilt trip. We're trying to have a rational discussion here. You're not going to sweet-talk your way out of this one.
Person2: Fine, be that way. But I'm not going to let you badmouth my ideas without putting up a fight. You're just mad because you're not used to working with someone as talented as me.
Person1: Talented? You call this talented? This is a mess, and you know it.
Person2: Maybe it's not perfect, but it's a start. And I'm willing to make changes, to work with you to make it better. But you have to meet me halfway.
Person1: Meet you halfway? You're the one who's been holding me back from the beginning. I'm starting to think you're intentionally sabotaging this project.
Person2: That's not fair, Rachel. I'm trying to help. You're just not used to having someone challenge your authority.
Person1: Challenge my authority? You're the one who's been playing games with me from day one. Well, I'm not buying it anymore.

Person1: You're my only problem, Alex. What does it take to make you go away?
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: Did you ever sit on the edge of the bed, take off your socks and stick your fingers between your toes?
Person2: What's on your wish list, detective? Pleading me out to a lesser charge with an agreed sentence?
Person1: You made three deals with the DA back there. We had to chase you through all this red tape and you tell me you're clean?
Person2: Please don't bullshit me, detective. You've got evidence problems, you've got witness problems...
Person1: Ever pick your nose in a deposition?

Person1: You're really blowing it, Rachel. You're cool, you're funny, you know your stuff. What's with this gloomy attitude?
Person2: You stabbed me in the back, literally. You were supposed to be my partner.
Person1: You were in my way. I had to make a move. And now you're holding me back with this negativity.

Person1: You've got to help them. They're counting on you.
Person2: I'm not sure I can trust you. What's in it for me?
Person1: Oh, I think you'll find my offer... persuasive. You see, I have a certain influence over the people you care about.
Person2: You're threatening me?
Person1: No, no, no. I'm simply stating a fact. And I'm willing to use that influence to help them... for a price.
Person2: I don't like being manipulated.
Person1: Ah, but that's where you're wrong. You do like it. You just don't like admitting it. And I'm happy to help you with that admission... for a price.

Person1: You're playing games with my head, aren't you? You think I'm crazy, just like the others.
Person2: I'm not playing games, I'm trying to help you. But yes, there's something wrong with you, especially after hearing that dream of yours, about the dark forest.
Person1: You're just like the others, trying to manipulate me, make me doubt myself. You're a witch, just like they said.
Person2: I'm not a witch, I'm a doctor. And I'm trying to help you uncover the truth about your past.

Person1: Do you believe in fate, Alex?
Person2: We're just trying to guide you in the right direction.
Person1: Who is... we? You're not even a crumb on the table of my life!
Person2: Eve, I think for you, we should go for "persuasion."
Person1: Where did you come from? You wouldn't even be a part of my story!
Person2: You'll know soon enough, Alex.

Person1: You're always trying to control me, aren't you? You think you know what's best for me, but you're just trying to manipulate me.
Person2: You're lying to yourself if you think you're in control. I'm just trying to help you see the truth. You're so caught up in your own lies, you don't know what's real anymore.
Person1: That's rich coming from you. You're the one who's been lying to me from the start. You're just trying to justify your own actions.
Person2: I'm not the one who's been living a fantasy. You need someone to force you to take a step back and see what's really going on.

Person1: You're so naive, thinking she doesn't lie to you. Why would I say I didn't do it if I did?
Person2: That's rich coming from you. You're the one who's always covering for her. Does she, widdle wee fing! Wuhve you so much!
Person1: You're just trying to deflect attention from your own actions. I know you're hiding something. People are dying, and you're not saying a word about it.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. You're just paranoid because you can't understand why anyone would lie.
Person1: I'm not paranoid, I'm just aware of your tactics. You think you can manipulate me, but I see right through you.

Person1: I know what you are, I am so sorry that you...when I read that script I said there's only one person to play that part.
Person2: We've spent everything on these operations.  Is it really worth it?  We've pawned your mother's wedding ring.  The kids have no winter clothes...
Person1: I, uh...  I've always thought so...  Well, you just get an idea, and try to find the best way to express it in pictorial form.  Take this, it's my last few bucks. You'll need a hot meal when you get there.
Person2: I...I don't want to hear that word!
Person1: An artist of your caliber...Joey, what's more important, the kids' clothes or your creative vision?
Person2: I'm only trying to...
Person1: I know...Trauma, toil...when are we free of them...?  When...?  You'll need to relax, this hospital in Des Moines is the best art clinic in the country.
Person2: The minute I read that script I said...she works with animals, she...she has a home...
Person1: ...yes...I know, I'm so...because I said yes, a woman who...the...the community respects her.  Please don't go.  Please don't go.  What can I do but beseech you...?  Stay with me.  I need you.  We start to shoot tomorrow and then it belongs to us.

Person1: You're not going to intimidate me, Detective. I won't confess to anything.
Person2: Pressure, huh? Well, let's take a little break then. We'll discuss this further when you're feeling more... cooperative.
Person1: You can't bully me into admitting something I didn't do.
Person2: Oh, I'm not bullying you. I'm just presenting the evidence. And if necessary, I can bring in the eyewitness who places you at the scene of the crime.

Person1: I'm warning you! If you don't take me seriously after all these years of loyalty, I'll never forgive you!!
Person2: Said who? The CEO? I'm learning as I go, but I know you're not as innocent as you seem.
Person1: You're making fun of me? You think I'm blind to your manipulation? You empowered the CEO to deal with me behind my back?
Person2: I'm sorry, I... I didn't mean to undermine your authority. But you have to admit, the CEO has a point.
Person1: A point? You let that snake in the door, and now you're trying to justify it? I brought this company to its current success, and you're going to let the CEO take that away from me?

Person1: You think you're teaching my kid some kind of respect, but really you're just showing them how to kiss up. You had to know how to say yes sir and no sir.
Person2: That's not what I'm doing. I'm preparing them for the real world.
Person1: The real world? You mean the one where you have to know your place? Well, maybe my version of growing up is about questioning authority, not just blindly following it.
Person2: You're not giving them the tools they need to succeed. You're just letting them think they can do whatever they want.

Person1: You know, like restaurants, night clubs... 
Person2: Anything specific?
Person1: Don't ask. I'm serious, you rock, Max. 
Person2: Easy, Sketchy. What is it now?
Person1: That psycho got exactly what she deserved... Yes. 
Person2: You would be making a mistake to come away from this thinking she's the villain in the piece... You are. 
Person1: She was the one... trying to have it both ways and being completely selfish. 
Person2: If I ever find out you're going out the back door on Natalie again, you're the one who's gonna be hanging by your ankles three stories up. Understand?

Person1: I've got a few questions for you, Dr. Patel.
Person2: And I've got a few for you, Agent Ross. What's your real interest in this case?
Person1: I'm here to uncover the truth, not play games.
Person2: Who, here, could possibly care what you want? You're just a pawn in a much larger game.
Person1: I've heard rumors of a new player in town. Someone who's been making some big moves.
Person2: (laughs) You mean the new investor? Oh, they're just trying to get a foothold in the market.
Person1: Save it, Doctor. I've seen the way they operate. They're not afraid to get their hands dirty.
Person2: And what makes you think you're any different, Agent? You're just as dirty as the rest of us.
Person1: I'm trying to clean up this mess, not make it worse.
Person2: (smirks) You're just trying to advance your own career. Don't pretend to be something you're not.

Person1: I'll give you what you've always wanted. A chance to start anew.
Person2: You're forgiven if you don't look back at your past for the rest of your life.
Person1: You're persistent, but it's kind of flattering. Don't get my hopes up, though.

Person1: You're the first one I'll come for if anything goes wrong. Understand what I'm saying?
Person2: What do you want from me, Victor?
Person1: I want you to marry me, and together we'll raise our empire. There are many perks that come with being my partner.
Person2: I'd rather die than be with you. You've ruined my life and destroyed everything I care about.
Person1: Many partnerships begin with a certain amount of tension, but after a while, I believe we could learn to trust each other. Think about it. You're running out of time, and soon I'll be the one in control.
Person2: You're insane if you think I'll ever agree to this.
Person1: Insanity is a matter of perspective. Now, is there anything you want to tell me before we take the next step?

Person1: You're free to go to her, if you want. If you'd rather be a part of this project and run with the team, just say the word.
Person2: I don't want to talk about it.
Person1: Why not? You're not having the time of your life, are you?
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: I wonder if we couldn't get some fresh perspectives in here, and shake things up. Still miss the old way of doing things?
Person2: No. Not something new.
Person1: Well, something's wrong. You're not yourself lately.
Person2: Nothing's wrong. It's great, okay? Having the best team leaders. And what can anyone say about the new strategy that hasn't been said. And it's great working with friends, blah blah blah.
Person1: Um. Happy for you.
Person2: Thanks. So tell me, how's it really going?
Person1: You're my closest colleague. But are you a team player?

Person1: You're quite the charmer, aren't you? I've even wondered whether you might have a hidden agenda.
Person2: Oh, no. I'm just trying to make a good impression. We have dull stretches every week or so, thank God, when there's nothing to do after midnight.
Person1: I loved you, and because you knew I loved you, you let me think you loved me. Didn't you see, couldn't you see?
Person2: It's a matter of definition. Faithful in spirit, yes. But the sex urge is a powerful force. In women just as much as men.
Person1: You'd think now, with only six weeks before they ship me back home, it would be easier. But it isn't. It's terribly hard. Sometimes the temptation is just too much.
Person2: Then why not, as long as it wouldn't hurt anybody...? You have a certain modest charm yourself.
Person1: But I'm not that easily swayed. I've seen through your tactics, Captain. Hawkeye. You helped me pull together when I needed it, but I won't fall for your tricks.

Person1: What's this supposed to be?
Person2: What does it look like to you?
Person1: You're not even trying to help me. Do you ever get the slightest inkling that you might want to assist me instead of doing absolutely nothing?
Person2: Oh, I'm doing plenty. You're just not seeing it.
Person1: Get the inkling, Alex. I'm getting tired of your attitude. You're hiding something, and I'm going to find out what it is.
Person2: You're just paranoid. Clark Brandon's throwing a party tonight. Want to come with me?
Person1: What's the point of that? You're just trying to distract me.
Person2: Maybe I am. But you could use a break from your own thoughts. Trust me, darling.

Person1: You think she's gonna tell her boss on us?
Person2: I've just been thinking, maybe we're not happy with each other.
Person1: Don't say "we" when you mean "you." What's going on, really?
Person2: I think maybe we're both so used to operating at this level that... Look, I'm telling you, they love that shit.
Person1: What are you talking about? You're gonna screw up our plan.
Person2: I need some space, maybe. You look money, baby. We both look money.
Person1: The trick is to look like you don't need it, then they give you shit for free. But I think you're just unhappy with yourself.
Person2: Who's around? I'm not making fun. Let's do it, baby. We can get some complimentary items if we don't fool around.
Person1: You're not listening to me. You're just trying to get laid, aren't you?
Person2: I'm telling you, it's not about that. It's about playing it cool and getting what we want.

Person1: You're all crazy, you know that?!
Person2: Look what you've driven me to!

Person1: You're not taking this seriously; you're just trying to avoid the conversation.
Person2: I'm trying to protect you from yourself. You're not ready to make these decisions.
Person1: You mean you didn't have these thoughts when you were my age? You're just trying to control me.
Person2: Stay out of this, it's none of your business. You don't know what's at stake.
Person1: I know exactly what's at stake. You're trying to manipulate me, just like you did with Emily.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly, Alex. Trust me, you hear something, change the subject. You find something, get rid of it, throw it away. You know what happened. The rest is only details.
Person2: I don't know, Rachel. Maybe I'm going out of my mind, but I get the feeling that everything revolves around me somehow. It's like I'm stuck in some kind of never-ending loop.
Person1: That's exactly what I'm talking about. You're getting caught up in the details. If you want to put this back together, just let it go. You're not going to find any answers by dwelling on it.
Person2: But what if I'm not just being paranoid? What if there's really something going on?
Person1: Then you'll figure it out. But for now, just focus on moving forward. You can't change the past, Alex. All you can do is control how you react to it.

Person1: I wish to resign from my position, effective immediately.
Person2: I'm afraid that's not possible. You're far too valuable to our organization. I'll speak to you further when I come to your office.
Person1: No, sir! I mean with all humility, no. I would rather you dismissed me. It's obvious I don't satisfy.
Person2: Then try harder, Rachel. I have no intention of letting you go. You will remain in our employ and learn your place. Besides, I'm sure you're curious about the project I have in store for you. Go now, and don't bother asking questions.

Person1: You're still growing, I suppose? That's why you're so careless with my things.
Person2: I'm sorry, sir. It won't happen again.
Person1: See that it doesn't. I need you to run an errand for me. Go to the store and pick up a pack of cigars. The owner, Dave, will know what I mean.
Person2: That's a lot of trust you're putting in me, sir. Are you sure you can trust me with your money?
Person1: Trust has nothing to do with it. I just want to see if you're capable of following simple instructions. And if you happen to "misplace" the money, well, that's your business. Just don't come crying to me when you get caught.
Person2: And what about containment, sir? You're not worried about me spilling the beans about your little scheme?
Person1: Containment? Ha! You're just a pawn in a much larger game, kid. You don't know the first thing about containment. Just focus on getting the cigars and keeping your mouth shut.

Person1: I'm so happy for you.
Person2: You know what they'd do if they found out. You know what they'd do to us.
Person1: Huh?! What are you talking about?
Person2: Let's just say we're in this together now. We can make it work, partner.
Person1: But I don't understand. What's going on?
Person2: It's only a small favor. And it'll probably clear up, once we get out of this situation. I promise.

Person1: You're really going to stand there and tell me it was an accident?
Person2: Well, I was going to lie and say it was, but you'd know I was lying.
Person1: Save it. I now have to replace my favorite vase. You're going to have to make it up to me.
Person2: I said I was sorry...

Person1: What did you do to her?
Person2: I didn't do anything. She's just trying to ruin my reputation.
Person1: Save it. I know what you're capable of. You're gonna have to do a lot more to convince me you're innocent.
Person2: You know, I've been thinking. If I were in your shoes, I'd want to make sure I'm not being played. But I'm telling you the truth. You're just not listening.
Person1: I'm listening. And I'm watching. You're not as slick as you think you are.
Person2: Maybe not. But I've got a lot to lose if this gets out. And I'll do whatever it takes to protect myself. You can count on it.
Person1: Is that a threat?
Person2: Just a promise. You know what I'm saying?

Person1: What's going on here?
Person2: You know what I want... it's not that difficult.
Person1: How long have you been planning this?
Person2: Years, why? You're playing a dangerous game here.
Person1: If you're trying to blackmail me... it's not going to work.
Person2: You already have the checks, darling. You know what I'm capable of.
Person1: I didn't mean it that way... I'm sorry.
Person2: Oh, forget it. I'll be back in an hour. Right?
Person1: Right. But don't think you can manipulate me that easily.
Person2: We'll see about that.

Person1: You're very right. I think the best thing we could all do is go home.
Person2: He cares about what I do? You're not exactly like the others, are you?
Person1: This time I imagine you would, yes. Hmm... With all this in mind, I can't logically make a formal bid on your company, can I?
Person2: Look, I'll try to find out what the hell's going on. When I see him I'll talk to him.
Person1: You'd be initiating a financial battle you'd ultimately lose. I'm not sleeping with him, it's not like that!
Person2: Well, I guess it's 'cause he loves you so much. He's jealous and worried.

Person1: I've been watching you from the beginning... from your very first move.
Person2: What do you want?
Person1: Then help me, for your own sake... Who is behind this?
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: I will never get tired of uncovering the truth, so you might want to change your story.
Person2: What am I gonna protect that secret for? It was never mine to keep.

Person1: I've got everything planned out for us, just like you always wanted. I just want you to be happy.
Person2: That's sweet, but it's not about the plan, it's about the people involved. You need to take care of the loose ends, or it'll never be over.
Person1: What do you mean? I thought we were past all that.
Person2: You're not thinking about the consequences, are you? You're not thinking about what's best for me. Do you love me? DO YOU LOVE ME?!
Person1: Of course, I do. But I don't see why I have to choose between my freedom and making you happy.
Person2: Your freedom? Ha! Your freedom has caused more pain and suffering than any plan I ever dreamed of. Face it, your way has failed. It's time to take responsibility.

Person1: You had to know how to act right. You had to know how to say yes sir and no sir.
Person2: Ah, but that's exactly what I'm trying to do - teach you the ways of the court. Don't trouble yourself, my dear. It's all just a game.
Person1: A game? It sounded like screams from the courtyard.
Person2: Oh, that? Just a little entertainment I've arranged. Nothing to concern yourself with. Now, let's focus on your etiquette. You wouldn't want to embarrass me in front of the nobles, would you?
Person1: I suppose not. But I still don't understand why I have to learn all this.
Person2: Because, my dear, in this world, one must know their place. And I'm here to show you yours.

Person1: I've been observing your team, Captain. You seem to be satisfied with them.
Person2: That's right. We work well together. But I think it's time we re-evaluate our priorities. It's over, between us, I mean.
Person1: What do you mean? We're just getting started on this project.
Person2: I mean, our partnership. It's not working out. You're too focused on efficiency, and I'm more concerned with the human aspect.
Person1: That's not fair. I've been trying to adapt to your... unconventional methods. And by the way, you have a little something on your upper lip.
Person2: Ah, thanks for noticing. But seriously, I think we're just too different. You're more of a "by the book" kind of person, and I'm more of a... well, a free spirit.
Person1: That's not true. I've been trying to work with you, despite your... let's say, unorthodox approach. But if you're not willing to meet me halfway, then maybe it's best we go our separate ways.
Person2: Exactly. I think it's for the best. And who knows, maybe we can still be friends. You can have the project, I'll just take my team and we'll work on something else.
Person1: Fine. But I'm warning you, I'll be watching you. And I won't hesitate to report any irregularities to our superiors.

Person1: You're a confidential informant? What a joke.
Person2: I'm telling the truth. You're just too blinded by your ego to see it.
Person1: Oh, so now you're a mind reader? You think you know what I'm thinking?
Person2: I know you're trying to distract me from the real issue. You're in love with Inez, aren't you?
Person1: Who's Inez? And what does she have to do with anything?
Person2: Don't play dumb, Tanner. I know all about your little secret.

Person1: You're not telling me the whole truth, are you?
Person2: What are you talking about? I've told you everything.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I know you're hiding something.
Person2: You're just trying to confuse me. You don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: Oh, I think I do. You're trying to manipulate me, just like you did with my brother.
Person2: That's not fair! You have no right to accuse me of that.
Person1: I have every right. You're not as innocent as you seem. You're capable of anything.
Person2: That's it, I've had enough of your accusations!

Person1: You're one sick bastard, using your power to exploit people. What do you need me for?
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. I'm just trying to uncover the truth.
Person1: The heck you don't. You're just trying to cover your own tracks. People are suffering, and you're more concerned with saving your own skin. I want to know how you sleep at night.
Person2: If you cooperate, I might be able to help you. But if you continue to resist, things will only get worse for you.

Person1: You know, Doctor, you have the most kindest heart beneath the professor way you act. I can tell you want justice in the world and have some real interesting ideas.
Person2: (laughs) Well, I suppose that's one way to put it. But let me ask you, would you be willing to make a sincere and heartfelt apology to me, right here, right now?
Person1: Whatever for? I think you're a wonderful doctor, and I'm not afraid of you at all. You could operate on me anytime and I wouldn't even be scared.
Person2: (smiling) That's very kind of you to say. But I think you'll find that I'm not just a doctor, I'm also a man who knows how to get what he wants. And what I want is for you to apologize to me.
Person1: (nervously) Oh, I don't know... I don't think I've done anything wrong.
Person2: (leaning in) Ah, but that's where you're mistaken. You see, I've been watching you, and I think you have a lot of potential. Potential that I can help you realize, if you're willing to do what I say.
Person1: (hesitantly) I suppose... I suppose I could try.
Person2: (smiling) That's all I can ask for. Now, let's get started, shall we?

Person1: You will never be free, though you deserve it. But just as the darkness will fall tonight, some power will rule your heart. And what if its force ran not with the chains of your past, but with the freedom of a true soul?
Person2: I cannot be swayed by empty promises. 
Person1: WHO ARE YOU TO DECIDE IF YOU SHOULD BE BOUND OR FREE? 
Person2: I... don't know... what do you want from me?
Person1: Nothing. I'm here to show you the truth... because I see the truth in you.

Person1: I've been noticing you've been spending a lot of time with Rachel lately. Who's she to you?
Person2: Oh, she's just a friend from work. We're collaborating on a project.
Person1: You're always telling us in class how writers make choices, but it seems like you're not making any choices with her. You're always "under the influence" when you're with her, aren't you?
Person2: That's not fair. You're just trying to provoke me. Rachel is a colleague, and our project is important to me.
Person1: I'm not trying to provoke you, but I think you're not being honest with yourself. You're always saying how good writers make choices, but you're not making any choices with Rachel. You're just going with the flow.
Person2: That's enough. I think we've talked about this enough. Let's just agree to disagree.

Person1: You're the one who's been acting strange lately!
Person2: I've never met anyone like you, Alex. You're so paranoid.
Person1: No, I mean, you said, "It's time for a change." Who were you talking to? Tell me!
Person2: Alex, stop it! You're getting worked up over nothing.
Person1: I've never seen you like this before. You're usually so calm and collected. What's going on?
Person2: Maybe I'm just tired of being dedicated to this relationship. It's easy to get caught up in the whole ego cycle of love and make it all about ourselves.
Person1: Yeah, I felt that way too, when we first started, but now... the fights, the jealousy... it's not all romance and candlelit dinners anymore. Maybe I should've listened to my friends and tried to make some changes earlier, I don't know...
Person2: ...but I love listening to you, so that's okay. You're like a warm breeze that's suddenly blown into my life.
Person1: Thanks. But I'd like to hear what you're really feeling. You're not telling me everything, are you?
Person2: Well, I just feel that life'll be much sweeter for you now that I'm around. I promise... and I know you'll do anything to keep me happy, won't you, Alex?

Person1: You've got to help them.
Person2: What's more important, their future or your own reputation?
Person1: Can you help me?
Person2: I've spent everything on these operations. Is it really worth it? We've pawned our last possessions...
Person1: Then I'll help them. For a price. And you'll need to relax, just like the Doc said.
Person2: I don't want to hear that!

Person1: You're still with him, aren't you? I can't take watching you touch him.
Person2: What's it to you? I've been doing good, though.
Person1: You've got nothing else to live for. You're just using him to fill the void.
Person2: That's not true. I'm happy with him.
Person1: Happy? You call that happy? He's suffocating you, and you're too blind to see it.
Person2: You're just jealous. You're the one who's lost everything.
Person1: I've lost everything because of you. Because of your lies and your manipulation.

Person1: You know what I mean? Like the burn marks on the outer thigh, same place as Karen Sumpter.
Person2: Yeah, I know what you mean. The UNSUB is able to abduct, kill, transport, and bury without detection.
Person1: All the same killer? You're trying to make me believe in Suspect Zero, aren't you?
Person2: I'm just saying, it's a theory. You can't deny the evidence.
Person1: Evidence? You call that evidence? It's just a crackpot theory to discredit Low.
Person2: Maybe, but what if I told you I have proof? Would you love me then?
Person1: What are you talking about? This has nothing to do with love.
Person2: Oh, doesn't it? You're so quick to dismiss the theory, but you're not looking at the bigger picture. I think you're scared of the truth.
Person1: I'm not scared of anything. I just want to apprehend Richard Low, not chase some wild goose chase.
Person2: That's exactly what Koessler wants you to think. But I know the truth. And I think you do too, deep down.

Person1: I don't know you and I got nothing to say to you.
Person2: You're the only one holding yourself to that standard. The people want to hear your story, they need to hear it!
Person1: Yeah, right. They don't believe me. They think I'm crazy.
Person2: I do. And I think of the scope of your experience, and it takes my breath away.
Person1: It's not enough, don't you understand? I know it happened, but by every standard of science, it's utterly beside the point.
Person2: The world is on fire, and people need something they can believe in, something worthy. You can give it to them!
Person1: I want to, more than anything. But it has to be real. It has to be true.
Person2: If you go out there like this, if you admit to even the possibility that what you experienced didn't actually happen, I'm afraid they really will crucify you. Please, for your own sake, for the sake of the world... tell them what you know to be the truth.

Person1: I'm giving you an opportunity to prove yourself, but I don't trust anyone. You're a skilled negotiator, it's in your nature to get what you want.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: This deal could make or break your career. I'm just protecting my investment. You should have taken their offer, especially if you were unprepared.
Person2: I had a chance to review the contract, and I'm not comfortable with the terms.
Person1: That happens. You're just trying to stall. I don't have time for games. You want to be independent? Be independent now. I've got no sympathy for you.

Person1: I'm afraid that your health is not good. You're my only friend and I ought to check in on you before things get worse.
Person2: Morning. I'm sorry I didn't call. I was irresponsible, I should have reached out.
Person1: You should be. You've always been there for me, always. Now I'm not asking what's going on, I just want to know that you're alright.
Person2: I'm fine. But I don't want to be a burden. I know this is a bad time.
Person1: You're not a burden. Do you want to make things easier on me? Now tell me what's been going on because this is, this is concerning. You can say anything to me, I hope you still know that.
Person2: I know that. But I hardly know where to start.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly. That dress suits you, by the way.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: I think you know. You're not safe on your own, and I'm not just talking about your marriage. Someone out there is pulling strings for you, and I can help you uncover who it is.
Person2: I don't need your help. I can take care of myself.
Person1: Really? Then why are you sleeping in separate bedrooms? Is it because your husband has a secret, one that you're not willing to confront?
Person2: That's none of your business.
Person1: Oh, but it is. You see, I know all about secrets and manipulation. And I think you're being played, just like Verbal was. Stay with me, and I'll help you uncover the truth. Refuse, and you'll be on your own, just like Verbal.
Person2: I'm not afraid of you.
Person1: You should be. I'm the only one who can protect you from yourself.

Person1: I've heard some foolish things in my life.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: You're actually considering quitting your job to travel the world with Rachel.
Person2: Who told you that?
Person1: Have you thought about your responsibilities, not to mention your family's expectations? And I need your help to finalize the project report.
Person2: You have no right to ask me to be a little bit better than you because you gave me a better head start. You sit right there with your no manners self.
Person1: I do have a right to ask you to be honest with yourself. You're not thinking clearly. You're being swayed by Rachel's charm.
Person2: Who are you to decide what's right for me? You're just trying to control me like you always do. I'm not going to let you dictate my life.
Person1: Don't make me remind you of all the times I've helped you. You owe me.
Person2: I don't owe you anything. You've always manipulated me to get what you want. Not this time.

Person1: I don't know what I'm supposed to say, Alex. I want to do the right thing here.
Person2: Wait, stop. You don't seem to understand. You're not really comprehending any of this. I'm not who you think I am. I've been lying to you from the start.
Person1: Do you love me? Did you love me? Something. I feel like I've been living in a dream.
Person2: No, I don't love you. I used you. And now you're starting to figure it out, aren't you? You're starting to see the truth.
Person1: You made me believe... you made me trust you.
Person2: That was the plan. And it worked, didn't it? You're my lawyer, and you never even suspected a thing.

Person1: I don't think you understand, Emma. This isn't a typical office job, it's a creative startup. You'll have the freedom to express yourself.
Person2: Are you joking? You're trying to sugarcoat this, but I know what it means to work for a startup. It means long hours and no work-life balance.
Person1: Don't think that I want to save myself from any embarrassment, from the awkwardness of you not fitting in... It's not that; it's that you can say certain things easier if you're alone. Please, Emma, do try to understand me... It would look like I was trying to influence you, to force you, to control you... and that makes me feel uncomfortable...
Person2: You're not listening to me! You're just trying to manipulate me into taking this job. I know what you're doing, and it's not going to work.

Person1: You're going to regret this, I swear on my life.
Person2: Oh, you're embarrassing me in front of my colleagues! You know how I get when I'm humiliated.
Person1: I'm doing this for us, to protect our reputation.
Person2: Why are you doing this?! You're suffocating me!
Person1: If I let you continue, you'll be right back where I found you - a mess.
Person2: Please understand, I've had enough of your control, Tyler.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you, Mr. Thompson? I hired you to find my sister, and now I'm firing you.
Person2: Why should I take it seriously, Mrs. Lee? You're not even telling me the whole truth about her disappearance. What are you hiding?
Person1: I'm not hiding anything. I just want results, not excuses.
Person2: Results? You want results? I've been working day and night, and you're not even willing to listen to my findings. You're not ready for the truth, Mrs. Lee.

Person1: You're very clever, Dr. Patel. You just sit there and let me talk. What a sorry old woman, you're thinking. What a crazy old fool.
Person2: I didn't mean to imply that, Rachel. I'm just trying to understand.
Person1: Understand? You want to understand? Try and find a decent cup of coffee in this hospital. Even when it's not visiting hours, Rachel, on this job you carry a lot of emotional baggage. You sleep rarely, eat even less, and sometimes the patients you're trying to help are more than you can handle!
Person2: Rachel, you don't have to be deliberately defensive just to impress me. I'm here to help.
Person1: If anything, I'm making it sound easy. Let's face it, Dr. Patel... you aren't made for this kind of work. Few people are.

Person1: You're really talented, but I think you're wasting your potential.
Person2: What do you mean? I'm doing exactly what I want to do.
Person1: Are you? Or are you just running from your past? You need to admit that your family's expectations have been holding you back.
Person2: That's not true. I'm just trying to make a difference in my own way.
Person1: I think you're afraid to take a real risk. You need to believe in something besides your own fears.
Person2: You're one to talk. You're just trying to distract me from your own flaws.
Person1: Maybe. But I think you're cute when you're trying to be defiant. And I have a feeling you could use a little guidance.
Person2: Guidance? You're not even guiding yourself.

Person1: You know, I've been thinking, and I want to cut through the b.s.
Person2: Oh God, just get it over with.
Person1: I think you're an immature idealist. No, let me correct that, a naive idealist. Which is fine, except you're going to be leading my company and I'm afraid your inexperience is going to sink us.
Person2: Mr. Lee, I...
Person1: Let me finish. You're a brilliant mind, but you have to dress for success. Not just physically, but mentally. You need to toughen up and make the hard decisions.
Person2: Feel free to give me some suggestions.
Person1: First, stop being so empathetic. It's a weakness in business. Second, your outlook on life... it's too optimistic. You need to be more cynical, more ruthless.

Person1: Commander, I'm proud to have you on my team! Now, show them what you can do!
Person2: I'm not a pawn. I refuse to play along.
Person1: If we panic now, we're done for. Nobody saw it. Nobody knows it was us. We're still okay.
Person2: This is some mission. I sure am having a good time. This is real fun.
Person1: Then, you'll die... Just, know this. If you weren't so concerned with having a good time, we wouldn't be here right now.
Person2: So this is all my fault, is it?

Person1: Who do you think you are, making up that nonsense about me?!
Person2: Oh, come on, I love you, but you know I only got this job because my sister needed a reference.
Person1: Shut up, you're just saying that to get under my skin. Take it easy, don't do anything reckless.
Person2: Then do it for my sister. Mrs. Johnson used to call her a "goody-goody" when she'd volunteer at the local animal shelter. She'd freak out if her old boss somehow, I don't know, got her fired.

Person1: I need time, Alex. I'm still adjusting to my new life.
Person2: You're using that as an excuse, aren't you? You think I'm dirty, tattooed, and uncivilized.
Person1: That's not what I meant. It's just... I don't know if I can trust you.
Person2: Trust me? You're the one who's been playing games with me. You know I can help you, but you're too scared to let me in.
Person1: I'm not scared. I just... I don't know what you want from me.
Person2: What I want is for you to be honest with me. You're not the only one who's been hurt, you know. My mom left my dad, and it took me a while to accept it. But I did.
Person1: That's not the same thing. You can't compare our situations.
Person2: Why not? Because you're too caught up in your own pain to see that I'm trying to help you? You need to move on, Rachel. Let go of the past.
Person1: You don't understand. You're just trying to manipulate me into doing what you want.
Person2: Maybe I am. But it's because I care about you, and I want to see you happy. You're just too afraid to take a chance.

Person1: You're making a grave mistake. Our organization doesn't tolerate threats.
Person2: Ah, but your organization needs talent like mine. Destroy your reputation over an issue of pride? What a waste.

Person1: I thought we were getting on here!
Person2: You know how I work, analyzing every little step before I take one.
Person1: That's whacked! You're not going to intimidate me with your tactics.
Person2: I'm not trying to intimidate you. I just need you to understand the situation.
Person1: The situation is that you're trying to control me, and I won't let you.
Person2: I'm trying to protect you. If you just give me a little more time, I can make sure everything works out.
Person1: I don't need your protection. I can take care of myself.
Person2: Fine. But if anything goes wrong, don't say I didn't warn you.

Person1: I don't need a reminder to know who I am, alright? You're not going to eat the rice, are you?
Person2: What did you tell the police, Rachel? 
Person1: Nothing about you, but I'll shop you if you don't give up being a journalist. It's that simple.
Person2: You're crying, Rachel. Are you happy now?
Person1: Shut up, Alex. This isn't funny, man. You're trying to manipulate me, but I'm not buying it.

Person1: You're wasting your talent, Will. I saw the papers, the second one was all over TV. Did you ever think about giving me a call?
Person2: I'm leaning toward no. I wouldn't be useful to you anymore, Jack.
Person1: That's not entirely true, Will. It's the way you think. You caught the last two like this.
Person2: You don't need me. The Bureau already has the best lab. Plus you have Bloom at the University of Chicago...
Person1: You're crazy, Will. You're running from your past. I can help you.
Person2: I think there has been a lot of bullshit about the way I think. I came down here to get away from all that.
Person1: You look all right now. But I can see the fire in your eyes, Will. You're not done yet.

Person1: You're playing with fire, Alex. You think you're above the law, but someday you'll learn that there's more to life than just getting ahead.
Person2: What's your problem, man? You're always lecturing me.
Person1: I'm trying to warn you. There are people out there who will stop at nothing to get what they want. They'll use anyone, including you, to get ahead.
Person2: And what about the people who are already ahead? The ones who are making a profit off of others' misery? You're not talking about them, are you?
Person1: I'm talking about the ones who think they're above the law. The ones who think they can buy their way out of trouble.
Person2: You mean like the ones who are buying and selling people's secrets? The ones who are making a killing off of other people's mistakes?
Person1: Exactly. And you're playing right into their hands. You're so focused on getting ahead that you're not even thinking about the consequences of your actions.
Person2: And you're not thinking about the consequences of your own actions. You're so quick to judge others, but you're not looking at your own reflection.

Person1: You're not going to get away with this, are you? You want the truth to come out, you want them to see you at your worst...
Person2: That's not technically accurate. You're just trying to distract me from the real issue.
Person1: Distract you? You're the one who's been playing games with me from the start. I know how ugly you can be, capable of anything.
Person2: You're just trying to sell more copies, aren't you? If people knew the real story, they'd be shocked.
Person1: Shocked? You think you're shocked? I've seen the worst of you, and I know you have no remorse. You want to use me to get ahead, to get your story out.
Person2: You're drunk on power, that's what you are. You think you can control the narrative, but you're just a pawn in a much larger game.

Person1: I'm telling you, if you want to impress a potential investor, you need to put on the right music. You can't walk into a meeting with a venture capitalist listening to elevator music.
Person2: That doesn't ring any bells. Are you sure it's that important?
Person1: Positive. You need something that exudes confidence and sophistication. Maybe some Mozart or Chopin.
Person2: I'm really drawing a blank here. Are you sure it's not just about the numbers and the business plan?
Person1: No, it's about creating an atmosphere. You can't present a revolutionary new product listening to Top 40 hits. You need something that says "I'm a visionary".
Person2: I see what you're saying. But what if I'm not comfortable with classical music?
Person1: Then you need to get comfortable. Trust me, it's all about the image you project. And if you project confidence and sophistication, people will take you seriously. Got it?

Person1: You're not thinking clearly, Alex. You're letting your emotions cloud your judgment.
Person2: I don't care what you think. I know what I want, and I'm willing to do whatever it takes to get it. You deserve better than him, and I'm the one who can give it to you.
Person1: You're not even considering the consequences. If he finds out, he'll destroy you.
Person2: That's not true. You're just trying to scare me. You're the one who's lost everything - your friends, your reputation. I'm the only one who can save you now.

Person1: I've been thinking about this for a long time, and I'm not going to back down.
Person2: I understand your determination, but let me make one thing clear: if you try to proceed without my guidance, you'll be putting yourself and others at risk. I've been watching you, and I know your weaknesses. You need me to succeed.
Person1: That's a pretty bold claim. What makes you think you're the only one who can help me?
Person2: Because I've been tracking your every move, and I know exactly what you're capable of. And let me tell you, it's not enough. But with my help, we can achieve something truly remarkable. Refuse my offer, and you'll be lucky to make it out alive.

Person1: You're not going to get away with this.
Person2: If you don't cooperate, I'll make sure everyone knows what you've done.
Person1: I've done nothing wrong.
Person2: Who will believe you? You need me to vouch for your innocence. The others who have been affected, they blame you for their misfortune. They say you're responsible for their downfall.
Person1: I'm not responsible for their downfall.
Person2: You think they'll take your word for it? You can either help me now or face the consequences.
Person1: You're just trying to manipulate me.
Person2: I'm just trying to get to the truth. You can either be a part of it or stand in the way. The choice is yours.

Person1: I've seen the tapes, and I know what you're capable of. You can feel my presence, can't you?
Person2: This isn't real. You're just trying to scare me.
Person1: Scare you? I'm trying to awaken you. You're trapped in a world of ignorance, and I'm the only one who can set you free.
Person2: I don't need your help. I can take care of myself.
Person1: Oh, really? Then why do you feel so drawn to me? Why do you feel like you can't resist my touch?
Person2: That's not true. I'm not under your control.
Person1: Aren't you? I think you'll find that you're more mine than you realize. And soon, you'll be begging for my touch.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly. I know something's in there - and so do you.
Person2: Don't try to spin this on me. I'm just saying, the situation is a problem. And it's your problem.
Person1: That's right, it wasn't your idea, none of this was your idea. You're just along for the ride.
Person2: If you think I'm gonna let my investment slip away because of your ego, you're wrong.
Person1: You will not do anything about it, because without my expertise, we're not getting out of this situation, so as far as I'm concerned, you can just sit back and let me handle it, got it?
Person2: Don't take that tone with me. I'm not some fool you can manipulate.
Person1: Oh, but you are. You're just too blind to see it.

Person1: You're as cold as this planet. You've spent so much time doing your duty and giving orders you've never learned how to be human.
Person2: If I go back on sedation, I won't feel the same way about you. You'll report me for drug evasion.
Person1: Spare me please! Don't tell me about your slip movement installation again. I've had it with your excuses. All you let yourself think about is your next shift.
Person2: You think you're the one to apply some heat? To make me feel something?
Person1: Sure... If I were interested. But I don't think it'd be much fun. You're too far gone, too numb. I could have helped you plenty in that department... if you'd have let go for a minute. But it's too late now, sweetheart. Your big opportunity is flying out of here.

Person1: You know what I've got at stake with this project. You know that.
Person2: What are you talking about? This isn't about you.
Person1: Ever since the incident, I've been worried that you'd been unhappy, or...
Person2: The incident? You mean the time I caught you snooping through my files?
Person1: That's not what I meant. But then you've been so much better... more cooperative.
Person2: Cooperative? You're the one who's been manipulating me, making me do your bidding.
Person1: I'm just trying to help you see things from my perspective. You're not thinking clearly.
Person2: You're trying to control me, like you always do. Well, it's not going to work this time.
Person1: Trust me, I can take care of this. I can make it all go away.
Person2: No, I don't trust you. And I'm not going to let you sabotage me again.

Person1: You're not going to find it because it doesn't exist.
Person2: Oh, I think it does. And I think you're hiding something. You're good at that, aren't you? Hiding behind your words, your actions.
Person1: I'm not hiding anything. I'm telling you the truth.
Person2: The truth? You know what the truth is? The truth is that you're a master manipulator. You twist words, you twist situations, you twist people. And you think you're so clever, don't you?
Person1: That's not fair. I'm just trying to have a conversation.
Person2: A conversation? You call this a conversation? This is a game, and you're the one making the rules. Well, I'm not playing by your rules anymore. I'm going to call you out on your lies, on your manipulation.
Person1: You're just trying to provoke me.
Person2: Maybe I am. But it's working, isn't it? You're getting defensive, you're getting angry. And that's exactly what I want. I want you to see yourself for what you really are.
Person1: And what's that?
Person2: A person who uses people, who uses situations, who uses words to get what they want. And I'm not going to let you do it to me anymore.

Person1: I've been hearing a lot of rumors about your new project. Mind if I take a look?
Person2: What's with the sudden interest? You're not exactly known for your environmental activism.
Person1: Let's just say I'm curious. I've heard some wild stories about the kind of materials you're working with.
Person2: Oh, you mean the ones about hazardous waste and secret experiments? Those are just myths.
Person1: Save it, okay? I've done my research. I know you're hiding something. Either you show me what's going on or I'll make sure everyone else finds out.
Person2: You're not going to bully me into giving you a tour. If you're so concerned, why don't you go save a tree or something?
Person1: That's not what this is about. You're not as slick as you think you are. I know you're reading something right now. What's the title of that book?
Person2: Uh, it's... uh... just a novel. Doesn't matter.
Person1: Don't lie to me. I saw you with it the other night. You were supposed to meet me at the club, but you didn't show up. What's going on?

Person1: There's something I need to discuss with you.
Person2: What's that?
Person1: Just trust me, it's important. You know my cousin, Rachel?
Person2: Yeah, what about her?
Person1: I need you to convince her to meet with me. Tell her it's urgent.
Person2: And what's in it for me?
Person1: You'll be doing me a favor, and I'll owe you one.

Person1: You're gonna be sorry we ever met if you don't pay me what you owe.
Person2: What are you guilty of? You must be hiding something or you wouldn't be so aggressive.
Person1: I'm not guilty of anything. I just want what's fair.
Person2: Fair? You're the one who's been playing with the numbers. I didn't say anything, but you're already on the defensive.
Person1: That's not true. You're just trying to distract me from the fact that you're trying to cheat me.
Person2: Cheat you? You're the one who's been making the deals. Maybe you should take a closer look at yourself.

Person1: Rachel, I need you to do me a huge favor.
Person2: What is it? You're scaring me.
Person1: I got a message from an old friend, and I need you to take care of something for me. Drop everything, it's urgent.
Person2: What's going on? You're not telling me something.
Person1: If anything happens to me, I want you to promise me you'll take care of my sister. You're the only one I trust with her.
Person2: Me? You want me to take care of your sister? What's going on, are you in trouble?

Person1: You're so spoiled. What is "not good" to you? Only a few hundred --
Person2: You murdered my brother! You used me, just like I used you. All part of the business.
Person1: Don't panic, I'm not going to hurt you. But there's --
Person2: You made me do it. You couldn't stand the thought of me deceiving you.
Person1: Shut up! Our money situation is not good. We've got sixteen dollars.
Person2: That's not correct. You're trying to manipulate me, just like you did with my brother.

Person1: You're not going to intimidate me, Alex. I know your tricks.
Person2: Oh, really? What tricks are those?
Person1: Don't play dumb. You think you can just charm your way out of this?
Person2: I'm not trying to charm you. I'm just trying to have a conversation.
Person1: Save it. You're not fooling anyone. Least of all, me.
Person2: You know, Rachel, you're not as young as you used to be. Maybe it's time to rethink your approach.
Person1: What's that supposed to mean?
Person2: Just that you're not as quick on your feet as you used to be. You're getting a little... predictable.
Person1: Predictable? You're one to talk. You're always playing the same games, using the same tactics.
Person2: And they always work, don't they?

Person1: You're a nice girl, anyway. And perhaps you didn't kill him on purpose. Perhaps you didn't kill the other one. You never know. Give her the benefit of the doubt.
Person2: I didn't say nobody, I said you.
Person1: Yes, you did. You're trying to make me believe you're innocent, but I know better. You're beautiful, and sad, and nowhere. Of course, you might have run awayif you knew how. And where to go.
Person2: That's what I'm doing. Couldn't they think of that?
Person1: If they had any reason to. Why make it tough for themselves? Why go to all that trouble? Here's an open book. Close it. No reason to keep it open.
Person2: You're trying to confuse me, aren't you? Make me doubt myself?
Person1: I'm just giving you the benefit of the doubt, baby. Come here.

Person1: You're playing with fire, Alex. Quit digging into my past.
Person2: Why should I care about your secrets? You're the one who says love's a funny thing.
Person1: Yeah, and sometimes I don't know if I want to love you... But I think we're getting in too deep, Alex.
Person2: That's rich coming from you. You're the one who's been pulling the strings from the start.
Person1: And I love you too, Alex. But don't think for a second that I won't cut you loose if you get too close to the truth.
Person2: I'm not afraid of you. But I am afraid of falling for someone who only looks out for themselves.

Person1: I mean, you know, at least I admit that I don't know. I know that things are messed up beyond belief and I know that I have nothing original to say about any of it, alright?
Person2: Don't give me that crap. That's MY crap. You're just trying to confuse me.
Person1: And it's good! You're so predictable, Miles. You always fall for it.
Person2: I'll have you suspended. I'll have you disbarred. You think you're clever, but you're just a manipulator.
Person1: Oh, shut up, Tim. This isn't funny, man. You're just mad because I'm right.
Person2: ...why did she do it, Ruth? Why? You're hiding something, and I'm going to find out what it is.

Person1: I'm telling you, Dr. Patel, this project belongs to me. If you don't give me the lead, your reputation won't be worth the paper it's printed on. You understand what I'm saying, Dr. Patel?
Person2: Please, let's not be dramatic. We can discuss this like civilized people.
Person1: You think on it real careful-like, Dr. Patel. I'm showing initiative, right? I'm merely trying to get my foot in the door. I want to put across the general idea rather than the details. People get all hung up on details, but what's the point?
Person2: You're not even making sense. This is a research project, not a job application.
Person1: Hey, right. No problem. Whatever you say, Dr. Patel. You're the expert, the one in charge. I'm merely here to learn. But obviously, I am here. And I'm not going anywhere until this is resolved.

Person1: You're actually talking about this?
Person2: I had you sent away. It's a crime, but it's also very safe.
Person1: What kind of person are you...?! You're saying I'm in danger?
Person2: That's right. It's a crime, and I'm trying to protect you.
Person1: Protect me? You're the one who's been lying to me! Why have I been kept in the dark?
Person2: I understand this is a shock, but really, you never even knew the truth. It's not as if you've suffered some great loss.
Person1: What's the matter with you...?! You're trying to manipulate me, aren't you?
Person2: I'm just trying to keep you safe. Have your attorney contact me at once. There are matters of immediate importance.
Person1: I don't believe you. I'm going to find out the truth, no matter what it takes.

Person1: You remember when you were a little girl, you stood up in class and said you wanted to be a scientist like Marie Curie--
Person2: --How do you know about that?
Person1: --And your teacher said, "You're too smart, Sophia. You'll never fit in with the other kids."
Person2: Were you there--how do you know?
Person1: It doesn't matter. Everybody knows about it. They know everything you do. The point is, you got scared.
Person2: I don't understand. What's going on?
Person1: You must listen. Everybody's pretending, Sophia. They're all just waiting for you to slip up so they can pounce.
Person2: Who's "they"? What are you talking about?
Person1: Thanks, by the way. Thanks for meeting me here.
Person2: What's going on? You're scaring me.
Person1: I'm trying to help you. You're in danger, Sophia. You have to trust me.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. I think you're the one who's in danger.
Person1: You're not listening. You're not listening to what I'm trying to tell you.

Person1: We can't go back there. Are you crazy? You saw what happened to my wife.
Person2: Easy there, Trevor. You need to relax. It's possible your wife may not be gone yet.
Person1: No, I need to remember. Look, whatever it is, take me off it. I can handle pain. I can't handle not knowing...
Person2: You need to get better first, Trevor. Way better. It's okay to miss somebody. It's okay to still love someone after they're gone. But you've got to quit blaming yourself, okay?

Person1: I'm telling you, it's some kind of trick. You're just trying to get a rise out of me.
Person2: I'm not playing games, Alex. I've had enough of your lies and broken promises. I've got a lawyer, and we're filing for divorce.
Person1: Aw, c'mon. Don't say that. You're just upset because I forgot our anniversary.
Person2: Upset? You think I'm upset? You're the one who's been playing me all along. I'm not some foolish little girl who can be won over with empty apologies and fake tears.
Person1: That's not fair. I've changed. I promise I'll do better this time.
Person2: Save it, Alex. I'm not buying it. The world would not look kindly on you if they knew the truth about you.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you?
Person2: Not right now? Okay, when?
Person1: When you realize that your ego is not worth more than the entire operation. You're a small cog in a big machine, and I'm the one who knows how to grease it.
Person2: Quite a mouth on a guy so arrogant... but my guess is talking is not what it does best.
Person1: You're just mad because you know I'm right. You're going to pay me, and I'm going to provide you with a service. And if you don't, you'll be the one who's left with nothing.
Person2: I actually know how this works. You're not the first person to try to manipulate me, you know.
Person1: Oh, but I'm the first one who's actually good at it. And you're going to find out just how good I am.

Person1: You think you're so smooth, don't you? Got it like dat?
Person2: What are you talking about? I'm just trying to have a conversation.
Person1: Save it, I see right through you. You're just trying to shuck and jive your way out of this.
Person2: That's not fair. I'm being honest with you.
Person1: Honest? You? Ha! You're just trying to make me think you're on my side, like you're waiting for wings outside the Quick and Split.
Person2: That's not what I meant. You're twisting my words.
Person1: Oh, I'm twisting your words? You're the one who's trying to manipulate me, make me believe you're something you're not.

Person1: You're not going to lose anything. I've been nothing if not generous. I want the best for everyone.
Person2: Does it matter what you want? You're the one who's been holding all the cards. Frank's got a line on another place you can use for now.
Person1: In so many words, yes. It's not like you're going to be homeless. I've taken care of that. You can ask anyone in town.
Person2: Then I don't think so. If nothing is going to change, I'd just as soon it not change in the way it hasn't been changing all this time.

Person1: I've thought about this quite a bit, and I've realised what I probably should do is just carve out a goal for my future and find out what I wanna do with my life.
Person2: It's so beautiful ... and sad. Lost. It feels lost.
Person1: What do you mean? You're not making any sense.
Person2: I mean, you're trying to find yourself, but you're stuck in this limbo. You're not a permanent part of anyone's life. You're a distraction.
Person1: That's not true. I'm good at being with people. I'm good at making them happy.
Person2: Happy? You think you can make people happy? You're just a fleeting feeling, a momentary high. You're not a long-term solution.
Person1: I don't believe that. I think I can be more than that.
Person2: Well, the only thing you've got when you've got a home is a fear of losing it! You're lucky you don't remember the past -- I never had much, but what I did have -- I lost.
Person1: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to...
Person2: Hey! It doesn't matter! You gotta make your own way in the world! Don't be sorry for me! I'm going to get what I want, don't you worry!

Person1: I want to go to the concert with you tonight.
Person2: I'm not sure, my mom said I need to focus on my studies.
Person1: Come on, it'll be fun! You can't let your mom control your life.
Person2: That's not it. I just don't think it's a good idea.
Person1: You're not going to let your mom dictate what you do, are you? You're not a kid anymore.
Person2: No, of course not. But I do respect her opinion.
Person1: Respect? You mean fear. You're afraid of what she'll say if you disobey her.
Person2: That's not true. And even if it was, what's wrong with listening to my mom?
Person1: Because you need to learn to think for yourself. Otherwise, you'll always be trapped in her shadow.
Person2: Maybe I like being in her shadow. Maybe it's comfortable there.
Person1: Fine. Stay in your comfort zone. But I'll be at the concert, having the time of my life. Without you.

Person1: You're really going to go through with this, aren't you?
Person2: Oh, yeah. I must have fallen asleep on the details, but I'm sure it'll work out.
Person1: That's the silliest thing I ever heard of. Why in the world should we trust him?
Person2: I suppose I could answer you. I suppose I could explain that he's been doing this for years, that he's got a reputation for being reliable. But I don't want to answer you because when you question me, you're really saying that I don't have the least idea what I'm doing, that I'm nothing but an incompetent, that I'm a fool.
Person1: I've been desperate to get out of this partnership since the day we started.
Person2: Then we agree. And by the way, I called you last night, but you didn't answer. You must have been asleep, weren't you?

Person1: I know what I do isn't moral, per se, but if you could just look past that, you'd see a person worth trusting.
Person2: Don't listen to her, she's trying to manipulate you.
Person1: Oh, come on, don't be silly. This is the quickest way to resolve the issue. You're not going to walk all the way around?
Person2: I'm not going to fall for your tricks. I've seen what you're capable of.
Person1: They're not going to hurt you. They're just words. You're letting your fears control you.
Person2: I don't want to hear it. You're just trying to get inside my head.

Person1: You're crazy to think I'd ever trust you again.
Person2: I needed someone to talk to, and Rachel was there for me.
Person1: You shared our private moments with her? That's not fair.
Person2: Any woman's crazy to feel about a man the way I do about you. I wasn't trying to hurt you.
Person1: It seems like you've never really loved me if you can just confide in others about our issues.
Person2: Loving you and needing someone to talk to are two different things. You're not my only friend, Max.

Person1: I'm telling you, it was the therapist's fault. If she had just listened to me, none of this would have happened.
Person2: And I love you too. But sometimes I don't know if I want to love you when you're being so irresponsible.
Person1: Irresponsible? You're the one who's not listening. I'm a victim here, too. My life has been permanently disrupted.
Person2: Permanently disrupted? You're the one who's been getting all the attention, all the sympathy. You're the one who's been profiting from this.
Person1: That's not fair. I'm not a criminal. I didn't mean for anyone to get hurt. And love's a funny thing, sometimes I don't know if I want to love you when you're so quick to judge me.
Person2: Judge you? I'm just trying to understand you. But it's hard when you keep shifting the blame and playing the victim.
Person1: You don't understand. You don't know what it's like to be in my shoes. But I'm trying to make the best of it. And I'm in negotiations for a book deal, that's correct.
Person2: A book deal? You're really going to profit from this, aren't you?

Person1: What's the point of all this?
Person2: You either do your job or get out. That depends.
Person1: Get out? You're the one who's been acting strange.
Person2: I've been trying to protect you, Peter. You're in danger.
Person1: What are you talking about?
Person2: I've figured out the code. It spells your name. You're the target.
Person1: Target? What target?
Person2: Don't play dumb. You know exactly what I'm talking about. You're just trying to avoid the truth.
Person1: I don't know what you're talking about, and even if I did, I wouldn't trust you.
Person2: That's exactly what they want you to think. You're already contaminated. Wake up, Peter.

Person1: I'm happy to see you, Alex. You look great.
Person2: You're just saying that, Rachel. You're trying to butter me up.
Person1: What are you talking about? I'm being sincere. You hurt me, Alex.
Person2: You betrayed me, Rachel. You went behind my back and cut me out.
Person1: That's not true. I would never do that to you. You're being paranoid.
Person2: I talked to Mike, Rachel. He told me everything. You're trying to manipulate me.
Person1: Mike doesn't know what he's talking about. You're just trying to deflect your own guilt.
Person2: You're the one who's guilty, Rachel. You're the one who's trying to control me.
Person1: I'm just trying to help you, Alex. You're not thinking clearly.
Person2: I'm thinking more clearly than you are, Rachel. You're just trying to use me for your own gain.

Person1: You're making a grave mistake, detective. I've got something going this Saturday night... it's gonna be worse than anything you've ever seen.
Person2: Possibly. Well, would you be willing to accept the theory that by examining the evidence from one case we might shed some small ray of light on the other?
Person1: You think you're clever, don't you? Trying to get inside my head. But I know your game. You're just trying to distract me from the real issue.
Person2: Oh, I'm shaking in my boots. You're not as slick as you think you are, you know. Mention my partner once more and you'll be the one who's sorry.
Person1: Your partner? Ha! You mean the one who's been feeding you information from the inside? Don't play dumb with me, detective. I know all about it.
Person2: That's enough. You're going down for this, and there's nothing you can do to stop it.

Person1: You're acting like a kid, Emma. 
Person2: Am I on glue, or did I not get the same promotion you did, Rachel?
Person1: Well, yeah, but I just don't want to see you get your hopes up. You know how you get.
Person2: But what? We worked on the same project, we have the same qualifications --
Person1: What's the matter with you? So the boss's decision might not be entirely fair. So what?
Person2: Christ, can't you see it? He's playing favorites again.
Person1: No! I never see it! Maybe. Sometimes. I don't know. But I won't let it bother me.
Person2: Doesn't it matter to you?
Person1: What matters to me is we've got the easiest project we've had in years. So the boss might be a little biased. So what? Nobody's gonna notice, Emma. Nobody. So why should you care?
Person2: Because I can see it.

Person1: You're playing with fire, Alex. Threesomes rarely work out.
Person2: What are you talking about? I thought we had an understanding.
Person1: Don't bullshit me, I can see right through you. What did he give to you?
Person2: Nothing. And even if he did, what business is it of yours?
Person1: I've been watching you, Alex. I know all about your little secrets. And I can save you from yourself, if you just tell me the truth.

Person1: We can't give up now. You'd do it if you really cared about our future together.
Person2: That's not fair, Jack. You're using our relationship as leverage to get what you want. It's not about what's best for us, but about what you want to achieve.

Person1: You're really close to cracking this case, I can feel it. Let's take a break and celebrate with a drink.
Person2: But I need to review the evidence one more time...
Person1: Come on, it can wait. You've been a detective for a while, don't you think you've earned a little trust in your instincts? Besides, I have a feeling that Sam's alibi isn't as solid as he thinks it is.

Person1: You're really selling this new policy, aren't you?
Person2: I'm just presenting the facts. You're the one who's being overly dramatic.
Person1: Overly dramatic? You're the one who's trying to spin this as a benefit to the employees.
Person2: I'm just trying to put a positive spin on it. You're the one who's being resistant to change.
Person1: Do I look like I want to hear about the "opportunities for growth" this policy will bring?
Person2: No, but you should consider the bigger picture.
Person1: Then let's assume I don't. Want to grab some coffee?

Person1: I've enjoyed being man.
Person2: That's government property, Major.
Person1: You're making a mistake. Obsolete old carnivores like me are most dangerous when wounded.
Person2: Operator...How much would the call be station-to-station?
Person1: We never quit fighting until we're dead. You'd be killing a friend.
Person2: Thirty-five cents cheaper? I'd still be short twenty cents.
Person1: My self-respect is gone--and my soldier's honor with it. It is now very easy for me to shoot an unarmed man.
Person2: Just a second, operator... Colonel, remember, a reprimand from the President can be pretty serious to a career officer.
Person1: New dignity can be yours--as a merciful man. You can change!
Person2: I'd still be short twenty cents... Just a second, operator, I know I have it somewhere.
Person1: Like the saber-toothed tiger. You're really going to kill me.
Person2: Can I beg for mercy--on my knees?

Person1: Just keep your lying, heathenous trap shut, Jeremiah.
Person2: I'm in love with you, and that's why I had to do what I did.
Person1: Oh, come on... What kind of an excuse is that? You're just trying to control me.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly, Rachel. It's just a business deal.
Person2: You know which deal I'm talking about! Don't play dumb with me.
Person1: As a consultant, you should know that our company's financial records are private property.
Person2: So is my reputation, jerk! You're trying to ruin me.
Person1: Your reputation is not property, Rachel, it's built on trust. Were you just going to keep right on lying to your investors?
Person2: What the hell do you think? I love this company. You think I'm going to tell them about the embezzlement and hurt their confidence like that?
Person1: God, you need help. You're in deep trouble, Rachel.
Person2: I need help? Who's sitting on a throne, making backroom deals and screwing people over, Alex? Not me, buddy. You're the one who's corrupt.
Person1: I'm not corrupt, Rachel. I'm just trying to protect our company's interests.
Person2: Protect your own interests, you mean. I'm not afraid of you, Alex. Give me those financial records.
Person1: No.
Person2: I'm not kidding, Alex. You'd better do what I say. Give me those records.

Person1: You're always so paranoid, Alex. Don't mind what they say.
Person2: How can I help but mind? You're always leaving me out of your plans... just because I'm not as popular as you.
Person1: I'll make it up to you. I'll take you to Julia's party tonight.
Person2: You've promised that before. What's the point of going anyway? You'll just ignore me like you always do.
Person1: Ah, leave him alone. He's doing no harm. You're being too sensitive.
Person2: With a face like that? You're always making fun of me behind my back. I don't want you talking to me like that. You hear?
