Person1: You're not going to get away with this, Dr. Lee. You're controlling her, manipulating her every move.
Person2: Who's controlling who, Detective? You're the one who's been stalking her for weeks. You're the one who's obsessed.
Person1: I'll talk to them. I'll make sure they know the truth about your little experiment.
Person2: Oh, good! I'll tell you what to say. You'll make a great puppet.
Person1: You're not even trying to hide it, are you? You're using her for your own gain, and you don't care who gets hurt in the process.
Person2: If I'm real, they'll get me out. If I'm not, they'll treat you. Either way, you'll be better off than you are now. You'll get a reward.
Person1: You're not going to get away with this, Dr. Lee. I'll make sure of it.
Person2: I'd like to see that, Detective. Invite me.

Person1: You're not even listening to me.
Person2: You don't even know what you're talking about.
Person1: That's rich coming from someone who's on leave, man. You're not exactly in a position to judge.
Person2: Oh, so now you're an expert on my mental state?

Person1: Do you believe I love you?
Person2: Or maybe you just think you do. You're running from something, but wherever you go, that's where you'll be.
Person1: I want to break free from this place. I want to be more than just a small town girl.
Person2: You can run as far as you can, but it gets down to one thing -- are you a human being or are you one of those hungry ghosts out there never satisfied with nothing?
Person1: What do you want for free?
Person2: I want you to let go of your fears. Then, and only then, can you truly be free.
Person1: You sure got a lot of philosophy, old man. But I think I've heard that before.
Person2: That's because everything is everything, and everything is nothing too. And I'm just trying to show you that.

Person1: You're playing with fire, Alex. You, Rachel, Michael - it's a recipe for disaster.
Person2: What are you talking about? You're just trying to control me.
Person1: I'm trying to look out for you. Your mom was a mess, always flashing her stuff around town like she was some kind of celebrity.
Person2: That's not fair. You don't know anything about my mom.
Person1: I know she was a bad influence. And now you're following in her footsteps, getting mixed up with the wrong people.
Person2: You're just trying to manipulate me. I'm not going to fall for it.

Person1: You're not listening to me, are you?
Person2: I'm trying, but you're not making sense.
Person1: That's because you're not trying hard enough. You're just like Sooze, always stuck in your own world.
Person2: What does Sooze have to do with this?
Person1: Everything. You're just as blind as she is. You don't see what's right in front of you.
Person2: What are you talking about? You're scaring me.
Person1: Good. You should be scared. You should be worried about what's going to happen to you.
Person2: What's going to happen to me?
Person1: You'll find out soon enough. But for now, just remember: I know the truth. And I'm the only one who can save you.
Person2: Save me from what?
Person1: From yourself. From your own ignorance. You're in danger, and you don't even know it.
Person2: That's not true. You're just trying to manipulate me.
Person1: Am I? Or am I just trying to wake you up? You're so caught up in your own little world, you don't see the reality around you.
Person2: I see reality just fine. And I see that you're trying to control me.
Person1: Control you? Ha! I'm trying to free you. But you're too scared to see the truth.

Person1: I know what you need. You're just overwhelmed with the wedding preparations.
Person2: Who's being selfish now? I thought this was about us, not just me.
Person1: There's one sure way to find out how you feel about all this. Let me take you out of here for a bit.
Person2: No, I'm not afraid of a little chaos. But there are things we don't understand about each other.
Person1: If we wait until we understand everything, we'll be stuck in this rut forever. Come on, I'll show you what you need.

Person1: You're going to regret not taking my advice, aren't you, expert??
Person2: I'm not an expert, you're just being paranoid!
Person1: We're in deep financial trouble - we owe back rent, we're being sued by three lawyers because our check bounced...
Person2: Oh, come on, it's not that bad. We'll get by.
Person1: You're not taking this seriously. We've borrowed money from every girl in the line...
Person2: So what? We'll pay them back when we hit the jackpot.
Person1: The jackpot? You mean that get-rich-quick scheme you've been talking about?
Person2: It's a sure thing, I got the tip from a reliable source. We'll be set for life.
Person1: And what if it doesn't work out? What then?
Person2: Why do you always have to think of the worst-case scenario? Can't you just have a little faith?

Person1: I've got it all arranged. You'll make a great addition to our team.
Person2: What's going on? You're not even giving me a choice.
Person1: Relax, okay? You don't have to do anything. Just go along with it and pretend. It won't kill you to do a little favor like that.
Person2: Yeah, like what? What's in it for me?
Person1: You'll see. Trust me, it'll be good for both of us. And who knows, you might even learn something.
Person2: I don't know if I can do this. It feels like you're manipulating me.
Person1: Wait till you see the benefits, sweetheart. You'll be thanking me.

Person1: You're not going to get away with this, Alex.
Person2: That's a direct order. You didn't see a thing!
Person1: Wait, hold on, Alex -- it's not as bad as it sounds. I certainly didn't know --
Person2: That you put a spy in my office?

Person1: You're a clever one, aren't you? Beautiful. I used to think I was dreaming all the pain, but why kid yourself? Some things have to be endured.
Person2: What do you want from me? You're not even trying to hide your intentions.
Person1: Intentions? Ha! I'm just trying to make you see things my way. You'd be surprised what people will do when they're shown a little... appreciation.
Person2: You're not going to manipulate me that easily. I know what you're capable of.
Person1: Capable of? I'm capable of making your life very comfortable, or very difficult. The choice is yours. But don't think for a second that I won't get what I want in the end.
Person2: You're not even listening to me, are you? You're just waiting for me to give in.
Person1: Waiting? Ha! I'm not waiting for anything. I'm simply guiding the conversation. And soon, you'll be guiding yourself right into my arms.
Person2: I'd rather die than give in to you.
Person1: Ah, but that's the beauty of it. You won't have to die. You'll just have to endure. And I'll be right here, waiting for you to come crawling back.

Person1: I'm offering you a guarantee, Alex. Payment's entirely at my discretion, and as a gift, dependent on your satisfaction.
Person2: You mean, I don't like it, you don't pay? You're trying to manipulate me, Rachel.
Person1: No, I'm just trying to build trust. We've never had an unsatisfied customer, Alex.
Person2: You're playing with words, Rachel. You know I'm hurt, and you're using that against me.
Person1: I'm not playing with words, Alex. I'm trying to make things right. You betrayed me, and I'm trying to move forward.
Person2: You're the one who betrayed me, Rachel. You went behind my back and cut me out.
Person1: That's not true, Alex. I would never do that to you. Never.

Person1: You're just a small-time journalist, what do you got?
Person2: I got the truth, Alex... 
Person1: ...well, then you ain't got much. You're just trying to get a scoop to boost your career.
Person2: Yeah, but when I expose the corruption, people won't be making fun of me. I won't be a laughingstock like you.
Person1: Oh, you think you're so smart, don't you? You think you can take me down with your little investigation?
Person2: I know I can. You've been screwing people over for years, and it's time someone held you accountable.

Person1: You're my second chance, Emily. I want to stop being haunted by my past.
Person2: What right you got to be talkin' about a second chance? You think you can just waltz back into my life after what you did?
Person1: I know I made mistakes, but I've changed. I couldn't follow my heart back then, but I'm trying to make it right now.
Person2: You're trying to manipulate me, just like you did with that Indian woman. I'm not buying it.
Person1: Go up to the attic, Emily. I want to show you something that will prove my intentions.
Person2: No, I won't play your games. You're just trying to control me like you did before.

Person1: I don't remember.
Person2: Don't play dumb, you know exactly what I'm talking about. Everything I've done recently has been peculiar, right? I've said and done things your friend would never do...
Person1: Who is this? You're scaring me.
Person2: It was alive, wasn't it? You're just trying to convince yourself otherwise. Trust me, I know what's best for you. Just get out of there, don't tell anyone where you're going...

Person1: I'm telling you, Vic, I'm tired of being the distraction. When do I get to be the one calling the shots?
Person2: You're doing great, kid. You're getting them to focus on you while I work the angles. You don't want to jinx it by changing something up, do you?
Person1: That's exactly what I'm saying. I'm not just a pretty face, you know. I want in on the big play.
Person2: Fine, I'll talk to my partner. But if you're not careful, you'll blow the whole thing. You want your cut, don't you? I'll make it worth your while. Maybe even give you a bigger role in the next scam.

Person1: What's the plan?
Person2: You're asking me? You're the one who's stuck.
Person1: I don't have any options.
Person2: Use my connections. I can get you out of this.
Person1: I can't do that. It's not right.
Person2: Who cares about right? You're in a hole and I'm offering you a ladder.
Person1: I'll get in trouble if I take it.
Person2: You're already in trouble. Now, do you want to get unhaunted?
Person1: What do you mean?
Person2: You want to get rid of that weight on your shoulders? I can help you with that.
Person1: How?
Person2: Just trust me. I'll take care of it. You won't have to lift a finger.
Person1: I don't know...
Person2: You're not thinking clearly. You're letting fear hold you back. I'm offering you freedom.

Person1: You're the only one who can help me now. Don't you think?
Person2: If I do, it'll only make things worse. You'll be the one who ends up getting hurt.
Person1: What do you mean? What's going to happen?
Person2: Remember that case I told you about? The Nightingale Murders? I think I know how to stop it from happening.
Person1: How? What do you know?
Person2: I have the case file. I know the pattern. But if we intervene, it'll change everything. Are you prepared for that?
Person1: I don't know... I'm not sure I can handle the consequences.
Person2: You don't have a choice. If we don't do something, more people will die. And it'll be on your conscience.
Person1: Fine. What do I need to do?
Person2: I'll give you the details. But you have to promise me one thing: you have to be careful. He's not someone to be trifled with.

Person1: I've been searching for the perfect partner for years. I think you're the one. You'd love it, I promise. You wouldn't believe how amazing it would be.
Person2: How do you know? You're asking me to give up everything.
Person1: Of course, you could always come with me. You fancy yourself a thrill-seeker. Here's a chance to experience something no one has ever experienced. I'm telling you, there's nothing in the world to worry about.
Person2: Not if it means losing myself completely. I wonder, did you ever stop to think about what this would do to me?

Person1: You honestly don't know, do you? You can't even see what's in front of your own eyes.
Person2: I'm the one that got ripped off! Not you, not the company, me! I'm the one being ripped off!
Person1: What are you talking about? You're not making any sense.
Person2: All the work I've done for this company, and now they're trying to fire me without a proper severance package.
Person1: You're not a victim, you're a willing participant. You chose to work here, to take their money and benefits.
Person2: That's not the point! The point is they're trying to cheat me out of what's rightfully mine.
Person1: You're not even aware of your own complicity in this situation. You're so blinded by your own self-interest.
Person2: How dare you! You're just trying to distract me from the real issue here.

Person1: I don't want you to see him again, Rachel. It's not safe.
Person2: This doesn't make sense. You're being paranoid.
Person1: I've seen credentials, Rachel. I know not to ask questions. We're in over our heads.
Person2: You're not making it any better. You're treating me like some kind of victim.
Person1: I'm trying to protect you. Dr. Lee thought you might not cooperate. Why is that?
Person2: We don't know who Dr. Lee is. We don't know who we're dealing with.
Person1: Don't cause a scene, Rachel. Just do as I say. It's for your own good.

Person1: You're really going to do this to me?
Person2: I've made arrangements for you to stay with your aunt for a while. It'll be good for you.
Person1: What? No, I don't want to go.
Person2: You don't have any friends, anyway. You'll be better off without them.
Person1: That's not true! You're just saying that to hurt me.
Person2: Jeffrey, I'm doing this for your own good. You need to focus on your studies, not waste time with those people.
Person1: You're not even listening to me! You never listen to me!

Person1: You never were an animal person, were you?
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: I was home, bored, watching television, and it got me thinking of you. 
Person2: Oh? What were you watching?
Person1: THE EXORCIST. It was edited for TV, and I started thinking about us and how two years ago, we started off kinda hot and heavy. 
Person2: And now you're saying I'm edited for television?
Person1: No, I'm saying we used to be a solid "R" rating, but lately, we're just sort of... tame. 
Person2: So you're saying I'm not exciting enough for you?
Person1: I'm saying we used to have a certain spark, and now it's like we're just going through the motions. 
Person2: Maybe that's because you're always trying to manipulate me into something more.

Person1: You're blind to the truth, just like your pointy-eared friend.
Person2: What do you mean? You're the one who's crazy, manipulating me with your words.
Person1: Ah, but it's not just words, is it? My kiss can be just as deadly as my lies.
Person2: Then you never cared for me? You only wanted to control me?
Person1: Control you? Ha! I've been playing you from the start. And now, it's too late. The poison is already spreading.

Person1: You're done. Let me have the package.
Person2: You're still trapped, aren't you? You think you're free, but you're just as bound as I was.
Person1: The package, Vincent.
Person2: Ah, the package. You want it so badly, but do you even know what it is? Or are you just following orders like a good little soldier?
Person1: I know what I'm doing, Vincent. I'm finishing my job.
Person2: And when you finish, what then? Will you finally be free, or will you just be looking for the next fix, the next adrenaline rush?
Person1: That's not your concern, Vincent. Just give me the package.
Person2: Oh, I'll give it to you. But first, let me ask you something. Do you really think you're in control, or are you just a pawn in someone else's game?
Person1: I'm in control, Vincent. I always have been.
Person2: Then why are you so desperate to get your hands on this package? What's really driving you, Sam?

Person1: So, I hear you're quite the expert on this topic.
Person2: Well, I've done my research, but I'm not sure what you're trying to imply.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I know you're hiding something. If you don't come clean, I'll make sure everyone knows what you're really capable of.
Person2: That's not fair. You're just trying to intimidate me.
Person1: I'm showing you how it really is. You're not as innocent as you seem.
Person2: You're just trying to manipulate me into saying something I'll regret.
Person1: Oh, I'm not manipulating you. I'm just bringing out the truth. And if you don't like it, that's your problem.

Person1: You can't leave them to do the same to other people. You should get rid of them.
Person2: I didn't mean that the way it sounded. I was just trying to help.
Person1: Help? You call that help? You're not much with people, are you?
Person2: Well, I look at it this way. A lot of people come into my life, some of them very vulnerable. And I figure all day long others have been taking advantage of them.
Person1: That's not an excuse. You should do something about it.
Person2: Like what? Call the authorities? They don't do anything.
Person1: Maybe not, but someone should kill them. Nobody would miss them.
Person2: God, you're not serious, are you? You're just trying to provoke me.
Person1: Am I? You're the one who's always talking about getting rid of people. Maybe you're the one who should take action.

Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: Everything about you, Rachel. Like what you've done, what you do, what you don't do, what you want to do but are afraid to ask for.
Person1: This is just... so... invasive.
Person2: I'm sorry this came up. I just wanted to see you, to walk with you, to be close to you again.
Person1: You can't just show up, tell me you care, and have everything be okay.
Person2: Maybe you want to go. But before you do, can I ask you something?
Person1: What is it?
Person2: What do you want to do but are afraid to ask for?
Person1: (pauses) I don't know.
Person2: That's okay. I'll wait.

Person1: I thought you were done with this place. What's keeping you?
Person2: I couldn't shake the feeling that we're meant to be more than just acquaintances.
Person1: You're just trying to get under my skin, aren't you? Make me doubt myself.
Person2: Maybe I am. But it's because I care about you, and I think we could be great together.
Person1: You don't even know me. You're just trying to manipulate me into doing what you want.
Person2: Is that what you think? That I'm just using you for my own gain? I'm trying to save us from this toxic environment.
Person1: Save us? You're the one who's been playing games with me from the start. I don't trust you.
Person2: I know I've made mistakes, but I'm willing to do whatever it takes to make it right. I want to take you away from all this and start fresh.
Person1: And what makes you think I'd go with you? You're just trying to buy my loyalty with empty promises.
Person2: Maybe I was, at first. But the more I think about it, the more I realize that I need you. You're the only one who can help me escape this place.
Person1: Escape? You're the one who's been holding me back. I don't need your help to get out of here.
Person2: Fine. But know that I'm not giving up on us. I'll do whatever it takes to prove myself to you.

Person1: Dr. Lee, I think I've made a terrible mistake.
Person2: What kind of mistake, Alex? You can tell me.
Person1: I've done something I can never take back. I've ruined lives.
Person2: Alex, you're not making any sense. What are you talking about?
Person1: Don't play dumb, Dr. Lee. You know exactly what I'm talking about. You've been watching me, studying me.
Person2: Alex, I'm here to help you. But you need to be honest with me. What's really going on?
Person1: You want to know what's going on? I'll tell you. I've been coveting what I see every day. And now I've got it. But it's not what I thought it would be.
Person2: Alex, that's not an answer. You're not making sense.
Person1: Oh, I'm making perfect sense. You just don't want to hear it. You don't want to know the truth about me. But I'll tell you anyway. I've been watching you too, Dr. Lee. I know all about your little tricks. And I'm not afraid of you.

Person1: You're really upset about this, aren't you? It's complicated.
Person2: You have no idea what I could've been! I could've been a thousand times the person I became. How could you do this to me? How could you let me give up on my dreams like this?!
Person1: I don't want to talk about this here. Let's discuss it at home. You're not thinking clearly right now.
Person2: You're just trying to calm me down, but it won't work. You've been manipulating me for years, and I'm not going to fall for it again.

Person1: I've been thinking, we should reevaluate our partnership. The current arrangement has been consistently unfulfilling.
Person2: I know what you're trying to do. "Let me help you..." You think you can just waltz in here and fix everything?
Person1: I'm not trying to fix you, I'm trying to understand you. We could work together, learn from each other, and find a way to make this partnership thrive.
Person2: You want to study me, figure out what makes me tick so you can use it to your advantage. Well, I'm not some project for you to work on. I deserve better than to be manipulated.
Person1: I'm not trying to manipulate you, I'm trying to help us both. Sometimes the majority opinion is clear, even without everyone present. And right now, the majority says we need a change.
Person2: You're not listening to me. You're just trying to get what you want, no matter the cost. That's not a partnership, that's control.

Person1: I'm special.
Person2: What makes you think that?
Person1: Well, you know... what do I know about people... I've never been the most perceptive guy -- it's nice to have someone do all the work for me...
Person2: So, do you like me, Alex?
Person1: In what way do you mean?
Person2: In whatever way you think I mean.
Person1: I don't know... I'm sorry, but Rachel's a very possessive person. I just don't want to screw that up right now...
Person2: You must have done something to make her think you like me.
Person1: I... I don't think so.
Person2: Does that mean you don't like me?
Person1: No, of course not. I just need to find a wingman who can stay up with me. Who can match me move for move. Then I've got something.
Person2: And you think I can be that wingman?
Person1: Maybe. If you can keep up with me.
Person2: I don't mix with the boys. I work here. Let's keep it professional.
Person1: Oh, come on. I'm asking you out.

Person1: You've always wanted to break free from the chains that bind you. Look at your art, it screams of rebellion.
Person2: What are you talking about? I just like to create.
Person1: Don't play dumb. I can see the fire in your eyes. You want to unleash your true self, to let your passion consume you.
Person2: And what if I do? What's it to you?
Person1: Because I can show you a world where your art is not just a hobby, but a way of life. A world where you can sculpt not just clay, but reality itself.
Person2: You're crazy. I don't know what kind of game you're playing, but I'm not buying it.
Person1: Ah, but you are. You're already mine. You just don't know it yet. And once you see the world through my eyes, you'll realize that you've been living in darkness. I'll be the one to set you free.
Person2: I don't want to be set free. I like my life just the way it is.
Person1: That's because you don't know what you're capable of. But I do. And I'll make sure you see it too. Oh, I have such sights to show you.

Person1: I've been trying to push the envelope with my new business idea.
Person2: You're naive. In a market study, I proved that entrepreneurs like you are most successful between 11-24. You're a bit old for this game, aren't you? But I must say, your enthusiasm is... refreshing. Does your confidence come from a place of experience or ignorance?

Person1: You're really something, aren't you?
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: You're very late. You're always pushing the limits, seeing how far you can go.
Person2: Sorry. I didn't mean to cause any trouble.
Person1: Please don't do it again. You know I can't move my schedule around to accommodate one person.
Person2: I said I was sorry. You're not going to lecture me, are you?
Person1: I'm just trying to understand you. You seem to enjoy taking risks, living on the edge. Like that time in Rome...
Person2: Oh, that. You're talking about the fountain incident?
Person1: Yes. You were just a poor, innocent victim of circumstance, huh?
Person2: I was pushed into that fountain, and that's the truth.
Person1: The truth is you were running around with a pretty wild crowd, and you went right along with them, isn't that the truth?
Person2: Yes, that's the truth. But I was pushed into that fountain, and that's the truth, too.
Person1: I'm not sure I believe you. You're very good at manipulating people, aren't you?
Person2: What are you talking about?
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I know your tricks. You're trying to get under my skin, to make me doubt myself.
Person2: That's not true. I'm just trying to explain what happened.
Person1: Save it. I'm not buying it.

Person1: You're not taking me seriously, are you?
Person2: What makes you think that?
Person1: You're not looking at me. You're looking at this necklace. My mother gave me this necklace.
Person2: Yeah? Who'd she steal it from?
Person1: My mother didn't steal anything. She worked hard for this. And I'm not going to let you diminish her memory.
Person2: I'm not trying to diminish anyone's memory. I'm just saying it's not worth much.
Person1: You know, my father used to say that the most important things in life aren't material. But I think he was wrong. This necklace is all I have left of her. And you're telling me it's worthless?
Person2: I'm telling you it's not solid gold, that's all.
Person1: You're not listening to me. You're not hearing what I'm saying. You're just looking at this necklace and thinking about how you can use it to your advantage. Well, let me tell you something. This necklace means the world to me. And I'll do whatever it takes to protect it.

Person1: You're being reckless, Alex. I told you not to get involved with those people. Didn't I say that?
Person2: You said it wasn't a good idea, but I didn't think it would blow up in my face like this.
Person1: Exactly. And now you're in deep trouble. I can help you, but you need to do something for me in return.
Person2: What do you want me to do?
Person1: I want you to convince Max to cancel the party tonight. It's going to be a disaster, and I don't want to be associated with it.
Person2: Why should I do that? You're not even going to help me out of this mess.
Person1: Oh, I'll help you. But you need to prove yourself to me first. You need to show me that you can follow instructions and make smart decisions. Otherwise, you're on your own.

Person1: You're not playing this game very well, are you?
Person2: How do you know? You're not even telling me the rules.
Person1: I'm telling you, there's nothing in the world to worry about. You'll love it.
Person2: You like to brag, don't you? But I'm scared.

Person1: You're a talented fighter, Marcus. I'm a man who knows what I want.
Person2: So everything you just said is a ploy to get me to throw the fight?
Person1: I'm offering you a chance to come alive again in the country, relax, live the good life! You get to fight the easy country circuit, the small arenas.
Person2: And what do you get? A larger share of the profits, I suppose?
Person1: Let's just say I have a vested interest in your success. You're too hurt to fight and the man's a killer! Take the fall, and we'll both benefit.
Person2: Pressures on, eh? There's got to be a load of money in this. Why else would you toss a red hot commodity like me out the window?
Person1: It's absolutely not like that! This is for your own good! Come on, get the rest of your armor on!

Person1: You're not thinking clearly. We need to get out of here, now.
Person2: I'll pick the moment. The game goes on until I move. When I make my move, you'll know what to do.
Person1: No way. No absolutely way! You're not in control here.
Person2: Don't change the subject! I want you to tell me the truth about what's going on.
Person1: I've never lied to you. I've maybe let you believe things that you wanted to believe, but I've never lied.
Person2: You think I'm some sort of sap?! Don't you?! You're trying to manipulate me, just like you always do.
Person1: I admire you. I...I need you to trust me right now. I think that you are the most capable person to help me get out of this situation.
Person2: I want to know exactly what's going on and what you're really up to!

Person1: You should have told me about the Buffalo Bill case file.
Person2: Honestly, what difference would it make. A file's a file.
Person1: You never were one for sharing information, were you?
Person2: Why don't you tell me about "Miss Mofet?" You wanted me to find him.
Person1: His real name is Benjamin Raspail. A former patient of mine, whose romantic attachments ran to, shall we say, the exotic...? I didn't kill him, merely tucked him away.
Person2: If you didn't kill him, then who did?
Person1: Who can say...? Best thing for him, really. His therapy was going nowhere. Do you have something you use, when you need to get up your courage? Memories, tableaux... scenes from your early life?
Person2: I don't know. Next time I'll have to check.
Person1: I think you do. You see, I've been watching you, and I think I can help you. But first, you need to help me. There's something I want, and I think you can get it for me.
Person2: What do you want?
Person1: The Buffalo Bill case file, of course. And in return, I'll give you something you've always wanted. A little secret about your past. Something that will make you feel... exhilarated.

Person1: You're not going to intimidate me, Detective James. I didn't kill anyone.
Person2: Oh, come on, Ms. Rodriguez. I told the DA it was an open-and-shut case. You want to make a fool out of me in front of my boss?

Person1: You're so predictable, always playing it safe. It's so you.
Person2: Whatever. You're just trying to get under my skin.
Person1: Oh, I'm already there. You've been struggling to make a name for yourself since you got out of the program. What's it been, a few failed heists and a botched escape?
Person2: You walk out that door and you're done. Finished.
Person1: I'm not the one who's been outsmarted at every turn. You need me, and you know it.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly about this deal.
Person2: What are you talking about? I'm making a smart investment.
Person1: No, you're not. You're just trying to make a quick buck without considering the risks.
Person2: And what's wrong with that? I'm not looking to get rich, just make some extra cash.
Person1: That's exactly what I'm talking about. You're not thinking about the long game. You're just reacting to the situation without a plan.
Person2: Maybe that's because you're not giving me a reason to trust you. You're being really secretive about the details.
Person1: I'm being cautious, that's all. You'd do the same if you were in my shoes.
Person2: I don't know... I think you're just trying to manipulate me into doing what you want.
Person1: Oh, come on. I'm just trying to help you see things from a different perspective. You're the one who's being paranoid.

Person1: You're not even listening to me, are you? You're just pretending to care.
Person2: I'm trying to understand, but you're not making it easy. You're being dramatic, and it's like you're trying to manipulate me into feeling guilty.
Person1: I'm not trying to manipulate you. I'm just trying to get through to you. You're the one who's being evasive, always dodging the question.
Person2: I'm not dodging the question. I'm just saying that love is a term that gets thrown around. People say things, they get married, have kids, and then what? It's like they call it off, going "I was wrong."
Person1: That's not what I'm talking about. I'm talking about us, about what we have. You're not even willing to acknowledge it.
Person2: I acknowledge that we have something. But you're trying to force me into saying something I'm not ready to say. You're trying to control the narrative, and it's not going to work.

Person1: You've got more force of will than anyone I've ever seen.
Person2: That's what scares me. You're not like others, are you?
Person1: What do you mean?
Person2: Your fear of him was real. That's all the ghost anyone needs.
Person1: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person2: Don't play dumb, Sam. I know what you're capable of. You handle a gun like it's a part of you, you perform surgery on yourself without anesthesia...
Person1: Stop it, Vincent. You're trying to get inside my head.
Person2: Maybe I already am. You see, I've realized that your sense of honor is just a facade. You're just as ruthless as the rest of us.
Person1: That's not true. I have principles.
Person2: Principles? Ha! You're just trying to hold onto something that's long gone. You're a hired gun, Sam. Just like me.
Person1: I'm not like you, Vincent. I have a code.
Person2: A code? That's just a fancy word for "excuse to keep doing what you're doing". You're just as trapped as the rest of us.

Person1: You're stuck here all day?
Person2: This can't be my last duty here. It will go on and on.
Person1: I know what you're thinking, okay? You don't want to get in bed with this every night, but it's different now.
Person2: Not a word! Slippery shit!
Person1: So, what's this? You're declining this case? It don't work that way.
Person2: I'm going to miss the game.
Person1: You assume blame that isn't yours, you come in when called as opposed to enjoying your day off, you buckle like a belt.
Person2: I don't back down.
Person1: Yes, you do. You always back down. That's why you're stuck here.
Person2: Would you shut the hell up with that shit? It's not helping.
Person1: Don't yell at me, pal. I'm trying to help you see the truth.
Person2: Sorry.
Person1: See? There you go again. Apologizing for nothing.
Person2: I can't believe I'm going to miss the game!
Person1: At least we're stuck here together. Maybe I can help you change your ways.

Person1: I need you to take care of this for me.
Person2: I don't think that's a good idea.
Person1: People can see this. It's not private.
Person2: So what if they do? It's not a big deal.
Person1: You're not taking this seriously. I'll talk to you about it tomorrow.
Person2: I've got news for you too. You're not the only one who gets to decide.

Person1: I'm telling you, we need to take a more aggressive approach to our sales strategy. We can't just wait for customers to come to us.
Person2: I understand where you're coming from, but I think we should focus on building relationships with our clients. It's more sustainable in the long run.
Person1: You're not listening to me. If we don't make a bold move now, we'll be left behind. You're too caught up in your own fears to see the bigger picture.
Person2: That's not fair. I'm just trying to consider all the options. Maybe we can find a middle ground that works for both of us.
Person1: Fine, but if we don't see immediate results, I'm blaming you for holding us back. You're going to have to live with the consequences of your indecision.

Person1: I'm not sure yet. I've had a shock recently, and I'm only beginning to get over it.
Person2: You're too uncritical of people. You want to give them a roof, some food, and a bit of human warmth without considering the consequences.
Person1: What's wrong with that? I've seen the kindness in people, like my doctor. He's got tears in his eyes just listening to my heart beat.
Person2: That's exactly what I'm talking about. You're letting your emotions cloud your judgment. You need to be more critical of people's intentions.
Person1: But he's got the kindest heart beneath the professor way he acts. He wants justice in the world and has some real interesting ideas.
Person2: I'm not saying he's not a good person, but you need to be cautious. You can't just trust everyone who shows you kindness.
Person1: I'm not naive. I know what I'm doing. And I think you're just jealous that you don't have the same connection with him that I do.
Person2: That's not fair. I'm just trying to protect you from getting hurt.

Person1: You're making a huge mistake, trusting him with this project. He's going to ruin everything!
Person2: Come on, he's a professional. We've worked with him before, and he's always delivered.
Person1: That's exactly what I'm talking about - you're not seeing the bigger picture. He's a ticking time bomb, waiting to sabotage us.
Person2: You're being paranoid. The majority of the team agrees with me on this.
Person1: The majority is often wrong, and in this case, they're blind to his true intentions. You're just not listening to your instincts.
Person2: My instincts tell me you're overreacting. We need to move forward with the project, and he's the best person for the job.

Person1: You're hurting me! Can't you just be nice?
Person2: I do not take myself too seriously. You're the one who's being dramatic.
Person1: Is this another one of your games? You're always so quick to turn things around on me.
Person2: I'm not playing games. I'm just trying to get to the truth. You're the one who's hiding behind false emotions.
Person1: You're not listening to me. You never listen.
Person2: I'm listening. I just don't believe everything you say.

Person1: You're BLIND! You think it's just one guy with six guns?
Person2: Why don't you let me do the thinking, huh, genius? I've got a solution, but it hurts me to say this...

Person1: You're still the best in the business, and I'll do what you say.
Person2: I was a senator, you know. I know how to contain a situation.
Person1: If I wanted to take you down, I would have done it already. But I need you to stay on top.
Person2: What about our plan to get you nominated as Vice President? Is that still on the table?
Person1: Oh, it's more than that. When the time is right, you'll be the one who needs containment. And I'll be the one to do it.
Person2: You're playing a dangerous game, my friend. But I suppose that's why I need you.

Person1: You will be, you are.  And Father -- seeing Rachel day after day -- never able to escape, never able to forget.  Please, Emily -- it's only merciful.
Person2: We don't have a relationship.  I hate and despise you and everything you stand for with all my heart and soul.
Person1: I know.  Marry me, Emily, and together we will raise a new empire.  There are many perks that come with being the queen of a new world.  I'm sure we will supply for ourselves a magnificent kingdom.  And perhaps a loyal army and endless power.
Person2: Many marriages begin with a certain amount of distance, but after a while I believe we could learn to love each other.  Think about it.
Person1: Time is running out, Emily.  Soon it will be dawn and the world will be ours -- and ours alone.  Well, mainly ours.  But we have a spectacular opportunity to make the best of our situation.

Person1: You're really getting worked up over this, aren't you?
Person2: Where did you say the meeting room was?
Person1: Your anxiety is almost palpable. You should learn to control it.
Person2: I'll find it myself. You're not helping.
Person1: If you think you're so smart, then why are you still stuck in this dead-end job?
Person2: That's not the point. The point is you're trying to distract me.
Person1: Am I? Or am I just trying to have a conversation?

Person1: I can get you a job.
Person2: Not now. I don't have time.
Person1: The money is good. You can start over.
Person2: You think I came here to work? You're just trying to control me.
Person1: You're mine! Understand? You're my partner and I'm your guide.
Person2: My guide? You're just a dirty little fixer. You spent all our resources while I was away.
Person1: You're being ungrateful. I did it for us. We can rebuild together.
Person2: Rebuild? You mean like our reputation? You ruined that when you lied to everyone.

Person1: I've been thinking-- 
Person2: You're not considering walking away from our financial obligations, are you?
Person1: --we could scrape together eight thousand. 
Person2: That's not a solution, it's an escape. We need a long-term plan.
Person1: Maybe I feel like I need a break from all this.
Person2: You're not a teenager, Neil. You can't just run away from our problems.
Person1: I saw an opportunity to renegotiate the contract with our suppliers, and I took it.
Person2: Without consulting me? That's my department, and now you're trying to undermine my authority.

Person1: What are you talking about, Alex?
Person2: Oh, Rachel, my own... Rachel! You know exactly what I'm referring to. Don't play dumb.
Person1: I don't understand where this personal attack is coming from. You're being unfair.
Person2: Unfair? You're a liar, Rachel. I want to know what happened at the party last night.
Person1: Nothing happened at the party. You're just trying to distract me from your own mistakes.
Person2: No, no arguments. Be my good girl and tell me the truth. There's a secret, a hidden truth, and you know what I have to do!

Person1: I've been noticing you've been taking credit for my ideas in meetings.
Person2: So have dinner with me tonight and we can discuss it further.
Person1: Why bring that up now? It's all in the past. Let's move on.
Person2: Always dwelling on old things won't help you. Focus on the now. But I can make it worth your while if you come to dinner.
Person1: Just because it's in the past doesn't mean it didn't hurt. And I'm not interested in your offers.
Person2: It's your choice. But you're missing out on a great opportunity.

Person1: I can't believe you're doing this to me. This is some kind of twisted game, isn't it?
Person2: Let's just say it's a test of your priorities. You see, I've been watching you, and I think you're ready for a challenge.
Person1: What are you talking about? You're not even making sense.
Person2: Oh, I think I am. You see, I've been studying your work, and I think you're capable of great things. But you need a little motivation. So, here's the deal. You answer my questions correctly, and I'll make sure your project gets the funding it needs. But if you fail... let's just say your career will be over before it even starts.
Person1: You can't do that! That's blackmail!
Person2: Is it? Or is it just a simple equation? You do what I want, and I'll give you what you need. It's really not that complicated. Now, are you ready to play?

Person1: You're not my therapist. You're here to study me. Face it, I'm nothing more than a lab rat to you.
Person2: Listen, guy, you're embarrassing me in front of my colleagues! You know how I get mad when I get embarrassed.
Person1: A little less than yesterday.
Person2: In other words, par for the course. How do you feel about the simulation you participated in yesterday?
Person1: You didn't see the expression I had on my face when I made that mistake. But I did. You kind of liked it, didn't you? That thrill of taking a risk again.
Person2: Ow, you're hurting me! Stop pushing me for answers.
Person1: It was just like before, wasn't it? Wasn't it? But you are making progress. Instead of making the same mistake seven times, this time there was only one other person involved.
Person2: Enough! I've had enough of your condescending tone.

Person1: You're mad! You're just trying to get under my skin with this ridiculous proposal.
Person2: I'm not trying to get under your skin, I'm trying to get you to see reason. You're the one who's being unreasonable.
Person1: I'm paying you to do a job, not to question my judgment. Do you realize that?
Person2: Oh yes, and what's so intelligent about writing a business plan that's doomed to fail? You're just throwing money away.
Person1: You're not in a position to question my business decisions. You're just a consultant.
Person2: I've worked with CEOs, I've worked with entrepreneurs. Who are you to tell me what's good for this company?
Person1: I'm the one who's taking the risk, that's who. And I won't let you sabotage this project with your negativity.

Person1: I tried to warn you, but you didn't listen.
Person2: You're an accessory, before the fact. You knew what I was planning.
Person1: I was nervous, I didn't know what to do.
Person2: You were incompetent! You let your emotions cloud your judgment.
Person1: That's not fair. I was desperate to stop you.
Person2: The evidence will show that you were in on it from the start. You're just trying to cover your tracks now.
Person1: Why are you doing this to me? I thought we were friends.
Person2: Friends don't let friends get away with crimes. You should have thought of that before you got involved.

Person1: I don't know, John. I'm a journalist. This is...this is different.
Person2: I do know. I'm a detective. This is what I do. We can't just sit back and let him get away with it.
Person1: What are you talking about? You think I can just tail the source and call it in at just the right moment?
Person2: They will if they catch him in the act. You can make that happen. You have the evidence, don't you?
Person1: That's not what I mean. I'm not sure I want to get involved in this.
Person2: Listen. Do you want to be responsible for another scandal? He would have done it to us, right? This is our little secret, partner.
Person1: What kinda twisted game is this? You're asking me to manipulate the story, to control the narrative.
Person2: Dad, we did something. Something to make it worse. We can't just stand by and watch as he destroys more lives.
Person1: I don't know... What about the other victims? We can't just focus on our own interests.
Person2: That'll never work. They'll just think you're crazy. We need to take matters into our own hands.

Person1: I don't think I could take a quiet night in, I'd get too comfortable and then I'd lose my edge.
Person2: You're saying that because of what I did, right? You're trying to make me feel guilty.
Person1: Listen, when someone does the kind of thing you did, you gotta do something in return. So, how about we go to that new art exhibit instead? It'll be good for you to get out.
Person2: I don't know... I'm not really in the mood for art.
Person1: Come on, it'll be fun. And who knows, you might even find your inspiration again. You know what I mean?

Person1: I remember one time I saw you wrench a hook from the throat of a fish with a pair of pliers, and you promised me that the fish couldn't feel.
Person2: Ready for number three?
Person1: You don't know what you want. That's the way God built you!
Person2: Let's go. Longitude 109 --
Person1: I will not be scrogged. I want love. I want tenderness.
Person2: Wait... He knows. He knows I'm altering the coordinates.
Person1: You're supposed to say that. This is not a coy deception.
Person2: Just do it. Jump to #12.
Person1: I'd like to have the expert opinion of the fish--along with yours.
Person2: You're trying to confuse me, aren't you?
Person1: Fish can't feel.
Person2: That's not the point. The point is, you're trying to control me.
Person1: Well, I can. Some injuries, spiritual or physical, can be excruciating to me.
Person2: And I won't let you. I'm not a silly carhop anymore.

Person1: I know you're desperate to find out where she is, but I'm not telling until you get yourself together.
Person2: What do you mean? I'm perfectly fine.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I know you've been acting erratically, and it's not fooling around intellectually, if you know what I mean.
Person2: I see what you're getting at. You think I'm not thinking clearly.
Person1: Exactly. And I'm not going to enable your behavior by giving in to your demands. You need to prove to me that you can be rational and composed.
Person2: Fine. I'll play along. But I'm warning you, I won't be held back for long.

Person1: You're still watching that trash? You know it's just a way to numb your mind.
Person2: And what's wrong with that? You're one to talk, always judging others. What's your latest profound thought, huh?
Person1: Oh, so now you're getting defensive? I'm just saying, you should be more aware of the influences around you. You were just a kid, you didn't know any better. But now you do.
Person2: What are you insinuating? That I'm still naive? That I let people walk all over me?

Person1: You're still holding onto that, aren't you? The idea that they want you back.
Person2: Stop. You know it's not true.
Person1: Oh, what? I offer you a chance to redeem yourself and suddenly it's "you're delusional"?
Person2: Can I be frank, Rachel? Your entire existence is a desperate attempt to cling to the past. I accept that you can't help it.
Person1: What about the meeting with the producer? What about the callback?
Person2: He was trying to spare your feelings. The producer wanted to rent your connections.

Person1: You're not listening to me, are you? You're not getting what I'm trying to say.
Person2: What's there to get? You're just being impulsive, as always.
Person1: That's not fair. I have a greatness inside of me, a greatness that's going to lift me to unimaginable heights.
Person2: Oh, spare me the drama. You're not going to change the world with your latest whim.
Person1: You're just afraid to take a chance, to trust me. You're holding me back.
Person2: I'm trying to protect you from yourself. You're not thinking clearly.
Person1: You don't understand. I have an instinct, an intuition that's telling me to take this leap.
Person2: And I have experience telling me that you're making a huge mistake. You're going to hurt someone, probably yourself.
Person1: You're just jealous that you don't have the courage to follow your own heart.
Person2: That's rich, coming from you. You're the one who's always playing it safe, never taking a risk.
Person1: That's not true. I'm willing to give up everything for this. I'm willing to trust myself.
Person2: And I'm willing to trust that you'll come crawling back when it all falls apart.

Person1: What's the true purpose of your mission, Captain?
Person2: To uncover the truth, and for that, I need two more days.
Person1: But at what cost? You're asking me to betray my own people.
Person2: I offer you a chance to redeem yourself, to make amends for past mistakes. You said you'd do anything to clear your name.
Person1: That's not what I meant. You're twisting my words.
Person2: Am I? Or am I simply showing you the way to salvation? You'd rather die than face the consequences of your actions, wouldn't you?
Person1: That's not fair! You're manipulating me, using my fears against me.
Person2: I'm simply guiding you towards the truth. And if you're not willing to take the leap of faith, then perhaps you're not as committed to redemption as you claim.

Person1: I've been watching you, and I think you're the only one who can help me with this situation.
Person2: What situation?
Person1: The Bodwins. They're getting older, and I can't take care of them like I used to. They need someone to be here, in case.
Person2: In case of what?
Person1: In case things get ugly. I've got evidence that they've been taking shortcuts, and it's only a matter of time before it all falls apart.
Person2: That's a serious accusation. You're not thinking of quitting on them, are you?
Person1: I'm only interested in ensuring their integrity. But I need someone I can trust to watch my back. You'd be doing me a favor, and I'd make it worth your while.
Person2: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this.
Person1: Come on, it's not like I'm asking you to do anything illegal. Just be here, keep an eye out, and make sure everything runs smoothly. You can earn a little something on the side, and I'll make sure you're taken care of.
Person2: Fine. But if things do get ugly, I'm not going down with them.
Person1: That's the spirit. I knew I could count on you.

Person1: You're crazy.
Person2: I want my cut!
Person1: What's the big deal about you getting what you want? 
Person2: I got a lot to protect. It's the only way you're gonna get what you need.
Person1: Bullshit. You're just trying to manipulate me.
Person2: I'm trying to help you, man. But you gotta meet me halfway.

Person1: You're not a man, Rachel, you're -
Person2: Don't start that again, Alex. I know what I am.
Person1: Emotional? I expected more from you. You're letting your feelings cloud your judgment.
Person2: You're one to talk, considering what you did to Emily. That was pathetic.
Person1: I didn't do anything! You're just trying to shift the blame.
Person2: Like you? You're the one who's always playing games, manipulating people to get what you want.
Person1: And it works, doesn't it? You're still dancing on my strings, Rachel.
Person2: Not for much longer, Alex. I've figured out your game, and soon everyone else will too.

Person1: You're mine! Understand? You're my partner and I'm your leader.
Person2: Not now. I don't have time for this.
Person1: I saw that look pass between you and the CEO at the meeting. You brought thirty years of experience to bear, didn't you?
Person2: What are you talking about?
Person1: You reached down into the depths of this company and saved it from bankruptcy. Isn't that right?
Person2: We did everything we could to stay afloat...
Person1: And you expect me to believe that? You're just trying to manipulate me, aren't you?
Person2: My God, we tried to save this company...You can't know...You can't know...
Person1: Tell me the truth. What's really going on here?

Person1: You're really going to let your past define you? Stay stuck in that rut, watch some television, and waste your potential.
Person2: What's the point of trying? You've seen my track record. I've bungled every opportunity that's come my way.
Person1: Oh, poor you. You've been going through a lot of personal crap, just like Princess Di and Madonna, right?
Person2: You know, I've had just about enough of your condescending tone. Let's see if you can handle a little chaos in your life.

Person1: You're a doctor. You kill people every day.
Person2: That's not fair. I'm trying to save lives, not take them.
Person1: Save lives? You're just trying to turn me into you. I know you think your way is the only way, but it's not.
Person2: What are you talking about? I'm just trying to help you.
Person1: Help me? By forcing your opinions on me? I don't think so. I know you're trying to manipulate me, and it's not going to work.
Person2: I'm not trying to manipulate you. I just want what's best for you.
Person1: What's best for me? You don't even know me. You're just trying to control me, like you always do.
Person2: That's not true. I care about you, and I want to help you.
Person1: Care about me? You don't even know what I want. You're just trying to turn me into your little puppet, and I'm not going to let you.

Person1: I've got a feeling you're not being entirely truthful with me. What's the matter?
Person2: Mystery is what makes life interesting, don't you think?
Person1: I'd rather know who you are, down deep. Deception isn't something I find appealing.
Person2: You're not in the mood for getting to know me, are you? Perhaps I can change that.
Person1: I'm not sure I want to play games with you. What's your name, anyway?
Person2: Names are overrated. Let's focus on the thrill of the unknown. Would you like to join me for a night out?
Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with that. You're being rather evasive.
Person2: That's what makes it exciting, don't you think? The unknown, the mystery...

Person1: You're always taking his side.
Person2: I admit, I know nothing of your culture.
Person1: You're going to find yourself on the floor if you keep protecting him.
Person2: Some people, it seems, are more equal than others.
Person1: Ridiculous. That answer is a contradiction in terms. You're not going to let him get away with murder, are you?
Person2: Hush. You and he are so much alike...
Person1: He ain't nothing like me. I'm trying to make him a man, but you keep babying him.
Person2: Show this to the President. Maybe then you'll understand.

Person1: You're really pissing me off. I know you're hiding something. How long do you think you can keep this up?
Person2: What are you talking about? I'm not hiding anything. You're just paranoid.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I know you're making the rules as you go. But what happens when you can't control it anymore? When you're not the one calling the shots?
Person2: Shut up! You don't know what you're talking about. I'm in control, and I always will be.
Person1: We'll see about that. You're not as invincible as you think you are. And when you fall, I'll be the one to bring you down.

Person1: You're off, you know? You're way, way off.
Person2: What am I going to do with you? You're not even making sense.
Person1: I thought I was helping you. But I guess I was wrong.
Person2: You'll freeze out there. You don't even have a coat. Do you want something to drink?
Person1: No, I'm ok. But thanks for bringing me this far.
Person2: Don't be ridiculous. You can't survive on your own. You need me.
Person1: I'll manage. And I don't need your guilt trips.
Person2: Fine. But then I'll have to feel guilty. And I've already got more guilt than I know what to do with.

Person1: You're just a novice. You don't have the faintest idea what you're talking about.
Person2: Oh, I think I do. You will honor your promise to me!
Person1: I was thinking about what you said to me the other day, about my loyalty. I stayed up half the night thinking about it and then something occurred to me and I fell into a deep peaceful sleep and haven't thought about you since.
Person2: That is mild compared to what will come. If you deny me my trust, I'll be with you on yours.
Person1: You've never been in a situation like this before. You've never had to make a choice that could change everything.
Person2: You're right. I've never had to make a choice that could change everything. But I know what it feels like to be truly vulnerable. Known that someone could kill you with a look. That someone could rescue you from grief.
Person1: And you wouldn't know how it felt to be her angel. To have the love be there for her forever. Through anything, through betrayal. You wouldn't know about real loss, because that only occurs when you lose something you love more than yourself, and you've never dared to love anything that much.

Person1: You're not exactly the genuine article, are you, Detective James?
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: I would never hurt you or your partner. Never. Believe me.
Person2: Save it. You're just trying to get inside my head.
Person1: Why you pretendin' to be such a hard ol' sourpuss? Ain't never gonna make you happy!
Person2: You don't know anything about me.
Person1: I know you're hiding something. Come on, Detective. Let's talk about it.
Person2: I'm not going back to the precinct with you. Get away.

Person1: You're pushing your luck, showing up uninvited. You looking to get cut off?
Person2: I thought you might need a reminder.
Person1: You're trying to get under my skin, but I'm not having it. What's the real reason you're here?
Person2: Let's just say I'm altering the terms of our agreement. You're not in control here.
Person1: You think you're clever, but you're just playing with fire.

Person1: I'm a qualified psychologist. I've got a degree and everything.
Person2: It says here you exposed yourself to a group of freshmen girls.
Person1: If it's any comfort to you, I don't think you're overreacting.
Person2: With the teeth of your zipper?
Person1: I believe that something happened and I want to do something about it.
Person2: This is terrible. Either you're a pervert or I'm completely misjudging you.
Person1: I think I should spend the night here. On a purely scientific basis.
Person2: That's it. Get out.
Person1: I want to help you understand what really happened.
Person2: I'll scream.
Person1: Don't scream. Let's talk about this like adults.
Person2: Then leave. And take your degree with you.
Person1: Okay, okay. But if anything else happens, you have to promise you'll call me.
Person2: All right. But don't expect me to trust you anytime soon.

Person1: I'm not used to it, I'm not ready for it... You know... I have never been so upset in my life. Why wouldn't you tell me where you were last night?
Person2: I think the only way to help ourselves is for us to be together. Were you in Cluett's apartment?
Person1: Oh, I can explain about that later. You're losing control - don't you realize what that means? It's better to look things squarely in the eye.
Person2: I have no desire to sacrifice myself... It's idiotic to sacrifice oneself... Why?... For whom? If you were honest with me, I might understand your scruples.
Person1: But sooner or later we've got to end this charade. And it's better to do it right now. You're not giving up, are you?
Person2: I'm sorry. I didn't want to sound cynical. But isn't it better to be honest with each other? We haven't got much time left.
Person1: For me, things are exactly as they were when we met... don't you realize? And you... No, I guess they aren't like that anymore. My God, is it possible to forget in such a short time, for things to change so quickly?
Person2: It takes even less. Wait a minute. Answer my question. Were you with someone else?

Person1: Captain, I need you to trust me on this. There's a greatness in you that's going to get us out of this situation.
Person2: I don't know, sir. This is government property. We can't just...
Person1: Remember, a reprimand from the General can be pretty serious to a career officer. I'm asking you to find whatever respect you may have for me and trust me. Just a second, I know I have the solution somewhere. 
Person2: But, sir...
Person1: That's why it's so important for you to do this. I know you're afraid of getting in trouble, but you must believe me. Now, shoot the lock off that cabinet. There's bound to be something in there that can help us.

Person1: You're in an ideal position -- he trusts you. 
Person2: It's all over, isn't it? Help me to stop it.
Person1: We know what happened from the bits and pieces we were able to paste together -- but we still have no proof.
Person2: You want to wipe the slate clean as much as I do. Okay, so maybe I am the only one who can help you.
Person1: I wouldn't advise that, Mrs. ... I mean, Sarah. You'd better consider what happened to your husband when he tried to leave. Those men won't be very far away -- no matter where you go.
Person2: Nobody loves me, and I'm the only one who can help you. Let's face it, the only place different social types can genuinely get along with each other is in heaven.
Person1: No, Sarah. His death is registered with the War Department in Washington. You're the only one who can help me uncover the truth.
Person2: Oh. Then who's this one? The one calling himself Dyle?
Person1: I don't know -- but I think you'd better find out, don't you? You're the only one who can help me.

Person1: I'm not gonna win, and let's be honest, I'm not the one who deserves the promotion.
Person2: You're being ridiculous. You're the best candidate for the job.
Person1: Oh, come on, I was only considered because my wife has connections. You know they only gave me an interview because of her.
Person2: That's not true. You have the skills and experience.
Person1: Skills and experience? Ha! I've been on vacation in America, not working. And you know it.
Person2: What's going on? You're not making any sense.
Person1: I'm making perfect sense. I want to talk to you about your salary. Because I can't...
Person2: What do you mean? You're the one who's getting the promotion.
Person1: Am I? Or am I just being strung along? You're the one who's been working behind the scenes, aren't you?
Person2: What are you insinuating?
Person1: I'm not insinuating anything. I'm just saying that sometimes people get what they want by manipulating others. And I think you're one of those people.
Person2: That's it, I've had enough of your paranoia.

Person1: I asked you to bring me the file, not the entire folder. Come on, sit down and explain yourself.
Person2: So that's what you're really after. I might have known it. No wonder you've been so secretive about this project.
Person1: You're trying to deflect, but it won't work. I mean, do you realize what you've done? You're trying to get a rise out of me, just like you did with Rachel last week.
Person2: I didn't mean to cause trouble. I just wanted you to see things from my perspective... and maybe get a little angry at the way things are being handled around here.
Person1: Save it. You're not as innocent as you're pretending to be. Certainly not.

Person1: You know I'm important to you, but love isn't about ultimatums. You're just scared of what you might find once the lights go out.
Person2: That's not fair, Alex. My career is on the line. And what about us? Where do I stand in your priorities?
Person1: Your voice is saying no, but your body is saying yes. You'd do it if you loved me.
Person2: I told you, I have that important work event. I can't just bail. But doesn't that turn you on, that curiosity and fear, swirling together?

Person1: You're not who I thought you were, are you? I was starting to believe you, but now I see the truth.
Person2: Oh, spare me the self-righteousness! You're just as guilty as I am, maybe more. You're just trying to shift the blame, to make yourself feel better.
Person1: That's not true! I'm standing up for what's right, unlike you. You're just trying to justify your own mistakes.
Person2: Justify? You're the one who's been playing me all along, using your sweet talk and your fake concern to get what you want. I'm not buying it anymore.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly, are you?
Person2: Oh, I don't know if you're interested in this, but I was just about to tell you that I've made up my mind. I'm going to do it, and I don't care what you think. I'm doing it for the person I want to be, and I'm doing it for the person I almost am. I'm doing it.

Person1: I've gone out of my way to make sure you're protected, Alex. After everything I've done for you...
Person2: I know you've done a lot, Rachel, but I'm not sure I'm comfortable with the arrangement.
Person1: You vanished quite effectively, Alex. Became Mister Nobody. And you've no idea how useful that could be.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: We've got some plans here. And we'll need a Mister Nobody to execute them. You owe me, Alex.
Person2: I don't owe you anything, Rachel. I'm not your puppet.
Person1: Oh, but you are, Alex. You're never out of my reach.

Person1: Something's wrong with you, Alex. You're not thinking clearly.
Person2: I know what I'm saying, Rachel. You're just trying to confuse me.
Person1: Confuse you? I'm trying to help you see reason. You're being emotional and irrational.
Person2: You're the one who's being manipulative, Rachel. You're trying to get me to do what you want.
Person1: I'm trying to protect you, Alex. You're not thinking about the consequences of your actions.
Person2: Protect me? You're trying to control me. I won't let you do it, Rachel.
Person1: Fine, Alex. But don't come crying to me when everything falls apart.

Person1: You're always chasing after something, but truth is, you're just running away. From yourself, mostly. 'Cause you're miserable. You hate yourself.
Person2: That's not fair, Rachel. I'm trying to make a decision about this project, and you're making it personal.
Person1: I'm making it personal? You're the one who's not listening to reason. I've evaluated all angles, and I think we should reconsider the project direction. The current approach has too many pitfalls.
Person2: And who writes your paycheck? Sometimes, it's best to follow orders and trust the process. You're just trying to undermine my authority.
Person1: I'm trying to do what's best for the company, not undermine you. But if you're not willing to listen, then maybe you're not the right person for this job.

Person1: I don't care what the experts say - I know what I saw.
Person2: You're not afraid, are you? There are things we don't understand.
Person1: If we wait until we understand everything, we'll be too late. Come on, I can show you the truth.
Person2: Well...I guess one look is all right.
Person1: He's lying. I can see it in his eyes.
Person2: But the polygraph says otherwise. Are you sure you're not just being paranoid?
Person1: I'm not paranoid, I'm just more aware than you are. And I know that sometimes you have to take a risk to uncover the truth.

Person1: Just what do you want from me, anyway? Permission to be a fake?
Person2: Desperate times call for desperate measures, Dr. Lee. Perhaps I need to remind you of your situation.

Person1: I've never seen you so hesitant, Alex. What's going on?
Person2: I don't know, Rachel. I just don't feel right about using my dad's connections to get us out of this mess.
Person1: Why not? He's not going to notice, and it's only fair that...
Person2: I know, but I don't want to owe him anything. He's already done too much for me.
Person1: Alex, we're in a tight spot here. This is an emergency. And I thought you cared about me...
Person2: I do care, Rachel. But I care about my integrity too. You're not going to convince me to do something I'll regret.
Person1: Fine. But I think you're being selfish. You're not thinking about what's best for us.
Person2: That's not fair, Rachel. You're the one who's always talking about yourself, your problems, your feelings... Maybe it's time you listened to me for a change.
Person1: Oh, I'm sorry. I didn't realize I was so selfish. You're right, let's talk about you. What do you think about me?
Person2: Honestly? I think you're scared and desperate, and you're trying to manipulate me into doing what you want.

Person1: I don't recall authorizing you to have a personal life.
Person2: You're not thinking clearly. We need to focus on the task at hand.
Person1: The reality is, you take away the emotional attachment to this project, take away the moral and ethical implications of all the crap you have had conditioned, beaten, into your head since grade one. What are we left with? A problem that must be solved.
Person2: I hardly knew the people involved. Why be impolite to strangers?
Person1: Trust me, I can take care of this. I see the solution. We just need to break it down into smaller, manageable parts.

Person1: You think I didn't need you?
Person2: If you did, you never showed it. You're only coming to me now because you need something, just like Warner said.
Person1: That's not fair. I'm trying to make amends.
Person2: Save it. I gave you my word, just like I gave Brooke my word. You're not the only one who can use people for your own gain.
Person1: That's not what I'm doing. I'm trying to prove to you that I've changed.
Person2: Prove it? You want to prove it? You'll be back to your old tricks in no time, and I'll be left in the dust. I'm not going to fall for it again.

Person1: I feel like you're not taking my concerns seriously. You always say you're busy, but I think you're just avoiding me.
Person2: You're being too sensitive, as usual. I just want what's best for you.
Person1: That's not what it feels like. It feels like you're trying to control me.
Person2: Maybe you should listen more carefully next time. You always take things too personally.
Person1: It's not about listening, it's about how you make me feel. You're always so condescending.
Person2: That's not true. I do care about you, I just need to handle my personal stresses better.

Person1: You're not going to find anything. Just leave now and we can forget this ever happened.
Person2: Forget what? You're the one who's been hiding something from me.
Person1: Nobody wants to get hurt. Just back off and we can both walk away from this.
Person2: You're not fooling anyone with your empty threats. I know you're involved in this up to your neck.

Person1: You look very good in the sun... I think we should take a walk instead of going back inside.
Person2: He wants us to follow. The little boy brought you to me, didn't he?
Person1: If you want to know the truth, trust me. I'll show you the way.
Person2: I have work to do, but I suppose it can wait. You're right, it's too nice outside.
Person1: My sister's coming by to pick me up for brunch. Why don't you come, too? It'll be fun.
Person2: I'm not sure... But if you insist, I'll come.

Person1: I've been thinking a lot about our last conversation, and I was wondering if I could come by and discuss it further.
Person2: I'm not sure that's a good idea. I've got a lot on my plate right now.
Person1: Just a minute, please. I promise it'll be worth your while.
Person2: Alright, alright. But make it quick.
Person1: You know, I've been noticing that you've been avoiding me lately. Is everything okay?
Person2: Everything's fine. Why do you ask?
Person1: Don't be evasive. I can tell when you're hiding something.
Person2: You're not my mother, you know. You can't just pry into my personal life.
Person1: I'm not trying to pry. I'm just concerned about you. And I think you're concerned about me too, deep down.
Person2: What are you talking about?
Person1: I think you know exactly what I'm talking about. You're just not willing to admit it yet.

Person1: You're still playing with fire, aren't you?
Person2: Don't tempt me. I've got a reputation for being ruthless in business.
Person1: I'm not afraid of you. I've got a proposal that can benefit both of us.
Person2: Save it. I'm not interested in your empty promises. You just want to use me for your own gain.
Person1: That's not true. I'm willing to make concessions. You're just still mad at me, aren't you?
Person2: You think I'm mad? You have no idea what I'm capable of.

Person1: I'd rather we settled this amicably, without involving the press.
Person2: You don't have to show me anything, Detective James. I believe you.
Person1: Careful, you're getting ahead of yourself. You see my office?
Person2: Yeah. Yours is nicer. But I'm not impressed.
Person1: Oh, okay. Here it comes. The threats, the intimidation...
Person2: I wasn't going to threaten you, Detective. I just want the truth.
Person1: Save it, Mrs. Johnson. You're holding me hostage with your silence.

Person1: I'm telling you, I had nothing to do with it. I'm just a small part of a much larger machine.
Person2: Save it. You think you're some kind of innocent bystander, but trust me, you don't even have an inkling of a hint of a clue as to what's really going on in this city. And if you want to find out even a little, you'll shut up and come with me.
Person1: You're not listening to me. I'm a victim here, too. My life has been permanently disrupted because of the actions of others.
Person2: Permanently disrupted? You're getting a nice paycheck out of this, aren't you? Hasn't this 'incident' jump-started your career?
Person1: That's not the point. The point is I didn't have control over my actions. I was manipulated, just like everyone else.
Person2: Oh, spare me the theatrics. You're not a puppet on strings, you're a willing participant. And if you don't like the way things are going, then maybe you should take a closer look at yourself.
Person1: You're just trying to confuse me, to make me doubt myself. But I know what I know, and I won't back down.
Person2: Fine. Keep playing the hero. But when you finally realize you're in over your head, don't come crying to me.

Person1: I think I've found a way to uncover the truth. I have a plan. But I need you to trust me.
Person2: What's going on? You're being cryptic again.
Person1: You don't want to know. Just know that it's for your own good.
Person2: That's exactly what I'm afraid of. You're not thinking clearly.
Person1: I'm thinking more clearly than you are. You're just scared of what you might find once the truth comes out. A little scared... and a lot curious. Maybe more than you want to admit.
Person2: I'm not scared of the truth. I'm scared of your methods.
Person1: My methods are necessary. And you'll thank me later. Now, just do what I say. Don't ask.

Person1: You're crazy, you know that? I've never met anyone like you.
Person2: That's what I like about you, you're not like anyone I've met either. We're having fun, aren't we?
Person1: Fun? You call this fun? You're making a fool out of me, and I'm standing at the pass of Thermopylae, refusing to budge!
Person2: Oh, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to make you uncomfortable. But I think we could have a real connection if you just let go of your inhibitions.
Person1: Inhibitions? You're the one who's been pushing me to reveal more about myself. What's your game, anyway?
Person2: No game, I promise. I just think we could be good for each other. You're not like the others, and I'm not like the others either.
Person1: That's what I'm afraid of. You're going to get tired of me, of my antics, of my... flaws.
Person2: I'm not looking for perfection, and I'm not going to get bored of you. You're like a breath of fresh air, and I want to keep you around.

Person1: You're hurting me!
Person2: What do you want from me?
Person1: I was just curious--you don't do it well, so I wondered.
Person2: ...No... never in so many words...
Person1: It's obvious you want to talk to someone--well, I'm someone.
Person2: Stop!!!!

Person1: I've been thinking about our little arrangement, and I'm not sure I'm comfortable with it anymore.
Person2: Oh? What's changed your mind?
Person1: Well, I've been going over the budget, and Treadstone is a rather sizable line item in my ledger. I'm not sure I can justify it.
Person2: You're getting cold feet, aren't you? You're thinking about what others might think if they found out.
Person1: Maybe. But I also think about what you'd have to explain if this got out. And what I'd have to explain about how I let you get this far.
Person2: (laughs) You're worried about being faithful to your principles, aren't you? But I think we can come to a new understanding. One that benefits both of us.
Person1: I'm not sure I trust you.
Person2: Trust is a matter of definition, isn't it? But I think we can find a way to make this work. For both of us.

Person1: I've done everything to protect you, Emma. After all I've sacrificed for you...
Person2: I know you have, but that doesn't give you the right to control my every move.
Person1: You're being paranoid. If you won't listen to me, then go outside and see for yourself.
Person2: You'll just find a way to spin it to your advantage. I'm not falling for that again.
Person1: Emma, be smart. If you cooperate, it'll look better for you in the long run.

Person1: You're being really unfair, Alex. I'm trying to make an effort here.
Person2: I'm uncomfortable with the way you're approaching this. It feels like you're trying to impress me or something.
Person1: Oh, come on! You're being impossible to talk to sometimes. I'm just trying to have a good time.
Person2: That's not true. I listen to you. But maybe if you stopped lecturing me about the art scene, I'd be more receptive.
Person1: Fine, whatever. You're just not open to new experiences, that's all.

Person1: You're a visionary. You oughta be able to see why I'm worried about your new business partner.
Person2: I was just trying to protect you from getting hurt. I only did that because I care about you.
Person1: Care isn't an excuse to control my decisions, Alex. We need to trust each other's judgment.
Person2: I realize that now. I'm sorry for overstepping. But don't you think you're being naive about this partnership?
