Person1: Maybe I am, but I'd rather be naive than have you dictate what's best for me. Let's work on trusting each other's instincts.

Person1: I'm sorry I didn't meet your expectations at the party last night.
Person2: Oh, come on. You're being too sensitive. It was just a joke.
Person1: It didn't feel like a joke to me. You made me feel like I was the only one who didn't get it.
Person2: Maybe if you weren't so self-conscious, you wouldn't have taken it the wrong way.
Person1: I wish you'd consider how your words affect others. It's not just about me.
Person2: I'm sorry, okay? But you need to learn to take a joke.

Person1: You're making it out like we're friends here or something. I met him alone twice.
Person2: Dizzy wouldn't want our tears. She'd want us to remember her... with a vengeance.
Person1: So you believed him. You believed Jason Bourne had suffered a severe traumatic breakdown.
Person2: Kill a bug for Dizzy. Kill as many as you can. You are her revenge, and every bug you kill honors her death.
Person1: Not good enough. You're the person who floated this amnesia story. Ever feel sorry for him? For what he'd been through?
Person2: I was reassigned. I'm out.
Person1: See, that's a problem for me, Nicky. Whatever he's doing, we need to end it. This isn't the kind of mess you walk away from.

Person1: I've been nothing if not generous. I want the best for everyone.
Person2: That's not how you told it. You said you'd support me every step of the way.
Person1: I did support you, in so many words, yes. But when you hit me with your demands, I saw who you really are.
Person2: You never said any of that! You led me to believe we were on the same page.
Person1: Okay, I may have written those things... and yeah, I had big thoughts of helping you out... but when I realized what you were really after, I saw through your game.
Person2: What did you call me? What did I hear you call me, you manipulative liar?

Person1: You're gonna get burned playing with fire like that!
Person2: Stop squawking! I've been doing this for years, and I know what I'm doing.
Person1: Yeah, but you're not thinking about the consequences. You're gonna end up with nothing.
Person2: How's the payoff?
Person1: A few hundred bucks, but it's not worth the risk.
Person2: I'll need it  I've got debts to pay off. Come on, let's make a deal, and we'll both come out on top.
Person1: Until then, the money stays with me. You're not getting it that easily.
Person2: Is that a nice way to talk to a partner? You're not thinking about the bigger picture here.
Person1: Don't let greed spoil a good opportunity. Look at the stakes we're playing with  this isn't a game.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly. Maybe you're just trying to get attention with these outlandish claims.
Person2: I've never felt so certain about anything in my life. You're just not listening to me.
Person1: If I said I was a visionary, would you believe me? You're so caught up in your own ego that you can't see the truth.
Person2: I'm not the one who's trying to control the narrative here. You're the one who's trying to gaslight me.
Person1: You're just not keeping it real, brother. You're too caught up in your own pretentious ways to see what's right in front of you.
Person2: That's exactly what you want me to think. You're trying to make me doubt my own sanity.

Person1: I've been noticing you've been questioning my decisions in front of the team. 
Person2: I just gave them a different perspective, that's all. 
Person1: You don't want to go down this road with me. I've always played fair with you. 
Person2: This doesn't make sense. 
Person1: It makes perfect sense. You're just not seeing the bigger picture. 
Person2: I don't like it. Something's wrong. 
Person1: You're just not used to thinking strategically. Let's keep our disagreements in-house. 
Person2: We don't know who we're really working for. 
Person1: I've had a lot of credentials flashed in my face. What I saw yesterday, I know not to ask questions.

Person1: You're trying to control me, aren't you?
Person2: I'm just trying to help you see things from a different perspective. You're like a puzzle piece that doesn't quite fit.
Person1: That's not what I meant. You're trying to manipulate me, using my fears against me.
Person2: Oh, come on. I'm just giving you a little nudge. You're probably going to be too busy with your own doubts anyway.
Person1: What are you talking about? You're not making any sense.
Person2: I have a friend who's an expert in psychology. I'm sure they'd love to take a look at your thought patterns. You know, help you uncover some of those deep-seated fears.
Person1: Fine. What's the first step in this little game of yours?

Person1: I always put you first, unlike others. Why can't you see that? You're being really unfair, Alex.
Person2: We never should have done this to her... I think we're making a huge mistake.
Person1: Don't get all worked up, Alex. I expected some common sense on your part and clearly I was expecting too much. Just calm down and think this through.
Person2: It's not like that. I just need some space to think about what we've done. This isn't about you, it's about what's right.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you? Some freak'll come by and take advantage of you!
Person2: Oh, come on. I mentioned it in passing. You're always so quick to assume the worst.
Person1: I had a chat with Rachel, and she mentioned your little secret. You never told me that.
Person2: You always rely on third parties to know my business. Maybe if you checked in more, we wouldn't have this confusion.
Person1: Communication goes both ways, Alex. But I suppose it's easier to manipulate people when they're in the dark.

Person1: You're still holding onto that, aren't you?
Person2: Holding onto what? You taking sides against me now?
Person1: Don't play dumb. You know exactly what I'm talking about. Eight years is a long time to hold a grudge.
Person2: Some people don't change, no matter how much time passes. You're still trying to manipulate me, just like you did back then.
Person1: I'm just trying to make amends. You're the one who's still bitter.
Person2: Amends? You think a simple apology will erase everything? You're not even sorry. You're just sorry you got caught.

Person1: I'm sorry, it's too flashy, too distracting. Would it be asking too much for you to put it away?
Person2: You're already contaminated. It's why you couldn't see the signs. There's probably a hidden message near your workspace.
Person1: What?!?! You're saying I'm possessed or something?
Person2: Not possessed, influenced. I'm trying to help you, but you need to trust me.
Person1: Trust you? You're the one who's been acting strange. I think you're trying to manipulate me.
Person2: Oh, if it's going to make you uncomfortable... Perhaps we can find something else to focus on. But you need to open your eyes.
Person1: My eyes are open, and I see right through you. You're trying to control my thoughts.
Person2: I'm trying to free your mind. You're the one who's been living in the dark.

Person1: You know, I've been thinking, and I want you to take a closer look at the Smith account. I want you to make it happen, no matter what it takes.
Person2: I'm not sure that's possible. The Smiths are very particular about their business dealings.
Person1: Forget how they work. Just do it. Like I always say, "By any means necessary." You owe me, after all. I've given you a chance to prove yourself, and this is the least you can do to repay me.
Person2: But what about the risks involved? We could lose everything if we're caught.
Person1: Risks? Ha! You're not thinking about the bigger picture. You're not thinking about what I can do for you, what I can offer you. I can make your life so much easier, so much more comfortable. All you have to do is this one little thing for me.
Person2: I...I don't know...
Person1: Come now, don't be shy. You know as well as I do that you're not happy with your current situation. You're not fulfilled. I can give you that fulfillment, that sense of purpose. Just do this one thing, and you'll see what I mean.

Person1: Go back to the mansion, Rachel. It will make you unhappy to stay here.
Person2: Why? What do you know about this place, about these people?
Person1: They wear masks, Rachel. And underneath the masks, they're hiding secrets, twisted desires.
Person2: That's not true. You're just trying to scare me.
Person1: Shut up and listen. I'm trying to protect you. You don't know what you're getting yourself into.
Person2: I'm not a child, I can take care of myself. But I think you're the one who's hiding something.

Person1: I've been having these recurring nightmares. I think it's because I'm afraid of what happens after we die.
Person2: You're letting your fears control you. You need to focus on the present.
Person1: But what if one hasn't a soul anymore? What of that?
Person2: That's just a myth, a way to make us feel better about our own mortality. You're just trying to distract yourself from the real issue.
Person1: What's the real issue, then? You know something, don't you? Come on, out with it.
Person2: I know you're still hung up on your ex. You're using these existential crises as an excuse to avoid moving on.
Person1: That's not true! I'm just trying to find some meaning in life.
Person2: Meaning? You'll find meaning when you stop chasing after people who are bad for you. You need to take control of your life, not let your fears and doubts dictate your every move.
Person1: You're one to talk. You're always trying to control me, telling me what to do and who to date.
Person2: I'm just trying to help you see sense. You're not thinking clearly, and it's my job as your friend to intervene.
Person1: Well, maybe I don't want your help. Maybe I want to figure things out for myself.
Person2: Fine, but don't come crying to me when you realize you've made a mistake. Again.

Person1: I've been thinking of taking a stand on this issue.
Person2: Rachel, that's not a good idea. Everyone else agrees with me.
Person1: Oh, I'm hearing you, Michael. That's not the problem. The problem is that what you think is best for the company, is really what's best for you. And I don't care how much you try to convince me otherwise, I will not back down.
Person2: Maybe they're just too intimidated to say it to your face. Trust me on this one, Rachel. You're not thinking clearly.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm ready for this commitment.
Person2: And love's a funny thing. Sometimes I don't know if I want to love you, but you've been stuck in a rut lately. You need a change.
Person1: You think this is what I need?
Person2: Don't you?

Person1: I'm telling you, he's a mastermind. He's convinced people to do his bidding without them even realizing it.
Person2: I'm not sure I believe you. What makes you think he's so manipulative?
Person1: Please, just hear me out. I have evidence that will change your mind. Just a minute of your time, and I'll show you the truth.
Person2: Alright, fine. But make it quick. I don't have all day to listen to your conspiracy theories.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly, I can get us out of this mess...
Person2: Look, I hate to be the kind of friend who does you a solid, then asks for a favor in return. But I'm afraid I gotta be that kind of friend.
Person1: What do you mean? You're not making any sense.
Person2: I need a favor, and it requires you to come with me tonight. I know you're not planning on going anywhere, but I'm the one who got you out of that tight spot last week.
Person1: That was different. I owed you one.
Person2: Exactly, and now I'm calling it in. You can help me, and I'll make sure you're taken care of.

Person1: You know, I'm not worried about Sooze. Life is too short.
Person2: The fault, dear friend, is not in our stars, but in ourselves. What kind of settlement do you seek? What are, for you, the parameters of the possible?
Person1: I'm not looking for a settlement. I just want to know what's going on with Tim.
Person2: Ah, Tim. Well, let me ask you this: do you think he's capable of making a great tape? Something fresh and raw?
Person1: I don't know, man. I think he's in trouble. You know, I heard Erica is in the van back there.
Person2: Oh, really? You wanna go look? I think you'll find that's just a rumor. Tim's a good guy, he wouldn't do anything to hurt anyone.
Person1: I don't know, man. I have a bad feeling about this. You're not telling me something.
Person2: Maybe I'm just trying to protect you from the truth. You know, for your own good.
Person1: What are you talking about? You're starting to scare me.
Person2: Oh, don't be scared. I'm just trying to help you see things from a different perspective. You know, like I said, the fault is not in our stars, but in ourselves.
Person1: Yeah, right. Whatever you say, man.

Person1: I'll go talk to him, are you sure?
Person2: Yeah, I'm honored. You're the best mediator I've ever had. Really.
Person1: He's being weird, I'm sorry. I have no idea why he's being so stubborn.
Person2: You didn't know I was so persuasive. It's time you found out.
Person1: For old time's sake. If you don't trust me, you can walk away.
Person2: I didn't know you were so confident.

Person1: You're playing a dangerous game, Alex. Whatever I do, I do because I care about you.
Person2: Care? You don't care about me or anyone else! You want to be needed, that's all. I'm the one who can give you the spotlight, just name it and it's yours! Only acknowledge my influence, don't expect me to be grateful.
Person1: Not at all. You brought me my script revisions. I had no idea there were so many people concerned about my performance. But I guess that's the best thing about working in the industry. You make so many... acquaintances.
Person2: You're telling me you feel trapped.
Person1: No... What I mean is... I'm just very excited by the prospect of getting on with my project, that's all.
Person2: Do you really believe I'm trying to sabotage you?
Person1: What? You told me you wanted to help me.
Person2: And you accused me of tampering with your script.
Person1: Oh for... That's just a misunderstanding. You said something, and I...

Person1: You're going to get killed chasing after your damn power and prestige!
Person2: Perhaps you've been counting my influence, and discovered exactly how limited I really am.
Person1: And what is this, then? Been off to gain more followers because you're a true leader? Or is this you, gaining your long sought after rise in politics by becoming a charismatic figure!?
Person2: I'd throw everything away for this cause.
Person1: You're not leaving without those connections, are you? You're gonna create a scandal in exchange for a glowing reputation and political influence laid at your feet!
Person2: Maybe... someday. Not today.

Person1: I'm not sure if I can deliver what you want.
Person2: Well, until you know, you can't go.
Person1: You got your head stuck up your ass with your pretentious ways. I'm keepin' it real and you're frontin', trying to be something you're not.
Person2: I don't know. When are you going to be back?
Person1: You will or you'll be back at square one so quick you'll never know what hit you. I need a breakthrough and pronto.
Person2: Oh, okay.

Person1: You know, I'm really disappointed in you. You said you'd help me out, and now you're backing out.
Person2: Hey, I like this new coffee shop. The atmosphere is great.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is you're not keeping your promises. And by the way, I got you that album you wanted, If I Were a Carpenter. It's all Carpenters covers by alt-rock bands.
Person2: Oh, thanks, but I didn't ask you to get it for me. And I didn't promise you anything. You're just trying to guilt trip me into doing what you want.
Person1: Guilt trip? You're the one who's being unfair. I'm just trying to help you see things from my perspective. And by the way, I think you'd really love the Stooges. I'll make you a CD.
Person2: Stop trying to manipulate me! I can make my own music choices, thank you very much.

Person1: You're in trouble. Now do it.
Person2: What do you mean? I thought we had an agreement.
Person1: Agreements are for the weak. You should have heeded my warning.
Person2: I don't have any other choice, do I?
Person1: You have a choice, but it's not one you'll like. Use my connections or face the consequences.
Person2: That's not a choice, that's blackmail.
Person1: Call it what you will. The result is the same. You'll do what I say, or you'll suffer.

Person1: You're the only one who can get me what I need. I've seen your skills, Alex.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. I'm just a researcher.
Person1: Don't play dumb. I have evidence of your little "extracurricular activities". Now, I need you to get into Dr. Lee's head and retrieve the data she's hiding.
Person2: You can't be serious. That's not something I can just do.
Person1: Fine. All of you want to play innocent? Be innocent... but I'm the one who knows the truth, and that makes me the one in control.

Person1: You said "the prophecy is fulfilled."
Person2: Just keep your foolish, superstitious mind shut, Elara.
Person1: No, I'm certain you did. You said it right before we entered the temple.
Person2: I didn't say that, and even if I did, it wouldn't matter. You're just trying to confuse me.

Person1: I'm telling you, Rachel, I saw you at the party last night. You were having a great time.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about, Alex. I didn't attend any party.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I have a photo of you on my phone. You're standing right next to the DJ.
Person2: Alex, I swear on my life I wasn't there. Maybe you're confusing me with someone else.
Person1: Then try harder, Rachel. I have no intention of believing you. You will admit the truth and learn your place.
Person2: Alex, sometimes our memories can play tricks on us. Maybe you're mistaken or confusing me with someone else.
Person1: No, Rachel, I'm positive it was you. I even have a witness who can vouch for me.

Person1: I miss you, Alex.
Person2: Don't be cruel, Rachel. You know I'm trying to move on.
Person1: Move on? You're the one who's been holding me back. You're the one who's been pretending.
Person2: Pretending what, Rachel? That I care about you?
Person1: No, pretending that you're someone you're not. You're not the person I fell in love with.
Person2: And who am I, then? According to you, I'm just a fake, a liar.
Person1: You're a master manipulator, Alex. You know exactly what to say to get what you want from people.
Person2: And what do I want from you, Rachel? Your love? Your trust?
Person1: You want control. You want to be in charge. And I'm not going to give it to you anymore.
Person2: Fine. If that's how you feel, then maybe we're better off apart. But before you go, can I ask you something?
Person1: What is it?
Person2: Will you kiss me goodbye?

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you? Before we slap you down.
Person2: I'm trying to warn you, Peter. You're the one Birdson was talking about at the exorcism.
Person1: What are you talking about? You think I'm possessed or something?
Person2: I know it sounds crazy, but I've seen the signs. You're already contaminated. There's probably a pentacle near your bed.
Person1: That's it, I've had enough of your games. Where is he, before we beat it out of you?
Person2: You're not listening. If you're possessed, you can't reveal anything Satan wants hidden. Unless you trick him.
Person1: Trick him? You're the one who needs to be tricked. Do you want us to call the cops and have them give you the boots?
Person2: You're not thinking clearly, Peter. Check your parents' blood types. Are you sure your parents are your birth parents?

Person1: You're playing with fire, and you know it. I can see it in your eyes.
Person2: What are you talking about? I'm just trying to do my job.
Person1: Oh, come on. You're not fooling anyone. Least of all, yourself. You're drawn to him, and you know it.
Person2: Who? Mr. Reed? He's my boss, for crying out loud!
Person1: Exactly. And that's what makes it so delicious. "Office Romance: When the Boss Takes Control." We're going to make a killing off this story.
Person2: You can't be serious. There's nothing going on between us.
Person1: Not yet, perhaps. But I can see the sparks flying. And I'll be there to fan the flames, every step of the way. You can't resist me, darling. I know exactly which buttons to press.

Person1: You're a clever woman, Sophia. I'm a man who knows what I want.
Person2: What do you want, exactly?
Person1: I want to know how you managed to keep your husband in the dark about your little secret. You're not as innocent as you seem.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: Don't play dumb, Sophia. I've had a long and unpleasant day. I'm tired and I'm angry. But I'm not mad... yet. I paid your husband's business partner a visit this morning. Found him alive and well. Why haven't you told your husband where he is since reading my note, eh?
Person2: You're just trying to intimidate me.
Person1: Am I? Or am I just trying to uncover the truth? You see, I think you're hiding something, Sophia. And I think it's only a matter of time before I find out what that is. Does a conscience still burn somewhere inside your sore mind, Sophia? Or is it just cold expediency?

Person1: You're no sob story.
Person2: I want your business, and I'll get it, no matter what it takes.
Person1: You're not smart. Even if you got it without me, I'd find a way to take it back.
Person2: Because I want you, will always want you - no other partner will ever take your place.
Person1: Why don't you leave me alone? I've had enough of your threats.
Person2: Get wise to yourself, Alex - you're not as powerful as you think. I'll find a way to make you an offer you can't refuse.
Person1: I wish I could believe that.
Person2: You should. I always get what I want, and I want your business.

Person1: You're involved, whether you like it or not.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. I just want to go back to my normal life.
Person1: You're kidding, right? You think you can just walk away from this?
Person2: What's the big deal? I didn't do anything wrong.
Person1: You're not taking this seriously. They want you, and I'm the only one who can protect you.
Person2: Or what? You'll shoot me?
Person1: Don't be ridiculous. I'm trying to help you. But you need to trust me and do what I say.
Person2: Why should I trust you? You're the one who got me into this mess.
Person1: I didn't get you into anything. You're the one who got yourself involved. Now, are you going to cooperate or not?

Person1: You're needed here--keep watching--
Person2: I don't think you understand the full implications of what's happening to her.
Person1: She's far from "fine." You knew that, didn't you?
Person2: Check the monitor, it'll tell you everything you need to know.

Person1: Father, I've been thinking a lot about my role in the community.
Person2: Neil, you're going to quit this ridiculous activism immediately. You're embarrassing me.
Person1: But Father, I understand the struggle. I've grown up around people from all walks of life. If the truth be told, I probably know what it means to be marginalized better than you do.
Person2: I would prefer you not use that tone in my presence. You're not one of them, Neil.
Person1: Oh, so now you're trying to silence me? You're trying to control what I say and do? That's rich, coming from you.
Person2: Neil, stop this nonsense. You're not going to change the world with your empty words.
Person1: Empty words? You're one to talk, Father. You've been using your wealth and influence to manipulate people for years. At least I'm trying to make a difference.

Person1: What's the purpose of this investigation?
Person2: Everything about the company's practices, Rachel.
Person1: Like what?
Person2: Like what they've done, what they do, what they don't do, what they want to do but are afraid to ask for, what they won't do even if asked.
Person1: You just ask them questions?
Person2: Yes. And sometimes they do things.
Person1: To you?
Person2: No, not to me, for the camera. For the record.
Person1: I don't... why... why do you do this?
Person2: Maybe you want to go. You're not comfortable with this, are you?
Person1: No, I'm not. But I need to know. Can I please see the facility?
Person2: Why do you want to see it? You're not going to find anything.
Person1: I want to know more about what you do here. Frankly, there have been a lot of rumors...
Person2: Rumors? You mean like the ones about our "questionable" business practices?

Person1: I've got a business proposition for you. You want to hear it?
Person2: What is it?
Person1: I've been thinking about expanding my operations to California. You know, take a chance, see what it's like.
Person2: You're not serious, are you?
Person1: I'm dead serious. I've got a meeting with an investor on Thursday, and I need someone I can trust to come with me.
Person2: I don't know...I've got a lot on my plate right now.
Person1: Ah, come on. You owe me one. Remember that time I helped you out of a tight spot? This is the least you can do.
Person2: That was different. This is a huge commitment.
Person1: I'll take care of all the arrangements. You just show up at my office on Thursday at 3 pm. It's a done deal.
Person2: I'm not sure...
Person1: Boy, do I know how you feel. First time I heard about this opportunity, I said you got to be kidding me. But trust me, it's a game-changer. You won't regret it.

Person1: I haven't even said I'll do this job yet.
Person2: We'll need to discuss the details. I happen to have the schematics with me. Where's your team's report?
Person1: What's the matter with right here? It's nice and quiet.
Person2: Quiet? Man, this place is a trap. I ain't talking any business in here. To me, this is a setup. I got to be someplace anyway. You want to talk, meet me at the old warehouse tomorrow night, we'll look at it good.

Person1: You're making a huge mistake, and I'm not going to stand by and watch you destroy yourself. I'm begging you to reconsider.
Person2: If I'm anything like you, I'll deserve the consequences.
Person1: What?! You think you're like me? You're not even close. You're just scared, and you're letting fear control your decisions.
Person2: I'm scared because I know you'll do whatever it takes to get what you want. You love me too much to let me walk away.
Person1: That's not love, that's obsession. And I'll do whatever it takes to save you from yourself, even if it means saving you from me.

Person1: You've felt it your whole life, felt that something is wrong with the world. You don't know what, but it's there like a splinter in your mind, driving you mad.
Person2: I know this.
Person1: Good. I want you to listen. You trust that doctor too much. So does your family.
Person2: The doctor's OK.
Person1: You listening to me? That doctor is not to be trusted. No one in that hospital can be trusted. The first time you turn your back, boom, they'll take advantage of you.
Person2: How do you know this?
Person1: I know. You've come to me because you know something. What you know you can't explain, but you feel it.
Person2: You really think so?
Person1: I know so. They're not to be trusted. So what do you want me to do?

Person1: You're suffocating me with your indifference. It would be so easy to just walk away and leave me to wither away.
Person2: You're being dramatic. I'm just not into the whole romantic charade.
Person1: Oh, so now I'm just a silly teenager, caught up in fairy tales? You're the one who's been stringing me along, making promises you had no intention of keeping.
Person2: That's not fair. I've been clear about what I want from the start.
Person1: Clear? You call this clear? You're playing with my emotions, Clayton, and it's tearing me apart.

Person1: You're telling me I'm the only one who can stop the apocalypse? That's a pretty big burden to put on someone.
Person2: I had to test you. You passed.
Person1: By "test", you mean trying to drive me insane with those creepy whispers in my ear? And what's with the clock on the wall? You're trying to tell me something, but I'm not buying it.
Person2: Time is running out. You need to accept your destiny.
Person1: My destiny? You mean the one where I'm supposed to save the world? I don't think so. I just want to graduate from college, get a decent job, and maybe travel a bit. I don't want to be responsible for the fate of humanity.
Person2: You're not listening. You're not just saving humanity, you're saving yourself. If you don't take control, you'll be consumed by the darkness.
Person1: And what makes you think I'm so special? What makes you think I can do what others can't?
Person2: Because I've seen it. I've seen the potential in you. And I'll do whatever it takes to bring it out.

Person1: I've been thinking about the Smith account. Why else would they have a strict confidentiality agreement as their policy?
Person2: Of course, the Smith account. I assume it's because they're hiding something.
Person1: That's not what I meant. I think it's because they're trying to protect their clients.
Person2: Protect their clients? From what? The truth?
Person1: Before we take on this account, I want you to know that - no matter what happens to us - it's your decision.
Person2: I assume full responsibility. But I have a condition: you have to tell me what you really know about the Smith account.
Person1: What makes you think I know something?
Person2: Because you're not as transparent as you seem, and I want to know what's behind that mask. You're not going to use me for your own gain, are you?
Person1: (laughs) Oh, sport, you're so naive. I'm afraid unless you can see through the smoke and mirrors, we're not going to get very far in this business.

Person1: You're really going to do this, aren't you?
Person2: This is my chance to turn the tables. The game isn't over, I just thought it was.
Person1: Emotional? I expected more from you.
Person2: If I don't take this opportunity, I'll be trapped forever. You know I'm innocent, but who would believe me?
Person1: By the time the truth comes out, it won't matter. You'll have played right into my hands.
Person2: You're underestimating me. I've figured out your game, and I'm not going down without a fight.

Person1: I don't know what you're insinuating, but I don't like it.
Person2: Oh, come on, Rachel. You're not naive. You know exactly what I'm talking about.
Person1: I think you're trying to intimidate me, and it won't work.
Person2: Intimidate you? Ha! I'm just trying to make you see reason. You're not prepared for what's down there.
Person1: Down where? The new project site?
Person2: Yes, exactly. You're not equipped to handle it. You're just a researcher, not some kind of explorer.
Person1: That's not fair. I've worked hard to get where I am.
Person2: I'm not questioning your credentials, Rachel. I'm questioning your judgment. You're not thinking clearly about this.
Person1: And you are? You're just trying to control me, to make me do what you want.
Person2: Control you? No, I'm trying to protect you. And myself, for that matter. We can't afford to make mistakes on this project.
Person1: I don't trust you. You're hiding something.
Person2: Maybe I am. But that's not the point. The point is, you need to listen to me and take my advice. For your own good.

Person1: I didn't know we were going to be married.
Person2: Not gonna let me help you with the project? I'm sorry, I'm not gonna let my skills go to waste.
Person1: You're a little ahead of yourself - the usual routine would be for us to discuss the project goals, and if we're on the same page, then we'd divide the tasks.
Person2: I'll give you plenty of ideas as soon as I get the creative juices flowing - what do you think?
Person1: I think we ought to take a break. I don't want you to get too comfortable and start making decisions for me.
Person2: What do you mean, what am I gonna do? I'm just trying to contribute! Big deal!

Person1: What's the point of all this?
Person2: You have complete freedom. To do what you want.
Person1: Like if I wanted to ask you something personal?
Person2: I don't appreciate you prying into my business.
Person1: How am I prying? You're the one who's being secretive.
Person2: You're making assumptions about me, about my family.
Person1: That's not what I meant. I just want to understand you better.
Person2: Maybe you shouldn't be so quick to judge. Maybe you should focus on your own life instead of trying to fix mine.
Person1: Maybe you're right. Maybe I'm just trying to distract myself from my own problems.
Person2: Exactly. And maybe I'm not the only one who's afraid to take a step forward.

Person1: Just keep your lying, heathenous trap shut, Rachel.
Person2: I can't do that.  He's the Dean.  He'll expel me.
Person1: So what? You're better off without this place.
Person2: I need the scholarship.

Person1: You're out in the open, the middle of nowhere with no one around for miles, and you say you're not ready? What's the matter? You were hoping to get it on home video? A keepsake for the grandkids.
Person2: I took the ball and that makes it mine.
Person1: Give it to me, Alex. I know you're just enough of a coward to hold onto it.
Person2: No! You're just trying to get inside my head, to make me doubt myself.
Person1: I know all right. I know you're just enough of a fool to think you can outsmart me. You'd probably lie, cheat and steal without thinking twice. But to take a stand; to get that courage in your heart. You can't fake that. You'd be a marked person for life. Just like a hero. And you're a coward who wants to walk with the brave.
Person2: You know so much about bravery why don't you show some yourself?
Person1: I guess I have what you'd call a love-hate relationship with power.
Person2: You love power, but you hate those who have it?
Person1: I hate loving the feeling it gives me. I hate the kind of person it makes me. I hate having to tolerate the little games people play. I hate letting them use me. But I love it too much to do otherwise. And I certainly love it too much to give it up. But you? You got the heart of a lion, Alex. You just need to unleash it.
Person2: Shut up.
Person1: Came close this time and it scares you.
Person2: Drop it, Rachel.
Person1: And next time, next time somebody is going to take a stand.

Person1: You're not taking me seriously, are you?
Person2: That necklace? Who'd you steal it from?
Person1: My grandmother gave it to me. It's been passed down for generations.
Person2: Looks like a cheap trinket to me. You're not getting any special treatment just because of some old family heirloom.
Person1: You have no idea what this means to me. It's all I have left of her.
Person2: I'm tired of your games. You're not getting anything from me until you tell me the truth.
Person1: The truth? You're the one who's been lying to me all along. You're just trying to get rid of me, aren't you?

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you?
Person2: I'm more interested in what I feel, not what I'm supposed to think.
Person1: But if you're not careful, you'll fall prey to your own desires. How would you recognize the truth? By what you feel?
Person2: I don't think you understand, I'm trying to find my own way.
Person1: Find your own way? You're being naive. Get the journal.
Person2: Oh, not the journal again. Can't I just make my own decisions?
Person1: This isn't about punishment, I don't believe in punishment. It's for your own good. Obviously, you're lost if you can think like that.

Person1: You're not picking a fight, you're coming to my rescue. Maybe we'd better go over the plan again. Where are you gonna be at 8:55?
Person2: I'm going to be at the party. But I'm not sure I can do this. I've never been good at lying.
Person1: You're not lying, you're protecting me. And you're unhappy, aren't you? You're troubled.
Person2: That's because you keep reminding me. If you go away then I'll forget.
Person1: Forget what? That you're not good enough? That you need me to make you look good?
Person2: No, that's not what I meant. I just don't want to get caught up in your games.
Person1: Games? This isn't a game, this is my life. And I need you to help me. You owe me that much.

Person1: You're really not making an effort to find a job, are you? Maybe I should start looking for an apartment without you.
Person2: That's just how my brain works, I guess. I'm not wired for responsibility.
Person1: Oh, don't be silly. You're just lazy. I swear, nobody else can stand to be around you because of your lack of motivation.
Person2: Maybe deep down, you're just trying to mother me into getting a job. You know, like a subconscious biological need to be nagged and bitched at constantly.
Person1: You're gross. I'm not your mother. And by the way, have you seen that new guy in the office? He's really cute.
Person2: Yeah, I've seen him. He's got a girlfriend, though. And even if he didn't, I'm not sure you're his type. You're a bit too...controlling for him.

Person1: You're not listening to me, are you?
Person2: Please, just calm down.
Person1: Don't tell me what to do. You're the one who needs to listen.
Person2: I am listening, but you're not making any sense.
Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you? You think I'm joking?
Person2: I'm trying to understand, but you're being unreasonable.
Person1: You're going to regret not taking me seriously. You savvy what I'm saying?

Person1: What do you want from me, Victor?
Person2: How would you like to take a little vacation? I mean you've earned it, you know? You deserve it.
Person1: You're not really very good at this, are you? You're trying to butter me up for something.
Person2: What else is ballast for? You're just holding me back, Rachel.
Person1: That's not fair, Victor. You know I've been loyal to you.
Person2: Loyal? You'll have to pack quickly. We don't have much time.
Person1: Where are we going? And what's with the hurry?
Person2: North. We're going north. And I'll tell you why when we get there.
Person1: You're not going to try to get me to do something I'll regret, are you?
Person2: You'll have to trust me, Rachel. I promise you, it'll be worth it.

Person1: I can smell it, we're onto something really big. We're going to make some headlines with this one.
Person2: What a waste. You're going to destroy your career over an issue of pride?
Person1: Relax, our profession needs talent like yours. I'll make sure to keep this whole thing nice and quiet, low key, no profile.
Person2: Why? You're not thinking clearly. This could ruin everything.

Person1: I've got a bad feeling about this, I'm telling you I got a bad feeling, man...
Person2: What's wrong, Red? You're not yourself lately.
Person1: I need a break, just three days. I was hoping you'd send me in on the chopper with King...
Person2: You said the vision, the images. They're just that. Just pictures. They can't hurt you.
Person1: You're not listening to me, hunh? I'm your friend, I'm only asking for three days...
Person2: I'm talking to you, and I'm telling you no. You need to focus on the mission, not your feelings.
Person1: Please, it's for your own good. You did too, don't tell me you didn't. You were crying like a baby.
Person2: Everybody's got to die sometime, Red. Get back to your position.

Person1: I've been thinking about what you said last time, about me trying to leave my husband. How maybe I can't do it, ever... 
Person2: That's not quite what I said, Rachel. You're putting words in my mouth.
Person1: You said maybe people would be happier if they'd accept that some things don't change. That it'd be some kind of relief or something...
Person2: I was talking about your job, not your marriage. You're not even listening to me.
Person1: My job? You know I hate my job. That's not the point. The point is, you're not taking me seriously.
Person2: I am taking you seriously, Rachel. But you're not being realistic. You're not thinking about the consequences of your actions.
Person1: Consequences? You're the one who's always saying I need to take control of my life. Now you're telling me to think about consequences?
Person2: That's not what I meant. You're twisting my words again.
Person1: I'm not twisting your words. I'm just trying to understand why you're not supporting me.
Person2: I am supporting you, Rachel. But you need to be honest with yourself. You're not doing this for the right reasons.
Person1: And what are the right reasons? You're always so quick to judge me, to tell me what I'm doing wrong. But you never offer any solutions.
Person2: That's not true, Rachel. I'm trying to help you. But you're not listening. You're just trying to justify your own selfish desires.
Person1: My selfish desires? You're the one who's always playing games with me, always trying to manipulate me. Well, it's not going to work this time.

Person1: You know you can always step in, work with me full-time as one of my investigators.
Person2: Boy, do I know how you feel.  First time I heard that number, I said you got to be kidding me.  Forty God damn percent?
Person1: What're you talking about? You're not making any sense.
Person2: I'm talking about the commission you're offering me. It's an insult.
Person1: Oh, that. I didn't think you'd take it seriously. You're not exactly qualified for the job.
Person2: Qualified? You're the one who's been trying to get me to work for you for years. Now you're saying I'm not qualified?
Person1: Well, you're not exactly what I had in mind. But I suppose you could learn.
Person2: Learn? From you? You're just trying to manipulate me into working for you.
Person1: Manipulate you? Don't be ridiculous. I'm just trying to help you out.
Person2: Help me out? By offering me a job that pays peanuts? You're just trying to get me to do your bidding.
Person1: Fine, don't take the job. See if I care. But you're missing out on a great opportunity.
Person2: Opportunity? You call that an opportunity? You're just trying to use me for your own gain.

Person1: You're in a precarious situation. You realize that?
Person2: I know that we've definitely got something between us. Something good. Something special.
Person1: But you don't love me. You're just using me for your own gain.
Person2: I didn't say that. I mean, love, it's like a term that gets thrown around. People say things, they get married, have kids, and then what? It's like they call it off, going "I was wrong."
Person1: You're a master of manipulation, aren't you? You're trying to make me doubt my own feelings.
Person2: I'm just trying to be honest with you. You're the one who's being paranoid.
Person1: Paranoid? You're the one who's been playing games with me from the start. You're a clown, a jester, a trickster.
Person2: And you're a pawn in my game. But I'm not going to hurt you. I just want to show you the truth.
Person1: The truth? You're the one who's been poisoning my mind with your twisted words.
Person2: I'm just trying to free you from your own illusions. You're the one who's been living in a fantasy world.
Person1: Fantasy world? You're the one who's been creating this twisted reality. I see right through you.
Person2: Do you? Or are you just seeing what you want to see?

Person1: I've been thinking about your proposal, and I've decided to take it on. But don't say a word, I want to lay out the terms.
Person2: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this. What makes you think you can help me?
Person1: Let's just say I have a feeling about you. And I think I know where to find the information you need. But first, we need to get our priorities straight. We could go down and get the necessary documents tomorrow.
Person2: Tomorrow? You're moving awfully fast. I haven't even agreed to work with you yet.
Person1: Ah, but I think you will. You see, I've looked into your past, and I think I know what motivates you. You want to uncover the truth, and I can help you do that. But you need to trust me.
Person2: How do I know I can trust you?
Person1: You don't. But I'm willing to take a risk on you. And I think you'll find that I'm a man of my word. Now, shall we discuss the details of our little arrangement?

Person1: You're not doing anything wrong, are you? Just because you're stuck in this dead-end town, you can't go out?
Person2: What's the matter with you? Aren't you happy? You got everything you want. You're the star quarterback, the big hero.
Person1: It don't look right. You're supposed to be focused on the championship, not partying with strangers.
Person2: I'm 18 years old. I wanna enjoy my life. I love this town, but you don't know. It gets suffocating sometimes. I'm scared of being trapped.
Person1: Try to understand, Alex. You're a role model. You've got a lot of people counting on you.
Person2: That's right, take their part. You're the coach's son. You're never gonna understand what it's like to be in my shoes. I'm gonna finish my drink, and I'm gonna have a good time, because I ain't doing nothing wrong.
Person1: You're drinking with the wrong crowd right now. They're not good for you, Alex. They're gonna bring you down.
Person2: Ah hell, we can always do that. Listen, believe me, once we win the championship, your tone is going to change.

Person1: I'm telling you, we need to revamp our social media strategy. It's the only way to stay relevant in this market.
Person2: Oh, come on, Alex. What you're proposing is a big, brainless, waste of resources. No offense.
Person1: If you understood the data, you'd agree with me. Our current approach is stagnant and we need a change.
Person2: I get your point, but we can't just abandon our current strategy without considering the short-term consequences. Maybe we can find a middle ground?
Person1: Please, let's not sugarcoat this. We're trying to make a tough decision here. Who's going to take responsibility if we stick with the status quo?

Person1: You think I can't grab bulls' balls?
Person2: What's on your mind? Don't be dim.
Person1: I have no idea. You're not a journalist. You're not a reporter.
Person2: Every Tom, Dick, and Harry thinks he can write. But a journalist gets in there, right where the bombs are.
Person1: Your unfaithfulness -- that's what I'm trying to talk about. Your betrayal. Your dalliance.
Person2: Geller, you don't want a reporter's life. They're very--messy. You're all about order. Control.
Person1: It's a starting place. You've done five of my ideas.
Person2: What kind of faithfulness are you after? You know what separates us office flunkies from the reporters?
Person1: A flack jacket. You don't think I can be out of control?
Person2: Oh. Cahoon. Yeah, he's--good.

Person1: You know I can't do this. Mom will never let me go.
Person2: Let me take care of your mother. You just pack your bags.
Person1: But I've got responsibilities. I can't just leave everything behind.
Person2: Are you crazy? Love is not rational! You're overthinking this.
Person1: You're right. I'm crazy. You have driven me crazy. No one in their right mind would go to this much trouble to win over someone as insane as you.
Person2: Gee, I'm flattered. What an incredibly romantic gesture. But I need more convincing.
Person1: I swear on your life. I'll make it worth your while. You just have to trust me.
Person2: I don't believe you. You're just trying to manipulate me.
Person1: Maybe a little. But it's for your own good. You'll see.

Person1: You're crazy, but I think that's what draws me to you. You're a puzzle I'm eager to solve. Am I right in guessing you've never let anyone get close to you before?
Person2: What makes you think that?
Person1: Oh, it's easy. You're a little bit bad, a little bit crazy, and I can see the passion burning beneath the surface. But I'm not afraid of it. In fact, I'm intrigued. Would you like to take a chance on me and see where it takes us?
Person2: (pauses) I think I left something back at the...

Person1: You're out of your mind.
Person2: Listen to me. This time is different. There's more at stake than ever before.
Person1: Who do you think you are? I don't know you.
Person2: I worry about you. You're not thinking clearly.
Person1: You've lived with me for two years, but that doesn't mean shit.
Person2: How hard can it be? I've taken care of you for so long.
Person1: You're just trying to manipulate me, like you always do.
Person2: Oh, stop that. You know I'm only trying to help.
Person1: Help? You call this help? You're suffocating me.
Person2: Well, I won't be around forever, you know?

Person1: You're not taking this project seriously, are you? I've been noticing your lack of effort lately.
Person2: Here we go again. You think you can dictate how I work?
Person1: I'm only doing this for your own good. Sometimes you need someone to force you to take a step back and re-evaluate.
Person2: I appreciate your concern, but I need to make those decisions for myself. You're not my boss, nor my mentor.
Person1: Fine, but if you become any kind of an inconvenience, I'll have to take matters into my own hands. Don't think I won't do it.
Person2: Is that a threat? You're not even making sense. Just step off and let me do my job.

Person1: I've always been there for you, supporting your decisions.
Person2: But sometimes it feels like you're trying to relive your own past through me.
Person1: You're just like your mother... always so quick to doubt me.
Person2: I appreciate your guidance, but I need space to make my own mistakes too.
Person1: It's a terrible thing to know something no one else wants to believe... that you're not living up to your potential.

Person1: Dr. Lee, I'm worried about your diagnosis. We need to run some more tests to be sure.
Person2: Not unless you hear my concerns. I've been doing some research and I think you're overlooking some crucial factors.
Person1: I understand your concerns, but as a medical professional, I assure you that we're doing everything in the name of your health and well-being. If you don't submit to our authority, we'll have to consider involving your family in the decision-making process.
Person2: That's exactly what I'm afraid of. You're trying to manipulate me into doing what you think is best, without considering my autonomy.
Person1: I'm only trying to help you, Dr. Lee. But if you persist in refusing our help, then we'll have no choice but to take drastic measures. So, will you please reconsider and let us do what's best for you?

Person1: I really wish you'd stop trying to maneuver me. I find it irritating, not to mention insulting.
Person2: Oh, come on. I'm just trying to make it up to you. I can run out and get your favorite dessert.
Person1: No! No! You won't come back either. You're just trying to sweet-talk me into something.
Person2: That's not true. I promise I'll be back. Trust me.
Person1: Trust you? Because of trusting you, we're in this mess. Remember the deal we made?
Person2: That was different. This is just a small favor. I'll do something else to make it right.
Person1: What else? You're not playing very well. There are clues all around you, and you keep missing them.
Person2: You're just trying to confuse me. I know what I said, and I know what I'm doing.

Person1: You're being ridiculous.
Person2: Oh, so now you're an expert?
Person1: I was just kidding, don't be so sensitive.
Person2: Save it, I've had enough of your games.

Person1: I've prepared a special entertainment for you, my dear. A battle of wits, a clash of steel.
Person2: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this. It seems... unsavory.
Person1: Ah, but you were not hired for your conscience, were you? You were hired for your skill, your cunning.
Person2: That may be, but I still have a sense of right and wrong.
Person1: Right and wrong are for the weak. In this world, it's every person for themselves. And I will stop at nothing to get what I want.

Person1: You're not a real artist. You know it, I know it... but they don't know it. That's why we gotta make you look like a genius, somebody who'll create something amazing, somebody who isn't a failure.
Person2: But I've never even held a brush in my life!
Person1: You're not holding a brush, you're creating a masterpiece. Maybe we'd better go over the plan again. Where are you gonna be at 3 pm?
Person2: I'm going to be at the gallery.
Person1: And where am I gonna be?
Person2: In the crowd, with them.
Person1: You think you come to this city to be a famous artist? You think I spent all the money on your fake portfolio for nothing? Now you tell me you can't even pretend to be a painter?!?

Person1: You're building a case against me, aren't you? Following me, tracking my every move.
Person2: I'm just trying to understand you, like a ghost in your life. You're not making it easy.
Person1: You think you're clever, don't you? Trying to get inside my head, figure out what makes me tick.
Person2: Someone has to. You're not exactly forthcoming. You're like a father who's always absent, leaving your loved ones to wonder.
Person1: That's not fair. You don't know what you're talking about.
Person2: Don't I? I know you're hiding something. And I'll find out what it is, no matter how long it takes.

Person1: I would have time for my own pleasures!
Person2: Wayne, if it was anybody else---
Person1: The moon is almost gone!
Person2: I'll cut it in half. Four guys, but that's it.
Person1: At the first sight of the morning's rays' light...
Person2: Your own pleasure comes only after mine, when I desire it.
Person1: We got one...two...three...four ...five...six...seven...eight.
Person2: I am the Sole Ruler of the Dark World. There is no one to challenge my authority here.
Person1: I understand, Master.
Person2: Then see that it does not happen again, in the penalty of Everlasting Despair. Now are there others?

Person1: You're going to the Academy, and that's the end of it.
Person2: Maybe I didn't know what I wanted like you did. But I owe it to myself to make my own decisions. It's a quest, like finding my own identity.
Person1: Oh, is that how it is? You think you're old enough to make your own choices?
Person2: I'm eighteen. It's my decision. And I won't let you discourage me.

Person1: What did you say to them...?
Person2: I'm trying to help you.
Person1: How do they know that, you told them?
Person2: I didn't say anything to them.
Person1: Are you crazy? What are you doing?
Person2: I saw it. I was there.
Person1: You were there. At...at the meeting, right?
Person2: No, I was there when it happened.

Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: You're not blowin' your young career for me or anybody else, are you?
Person1: Stop acting like an infant. You're here because you want me to help you in some way. What do you need from me?
Person2: You got your ways to affect change, I have mine. And I would appreciate it very much if you took your field...I mean, your entitled ass out of my office.
Person1: You're your father's son, all right. You got it all worked out, don't you?
Person2: I'm talking 'bout me, your only business partner, ya own flesh and blood, hook a partner up, you know what I'm sayin'.
Person1: If you think I'm a house nigga, then that's your prerogative. You need money or something?
Person2: I never asked you for a goddamn thing! I've tried to make your business obligation as easy as possible. After the last project, did I ask you for anything? When I wouldn't see ya for six months to a year at a time, did you ever get your shit about it? No, it was always "OK", "No problem", "You're a busy person, I understand". The whole time you were a drunk, did I ever point my finger at you and talk shit? No! Everybody else did. I never did. You see, I know that you're just a bad business partner. You're not really very good at it. But I know you love the company. I'm basically a pretty resourceful guy. If I didn't really need it I wouldn't ask. And if you say no, don't worry about it. I'm gone. No problems.

Person1: You're not my therapist. You're here to study me. Face it, I'm nothing more than a lab rat to you.
Person2: Listen to me, baby, there are going to be beautiful people at this party tonight. You need to get out of that stuffy apartment.
Person1: A little less than yesterday. I don't know how much more of this I can take.
Person2: In other words, par for the course. You're making progress, but you need a break. That's why we're going to Vegas tonight.
Person1: What are you talking about? Vegas? You're not my therapist, you're just trying to distract me.
Person2: I'm trying to help you, Parker. You're getting too caught up in your own head. You need to let loose and have some fun.
Person1: Fun? You call this fun? You're just trying to manipulate me, to see how I react in different situations.
Person2: Maybe a little, but it's all part of the process. And who knows, you might actually have a good time. You didn't see the expression you had on your face when you were talking about the party. You kind of liked the idea, didn't you?
Person1: Go to hell. You're just trying to get inside my head.
Person2: That's not true, Parker. I'm trying to help you. But if you're not willing to meet me halfway, then maybe we're wasting our time.

Person1: You have no right to be here! This is my family's business.
Person2: I'm here to help you, but you need to listen. Your father is in grave danger. He's involved with some very dangerous people.
Person1: You're just trying to manipulate me. I know what you're after.
Person2: I'm trying to save your father's life. You owe it to him to listen. Don't let your pride get in the way of doing what's right.

Person1: I don't mean to be a prick, but that's how I feel.
Person2: Federation support, Federation procedures, Federation rules... look in the mirror, Senator... the people are tired of empty promises. They smell the scent of corruption on your administration. That's why you've embraced our offer... because it will give your dear career new life. Well, how badly do you want it, Senator? Because there are hard choices to be made now. If the truth gets out about your involvement in this scandal, your political allies will waver, your public image will be tarnished, your donors will want their say... need I go on?

Person1: You're hiding something from me, aren't you?  You're willing to do anything to keep your secrets safe.
Person2: Ah, but you're so curious, little one. You must show me your true intentions before I reveal mine.

Person1: I didn't hear you. What was that?
Person2: I said, "Don't wear that outfit again." You're not taking this investigation seriously.
Person1: I can't be expected to remember every detail eight years after the fact. You're just trying to distract me from the real issue.
Person2: The real issue is that you're not cooperating. And that outfit is a distraction. Wear a suit next time, something professional.
Person1: You're trespassing into areas that are none of your concern. Such showboating puts lives at risk.

Person1: I've brought you a unique opportunity, Senator -- one that will benefit us both greatly.
Person2: I'm not interested in your proposals, Mr. Blackwood.
Person1: This is a gift, really. You'll find it's an offer you can't refuse.
Person2: I refuse to be swayed by your empty promises.
Person1: Let me reassure you, Senator... I will make sure you're remembered as a visionary, just like the great leaders of the past.
Person2: You're not fooling anyone with your flattery, Blackwood. I know your true intentions.
Person1: Ah, but that's where you're wrong, Senator. I'm simply trying to encourage life... in a way that benefits us both.

Person1: You're afraid of the competition out there, aren't you?
Person2: What do you mean? I'm just trying to do the right thing.
Person1: Save it, Alex. I know your tricks. What happened to our project?
Person2: Don't worry, we did the right thing with it. It's on the level this time.
Person1: You're not pulling one of your old stunts, are you? I swear, if you're hiding something from me...
Person2: No, no, it's not like that. You're just being paranoid.

Person1: You're getting obvious.
Person2: I told you, I don't have them all. But I know you're hiding something.
Person1: What do you mean? You think I'm writing another book?
Person2: No, but you're not telling me the whole truth. You're using me, just like I used you.
Person1: That's not true. I'm trying to uncover the truth about my father.
Person2: Ah, your father. Yes, I knew him. We were old friends. But you're not ready for the truth yet.
Person1: You're just trying to manipulate me. Watch your back, because I'm not going to fall for it.
Person2: Oh, I'm shaking in my boots. Seeya soon, Gale.

Person1: You looked just like your mother... The first time I saw you at the party....
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. What do I owe you?
Person1: Oh, eleven twenty-five. But that's not what's important. It's a terrible thing to know something no one else wants to believe. You're trying to forget, aren't you?

Person1: I know this.
Person2: You're crazy. You've gone crazy.
Person1: I'm listening. What's wrong with you?
Person2: You're talking about giving up everything for some wine-pourer chick. Twenty-four hours and you think you're in love?
Person1: I trust my instinct. My intuition is all I have.
Person2: And what about your commitment to Rachel? She's a single mom, looking for stability.
Person1: That's the distinction. I haven't made the commitment yet. I'm not married.
Person2: You're asking me to trust you, but you don't even trust yourself. You're trying to convince me, but you're not convinced yourself.
Person1: What do you care anyway? You don't even like Rachel.
Person2: Of course I like Rachel. But I also know you're not thinking clearly. You're being impulsive and reckless.
Person1: You're just trying to manipulate me, to make me doubt myself. But I know what I want.
Person2: I'm trying to make you see reason. You're not thinking about the consequences of your actions.

Person1: You're a little ahead of yourself, don't you think?
Person2: I thought we were tight. You want me to die?
Person1: What, again? You're trying to impress me with your twisted mind?
Person2: Would that impress you? Is that what it takes to get what I want from you?
Person1: I didn't know we were going to make a deal. You're proposing a partnership, not a marriage.
Person2: I'll give you plenty of reasons to work with me as soon as I get what I need from you.
Person1: I think we ought to walk away from this conversation before it's too late.

Person1: I've been thinking, and I have one additional question for you, Detective.
Person2: Yes, sir?
Person1: Why did we not know about this sooner? You're supposed to be the best in the business.
Person2: Sir, I-
Person1: Please, spare me the excuses. I pay you to stay one step ahead, not to be caught off guard. You're not doing your job.
Person2: Sir, I can explain...
Person1: No, I don't think you can. You see, I've been watching you, and I think you're hiding something. You're not as innocent as you seem.
Person2: That's not true, sir!
Person1: Oh, really? Then perhaps the temptation to deceive would have been stronger... too strong perhaps? You're not as trustworthy as I thought.
Person2: Sir, I assure you...
Person1: Save it, Detective. I'm not buying it. You're going to have to do better than that if you want to keep your job.

Person1: You're going to openly be a troublemaker, aren't you?
Person2: I'm sorry, it's just that I think Okra asked me to marry him the other evening.
Person1: Rush your mouth, girl. No, he didn't. He cannot be that big of a damn fool.
Person2: I asked Harry about it. He didn't own up to it. He said he didn't know what got into Okra.
Person1: If I did, I probably wouldn't mind talking to the Geek Squad. But I'm not Mother Theresa, so surprise me gently with a chainsaw.
Person2: Everybody who has been associated with Harry ends up with pennies over their eyes. If it was left up to me, I would poison him.
Person1: What must I do?

Person1: You're doing this to spite me, aren't you!
Person2: Get someone to double for her, her face, the close-up scene, call L.A. I want to see some pictures of the women's profiles.
Person1: I'm very sorry, I...
Person2: You're very sorry, you passive aggressive, son-of-a-bitch...can we replace him? He's sick, he's going to die.
Person1: If he does it's his own fault! But I'm not burying that swollen bag of flesh. We're very upset with her.

Person1: I'm telling you, I've never seen that man before in my life. You must have gotten your information from a crazy person.
Person2: "Let all who love me follow me"... Where does God get mentioned? Come on, be honest. You fought for yourself, in your name.
Person1: What are you talking about? This has nothing to do with God. We're discussing a man named Lee Harvey Oswald.
Person2: I was defending myself as best I could! Everyone has the right to defend themselves, don't they? Or should I have let myself be killed?
Person1: No, no, I'm not talking about self-defense. I'm talking about your alibi for Friday. You said you went ice skating in Houston, but I think you're hiding something.
Person2: I... I was just trying to get away from the storm. I didn't do anything wrong.
Person1: The storm wasn't that bad, was it? And what about Galveston? Why did you really go there?
Person2: I told you, no particular reason. Just to go somewhere.
Person1: I see. And then Sunday? You went goose hunting, but you didn't bring any shotguns. Isn't that a bit difficult?
Person2: Oh, yes... I remember now. We got out there near the geese and it was only then we realized we'd forgotten our shotguns. Stupid, right?
Person1: I'm not buying it. I think you're lying to me. And I'm going to find out why.

Person1: I've had enough of your lies, Father.
Person2: You're not thinking clearly, my child. You're letting emotions cloud your judgment.
Person1: Emotions? You're the one who's been hiding the truth from me. I demand to know what happened to my sister.
Person2: Your sister is dead, and it's for the best. She was a prisoner, and it was a mercy killing.
Person1: A mercy killing? You expect me to believe that? I've seen the way you look at me, like I'm some kind of pawn in your game.
Person2: You're being paranoid. I'm only trying to protect you.
Person1: Protect me? By keeping secrets from me? By controlling what I know and what I don't know?
Person2: You're not ready for the truth. You're not strong enough to handle it.
Person1: That's not for you to decide. I want to know what really happened to my sister. And I want to know now.
Person2: Fine. If you want to know, I'll tell you. But don't say I didn't warn you.

Person1: You're telling me it's just a bunch of winos and bag ladies, but I saw them, Rachel. They were aiming right at me.
Person2: Oh, come on, Alex. You're not going to get married. You're a bachelor, and that's all you'll ever be.
Person1: What does that have to do with anything? You're trying to distract me from what's really going on here.
Person2: I'm trying to get you to focus on your life, Alex. You're letting fear control you.
Person1: Fear? You think I'm afraid of those...things? I'm telling you, they're not human.
Person2: Alex, you're a smart guy. You know as well as I do that it's just your imagination playing tricks on you. You're lonely, and you're letting your mind get the best of you.
Person1: Lonely? You think I'm lonely? You're the one who's always trying to set me up with someone, Rachel. You're the one who's always pushing me to go out and dance.
Person2: That's because I care about you, Alex. I want to see you happy.
Person1: Happy? You want to see me happy? You're the one who's been lying to me, Rachel. You're the one who's been telling me that everything is going to be okay, that it's all in my head. But I know what I saw.
Person2: Alex, stop it. You're being paranoid.
Person1: Paranoid? You're the one who's been manipulating me, Rachel. You're the one who's been trying to control me.

Person1: I don't remember. What do I owe you?
Person2: You owe me the truth, Rowan. Listen carefully, I've been waiting for this moment for a long time.
Person1: What are you talking about? Who are you?
Person2: Someone who knows your secrets. You've been living a lie, Rowan. And I'm here to reveal the truth.
Person1: What secrets? What lie?
Person2: Your whole life, Rowan. You've been manipulated, controlled. And I'm the one who can set you free.
Person1: I don't believe you. You're just trying to confuse me.
Person2: Am I? Or am I showing you the truth you've been too afraid to see? You owe it to yourself to listen, Rowan.
Person1: Fine. I'll listen. But if you're lying to me, you'll regret it.
Person2: I'm not lying, Rowan. And soon, you'll realize that I'm the only one who's been telling you the truth all along.

Person1: You're paying me to find your sister, not to sugarcoat the truth. She wasn't a saint, and I'm not here to make you feel better about it.
Person2: I don't think I like your tone, Mr. Reed.
Person1: You don't have to like it. You just have to pay me. I'm like a little animal, once I get my teeth into something, I never let go. If your sister's in trouble, I'll find her.
Person2: And what makes you think you're the only one who can do that?
Person1: I've been doing this a long time, kid. I've seen it all. You think you can handle the truth about your sister? You think you can handle the kind of people she's gotten herself mixed up with?
Person2: I can handle it.
Person1: We'll see about that. You want to play outlaw, kid? You want to ride into town with a posse at your back? Because that's what it's going to take to get your sister out of this mess.
Person2: I'm not afraid of a little danger.
Person1: You should be. You should be very afraid.

Person1: I've never been to a party like this before.
Person2: That's a good thing, isn't it? You're skating on thin ice already, so I wouldn't push my luck.
Person1: What do you mean? I thought this was just a normal gathering.
Person2: Normal? You're the only person I've ever invited. I want to see how you react when things get out of hand. Come on, don't be shy.
Person1: I don't know... I've never been in a situation like this before. How much can you really know about yourself if you've never taken a risk?
Person2: Exactly. And I'm here to help you take that risk. Now, let's get started.

Person1: You're a master of deception.
Person2: Almost as skilled as you, Agent. I'm surprised you didn't keep that evidence. It's going to be crucial in building a case against Richard Low.
Person1: I always get what I want, one way or another. Pity Koessler wants us to believe Low is Suspect Zero. It's a crackpot theory.
Person2: That's what they want us to think. But I've seen the burn marks, same as Karen Sumpter. Low is just a pawn in a larger game.
Person1: You're getting too close to the truth, Mack. I have to warn you, it's not safe to pursue this line of inquiry.
Person2: But it was your idea to investigate Low's alibi. Now you're trying to discredit me?

Person1: You're always taking his side.
Person2: I'm sick of it. I can't watch you this way.
Person1: I asked you to trust me on this one.
Person2: You and your brother are so much alike...
Person1: He ain't nothing like me. You're just trying to distract me.
Person2: I'm trying to make you see reason, but you're too blinded by anger.
Person1: You're just trying to protect him, like you always do.
Person2: I'm trying to protect you from yourself. You're going to end up hurting someone.
Person1: You're just trying to manipulate me, like you always do.
Person2: I'm trying to stop you from making a mistake.

Person1: You're taking all the fun out of this. I thought we had an understanding.
Person2: Wherever you go, I'll be watching. You can't escape me. If you try to leave, you'll regret it. Is that clear?
Person1: You're turning me into a prisoner. I used to be in control, but now I'm just a puppet on strings.
Person2: Then do me a favor and take care of our little problem. If not for me, then do it for yourself. You're better than this. You're letting fear hold you back.

Person1: I'm not sure I believe you. You're hiding something.
Person2: What are you talking about? I've told you everything.
Person1: No, you haven't. I can see it in your eyes. You're not telling me the whole truth.
Person2: Fine. If you must know, I did take that file from the office. But it was just a mistake, and I'm willing to return it.
Person1: A mistake? You expect me to believe that? You're not even a good liar.
Person2: Hey, I'm trying to be honest with you. You're the one who's being paranoid.
Person1: Paranoid? You're the one who's being deceitful. And I'm not going to let you get away with it. You're going to tell me everything, or there will be consequences.
Person2: Consequences? You're not my boss. You can't threaten me.
Person1: Oh, can't I? You'd be surprised what I can do. Now, are you going to tell me the truth, or do we need to take this further?

Person1: I think I'll tell her I found her number in a cab... 
Person2: ...and then ask if she remembers me. 
Person1: Yeah, I'll play it cool, like I'm not really interested. Then I'll ask what she's been up to lately. 
Person2: And when she starts to open up, you'll make a comment about how you're not looking for anything serious. 
Person1: Exactly! I'll make her think I'm not into her, and then she'll try to convince me otherwise. 
Person2: That's the idea. Make her think she's in control, and she'll be putty in your hands. 
Person1: You're a genius, Tee. But what if she sees right through me? 
Person2: Then you'll know she's not the one for you. But I think you'll be surprised at how well this works. Trust me, I've done it before.

Person1: I'm not scared of you, Victor.
Person2: Mayors come and go, and heirs tire easily. Really think a flyweight like you could last fifteen rounds with Muhammed Shreck?
Person1: That's your answer to everything, isn't it? And let me point out - pacifism is not something to hide behind.
Person2: If my life has had any meaning, that's the meaning. You're just trying to intimidate me, Victor.
Person1: I'm perfectly calm, and I know you're not. You're just taking it easy, as always.

Person1: I've got half the British government breathing down my neck. I don't have time for your nonsense.
Person2: You don't like it, do you? The way I'm always one step ahead of you.
Person1: Stop talking as if we were married! You're always trying to get under my skin.
Person2: Oh, you started it. You're the one who's been playing games with me from the beginning.
Person1: I just said I didn't feel like going along with your plan. It seems a little bit crude, that's all.
Person2: What about the way you've been manipulating me? That's just as crude, isn't it?
Person1: Oh well -- you've GOT to do what it takes to get ahead.
Person2: Why? Why have you got to go round manipulating people? Is it just to pay for your own ego?
Person1: To get what I want, of course. And I'll stop at nothing to get it.

Person1: You're afraid of the competition out there, that's why you're not asking her out.
Person2: I'm not scared, I just want to know where she's staying in Hawaii.
Person1: Oh, come on, you're so scared. You're killing me with the way you're towards me.
Person2: That's not fair. I just want to return her purse, she left it at my work.
Person1: Save it, I know exactly where she is. You're not fooling anyone with that excuse.
Person2: Please, just give me the number of where she's staying. I'm not going to bother her, I promise.
Person1: You're not growing old chasing after her, are you? You're not going to spend the rest of your life in a bathing suit, living off nickel and dime grants.
Person2: That's not what this is about. You're treating me like dirt, and I don't deserve it.
Person1: You want to be a bum all your life, be my guest. But don't come crying to me when you're dying from terminal crotch rot.
Person2: You're pushing me to the edge, Elizabeth. Just give me the number, or I'll...I'll...

Person1: I've heard of giving up finding a man and raising a family to pursue a career. And I've heard of foregoing a career to start a family-- but I think you're onto something new, Alex. "Absolutely nothing"-- Has a ring to it. I think it could catch on...
Person2: Oh, spare me the sarcasm, Rachel. We have to think this through. We have to be smart. Now is not the time to panic. If we panic now, we're done for.
Person1: You're one to talk, considering your track record. You're still reasonably pretty, but that's about it. The fact that you're still employed is the one thing you've got going for you.
Person2: That's it, I've had enough of your condescending tone. You're not even making sense. What does my job have to do with anything?
Person1: Everything, Alex. You're so caught up in your own mess that you can't see the bigger picture. We need to figure out our next move, and fast.
Person2: Our next move? You're the one who's been making all the wrong moves, Rachel. If you weren't so concerned with being right all the time, we wouldn't be in this situation.

Person1: You're playing with fire, Alex. Let her walk out of here before it's too late.
Person2: She's already in too deep, thanks to you. Now, if you care about her survival, you'll convince her to hand over the evidence. The clock is ticking, and I'm not known for my patience.

Person1: You tell me.
Person2: I'm not leaving without the truth.
Person1: You're gonna get hurt chasing after your damn secrets!
Person2: Maybe... someday. Not today.

Person1: I need to make a call, but I'm short on change. Can you help me out?
Person2: What's in it for me?
Person1: I'll owe you one, and I'm a man of my word. Just a second, let me check my pockets.
Person2: You're not going to find anything in there. You're always coming up short.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is, I need to make this call. And I'll do whatever it takes to make it happen.
Person2: Whatever it takes? You mean like breaking into the vending machine?
Person1: If that's what it comes to, then yes. I'll do what I have to do. You know I'm not a man to be trifled with.
Person2: I'm not afraid of you. But I'll help you out this time. Just don't think you can manipulate me into doing your bidding.
Person1: I'm not trying to manipulate you. I'm just trying to get what I need. And if you're smart, you'll help me and we can both come out on top.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's a trap. You're playing right into their hands.
Person2: Are you crazy, paranoid, or just stupid? Jaeger says you're crazy.
Person1: How do you know Jaeger? What's going on here?
Person2: I know everything about you, Alex. You're innocent, and I need you. Come with me, and I'll show you the truth.
Person1: What about my sister? Do you know where she is?
Person2: She's safe, for now. But if you don't come with me, she'll be the one who suffers.

Person1: Tell me, don't lie, or I'll know. What's holding you back from creating something truly remarkable?
Person2: I've never been given a fair shot. People don't understand my vision.
Person1: You're not keeping it real, brother man. You're trying to be someone you're not. I'm the one who knows what the people want.
Person2: That's not fair. You're not giving me a chance to prove myself.
