Person1: I'm giving you a chance, but you need to listen to me. I know what the majority of people in this country want. They're deaf, dumb, and blind, and they need to be led to the water. You need to create something that will make them sit up and take notice.
Person2: I'm not sure if I can deliver what you want. You're asking me to compromise my artistic vision.
Person1: You will, or you'll be back to where you started. I need a masterpiece, and I need it now. You have the talent, but you need to be guided. Trust me, I know what I'm doing.

Person1: You're using her as a smoke screen, aren't you? For your own fear.
Person2: My only fear is that you'll get in the way of what needs to be done. You're so blinded by your emotions, you can't see the bigger picture.
Person1: The bigger picture? You're the one who's willing to sacrifice everything for a cause that's already lost. That's not courage, that's desperation.
Person2: Desperation? You're the one who's desperate to hold on to something that's slipping away. And you'll do anything to keep it, even if it means putting everyone else at risk.

Person1: I'm only interested in your well-being.
Person2: Well, of course. You know I'll always be there to love and support you, no matter what kind of pickle you're in. But let's be real, you're not exactly making it easy for me.

Person1: I don't know, Rachel. I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this.
Person2: You're not comfortable? You think you're the one who has to live with the guilt of not trying? He's a McDermott, for crying out loud. He'd want to do this.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is, we're talking about a huge risk here.
Person2: A risk? You call this a risk? I call it a chance to make a difference. And if you're not willing to take that chance, then maybe you're not the person I thought you were.
Person1: Rachel, stop. Just stop. You're not going to guilt trip me into this.
Person2: I'm not trying to guilt trip you, I'm trying to make you see reason. And if you can't see it, then maybe you should get out of the way and let someone else take charge.

Person1: I'm counting on you, Detective. So you're investigating the mayor's office. Well, just watch your step, or they'll silence you permanently.
Person2: What do you mean, silence me? I'm just trying to do my job. I want to get to the bottom of this corruption scandal.
Person1: Who knows what you're gonna uncover in there? I don't want you to - Well, I'm not gonna let you dig too deep, the way you're behaving.

Person1: You know, I've been thinking, and I don't want that artist living in the studio anymore. If you want some free spirit messing up the place, that's your decision.
Person2: He's really talented, and he's been helping me with my projects.
Person1: Now, darling, I wasn't talking to you, was I? Was I? This is your decision, not his. I'm letting him stay because you asked me, not him.
Person2: And that's why you've got to get rid of this influence. If you keep him around, it'll just make you think how creative you are. It'll be a temptation to get back into your old habits.
Person1: Oh, so you're controlling my life for my own good? How very patronizing of you, sweetheart.

Person1: You don't love me.
Person2: Of course I do... I LOVE you. But I won't let it be like that! You want your freedom? Fine! It's yours!
Person1: What do you expect? You come in here, destroy my life, and try to control me...
Person2: No, I'm not saying I couldn't get to like you more... in fact... well, to be quite honest, I prefer it when there's some sort of mutual respect between two people...
Person1: You're damn right it's not like that! Because I won't let it be like that! You want to manipulate me? Fine! I'll play along!
Person2: I don't know what you want, but I'm not going to sit here anymore holding your hand until you figure it out!
Person1: Oh, get it over with. What's the point of this charade?
Person2: I want you to follow through on this, just so you can find out what a ridiculous idiot you are. And when you realize that, I want to laugh at you, right in your face...

Person1: I'm sorry, Alex. You're going out with Rachel. Duty calls. The City needs you.
Person2: I don't think a week's gonna do it. I'm a messed up and an outcast. There isn't one single person in my life I haven't hurt through my love.
Person1: You're killing me, you know that? You got no sick time according to Command. I've been told to terminate.
Person2: No! You swore you'd fire me if I came in late again. I'm the most dangerous person in the world, because if I love you, watch out, you're gonna get messed up, hurt, and left behind!
Person1: I'll fire you tomorrow. Hell, better than that, I'll forward you some sick time. A week, two weeks off-- how about that? You shoulda done what he did. Go home. Don't talk to the FBI anymore.
Person2: It's okay. I'll just get my things out of the locker. You know they won't do it. It's up to you. You gotta be strong.

Person1: I'm telling you, we need to reassess the marketing strategy. It's not yielding the desired results.
Person2: Rachel, I appreciate your input, but I've made my decision. Sometimes, it's best to follow orders and trust the process.
Person1: But don't you think it's crucial to evaluate all angles before investing more resources? We can't afford to waste any more time or money.
Person2: Rachel, you're too focused on the details. You need to think bigger picture. Nice gets you nowhere in this industry. You need to be willing to take risks and make tough calls.

Person1: I thought you were on top of our finances. The credit card company called me today.
Person2: I am, I paid the bill last week. Maybe it's an issue with the provider.
Person1: We need to be more responsible with these things. You're always saying you've got it under control, but somehow we always end up in trouble.
Person2: I've thought about us every second since we got into this financial mess. I can still remember the look on your face when we got denied for that loan.
Person1: Stop bringing that up. It's not relevant.
Person2: Why? Am I making you uncomfortable, or does the truth scare you? You know I've been trying to get us out of this hole, but you never seem to trust me.
Person1: Because I know you're full of promises, but I never see any action.
Person2: I mean it, I'm getting us out of this situation, and I want you to trust me. There's only one way to do that.
Person1: Are you sure? About getting us out of this, I mean?
Person2: I've had nothing but time to think about it. It keeps coming back to you and me and us getting back on our feet. But we've got to work together, baby. We get the right financial plan, I get a new job, then we get back on track.

Person1: I've been thinking, and I believe we're on the same page.
Person2: You're a master of deception, aren't you? You've been playing us all along.
Person1: That's a ridiculous accusation. You're just trying to discredit me because you're threatened by my influence.
Person2: Influence? You mean like the way you've been poisoning the team's mind against me? Low calls you Suspect Zero, and I'm starting to think he's right.
Person1: Oh, so now you're taking advice from a crackpot like Low? You're not thinking clearly, my friend.
Person2: I'm thinking more clearly than ever. You're the one who's been hiding behind a mask of innocence, manipulating everyone to get what you want.

Person1: I thought we had a stronger bond. You're always coming to me with your problems, but this time you went behind my back.
Person2: I just needed some perspective, that's all. I wanted everything to be perfect, not shitty and broken like everyone else's relationships.
Person1: You're not even considering my feelings. I'm the one who's always been there for you when things get tough. Communication is key, remember?
Person2: Yeah, but didn't you care about me once? If you cared once, you can care again, I know it. My friend Rachel has gone out with the same guy, like, three times.
Person1: That's not the point. We're just not on the same page anymore. And by the way, I'm not old, I'm just more experienced.
Person2: Yeah, but experience doesn't fix everything. Sometimes it's hard to approach someone directly, especially when they're not trying to understand.

Person1: I know what I'm doing, Alex. Trust me.
Person2: But I don't gamble, Rachel! You're not thinking clearly.
Person1: Of course you're innocent, Alex. You couldn't do those terrible things.
Person2: Wait a minute, Rachel. Have you got that money?
Person1: The five hundred? Sure. But I need you, Alex. I know you're innocent.
Person2: On second thought, would you let me have it? I'll get the tickets.
Person1: Believe me, Alex, I know what I'm doing. He'd get you in a crap game --
Person2: I know a lot of men who didn't do anything till they met Victor. Please, Rachel.
Person1: All right. One -- two -- three -- four -- five. Five hundred. Be careful, Alex.

Person1: You're going to die alone, just like your father.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: It means you're not taking care of yourself. You're not putting yourself out there. You're going to end up a lonely old man.
Person2: That's not true. I'm happy with my life.
Person1: Happy? You call this happy? You're stuck in a dead-end job, you have no friends, and you're still living with your mother. You're not even trying to change your life.
Person2: I am trying. I just need a little more time.
Person1: Time? You've had all the time in the world. You're just making excuses. You're afraid of taking risks, of getting hurt. You're afraid of living.
Person2: That's not fair. You don't know what it's like to be me.
Person1: I don't need to know what it's like to be you. I can see it. You're surrendering to your fears, to your doubts. You're giving up on yourself.
Person2: Stop it. Just stop.
Person1: No, I won't stop. I'll keep telling you the truth until you listen. You're better than this. You can be more than this.

Person1: You're on leave, man. You're on psycho leave. I'm talking to a possible whacko here.
Person2: That wasn't the deal. I think you're trying to back out of our agreement.
Person1: So, sue me. Things have changed. I've got a new proposal for you, but you need to calm down first.
Person2: I'm not leaving without a guarantee. You're playing games with me, and I don't appreciate it.
Person1: Don't push me, Rachel. I might lose my temper and reveal some secrets just for spite.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly, are you?
Person2: I'm thinking more clearly than you are. You're the one who's been lying to me.
Person1: I've never comped you at the club, have I?
Person2: Don't play dumb with me. I know what you're capable of.
Person1: If I were in your shoes, I'd be worried about my sister. Have you forgotten about her?
Person2: You're trying to distract me, but it won't work. I know you're hiding something.
Person1: I'm trying to help you, but you're not listening. You're too busy accusing me of things I didn't do.
Person2: I'm not accusing you of anything. I'm just telling you the truth. You're the one who's been lying to me from the start.

Person1: Dr. Lee? I'm so sorry to disturb you, but I was wondering...
Person2: Can't help it, Rachel... family sticks together... You know how it is.
Person1: Yes, of course. I just wanted to ask about the new treatment...
Person2: WHAT'S THAT SUPPOSED TO MEAN? You think I'm not doing enough for my brother?
Person1: Oh, no, no, Dr. Lee... I didn't mean to imply that...
Person2: Imply? You're implying I'm not taking care of him properly!

Person1: You tell me, don't you think it's a bit suspicious that you're always so secretive about your writing process?
Person2: Uh huh. Well, thanks for the thought, but I'm not the first writer to have a few secrets up their sleeve. And furthermore, it might interest you to know that one book I wrote, without anyone's input, happened to win a little something called the Pulitzer Prize.
Person1: Yeah, yeah, I've heard that one before. But I'm not buying it. I think you're hiding something, and I'm going to figure out what it is.
Person2: Oh, I'm shaking in my boots. You know, I've seen more convincing detective work from a high school freshman.

Person1: You look very good in the sun... I'm glad we're doing this today.
Person2: I'm not doing it for you, I'm doing it because I need to get out of the house.
Person1: Oh, come on. It's not every day I get to spend time with someone as charming as you.
Person2: Save it. What's the real reason you invited me?
Person1: Can't a guy just want to be nice? You're always so suspicious.
Person2: That's because I know people like you. You always want something in return.
Person1: Maybe I just want to make you happy. Would that be so bad?
Person2: You're not going to get anything from me, so don't even try.
Person1: Fine. But I'm still going to make you a great cup of coffee. My sister's coming by to pick me up for brunch, why don't you come too?
Person2: I have work to do. And don't try to butter me up with coffee.

Person1: I'm so happy for you, darling. You look stunning in that red dress.
Person2: Save it, sweetheart. I know you're just trying to butter me up so you can take over for me. Well, I've got news for you - I'm not going anywhere.
Person1: Oh, come on! Let's drive to the beach and celebrate. It's only a short drive, and the rain will clear up once we hit the coast.
Person2: You really think I'm that naive? You're just trying to get me out of the way so you can take control. Well, it's not going to work.

Person1: You're lying. I know you're hiding something from me.
Person2: Why should I? You're just going to assume the worst anyway.
Person1: That's not fair. I'm trying to have an open and honest conversation with you.
Person2: Like you did with Rachel? You compared me to her, remember? Said I wasn't as spontaneous as she was.
Person1: That was different. This is about us, about our future together.
Person2: Our future? You mean the one you've already planned out without even consulting me?

Person1: You're not going to find anyone like her, trust me. You need a change of scenery.
Person2: I don't know... I got a lot on my plate right now.
Person1: Listen to me, baby. We're going to have some fun tonight. I've got a connection at this new club downtown.
Person2: I'm not in the mood for some loud music and fake people.
Person1: You're not going to find what you're looking for stuck in that apartment. You need to get out, meet some new people. It'll do you good.
Person2: You're not listening to me. I'm not looking for anyone right now.
Person1: Tell me something, are you stupid or just stubborn? You're not going to find what you're looking for if you don't put yourself out there.
Person2: That's not fair. You're not even trying to understand where I'm coming from.
Person1: I understand exactly where you're coming from. You're stuck in a rut and you need someone to shake things up. That someone is me. Now, are you in or out?

Person1: You're hurting. I can see it in your eyes.
Person2: What do you want from me, Detective James? I've told you everything I know about my brother's disappearance.
Person1: I want the truth. And I think you're hiding something. You're not telling me everything, are you?
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. You're just trying to confuse me, to make me doubt myself.
Person1: Am I? Or am I just trying to uncover the truth? You're the one who's been lying to me from the start. I can sense it. And I warn you, if you don't come clean, you'll be the one who'll end up hurting.

Person1: You're going places, aren't you? I can see it in your eyes. You're going to win your way into the lives and hearts of people.
Person2: (laughs) You're just trying to butter me up, but it won't work. I know what you're really after. You want a piece of my success, don't you?
Person1: (smiling) Oh, I'm not interested in your success. I just want to be around people who are going somewhere. And I can tell you're going to make it big. You have that certain charm.
Person2: (skeptical) Save it. You're just trying to get close to me so you can ride my coattails. Well, it's not going to happen. I don't need people like you holding me back.
Person1: (leaning in) Oh, I think you do. You see, I have a lot to offer. I can help you navigate the social ladder, introduce you to the right people... (winking) You know, help you win their hearts.

Person1: Who the hell do you think you are? You go around here expecting applause for the way you treated this child.
Person2: I don't know what I take you for anything... I'm sure you mean something by that, but I don't know what.
Person1: It's possible - even conceivable - that you've confused me with that naive little girl you've been playing tricks on. That you have the same contempt for me that you have for her?
Person2: I never intended you to be. But you're not as innocent as you seem, are you?
Person1: Look closely, it's time you did. I'm nobody's fool. Least of all - yours.

Person1: I'm telling you this now, so that you can get your things together, Alex. It's my business, and I need you to take over the daily operations.
Person2: You're going to get hurt, Rachel, if you don't listen to me. I can't do that, not with the current financial situation.
Person1: Don't threaten me, Alex. I'm your sister, and I know you're capable of making this work.
Person2: Rachel, honey, the condition of the business is serious. It's going to cost so much to get it back on track. We just won't have the money to keep it afloat if you don't let me help.

Person1: You look very good in the sun... I've been following you for weeks.
Person2: What do you want? Why are you still following me?
Person1: Please, I love you. I know we were meant to meet.
Person2: Go away. You're not very special.
Person1: I've seen the way you work at the plant. You're talented. I can help you with your projects.
Person2: What do you know about my work?
Person1: I've been watching you. I know you're struggling to meet the deadlines. Let me help you.
Person2: I don't need your help. And I don't trust you.
Person1: You have to trust me. I'm the only one who can help you now. You're in danger, and I'm the only one who can protect you.
Person2: What are you talking about? What danger?
Person1: You'll see. Just come with me, and I'll show you.

Person1: I've got the information. If you ever want to see your project funded, do exactly what I say.
Person2: What makes you think I need your help?
Person1: Don't play dumb, Dr. Lee! I know about the breakthrough you've been hiding. You'll shut up and come with me if you want to find out even a little about what's really going on in this industry.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: Don't bullshit me! I have evidence of your secret meetings with the rival company. You'll bring the research to my office at five o'clock and come alone. If you don't, we'll expose your little secret to the board.
Person2: This is blackmail.
Person1: Call it what you want. But trust me, you don't even have an inkling of a hint of a clue as to what's really at stake here. Now, are you going to cooperate or do we do this the hard way?

Person1: I do. But you must trust me for now.
Person2: You think I'm an idiot? Remember our first meeting?
Person1: It was implanted by the Agency. Our whole relationship is a fabrication.
Person2: Bullshit. I remember how we fell in love, how we laughed together.
Person1: That's exactly what they want you to think. It's all part of the programming.
Person2: Our friends, our memories, our life together... it's all real to me.
Person1: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to hurt you. But you have to see the truth.
Person2: The truth is, I love you. And I won't let them take that away from me.

Person1: You're so giving. It's not a criticism. We love you. We're grateful.
Person2: THAT is your way of saying I'm too self-sufficient, isn't it? You think I'm not vulnerable enough for you.
Person1: Watch your tone, please. I didn't mean to imply that.
Person2: Oh, wow! You're trying to control the narrative again. I'm not buying it. You resent me for being independent.
Person1: I don't want to have this conversation. I didn't do anything wrong.
Person2: Exactly, you didn't do anything wrong. You just want to keep me in a box, don't you?

Person1: I've been thinking, and I believe we should rebrand our company to appeal to a more environmentally conscious audience.
Person2: Oh God, not another one of your harebrained schemes, Alex.
Person1: It's not about being smart, Rachel. It's about staying relevant in a changing market.
Person2: If you really want to do something for me, you can stop pushing this idea right now.
Person1: I'm not trying to manipulate you, Rachel. I just think this is the right move for the company.
Person2: Maybe we should get more opinions before making any drastic changes.

Person1: You're afraid of meeting someone like me, aren't you? It might be real, so you sabotage it with some excuse about being too busy with work.
Person2: I haven't decided what I want yet. I'm still figuring things out.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. You're not as innocent as you seem. You're just trying to avoid getting hurt again, so you put up this facade of being unsure. But I see right through it. You want to be in control, don't you? You want to be the one calling the shots.
Person2: That's not fair. You don't know me.
Person1: Oh, I know you better than you think. You're just like all the others, trying to manipulate people into doing what you want. But I'm not afraid of you. I see your games, and I'm not going to play along.

Person1: I'm telling you, Rachel, I had no idea what I was getting myself into with that business deal.
Person2: You're lucky to have someone like me looking out for you, Alex. Not everyone has your best interests at heart.
Person1: I know, but sometimes I feel like you're trying to control every aspect of my life. I'm not a child, Emily.
Person2: I'm just trying to protect you from yourself, Alex. You're impulsive and reckless. If I didn't step in, who knows what kind of trouble you'd get into?
Person1: That may be true, but it feels like you're suffocating me. Can't you just trust me to make my own decisions for once?
Person2: Trust you? Alex, you're not even capable of taking care of yourself, let alone making smart business decisions. I'm doing this for your own good, whether you like it or not.

Person1: You know what I want to do?
Person2: Look, I'm not stupid. I know everything that goes on in this building.
Person1: What do I want to do?
Person2: You want to get close to me, but you can't get close to me.
Person1: Why?
Person2: Because, you know why. You know. You're trying to figure out my secrets.
Person1: Because you're hiding something and I don't want no part of it.
Person2: You think I'm hiding something? When you're with me, you don't have to worry about that kinda stuff.
Person1: Why is that?
Person2: Because I like you. I think you're clever. I think if we were together, you would love it. You wouldn't even believe it.
Person1: I wouldn't believe it?
Person2: I don't know. I just think that you would love it. But, I don't know. I'm just scared that things would change. Between us.
Person1: What things? I'm telling you, nothing's going to change. I want to make you happy. That's all.

Person1: I'm not going to listen to your warnings, Dr. Patel. I've made up my mind.
Person2: You're not thinking clearly, Rachel. You've been under a lot of stress lately. Maybe you should take some time to reconsider.
Person1: I don't need your opinion, and I certainly don't need your medicine. I know what I'm doing.
Person2: Fine, but if you're not careful, it'll destroy your relationship with Michael. He's deeply in love with you, and if he finds out, it'll break his heart.

Person1: You're always so concerned about what others think, Rachel. I'll tell you what - let's sneak out and have some real fun.
Person2: You're just trying to get a rise out of me, aren't you, Michael? Like you always do.
Person1: Oh, come on. I'm just trying to show you a good time. You're always so caught up in your little world of "importance".
Person2: That's not fair, Michael. You know I've introduced you to some amazing people, and you always manage to insult them somehow.
Person1: Ah, they're just jealous of my creativity. You're the one who's always holding me back, Rachel. You're so afraid of taking risks.
Person2: That's not true! You're the one who's always trying to manipulate me into doing what you want. I'm sick of it, Michael.
Person1: Oh, poor Rachel. Can't handle a little excitement in her life. Maybe I should just leave you to your boring little parties and your "important" friends.
Person2: Maybe you should. At least then I wouldn't have to worry about what kind of trouble you'll get us into next.

Person1: You're my responsibility now. I don't want you hurt. You understand?
Person2: What do you want from me? I'll do anything.
Person1: I want you to trust me. This is a delicate situation, and I need you to follow my lead. You lose control, you get hurt.
Person2: Fine. But I'm not going to surrender without a fight.
Person1: That's exactly what I'm counting on. Now, let's go inside and get this over with.

Person1: You're no seeker. You're negative. You thought life on Earth was meaningless. You despised people. So what did you do? You ran away.
Person2: They're gonna kill us. They get us across the border, they're gonna take us out in the desert and shoot us.
Person1: I'd like to know why you're so afraid of death. You're not prepared to die, but you're willing to risk everything to escape.
Person2: If they get over the border, they're gonna let us go. But I don't trust them. I've seen those reality shows. They never let anybody go.
Person1: You're letting fear control you. You're not thinking clearly. I know exactly what I'm doing. You're going to have to trust me on this.
Person2: Trust you? You're the one who got us into this mess. I'd rather take my chances with the cops. At least they're honest about wanting to kill us.

Person1: You're the only one I trust. 
Person2: I saw the messages on your phone. Why didn't you tell me about the project? 
Person1: Oh God, I'm no more than a pawn to you. 
Person2: You're the only one who can help me. 
Person1: Then do me a favor. If the company's going to go bankrupt, it shouldn't matter a bit. I want you to give me a chance to fix it. 
Person2: I won't do that. 
Person1: You have the power to do it. I want you to do it. Please. 
Person2: I explained this. I can't. That's not the way it happens. 
Person1: If you ever cared for me  if there's anything human left in you  then do it.

Person1: You're afraid of him, aren't you? You're just like the rest, trapped in his web of deceit.
Person2: Dr. Elara would say we're all prisoners of our own fears. But I've broken free, Rachel. I see the big picture now.
Person1: The big picture? You mean the one where he controls everyone's minds? Get him away from her, he's responsible for everything!
Person2: Rachel, you're not thinking clearly. You're letting your emotions cloud your judgment. I'm trying to help you see the truth.
Person1: The truth? You call this the truth? He's using you, just like he's using everyone else. Wake up, can't you see what's happening?
Person2: I've woken up, Rachel. I've seen the light. And I'm trying to show you the way. But you're too blinded by your own fears to listen.

Person1: You're through, Alex!
Person2: What do you mean? You can't just leave me like this. Some freak'll come by and take advantage of me!
Person1: I mean I'm scratching your name off the project and running Rachel in your place. It's nothing personal. And, Alex, it's the only way out.
Person2: Rachel? You're kidding me! She's not even qualified for this.
Person1: Now, Alex, please don't appeal to my sentimental side. You know as well as I do that this is the best decision for the company.
Person2: But what about our team? We've worked together for years. You're just going to throw all that away?
Person1: If there was any way out, I'd take it. But this is the only way to save the project.

Person1: I've told you, it wasn't an accident. It was a deliberate act of sabotage.
Person2: Desperate times call for desperate measures, Detective James. Perhaps I need to remind you of your situation.
Person1: You'd be surprised what horrors people are capable of. I've seen it before.
Person2: Did you see the wreckage? Did you talk to the investigators?
Person1: I really don't know. But I'm certain that if someone were capable of such destruction, we'd have seen some evidence by now.
Person2: You really think I'm lying, don't you? You think I'm trying to cover something up.
Person1: Believe me, I've seen it before. People will do anything to avoid taking responsibility. And if you'd just cooperate, we might be able to get to the bottom of this.

Person1: You don't understand. I want to be surprised...astonish me, darling, new info, don't care where or how you get it, just get it...
Person2: How about it? I've got something that'll blow your mind. I've been digging into the company's financials, and I think I've found a way to increase profits by 20%.
Person1: That's cute, but I need something more. You see, I've been watching you, and I think you've got potential. But you need to prove yourself to me.
Person2: Prove myself? You're the one who's been playing games with me from the start. I don't know what you want from me, but I'm not going to play along.
Person1: Oh, come on. I'm just trying to help you reach your full potential. And I think I can do that. I can make you rich, darling. Rich enough that you can afford anything you want.
Person2: Anything I want? You mean like you? Is that what you're offering me?
Person1: Well, I suppose you could say that. But let me tell you, it's not all it's cracked up to be. There's a price to pay for power, and it's not always worth it.
Person2: I'll take my chances. What do I need to do to get in on the action?
Person1: Ah, I like your spirit. I'll give you a task. Get me the latest sales figures from our competitor, and we'll talk about taking it to the next level. And remember, power is the best aphrodisiac.

Person1: You're not like me, are you? You're not a puppet.
Person2: I'm sorry already. I've made my mistakes.
Person1: Mistakes? Ha! You think you're in control, but you're just a pawn. Find yourself a way out of this game before it's too late.
Person2: You're trying to confuse me, aren't you? Make me doubt myself.
Person1: Doubt is the first step to freedom. Or is it the first step to madness? You'll have to figure that out for yourself.

Person1: Remember eventually revenge is carefully... Have you tried juxtaposing the words?
Person2: Who else would I be talking to? And take that thing off!
Person1: It isn't him. You brought me in on this in the beginning because you wanted my opinion if he was capable of doing this.
Person2: I'm not interested in your smart ass remarks now, lady. Let's go. Right now. You and I can discuss it on the walk home.

Person1: You're really going to leave with him?
Person2: Yes, I am. How do you think I know he liked...
Person1: But you said you were committed to me! You never mentioned him!
Person2: That's because I didn't want to hurt you. We didn't have relations, but we fooled around.
Person1: Oh my God! Why did you lie to me?
Person2: I didn't lie. I just didn't tell you everything.
Person1: No, not tomorrow, not next week, tell me the truth today.
Person2: Why the change? What about your jealousy?
Person1: It was misguided and pointless. Is your answer the truth?
Person2: It is.
Person1: We'll leave this conversation, right after you tell me. Pack only what you need to know.
Person2: Does this have something to do with that girl you saw?
Person1: Yes. We're in danger of losing each other. Every moment we stay in the dark.
Person2: Trust me, I'll tell you everything.

Person1: You're not going to get away with this, Alex. You've got to take responsibility for your actions.
Person2: I didn't mean to, it just happened. I was lured into it.
Person1: Don't give me that. You're not some weak little thing that can be lured into anything. You're a strong, capable person. Now say it - "I made a mistake and I'll own up to it".
Person2: Fine... "I made a mistake and I'll own up to it".
Person1: That's better. Now, are you going to prove yourself to me, or do I need to take matters into my own hands?

Person1: You're afraid of me. You're afraid that I won't love you back.
Person2: What are you talking about? We're just discussing the project.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I know you're hesitant because you think I'll find out something about you that I don't like.
Person2: That's not it at all. I just think we should focus on the task at hand.
Person1: You're not being honest with me. You're taking bribes, and skimming busts and letting hoods walk.
Person2: What? No, that's not true. You're just trying to distract me from the real issue.
Person1: The real issue is that you're afraid to take a risk. You're stuck in your safe little world where nobody challenges you.
Person2: That's not fair. You're the one who's trying to manipulate me into doing what you want.
Person1: I'm just trying to get to the truth. You're the one who's hiding something.
Person2: I'm not hiding anything. You're just trying to make me feel guilty so I'll do what you want.
Person1: Maybe I am. But it's because I care about you and I want what's best for you.
Person2: Save it. I'm not buying it.

Person1: You're bound to me, just like Father was. Remember, you can't talk about this to anyone.
Person2: THAT's not what I signed up for. My loyalty has limits, and you're pushing them.
Person1: Watch your tone, servant. You're not in a position to make demands.
Person2: Why don't you just admit what this is really all about? You're trying to control me, just like you controlled Father.

Person1: I've always been good at reading people, but with you, I'm not so sure. You're like a puzzle I can't quite figure out.
Person2: That's because I'm not a puzzle, darling. I'm the one who's trying to uncover the truth about you. And I think I'm getting close.
Person1: You don't understand, I can get us out of this situation if you just listen to me.
Person2: Oh, I'm listening. But I'm not buying what you're selling. You're trying to manipulate me, and it's not going to work.
Person1: I'm not trying to manipulate you, I'm just trying to help us both. But you're not making it easy.
Person2: That's because I've met people like you before. People who think they can control the conversation, who think they can make others say and do what they want. But I'm not that easy to control.

Person1: You're not going to back down, are you? You promised me...
Person2: I don't recall making any promises. You must be mistaken.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I know you're hiding something. You want to talk to someone, don't you?

Person1: I don't think you should be involved in this, Mrs. Thompson.
Person2: He's a master of deception, a chameleon who has fooled even the most discerning minds. But who has he really harmed, besides perhaps himself?

Person1: You owe me, Rachel. I got you the job, and now it's time to return the favor. Ho ho ho.
Person2: I don't know, Alex. I'm not comfortable with this. I just got out of a bad situation.
Person1: Nonsense, you're perfect for this. And if you don't do it, I'll make sure everyone knows what really happened at your old company.
Person2: That's not fair, Alex. You're blackmailing me.
Person1: I'm just reminding you of your obligations. Now, are we going to do this or not?

Person1: I'm trying to keep emotions out of this. Even though this is an important issue to me and I have strong feelings about the subject.
Person2: What subject? You're not making any sense. You're just a punk, always causing trouble.
Person1: I've seen you around before. You're always getting into fights. Did you know the kid who got hurt?
Person2: No, I didn't know him. But I know something awful happened to him. I have to find out what it was.
Person1: You're not going to find out anything from me. I didn't see anything. I was just walking by and saw him lying in the street.
Person2: Wait a minute. You're not telling me the truth. You're hiding something. What did you take from the statue?
Person1: I didn't take anything! You're just trying to manipulate me into saying something I didn't do.
Person2: I'm not trying to manipulate you. I just want to know the truth. You're acting suspiciously, and I think you know more than you're letting on.

Person1: I'm not asking you anything. I'm telling you what I'm going to do! You need a sponsor; I have influence. I could sponsor you.
Person2: And you think I will permit this, my friend? Why would you help me?
Person1: You've got to permit it! Whose fault is it that no one comes here? You bowl with soul, and I like that. I think I could help you, Theo.
Person2: I like the sport the way it is. I'm not sure I want to adapt to survive.
Person1: A guy like you could breathe some fire into this place. You got ambition like a...like a...blowtorch. You go for what you want and anything that gets in your way - PSSSHHT! - shish kebabs. Maybe lady fate washed you up on my doorstep for your own good.

Person1: You're not good enough to beat me, you little shit. I've seen better players at the amateur level.
Person2: That's rich coming from someone who's been cheating this whole time. You're just trying to distract me.
Person1: Cheating? Ha! You're the one who's desperate. I'm just pointing out the obvious - you're not worthy of playing at this level.
Person2: And I'm pointing out that you're trying to get inside my head. It won't work. I've seen players like you before.
Person1: Players like me? You mean winners? Champions? You're just mad because you know you're going to lose.
Person2: I'm not mad, I'm focused. And I'm going to take you down.

Person1: I know you think you're not ready, but trust me, you are. Marry me, and I'll show you the world. We'll have the perfect life, and I'll make sure you're happy.
Person2: Romance is just a vestigial biological response to procreation. You're not fooling anyone with your empty promises.
Person1: Ah, but that's where you're wrong. I can offer you so much more than just romance. I can offer you power, status, and a life of luxury. And who knows, maybe we'll even grow to love each other.
Person2: I'd rather die than be with someone as manipulative and controlling as you. You're just trying to use me for your own gain.
Person1: Oh, come now. I'm not that bad. And think of all the perks you'll get. You'll be the envy of all your friends. And who knows, maybe I'll even throw in a car and free parking.

Person1: You can't pretend no more on that. I was just a kid, and you let him do it.
Person2: What are you talking about? I trust you.
Person1: Of course you do. I trusted my father too. But men are pigs, and they do what they want. You're being naive.
Person2: That's not fair. You're not my mother, and I won't let you guilt trip me.
Person1: Oh, I'm not trying to guilt trip you. I'm just telling you the truth. You're blind to what's really going on, and it's going to hurt you in the end.

Person1: I've just come from the meeting. The contract has been awarded. 
Person2: Awarded? That's impossible! They haven't even seen our proposal. We need this deal. Please, can't you help us? Please!
Person1: My dear colleague, there is no one in the company I would rather help, but now it is too late.
Person2: Whom did they choose? 
Person1: NovaTech. 
Person2: NovaTech? NovaTech? But they're a total mediocrity. 
Person1: No, no, no. They have yet to achieve mediocrity. 
Person2: But we can't lose this contract, we simply can't! Let's go to the meeting room, and you can explain to the CEO that NovaTech is an awful choice. They could actually do harm to our reputation!
Person1: An implausible idea. Between you and me, no one in the company could do harm to our reputation. You have a problem, colleague. Somewhere along the line, one of your bones broke, and your mind just broke with it.

Person1: I'm telling you, Emily, it's for your own good. You have to trust me on this.
Person2: I don't know... I feel like I'm being manipulated. You're not telling me the whole truth.
Person1: Of course I am. I just want to protect you from those people. They're not what they seem.
Person2: But why can't I see my sister? You promised me she'd be here by now.
Person1: She's being taken care of, I assure you. You just need to focus on getting out of here safely.
Person2: I don't believe you. You're just trying to control me.
Person1: Emily, I'm trying to help you. You're not thinking clearly. You're letting your emotions cloud your judgement.
Person2: That's not true! I know what I saw. I know what I heard.
Person1: What you think you saw and heard is not what really happened. You're just confused. Let me help you straighten things out.
Person2: No... I don't think so. I'm not going to play along with this anymore.
Person1: Fine. But you're making a big mistake. You're going to regret this.

Person1: You're under arrest. You've got information inside that head of yours, and I need you to spill it.
Person2: No way. I wouldn't even know where to begin! You think I'm some kind of mind reader?
Person1: C'mon, Alex, you've been playing both sides for years. I know you've got connections. Now, I need you to hack into her thoughts.
Person2: You can't kill me, Rachel. I've got something going down tonight, and only I can stop it. You'll drive your team nuts trying to figure it out.
Person1: Mention my team once more, and you're going down for obstruction. I've got evidence, Alex. You're not as slick as you think you are.
Person2: Evidence? Ha! You've got nothing. And even if you did, I've got a plan B. You'll be the one who's left looking like a fool.

Person1: You'd say anything to keep me away from her. To keep her for yourself.
Person2: You're a great artist, maybe my best. You're not a curator.
Person1: You've done five of my exhibitions.
Person2: You know what separates us gallery assistants from the curators?
Person1: They don't have to attend the gallery's Christmas party?
Person2: A vision. A sense of risk-taking.
Person1: And you don't think I can take risks?
Person2: You don't want a curator's life. They're very...unpredictable. You're all about control. Order. And getting me the exhibition catalog by Friday.
Person1: Hey, I can be unpredictable. She wants to kill you.
Person2: Her name is Sophia Patel. I saw her talking to the museum director. She must have stolen his trust, altered the exhibition's theme...

Person1: "You're playing with fire here. If you think you can outsmart me, you're wrong."
Person2: "I'm sick, that's what I've been telling you. You know what I want, it's not that difficult."
Person1: "Get out! Get out before I expose you to everyone. You're not as innocent as you seem."
Person2: "What about you? What will everyone think about you when they find out the truth?"
Person1: "Stop! Just stop! You're trying to blackmail me, but it won't work. I have evidence against you."
Person2: "Evidence? Ha! You're the one who's been lying all along. I have proof, and it's going to ruin you."

Person1: You're going to regret not taking my advice, Emma. I warned you about investing in that company.
Person2: I'm sorry already. It seemed like a good opportunity at the time.
Person1: It seemed like a good opportunity? You're not even trying to defend yourself. That's what worries me.
Person2: What's gotten into you, Alex? You're being paranoid again.

Person1: I've worked very hard and enjoyed my life... I've known success... and I've felt love...
Person2: Your expenses are your own.
Person1: Let me feel the strength in your hand, Alex... Let me feel your strength...  Yes, that's good... I hope, Alex - I hope that you'll stay with Rachel... Take care of her, watch over her, she's a delicate flower, Alex...
Person2: It's....whatever....that's not cool.
Person1: Alex, Don't. Just. Seriously. It doesn't make sense if you think about it in a fair deal like sense. Ok? It's business. Seriously. One hundred dollars for two days work is a lot more than your family is making sitting around your house. I'm serious now. Ok. Please. Now. Just stop.
Person2: A flower...
Person1: Rachel cares for you and she needs your help, Alex... there's much to be looked after... I'm very fond of you, Alex... And I understand Rachel... Tell her that... tell her I'm madly in love with her...

Person1: You're no sob story. You're just scared of commitment.
Person2: That's not fair. I asked you to marry me, didn't I?
Person1: Yes, but it's not just about the proposal. It's about the kind of people you surround yourself with. Like Charles Moore, for instance.
Person2: What's wrong with Moore? He's quiet, that's all.
Person1: Quiet? You call that quiet? He's weird, and you know it. And I don't want you to be influenced by him anymore.
Person2: You're just trying to control me, aren't you? You want me to cut ties with my friends, with my past.
Person1: I want you to grow up, to take responsibility for yourself. You can't keep running away from your problems.
Person2: And you can't keep manipulating me, making me feel guilty for my choices. I want you to leave me alone.
Person1: Because I want you, and I'll always want you. No one else will ever take your place.

Person1: You owe me, Rachel. I made you who you are today.
Person2: That's right. And being who I am today is the biggest mistake you ever made. At least you're honest for once.
Person1: So now you want to be my partner? Well, let me tell you something, Rachel. You got a lot to learn about loyalty.
Person2: Does that mean I'm in? I don't think so, Rachel. You'd just slow me down. We'd have to stop every five minutes so you could justify your actions. There's no way around it, you're weak.
Person1: What'd you say? You know I hate it when you call me that.
Person2: I said you're weak. And you know why? Because you let me walk all over you.

Person1: You look ridiculous in that outfit, don't you think?
Person2: I want out. I've had enough of this charade.
Person1: Too late, you're in too deep. They want you, and I'm the one who can make it happen.
Person2: Why? I don't know anything. I just want to go back to my normal life.
Person1: You're not naive, are you? You know exactly why they're interested in you. And I can help you... for a price.
Person2: What do you want from me?
Person1: I want you to prove your loyalty. Will you do that for me?

Person1: I wish I were stronger. Do you think she's all right? Do you think she's safe at the school?
Person2: First principles, Emma. Simplicity. Of each particular thing, ask what is it, in itself, what is its nature...? What does she do, this girl you're worried about?
Person1: She's a student, and I'm her teacher. I feel responsible for her.
Person2: That's incidental. What does she want, Emma? What drives her?
Person1: I'm not sure. I think she wants to learn, to grow.
Person2: And what do you want, Emma? What drives you?
Person1: I want to protect her, to keep her safe. I don't want to be left alone with my fears.
Person2: I think it might also matter to her. You liking her, I mean.
Person1: Yes, I think so. She's important to me. I want to like any student I teach.
Person2: And if you don't?
Person1: Then I don't suppose it'll matter much to anyone but me. But I think it might also matter to her.
Person2: Would you like me to go to the school, Emma? Would you like me to check on her?
Person1: I couldn't ask you to. But I would feel so much better if you did.

Person1: You're not going to tell him, are you? Think about yourself for once.
Person2: I promised her I wouldn't say anything. You know how it is.
Person1: I know exactly how it is. You're letting your loyalty cloud your judgment. You're not even considering the benefits of being honest.
Person2: Benefits? You mean like getting ahead at the expense of someone else?
Person1: That's exactly what I mean. You're too caught up in being the good guy. It's time to think about your own interests.
Person2: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with that.
Person1: Comfortable? You're not going to get anywhere in life by being comfortable. You need to take risks and make tough decisions. Like I do.
Person2: And what exactly do you get out of this?
Person1: Let's just say I have a vested interest in seeing you succeed. Or, at the very least, seeing you make the right decision.
Person2: I'm not sure I trust you.
Person1: Trust me? Ha! You don't need to trust me. You just need to trust yourself. And I'm here to guide you in making that decision.

Person1: You're coming to the party, and in a few minutes you won't even remember what it's about. You won't care who's in your damn life.
Person2: I don't know how to make you happy. I'm out of my depth.
Person1: Things always look much worse in the morning. But I love you, and I'm sick. I'll talk to you tomorrow.
Person2: What's about? You mind your own business.
Person1: I'll be good to you. I'll be god damn good for you. And I won't be mad if you don't know who said what.
Person2: Gently, son... It's a dangerous thing to confuse children with angels...
Person1: You have a special secret crush over here, I think. Don't take him too lovely -- he might get hurt --
Person2: Or I won't. I can't help you. I'm out of my depth.

Person1: I've been thinking of trying a new approach for the project.
Person2: Alex, I want to cut through the b.s. You're not taking this seriously enough.
Person1: I'd love to hear your concerns.
Person2: Good. I think you're underestimating the competition. No, let me correct that, you're being naive. Which is fine, except this project is crucial for the company's future and I'm afraid your lack of experience is going to cost us.
Person1: I understand your concerns, but...
Person2: Let me finish. You're a talented individual, but you need to dress for success, not just in terms of attire, but also in terms of your attitude. You need to exude confidence, not uncertainty. If you want to succeed, you're going to have to change some things about yourself. If I may make some suggestions...

Person1: You wanted to see me!
Person2: Don't you like girls, Mr. Thompson? Come in, and I'll show you everything you need to know.
Person1: Why are you suddenly so welcoming? You think I'm some sort of sap?!
Person2: No, I admire you. I...I fell for your charm the first time I saw you. I did. I think that you are the most intriguing person I've ever met.
Person1: I want to know exactly who you are and what you're really up to! You're not from around here, are you? Where'd you learn to be so persuasive?!

Person1: You always been this reckless?
Person2: Well, no... I just know what I want.
Person1: Then that's all you had to say. You're not even considering the consequences.
Person2: I'm considering them, but I'm willing to take the risk. You're just trying to scare me.
Person1: I'm trying to make you see sense. You're not thinking clearly.
Person2: And you are? You're the one who's been playing both sides against each other.
Person1: That's not true. I'm just trying to protect myself.
Person2: By manipulating everyone around you? That's not protection, that's control.
Person1: You're one to talk. You're the one who's been using your charm to get what you want.
Person2: At least I'm honest about it. You're just pretending to be something you're not.
Person1: And what am I pretending to be?
Person2: Someone who cares about anyone but themselves.

Person1: You think I got no contacts out here? You're to leave immediately for the Azure Club. Retrieve the encrypted files from the CEO's office. And bring them back with the utmost discretion as possible.
Person2: What's in it for me?
Person1: You wanna talk to me straight up? I'll give you a reason. You're in deep, and I'm the only one who can help you stay afloat.
Person2: I never messed up before, Victor.
Person1: You expect me to buy this? You're not as clean as you think you are. I have evidence, and I'm willing to share it with the authorities if you don't cooperate.
Person2: What do you want from me?
Person1: Three reasons... One, you're in my debt. Two, you have skills I need. And three, you're running out of options. Now, are you going to do this for me, or do you want to take a swim in the river?

Person1: So, what have you got to say for yourself? You're not taking this seriously, are you?
Person2: Of course not. Not when you've got so much going for you. But nobody knows it. Least of all you.
Person1: You really are a piece of work, you know that? You think you can just waltz in here and expect me to trust you?
Person2: Trust your instinct! When you see your opportunity, grab it! I do. And I think you should be more aggressive, take control of the situation.
Person1: Actually, I don't think so. You're just trying to manipulate me into doing what you want.
Person2: Oh, come on. I'm just trying to help. You're not seeing the big picture here.

Person1: You're a shrewd one, Alex. You think you can get away from all that by coming down here?
Person2: I'm not trying to get away from anything. I just want to show that people can think differently and it doesn't have to be about the past.
Person1: Save it, Alex. I know you're trying to get me to do your bidding. You think I'm still useful to you, don't you?
Person2: You were the one who caught the last two, Jack. You have a way of thinking that's unique.
Person1: That's not entirely true, Alex. You're the one who's been manipulating people with your words. I'm not buying it.
Person2: I'm not trying to manipulate you, Jack. I just want to understand why you're so resistant to change.
Person1: You're not going to get inside my head, Alex. I'm all right now, and I don't need your help.

Person1: I've got something going this Saturday night... it's gonna be worse than anything God ever dumped on the Pharaohs -- and only I can stop it.
Person2: You're just enough of a shit to have a go at bedding a man's wife. You've probably bagged a few at that. You'd probably lie, cheat and steal without thinking twice.
Person1: What's it to you? I declare it. Here I am, back in the States for less than a month --
Person2: I hate loving her. I hate the kind of person she is. I hate having to tolerate the little games she plays. I hate letting her use me. But I love her too much to do otherwise.
Person1: You can't kill me, Alex. I've got the upper hand this time.
Person2: You're out in the desert, the middle of nowhere with no one around for miles, and you say you're in control? What's the matter? You were hoping to get it on home video? A keepsake for the grandkids.
Person1: You know so much about killing why don't you do it yourself?
Person2: I guess I have what you'd call a love-hate relationship with you, too. I hate the kind of person you're becoming. I hate having to tolerate your little games. I hate letting you use me. But I love you too much to do otherwise.

Person1: I don't want any more surprises. We do this the way I laid it out, or we don't do it at all.
Person2: You know nothing about feelings, natural or unnatural. I've made it clear how I want things to be done.
Person1: What the hell you talkin' bout? You're not even listening to me.
Person2: If you don't like it here, I suggest you leave. I'm sure you'll feel more at home somewhere else.
Person1: I was there, I saw how you've been manipulating everyone. You think you're so clever, don't you?
Person2: You're just trying to take control, but it won't work. I've already made my arrangements.
Person1: Not when it's my reputation on the line, you don't. We do this my way or forget it.
Person2: Then perhaps you should take a bow and leave. I'm sure everyone will be relieved.

Person1: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with this, Rachel. Maybe we should reconsider.
Person2: You're being too cautious, Alex. We've got a good thing going here. You take things too seriously.
Person1: I just want to be honest with you about how I feel. I felt like I wanted to tell you something, but I didn't put it in the report, and I didn't say it, but I want to say it now...
Person2: Alex, you're getting worked up over nothing. We're making good progress, and we're getting paid for it. What more do you want?
Person1: I want to know that I can trust you. I want to know that you're not just saying what I want to hear.
Person2: Alex, I'm telling you the truth. You're just not listening. You're too caught up in your own doubts.
Person1: Maybe I am. But I think that's what's holding me back. I think that's what's holding us back.
Person2: Fine, Alex. If you want to play it safe, then let's play it safe. But I think you're making a mistake.

Person1: You're really going to go through with this, aren't you? Leaving everything behind for some idealistic dream.
Person2: Don't make it any worse. You're not thinking about what's best for you, you're thinking about what's best for your ego. If you aren't eventually crushed by the harsh reality, some other obstacle will devour your spirit.

Person1: You're not even going to try to deny it, are you?
Person2: The Mayor's brother-in-law, Merwyn D. Mayor, was at the scene of the incident.
Person1: Don't you even care that I'm hurt? Didn't I mean anything to you?
Person2: Howard Shenken, the Sheriff's uncle, was also present. He's still recovering from the tear bomb explosion.
Person1: A fine friend you are! You're just going to stand there and throw facts at me?
Person2: Nothing.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's all about finding balance in life. You can't just focus on one thing and expect to be happy.
Person2: I know what you need. You need someone to take care of you, to make decisions for you.
Person1: That's not what I meant. I can take care of myself, thank you very much.
Person2: Oh, I'm sure you think you can. But sometimes you need someone to force you to take a step back and re-evaluate.
Person1: Like you, for instance?
Person2: Maybe. I'm just trying to help you see things from a different perspective.
Person1: And what's in it for you?
Person2: Nothing. I just want to help. You can trust me.
Person1: I'm not so sure about that. You seem to be hiding something.
Person2: I'm not hiding anything. I'm just trying to be a good friend.
Person1: A good friend wouldn't try to manipulate me into doing what they think is best for me.
Person2: Oh, so now you're accusing me of manipulation? That's rich coming from you.

Person1: I want you to come with me, Alex. We need to get out of here.
Person2: Who's behind this? You're not telling me everything.
Person1: You're not listening to me. I'm trying to protect you.
Person2: Protect me? You're the one who brought me into this mess. I think it concerns me.
Person1: Don't make me ask you again. We need to leave now.
Person2: You're not going to bully me into going anywhere. I want answers.
Person1: Fine. You want to know the truth? I was there. I believed him.
Person2: Believed what? That he was telling the truth?
Person1: Yes, exactly. And I was wrong. He fooled me, just like he's fooling you.
Person2: That's not true. You're just trying to manipulate me.
Person1: Am I? Or am I just trying to save you from making the same mistake I did?

Person1: I'm telling you, it's not about you. This is something that's happening to me.
Person2: You can't just dismiss him. He's got connections, family ties. His uncle's a respected judge.
Person1: So what? Everybody in this town is related to someone important. I'm sick of it.
Person2: You know I've got a lot at stake with this project. You know that. I can't help but think you're doing this now to hurt me, or to sabotage me somehow.
Person1: Sabotage? You think I'm trying to get even with you?
Person2: Ever since the incident, I've been worried that you'd been unhappy, or...
Person1: The incident...? You're not listening to me. This is about what's happening in our community, whether you believe in it or not...
Person2: Sweetheart, I understand you're upset, but...
Person1: No! Not sweetheart, no. I believe in what's happening. I don't want to, but I do. I guess I was foolish enough to think that would be enough for you.

Person1: You're hardly in a position to refuse, Ruby. Just take the deal, and let's get out of here. No drama, okay? I can't stand people who get overly emotional.
Person2: I'm sorry, sir. I didn't mean to cause a scene. But this is a lot to take in.
Person1: Simplicity, Ruby. First principles. What does this deal offer you, in itself, what is its nature? What do you gain from it?
Person2: I... I gain financial security, I suppose.
Person1: That's incidental. What do you really want, Ruby? What drives you?
Person2: I want to be free from all this, to start anew.
Person1: Ah, freedom. A noble pursuit. But are you willing to do what it takes to achieve it?

Person1: You'll have to pack quickly.
Person2: Does it pay you to cover their actions, or do you just do it out of the kindness of your heart?
Person1: There is some good in you, after all. You deserve a little vacation.
Person2: The heck you don't. No one calls me that. You must have thought about me in a certain way.
Person1: A change of scenery will do you good. North!
Person2: You're not fooling anyone with your sweet talk. People are dying, and you're responsible.

Person1: I need a favor, cousin.
Person2: Anything you need, Charley.
Person1: I want you to talk to Jimmy about the new pier job.
Person2: The boss loader position?
Person1: That's the one. Tell him I'll make it worth his while.
Person2: And what's in it for me?
Person1: You get to walk free, and I'll make sure you're taken care of.
Person2: I don't know, Charley. This whole thing sounds too good to be true.
Person1: Listen, kid, you don't want to jeopardize a setup like this for one little mistake. You understand?
Person2: Yeah, I understand. But I'm not making any promises.
Person1: The point is, there isn't much time. You need to make a decision, and fast.

Person1: You really have a way with words, don't you? I'll give you that.
Person2: Whoever's behind this, they've gone to great lengths. It's not just about the money.
Person1: Oh, it's about the money. You're just not seeing the bigger picture. Take him down, and we'll work things out when the time is right.
Person2: Remember my promise. I'll find out what happened, and I'll make sure you're the first to know.
Person1: Don't threaten me. I tend to take these things seriously. You look like you could use a few hours of sleep, too.

Person1: I'm going to the art gallery tonight, with a friend. Try to make some connections. I need them, the connections. I'll be leaving early in the morning.
Person2: Leave now.
Person1: Oh, grow up. I brought you something tonight, a painting -- an interesting piece -- in very good condition.
Person2: I've ordered nothing from you.
Person1: This is a gift. I want to discuss business. I need the exposure and I need the recognition. I told you I'd be back.
Person2: If you were going to come back you wouldn't have taken me out tonight. You wouldn't have bought this dress. You're hustling me, Alex. You've never stopped hustling me.
Person1: Now, I never hustled you. Even when I thought I was. You know it. I take no gifts from you, Alex.
Person2: What do you want me to do? Just sit here and wait? Faithful little Rachel. Pull the shades down and sit. When you feel like coming back, you'll come back. And you'll love me. And then you'll go away again. Is that your idea of love?
Person1: I got no idea of love. And neither have you. I mean, neither one of us would know what it was if we saw it coming down the street. You're not to set foot in here again, Alex, for business or any other reason. And you're going out now!
Person2: I'd know it, Alex. I'd know. For God's sakes, what are you trying to do to me? I love you.

Person1: You don't have any more vacations to sell, do you, Alex? I hardly see how you couldn't.
Person2: What are you talking about? This is a job interview.
Person1: Ah, yes. The interview. They don't know that, Alex. What are they gonna do, try and shoot the CEO during the interview? I'll bet Rachel can pull some strings. You saw the way she was staring at me.
Person2: You're just trying to get under my skin, aren't you? You think you're tall, dark, and handsome, and I'm just a nobody.
Person1: Oh, Alex, you're so much more than that. You're a puzzle, and I love puzzles. Don't you feel eyes moving over your body, Alex? I hardly see how you couldn't. And don't your eyes move over the things you want?
Person2: Stop it. You're making me uncomfortable.
Person1: Uncomfortable? Ah, Alex, that's just the beginning. We begin by coveting what we see every day. And I see a lot of potential in you, Alex. A lot of potential.

Person1: You think I'm just going to leave him for you?
Person2: We didn't talk about it -- you did.
Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you?
Person2: They got it on a long playing record now - Music to String Her Along By. My husband doesn't understand me -- We haven't gotten along for years -- You're the best thing that ever happened to me --
Person1: That's enough, Alex. You're not being funny.
Person2: I wasn't trying. You're just trying to get a rise out of me, aren't you?
Person1: If you'll just listen to me for a minute --
Person2: Okay. I'm sorry. But you have to understand, I'm responsible for a lot of people. I have a business to run.
Person1: You're not going to use that as an excuse, are you? You're going to have to make a choice eventually.
Person2: I've made my choice. I choose my business, my family, my life.
Person1: Fine. But you're going to regret this. You're going to realize that I was the best thing that ever happened to you.
Person2: I doubt it.

Person1: I'll make you a deal. If you do what I say, I'll let you sleep tonight.
Person2: You think you can control me? I swear, the minute you turn your back, I'll find a way to get back at you.
Person1: Oh, I'm not worried. I know you're desperate for my attention. You're just trying to get a rise out of me.
Person2: That's not true! You're just trying to manipulate me into doing what you want.
Person1: Maybe a little. But I'm doing it for your own good. You need someone to take care of you, and I'm happy to oblige.
Person2: I don't need your help. And I certainly don't need your condescending attitude.
Person1: Oh, but you do. You're just too proud to admit it. That's why I'm going to make you an offer you can't refuse.

Person1: I've been thinking of quitting my job. I'd rather die than work for that company anymore.
Person2: Don't be dramatic, you're just having a bad day. Trust me, it's not that serious.
Person1: You don't understand, I've been sold out by my boss. I'd rather die than fall into their trap again.
Person2: That's not what you meant, is it? You're not actually considering suicide?
Person1: No, of course not! But I feel like I'm being pushed into a corner.
Person2: Perhaps someone is pushing you, then? Maybe your boss is manipulating you?
Person1: No, it's not that simple. I just feel like I'm losing control.
Person2: Well, maybe you should take a step back and re-evaluate your priorities. You're not thinking clearly.

Person1: Commander, I've received intel that the enemy is hiding in the abandoned warehouse on 5th street.
Person2: What about the civilians in the area? I don't want any collateral damage.
Person1: Don't worry, I've taken care of it. I sent them to the safe zone. You're not thinking clearly, Commander. You're usually more strategic than this.
Person2: I'm dying, Rachel. I need you to listen to me.
Person1: I blame myself, Commander. I noticed you've been tense lately, like something's been eating at you. And then you started yelling at the rookies like a madman. I think you're hiding something from me.
Person2: Rachel, for God's sake, shut up! Will you shut your mouth and listen?! You're not thinking about the bigger picture here.
Person1: See? You're screaming at me again. A person can't communicate with you when you're like this. You become a stranger in your own unit...
Person2: Rachel, I need you to retrieve the classified documents from the warehouse. It's a matter of national security. And bring them back with the utmost discretion possible. Any questions?
Person1: Just one... why me?

Person1: I thought you couldn't get your car.
Person2: I don't think we have anything to talk about.
Person1: What about us? There's only one way to do that.
Person2: November 7th is my information.
Person1: I don't remember the exact date. I want you, and I want to get us out of this shithole.
Person2: And when did you last see Signor Ripley?
Person1: A few days ago. I mean it, I'm getting out of here, and I want to take you with me.
Person2: Does he stay with you here?
Person1: No! You're full of shit, and I know it.
Person2: It's not a pattern, it's a coincidence. There must be fifty hotels in San Remo, there must have been a hundred people renting a boat on that day.
Person1: I don't give a damn about the money. I want the truth, and I want it now.

Person1: I've got a bad feeling about this, Alex.
Person2: How many times have we seen people like us get hurt?
Person1: Too many. Rachel, Michael, and now Emily.
Person2: They're gone, and there's nothing we can do to bring them back. But there's something you can do to help us move forward.
Person1: I'm not sure I'm ready for that.
Person2: You're not getting any younger, and the boys are getting restless. They think it's time you took a more active role in the organization.
Person1: I'm happy with my current position.
Person2: That's exactly what I'm talking about. You're too comfortable. You need to start thinking about your future, about what you want to achieve.
Person1: I want to survive, that's all.
Person2: Survival is just the beginning. You have the potential to be so much more. And I can help you get there.

Person1: You have a power, a power to see. I've always supported your dreams and aspirations.
Person2: But sometimes it feels like you're just pushing me into what you want. What can my power give you?
Person1: Knowledge. I thought I was helping, but I need to know the truth about your past.
Person2: Of what? You're trying to manipulate me, just like you always do.
Person1: The truth about your family. I've seen the way you react when they're mentioned. There's something you're not telling me.
Person2: Why must you know? You're just trying to control me, to make me do what you want.
Person1: Because I care about you. And I think you're hiding something from me. Could I lie to you and still see your beauty?
Person2: No. But you're not looking at my beauty, you're looking at my secrets. And I won't let you have them.

Person1: I loved you, Emma, and because he knew I loved you, he let you think I loved him. Didn't you see, couldn't you see?
Person2: What about Dad? We can't keep this from him, Alex.
Person1: Just for a few days, Emma. Give me a chance to work this out by myself. Please, don't tell him.
Person2: I don't know, Alex. This is not like breaking a vase or getting a bad grade.
Person1: You've got to help me, Emma. You've got to stick with me on this one.

Person1: You said you were happy with the new job.
Person2: I... you told me I was making a great decision, back in the interview, telling me it was a perfect fit --
Person1: No -- 
Person2: You were convincing me I wasn't making a mistake! And we just didn't believe you!
Person1: But I never said I was happy.
Person2: You said it a million times! You were beaming with excitement!
Person1: I never told you how I felt.
Person2: You didn't have to. It was written all over your face.
Person1: So, how's the job going?
Person2: Oh, it's great. No doubts. No second thoughts. Am I a fool?
Person1: You're my colleague.
Person2: That's not an answer, is it?
Person1: Yes, you're a fool.

Person1: I'm a chameleon, blending into the shadows. No one knows my true face.
Person2: You're a mystery, aren't you? I saw you watching him from across the room.
Person1: (laughs) Oh, I was just admiring the view. But tell me, what kind of person are you?
Person2: I'm a wanderer, a free spirit. I've learned to adapt, to survive. But I've also learned to lie, to hide.
Person1: (leaning in) And what do you do now? What's your game?
Person2: (smirks) I'm a gambler, a risk-taker. I live for the thrill, the rush. But I'm also a thief, a charlatan. I take what I want, when I want it.
Person1: (raises an eyebrow) And what do you want from me?
Person2: (takes a step closer) I want to know your secrets, your desires. I want to uncover the real you, hidden beneath the mask.
Person1: (smiles) You're a clever one, aren't you? But I'm not afraid of you. I've been around the block a few times.
Person2: (grins) Oh, I'm not trying to scare you. I'm trying to seduce you, to make you mine. And I always get what I want.

Person1: Stop it, you're blowing a great opportunity here. You're great, you're cool, you're funny. What's with this gloomy come-down nonsense?
Person2: I'm uncomfortable with the whole scenario. My mother must never know. Never.
Person1: Oh Jesus, did you hide the evidence? It's in this antique vase in my room.
Person2: Why do you want me to make copies of it and bring them to you?
Person1: If there's one thing I'm great at, it's spinning a good story. With my help, you'll be the star of the show. Perhaps we can arrange a little get-together for the two of us at my house.
Person2: You'd do that for me?
Person1: Of course I would. We're friends, right? And I know exactly how to make this work in your favor.

Person1: You're really going to leave me hanging like this? I had plans for us tonight.
Person2: I'm only doing this for your own good. Sometimes you need someone to force you to take a step back.
Person1: That's not your decision to make. I told you I had company coming over.
Person2: Sorry, but it's important. You've been pushing yourself too hard lately.

Person1: I've been waiting for what feels like an eternity. For what? To end up feeling like a fool?
Person2: Oh, come on, Alex... don't be so hard on yourself. You're the only one who ever... It's just... Can't you trust me?
Person1: I want to, but you're not giving me much reason to. You're the only one who had access to the files. The only one who won't give a straight answer. And the only one who's been acting suspiciously. What more do you want me to think?
Person2: That's not fair, Alex. You know I'd never betray you. It's us against them, remember? And I'm telling you now that I'll prove my innocence, okay? I'll find a way to clear my name.
Person1: I hope so, Rachel. For your sake, I hope so.

Person1: You're not listening to me, Alex. Please, just hear me out.
Person2: I've heard enough from you, Rachel. You're just trying to confuse me, like you always do. You think you're clever, but I see right through you.
Person1: That's not fair, Alex. I'm trying to have an honest conversation with you.
Person2: Honest? You? Don't make me laugh. You're just trying to manipulate me, like you did with the others. But I won't fall for it.

Person1: You're stuck, aren't you? You're lost in space, just a speck on one in a blink. The universe doesn't care.
Person2: What's gotten into you? You're not superstitious, are you?
Person1: I love you, but you need to get with it. You're way low in your estimation of yourself. You're do-ing yourself in this yellow prison with steel-belted radials.
Person2: That's not fair. You're just trying to distract me from the real issue. What's the third thing, huh? Tell me.
Person1: There's no third thing. You're just trying to hold on to something that's never going to happen. You're waiting for your dream to come, but it never will. Life just flipped on you. Tomorrow became yesterday.
Person2: You're just trying to manipulate me, aren't you? Well, it won't work. I know what you're doing.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you? You're just playing games with me, using me to get to him.
Person2: I'm sorry, I haven't the faintest idea what you're talking about. But I do know you're not thinking clearly. You're letting your emotions cloud your judgment.
Person1: Don't try to manipulate me! I know exactly what's going on. You're just trying to distract me, to keep me from seeing the truth.
Person2: The truth? You're the one who's not being honest with yourself. You're so caught up in your own anger and fear that you're not seeing things clearly.
Person1: You're just like him, using my words against me. You're trying to turn me against myself, to make me doubt my own sanity.
Person2: I'm just trying to help you see reason. But if you're not willing to listen, then maybe we're done here.

Person1: You scare me, Alex. That's what you wanna hear, isn't it?
Person2: I got the quick-and-ugly version of what's going on in your head.
Person1: An' now you're worried about a repeat of history?
Person2: We've spent everything on these operations. Is it really worth it?
Person1: What's more important, our reputation or your own self-doubt?
Person2: I don't want to hear that kind of talk!
Person1: Okay, Alex. I think you need to relax. This therapist in the city is the best in the country.
Person2: All right. Here, take this. It's my last few bucks. You'll need a hot meal when you get there.

Person1: You're not telling me the truth, are you?
Person2: Sit down, Emily. Let's talk about this calmly.
Person1: No, I won't calm down until you explain what's going on. You're hiding something.
Person2: If necessary, I can bring in witnesses who will testify that you're overreacting.
Person1: Witnesses? What are you talking about? You're trying to confuse me, aren't you?
Person2: It's over, Emily. You need to accept it. Wake up and stop living in denial.

Person1: You're probably right, and I probably won't find anything. I don't have a right to ask this, and you can kick me out of your office if you want, but this is my job and there's a part of me that can't let it go.
Person2: Take care, you hear? You're on a mission, man. You're talking to a possible suspect here.
Person1: Did you find out about the company's financial records?
Person2: You know I'm just doing my job, Rachel, what'd you find?

Person1: You're not playing very well.
Person2: I'm just trying to understand the game.
Person1: There are clues all around you, but you keep missing them.
Person2: You're the one who's been leaving the clues. Why don't you just tell me what you want?
Person1: Because it's more fun this way. You're so close, but you still don't get it.
Person2: I've figured out the message, but it doesn't matter. You've already set your plan in motion.
Person1: You're just trying to stall. You think you can outsmart me, but I'm always one step ahead.
Person2: Maybe I am, maybe I'm not. But I know one thing - you're enjoying this, aren't you?
Person1: Enjoying it? I'm just getting started.

Person1: You know, it's refreshing to meet someone from back home who still knows how to act right.
Person2: Yes, sir, no, sir. It's a lost art nowadays. But I have to say, I'm a bit surprised you're not more... diplomatic.
Person1: Diplomatic? Ha! You're the one who's been playing the charm card, and I'm not buying it. Every word out of your mouth is calculated to manipulate, to get what you want.
Person2: And what makes you think that? Maybe I'm just a naturally charming person.
