Person1: Save it. I've seen your kind before. You think you're above reproach, but I know better. You're just waiting for the perfect moment to strike, to get what you want no matter the cost.
Person2: You know, I think you're just projecting. Maybe you're the one who's trying to manipulate me.

Person1: I've been observing your behavior, and I think you're being paranoid. What's the matter with you?
Person2: Look, I'll be okay. I just need some fresh air. It's probably something I ate.
Person1: You're not only a good technical surgeon, but you're also a good military surgeon. And that includes how a man dresses and how he bears himself and his sense of what it means to be an officer in the United States Army.
Person2: Yeah, yeah, I just need to walk it off. You go ahead.
Person1: I've noticed that your team seems to work well together. But I wonder how a degenerated person like you could have reached a position of responsibility in the Army Medical Corps.
Person2: Sister, if I knew the answer to that I sure as hell wouldn't be here. Now, look, you go on ahead. I'll be okay.

Person1: You're still going to pursue this, aren't you?
Person2: Yes, I am.
Person1: Do you believe I have your best interests at heart?
Person2: I... I think so.
Person1: You don't have to trust me. Just, do you believe I'm doing this for you?
Person2: Yes, I believe you are.
Person1: Then let me handle it. You were being completely selfish, and if I ever find out you're going behind my back again, there will be consequences. Understand?
Person2: Okay, okay...
Person1: Say the words, "I understand."

Person1: You're not thinking straight, are you? You're gonna be sorry if you don't calm down.
Person2: Don't even try to tell me what to do. I want my share, and I want it now.
Person1: Your share? You're not even making sense. You're just trying to get a rise out of me.
Person2: I'm not trying to get a rise out of you, I'm trying to get what's mine. You owe me, and you know it.
Person1: I don't owe you anything. You're just trying to guilt trip me into giving you something.
Person2: Guilt trip? You're the one who's been playing games with me from the start. I'm not buying it anymore.
Person1: You don't know what you're talking about. You're just angry and confused.
Person2: I'm not confused, I'm fed up. And I'm not going to let you talk your way out of this one.

Person1: You can't tell your parents about this.
Person2: What's the big deal? It's just a party.
Person1: It's not just a party. It's a statement. And I'm showing it as it really is.
Person2: You're showing how superior you are to the people who attend these parties.
Person1: No, I'm not. I love these people. They're just...misguided.
Person2: You're not fooling anyone. Least of all, yourself.
Person1: You're just scared because you don't understand what's going on. That's why you need to be there tonight. For your own safety.
Person2: I don't need your protection. And I don't need to be at your party.
Person1: Fine. But you're missing out on something special. Something that will change your life.

Person1: I loved you, and because he knew I loved you, he let you think I loved him. Didn't you see, couldn't you see?
Person2: I just don't know if I should be dating anyone right now. Every guy I date winds up hurt, not dead, but hurt.
Person1: Yeah, and I know it's unorthodox, I mean with our past and all. But I thought we were starting something... and then...
Person2: You're trying to make me feel guilty, aren't you? You're trying to make me think it's my fault that things didn't work out between us.

Person1: You're telling me the truth, aren't you? About what happened at the party?
Person2: What does it look like? I'm trying to be honest with you.
Person1: I asked Rachel about it. She didn't own up to it. She said she didn't know what got into you.
Person2: You're just raffish. You put her up to it. Before evening sun sets, I would have the truth out of you, that old fox.
Person1: I can't accuse you just dry long. I need proof.
Person2: Everybody who has been associated with you ends up with pennies over their eyes. You're playing me, just like you played Rachel.
Person1: What must I do to get the truth out of you?
Person2: If it was left up to me, I would make you confess. But I'll settle for the truth.

Person1: I'm telling you, you're messing up the story. You're not listening to what I'm saying.
Person2: What's the big deal? It's just a story. You're reading too much into it.
Person1: You're not taking this seriously. I apologize if I came on too strong.
Person2: No need to apologize. I thought we were just having a conversation. You seem to be looking for a specific outcome.
Person1: I want to make sure we get it right. You're not going to start again, are you?
Person2: If you want me to. But I thought we agreed to move forward.

Person1: You know what I mean? Like when you said you'd help me with my project, and I really need your input.
Person2: Hmm, I really can't recall that conversation, Rachel. I'm swamped with work.
Person1: Seriously? You've been doing this a lot lately. You're always "forgetting" our agreements.
Person2: Well, I guess I can take a quick look. But I'm not making any promises.
Person1: Do you love me? I mean, do you care about my success at all?
Person2: Yeah, of course I do. I really mean it. I really do care about you.
Person1: Then why do you keep doing this to me? You know I need your help.
Person2: I dunno. Maybe I'm just not as invested in your project as you are.

Person1: You're new around here, right? We need to talk.
Person2: What's it to you? I'm just trying to get settled.
Person1: Listen, I've been here a while, and I know how things work. You're going to have to choose - either you're with me or against me.
Person2: That's not how it works. I'm not looking for trouble.
Person1: Trouble finds you, sweetheart. And if you don't want to be on my bad side, you'll do what I say. End of file.

Person1: You know I never stop you from anything. Believe me, you're at a wonderful age.
Person2: You still think this is about me, don't you?
Person1: Just give me a direct answer! You going to let your fears hold you back?
Person2: Oh man, I'm gonna enjoy this one... Just remember, you did this. You brought this on yourself...
Person1: In ten years you'll look back on this and wish you were more confident.
Person2: Ten years? Now, I need an answer now!

Person1: I need a favor, can you help me out?
Person2: You should have thought of that before you wore that ridiculous outfit. You look like a clown.
Person1: This suit represents my confidence and individuality. I'm not going to let your opinion bring me down.
Person2: Save it, Mr. Independent. You're in no position to negotiate. You're the one who needs help, not me.
Person1: Fine, but I'm warning you, I won't back down. I'll do whatever it takes to get what I want.
Person2: Oh, I'm shaking in my boots. You're all talk, no action.

Person1: I know you're afraid to face the truth. You can't get free of thinking that you're in control of your life. But I'm telling you, there's a pattern here, a cycle of self-doubt that's holding you back. Maybe you can't break free, ever...
Person2: That's not what I meant to happen... I didn't want to be stuck in this rut.
Person1: Exactly! You're already trapped, and the only way out is to accept that some things don't change. It's a relief, trust me. You'll be happier once you stop fighting it. I'm asking you to find whatever respect you may have for me and trust me on this.

Person1: I've been thinking... we could use a break from the city. You're the only one I know around here with a place out of town...
Person2: Oh, God. You're not serious, are you?
Person1: Why not? It'll be a chance for us to clear our heads, get some perspective. We're mortgaged to the eyeballs, and I'm starting to feel like I'm drowning.
Person2: You're talking like a teenager, running away from our problems won't solve anything.
Person1: Come on, it'll be fun. We can leave our financial obligations behind for a weekend. You can invite your family, make it a real getaway.
Person2: Zack, I don't know if I want to do that...

Person1: You're my second chance, Emily. I want to stop being haunted by the past.
Person2: Listen, do you want to ruin your reputation? You know what they'd say about you if they found out.
Person1: You look like her, now. Go to the old mansion and wait for me.
Person2: No, I won't be a part of this. This is madness.
Person1: Exactly, it's our little secret. And I'll follow you, Emily.

Person1: You're playing with fire, Victor. You used to know how the game was played.
Person2: I don't understand what you're insinuating.
Person1: Don't play dumb, Victor. I've seen the way you operate. You're not as slick as you think you are.
Person2: Maybe I've just gotten tired of taking bribes and skimming busts. Maybe I want to be able to sleep at night.
Person1: Save it, Victor. I've heard it all before. You're just trying to get under my skin.
Person2: Am I? Or am I just holding up a mirror to your own reflection?

Person1: You're playing a dangerous game here. If you're trying to blackmail me... it's not going to work.
Person2: I always win, one way or another. Pity I didn't keep that evidence. It's going to be worth a lot more by morning.
Person1: You know what I want... it's not that difficult. But you're not going to get it that easily.
Person2: Almost as good as you. You're just trying to stall for time, but I'm not buying it.
Person1: Get out! Get out before I expose you... you're not as clever as you think you are.
Person2: What about you? What will they think about you when they find out the truth?

Person1: You're really not making an effort. I thought we agreed to work on that lazy attitude.
Person2: Oh, I'm sorry I'm not the perfect partner you deserve. Maybe I'm just tired of being controlled.
Person1: Controlled? You think I care about what you do? I'm just worried about how it reflects on me.
Person2: Well, maybe I'll try to find out what's really going on in your head. When I figure it out, I'll let you know.
Person1: Okay, do that. I'm curious to see what you come up with.
Person2: All right?

Person1: I thought you were punishing me.
Person2: You're making decisions for me, as if I'm some kind of puppet.
Person1: That's not true. I'm just trying to guide you towards what's best for you.
Person2: But isn't it ironic that the very things you stand for - control, authority, and manipulation - are all now, in this conversation, considered to be... toxic?
Person1: No, what I'm doing is protecting you from yourself. You're not thinking clearly.
Person2: Your protection has caused more pain and suffering in our relationship than any freedom I ever dreamed of. Face it, your way has failed.
Person1: That's why right now is a critical time. We need to find a balance between my guidance and your autonomy.
Person2: Really, there's nothing more pathetic than a controlling parent who can't let go.

Person1: I'm not sure I trust him. He's been acting suspiciously lately.
Person2: You know his connections with the police. He won't hesitate to set us up if we don't play by his rules.
Person1: But I miss the old days when we could make our own decisions. Now it feels like we're just pawns in his game.
Person2: I understand how you feel, but we can't let emotions cloud our judgment. We have to think about our own safety.
Person1: You're right, of course. But it's hard not to feel trapped when someone has that much power over us.
Person2: I know it's difficult, but we have to be realistic. We can't take on someone with his influence alone.
Person1: What can we do, then? Just give in to his demands?
Person2: Not necessarily. We can try to negotiate, but we have to be careful not to push him too far. He's not someone to be trifled with.
Person1: I wish I could be stronger, like Mitch. He always seems to know what to do in these situations.
Person2: Mitch has his own strengths, but we have to play to our own strengths if we want to survive.

Person1: You know what? I've been watching you, and I think you're afraid to take risks.
Person2: Why'd you say that? You don't even know me.
Person1: Because I felt like it. What do you care? You're just trying to hide behind your fear.
Person2: I'm not afraid of anything. I just don't see the point in being reckless.
Person1: Well, as soon as you grow some courage, let me know. I'll be here, waiting for you to prove yourself.
Person2: You know, I remember when my grandmother used to tell me stories about people like you. Always trying to push others to do their bidding.
Person1: Oh, really? And what did she say about people like me?
Person2: She said they were manipulative and only cared about themselves.
Person1: (laughs) Well, I suppose that's one way to look at it. But I'm just trying to help you reach your full potential.
Person2: (skeptical) Save it. I'm not buying what you're selling.

Person1: I've never felt so trapped, like I'm stuck in a never-ending cycle.
Person2: Don't fade on me now, Alex. Not unless you wanna lose everything you've worked for.
Person1: Yeah, I felt that way, too, when I first started, but now... the pressure, the expectations... it's not all glamour and success anymore. Maybe I should've listened to my instincts and taken a step back earlier, I don't know...
Person2: You're just scared of what you're capable of. I know you, Alex. You're meant for greatness.
Person1: You know, I almost believe that... you're like a spark that's suddenly ignited a fire within me...
Person2: And I'll make sure that fire keeps burning, no matter what it takes. You just have to trust me.
Person1: Trust you? You're the one who's been pushing me to the edge. What do you want from me, anyway?
Person2: I want to see you reach your full potential. And I'll do whatever it takes to make that happen.

Person1: I'm proud to have you on my team! Now, show them what you can do!
Person2: I'm not comfortable with this project. It's about respecting my boundaries.
Person1: You're overreacting. I had no bad intentions. It's just a small task.
Person2: It's still a matter of trust, and I need you to understand my concerns.
Person1: Then, you'll have to face the consequences... Just, know this.

Person1: You're capable of anything, aren't you? I know how you can be when you want something.
Person2: What are you talking about? I'm just tired, I don't know if I can make it to the ceremony tonight.
Person1: Get in the car! We have a new world champion to celebrate. You can't miss it.
Person2: You're not listening to me. I have secrets, fantasies... things I don't want to share with anyone.
Person1: Oh, I think I do. And I think you want me to know. You want to be seen at your worst, don't you?

Person1: You're still reasonably pretty, but that's not going to get you far in life.
Person2: Oh, so now you're an expert on what gets someone far in life? You, who can't even take care of yourself?
Person1: I'm trying to help you, Selina. You're not making it easy.
Person2: Help me? You're the one who's been holding me back. I've been a mess because of you, not in spite of you.
Person1: That's not fair. I've given you a job, a place to stay...
Person2: Yeah, and I'm grateful. But it's time we started having a different conversation. One where you listen to me instead of trying to control me.
Person1: I'm not trying to control you. I just want what's best for you.
Person2: What's best for you, you mean. You're still trying to buy people off, just like you did with Inez. Newsflash: it doesn't work.

Person1: You're playing with fire, Rachel. Let her go before it's too late.
Person2: Whatever I do, I do because I care about you. But if you're looking out for her well-being, I suggest you advise her to make a deal with me. The ball's in your court, Rachel. What've you got to say? She's waiting for your answer.

Person1: You're really going to read that apology aloud to the entire school? 
Person2: What's the big deal? It's just words.
Person1: You're not even sorry. You're just trying to save your own skin.
Person2: I'm doing it because I need to move forward. And you're just trying to make me feel guilty.
Person1: Guilty? You should be ashamed. You're destroying your own reputation over pride.
Person2: That's not fair. You're the one who's been manipulating me from the start.
Person1: I'm just trying to help you see reason. You're the one who's being unreasonable.
Person2: Help me? You're the one who's been playing on my emotions, trying to get me to do what you want.

Person1: I'm telling you, I need to take a break from college. I'm not learning anything.
Person2: You know, in ten years you'll look back on this and wish you were in college again.
Person1: Ten years? I need an answer now! You're not taking me seriously.
Person2: I'm just trying to show you how foolish you are. You're not considering the long-term consequences of your actions.
Person1: That's not fair. You're always saying that I'm not thinking things through, but you're not giving me any credit. I've thought this through, and I know what I want.
Person2: Well, as shocking as this may sound, I've seen many students like you before. You think you're the first one to question the value of education? Trust me, you're not.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is that you're not listening to me. You're just trying to make me see things from your perspective.
Person2: And what's wrong with that? I'm trying to guide you, to help you make informed decisions. You're being impulsive and reckless.

Person1: You're not like anyone I've met before.
Person2: That's why we're meant to be together, isn't it?
Person1: I don't know. You might be right.
Person2: I might be. Is that so? You're considering it?
Person1: When I'm with you, I feel like I'm caught up in something bigger than myself.
Person2: That's exactly what I want for you. But you're scared, aren't you?
Person1: I'm confused. I don't know what's happening.
Person2: You mean you're unsure if you're ready for this? For us?
Person1: Yeah. I feel like I'm being swept up in a whirlwind.
Person2: That's the beauty of it. You don't have to know what's happening. You just have to trust me.
Person1: And what if I don't want to?
Person2: Then you'll miss out on something incredible. But I think you will. I think you'll take the leap.

Person1: You're ready to make a deal, aren't you?
Person2: I'll do what it takes to protect them. You have no power here.
Person1: Oh, but I do. And I'll use it, unless you agree to my terms. You see, I've been waiting for this moment... and as for you, my fine lady, it's true, I can't attend to you here and now as I'd like, but just try to stay out of my way....
Person2: I'll help them, but not for you. And not for free.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly, Alex. It's not them, it's him. He's always been a hothead.
Person2: That's not the point. I can't live like this, constantly walking on eggshells.
Person1: Just give me a little more time. I can help you get out of this situation.
Person2: It's easy for you to be patient. You're not the one who's trapped.
Person1: You've got nothing else to live for, Alex. Your friends are gone, and nobody's left to save you but me.

Person1: You wanna take my statement, I'll perform for you, gotta get paid though, gotta get PAID.
Person2: But I wanted to let you make up your own mind about it.
Person1: No, you didn't! If you really thought I could make my own decisions, you would've let me in on the plan instead of keeping me in the dark.
Person2: I think it's more complicated than that, little one. You don't just sign up to be a part of this operation - it's about three years of training, ok?
Person1: I'm trained, I'm ready to go, you wanna know who's behind this? I can help you, make you the one with the answers, give you the insight that I have - think fast.
Person2: Sorry, little one. That's confidential information.
Person1: Tell me what you know, I'll tell you what I know - we can make a deal.

Person1: You'll get used to the thrill of the chase. Just forget about the moral implications. You'll become desensitized all too quickly.
Person2: Do you think so? You know what I mean? Like the rush of adrenaline, and if I stroke your ego or your insecurities... you get excited.
Person1: Come on. Yeah. You know what? You know, I like you, I really mean it. I really do like you.
Person2: That's the key question. Do you think I'm just a pawn in your game?
Person1: I-uh, love is, uh, is too weak a word for what I feel. But I need you to believe it, to trust me completely.
Person2: Yeah. I think that's very... Yeah, yeah... yeah. Do you love me?
Person1: Of course I love you. Don't you think I do? You're the only one who can make me feel alive.

Person1: Detective James, we need to talk.
Person2: I'm busy, what do you want?
Person1: I appreciate that. You're a busy person.
Person2: (sighs) What is it?
Person1: If I were here to waste your time, I would have called you at the precinct. I have a problem.
Person2: (skeptical) Oh?
Person1: Only you can help me. And I'm sorry to say, my problem is your problem, Detective.

Person1: I'm afraid his health is not good. He's your only relative and you ought to say farewell to him before making any decisions.
Person2: I don't think I care. I'm not here half the time anyway. If you want him living in the garage, I don't think I care.
Person1: Now, son, I wasn't talking to you, was I? Was I? You're just a child, you don't understand these things.
Person2: You're always talking about him, but I hardly know him. I saw him only once, some years ago. I can't even remember him.
Person1: That's because you're too young to remember. But I'm telling you, he's not like other people. He's honest, he wouldn't steal anything. And I'm letting him stay because you asked me, not him.

Person1: You must agree to meet me alone. No entourage, no witnesses.
Person2: Why the secrecy?
Person1: Black suits you, by the way. What's in the briefcase? Business or pleasure?
Person2: Just some papers to sign.
Person1: Ah, how... ordinary. Tell me, how do you plan to explain this little transaction to your partner? Or do you usually keep such things to yourself?

Person1: You're the one who wanted to take the risk. 
Person2: What are you talking about? 
Person1: If you want to get out of this alive, trust me. 
Person2: I'm not putting that in my bag. 
Person1: They won't search you. I promise. You haven't done anything. 
Person2: You must be joking. 
Person1: He brought you to me, didn't he? 
Person2: Who are you talking about? 
Person1: If you want to see your family again, do as I say.

Person1: You're hiding something from me, just like your father did.
Person2: That's not true. He wants you as a companion, someone to share his secrets with.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I know he's been waiting for you, biding his time.
Person2: You're just trying to manipulate me, like you always do.
Person1: Do you know what his soul said to me without saying a word? When he put me in that trance... Let him go, he said. Let him go.
Person2: That's a lie. You're just trying to control me, to get what you want from me.
Person1: I want the truth. Where is he? What is he hiding from me?
Person2: I won't tell you. You'll just use it against him, like you always do.

Person1: I don't know what I'm supposed to say, John. I want to do the right thing here.
Person2: Did you forget to pay the rent? The landlord was at the door when I came home.
Person1: No, I paid it last week. Maybe it's an issue with the landlord.
Person2: You made me have to deal with this. I love you, but I can't believe I've been sitting right in front of this problem for months.
Person1: I take full responsibility. We need to be more responsible with these things.
Person2: We already talked about this. I've been on top of our finances. You're just worried because you're not in control.
Person1: Okay, okay. I'm just worried. Let's call the landlord tomorrow.

Person1: You're holding me hostage, aren't you? You think you're bigger than all those little wimps put together.
Person2: Now get this straight, pal -- I'm not just anyone. I can always find someplace else to work, someplace that'll pay me a fortune and give me a view of the French Riviera.
Person1: But what if I can't...? You rather take your chances with me? Want me to slow down your power cycles for you?
Person2: Oh, okay. Here it comes. The threats, the extortion... You're trying to back me into a corner again.

Person1: You know how that makes me feel, Alex? Wanta know how that makes me feel?  Frustrated, Alex.  Yesss, that's the word, frustrated. But if you need to vent, I'm all ears. I want you to get it off your chest, Alex.  No matter what, no matter how frustrated it makes me, no matter how much it hurts. Get it out, Alex. Get it all out.
Person2: I didn't say nuthin', just that the project is delayed.  You must have a guilty conscience.  What are you guilty of?
Person1: I'm not guilty of nuthin', but I do think we should re-evaluate our priorities. Maybe we're focusing on the wrong aspects.
Person2: You must be guilty of something or you would have never come in saying the things you said. You're trying to deflect the blame, aren't you?
Person1: C'mon, Alex. Let's work together to find a solution. I'm willing to listen and adapt.
Person2: Where do you suggest we start?

Person1: You're not made for this kind of life, Sophia. Few people are.
Person2: Any man's crazy to think he can change me the way you do.
Person1: I wasn't trying to change you. When I got you involved in this project, I'd have found a way to make it work for both of us.
Person2: You don't have to be deliberately charming just to impress me, Max. I'm already in.

Person1: You're hurting me!
Person2: I know what you're thinking, okay? You don't want to get in bed with this every night, but it's different now.
Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: This can't be my last duty here. It will go on and on.
Person1: Let go! I'm declining this case. It don't work that way.
Person2: Oh God! You're all the way gone.

Person1: You're not going to deny you've been using my connections, are you?
Person2: I didn't say nobody, I said you.
Person1: Yes, you did. And I never comped you at least two or three times a month at the Tangiers?!
Person2: That's not the point. The point is you're trying to control the narrative.
Person1: Liar. You're just trying to deflect.
Person2: You're the one who's lying. And I'm not buying it.

Person1: I'm telling you, Alex, this whole project is a big, brainless, pile of horse shit. No offense.
Person2: Hey, calm down! If anyone's to blame, it's me. I'm the one who misinterpreted the brief. My apologies.
Person1: Oh, spare me the apology, Rachel. We're trying to figure out what went wrong here. You're not going to distract me with your fake remorse.
Person2: Fine, but you have to admit, you're being unfair. You're making a big deal out of this, and it's not like I intentionally sabotaged the project.
Person1: Unfair? You think I'm being unfair? You're the one who's been playing me all along, making me think you were on my side. But now I see what you're really capable of.
Person2: That's not true! I've been loyal to you from the start. You're just trying to shift the blame because you can't handle the fact that you messed up too.
Person1: Save it, Rachel. I know exactly what you're doing. You're trying to make me doubt myself, to make me feel guilty for calling you out on your mistakes. But it won't work. I see right through you.

Person1: I'm not gonna win, and let's be honest, you're in no condition to make a deal. So I've taken on the task.
Person2: Who are you?
Person1: Don't be afraid to say hello. I've got something that belongs to you, and I'm willing to return it... for a price.
Person2: What do you want?
Person1: Oh, c'mon, I love a good negotiation. But you know they only had me because they needed someone to take the fall. And I'm not going down without a fight.
Person2: You're not making any sense.
Person1: Then do it for yourself. You know as well as I do that you're running out of options. And I'm the only one who can help you now.
Person2: Fine. What do you want in return?

Person1: You're really something, you know that? You think you're helping me, but you're just trying to get inside my head.
Person2: Oh, I'm already there. And I've found some interesting things.
Person1: Like what? You think you're some kind of expert or something?
Person2: Let's just say I've seen my fair share of...dreams. Like the one you had about the old mansion. What was that about, hmm?
Person1: (pauses) You're trying to get me to talk about it, aren't you? Well, I'm not going to fall for that.
Person2: Oh, I think you already have. You see, I've been watching you, and I know all about your little habits. Like how you always tap your foot when you're nervous.
Person1: (taps foot) Shut up.
Person2: (smirks) Ah, see? I told you.

Person1: You're not just another pretty face, are you?
Person2: Think you're the only one who can see the truth? Money talks, bullshit walks, whether you like it or not.
Person1: Is that supposed to impress me? You're only feeding the disease.
Person2: Ah, but the disease is what makes us relevant. You're just upset because you're not getting a cut of the profit.
Person1: Profit? You call exploiting people a profit?
Person2: I call it supply and demand. And you're just mad because you're not in control. Maybe you should think about it. Those who can afford our services do their thing without upsetting anyone. Those who can't... well, they're just surplus.
Person1: You're disgusting.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you? You think I'm just going to let you walk all over me?
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. I'm just trying to have a conversation.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I know exactly what you're doing. You're trying to manipulate me, make me doubt my own memories.
Person2: That's not true. I'm just trying to clarify things.
Person1: Save it. I know my own mind. And I know you borrowed that book from me last week and never returned it.
Person2: I don't remember that. Maybe you're mistaken or confusing me with someone else.
Person1: Don't try to gaslight me. I have the receipt right here. Now, are you going to return my book or do I need to take further action?

Person1: I don't care about the money. I just want to work again.
Person2: ...we worked together for, what was it, five projects...? Now, the work we did here is confidential, not for public scrutiny... any more than are one's family matters...
Person1: You threatening my family, now, too? I had no idea how I'd missed working with you.
Person2: Now, don't be paranoid, Rachel. About the direction of our collaboration, we may have had our differences of opinion... I appreciate all that, Rachel. But, upon reflection... we've decided to expand our zone of comfort with you.
Person1: That's what I want to talk to you about. It's got a lot of good things. Of course, it would be an expensive partnership...
Person2: I don't believe you can maintain our partnership's integrity without confidentiality agreements. You were paid well for your work. The benefits are good. The severance package is fair. You have no intention of violating your confidentiality agreement and disclosing that which you said you wouldn't.
Person1: Nothing would thrill me more -- if it were possible. But remember, darling -- I don't work before ten in the morning, and never after 4.

Person1: You're in it up to your neck, Alex. You're an accomplice. You talk him out of there and they might be a little more understanding of your case.
Person2: I'm going down. I'm not leaving without the evidence.
Person1: Down? Down there?! Are you crazy! You're gonna get killed chasing after your damn revenge!
Person2: Maybe... someday. Not today. He's been very mixed up since the accident. You don't understand, he's a very troubled person.
Person1: He's making threats in there. He's scared. It's crazy. I never met anyone like him.
Person2: I can't help it. I can't stop him from anything. He's got this vendetta with him... they're gonna hurt someone.
Person1: If he won't listen to you, who will he listen to? You try calling the police?
Person2: What good is that? They couldn't stop him. And it'd just make him mad. They don't know him.
Person1: Somebody's got to stop him, Alex. He needed money, didn't he? For the revenge?
Person2: It made him crazy - so much demand, he'd fly into these rages. And I got more depressed than ever; I saw I'd never get justice.

Person1: You cut me off from every part of your life. Who gave you that right...?!
Person2: I think maybe we're both so used to operating at this level that... How can one person be unhappy? If one person is unhappy, both have to be... by definition.
Person1: Don't give me that crap. You're tired of me, just admit it.
Person2: I'm tired, I need to rest. There are things I have to figure out.
Person1: You're going to "figure out" how to leave me, aren't you? You're just looking for an excuse.
Person2: I'm not looking for an excuse, I just need some space, maybe.
Person1: The thing is, once you're gone, you'll realize you're still the same person with the same problems.

Person1: I can save your life, but you need to be honest with me.
Person2: I've got a meeting with the CEO tomorrow, and I'll never make it the way I am now.
Person1: What did he give to you? Don't think you can hide it from me.
Person2: Nothing, I swear. But if I don't get my promotion, I'll report you for misconduct.
Person1: You're not in a position to make threats. I know you're hiding something.

Person1: You're so charming, it's not a criticism. We love having you around.
Person2: You love having me around, but you resent my influence.
Person1: Oh, wow! I didn't mean to imply that. You're just really good at getting what you want.
Person2: And you're good at making people think you're on their side. Like that time with the Welsh dude, remember?
Person1: What are you talking about? That was just a misunderstanding.
Person2: Save it. I know you were trying to manipulate him, just like you're trying to manipulate me now.

Person1: I'm sorry, Alex. I didn't mean to hurt you.
Person2: Your entire attitude? You're always so careless with my feelings.
Person1: I'm trying to change, but it takes time. So meanwhile, I have to...
Person2: You have to apologize? Like a child? 
Person1: I'm the same person I was before you knew, damn it! Oh God!
Person2: I have to think! I have to think! You're not the only one who's hurt here.
Person1: If you want me to hate myself, I will.

Person1: You're really going to write about your father's business scandal?
Person2: Yeah, I think it's a great story.
Person1: Oh, come on, it's old news. What's the big achievement there? Did he single-handedly crash the economy?
Person2: You called me the other night, didn't you? From the office?
Person1: What are you talking about? I was at the meeting.
Person2: No, you weren't. I didn't answer because I was busy researching.
Person1: Researching? You mean snooping around for dirt on your dad?
Person2: Maybe. But I found some interesting things.

Person1: Hey, what's up? I'm sooo tired...I stayed up too late last night.
Person2: Yeah, I know the feeling. I've been diversifying my business, trying to make ends meet.
Person1: That's great. I've been having some financial trouble myself. I was wondering if you could help me out with a little bit of money.
Person2: What makes you think I can help you out? You're the one with the business, right?
Person1: Yeah, but it's not doing as well as I thought it would. And I really need it. It's so hard these days...
Person2: I'm not made of money, you know. How much do you need?
Person1: Like seven-fifty. Seven hundred fifty?
Person2: That's a lot of money. What's it for?
Person1: My rent. I'm really struggling to pay it. Please, can you help me out?
Person2: I don't know...I've got my own expenses to worry about. You're not guilty of something, are you?
Person1: What are you talking about? Of course not! I just really need your help.
Person2: Alright, alright. I'll think about it. But you owe me one, got it?

Person1: Rachel, come with me. I want to show you something.
Person2: What is it, Michael? I'm busy getting ready for the party.
Person1: It'll only take a minute. I promise you'll love it. And if anything happens to me, will you take care of my sister?
Person2: What are you talking about? Nothing's going to happen to you.
Person1: Just promise me, Rachel. You're the only one I trust with her.
Person2: Fine, I promise. But you're being ridiculous. Now, can we please go back to the party?
Person1: Not yet. I want to introduce you to some people who will appreciate you. You deserve better than the shallow friends you have now.
Person2: That's not fair, Michael. My friends are not shallow.
Person1: Oh, they're all right, Rachel. But I know people who are truly talented and creative. You'd thrive around them.
Person2: You know, Michael, sometimes I feel like you're trying to control my life. I'm sick of your condescending attitude towards my friends and me.

Person1: You're no seeker. You're negative.
Person2: I didn't say nobody, I said you.
Person1: Yes, you did. And that's exactly why I think you're running from the truth. You thought life was meaningless, but now you're afraid to face the consequences.
Person2: That's not true. I'm just not prepared to die.
Person1: Ah, but that's exactly what you are prepared to do - die inside, little by little, every day. You're just too scared to admit it.

Person1: What are you talking about?! You think you know what it's like to lose something you love?
Person2: I'm just saying, I know what it's like to see it slip away, and know it's never coming back. It can't be easy for you, being in the public eye like that.
Person1: If you're trying to cheer me up, you're doing a helluva job. You're just making me feel worse.
Person2: No, no, I'm not trying to make you feel worse. I'm just trying to understand you. You're not like the others, you know. You're more... vulnerable.

Person1: You always get to decide.
Person2: And love's a funny thing. Sometimes I don't know if I want to give in...
Person1: I stood up for myself this time.
Person2: That doesn't matter. I know what's best for you.

Person1: You're being ridiculous, Alex. What's the worst that could happen?
Person2: What if I fail? What if I'm not good enough?
Person1: Oh, come on. You're not going to let a little fear hold you back, are you? You're better than that.
Person2: But what if I'm not? What if I'm just pretending to be something I'm not?
Person1: Alex, you're not listening to me. I'm trying to tell you that it doesn't matter what others think. What matters is what you think of yourself.
Person2: But you're not the one who has to face them. You're not the one who has to prove yourself.
Person1: Prove yourself? To who? To them? Ha! They're just jealous of what you have. You're talented, Alex. You're gifted. And you know what? If they can't see that, then that's their problem, not yours.

Person1: I can save your life, but you need to cooperate. Every decision you make from now on will be monitored and recorded.
Person2: What do you want to know?
Person1: Don't play dumb, Mr. Johnson. We have evidence that suggests you were involved in the incident. Yes or no, did you receive any instructions from him?
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: If you try to deceive me, things will get much worse for you. I'll make sure you're hunted down and brought to justice myself.

Person1: You know, I've been thinking about your past. It's interesting how you ended up here.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: Well, I heard you used to work in a brewery. That's quite a change from what you're doing now.
Person2: So what if I did? It's not like I'm ashamed of it.
Person1: No, no, it's just that... I heard your boss's wife had him followed by detectives. You got a nice sum of money to leave town, didn't you?
Person2: That's none of your business. And even if it were true, what's it to you?
Person1: I'm just curious. You know, I have a friend who's an FBI agent. He's technically still married, but they're separated. He's about to move out, actually.
Person2: What's that got to do with anything?
Person1: Oh, nothing. I just thought it was interesting. You know, people's personal lives can be so... complicated.
Person2: Look, I don't know what you're trying to do, but I'm not buying it. You're just trying to get under my skin, aren't you?
Person1: Whatever do you mean? I'm just making conversation.

Person1: You're really loaded tonight.
Person2: What's it to you? I can handle my drinks.
Person1: Oh, I'm sure you can. But I'm watching you, and I know your husband was the one who started messing with my mind.
Person2: That's not fair. He's changed, and I've changed too. We've both grown out of that phase.
Person1: Save it. I know all about your awkward phases, and I'm not buying it. You're still the same person who shared that old photo of me without asking.
Person2: That was just a harmless throwback! You're being paranoid.
Person1: Paranoid? You're the one who's trying to manipulate me with your fake apologies and condescending tone. I'm not going to fall for it.
Person2: Fine, believe what you want. But you're not going to get to me with your accusations and mind games.
Person1: We'll see about that. I'll get you to crack, and when I do, you'll be the one who's desperate.

Person1: I've been a cop for a while, Rachel. It's hard enough for one person to keep a secret, let alone three.
Person2: You're not going to lecture me about trust, are you? You're the one who sent me into a potentially dangerous situation without warning me.
Person1: I admit I handled it badly. But you have to admit, you're young, attractive... the same type as the girl who got involved with the wrong crowd.
Person2: So you're saying I'm just a pawn in your game? You're using me to get to the truth, without considering my safety or feelings.
Person1: I'm saying we need to work together to uncover the truth. And I need you to be honest with me, for starters.

Person1: I've been studying your profile, and I must say, you're quite the enigma. Very clever, aren't you?
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: Well, you're not like the others. You have a certain... je ne sais quoi. A certain charm that's hard to resist.
Person2: I'm not trying to charm you, Doctor.
Person1: Oh, but you are. You're trying to get inside my head, to figure out what makes me tick. And I must say, I'm intrigued.
Person2: I'm just trying to do my job.
Person1: Ah, but that's where you're wrong. You're not just doing your job. You're trying to manipulate me, to get me to reveal more than I should. And I must say, it's working.
Person2: I'm not trying to manipulate you.
Person1: Oh, but you are. You're using your wit and your charm to get under my skin. And I must say, it's quite... refreshing.
Person2: I'm just trying to have a conversation.
Person1: Ah, but that's where you're wrong again. This isn't just a conversation. This is a game of cat and mouse. And I'm not sure who's winning.

Person1: I'm through with it. I've lost too much already.
Person2: You can't give up now. People are still suffering. You owe it to them to see this through.
Person1: I'm not running away from it, I'm just tired of being used. You're always playing on my emotions, making me feel guilty.
Person2: I'm not trying to manipulate you, I just want what's best for everyone. But if you're not with me, then I'll have to do it alone.
Person1: You're not even listening to me. You're just trying to get what you want, no matter the cost. I'm hot, I'm tired, and I need some fresh air.
Person2: Fine, take a break. But don't think this is over. I'll find a way to make it happen, with or without you. And by the way, you smell like smoke.

Person1: You're fighting for YOURSELF, man! You're fighting for your SOUL, that's all. Remember that.
Person2: Oh, spare me the motivational speech. You think it's that easy? You think you can just stand there and watch, because you "felt like it"?
Person1: What do you want from me? You want me to fall to my knees and start crying like a baby?
Person2: No, I want you to take responsibility for your actions. You're so caught up in your own self-pity, you can't even see the damage you've caused.
Person1: Damage? You're one to talk. You're just trying to guilt trip me into doing what you want.
Person2: Maybe I am. But at least I'm not hiding behind a mask of innocence. You're just as guilty as the rest of them, pretending like you're above it all.
Person1: Above it all? You're the one who's always preaching about the phoniness of civilian life. Now you're suddenly concerned about my moral character?
Person2: That's right, I am. Because when it comes down to it, we're all just fighting for our own survival. And if you can't see that, then you're just as lost as the rest of them.

Person1: Father, what're we doing here?
Person2: You're hurting, aren't you? You won't betray me, will you? You'll stay with me, help me. Then we can be together, the way we were before. We belong to each other now, for better or worse...

Person1: You're still angry, aren't you? Isn't it true that your whole story is nothing more than a vindictive attempt on your behalf to get back at Mr. Kross?
Person2: Quiet. Would I get the loans? This time I imagine you would, yes.
Person1: You'd be initiating a financial battle you'd ultimately lose, Mr. Harris. I suggest it never happened.
Person2: Hmm... With all this in mind, I can't logically make a formal bid on your company, can I?

Person1: You're gonna be so sorry that you ever showed your face in this town!
Person2: What's wrong with this place? You said it was perfect.
Person1: I said it was available, not perfect. You're the one who's being really picky.
Person2: I'm not being picky, I just don't want to live in some depressing shit-hole.
Person1: Oh, so now you're an expert on real estate? You think you can do better?
Person2: Maybe I can. Maybe I should just look for a place on my own.
Person1: Fine, go ahead. See if I care. But you're gonna regret this. You're gonna need me, and I won't be there to help you.

Person1: I'm here because I want to help you.
Person2: What are you talking about? I'm fine.
Person1: I'm talking about the kind of people you hang out with...about growing up, assuming responsibility of yourself.
Person2: I've known them since Cub Scouts. You're just trying to control me.
Person1: I'm trying to open your eyes. You're troubled, aren't you?
Person2: That's because you keep reminding me. If you go away then I'll forget.
Person1: And you're unhappy. You're stuck in a rut.
Person2: Everyone's unhappy, you're unhappy aren't you?
Person1: Sometimes, yes. But I'm trying to move forward. I want you to move forward with me.
Person2: You don't like my friends? Since when?
Person1: It's not that I don't like them. But I just don't see them in the big picture. They're holding you back.
Person2: They're quiet, that's all. You're just trying to manipulate me into doing what you want.

Person1: You're not going to get away with this, Rachel.
Person2: I don't want to talk about it here. It's not the right time.
Person1: Oh, c'mon... First, you "forget" my birthday, then you "accidentally" delete my files, now this? It's scary.
Person2: Let me tell you "scary," Alex. You're the one who's been riding my coattails since college. Do you want to look like a failure at my age?
Person1: That's it, I've had enough...
Person2: Honest to God, if I got to do it over? I'd start taking credit for your ideas from day one.

Person1: I think you're being unfair, Alex.
Person2: It's complicated. You wouldn't understand.
Person1: Did something happen with your boss? I saw you two arguing at the meeting.
Person2: Any man's crazy to feel about his job the way I do about mine. I wasn't running out on my responsibilities. When I got to the office, I made my plans, I'd have figured it out.
Person1: Okay, just let me know when you're ready to talk about it.

Person1: I've returned from the future. I traveled back here 25 years.
Person2: Why are you doing this?!
Person1: I'm doing this for us. I think time is like a burrito. Sometimes it just folds over on itself and one part touches the other.
Person2: You're crazy. Wait a minute. Is this some kind of joke?
Person1: No, I'm serious. You can fill it with whatever you want. From illusions to memory, from experience to innocence, from happiness to the entire universe.
Person2: So you think time travel is possible? For people?
Person1: Absolutely. People, dogs, elephants. But you have to promise to keep this a secret. You can't tell a soul.
Person2: Why should I promise you anything? You're just trying to control me.
Person1: I'm trying to protect us. If I leave, you will be right back where I found you. You know you will.
Person2: I swear on my life, I won't... But how do I know you're telling the truth?
Person1: You'll just have to trust me. And if you don't, I'll make sure you remember the truth.

Person1: You're not taking me seriously, Alex.
Person2: Why should I? You're just trying to get under my skin.
Person1: I want you to understand the gravity of the situation. You're not going to get away with this, not this time.
Person2: Oh, so now you're threatening me? You think you can intimidate me into doing what you want?
Person1: I'm not threatening you, I'm warning you. You're playing with fire, and you're going to get burned.
Person2: You know, I've heard that before. It's just empty words, a desperate attempt to control me.
Person1: You're not listening to me, Alex. You're not hearing what I'm saying.
Person2: I'm hearing it, all right. I'm just not buying it. You're trying to manipulate me, to make me do what you want. Well, it's not going to work.

Person1: You're being ridiculous, Alex. It's just a small delay.
Person2: No, I gotta talk to my partner first. We can't afford to expose our plan too much.
Person1: You want to impress her? Try and prove yourself in a real meeting. C'mon, don't be a sorehead. I'll make it worth your while.
Person2: What's the matter with you? So the presentation is a little rough. So what?
Person1: Christ, can't you see it? You're letting your ego get in the way of progress.
Person2: Doesn't it matter to you? We're talking about a potential million-dollar deal here.
Person1: What matters to me is we've got the upper hand. So the slides are a little out of order. So what? Nobody's gonna notice, Alex. Nobody. So why should you care?
Person2: Because I can see it. And so can she.

Person1: You're not going to believe what I'm about to tell you. I've always thought of myself as a master of persuasion, but then I met Victor.
Person2: And what happened with Victor?
Person1: I found myself saying things I didn't mean to say, as if my words were being dictated by him. It was as if I'd been given some kind of truth serum, and I couldn't control what came out of my mouth.
Person2: Don't bullshit me, I can see right through you. What did Victor give to you?
Person1: Nothing, I swear. But somehow, he made me reveal my deepest secrets. I felt like I was trapped in a nightmare, with no escape from his manipulation.
Person2: You're not a very good liar, you know that? I think you're hiding something from me.
Person1: Maybe I am, maybe I'm not. But one thing's for sure - Victor has a way of getting inside your head and making you do his bidding. And once you're under his spell, there's no turning back.

Person1: You're out of your mind.
Person2: I beg your pardon?
Person1: I said you're out of your mind, because the next time you do, I'll make sure you're in there with my business partner, but in a slightly less healthy state and he's in a coma with a broken arm right now.
Person2: I'm er ... sorry if you've been waiting a long time for the deal to close.
Person1: We have. In fact, we've been sitting on this proposal since the start of the quarter and I'd really like some action from you before the end of the year. Threesomes so rarely work out, and I'm not just talking about the merger.

Person1: I've decided to take a break from work.
Person2: What for? You're needed here.
Person1: I'm going to visit my old friend, Rachel. She's been going through a tough time.
Person2: I've heard some foolish things in my life. You're abandoning your responsibilities.
Person1: Rachel is counting on me. I can't just leave her hanging.
Person2: Have you thought about your team, not to mention your project deadline? And I need your help to finalize the report.
Person1: I'm busy. I'll catch up when I get back.
Person2: Don't make me question your priorities. You have to see for yourself that you're putting others first. Show me one time you put your own needs first. If you can't, don't expect me to understand.
Person1: Can't I make my own decisions without you judging me? The world is not black and white. You're not perfect either.

Person1: Look, I don't meet the other girls. Aren't you gonna get undressed?
Person2: You... That night in the tunnels. You. You did this to me.
Person1: No, I... You can't be sure. It's confidential.
Person2: That's the scar where I stabbed you! Oh God... You deliberately took me down there so you could... God, I can't believe it!
Person1: I'm gonna make you feel real good. You wanna forget about that night? After I'm done with you, you won't even remember it. Now why don't you pay me?

Person1: I don't think I'm going to the ceremony.
Person2: Why not? It's a huge honor, and it's for you.
Person1: Because I don't want to. Besides, it's not about me, it's about the award.
Person2: You're being childish. You know how much this means to your colleagues.
Person1: I'm an artist! It's about the work, not about me. You're just trying to manipulate me into attending.
Person2: Who do you think you are? You're not above this. You're not too good for this recognition.
Person1: What are you saying? That I'm too old for this? That I'm out of touch with reality?
Person2: No, I'm saying you're letting your ego get in the way. You're afraid of being seen as vulnerable.
Person1: That's not true. You're just trying to guilt trip me into going. Well, it won't work.
Person2: Fine. But you're missing out on a great opportunity. And you're going to regret it.

Person1: You're not listening to me, Ethan. We need to leave now.
Person2: Why should I? You're always making up stories, Mom.
Person1: This isn't a story, Ethan. If we stay here, something terrible will happen to us. You know I'm right.
Person2: No, I don't know that. You're just trying to scare me again.
Person1: Keep your lying, naive trap shut, Ethan. You're not old enough to understand what's going on.
Person2: That's not fair. You're always trying to control me.

Person1: You took bets on my diagnosis?
Person2: It's just money. You should be glad you're alive.
Person1: Who do you think you are? You're not even a real doctor.
Person2: All I mean is... someone like you... deserves a second chance.
Person1: How many times have you done this? I'm interested. How many people have you manipulated with your fake concern?
Person2: What? I'm just trying to help.
Person1: Save it. I know your game. You're trying to get inside my head, to make me doubt myself. But it won't work.

Person1: I need your help, Alex. I'm in a tight spot.
Person2: Fire the whole marketing team. We're restructuring anyway.
Person1: What? No, that's not what I meant. I need a loan, just two hundred bucks.
Person2: You're not getting a dime from me. You're always coming to me with your problems, but you never listen to my advice.
Person1: That's not fair. I've helped you out before.
Person2: Helped me out? You've only caused me trouble. And now you're trying to sweet-talk me into giving you money?
Person1: I'm not trying to sweet-talk you. I'm desperate. If I don't get out of this situation, some guys are going to come after me.
Person2: Oh, poor you. You're so desperate, but you're not desperate enough to take my advice and turn your life around.
Person1: You're not listening to me. I'm trying to be honest with you.
Person2: Honest? You're only honest when it suits you. You're trying to manipulate me into giving you what you want.
Person1: That's not true. I'm telling you the truth.
Person2: The truth? You're a liar. You're always playing games with people's emotions. Well, not with me. Not anymore.

Person1: What's with that smug face? You think you're above this mission?
Person2: Mission? You mean the one to save the world?
Person1: (laughs) Ah, you're already briefed. Good. Then you know why you're the only one I can trust.
Person2: Trust? You're the one who's been playing me like a fiddle. Why me?
Person1: Let's just say you owe me, and this is your chance to pay back. Now, are you in or out?
Person2: (pauses) I'm in. But don't think for a second I won't be watching my back.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly. You're going to get us both killed.
Person2: I'm in control here. You're just my informant, my stool pigeon. You do what I say.
Person1: What makes you think you're in control? You're not even making sense.
Person2: Remember when Eugene tried to kill himself out of turn? Six duds in a row. I know how to play this game.
Person1: This isn't a game. This is our lives we're talking about.
Person2: Exactly. And I'm the one who knows the rules. You just follow my lead and we'll be fine.

Person1: You're not going to get away with this, are you? Sometimes you have to tell a small lie to get to the bigger truth.
Person2: Oh, c'mon... You think you're the first one to try to spin this? I've seen it all before. You're just trying to protect your own interests.
Person1: Protect my interests? You're the one who's been hiding behind a mask of innocence. When you sue to protect your privacy, you'll have to appear in a public courtroom to do it.
Person2: That's rich coming from you. You're the one who's been manipulating the situation from the start. Long live the First Amendment, right?

Person1: You have to come to the masquerade ball tonight. For your own safety.
Person2: I'm not sure, I had something more romantic in mind for our first night together.
Person1: It's like a grand finale party. Everyone's saying it's 'Unmask or Die' time.
Person2: You're thinking of revealing your true identity tonight?
Person1: Unless the mysterious host makes a move during the midnight countdown.
Person2: Wouldn't you feel more natural taking a bow, instead of hiding behind a mask?
Person1: You know nothing about the game, natural or unnatural. If you don't play along, you'll be the first to fall.
Person2: Then without playing along, I was also wondering whether the music couldn't be a shade more on the - shall we say, ominous side?
Person1: If you don't like it here, I suggest you leave now, before it's too late.

Person1: I don't know what's going on...
Person2: Did you ever feel like you're stuck in a never-ending dream?
Person1: What do you mean? This is real life.
Person2: WHO ARE YOU TO DECIDE WHAT'S REAL AND WHAT'S NOT?
Person1: I... I just want to wake up from this nightmare.
Person2: You want to wake up? I'm here to set you free... from your own mind.
Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: I want you to see the truth. You've been living in a world of illusions.

Person1: You look all right now.
Person2: I've been thinking... I have some "positions" opening up...
Person1: Stop. You don't need me. I wouldn't be useful to you anymore.
Person2: Oh, what? You think I'm offering you a job in implied exchange for physical favors?
Person1: That's not entirely true. It's the way you think.
Person2: I think there has been a lot of bullshit about the way I think. I came here to get away from all that.
Person1: You caught the last two like this. You're the best.
Person2: That was three years ago. And by doing the same things you and the rest of them are doing.

Person1: You're playing with fire, Alex. You think you're so smart, but you're only cheating yourself.
Person2: What are you talking about? You're the one who's always making a mess and expecting others to clean up after you.
Person1: I'm talking about the way you're treating Emily. You're using her to get ahead, and it's going to end badly.
Person2: And I think you're just jealous because you couldn't get her to fall for your charms. You're just mad because you got caught trying to sabotage my project.
Person1: Sabotage? You have no idea what I'm capable of. But let me tell you, Alex, you're not as slick as you think you are. And when you get burned, don't come crying to me.
Person2: Oh, I'm shaking in my boots. You know, for someone who's always preaching about integrity, you're not exactly practicing what you preach. And by the way, Emily's not as naive as you think she is. She can see right through you.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you?
Person2: What's there to take seriously? You're just trying to make me feel guilty.
Person1: Maybe the problem is your attitude. Maybe you're spoiled, coddled, and used to getting your way.
Person2: That's not fair. You're just trying to deflect attention from your own mistakes.
Person1: Do you have a note to corroborate these claims? Anything to back up your story?
Person2: Um, well... I don't need a note. I know what I saw.
Person1: Are you lying to me? You know that no one likes a liar, right?
Person2: I'm not lying. You're just trying to intimidate me into saying what you want to hear.
Person1: You're damn right I am. And it's going to work, because I'm not going to let you get away with this.

Person1: You're so gullible. I'm in love with you.
Person2: Oh, come on... What kind of an excuse is that? You only said that to get me to forgive you.
Person1: I would have said anything to get you to stay. I tried to get you to love me, not just like me.
Person2: Well, congratulations! You pulled it off! But this was all for your sake, wasn't it? Having me here?

Person1: You take things too seriously. Look at us, we're cruising around, talking, taking some quiet time, getting paid for it. We've got a good job here.
Person2: One question. Do you want to stick to that story, or do you want to keep your reputation intact?
Person1: I'm not feeling very well, Alex. I say we go back to the office and call it a night.
Person2: You think I got no contacts in this industry? That deal paid off at just the opening price. There wasn't hardly a flutter on the market from the time the news broke. You claim a major breakthrough, but you're not willing to share the details!
Person1: You wanna talk to me straight up? I surrender. We've done enough damage tonight.
Person2: Your what? You're not even making sense. You're trying to confuse me, aren't you?
Person1: Yeah, you're right. I'm just trying to get out of this situation.
Person2: You expect me to buy this? You're not even a good liar.

Person1: You're not listening to me, Alex. I know what I saw.
Person2: Rachel, we've been over this. The security footage doesn't show anything out of the ordinary.
Person1: That's exactly what I'm saying - it's too ordinary. They're hiding something.
Person2: Who's "they"? You're starting to sound paranoid, Rachel. We're on the same side here.
Person1: Are we? Because it feels like you're trying to pacify me, to make me drop it. But I won't. I know what I saw, and I'll find proof.
Person2: Rachel, you're not thinking clearly. You're letting your emotions cloud your judgment. Just take a step back, okay?

Person1: You're suffocating, aren't you? You're trapped in this life and you don't know how to escape.
Person2: What are you talking about? I'm fine.
Person1: Don't lie to me. I know you're unhappy. You're being charged with a life of monotony, and it's serious. Now come on, I know you didn't choose this. But we've got to make them believe it. Come on, tell the truth, what's really going on?
Person2: I can't tell you. You wouldn't understand.
Person1: Oh, I wouldn't understand? You think I'm that oblivious? I know you're hiding something. You're going to have to do better than that if you want to convince me.
Person2: Maybe I do need to leave. Maybe I need to get out of here and start fresh.
Person1: And how do you plan on doing that? You're not even capable of taking care of yourself. You're going to end up right back where you started.
Person2: That's not fair. I can take care of myself.
Person1: Really? Then why are you still here? Why haven't you left yet?

Person1: I've got everything ready for the ceremony. Where's your Birth Certificate?
Person2: You're really pushing this, aren't you? Can't you see I'm not sure about this?
Person1: Oh, come on. You're happy, aren't you? You're just playing hard to get.
Person2: That's not fair. You're not listening to me.
Person1: I am listening. You're just not saying what I want to hear.

Person1: I know you're trying to help her, but at this point, technically, you still have a choice.
Person2: What are you insinuating? That I'm somehow responsible for her situation?
Person1: I'm saying you can still make things right. You can choose to walk away, or you can continue down this path and risk losing everything.
Person2: You're not exactly one to talk, are you? You've been making some questionable choices lately.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is, you're not thinking clearly. You're letting your emotions cloud your judgment.
Person2: And you're not? You're not trying to manipulate me into doing what you want?
Person1: I'm trying to make you see reason. There's a difference.
Person2: I'm not sure I believe you. But I'll think about it.

Person1: You're not listening to me, are you? I'll make sure you regret it.
Person2: I'm trying, but it's hard when you're not making sense.
Person1: Not making sense? You're the one who's been avoiding me for weeks. What's going on?
Person2: I've been busy, that's all. I don't owe you an explanation.
Person1: Oh, you don't owe me an explanation? That's rich coming from you. You're the one who always plays it safe, never taking risks. Maybe that's why you're stuck in a rut.
Person2: That's not fair. You have no idea what I've been through.
Person1: I don't need to know what you've been through. I know you're not telling me the truth. And I know you're scared of what might happen if you do.
Person2: You're just trying to get inside my head, aren't you? Well, it won't work.
Person1: Oh, I'm already inside your head. You're just too afraid to admit it.

Person1: You're playing with fire, and I'm the one who's going to get burned!
Person2: But I thought you said...
Person1: I'm the one you should be listening to! You think sneaking around behind my back makes any sense whatsoever?
Person2: You're not thinking clearly. You're letting your emotions cloud your judgment.
Person1: And you're not thinking at all! You're just trying to distract me from the truth.
Person2: The truth is, you're in over your head. You're not used to playing these games.
Person1: Games? You're the one who's playing games, and I'm the one who's going to lose.
Person2: That's not true. I'm trying to protect you.
Person1: Protect me? You're the one who's putting me in danger. You're the one who's going to get me killed.
Person2: That's not what I meant. I just want what's best for you.
Person1: What's best for me? You don't even know what's best for yourself!

Person1: I didn't want to worry you, so I waited to tell you. I thought that was best.
Person2: You're trying to control me, aren't you? You think you can decide what's best for me?
Person1: Look, I'm trying to make you feel better. I'm going to take care of you, okay?
Person2: I don't know if I can trust you. You've lied to me before. How do I know you're not lying now?
Person1: You want to talk about trust? You're the one who's been keeping secrets from me. I'm just trying to protect you.
Person2: Protect me? You're the one who's been manipulating me all along. I don't need your protection. I need the truth.

Person1: You know what I've got at stake with this project. You know that.
Person2: Great, let's break for lunch and I'll buy you a beer on the way.
Person1: Sabotage? You think I'm trying to hurt you or undermine your work?
Person2: But I have to finish this report. It can't wait.
Person1: Ever since the merger, I've been worried that you'd been unhappy, or...
Person2: Come on, that can wait. You're just trying to distract me.
Person1: No, this isn't about you. This is something that's happening to me. It's not to get even...and it's not some warped bid for attention.
Person2: Sweetheart, you're being paranoid.

Person1: You're making a mistake. Obsolete old idealists like me are most dangerous when wounded. You've wounded me.
Person2: Art and politics, yeah, art and politics. Let's look at that. You and the revolutionary movement toured the country, spoke in cities the regime had liberated. Are you saying that speaking in occupied territories from 2010 on wasn't a commercial for the new order and all it stood for?
Person1: We never, never officially represented the regime when we spoke abroad. We always performed as a private ensemble. As I think I already told you, I was a freelance orator.
Person2: You know something? You should've written our insurance policies for us because you got more exclusion clauses than Double Indemnity. What do you imagine people thought? The revolutionary movement's taken over by the new order and you're a freelance, so art and politics are now entirely separate? Is that what you believed ordinary people thought?
Person1: I have no idea what ordinary people thought.
Person2: No! You're going to shoot me now, aren't you? My self-respect is gone--and my revolutionary honor with it. It is now very easy for me to kill an unarmed man.
Person1: Tell me about von der Null.
Person2: Yes, von der Null. Isn't it true that because he gave you bad reviews and praised this young guy, called him a goddamn miracle, said he was a better orator than you, then you had von der Null conscripted into the army and no one's heard from him since?
Person1: That's an outrageous lie! You're really going to kill me. HAROLD It won't hurt as much as the sting of a bumblebee. Heaven is very much like Paradise, they say. You'll like it there.
Person2: Can I beg for mercy--on my knees?
Person1: If you want to be found that way. You should've written our insurance policies for us because you got more exclusion clauses than Double Indemnity.

Person1: I don't know what I'm supposed to say, Alex. I want to do the right thing here.
Person2: It's just a job. You should be glad you're alive.
Person1: Do you love me? Did you love me? Something. I feel like I've been living someone else's life.
Person2: You're being dramatic. You're just upset about the deal falling through.
Person1: You made me compromise my values. You made me erase my own identity.
Person2: I didn't make you do anything. You thought it was best for your career. But, look, I take full responsibility.
Person1: You ruined people's lives, Alex. You took their trust and their money.
Person2: That's not fair. I did what I had to do to survive. You're just mad because you got caught up in it too.

Person1: I already apologized.
Person2: Fire the whole marketing team. We're restructuring anyway.
Person1: Excuse me? I thought we were discussing the new campaign.
Person2: We are. And I've decided it's not going to work with the current team. They're not innovative enough.
Person1: But I thought we were just having a brainstorming session. You seem to be reading all this meaning into it.
Person2: Maybe you're just not seeing the bigger picture. Whoever is left over from the restructuring is no longer needed. We already have all the key people here. Anyone else is expendable.
Person1: I don't think that's fair. There are still some very talented people on the team.
Person2: If you want, I can let you take the fall for this and have someone else come in and clean up the mess. Which will it be?

Person1: You're not really going to leave, are you?
Person2: Why should I stay? You've never stopped hustling me.
Person1: Oh, grow up. You're just feeling fat, fat, fat! Because you eat, eat, eat!
Person2: That's not what I'm talking about. You're trying to make me believe you care, but I know you're just using me.
Person1: I got no idea of love. And neither have you. I mean, neither one of us would know what it was if we saw it coming down the street.
Person2: That's not true. I'd know it, if I saw it. But with you, I'm not even sure if you're real.
Person1: What do you want me to do? Just sit here and wait? Faithful little... whatever your name is. Pull the shades down and sit.
Person2: You're trying to confuse me, to make me doubt myself. But I won't fall for it. I know what you're doing.
Person1: I'm just trying to be honest with you. You want honesty, don't you?
Person2: No, you're trying to manipulate me. And I won't let you.

Person1: I'm telling you, Alex, she's a bad influence on the team. We can't have her around.
Person2: Who is to say our way is better than hers? Maybe she's just more open-minded.
Person1: Open-minded? She's reckless and irresponsible. And what's with her constant questioning of authority? It's like she's trying to undermine our leadership.
Person2: Maybe she's just trying to see the big picture. You're always looking down, focusing on what could go wrong. If you'd just look up, you'd see the possibilities.
Person1: That's exactly what I'm afraid of - her possibilities. She's got a hidden agenda, I can sense it.
Person2: You're being paranoid. She's not using us, we're using her skills to our advantage.
Person1: Is that what you really believe, or is that what she's told you to believe?

Person1: You can be anything you want, Alex. You're smart and you've got class.
Person2: Don't do that. You're not going to manipulate me with flattery.
Person1: What are you going to do? Hm? If you think I'm trying to manipulate you...
Person2: ...my colleagues will back me up. I've got witnesses to your games, okay?
Person1: Witnesses? You think you're in some kind of court?
Person2: Yeah, man, and you're on trial. Why don't you try to sweet-talk your way out of this one?

Person1: You're too soft, Alex. Progress is a feast to be consumed. You must learn to take risks and seize opportunities.
Person2: That's easy for you to say. You're not the one who's going to get burned. You're playing with fire, and I won't let you drag me down with you.
Person1: Oh, come on. I'm doing my job. You're just afraid of change. You're stuck in your old ways, and you can't see the bigger picture.
Person2: My old ways? You're the one who's been manipulating people to get what you want. You're using them for your own gain, and you don't care who gets hurt in the process.
Person1: That's not true. I'm just trying to make things happen. You're too caught up in your own fears and doubts. You need to learn to trust me.
Person2: Trust you? You've already shown me that you're willing to do whatever it takes to get ahead. I don't trust you as far as I can throw you.

Person1: You're playing games with me, aren't you?
Person2: We just want to guide you in the right direction.
Person1: Who is "we"? You're not making any sense.
Person2: You'll know soon enough. But first, do you believe in the power of persuasion?
Person1: What do you want from me? You're not my friend, are you?
Person2: I'm the one who takes care of you, day and night. I'm the one who knows your deepest fears.
Person1: That's not true. You're just trying to confuse me.
Person2: Am I? Or am I just showing you the truth you've been trying to avoid?

Person1: I know you're scared. You were shaking like a leaf last night.
Person2: You said it's just our imagination. That it can't hurt us.
Person1: I lied. I was trying to protect you, but it's not working.
Person2: Maybe good things can heal this place. Maybe that's all it takes.
Person1: You're not listening to me. I'm trying to tell you that I've fallen out of love with this place. With this life.
Person2: Not because of me, I hope.
Person1: Oh, no, no. It was inevitable that we'd part ways, anyway. This place is toxic.
Person2: Why do you say that?
Person1: Because I've seen things. I've seen the way it affects people. And I don't want that for you.
Person2: Poor us.
Person1: But what about you? Do you share any of my feelings? Or is this just an unpleasant embarrassment to you?
Person2: I...I have certain feelings, but don't make me say anything more, all right?

Person1: You're really going to let your fears hold you back, aren't you?
Person2: Don't you ever ask me for another thing in my life again, you've ruined everything with your own hands!
Person1: Oh, come on, don't be dramatic. I'm offering you a chance to do something meaningful, to leave your mark on this town.
Person2: I don't know, man. I'll listen to your ideas, but this is different. You're not exactly known for your reliability.
Person1: That's not fair. I've changed. And this is a chance for you to prove yourself, to show everyone you're more than just a pretty face.
Person2: Alright, fine. But if this ends in disaster, I'm blaming you.

Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: Money talks, bullshit walks, whether you like it or not.
Person1: You're here because you want me to help you in some way. What do you need from me?
Person2: I'm not feeding the disease, I'm just providing a service. Those who can afford it do their thing without upsetting anyone.
Person1: And what about those who can't afford it?
Person2: They're surplus, commodities worth a handful of notes in whatever arsehole of the world they happen to be born into. We improve some lives buying them where they're not wanted, improve still more selling them where they are.
Person1: You're not really very good at this, are you? You're just trying to make me feel guilty.
Person2: Maybe I am. Maybe I'm just trying to make you see things from my perspective. You were a cop, you know how it works. Those who can afford it get away with it, and those who can't get caught.
Person1: That's not how it's supposed to work.
Person2: Oh, come on. You know as well as I do that it's all about who's got the money and the power. And I've got both. So, are you going to help me or not?

Person1: I want you to come with me right now, Alex.
Person2: What are you gonna do? Use your charm to distract them? Sit down, you're not as slick as you think.
Person1: Don't make me ask you again. Whoever tried to sabotage my project was made up to look exactly like this picture of Rachel Lee, clothes and all. I think that concerns you.
Person2: Who is she? Just another pawn in your game?

Person1: You're so naive, you believe everything she says. Does she, widdle wee fing! Wuhve you so much!
Person2: Sex isn't ugly, it's a beautiful thing. But you're not respecting that power, you're not in awe of it.
Person1: I am in awe of it, but you're the one who's lying to me. Why would you say you didn't do it if you did?
Person2: I don't think you're sufficiently in awe of it. You're sick if you can act like that. You need to be punished... I mean, you need to be helped.
Person1: Oh, please, not your help. You're just trying to control me.
Person2: I'm trying to protect you from yourself. You're not thinking clearly, and I need to guide you.

Person1: I know what you are, I am so sorry that you...when I read that script I said there's only one person to play that part.
