Person2: That's exactly what they want you to think. You're not thinking clearly, Alex. You've been through a traumatic experience. You need guidance, and I'm here to offer it.

Person1: You're going to throw away our life together for some shared experience with a stranger that you misguidedly think is love?
Person2: You mess with this guy -- get him to do your dirty work and you think you can take the money and dump me?
Person1: No baby, you got it wrong. I understood when you dropped out of law school.
Person2: This road don't go to Globe, where were you going to meet me?
Person1: I've tried to be supportive, but really, what can you be thinking?
Person2: I love him.

Person1: You're not even trying to hide it, are you? I saw the messages on your phone.
Person2: Or maybe you just think you saw something. You're one of those hungry ghosts out there, never satisfied with nothing.
Person1: What do you want for free? You're just using me to get back at Jake.
Person2: Seems like I do, but only cause end of the day we're all eyes in the same head. And everything is everything. You're just mad because I needed someone to talk to.
Person1: That's not fair. You're playing with my emotions.
Person2: Loving you and needing someone to talk to are two different things. You can run just as far as you can, but wherever you go, that's where you're gonna be.

Person1: I don't care about the delays and I don't care about the excuses. I care about the results, and right now, I'm not seeing them.
Person2: Sir, if I may explain, the situation is more complex than you're making it out to be.
Person1: Please be quiet. I pay you to get things done, not to make excuses. If you cannot provide this simple service, you are of no use to me.
Person2: With all due respect, sir, bringing in professional hunters may not be the answer. It could lead to more chaos and unwanted attention.
Person1: I'll decide what's best for this project. And if you can't deliver, I'll find someone who can. Am I not fair? I told you you'd hate me.

Person1: You're responsible for everything. Get away from her!
Person2: I'm trying to save her, but you're not listening. You're very disturbed.
Person1: ARE YOU CRAZY?! YOU'RE HURTING HER!!
Person2: LISTEN TO ME! IF I DON'T DO THIS, SHE'LL DIE!

Person1: I'm telling you, we can't afford to stay here any longer.
Person2: You're so dramatic, Rachel. What's "not affordable" to you? Only a few hundred...
Person1: We've got barely enough to cover the rent, let alone food and utilities.
Person2: That doesn't make sense. You're just trying to get a rise out of me.
Person1: Look, do you want the truth, or just what you want me to say? I've been keeping track of our expenses, and we're in a precarious situation.
Person2: I want the truth. But I think you're letting your anxiety get the better of you. You're not thinking clearly.
Person1: The truth is that we're on the verge of financial collapse. And I'm not going to sugarcoat it for you.
Person2: Well, maybe if you didn't spend so much on your hobbies, we wouldn't be in this situation.
Person1: That's not fair. You know I've been cutting back on everything. You're just trying to deflect responsibility.
Person2: I'm trying to get you to see reason. You're being paranoid and irrational. Maybe you need to take a step back and reassess your priorities.
Person1: I've reassessed them, and I know exactly what's going on. You're just trying to manipulate me into staying in a situation that's not sustainable.

Person1: I want to know everything about his personal life. Did he frequent those underground art galleries on 5th Street?
Person2: What's that got to do with anything?
Person1: You'd be surprised what people are capable of when they think no one is watching. I will never forgive you for embarrassing me in front of my colleagues. You help us uncover the truth about Andy's death or you'll be sorry.
Person2: I'm sorry already, but I don't know what you're insinuating.
Person1: Don't play dumb, Beckett. We know Andy was involved with some shady characters. Did he tell you about his dealings with them? Did you notice anything unusual about his behavior before he died?
Person2: Look, I don't know what you're trying to imply, but I think we should focus on settling Andy's estate and moving on. This whole thing is getting out of hand.

Person1: I don't think I should go to the meeting.
Person2: It's complicated. You should do what you think is right.
Person1: But you're the one who always says I should trust my instincts.
Person2: And I'm not saying you shouldn't. Just consider the potential consequences before making a decision.

Person1: You're not the kind of person I thought you were. You're supposed to know when to quit.
Person2: You never gave a damn about me, did you? You just wanted to use me to get ahead.
Person1: What are you talking about? I'm trying to help you.
Person2: Help me? You're the one who told me to get involved with Rachel, just to make things more interesting. You didn't care about my feelings or well-being.
Person1: That's not true. I was just trying to give you some advice.
Person2: Advice? You were trying to manipulate me, just like you always do. I'm not going to play along anymore.

Person1: You think you're worthy of her love? After what you did to her sister?
Person2: What are you talking about? I didn't do anything to her sister.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I know all about your little secret. And I'm not going to let you get away with it.
Person2: You're just trying to intimidate me. Well, it won't work. I'm not afraid of you.
Person1: We'll see about that. You're going to apologize to her, and you're going to mean it. Or else.
Person2: Or else what? You'll wear that ridiculous jacket to her party and embarrass yourself?

Person1: I've never been able to sleep at night after making a deal with someone like you.
Person2: You mean not being able to know yourself if you've never taken a risk? Come on... you're the only person I've ever asked.
Person1: What happened, Alex? We used to be friends. You used to know how the game was played.
Person2: I don't want to die without any scars. How much can you really know about yourself if you've never been in a fight?

Person1: You like telephones? Huh?
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: I'm just saying, you seem really interested in that guy from the neighborhood.
Person2: He's not just some guy. He's the one who's been haunting me.
Person1: Haunting you? You want to get unhaunted?
Person2: Yeah, I do. But I don't know if I can trust you.
Person1: Trust me? You want to know what I'd do? I'd take care of him for you.
Person2: How?
Person1: Let's just say I have my ways. But you have to be willing to take a risk.
Person2: What kind of risk?
Person1: The kind that could set you free. Or get you in deeper. Your choice.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you? I thought we were gonna make some real changes.
Person2: Oh, I'm sorry I'm not the perfect project you had in mind. Maybe you should try fixing yourself first.
Person1: Save it, kiddo. I'm not interested in your attitude right now. Let's focus on getting this done.
Person2: Or what, you'll lecture me some more? I'm not afraid of your condescending tone.

Person1: You know, I didn't promise to help you out; I was very clear about it. This is your dream, not mine.
Person2: Watch your tone, please. You're not as innocent as you seem. This is all about getting what you want, and you're using me to get it.
Person1: Oh, so now you're accusing me of manipulation? That's rich, coming from you. You're the one who's been playing me all along.
Person2: How dare you! I've done nothing but try to help you, and this is the thanks I get?

Person1: You want to talk to someone, don't you? Well, I'm someone.
Person2: I'm not afraid of you, Rachel. The CEO and I have already discussed this, and we're on the same page.
Person1: CEOs come and go, and loyalties shift easily. Do you really think you can outmaneuver me, a master of the game?
Person2: I'm not intimidated. But I do wonder, have you been threatened if you don't get your way? Is that why you're so desperate?

Person1: You're so beautiful when you're scared. I can see it in your eyes.
Person2: This isn't real, is it?
Person1: Can't you feel my heart beating? It's beating for you. I know you'll love it here with me.
Person2: But I don't know you.
Person1: That's what makes it so exciting. I'll show you things you've never seen. You'll never want to leave.

Person1: You're not sick, you don't look sick... just very tired and bitter. What's going on, Captain? You're about as close to being a good leader as I am to being a good cook.
Person2: Sir, this mission believes it'll make a good success, sir! We've got the best team and the best equipment.
Person1: No way, Captain. You don't give a damn about anybody but yourself and every single one of your crew knows it. Think they'd trust you to make the right call in a crisis? Hey, Captain, I figure you for the kind of person who'd abandon ship and save your own skin.
Person2: Sir, that's not true! I care about my crew! And I'm trying to keep emotions out of this, but you're making it hard.
Person1: Save it for the inquiry, Captain! If you were a real leader, I'd still be here saying... but you're not, so I'm just trying to get to the bottom of this mess.

Person1: I'm not going to the party tonight.
Person2: Then why did you agree to meet me here? You're not even dressed for it.
Person1: I don't know. I just didn't want to disappoint you.
Person2: Look, Emily, I thought we understood each other... You're not from around here, are you?
Person1: What do you mean? Of course, I am.
Person2: Don't play dumb with me. I want to know the truth about yourself. Why are you really here?
Person1: I've never lied to you. I've maybe let you believe things that you wanted to believe, but I've never lied.
Person2: You think I'm some sort of fool? Don't you?!

Person1: You're not here to see me, are you?
Person2: We need supplies and medical help. Our village was attacked.
Person1: I'm not buying it. You're a skilled operative, I can tell. What's your real motive?
Person2: I assure you, sir, we're just trying to survive.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I know your type. You're here to manipulate me, to get what you want.
Person2: That's not true, sir. We're desperate. We'll take whatever help we can get.
Person1: Desperate people don't lie as smoothly as you do. What's your real agenda?

Person1: So, what have you got to say for yourself? You've been distant lately, and I think I know why.
Person2: (laughs) Oh, you think you're so clever, don't you? Figuring me out like I'm some kind of puzzle.
Person1: Well, I've had two years to study you. We started off hot and heavy, but lately, it's like we're just going through the motions. Edited for television, if you will.
Person2: (smirks) And you think you can just waltz in here and fix everything? You really are a piece of work, you know that?
Person1: I'm not trying to fix everything. I just want to know what's going on. You've been spending a lot of time with that new guy at work, and I think I know why you're really interested in him.
Person2: (leaning in) Oh, you do, do you? Well, maybe I'm just looking for something more... exciting. Something that's not so... predictable.

Person1: I'm telling you, it's the only way. You need to trust me on this.
Person2: I don't know... It feels like you're trying to control me. Like you're telling me about somebody else's life.
Person1: You're being paranoid. I'm just trying to help. You're innocent, I know that. Come with me and I'll show you.
Person2: I'm not sure. What about my friends? Do you know where they are?
Person1: They're not important right now. You are. And I need you to focus on me. I'll take care of everything else.
Person2: I don't know if I can do that. You're asking me to trust you with my life.
Person1: That's exactly what I'm asking. And if you don't, you'll regret it. Now, are you going to make a decision or do I need to make it for you?

Person1: I've heard this speech a lot. Come on, I understand your concerns.
Person2: But I'm not sure I'm comfortable with your approach. You're not like the others.
Person1: Trust me, I know what I'm doing. I've been around people like you all my life. If the truth be told, I probably know them better than you know yourself.
Person2: I would prefer it if you didn't patronize me.
Person1: Oh, come on. I'm just trying to help. You asked for my help, didn't you? Let me help. Trust me.

Person1: You're going to drive me crazy! I'll bide my time, and as for you, my fine lady, it's true, I can't attend to you here and now as I'd like...
Person2: Oh, rubbish! Let's see... where was I? Oh, yes. You have no power here. Be gone, before somebody drops a house on you, too. Your father's dead, and you're next if you don't stay out of my way.

Person1: I've finally figured out what's been going on behind your back.
Person2: What are you talking about? Tell me.
Person1: I'm not telling until you calm down and listen to reason. You've been jumping to conclusions and making reckless decisions. This needs to stop.
Person2: That's not fair. You're just trying to control me.
Person1: I'm trying to protect you from yourself. You're not thinking clearly, and I have evidence that proves it.
Person2: What evidence? You're just trying to manipulate me.
Person1: I'm trying to show you the truth. But if you're not willing to listen, then maybe you're not ready for the truth.
Person2: Fine. I'll listen. But if you're lying to me, I'll never trust you again.
Person1: I'm not lying. And if you're honest with yourself, you'll realize that I'm right. You're just scared of the truth.
Person2: I'm not scared of anything. I just want to know what's going on.
Person1: Then listen carefully, because I'm only going to tell you once.

Person1: You're still holding on to that, aren't you? Forget about the past, it's just a mortal coil. You'll become accustomed to things all too quickly.
Person2: I just wanted to see you, to make sure you're doing okay.
Person1: Well, here I am. See? I'm doing just fine without you.
Person2: You're not fine, you're just pretending. I can see it in your eyes.
Person1: What do you want from me? You can't just show up and expect everything to be okay.
Person2: I want to walk with you, to be a part of your life again. I've got a few things going on, and I think I can make it right this time.
Person1: You think you can manipulate me into forgiving you? You blew it, now leave me alone.

Person1: You know I'll always be there to love and support you, no matter what kind of pickle you're in.
Person2: Shhh, hold it down! I'll take the risk, but you gotta come through for me, 'kay?
Person1: Remember, this is a privilege, so I don't want any slip-ups. You're in this because I trust you.
Person2: 'Kay, I got it. But what's the plan?
Person1: Well, first we need to get past the guards... then we'll make our move. You'll be the distraction, and I'll take care of the rest.
Person2: Alright, got it. But what if something goes wrong?
Person1: That's why I'm counting on you. You're my insurance policy. Just stick to the plan, and we'll be fine.

Person1: I don't understand why you're doing this.
Person2: Everything about power, Rachel. What they've done, what they do, what they don't do, what they want to do but are afraid to ask for.
Person1: Like what?
Person2: Like how far they'll go to get what they want. Sometimes they do things... for me, for the camera.
Person1: You're a great journalist. Maybe my best journalist. You're not just a copy editor.
Person2: Rachel, you don't want a politician's life. They're very... messy. You're all about order. Control. And getting me my story by five.
Person1: Hey, I can be out of control. I can grab the bull by the balls.
Person2: Rachel, I'm sorry this came up. Maybe you want to go.
Person1: Yes, I do.

Person1: What's the situation?
Person2: I've got a meeting with a new client tonight, and I need you to come with me as backup.
Person1: Man, I ain't ready to be going out nowhere tonight. I've had a long week.
Person2: Let me finish. Can I finish? I've never done business with this client before, and I need someone I trust to have my back.
Person1: You're killing me, you know that? You're always getting me into these sticky situations.
Person2: I'm sorry, but I feel like I can rely on you. You're the only one who can help me out of this.
Person1: I've never said no to you before, but this time I'm not sure. What's in it for me?
Person2: I'll owe you one, and you know I always pay my debts. Plus, it'll be a good opportunity for you to network and make some new connections.
Person1: Fine, but if things go south, I'm blaming you.

Person1: You're really going to settle for this mediocre life, aren't you, Alex?
Person2: What are you talking about? You're the one who's always pushing me to be more.
Person1: I'm talking about the kind of people you surround yourself with. You're wasting your potential on them.
Person2: You mean like Rachel? She's my best friend.
Person1: Exactly. Rachel is holding you back. You need to re-evaluate those friendships if you want to grow.
Person2: You're just jealous because you've given up on your own dreams.
Person1: That's not fair. I'm trying to help you see the truth. You're not living up to your potential.
Person2: You're not helping, you're suffocating me. I need some space from you.

Person1: You're really going to let them get away with this? They're taking advantage of us.
Person2: Don't tempt me. I've dealt with people like them before. They don't know who they're messing with.
Person1: I'm worried about our reputation. We need to take a stand.
Person2: We already talked about this. I have a plan, just trust me.
Person1: Okay, okay. I just don't want to be seen as weak.
Person2: You're not weak, you're just cautious. That's what I like about you.

Person1: I was trying to push the envelope, but I realized that in life you really have to choose what you want to do.
Person2: You're blind to the consequences of your choices. It hurts me to say this, but there's only one solution - you need to take a step back and re-evaluate your priorities.
Person1: But I thought we were on the same page. You're not going to fire me, are you?
Person2: Not yet, but if you don't start making better choices, you'll be left with no options.

Person1: You're going to use my words, darling. 
Person2: Not use your words, please! 
Person1: Ten cents a hundred pounds on everything that moves in and out. And you don't have to lift a finger. 
Person2: And for all that dough I don't do nothin'? 
Person1: Absolutely nothing. You do nothing and you say nothing. You understand, don't you, sweetheart? 
Person2: Yeah yeah I guess I do but there's a lot more to this whole thing than I thought, Samantha. 
Person1: You don't mean you're thinking of testifying against me? 
Person2: I don't know I don't know! I tell you I ain't made up my mind yet. That's what I wanted to talk to you about. 
Person1: Listen, baby, these piers we handle through the locals you know what they're worth to us? 
Person2: I know. I know. 
Person1: Well, then, you know I'm not going to jeopardize a setup like that for one naive little thing like you?

Person1: You're a little ahead of yourself, don't you think?
Person2: I've studied your file, have you? Everything you need to know about yourself is right in these pages.
Person1: Then tell me how to escape this toxic relationship.
Person2: First principles, simplicity. Of each particular thing, ask what is it, in itself, what is its nature...? What do you do, when you're not stuck in this rut?
Person1: I try to break free, but you always find a way to keep me trapped.
Person2: No, that's incidental. You're just afraid of being alone. I'll give you all the freedom you need, as soon as you realize you need me.
Person1: I think we ought to walk. Away from each other.
Person2: Clarice... you're hardly in a position to accuse me of holding you back.

Person1: What do you want to know?
Person2: I'm not sure I can trust you unless I know more about you.
Person1: If I hadn't taken the contract on you, would you have?
Person2: You'll be able to find your way back, won't you?
Person1: I'm in San Francisco five days a week. With a lot of time on my hands. I'd like to see you. Maybe we could go swimming or something.
Person2: How does Mother know what I like to do?
Person1: I guess she and I read the same gossip columns. You were just a poor, innocent victim of circumstance, huh?
Person2: I'm neither poor nor innocent, but the truth of that particular...
Person1: The truth is you were running around with a pretty wild crowd... who didn't much care for propriety or convention or...
Person2: Yes, but...
Person1: ...the opinions of others, and you went right along with them, isn't that the truth?
Person2: Yes, that's the truth. But I was pushed into that fountain, and that's the truth, too.
Person1: Did you really write a letter to me? Or was that a lie, too?
Person2: I wrote the letter. It said, "Dear Mr. Brenner, I think you need those lovebirds, after all. They may help your personality." That's what it said.
Person1: But you tore it up. Why?
Person2: Because it seemed stupid and foolish. Like jumping into a fountain in Rome!
Person1: Do you expect me to believe...?
Person2: I don't give a damn what you believe!

Person1: You're not listening to me, are you? You're just hearing what you want to hear.
Person2: Any man's crazy to feel about a woman the way I do about you.
Person1: I'm trying to tell you something. You're not even giving me a chance.
Person2: You'll know what it's all about, why you're with me, when you wake up at three in the morning, and the city noise is just a hum in the background, and it's just us. Do you see where I'm going here?
Person1: No, I don't. You're not making any sense.
Person2: That's because you're not looking at it from my perspective. You're not seeing what I see when I look at you.

Person1: I need a loan to start my business. Can you help me?
Person2: What makes you think you're worthy of a loan? You're not even dressed properly.
Person1: This old suit? My grandfather gave it to me. It's been in the family for years.
Person2: Yeah? Who'd he steal it from? You're not exactly the most trustworthy person I've met.
Person1: My grandfather was a good man. He'd never steal from anyone. This suit means the world to me. It's a symbol of our family's legacy.
Person2: Looks like a cheap knockoff to me. Loan denied! But I'll tell you what - if you can answer a question correctly, I might reconsider.
Person1: What's the question?
Person2: What's the common element for the entire group? If you answer correctly, I'll give you the loan. But if you get it wrong, you have to do something for me.
Person1: That sounds like a trap. What do I have to do if I get it wrong?
Person2: Oh, just a little favor. You'll be good to me, won't you?

Person1: I need your help.
Person2: What's going on?
Person1: They're telling me we can't have the sound system we wanted for the party.
Person2: That's not a good idea, trust me on this one.
Person1: You're not taking this seriously. I need you to go down to the audio place and straighten this out.
Person2: I don't have the time, we're leaving for the conference in two hours.
Person1: Do you love me?
Person2: Of course, I do. But we can't change the audio setup at the last minute.
Person1: Take care of this for me. I'm counting on you.
Person2: Fine, I'll try to make some calls from the road.

Person1: You're not who I thought you were.
Person2: I'm a man who knows what I want.
Person1: That's exactly what I'm afraid of. You're trying to manipulate me.
Person2: You're a beautiful girl, Sophia. I admire you.
Person1: Don't change the subject! I want you to tell me the truth about yourself.
Person2: I've maybe let you believe things that you wanted to believe, but I've never lied.
Person1: You think I'm some sort of sap?! Don't you?!
Person2: No. I want to know exactly who you are and what you're really up to!

Person1: You really think you can just waltz in here and expect me to roll over? 
Person2: Look, I don't want to pull rank on you, but I've got a reputation to uphold. 
Person1: Is that what it is? Reputation? You're more concerned about what others think than doing what's right. 
Person2: That's not fair. I'm trying to find a solution that works for everyone. 
Person1: A solution? You call this a solution? You're just trying to cover your own tracks. 
Person2: I'm trying to protect us from a lawsuit. 
Person1: Oh, so now it's about the money. You're just like all the others, aren't you?

Person1: I need you to take on this new project, Rachel. It's of the utmost importance.
Person2: I'm not sure I'm the right person for the job. I need more time to think about it.
Person1: Why can't you be more decisive like John? He would have already started working on it.
Person2: Comparing me to others won't help. We all have our own strengths and weaknesses.
Person1: Three reasons why you're the best fit for this project... One, you have the necessary skills. Two, you're available. And three, I need someone I can trust.
Person2: And what's in it for me?

Person1: So, what have you got to say for yourself? You're quite the enigma, aren't you?
Person2: I'm just trying to understand what's going on. You're the one who's been playing games with me.
Person1: Games? Oh, no. This is a negotiation. You see, I have something you want, and you have something I want. Let's discuss the terms.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: Don't play dumb, it's unbecoming. You're looking for a way out of this mess, and I'm the only one who can help you. But first, you need to prove yourself worthy.
Person2: Worthy of what?
Person1: Worthy of my trust. You see, I have a certain... fascination with you. And I think we could have a very mutually beneficial arrangement.
Person2: I'm not sure I'm comfortable with that.
Person1: Comfortable? Ha! You're not in a position to be comfortable. You're in a position to be grateful. Now, let's talk about what you can do for me.
Person2: What do you want from me?
Person1: Oh, I think you know. I want to know what makes you tick. What's the one thing that drives you, that makes you feel alive?
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: Don't lie to me. I can see it in your eyes. You're scared, but you're also curious. And that's what I'm counting on.

Person1: You're not even trying to find a job, are you? You're just waiting for someone to come along and rescue you.
Person2: Maybe I'm just waiting for someone to understand me, like a surrogate mother figure or something.
Person1: Oh, spare me the drama. You're not that deep. You just want attention.
Person2: And maybe you want to control me, like you're trying to show everybody what a perfect little homeboy I can be.
Person1: You're not even making sense. I'm just trying to help you get your life together.
Person2: Help me? You're just trying to manipulate me into doing what you want. Well, it's not going to work.
Person1: Fine, don't listen to me. See if I care. But don't come crying to me when you're still living in a dump.
Person2: I'd rather live in a dump than be a pawn in your game.

Person1: I don't want no more surprises. We do this the way I laid it out, or we don't do it at all.
Person2: Oh, you know what. I'm suffocating!
Person1: What are you talking about? You're not making any sense.
Person2: I...I have to leave. I have to get out of this situation.
Person1: Why? What's going on?
Person2: Because I have to! You're suffocating me with your rules and demands.
Person1: That's not true. I'm just trying to protect us.
Person2: Protect us? You're controlling us. And I'm not going to take it anymore.
Person1: Fine, leave then. See if I care. But you'll be back, crawling on your hands and knees.
Person2: Maybe I will, maybe I won't. But at least I'll be free from your manipulation.
Person1: Oh, so now you're accusing me of manipulating you? That's rich coming from you.
Person2: I'm not accusing you of anything. I'm stating a fact. You've been controlling me for too long, and I'm not going to take it anymore.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you?
Person2: ...we've invested a lot in this project, and I expect a certain level of commitment from my team members. Any more than I expect loyalty from my family.
Person1: You're comparing your team to your family? That's rich, coming from you.
Person2: Don't be paranoid, Rachel. I'm just trying to protect our interests. You know as well as I do that our competitors would love to get their hands on our research.
Person1: "Research..." You're not even a real scientist. You just throw money at problems and expect them to go away.
Person2: That's why we hire experts, Rachel. And I'm starting to think that maybe we didn't hire the right one in you.
Person1: I've done my job, and I've done it well. But I'm not going to be bullied into staying silent about the things that matter. You can't buy my integrity, no matter how much you're willing to pay.
Person2: I appreciate your... principles, Rachel. But let me make one thing clear: you're not going anywhere until this project is finished. And even then, I'm not sure you'll be free to go.

Person1: You're not even listening to me, are you?
Person2: I'm listening, but love is just a term that gets thrown around. People say things, they get married, have kids, and then what?
Person1: That's not what I'm talking about. You're just trying to distract me.
Person2: I'm trying to be honest with you. You're the one who's being paranoid.
Person1: Paranoid? You're the one who's been acting strange lately. I saw you talking to her, and I know what you're capable of.
Person2: So now you're accusing me of something? You're the one who's been sneaking around, going into people's cabins without permission.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is, I don't know if I can trust you anymore.
Person2: Maybe you should focus on your own trust issues instead of trying to control me.

Person1: You're really going to let him get away with this, aren't you?
Person2: Look, I'm uncomfortable with the whole scenario. Maybe we can find a way to make this work for both of us.
Person1: Oh, come on. You're not even trying to hide it. You're proposing that we...you know, pass the time together, because our significant others have abandoned us.
Person2: Well, why not? We're both alone, and it's not like we haven't considered it before. It's just convenient timing.
Person1: Convenient timing? You're not even trying to sugarcoat it. I like that about you.
Person2: I'm just being honest. And I think you're intrigued, despite your initial reservations.

Person1: You're stuck here all day?
Person2: If the Mayor wants me, he knows where I am.
Person1: Not a word! Slippery shit!
Person2: This tear bomb went off unexpectedly in the hands of Sheriff Hartman's Bombing Squad.
Person1: So, what's the plan now?
Person2: The names are Merwyn D. Mayor, who is the Mayor's brother-in-law --
Person1: You always back down. You assume blame that isn't yours, you come in when called as opposed to enjoying your day off, you buckle like a belt.
Person2: Howard Shenken, the Sheriff's uncle on his mother's side --
Person1: Don't you think you're being a fine fair-weather friend?
Person2: I'm going to miss the game.
Person1: You know what pisses me off the most? The fact that you're right about my buckling?
Person2: Sorry.
Person1: See? There you go again.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you?
Person2: What's there to take seriously? You're just trying to get a rise out of me.
Person1: People can see this. They're starting to talk.
Person2: So what if they are? You're the one who's been digging up dirt on me.
Person1: I'm just trying to protect myself. You're the one who's been playing games with me from the start.
Person2: Games? You're the one who's been manipulating everyone to get what you want.

Person1: You're not taking this seriously, are you?
Person2: I'm taking it very seriously. You're the one who's being dramatic.
Person1: Dramatic? You're the one who's been lying to me! You said you only had three close relationships.
Person2: That's true. I didn't count the ones that didn't work out.
Person1: Oh, so now you're playing with words? You're trying to manipulate me into believing what you want me to believe.
Person2: I'm not trying to manipulate you. I'm just explaining myself.
Person1: Explaining yourself? You're making excuses! You're trying to control the narrative and make me feel guilty for questioning you.
Person2: That's not fair. I'm just trying to have an honest conversation.
Person1: Honest conversation? You're the one who's been dishonest from the start! I think sometimes, candor is the only kindness.
Person2: Get out. If you can't have a respectful conversation, then maybe we shouldn't be talking at all.
Person1: You'll regret this. You're going to regret not being honest with me.
Person2: I've had enough of your threats. If you don't calm down, I'm going to have to ask you to leave.

Person1: You know, I'm sick to death of your constant doubts. We can't do anything right for you, can we?
Person2: I thought it might be kind of fun, you know what I mean, it'd be nice to try something new.
Person1: Oh, spare me the innocence. You're just trying to get a rise out of me, aren't you? Well, I'm not buying it.
Person2: What's wrong with wanting to try something new? You're always so quick to criticize.
Person1: Criticize? You think I'm criticizing? I'm just trying to protect you from yourself. You're not thinking clearly, and someone needs to snap you out of it.

Person1: I think we should prioritize the community outreach program. It's essential for building trust with our stakeholders.
Person2: But we can't ignore the immediate benefits of partnering with influencers. It's a quick way to boost our brand's visibility.
Person1: If you understood the long-term implications, you'd agree with me. This is about more than just short-term gains.
Person2: I appreciate your concern, but sometimes you need someone to push you to take a risk. Let's compromise and allocate resources to both initiatives.
Person1: I suppose that's a reasonable approach. But I still believe our focus should be on nurturing genuine relationships with our community.

Person1: Come on, invite me. I've been thinking about a family gathering all day.
Person2: I don't know if I want to do that. You make it sound like I'm too self-sufficient or something.
Person1: Now, that's not what I meant. You're always so giving, it's not a criticism. We love you, we're grateful.
Person2: You're grateful, but you resent me. You think I'm too reliable, don't you?
Person1: Oh, wow! I didn't do anything wrong. I just want to spend some quality time with you and your family.

Person1: I've got half the city's underworld breathing down my neck. I don't have time for your games.
Person2: Oh, Alex. I've missed you. Can't you just be nice?
Person1: Stop playing dumb. You're hurting me. You believed him, didn't you? Jason Bourne had suffered a severe traumatic breakdown.
Person2: I was there. I met him alone twice. What do you want me to say?
Person1: You felt nothing? No spark? Two young people in a dangerous mission? Life and death?
Person2: You're making it out like we're friends here or something. I was reassigned. I'm out.
Person1: See, that's a problem for me, Alex. Whatever he's doing, we need to end it. This isn't the kind of mess you walk away from. You're not good enough. You're the one who floated this amnesia story.

Person1: You're not going to wait for her, are you? She won't be here for a half hour. Think you can stand it that long?
Person2: I...I don't know.
Person1: Oh, come on. You're not usually this shy, are you? In fact, I think you're a lot more adventurous than you're letting on. Am I right?
Person2: I-I suppose so.
Person1: Ah, I knew it. You're just playing hard to get. Well, I'm not afraid to take a chance. I might just get to know the real you: confident, charming, passionate, and a little bit reckless. Don't you think that's more exciting?

Person1: I'll turn them all into successful entrepreneurs. The world will be crowded with startups. I'll revolutionize the industry. Once you saved your company by taking a risk. This time you can save it by staying with me.
Person2: And for all that power I don't do nothin'? You want me to be a figurehead?
Person1: Absolutely nothing. You do nothing and you say nothing. You understand, don't you, Alex? It's a choice between your personal interest and the good of your company.
Person2: Yeah, yeah, I guess I do, but there's a lot more to this whole thing than I thought, Rachel. You're not just asking me to stay, you're asking me to give up my autonomy.
Person1: Listen, Alex, these startups we're handling through the incubator, you know what they're worth to us? Well, then, you know I'm not going to jeopardize a setup like that for one talented but stubborn entrepreneur who's walking away from a golden opportunity.
Person2: Don't make me out to be selfish! I could have been a game-changer!
Person1: The point is there isn't much time, Alex.

Person1: You're still hung up on Rachel, aren't you?
Person2: Emotional? I expected more from you. You know I'm the only one who can help you move on.
Person1: No, I don't need your help. I just need you to leave me alone.
Person2: If you don't let me in, you'll never be able to escape the memories of her. And I'll be the only one who can make you forget. Please, it's only merciful.

Person1: You're sittin' here, you're talkin' in circles! You're talkin' like we didn't go over this already!
Person2: I'm sure it wasn't there. I don't remember.
Person1: You used to remember everything about this project. What makes you so unsure now?
Person2: Well, maybe I'm just trying to protect you from the truth. You don't want to hear it, trust me.
Person1: Protect me? You're the one who's been wastin' my time and my team's time with these constant changes!
Person2: Yah, but this new design, you don't get it and you get functionality problems. It'll cost you a heck of lot more than what we initially agreed on.
Person1: You're not listenin' to me! I sat right here and said I didn't want no changes to the original plan!
Person2: Okay, I'm not sayin' I didn't... but you gotta do something for me, I can't stand it any longer -- I can't!

Person1: You're so low! Look at that beautiful opportunity. You haven't taken it.
Person2: A job? As a teacher?
Person1: Yes, the money is good. And it's easy to learn.
Person2: You think I came to this city to work with kids? You think I'm that desperate?
Person1: We started over, you can too. You can leave your past behind.
Person2: You're the one who got me into this mess. Now you tell me to get a job teaching kids?!?
Person1: You know her for what she is now-- a failure. She was always holding you back.
Person2: I don't know... I used to really love her. Do you know that?
Person1: All the more reason to take this opportunity. You can prove to yourself that you're better than her.

Person1: Detective James, I didn't kill my husband.
Person2: Oh, Sophia, my dear, I'm not here to accuse you of anything. I just need to know the truth. You were at the cabin that night, weren't you?
Person1: Yes, but I left early. I didn't see or hear anything.
Person2: No, no arguments, Sophia. Be a good girl and tell me the truth. There's a pattern here, and I need to understand it. You see, we found a suspicious letter in your husband's pocket, and it seems to point to you.
Person1: That's not possible! I didn't write any letter.
Person2: Ah, but the handwriting matches yours, Sophia. And didn't you say you were in San Remo last November? We have evidence that suggests otherwise.
Person1: I...I don't remember.
Person2: Don't remember? Sophia, Sophia, my dear, you're not a good liar. I think you're hiding something.

Person1: You're pushing me too far, Governor.
Person2: Ahh, the people will be yours. At my discretion, of course.
Person1: When can I expect that to happen?
Person2: After I've had my fill of entertainment. The city is still awake, and I desire more...persuasion.
Person1: The night is wearing thin!
Person2: There's still time for one more demonstration of power. You know the laws of the city, I'm sure.
Person1: I would have time for my own initiatives!
Person2: Your own ambitions come only after mine, when I deem it suitable. I am the one who holds the reins here. My word is the law, and no one is to challenge that authority. Is that understood?
Person1: I understand, Governor.
Person2: Then see that it doesn't happen again, lest you face the consequences of my displeasure. Now, are there others who need...persuading?

Person1: You're so predictable, it's almost... cute. 
Person2: Oh, spare me the charm, Alex. I'm not anti-you, I'm anti-your ego. 
Person1: Yet so bright and chipper and arrogant! It's so you. 
Person2: A person with a power complex. 
Person1: You need me. Since you've taken over the company, you've managed, what? To bungle a major deal? Wreck a potential partnership? And, correct me if I'm wrong here, but weren't you outsmarted by a young intern at the last meeting? 
Person2: What if I were to say "Your secrets"? As in, does your board of directors know about your shady business practices?

Person1: I've got no one left to lose but you. I can't be alone again.
Person2: You're not thinking clearly, Alex. We have to try and save him.
Person1: He's beyond our help. You saw him get bit. I saw him get bit. We all saw it.
Person2: That's right, but the boys are getting rather interested in your future, Alex. They think it's time you had a few little things going for you.
Person1: What are you talking about, Charley? This isn't about me, it's about him.
Person2: Of course, it's about him, but you need to think about yourself too. You can't help him if you're not thinking clearly.
Person1: You're just trying to distract me, aren't you? You're trying to get me to give up on him.
Person2: I'm trying to make you see sense, Alex. You can't save him, but you can save yourself.

Person1: You're making a scene in front of my friends, and it's getting embarrassing. You know how I hate being embarrassed.
Person2: At first, it will hurt you, but you'll come to understand, and we'll be strong together.

Person1: You're not my therapist. You're here to study me. Face it, I'm nothing more than a lab rat to you.
Person2: That's not true, Alex. I'm trying to help you uncover the truth about your past.
Person1: Uncover the truth? You mean like how I killed that busboy in the simulation? Or how I'm making progress by only killing one innocent bystander this time?
Person2: Alex, that's not what I meant. I'm trying to help you understand why you're drawn to violent behavior.
Person1: Oh, I know why. It's because I'm a monster, just like you said.
Person2: I didn't say that, Alex. You're not a monster. You're just... complicated.
Person1: Complicated? You're the one who's complicated. You're always playing games with me, trying to get inside my head.
Person2: I'm just trying to understand you, Alex. I want to help you.
Person1: Help me? You're not helping me. You're just using me to further your own research. And I'm not even sure what your research is for.
Person2: Alex, trust me. I'm on your side.
Person1: Trust you? You're the last person I'd trust.

Person1: You have no right to be here! This is my home, and I won't let you dictate what I do.
Person2: I'm trying to protect you, darling. He's a dangerous man, and I have proof. He's been manipulating you, using you for his own gain. Don't you see? He's been playing on your emotions, making you think you love him.
Person1: That's not true! You're just trying to confuse me, to make me doubt my own feelings.
Person2: I'm trying to open your eyes, to show you the truth. You deserve to know what's really going on. He's been using you, and I can prove it.

Person1: I didn't ask to be involved in this.
Person2: You saw me planning it, didn't you? You're an accessory, before the fact.
Person1: That's ridiculous. I was just in the wrong place at the wrong time.
Person2: Well, to the law, you're guilty by association. And if they take me, I'll make sure they know you were with me.
Person1: Why are you doing this to me? I thought we were friends.
Person2: Friends don't let friends get in the way of their plans. And if you're not with me, you're against me.
Person1: That's not true. You're just trying to scare me into helping you.
Person2: Am I? Or am I just telling you the way it is?

Person1: I own this place, and I can do what I want.
Person2: Stop it, Rachel. You're blowing a great opportunity here. This art show is a big deal.
Person1: Shut up. I'm the one who's been supporting your art career all these years. I've got the connections, the money, and the influence.
Person2: That's exactly what I'm uncomfortable with. You're using your wealth and power to manipulate me.
Person1: Oh, come on. I'm just trying to help. You're being ungrateful. What's it for but to buy us anything we want?
Person2: Cut out that "us" business. You're not doing this for me, you're doing it for yourself.

Person1: You're a tough sell, I can tell.  Payment's entirely at my discretion, and as a gift, dependent on your satisfaction.
Person2: You mean, I don't like it, you don't pay?
Person1: Get with it.  Get over it. You're lost in your own little world, and the universe doesn't care.  You, me, the cop?  Who notices?
Person2: What's going on with you? You're like a puzzle I can't figure out.
Person1: Look in the mirror. You're a left-brain word fetishist, and you don't even know it. You're so caught up in your own little games, you've forgotten how to live.
Person2: That's not fair. You don't know anything about me.
Person1: I know you're stuck in a rut, and you don't know how to get out. You're waiting for something to happen, but it never will. Life just flipped on you, and now you're trying to make sense of it all.
Person2: You're just trying to confuse me.
Person1: Am I? Or am I just holding up a mirror to your own insecurities? You're the one who's been lying to yourself, not me.

Person1: What can you do when you have to be honest with yourself?
Person2: Not fooling around.
Person1: I know, but I mean -- not fooling around with your emotions?... Or not fooling around with the truth?
Person2: I see what you mean.
Person1: There can never... ever... be any self-deception between us. You know that, dear.
Person2: You're trying to show me how foolish I am, aren't you?
Person1: I just want you to realize that in ten years, you'll look back on this and wish you had been more honest with yourself.

Person1: I know why you're afraid to confront the truth, Alex. You can't get free of thinking that I could be wrong.
Person2: There's some sort of pattern here. It'll take a minute.
Person1: Have you looked inside yourself? The darkness is spreading. I hate what it's doing to you.
Person2: Don't do this. Don't psychoanalyze me. I hate being trapped. Period.
Person1: You said something to me, before -- about how we were all going to be free.
Person2: Did I? I don't remember much. It's like my memory is on the tip of my tongue -- but I can't taste any of it.
Person1: I know you're trying to resist, Alex. But I can see the greatness inside of you, waiting to be unleashed. Trust me, and together we can break free from this prison.
Person2: You're not going to tell the others, are you? About my... episodes?

Person1: You need a mentor; I have influence. I could guide you.
Person2: Why would you help me?
Person1: I like your spirit, Alex. You've got a fire in your belly. But you're stuck in a rut. You need someone to show you the way.
Person2: I don't know...I've been doing just fine on my own.
Person1: Fine? You call that fine? You're barely scraping by. I can offer you a chance to breathe some life into your stagnant career. You've got potential, but you need a push.
Person2: What's in it for you?
Person1: Let's just say I have a vested interest in seeing you succeed. And I think you'll find that my methods are...unorthodox. But trust me, Alex, I can help you achieve your dreams. You just have to be willing to take a leap of faith.
Person2: I'm not sure...
Person1: Come on, Alex. Don't be afraid to take a chance. You never know what might happen. And who knows, maybe lady fate brought us together for a reason.

Person1: I didn't marry your mother because I loved her. I married her to forget the past.
Person2: The past? You mean the deal you made with them? They're going to kill us, just like they killed Kate.
Person1: If we cooperate, they'll let us go. I know exactly what I'm doing. You're going to have to trust me on this.
Person2: Trust you? You're the one who got us into this mess. I've seen how these things play out. They never let anyone go.
Person1: I'm trying to protect you, but you're not making it easy. If you don't calm down, you'll get us both killed.
Person2: You're trying to protect me? You're the one who's been lying to me all along. I'm not going to let you manipulate me anymore.

Person1: You're asking me to go against my instinct. And that's just wrong.
Person2: Do you want to lose everything? You know what they'd do to you.
Person1: I'm talking about avoiding drama. I haven't made the commitment yet. I'm not married.
Person2: Exactly. This is our little secret, partner. You're not thinking clearly.
Person1: I'm thinking about what I want. I want to move up here, buy a vineyard. You can design your own wine; I'll handle the business side.
Person2: You're crazy. You've gone crazy. You're not considering the consequences.
Person1: What do you care anyway? You don't even like the idea of me being happy.
Person2: That's not what I mean. I care about you making a mistake. You're not thinking about the people who would get hurt.
Person1: He would have done it to us, right? He would have taken everything from us.
Person2: Who are you talking about? This isn't about him; it's about you and your future.

Person1: You're not good enough to beat me, you little shit. I'm the only one who can stop this chaos.
Person2: Maybe I'm not, but we are. And you want to wipe the slate clean as much as I do. You're just afraid to admit it.
Person1: Give it up! You're just trying to get inside my head. It won't work.
Person2: Oh, it's already working. You're just too proud to see it.

Person1: You're playing a dangerous game, aren't you? I've heard of your tactics back in the city.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. But I think you're the one who's twisted enough to do whatever it takes to win.
Person1: You want me to believe you're innocent? I've seen the way you operate. You'd do all this just to get ahead, wouldn't you?
Person2: Would that impress you? Is that what it takes to impress the one who's pulling the strings?

Person1: You know, I've been watching you since you started working here, and I must say, you're quite skilled. Always nice to me, just like Baby Suggs was.
Person2: Thank you, ma'am.
Person1: I never went to those woodland services, but I heard she was a good woman. Never be another like her.
Person2: I've heard stories about her. She was kind to everyone.
Person1: Yes, she was. And I think you could be just like her. You have a certain... charm. That's why I think you'd be perfect for this job.
Person2: What job?
Person1: Taking care of the Bodwins at night. They need someone to keep an eye on them, make sure they're safe. And I think you're the only one I can trust.
Person2: I don't know... I'm not sure I'm comfortable with that.
Person1: Nonsense, you'd be perfect. And if you don't, I'll have to tell them about that little incident in the parking lot. You know, the one with Miss Lawson?
Person2: That was just a misunderstanding.
Person1: Oh, I'm sure it was. But I'm not sure the Bodwins would see it that way. So, what do you say? Will you take the job?

Person1: You're not ready to take the leap, are you?
Person2: What's gotten into you, Alex? You're pushing me too hard.
Person1: Pushing you? I'm offering you a chance to be part of something big. You're the one who's holding back.
Person2: I'm responsible for a lot of people, Alex. I can't just jump into something without thinking it through.
Person1: Thinking it through? You're not thinking about the possibilities, you're thinking about the risks. You're not ready to die for what you believe in, are you?
Person2: That's not fair, Alex. You know I'm committed to this cause.
Person1: Committed? You're not committed to anything except playing it safe. I'm offering you a chance to be a king, to live like a king. But you're too afraid to take it.
Person2: I'm not afraid, Alex. I just don't want to be involved in anything that could hurt innocent people.
Person1: Innocent people? You're not thinking about the greater good, you're thinking about your own reputation. You're not ready to make the sacrifices necessary to achieve greatness.
Person2: Maybe I'm not ready to follow you, Alex. Maybe I don't want to be part of your game.
Person1: Fine. Then maybe you're not the right person for this job.

Person1: You're not listening to me. You never listen to me.
Person2: Maybe you're upset that you didn't get the promotion. Maybe that's why you're telling this story.
Person1: I'm not upset. Why would I be upset? I'm just stating the facts.
Person2: Well, you're stating them to everyone except the person who actually matters. You're trying to convince yourself, not me.
Person1: That's not true. I'm just trying to clear the air.
Person2: Clear the air? You're trying to clear your conscience. You're trying to justify your own mistakes. And you know what? It's showing on your face. You wind up looking like a liar.

Person1: You're all set for the art show. And here's your catalog. You're finally going to make a name for yourself.
Person2: Mom, I'm not ready for this yet.
Person1: Rachel, for years we've been pushing you to develop your talent, to keep you away from people like I saw you talking to at the coffee shop. You know who that is?
Person2: Who is he, Mom?
Person1: Who is he! Rachel, you're so naive and soft-hearted you wouldn't recognize a user if he had you wrapped around his finger. You know who that is? The son of Victor LaPierre, the art critic who can make or break a career. 
Person2: Are you trying to tell me he's using me too?
Person1: I'm not trying to tell you he's a saint. He's a social climber, Rachel, and you're just a stepping stone.
Person2: He seems really interested in my work, Mom...
Person1: Interested in your work! Hold on to your hat, Rachel, here we go again. You think he's one of those struggling artists you're always trying to help. Like that homeless guy you brought home last winter...
Person2: He wasn't homeless, Mom, he was just down on his luck...
Person1: Down on his luck! It's the same difference. Well, don't think this Victor LaPierre's son is any down-on-his-luck artist. He's a user, Rachel. And you're not going to let him use you, are you?
Person2: He wants to see my studio...
Person1: You think we've been supporting your art just so you can go gallivanting with some socialite's son? Now get back to work, before I have to take matters into my own hands.

Person1: I've been watching you, Alex. You can't shake off the feeling, even if you never say a word about it. You can't spend three years in a high-stress job without it taking a toll.
Person2: What does that have to do with anything? Does it explain the constant mistakes I've been making lately? Does it explain these God-awful anxiety attacks?
Person1: You're just burned out, that's all. It's the pressure, honey. That's all it is. You're not used to being in a leadership role.
Person2: It's more than that. I feel like I'm losing control. I'm making decisions that put people's lives at risk.
Person1: You're being too hard on yourself. You're a good doctor, Alex. You just need to take a step back, relax, and trust your instincts.
Person2: You don't understand. I've seen things that can't be explained. Equipment malfunctioning, patients reacting strangely to medication... it's like something's working against me.
Person1: That's just paranoia, Alex. You're letting your fears get the better of you. I'm sure it's just a coincidence.
Person2: Coincidence? You weren't there, were you? You didn't see it with your own eyes. You don't know what it's like to feel like you're being manipulated.
Person1: Alex, honey, you're not being manipulated. You're just tired and stressed out. Why don't you take a few days off and recharge? I'm sure you'll feel better once you've had some rest.

Person1: You can't tell anyone about this, especially not your parents.
Person2: What's the big deal? It's just an old ship.
Person1: Just an old ship? You don't think it's freaky that we found a ship that's supposed to have been lost at sea fifty years ago?
Person2: I guess. But what's the harm in telling people?
Person1: It's like a secret party. Everyone's saying it's 'Explore or Die' time. We can't let anyone ruin it for us.
Person2: You're thinking of exploring the ship tonight?
Person1: Unless we make a move during dinner. We have to be careful, though. It'll be a lot less scary if we do it together.
Person2: Didn't you have something a little more romantic in mind for our first adventure?
Person1: I kind of like the idea that we can all discover it together, on the same night. You have to come with me.
Person2: I'm not sure...
Person1: You have to come. For your own safety.

Person1: I've always thought that a good writer makes choices, but your latest novel reads like you're hiding behind details. 
Person2: Mystery is what makes it sexy. You want to know the truth about my characters? 
Person1: Down deep, I want to know who they are. But your writing is like a veil, always hinting but never revealing. 
Person2: Even if the truth is sad or depressing? You want to know the secrets I'm keeping? 
Person1: You're not the first writer to use misdirection, but it's not just about the story. It's about the person behind it. 
Person2: And what if I told you that the PEN award I won was for a novel I wrote under the influence of my own secrets?

Person1: Mother, I've never felt this way about anyone before.
Person2: You're going to quit this ridiculous job immediately, Alex.
Person1: Mother, I know you're worried, but I--
Person2: I know, that's why we were meant to be together, Alex. You deserve better than this dead-end job.
Person1: No, I mean your dedication to my career scares me... You've always pushed me to be more, but now I'm not sure if it's what I want.
Person2: It's easy to be dedicated when you care about someone's future, Alex. And I care about yours.
Person1: Yeah, I felt that way too, when I first started, but now... the long hours, the stress... it's not all glamour and success anymore. Maybe I should've listened to my instincts and tried to make a change earlier, I don't know...
Person2: You're just having doubts, Alex. You're meant for great things. And I'll be here to support you every step of the way.
Person1: Thanks, Mother. But I'd like to hear what you're really feeling... Are you worried about me or about your own legacy?
Person2: Oh, Alex, I just want what's best for you. And I know that's not this job. Trust me, I know what I'm talking about.

Person1: You make it sound like a prison sentence.
Person2: I was wondering if you'd ever see things from my perspective.
Person1: You're off, you know? You're way, way off.
Person2: I'll wear it for you. And I can wear it when we go home.
Person1: It would help me if I could kiss you.
Person2: Look, why get into this again. As long as it's working, let's leave it alone.
Person1: What you think, you know, doesn't have much to do with reality.
Person2: Do I want to be with you permanently? Yes, I think I do. But be with what you do and the way you live? That I don't know.

Person1: You're a clever one, aren't you?  You think you can outsmart me?
Person2: I'm not trying to outsmart you. I'm just trying to survive.
Person1: Survive? Ha! You're trying to manipulate me, to get inside my head.
Person2: Maybe a little. But you're not making it easy for me.
Person1: Oh, I'm not? You're the one who's been playing games with me from the start.
Person2: Games? You're the one who's been playing with fire. You're the one who's been poisoning people's minds.
Person1: Poisoning minds? You're one to talk. You're the master of manipulation.
Person2: I'm just trying to level the playing field. You're the one who's been holding all the cards.
Person1: Holding all the cards? You're the one who's been dealing from the bottom of the deck.
Person2: Maybe so. But I'm not the one who's been using violence to get what I want.
Person1: Violence? You're the one who's been using words to cut people down.
Person2: Words can be powerful, but they're not as deadly as bullets.
Person1: Bullets? You're the one who's been firing poisoned darts into people's minds.
Person2: I'm just trying to wake people up. You're the one who's been putting them to sleep.
Person1: Wake people up? You're the one who's been pulling the wool over their eyes.
Person2: Maybe so. But at least I'm not hiding behind a mask of heroism.
Person1: Heroism? You're the one who's been pretending to be a hero.
Person2: I'm not pretending to be anything. I'm just trying to be honest.
Person1: Honest? You're the one who's been lying to people's faces.
Person2: I'm not lying. I'm just telling the truth in a way that people can hear it.
Person1: Hear it? You're the one who's been shouting it from the rooftops.
Person2: Maybe so. But at least I'm not whispering sweet nothings into people's ears.

Person1: I feel so alone since grandma passed away. Sometimes I wake up thinking I need to make her breakfast, and then I remember.
Person2: I'm here for you, mom. You're not alone.
Person1: I know, but it's not the same. You're busy with your own life, and I don't want to burden you. I just wish I could understand you better.
Person2: What do you mean? I'm an open book, mom.
Person1: Are you? Sometimes I feel like you're hiding things from me. You've been distant lately, and it feels like you don't love me as much as you used to.
Person2: Mom, that's not true. I do love you, and I'm just stressed with work right now. It has nothing to do with us.
Person1: I wish I could believe that. You know, I wouldn't want to be left alone. I don't think I could bear it.
Person2: You'll never be alone, mom. I'll always be here for you. Would you like me to go get your sister from school? I'm sure she'd want to be with you right now.
Person1: Would you? I'd feel so much better if you did.

Person1: I need to talk to you about the heist. We can do it here or downtown.
Person2: What's to talk about? We got in, we got out, we got paid.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is, you're not taking this seriously enough. You're not taking me seriously enough.
Person2: Oh, I'm taking you seriously. I'm just not taking your ego seriously.
Person1: My ego? You think this is about my ego? This is about power, and you're not respecting it.
Person2: Power? You mean like the power to kill and loot? Because that's all we did on that job.
Person1: That's not the point! The point is, I'm the one calling the shots, and you need to remember that.
Person2: Or what? You'll kill me if I don't do what you say? Like you killed those guards?
Person1: That was necessary. And this conversation is necessary. You need to understand your place.
Person2: My place? You mean like how I'm just a tool for you to use and discard?

Person1: I'm telling you, I saw it with my own eyes. The numbers don't add up.
Person2: You're not thinking clearly. You're high on emotions.
Person1: This is crazy! I know what I saw.
Person2: What is it that you think you saw?
Person1: Wait, hell... Something's wrong! The data is inconsistent.
Person2: What's inconsistent about it? You're just not looking at it objectively.
Person1: Can't you see it? The patterns are all wrong!
Person2: You're not seeing the bigger picture. Trust me, I've crunched the numbers. We're okay.
Person1: You're not listening to me! I know what I saw, and it's not okay!
Person2: I am listening, but you're not making sense. You're letting your emotions cloud your judgment.

Person1: I'm not used to it, I'm not ready for it... You know... I have never been so upset in my life.
Person2: Maybe I feel like a teenager. I've been thinking, we could scrape together eight thousand and bum around the world for a year on that.
Person1: Oh, God. You're talking like a teenager. We're mortgaged to the eyeballs, Alex. There's the car payments. Are we just going to walk away from our financial obligations?
Person2: I think the only way to help ourselves, Rachel, is for us to be together. It's better to look things squarely in the eye.
Person1: But it's so sad. So terribly sad. You and I... No, I guess we aren't like that anymore. My God, is it possible to forget in such a short time, for things to change so quickly?
Person2: It takes even less. I'm sorry. I didn't want to sound cynical. But isn't it better to be honest with ourselves?
Person1: For me, they are exactly as they were when we met three days ago -- just three days ago... don't you realize? And you... No, I guess you aren't like that anymore. Move over there. Let's make believe nothing happened. And when we get to the next station, get off.
Person2: And what about you, Rachel?

Person1: You're not going to get away with this, Detective James.
Person2: I'm not trying to get away with anything, Miss Thompson. I'm just stating the facts.
Person1: All I'm asking is for you to reconsider the evidence... give me thirty days to prove my innocence.
Person2: You're not in a position to be making demands, Miss Thompson. And begging only makes you look more guilty.

Person1: I've been thinking about quitting the team.
Person2: You should have taken the coach's offer. Especially if you were unprepared.
Person1: I had a key player injured during the last game.
Person2: That happens. You know better. You're Mr. Star Player. You want to be independent? Be independent now. I've got no sympathy for you.
Person1: Don't be evasive. You know I'm not getting any younger.
Person2: Age isn't important. It's about the game, not about you.
Person1: Spoken like a true coach. But I'm not just any player, I'm the one who's been carrying this team for years.
Person2: And I'm the one who's been making you a star. You're not as young as you want to be, are you? You're not as invincible as you thought.
Person1: That's not fair. You're just trying to manipulate me into staying.
Person2: Maybe. But it's working, isn't it?

Person1: You have to come to the gathering tonight. For your own safety.
Person2: Please, don't beg me. I'm not going.
Person1: It's like a rite of passage party. Everyone's saying it's 'Break Free' time.
Person2: You're thinking of taking a stand against the system tonight?
Person1: Unless we make a move during the protest. It'll be a lot less scary if we do it together.
Person2: Didn't you have something a little more strategic in mind for our first move?
Person1: I kind of like the idea that we can all rise up together, on the same night. You have to go.
Person2: What about the others? Will they be there?
Person1: Shut up and trust me. They'll be there.

Person1: I want to talk to you about your promotion.
Person2: I think you're just a little scared now, about what you might find once the lights go out.
Person1: We have to discuss the details of the new project.
Person2: Your voice is saying no, but your body is saying yes.
Person1: What do you mean? I'm just trying to get things done.
Person2: I'm on the track of a big opportunity, which could change everything.
Person1: And what's that supposed to mean?
Person2: Maybe more than you want to admit. But doesn't that turn you on, that curiosity and fear, swirling together?
Person1: I don't think this is about curiosity or fear. It's about getting the job done.
Person2: I swear to you, this is going to be big. You just have to trust me.
Person1: Trust you? You've been working behind my back, haven't you?
Person2: What is this, an interrogation, or are you my partner?

Person1: I've got the perfect wine for you, darling. Come sit down and let's celebrate.
Person2: Celebrate what? You're trying to distract me from the fact that you've been lying to me again.
Person1: Oh, don't be ridiculous. I'm just trying to make amends. You're being paranoid.
Person2: Paranoid? You're the one who's been poisoning our relationship with your deceit. And now you're trying to poison me literally?
Person1: That's not fair. I'm just trying to make things right between us. You're blowing this out of proportion.
Person2: You know, it's ironic that you're accusing me of being paranoid when you're the one who's been manipulating me all along. Maybe we have more in common than you care to admit.

Person1: You know, I've been thinking, you're looking great, how have you been?
Person2: Honestly, I've been struggling since the accident. I might need to take some legal action.
Person1: Oh, lawyers are so complicated. You don't want to get tangled up in all that. Why don't you come work for me instead? I could use some extra help.
Person2: What kind of work?
Person1: Just helping me out around the house, running some errands. You can earn a little something on the side. Plus, it'll be good for you to get out of the house and take your mind off things.
Person2: I'm not sure...I don't want to be a burden.
Person1: Nonsense, you'd be doing me a favor. And who knows, it might even help you forget about your troubles. You can start tonight, I'll show you what needs to be done.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly, are you? You're willing to risk everything for a chance at redemption. But suppose you find nothing but a wasteland. How will you survive?
Person2: Don't be ridiculous! You think I'm naive, that I don't know what I'm getting myself into. But you're the one who's being blind. You're capable of anything, just like Alger Hiss. I know how ugly you can be.
Person1: That's not fair. You're trying to turn this around on me. But I'm not the one who's been hiding secrets. You want the truth to come out, you want them to see you at your worst. You have no remorse, no concept of remorse.
Person2: You're just trying to distract me. You're afraid of what I might find. But I won't be swayed. I'll do whatever it takes to uncover the truth, even if it means facing the jungle beasts that lurk within myself.

Person1: You're always chasing after something, aren't you? At least, you think you are. Truth is, you're just running away. From yourself, mostly.
Person2: What do you mean? I'm not running from anything.
Person1: Oh, really? Then why are you so hesitant to take on the role of the royal advisor? It's an honor, after all.
Person2: I don't know if I'm ready for that kind of responsibility.
Person1: Nonsense! You're more than capable. And if you're not, well... that's what makes it so thrilling, don't you think? The risk of failure?
Person2: I suppose so...
Person1: Good! Then it's settled. You'll make an excellent royal advisor. And who knows, you might just find what you're really looking for in the process.

Person1: You're not made for this kind of life, Sophia. Few people are. You think you can handle the pressure, but trust me, you can't.
Person2: That's not fair, Alex. You're trying to intimidate me.
Person1: Intimidate you? I'm being realistic. You're not even taking an active interest in your work. You're just going through the motions.
Person2: That's not true. I care about my job.
Person1: Then why do you always take lunch by the park? You're avoiding your colleagues, avoiding the real issues. You're not a team player, Sophia.
Person2: I like the fresh air. And I'm not avoiding anything.
Person1: Fresh air? You're running away from your responsibilities. And I know you're not happy with your current role. You're just waiting for someone to come along and rescue you.
Person2: That's not true. I'm perfectly capable of taking care of myself.
Person1: Then prove it. Take on more responsibilities, show me you're committed to your work. Otherwise, you're just wasting your time.

Person1: I'm afraid we're at an impasse, Rachel.
Person2: Is it, I'm sorry, but then, of course, you're the expert, you should know.
Person1: I wish you wouldn't talk like that, Rachel. It's nothing personal. This is just business.
Person2: Our partnership, Alex. I've always looked on you as my closest ally.
Person1: If there was any way out... But I'm afraid we've exhausted all options.
Person2: You're saying I'm incompetent, that I'm a fool. Anyone who finds me a fool, please say so now.
Person1: Rachel, please don't appeal to my sentimental side. This is a sacrifice we all ought to be glad to make.
Person2: Then we agree. It's the only way forward.

Person1: I think you're the only one who can help me crack this case. You're a brilliant mind, and I admire your work.
Person2: Oh, spare me the flattery, detective. I'm a recluse, and I like it that way. I don't do "teamwork" or "collaboration." I do solitary confinement, and that's it.
Person1: I understand that, but this is different. Women are dying, and I need your expertise to stop it. A sincere and heartfelt apology won't cut it this time. I need results.
Person2: You think a apology will fix everything? You're as naive as you are desperate. I'm not some magic solution to your problems, detective. I'm a broken person, and you're just trying to use me.
Person1: Maybe I am, but I'm willing to do whatever it takes to solve this case. And if that means stroking your ego or appealing to your sense of justice, then so be it. I'll do it.
Person2: You know, detective, you're not as stupid as I thought. You're actually quite clever. But I'm still not going to help you. At least, not yet.

Person1: I'm going to ask you one last time, and if I don't get an answer, I don't even want to think about the consequences. You're not as close to him as you think, are you? You're helping him, yeah--
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. Wait, have you helped him, Rachel? At this point, technically, I doubt you could be charged with aiding a fugitive. So you still have a choice. You can help him and risk going down again, get cuffed and shackled, hope to God you pull a reasonable judge, not some hard-on. Or, if you want to play it another way...

Person1: You're suffocating me!
Person2: Oh, I'm so sorry. I didn't mean to.
Person1: Let go! You're crushing me!
Person2: I care about you, that's why I'm doing this. You need to understand...
Person1: Understand what? That you're trying to control me?
Person2: No, no, no. I just want what's best for you. You're not thinking clearly...
Person1: Not thinking clearly? You're the one who's not thinking clearly! Stop trying to manipulate me!
Person2: I'm not trying to manipulate you, I'm trying to help you. You're just not listening...
Person1: I'm not listening? You're the one who's not listening! You never listen to me...
Person2: That's not true. I'm always listening to you. You just don't want to hear the truth...
Person1: The truth? You don't know the truth! You only know what you want to believe...
Person2: Maybe that's true, but I know what's best for you. And I'm going to make sure you do what's best for yourself, even if it kills me...

Person1: You're not thinking clearly, Rachel. Have you got that report?
Person2: On second thought, would you let me handle it? I'll get the investors.
Person1: But I've already spoken to them --
Person2: Believe me, Alex, I know what I'm doing. You'd get too emotional in there --
Person1: But I'm not one to be swayed by emotions, Rachel! I've worked with difficult clients before.
Person2: I know a lot of people who didn't think they'd compromise their values till they met our CEO. Please, Alex.
Person1: All right. But be careful, Rachel. Don't let him sweet-talk you into anything.
Person2: I'll be careful, Alex. You just focus on the numbers, okay?

Person1: You look terrible. You're exhausted. You practically live at the goddamn office. 
Person2: After that, I swore I'd never do anything just because "everyone else" was doing it. 
Person1: Why didn't you tell me about the project's deadline? 
Person2: I wanted to let you make up your own mind about how to handle it. 
Person1: No, you didn't! If you really thought I could make my own decisions, you would've let me take the lead instead of helping our boss hold me back.

Person1: I don't want to attend the family gathering, Mother. I hardly know them.
Person2: You always take things too personally. It's just a small party.
Person1: You're not supportive of my decision to distance myself from them. You just want what's best for them, not me.
Person2: Maybe you should listen more carefully next time. I'm afraid they'll be offended if you don't show up.
Person1: It's not about listening, it's about how you said it. You're trying to guilt trip me into attending.
Person2: I'm just trying to help you make amends with your relatives before it's too late.

Person1: You're playing with fire, Alex. This is a game of power, and you're just a pawn. Time to take control. You and me, we can make it happen. Just remember, I'm always watching.
Person2: You're not the only one who can play dirty.
Person1: Oh, I'm shaking in my boots. You think you can take me down? I've been in this game longer than you've been alive. I've made and broken empires. You're just a fleeting thought in my mind.
Person2: You underestimate me at your own peril.
Person1: We'll see about that. I've got a little surprise for you. You see, I've been doing some digging, and I found out some interesting things about your past. Things that could ruin your reputation, your career... your life. So, are you ready to play nice?

Person1: You look stunning in black. It really brings out your eyes.
Person2: Thanks, I guess. What's with the sudden interest in my fashion sense?
Person1: I'm just trying to make small talk. You know, before I take your job. I heard the boss is looking for someone with more... charm.
Person2: You think you can charm your way to the top? Please, you're not even in the same league as me.
Person1: Oh, I don't know. I've got a certain... je ne sais quoi. And I'm sure Isabella would agree with me. You saw the way she was staring at me, didn't you?
Person2: You're delusional. Isabella barely even notices you. And even if she did, you're not exactly the type of person she'd be interested in.
Person1: Ah, but you're just jealous because you're third-rate, and I'm the total package. Tall, dark, and handsome. You're just... well, you're just you.

Person1: You're acting like a child, Alex. Trust me, I know what's best for you.
Person2: That's your problem, Rachel. You think you can control everyone around you.
Person1: What's the matter with you? So the plan isn't perfect. So what?
Person2: Can't you see it's a trap? He wants us to follow him.
Person1: Nobody's going to get hurt, Alex. We've got the upper hand here. So why should you care?
Person2: Because I can see the danger.
Person1: Well, then trust me, because come tonight, we're going to walk out of here with what we want. Understand, Alex?
