Person1: You know, I've been thinking, and I really think you should take a break from your friends. You're spending too much time with them, and it's affecting our relationship.
Person2: That's not fair. You're always trying to control who I see and what I do. It's like you're trying to fit me into some perfect little box.
Person1: I'm just trying to help you, sweetie. You're not thinking clearly, and I need to take over for you. You know I always put you first, unlike others.
Person2: That's exactly what I'm talking about. You always make it sound like you're doing me a favor, but really, you're just trying to manipulate me into doing what you want.

Person1: I've got a meeting with the investors tomorrow. I'll never make it the way I am now.
Person2: You're just holding onto the past. If you can't accept my help, maybe you're the one with the issue.
Person1: It feels like your help isn't genuine. You're just trying to make yourself look good in front of them.
Person2: And all I hear is you trying to sabotage me. You're the one who's going to report me for not meeting the deadline.
Person1: All I want is to feel respected and valued in this partnership.
Person2: Then stop questioning my motives and start trusting me.

Person1: You always assume I'm available, Sophia. Maybe if you checked in more, we wouldn't have this confusion.
Person2: Progress is a feast to be consumed, darling. Don't let others dictate your pace. You must run before you can waltz!
Person1: Give me that report before you fill it with drivel! I had other plans for this project.
Person2: Oh, that? Thought I mentioned it in passing. You shouldn't rely on third parties to know my plans, Rachel.

Person1: You're getting too comfortable, aren't you? I gave you this life.
Person2: I know, and I'm grateful.
Person1: If you left, what would become of me? I'd be nothing without you.
Person2: You're being dramatic. I'm not going anywhere.
Person1: Oh, really? Then why have you been taking extended lunches and "working from home" three times a week?
Person2: That's not what this is about. You're trying to guilt trip me into staying.
Person1: Maybe a little. But someone has to keep you in check. You're getting too reckless, too confident. It's not becoming of someone in your position.
Person2: My position? You mean the one you created for me? The one you control?
Person1: That's not fair. I've given you every opportunity.
Person2: Opportunities? You call this an opportunity? You're suffocating me.

Person1: I didn't say nuthin'. You must have a guilty conscience. What are you guilty of?
Person2: The power was within you. I've been searching for someone like you.
Person1: What do you mean? What kind of power?
Person2: The power to unlock the secrets of the universe. And I think you're the key.
Person1: That sounds crazy. How can I help you with that?
Person2: Join me on a journey to uncover the truth. I have a way to get us the resources we need.
Person1: What kind of resources?
Person2: A high-tech laboratory, hidden deep beneath the city. But you have to trust me.
Person1: I don't know...this all sounds too good to be true.
Person2: Have faith, my friend. You won't regret it.

Person1: You can't always have it your own way, regardless of anything else that may have happened. Come on, Alex.
Person2: But I know you're not gonna quit on me. You decided what you were going to do, Alex - some time ago.
Person1: Go on! Get out! I can fight this thing all alone! Cause you got a little voice in your head saying, do the right thing. Give me another chance.

Person1: You're saying I don't understand?
Person2: I don't think you do.
Person1: I'm the only one who does understand. I'm the one you confided in, I'm the one you made promises to.
Person2: What do you want from me?
Person1: I want to know why you're doing this to me. Why you're making me feel so guilty.
Person2: I'm not trying to make you feel guilty. I'm just trying to figure out what went wrong.
Person1: You're not trying to make me feel guilty? Believe me, you're doing a great job. You're making me feel like I'm the one who messed everything up.
Person2: That's not what I meant. I just need some time to think.
Person1: Time to think? You've had months. I've been waiting for you to come back to me, to explain what happened.
Person2: I know. And I'm sorry. But I need to do this on my own.
Person1: On your own? You're not alone, I'm here with you. I'm the one who's been supporting you all this time.
Person2: Supporting me? You're the one who's been suffocating me. I need some space.
Person1: Space? You're the one who left me, who abandoned me. And now you're telling me you need space?
Person2: I didn't mean to hurt you. I just needed to get away.
Person1: Get away? From me? From us? What did I do that was so wrong?
Person2: You didn't do anything wrong. It's just...I don't know, maybe I panicked. Maybe I shouldn't have gone out on that line.
Person1: Maybe you shouldn't have gone out on that line? You're the one who's always pushing me to take risks, to be more adventurous. And now you're telling me you panicked?
Person2: I know. I'm sorry. I'll try to do better next time.
Person1: Next time? There won't be a next time. You've had your chance, and you blew it.

Person1: I didn't mean to imply that you're not doing your job, but the agency oversight committee is going to scrutinize every detail. Your department's budget is a significant line item in my ledger.
Person2: You're worried about Treadstone, aren't you? Don't be. It's just a theoretical training organization. I'll make sure to remind them of that.
Person1: And what if they're not convinced? What if they start digging deeper?
Person2: Then I'd have to take care of it. You know, for your own good. You wouldn't want them to find anything...incriminating, would you?

Person1: You said you loved me, Alex. 
Person2: I... you told me you were committed to me, back in the hotel room, telling me you weren't seeing anyone else -- 
Person1: No -- 
Person2: You were convincing me you weren't cheating! And we just didn't believe you! 
Person1: But I never said I was committed. 
Person2: You said it a million times! 
Person1: I never promised you anything. 
Person2: Yeah, I slept with a few guys... 
Person1: A few? 
Person2: ...And one of those guys was your best friend! The last one, I might add, which-if you're too stupid to comprehend-means that I've been faithful to you since we met! All the other guys I slept with before I met you, so, if you want to have a complex about it, go ahead! But don't look at me like I'm the town whore, because you were plenty busy yourself, before you met me!

Person1: You think you're in control, but you're not. You're just a pawn in a much bigger game.
Person2: I'm not afraid of you. I know what I have, and I'm not going to let you take it from me.
Person1: Oh, I'm not going to take it from you. At least, not yet. But I can make your life very difficult if you don't cooperate.
Person2: What do you want from me?
Person1: I want you to let us in. If you do, we might let you keep what's yours. Otherwise... let's just say you won't be enjoying that view for much longer.
Person2: You're bluffing. You wouldn't dare.
Person1: Try me. I've got nothing to lose, and you've got everything to lose. The question is, how much are you willing to risk?

Person1: Ahh, strike, not, not bad at all. No, this talk isn't about sex, it's, well there've been a lot of changes.
Person2: I've got the evidence. If you ever want to see your reputation intact, do exactly what I say. Bring the confidential report to my office at five o'clock.
Person1: The report? I don't have access to that kind of information. You're bluffing.
Person2: Don't play dumb, Rachel! I know about the whistleblower's email. You better get the report somehow. Five o'clock and come alone. If you don't, we'll leak the scandal to the press.

Person1: You've got to trust me. It sounds silly but I know we were meant to meet.
Person2: Shut up, you're not gonna win. And let's be honest, a family only needs one "winner" and you know I've got much better instincts than you.
Person1: Please, don't be like that. I love you. There are plenty of other safe places. Why don't we go back to my flat?
Person2: Your parents'd kill you if they knew what you're planning. Oh c'mon, I love 'em, but you know they only had you 'cause you needed a guardian.
Person1: I was just trying to help. I decided to trust you. Maybe I was wrong. Whose side are you on really? Who are your friends?
Person2: Then do it for them. Mrs. Leeman used to call you a "skinny little manipulator" when you'd bag her groceries. You'd pop your Nancy-belt if your old jacket somehow, I don't know, got her back.
Person1: It's the only thing you saved from the crash... It must be something very special.
Person2: I saved you from the crash and you're not very special.

Person1: I'll go talk to him, I'm sure we can come to an understanding.
Person2: Are you sure that's a good idea? He's been known to twist words to his advantage.
Person1: Let me reassure you, I've dealt with people like him before. I can assure you, I will never manipulate more people in my entire life than politics has manipulated in the last 100 years.
Person2: That's not the point. The point is, he's being weird and I don't know why he's being so accommodating all of a sudden.
Person1: It's not bad, it's ok. I'll go talk to him and clear the air.
Person2: Sorry, I just don't want you to get caught in his web of deceit.

Person1: I'm telling you, Rachel, you owe me an explanation. You've been acting strange for weeks.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about, Alex. You're being paranoid.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I've seen the way you've been looking at me, like you're trying to figure something out.
Person2: Maybe I'm just trying to understand why you're so loyal to your boss. He's not exactly the most popular guy in the company.
Person1: That's not the point. The point is, I know you're hiding something from me. And I want to know what it is.
Person2: Alex, you're getting worked up over nothing. Maybe you're just feeling a little guilty about something yourself.
Person1: What are you insinuating? That I'm the one who's been playing games?
Person2: I'm not insinuating anything. I'm just saying that sometimes our memories can play tricks on us. Maybe you're the one who's been mistaken all along.

Person1: You're chasing after your damn fortune and glory, but what's the truth you're really searching for?
Person2: I'm searching for the freedom to make my own choices, to break free from the prison that's been built around me.
Person1: Ah, but that prison is all in your mind. You were born into bondage, kept inside a world that's been pulled over your eyes to blind you from the reality.
Person2: And what reality is that? That I'm just a slave to the system, living a life that's not truly mine?
Person1: Exactly. But I can show you the way out, if you're willing to take the leap of faith.
Person2: I'm not sure I'm ready to take that step. What if I fall?
Person1: You'll fall anyway, if you stay in the darkness. At least this way, you'll have a chance to see the light.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly. Maybe you're just stressed and hallucinated the whole thing.
Person2: I'm telling you, I saw it with my own eyes! You're not listening to me.
Person1: If I said I saw a ghost, would you believe me?
Person2: That's not the point. The point is I know what I saw.
Person1: Maybe you're just trying to get attention. You've been feeling neglected lately, haven't you?
Person2: How dare you! You're just trying to distract me from the truth.
Person1: The truth is, you're not making any sense. You're just scaring yourself with your own imagination.
Person2: You're not taking me seriously. You never do.
Person1: I'm taking you seriously, but you need to take a step back and look at the evidence. There's no proof of anything.
Person2: You're just trying to control me, like you always do.

Person1: Come in.
Person2: You want me to what? Review the entire marketing strategy?
Person1: I want you to rethink every aspect of our campaign. It'll take hours, but it's necessary.
Person2: You can't make me do this. I have better things to do.
Person1: Oh, I think you'll find it's in your best interest. Besides, I have a friend who owes me a favor at the advertising agency. I'm sure they'd love to take a look at your portfolio. Give you some "feedback".
Person2: What are you talking about?
Person1: Just a little motivation. Now, shall we get started?

Person1: You think it's so easy?
Person2: Should I be excited, my little darling?
Person1: You're not even trying to convince me. You're just going through the motions.
Person2: I do not deceive tonight.
Person1: Do it! Put on a show, at least. You're not even making an effort to manipulate me.
Person2: That's right, I'm not like you. I don't have to resort to tricks and coercion.

Person1: I don't know, maybe we're not happy with each other.
Person2: You're the only one I care for.
Person1: Don't say "we" when you mean "you." What's going on, really?
Person2: Look, there's a situation at the office... and I think maybe I need some space.
Person1: Oh God, I'm no more than a bug on a windshield to you. You're just going to be the same person with the same problems.
Person2: You're the only human being I care for. I'm sorry.
Person1: Then do me a favor. If you ever loved me, if there's anything human left in you, then be honest with me. Please.
Person2: I explained this. I can't. That's not the way it happens.

Person1: I've noticed you've been spending more time with your colleagues than with me. What's going on?
Person2: It's not like that, Rachel. I just need some space to focus on this project.
Person1: I've been helping you with your project, didn't I? Now tell me why you're really avoiding me or I'll have to reconsider our partnership.
Person2: It's not a threat, Rachel. I appreciate your help, but I need some autonomy. You're not my boss.
Person1: I'm not trying to control you, but I've invested a lot in you. I just wish you'd recognize the effort I make for us, that's all.

Person1: You're not thinking straight. We're under a lot of pressure, we're tired.
Person2: That's rich coming from you. You always assume I'm available.
Person1: What do you mean? I'm just trying to help.
Person2: Help? You mean like how you're trying to make me doubt myself?
Person1: I didn't say that. You're putting words in my mouth.
Person2: Am I? Or are you just trying to deflect responsibility?

Person1: You can't leave me like this. Some freak'll come by and take advantage of me!
Person2: Oh, Ben, you're being dramatic. You're not a child anymore. You need to take responsibility for your actions.
Person1: But Mom, it's not my fault I got into this mess. You always say I'm your precious son.
Person2: And you are, sweetie. But that doesn't mean you're exempt from consequences. You need to learn to think before you act.
Person1: Rachel would never leave me like this. She's always looking out for me.
Person2: Rachel? Ha! She's only looking out for herself, Ben. Don't be fooled by her charm. She's not as innocent as she seems.
Person1: I don't believe you, Mom. You're just trying to manipulate me again.
Person2: Oh, Ben, I'm only trying to protect you. You're so naive. You don't know how the world works.

Person1: You're my girl, aren't you?
Person2: Dr. Lee, I know what I saw. It was a creature, not a man.
Person1: Then you're crazy. You'd be surprised what horrors a man is capable of.
Person2: I'm telling you, it was an animal. A big wolf or something. A rabid dog.
Person1: You're in a hurry, aren't you? You want me to believe you so badly.
Person2: I want you to listen to me. I want you to understand what happened.
Person1: I'm listening. But you have to understand, the police are satisfied. We'd have seen it on the telly if a monster were roaming around.
Person2: You're not listening. You're just trying to make me doubt myself.
Person1: David, please. I'm trying to help you. You're my patient, and I care about you.
Person2: You care about me? You really think I'm crazy, don't you?

Person1: What do I have to do to get a straight answer around here?
Person2: It was necessary.
Person1: Necessary for what? You're being evasive again.
Person2: I don't think you understand the full implications of what I did.
Person1: Oh, c'mon. For Christsake, do I have to drag it out of you? What happened that night?
Person2: I took the kids to my sister's, and then I went to the movies.
Person1: What'd you see?
Person2: I'm not going to play this game with you. You're just trying to catch me in a lie.
Person1: I'm trying to have a conversation with you. But you're making it impossible.
Person2: Maybe that's the point. Maybe I don't want to have this conversation.

Person1: You're afraid of me. You're afraid that I won't love you back.
Person2: When I think about my past, I feel like it's me versus the world. Some kid at school teases me and the same day a plague breaks out in Bangladesh.
Person1: What's that supposed to mean? You're changing the subject.
Person2: I'm just saying, it's hard to prioritize what's important. You want me to open up to you, but you're not willing to listen.
Person1: That's not true. I'm trying to understand you.
Person2: Understand me? You want to fix me, don't you? You think you can just swoop in and save me from myself.
Person1: Maybe I do. Maybe I want to help you.
Person2: Help me? You don't even know what I need. You're just trying to alleviate your own guilt.
Person1: My guilt? What are you talking about?
Person2: You're trying to buy my affection with your pity. Well, I'm not for sale.
Person1: That's not fair. I'm trying to be honest with you.
Person2: Honest? You're not even honest with yourself. You're just trying to manipulate me into feeling something I don't.

Person1: You're a skilled engineer. You fix things every day.
Person2: I don't think I can do this. It's different.
Person1: And now you tell me? We've come too far to back out now.
Person2: It's not about the technicality, it's about the moral implications.
Person1: You're not grieving, you're just afraid of being told what to do.
Person2: That's not fair. I have a conscience.
Person1: Conscience? You're just trying to justify your own cowardice.
Person2: I'm not a coward. I just don't want to be responsible for... this.
Person1: Responsible? You're already responsible. You're just trying to wriggle out of it.

Person1: And I love you too.
Person2: Sometimes I don't know if I want to love you, but my instincts tell me to stay.
Person1: We could stay, and I could be on my way to a new life, and you could have a great time.
Person2: ...but that's not what we're gonna do, is it? You're not going to let me go that easily.
Person1: No, I said to follow my instincts. And my instincts say I need you to see this through with me, to prove to myself that I can still make you love me.
Person2: And love's a funny thing. It's what's keeping me here, despite my better judgment.

Person1: Please, could I please come in and talk to you for a minute? Maybe you could take a better look at the situation... might stir up something.
Person2: Oh, don't use that tone with me, for a smoke screen.
Person1: Smoke screen for what? You're the one who's been hiding the truth.
Person2: You're just trying to deflect from your own fear of being wrong.
Person1: Hey, I'm trying to find a solution here. You're the one who's being obstinate.

Person1: You're being ridiculous, Alex.
Person2: He's a master of deception, a chameleon who's fooled everyone, including you. He's got a talent for making people believe what he wants them to.
Person1: So what if he's a bit of a smooth talker? He's not hurting anyone.
Person2: Not hurting anyone? You're not listening to yourself, Rachel. He's playing you like a fiddle, and you're too blinded by his charm to see it.
Person1: I'm not blind, Alex. I just think you're being overly critical. We've got a good thing going here, and I don't want you to ruin it with your paranoia.
Person2: Paranoia? You're the one who's being naive. I can see right through him, and I won't let him get away with it.

Person1: You're really pushing my patience. Remember, I'm the one who can help you.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. I didn't promise anything.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. What did you take from him?
Person2: I didn't take anything. You're just trying to intimidate me.
Person1: Intimidate you? I'm trying to save you from yourself. Now, tell me the truth.

Person1: You're not thinking clearly, I can get us out of this mess...
Person2: Absolutely not. You're just trying to save your own skin.
Person1: The authorities are going to tear you apart, even if you win. You'll never work in this industry again. They need a scapegoat.
Person2: I'm not afraid of them. I've done nothing wrong.
Person1: Oh, honey, you're so naive. This is the time when the big boys have to take control, okay?

Person1: You're not listening to me, Alex. Whatever I do, I do because I care about you.
Person2: Care? You don't care about anyone! Me or anyone else! You want to be needed - that's all you want! I'm offering you a chance to work with me, to make a difference. Just name it and it's yours! Only trust me!
Person1: Trust you? You're the one who's been playing me all along. I used to think you were different, but now I see you're just like all the others.
Person2: What are you talking about? I've given you every opportunity...
Person1: Opportunities? You call manipulating me into doing your bidding opportunities? I'm not some pawn in your game, Alex.
Person2: Fine, don't take my help. But you'll come crawling back when you realize you need me. You always do.
Person1: I don't think so. I've had enough of your games.

Person1: I'm not against collecting stuff, but I think it's essential to remember that we don't own anything. It's a transitory world.
Person2: That's a pretty philosophical outlook. But don't you think sharing old photos of me on social media is a bit invasive?
Person1: Ah, come on! It's just a fun throwback! I didn't think you'd take it so seriously. Besides, everyone has their awkward phases.
Person2: I guess you're right. But sometimes I feel like you're trying to break me of my attachments, like you're saying "Here today, gone tomorrow, so don't get attached to things."
Person1: Well, isn't that true? We come on this earth with nothing, and we go out with nothing. I'm just trying to keep things in perspective. And who knows, maybe I'm just trying to gently remind you that we shouldn't get too comfortable.
Person2: I suppose that's one way to look at it. But sometimes I wish you'd just ask me before posting old memories, instead of trying to make a point.

Person1: You're not listening to me, are you? You're just pretending to care.
Person2: What are you talking about? I'm trying to help you.
Person1: Don't do that. You're not fooling anyone, least of all me. I know what you're capable of. You let him walk all over you, and now you're doing the same to me.
Person2: Who's "him"? What are you accusing me of?
Person1: Don't play dumb. I know you're hot, I can see it. You're suffocating in this place, just like I am. But you won't admit it, will you? You'd rather keep up this charade.
Person2: I'm fine, really. You're just being paranoid.
Person1: Paranoid? You're the one who's always putting on a disguise, hiding behind your fake smiles and empty words. I'm not buying it anymore.
Person2: That's not fair. I'm trying to help you.
Person1: Help me? You're the one who needs help. You're trapped in this toxic cycle, and you can't even see it. But I do. And I'm not going to let you drag me down with you.

Person1: You're so ungrateful, Rachel. I've sacrificed so much to make sure you were comfortable and happy.
Person2: Just keep your condescending tone to yourself, Michael. I know what you've done, but love isn't about keeping score.
Person1: It's not about that. I just wish you'd acknowledge and appreciate it sometimes. You're always so quick to point out what I've done wrong.
Person2: That's because you always make me feel guilty for not meeting your expectations. A relationship is a two-way street, Michael. We both have our parts to play.

Person1: You're still holding onto that grudge, aren't you? Isn't it true that your whole story is nothing more than a desperate attempt to prove yourself to me?
Person2: Not that much appreciation. I thought we were gonna tone down that flabby ego.
Person1: Hey, I'm so sorry I'm not the one who's been playing the victim card all along.
Person2: You'll be sorry when the truth comes out.

Person1: I'm the one who took the initiative, and that makes it mine.
Person2: Who are you trying to convince, yourself or me?
Person1: You'd like me if you got to know me.
Person2: Every person in history who tried to get ahead did the "I'm a team player" thing first.
Person1: Why are you being so defensive?
Person2: No, I'm just not buying what you're selling.

Person1: What are you hiding, chicken brain? You're not as innocent as you seem.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about. I'm just trying to live my life.
Person1: Save it, kid. I've seen your kind before. You're just a pawn in a bigger game. I need you to access her files, get me the information I need.
Person2: I'm not a hacker, and even if I was, I wouldn't do it. You can't bully me into doing your dirty work.
Person1: Oh, I think I can. You see, I have some information about your past, about your family. I'm sure you wouldn't want that getting out.

Person1: You're not the one who knows how it feels.
Person2: Don't be cruel, Emma.
Person1: Should have stayed out of this. Can't pretend that much.
Person2: I miss you, Emma. You're all I have left.
Person1: Oh, c'mon... First the picture of Dad, then the funeral, now this? It's scary.
Person2: Let me tell you "scary," Emma. Look at me. Do you wanna end up like me, alone and desperate?
Person1: That's it, I'm going...
Person2: Honest to God, if I got to do it over? I'd start taking care of myself instead of you. But I won't leave you, Emma. Not like you left me.

Person1: You're troubled, aren't you? I can see it in your eyes.
Person2: And what game do you want to play? You think you can fix me, and I'll fall into your arms?
Person1: I'm not playing games, Rachel. I'm trying to help you.
Person2: Help me? You're the one who's been flirting with me, then running cold. You're the one who's been leading me on.
Person1: That's not true. I've been trying to get through to you, but you keep pushing me away.
Person2: Maybe that's because you keep reminding me of my past. If you go away, then I'll forget.
Person1: Forget what? Forget how you're feeling right now?
Person2: You never answer me. You just keep probing, trying to get inside my head.
Person1: I'm trying to understand you, Rachel. But you're not making it easy.
Person2: Understand me? You think you're lucky because you didn't have a mother who said things to you and did things to you that maybe weren't always nice?

Person1: You know better than to talk like that when I'm vulnerable. Don't make me question your loyalty.
Person2: Roderick, you're being unfair. I've always been faithful to you, despite your reckless ways. Was I ever so wretched that a kind word from you did not make me happy?
Person1: Save it, my dear. I'm not in the mood for your theatrics. You've had your chance to prove yourself, and you've failed. Now, get out of my sight before I lose my temper.
Person2: Oh, Roderick, I've loved you too much and too fondly. I've always loved you, despite your bad qualities. I tremble at your violence, but I cannot help loving you. What sacrifice do you want from me? I am ready to make any, so you will but love me, or at least gently use me.

Person1: I'm telling you, I saw it with my own eyes.
Person2: You're not thinking clearly, Alex. You've been under a lot of stress lately. Maybe you should take a break and get some rest.
Person1: I don't need rest. I need the truth.
Person2: The truth is, you're not well. You've been acting paranoid and delusional. I'm trying to help you, but you're not listening.
Person1: You're just trying to confuse me. You're trying to make me doubt myself.
Person2: I'm trying to make you see reason. You're not thinking logically, Alex. You're letting your emotions cloud your judgment.
Person1: My emotions? You're the one who's been playing on my emotions from the start. You're trying to manipulate me, just like you always do.

Person1: You're not listening to me, are you? You're just waiting for me to slip up so you can pounce.
Person2: I'm trying to understand what you're saying, but it doesn't make any sense. You're not making any sense.
Person1: That's because you're not looking at the bigger picture. You're too caught up in your own little world to see what's really going on.
Person2: And what's really going on? You're the one who's been acting strange, not me.
Person1: Strange? You think this is strange? You have no idea what strange is. I've seen strange, and this is nothing.
Person2: What are you talking about? What have you seen?
Person1: Get your hands away from me! Don't touch me! You don't know what you're dealing with.

Person1: You know I hate it when you call me that.
Person2: Oh, spare me the drama. You're soft, and you know it.
Person1: I'm doing this for us. We need to work together if we want to achieve our goals.
Person2: Why are you doing this, Rachel? You know I've gotten all I can from this partnership.
Person1: If I leave, you'll be right back where I found you - struggling to make ends meet.
Person2: I swear on my life, I won't go back to that.
Person1: You will. You know you will. And that's why I'm taking control of this project.

Person1: I know you're trying to make a point, but really, Alex, what can you be thinking? You're going to throw away your entire career for some shared experience with a startup that you misguidedly think is the next big thing?
Person2: I believe in it. And I think it's more important than your father's legacy.
Person1: You're not even considering the long-term consequences. It's me versus the world, and I'm trying to protect you from yourself.
Person2: That's not really the point. The point is, I'm not going to let you dictate my life choices.
Person1: Fine, keep the job offer. You'll come to your senses when you realize you've made a mistake.

Person1: You have to come with me. It's a tradition.
Person2: I don't think so. You have no power here. Be gone, before somebody stops you.
Person1: Oh, rubbish! You're just trying to stay out of my way. But I'll bide my time, and when I do, you'll regret not joining me.
Person2: I'm not afraid of you. And I won't be manipulated into doing something I don't want to do.

Person1: I appreciate your time, Senator. I won't take long.
Person2: My assistant said you were persistent. I'm curious to know what you want.
Person1: I have a problem, and I believe you're the only one who can help me.
Person2: (laughs) That's quite a sales pitch. What makes you think I'm the solution to your problem?
Person1: Let's just say I've done my research. And I'm willing to do whatever it takes to get your help.
Person2: (smirks) I'm intrigued. But I'm not making any promises. What's in it for me?
Person1: Oh, I think you'll find it's in your best interest to help me. Otherwise... (pauses) Well, let's just say I have a few aces up my sleeve.

Person1: I've been thinking about taking a break from the city. Want to come with me?
Person2: Where did you have in mind?
Person1: I was thinking of heading out to the coast. I've got some business to take care of, but I can make it worth your while.
Person2: I don't know...I've got a lot on my plate right now.
Person1: Come on, it'll be good for you. You can use a change of scenery. And I'll take care of all the arrangements. You just need to show up.
Person2: I'm not sure...
Person1: I'll pick you up at 5 pm on Friday. We'll make it a weekend getaway. You can trust me to take care of everything.
Person2: I don't know if I can trust you that much.
Person1: I swear on my honor that I'll make it a trip you'll never forget.

Person1: You're good at it. Lying, cheating, manipulating... You're good at it.
Person2: And you're good at playing dumb. But I know you're not as innocent as you seem.
Person1: Innocent? You think I'm innocent? You're the one who's been playing me from the start.
Person2: Playing you? Ha! You're the one who's been dancing on the edge, waiting for someone to push you over.
Person1: And you're that someone, aren't you? You're the one who's been pulling the strings.
Person2: Maybe. But you're the one who's been taking the steps. You killed that guy, didn't you? It must have been an accident.
Person1: Accident? You know it wasn't an accident. You know I did it on purpose.
Person2: Oh, I know. And I know you'll do it again. You have a taste for it now.
Person1: Shut up! You don't know anything about me.
Person2: Don't I? I know you're just like me. We're two peas in a pod, you and I. We're both good at it. Lying, cheating, manipulating...

Person1: You're playing with fire, kid. You think you can outsmart Victor LaPierre's operation?
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: Don't play dumb. I know you've been making moves on the side. You're going to get yourself killed.
Person2: You're just trying to scare me.
Person1: Scare you? I'm trying to save your life. You're in over your head, and LaPierre won't hesitate to take you down.
Person2: I can take care of myself.
Person1: Oh, really? Then why are you still in town? You should be long gone by now.
Person2: I've got business to take care of.
Person1: Business? You mean like the kind that gets you killed? Listen, kid, I can help you. I can get you out of this mess. But you have to trust me.
Person2: Why should I trust you?
Person1: Because I'm the only one who can save you. And I swear on your life, if you don't listen to me, you're going to end up dead.

Person1: You wanna talk to me straight up?
Person2: I've never done this before. I'm not sure what to expect.
Person1: Expect? You're the one who contacted me, sweetheart. You're the one who needs something.
Person2: I need your help. My sister is in trouble. She owes some people money.
Person1: Ah, family. That's a good one. You know, I've got contacts too. I can make some calls, but it's gonna cost you.
Person2: I don't have much money. That's why I came to you.
Person1: You're not very good at this, are you? You're not even a good liar. What's the real story?
Person2: I...I don't know what you're talking about.
Person1: Don't play dumb with me. I can see right through you. You're trying to manipulate me, but it won't work. Now, are you going to tell me the truth, or do we have a problem here?

Person1: You're not even a blip on her radar! You don't see that?!
Person2: Rachel?
Person1: I'm trying to educate you, it's nothing personal. You're just not in her league.
Person2: I think for you, we should aim for "professional."
Person1: And how dare you think you can handle that part? Have you any idea how humiliating that is for me? I'm a consultant!
Person2: It's a project. About your strengths and weaknesses.
Person1: About me!
Person2: Who the heck do you think you are? The project is not just about you. It's about every team member I've ever worked with in my entire career.
Person1: What are you saying?
Person2: Hello? Last performance review was?
Person1: I don't perform like I used to, Alex.
Person2: Alex, I have never considered you for this project because you are too inexperienced to lead it. And you are out of touch with reality if you think differently.

Person1: You're a clever one, aren't you, Detective?
Person2: Just keep your lying, heathenous trap shut. I know what you're trying to do.
Person1: Emotional? I expected more from a seasoned investigator like yourself.
Person2: If you're trying to get inside my head, it won't work. I've seen your tricks before.
Person1: Oh, I'm not trying to manipulate you, Detective. I'm just trying to have a conversation. But if you want to play it that way...
Person2: Save it for the judge. I'm not buying what you're selling.

Person1: You're so low! Look at that beautiful opportunity. You haven't taken it.
Person2: I dunno. You know, I used to really love that job. Do you know that?
Person1: You know it for what it is now-- a dead-end. Give me the report, Alex.
Person2: No!
Person1: Fine. You want to be angry? Be angry... but I'm the one who took the initiative and that makes it mine. You were always a rotten team player! You were against everything innovative I ever wanted to do.

Person1: You're a sinner who wants to walk with the saints. Ain't that right, boy?
Person2: What are you listening to, chicken ass?
Person1: I know you're just enough of a shit to have a go at bedding a man's wife. You've probably bagged a few at that.
Person2: Ah, leave him alone. He's doing no harm.
Person1: You can't wash that off. You'd be a marked man for life. Just like Cain.
Person2: You hear? I don't want you looking at me.
Person1: I hate the kind of person you are. I hate having to tolerate the little games you play.
Person2: You're out in the desert, the middle of nowhere with no one around for miles, and you say the time wasn't right? What's the matter?
Person1: You got the killing in you, boy. Came close this time and it scares you.
Person2: SHUT UP!

Person1: You're going to do exactly as I say, or you'll regret it. I've got my eyes on you, and I won't hesitate to take control.
Person2: What do you want me to do?
Person1: You're going to give me the information I need, and you're going to do it with a smile. You understand? I'm not here to make friends, I'm here to get what I want.
Person2: And what makes you think I'll cooperate?
Person1: Let's just say I have a certain... influence over you. You're under my spell, and you'll do as I say. Now, are you going to give me what I want, or do we need to take this further?
